column2: Mr. Zhang was a former Chinese diplomat who once served as Mao’s English tutor and also interpreted for President Nixon during his trip to China in 1972.
If every rat, cockroach and bedbug disappeared from New York City, would that be a good thing, ecologically speaking?
China on Monday allowed a United States warship to make a port call in Hong Kong, two months after it turned away an American aircraft carrier battle group.
Severe snowstorms over broad swaths of eastern and central China have wreaked havoc on traffic throughout the country.
Kisumu, Kenya’s third largest city, erupted again on Monday as the police and military struggled to stop a wave of revenge killings.
Officials said that six workers had died and four others had suffered injuries at Olympic venues since construction for the 2008 games began five years ago.
Archbishop Christodoulos, who helped heal centuries-old grievances with the Roman Catholic Church but also but stirred controversy, was 69.
With the selection of Samak Sundaravej as prime minister, Thailand has completed a transition back to democracy, but the bumpy ride may not be over.
The claim has the ring of a myth. But environmental scientists say it is real.
Studies have shown that sexual phobias are rarely the explanation for a condition known as vulvodynia.
The writer Susan Sontag’s death, as set out in a short and immensely disturbing account by her son, David Rieff, must rank as one of the worst ever described.
Wearing a Red Sox cap or a Patriots jersey no longer identifies the city’s citizens as connoisseurs of pain.
The 75th anniversary of the day Hitler took power has prompted a new round of soul-searching in Germany.
Eli Manning grew up in the very long shadow cast by his celebrated father and high-achieving brothers. But it is his mother he most takes after.
A study in Louisiana has found that judges tend to rule in favor of their campaign contributors, raising questions about whether judges should disqualify themselves from more cases.
For a cool $3,309, you can book a round-trip coach ticket from Newark to Phoenix for the big game.

Ramona Palanco, who has been deaf since birth, has been diagnosed with Usher syndrome, a gradual worsening of vision that affects a small percentage of the hearing impaired and leads to complete blindness.
If Bill Belichick can be judged by the company he keeps, then his relationships with Jim Brown and Bill Russell provide an intriguing insight into a man few outsiders know.
The Red Sox Foundation, not the Jackie Robinson Foundation, is to receive all net proceeds from a $50-a-ticket panel discussion Friday on the legacy of Jackie Robinson.
Viewers on Monday were treated to a rare look at three dynasties working out their psychodramas at once.
President Bush’s call for a $400 million program to use tax dollars to help parents send their children to private or religious schools was quickly denounced by some top Democrats.
President Bush used his final State of the Union address to call for passage of his tax rebate package and patience in Iraq.
Democrats and Republicans acknowledged the sense that an era was ending as President Bush gave his last State of the Union speech.
The kinder Tom Coughlin emerged as a favorite topic Monday among Giant players at the first of many Super Bowl news conferences in Arizona.
Patriots quarterback Tom Brady practiced Monday for the first time since sustaining a mild ankle sprain in the American Football Conference championship game on Jan. 20.
Sunday’s Super Bowl XLII will be the first in 20 N.F.L. seasons for Jeff Feagles and an unexpected return to Arizona, where he was supposed to be enjoying his retirement.

Excerpts from John McCain’s speech at a rally at an airplane hangar on Monday in Orlando, Fla.

It is hard to think of a case in which a murderer should become a medical doctor. Murder and medical practice are simply incompatible.

Edward M. Kennedy placed the aura of the most prominent Democratic family around Senator Barack Obama’s candidacy.
Something fundamental has shifted in the Democratic Party, now that a throng of Kennedys has endorsed Barack Obama.

GOLDMAN--Daniel . The Board of Governors and members of The Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Daniel Goldman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Sally and family. William Murphy, President

KESSELMAN--Madeline , Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Madeline Kesselman, beloved sister of our devoted member and benefactor Hermine Gewirtz. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

HOLZE--Lenore Richardson , January 24th in Hudson, NY. Beloved daughter of Evelyn Shatkin and the late Perry Shatkin, wife of Russell Holze and the late Doug Richardson, mother to Toni Sue, beloved sister of Susan Shatkin, JoAnne Shatkin, sister-in-law Christine Steinwand, nephew Joshua Steinwand, adored niece of Janet and Ken Dobrer and Walter Bergman, beloved cousin of Jon, Fred, Andy and James Intrater and Yvette and Joel Bergman. A graduate of Boston U, ''Lola'' was a great talent agent. A memorial service was held January 27th in Cold Spring, NY. A wonderful bubbling and loving personality, sorely missed by family and countless friends, we will hold her in our hearts forever.

SCHNEIDMAN--Hilda , peacefully passed away January 27, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Arnold Schneidman, cherished mother of Jill and Larry Cohen, Steven and Bette Schneidman and Gary and Hillary Schneidman, loving grandmother of Aron and Noah Cohen, Sari and Dana Scneidman, David and Rachel Schneidman. Devoted daughter of the late Arnold and Helen Funk. Also survived by her dedicated care giver and friend Audrey Sinclair. She will be in our hearts forever, we will miss her. Services today, January 29, 2008, at 10:30am Beth El Synagogue North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY.

ZEITZ--Willard . It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club, record the passing of our esteemed member, Willard Zeitz. Mr. Zeitz's father, Harry, was the club's second president and a founding member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Allen Kaplan, President Victor Linell, Secretary

SOLOMON--Anthony M . A memorial service will be held in honor of Anthony M. Solomon, former President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Art Collector, Sculptor and Economist, on Wednesday, February 27th at 5:30pm at the New York Historical Society in the Auditorium. There will be a reception immediately following also at the New York Historical Society in the Great Room. The Society is located at 170 Central Park West. (Due to limited space, please RSVP to Arlene at 212-688-2692).

8:30 P.M. (HBO) BAGHDAD HOSPITAL: INSIDE THE RED ZONE Al Yarmouk hospital, above, in the most dangerous part of Baghdad, is a place of both hope and despair for thousands of wounded civilians and their families. Staff members like Dr. Omer Salih Mahdi are at the center of the chaos. In this new documentary, Dr. Mahdi ventures into the hospital's emergency room with a hand-held camera to expose the horrific injuries suffered by Iraqis as well as the dangerous and substandard conditions the hospital's staff endures each day. The filming of the documentary was considered so dangerous that Dr. Mahdi originally hid his identity; his voice was recorded by an actor. Dr. Ali Abdul Wahed, a surgeon and one of the few staff members to allow his image to be used in the film, said: ''Whoever is on duty, if they don't have to deal with an explosion or a shooting, we say that they're not really living the real Al Yarmouk.'' Dr. Mahdi is currently studying journalism on a Fulbright scholarship at Ball State University in Indiana. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER: COUPLES This week's temptation: soda on tap. Meanwhile an escalator challenge changes the game for everyone.

LEVIN--William A. , died January 26th, 2008, one day after his 84th birthday. He was an entrepreneur as President and Chairman of the Board of Gold Mills, Inc., a textile manufacturing company and Commissioner of New York State Thoroughbred Racing. He leaves his devoted wife Corinne Knepper Levin, his daughter Dr. Linda Levin Carmine, her husband Professor Michael Carmine, and their daughter, his adored granddaughter Gabrielle. He is predeceased by his late son, Louis R. Levin. Funeral Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30 Tuesday, January 29th and burial at the Westchester Hill Cemetery to follow.

BUSH PUSHES STIMULUS PLAN In his final State of the Union address, President Bush called for Congress to pass his economic stimulus plan quickly. REVELATIONS ABOUT TRADER Management at Société Générale had new questions to answer when Jérôme Kerviel, the renegade trader who lost $7.2 billion, told French prosecutors that his trading spree started as in 2005 -- a year earlier than the bank had said. [A1.]

WEINER--Shirley . Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Charlotte (Stanley) Plotnick and Marcia Kerr (Michael Cherbini). Cherished grandmother of Michael and Linda, Lisa and Chris, Richard and Elana, Eric and Lisa, Mark and Kathy. Great-grandmother of 11. Funeral services today, 10am, at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

STRONG--Richard Wilson . An extraordinary educator, thinker, and writer, died January 27th, 2008, after a valiant battle with cancer. Richard Strong was born in NYC on February 26th, 1946. He was the co-founder of Silver, Strong and Associates, and a member of the Communities for Learning Advisory Council. He was a consummate learner, a selfless listener, and a provocative presenter who deeply touched the lives of thousands of teachers who crossed his path. He is survived by his wife Sheila, and his sons Tom and Danny, by his sisters Alice and Margy, and by his family in heart Ron, Roberta, Jessica and Giselle. He will be sorely missed by the Fellows and staff from Communities for Learning and by the educational community at large. Memorial and contribution information can be found at RichardStrong.legacy.com. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Saint Vincent's Catholic Medical Center Foundation, 130 West 12th Street, MP6, NY, NY 10011.

BURCKMYER--Peter A. , 72, of Somers, died January 25, 2008. Son of the late Elizabeth L. and Lawrence A. Burckmyer, Jr., of Ithaca, NY. He graduated from Cornell University and was a publishing executive at Readers Digest for most of his working life. Mr. Burckmyer served as treasurer of the Somers Land Trust and was instrumental in the purchase of the 654 acre Angle Fly Preserve in 2006. An indefatigable traveler, an active sailor, kayaker, biker, and hiker, and a prizewinning photographer, he is survived by his brother and sister-inlaw, Lawrence and Rebekah Burckmyer of Marblehead, MA; three nieces, Elizabeth Anderson of Washington, D.C., Mary Spencer of Charlottesville, VA, and Sarah Westwood of Medford, MA, and their families; a nephew, Charles Burckmyer of Boston; and his dear friend Patricia Gross of Rowayton, CT. Memorial service Friday, February 1, at 11:00 a.m. at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, Somers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Angle Fly Preserve. Make checks out to Somers Land Trust, c/o Michael Barnhart, 12 Butlerville Road, Somers, NY 10589.

GROSS--Ralph , age 93, of Shelter Island, NY, died on January 19, 2008. He was the former president of the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry. He will be remembered with love and affection by his wife Susan, sons Gary and Richard, grandson Nicholas and stepgrandson Travis.
FOX--Carrol Agnes , born 25 December 1938. Passed away 29 January 2003. Remembered, missed and loved. Marian and family

LIFTON--Helen , age 96, on January 26, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Devoted mother of David S. Lifton and Judy Schreiber. Cherished grandmother of Hal and Tim Mosher; Missy and David Lee Galanida. Lover of the theater and the arts, a feminist ahead of her time. Her son David is forever grateful for her moral support. Services Wednesday, 11:15am, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to Continuum Hospice Care, 1775 Broadway, Suite 300, NY, NY 10019.

An early tumble gave way to a rally on Wall Street on Monday, as investors shrugged off heavy losses in the Asian markets and sent stocks steadily up in the afternoon. The Dow Jones industrials closed up 176 points and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained almost 1.8 percent, led by a strong recovery among beaten-down financial stocks. Shares of JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America were up by more than 4 percent.

ARCURE--Matthew , on January 25. Beloved son of Catherine. Dear brother of Jennifer (Eric Potoker). Devoted uncle of Matthew and Nicholas. Donations in his memory may be made to the Shake-aLeg Foundation, 2620 Bay Shore Drive, Miami, Florida 33133, Attention: Ashley Sullivan. Services are private.

LANDAU--Sidney , 90. An intelligent, elegant, WWII veteran, humanitarian with deep passion for jazz music, conservationist, birder, devoted husband. Sidney was a teacher to all of us, nonjudgmental, nurturing the best within. His sparkling wit, fierce intellect, and wisdom will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by a daughter, Nina Stagakis, and two stepdaughters, Elizabeth Millet and Jessica Rosenberg.

BIERENBAUM--Marvin Leonard, M.D. , 81 of Newark and West Orange, NJ died peacefully on January 28 after a prolonged struggle with Parkinson's disease. Beloved husband of Nettie; loving and cherished father of daughter Dr. Michele Reichstein and her husband Robert, and son Robert; adoring grandfather of Dr. David Reichstein, Matthew Reichstein, Jonathan Reichstein and Annah Bierenbaum; loving brother of Bernice. Born on August 30, 1926, World War II veteran, graduate of Rutgers University (summa cum laude) and Hahneman Medical School. An astute and compassionate physician, after he established a medical practice in Montclair, NJ, he founded the Kenneth L. Jordan Heart Research foundation in honor of a colleague who died prematurely from heart disease. Over the next four decades, he authored over 150 journal articles and lectured around the world in epidemiology and arteriosclerosis research. His was among the earliest voices calling attention to the harmful effects of cigarette smoking and obesity and he produced seminal research establishing the long-term benefits of a low-fat, lowcholesterol diet. A tireless and enthusiastic public servant, he worked in government for 25 years at the state and national level for the Social Security Administration as Regional Director. That his life was full of accomplishments was a tribute to his intellectual curiosity fueled by boundless energy. But to his family and friends, he was warm and loyal beyond measure, quick to flash a broad smile and endearing giggle, a mesmerizing raconteur who shared his worldly perspectives without braggadocio, an avid and accomplished tennis and bridge player whose favorite game was anywhere he could root for one of his grandchildren, a cherished patriarch and mentor whose loving memory will never cease to inspire. Funeral will be held at Menorah Chapel, 2800 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ on Tuesday January 29 at 1:00 pm.

He was a brilliant attorney and a great humanitarian who cared deeply about the education of the children in New York City's Public Schools. We shall miss his sound counsel, his loyalty and his friendship, and we extend our condolences to Alice, Larry and his entire family. Seymour Fliegel, President Judy Roth Berkowitz, Chairman KRAMER--Arthur B. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Arthur B. Kramer, founder of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP, whose profound commitment and enduring generosity have strengthened our ability to serve those in need, making a lasting impact on all New Yorkers and the Jewish community in Israel and throughout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family and to the partners and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO KRAMER--Arthur B. For 59 years we shared our lives, starting at law school, continuing professionally and through the close family friendship and shared experiences that will live vividly in our memories. We mourn the loss of our dear friend. He was a remarkable man of wide ranging interests and contributions to our society, and we will sorely miss him. We offer our deepest sympathies to Alice, Liza, Andrew, Rebecca and Larry and their families. Loretta and Robert K. Lifton KRAMER--Arthur, Gay Men's Health Crisis mourns the loss of Arthur Kramer, brother of one of our founders Larry Kramer and longtime donor to GMHC. Under Arthur's leadership, Kramer Levin, the firm he founded, provided groundbreaking pro bono legal support in the earliest days of the AIDS epidemic and throughout his life. We celebrate his fearlessness as we extend our condolences to his family.

Al was warm, lively, very funny and generous. Services January 29, 1pm, Beth Shalom Chapel, Smithtown, NY. Shiva at the homes of Howard and David Fingeroth.

DITTRICK--Barbara . The Board of Governors of the Atlantic Golf Club expresses its sincere condolences on the passing of Barbara Dittrick, wife of our former Governor, Douglas Dittrick. David M. Silfen, President Harvey L. Radler, Secretary

BRUMBERG--Abraham , died Saturday, January 26, 2008. Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 17 about a new report on publication of drug company studies of antidepressants referred imprecisely to one of its findings. The report, in The New England Journal of Medicine, found that Eli Lilly had presented one study of its antidepressant Prozac as positive, even though a review of the study by the Food and Drug Administration determined that the drug did not perform as well as a placebo. None of the Prozac studies analyzed in the report went unpublished.

ROMM--Sam , 94, died January 19, 2008 in Eugene, Oregon. Survived by his son Richard, and his grandchild Robin. His wife of 60 years, Helen, preceded him in death. He was a devoted and esteemed educator. He studied at Brooklyn College and Columbia University. He taught at PS 180 and was principal at PS 101, both in Brooklyn. He served as a member of the NYC Board of Examiners. A memorial service was held in Eugene.
MIHLRAD--Jack 5/17/14-1/29/95. 13 years of beautiful loving memories. Always, Diane and Mom

KAUF--Friedrich , passed away on January 23 at age 88. Born June 7, 1919 in Vienna and served with U.S. Army in Europe in WWII. Devoted husband and loving father. Survived by Celia, his wife of 60 years, and his daughters Joyce and Laraine.

WASSMAN--Edward Robert , of Larchmont and Brant Lake, NY. Loving father of Diane Wassman Darst, Ph.D., E. Robert Wassman, Jr., M.D., and Debra Wassman Lanman, M.Arch. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth M. Darst, David M. Darst, Jr., Eleanor F. Lanman, Jonathan T. Lanman, Jr., Anna Cecelia Wassman, and E. Robert Wassman, III. Silver Star recipient for his heroism during WWII on board the U.S.S. Franklin aircraft carrier, a 1948 graduate of Columbia University, and for many years a senior executive of Rockefeller Center Inc. Funeral service to be held at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church on Friday, February 1, at 11am. Donations may be made in his memory to the Larchmont Avenue Church, the Naval Order of the U.S. New York Commandery, or The Adirondack Council. As an emblematic member of the ''Greatest Generation,'' he will live on in our hearts forever.

STEINBERG--Marlene Gracie , died on January 21, 2008 in New York City at home. She was the mother of Lucas Steinberg and Sierra Fromberg. Daughter of George and Anita Blumenfeld. Sister of Robin Kellner. Wife of Bill Steinberg. She was 56 and died tragically, way too young. She will be missed. Robin Kellner

SALLEN--Gertrude . Our extraordinary and treasured family matriarch passed away peacefully on January 27th, 2008. Devoted aunt of Sherry Goldstein, Lynda Cohen (husband Robert Grappel), Leonard Shapiro, Donald Tobias (wife Claudia Taft), Philip Shapiro, Richard Sallen (wife Cheryl) and David Sallen. Beloved cousin, great-aunt and great - great - aunt. Her warmth, wisdom and independent spirit, all of which she retained to her last day, will be cherished forever. Gertrude, we will miss you and remember you always. Services Wednesday, January 30, at 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
WILKIE--Dorothea Jones , died in NYC on January 23rd. She is survived by her four children, seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

DEICH--Helen , Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Helen Deich, beloved mother of our devoted member Judith Deich. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

ROBINSON--Phoebe Stettner Robinson , of Monroe Township, NJ, died Sunday, January 27, 2008 at her home at age 81. Born in the Bronx, she lived in Longmeadow, MA, before moving here in 1993. Mrs. Robinson was a copywriter for station WSPR in Springfield, MA, and then a school teacher in Somers, CT, for 21 years. Predeceased by her daughter, Barbara Robinson, and sister, Joyce Miller, she is survived by her cherished husband of 59 years, Bertram Robinson; her dear son, Marc, and her cherished grandson, Zachary. She was also a loving aunt to Phillip, Kevin and Pam Miller; and Dan, Meryl, Deb, Jeff and Rick Linzer. Memorial contributions may be made to the Barbara Robinson Scholarship Fund at Suffolk Law School, Boston, MA.

In this election year, let us show our fellow Americans that we recognize our responsibilities and are determined to meet them. Let us show them that Republicans and Democrats can compete for votes and cooperate for results at the same time. PRESIDENT BUSH [A18]

Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints who led Mormonism through a period of global expansion, died Sunday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 97. The church, which announced his death on its Web site, said a successor to Mr. Hinckley was not expected to be chosen until after his funeral.

For the New York papers, the focus today is on Rudolph W. Giuliani’s precipitous political free fall, after his third-place finish in the Republican presidential primary in Florida on Tuesday night. “Rudy’s Ruin,” says the front of The Post. “The Fat Lady’s Singin’,” declares The Daily News. In The Times, Michael Powell and Michael Cooper dissect what is called a “dizzying free-fall” for the ex-mayor, noting that just a few months ago a senior Giuliani aide had surveyed the Republican field and said: “I don’t believe this can be taken from us. Now that I have that locked up, I can go do battle elsewhere.”Instead, hubris and strategic miscalculations plagued his campaign, political observers say. For one, he allowed a tight coterie of New York aides, none with national political experience, to run much of his campaign. And while he accumulated a fat war chest — he had $16.6 million on hand at the end of September, more than Mitt Romney ($9.5 million) or Senator John McCain ($3.2 million) — he spent vast sums on direct mail instead of building strong organizations on the ground in South Carolina and New Hampshire.

Updated, 1:48 p.m. | Eight years after New York Republicans, led by Gov. George E. Pataki, fought unsuccessfully to keep Senator John McCain off the Republican presidential primary ballot, they are moving swiftly to embrace him as the party’s front-runner Wednesday morning, as Rudolph W. Giuliani prepares to exit the race. The Republican leaders in the State Legislature both announced their support for Mr. McCain this morning.

Updated, 5:10 p.m. | Michelle Obama spoke this afternoon at a fund-raising lunch on the Upper East Side for her husband’s presidential campaign, and one of the more prominent people present was Alma Rangel, the wife of Representative Charles B. Rangel, according to a person familiar with the guest list for the event. Mr. Rangel has been a leading supporter of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, so his wife’s attendance at a fund-raiser for Senator Barack Obama, Mrs. Clinton’s chief rival, seems noteworthy.

Silverstein plans at 99 Church Street was described on Tuesday by the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which will handle condominium sales, as a project that would “unquestionably advance the revitalization efforts of downtown.” The architect of the project near ground zero, Robert A. M. Stern, said the tower would “help Lower Manhattan realize its potential.”

Elizabeth B. Moynihan, the widow of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who shepherded Hillary Rodham Clinton as his successor in the United States Senate, has endorsed Barack Obama, Mrs. Clinton’s chief rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

In a relatively liberal bastion of western Queens, Alice Lemos said that she has found it hard to find like-minded, socially conservative New Yorkers. And to find kindred Republican spirits, she explained, she must sometimes travel outside of her neighborhood of Woodside, Queens, to other parts of the city.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will play host to a “national town hall” in New York City at 9 p.m. on Monday — the eve of the Democratic presidential primaries in 22 states, including New York — that will allow voters in 22 cities to ask questions through a live Webcast, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign just announced.

The New York Post has endorsed Barack Obama in Tuesday’s New York Democratic primary, saying that his chief rival for the party’s presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, represented the politics of the past. “Obama represents a fresh start,” The Post stated in an editorial on its Web site. “His opponent, and her husband, stand for déjà vu all over again — a return to the opportunistic, scandal-scarred, morally muddled years of the almost infinitely self-indulgent Clinton co-presidency.”
TRENTON — Richard J. Codey, the popular and powerful president of the New Jersey State Senate, plans to endorse Barack Obama for president.

STAMFORD, Conn. — Michelle Obama told a group of supporters today not to assume that her husband, Barack Obama, would return for another try at the White House, or be any more appealing as a candidate later, if this bid falls short. “It’s not a threat,’’ she said. “It’s the reality.’’

The relationship between the Clintons and the Democrats of New York goes back far before Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to New York to run for the Senate in 2000. In 1992, New York played a crucial role in securing the Democratic nomination for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, but the outcome of the primary also revealed a divided and uncertain electorate.

When he did, the restaurant's name changed slightly --- it's now simply called Fiamma --- and its cooking changed more than that. While it still bills itself as an Italian restaurant, its dishes are less traditionally Italian, more fanciful and more reflective of French influences than the dishes under the previous chef, Michael White, were.

There's no question that "neoconservative" has become, in many quarters of both the left and right, a fashionable pejorative, to be casually tossed about, and just as casually misapplied.

The Moment spoke with the rising British pop star Mika on the eve of his performance at the NRJ music awards in Cannes, France, where the bouncy, mop-headed singer had plenty of reasons to celebrate. To name a few: he's about to kick off a short North American tour, Marc Jacobs named a bag from his spring collection "Mika," and the 24 year old, Lebanese-born singer recently received his first Grammy nomination, for Best Dance Recording. To hear what the excitement is all about for yourself, check him out February 2nd when he plays at the Terminal 5 in New York. The last time we checked, tickets were sold out. When I tell people I'm buying a Smart Car, I generally get one of three reactions. Most people still don't know what it is - they haven't seen the half-pint two seater from Daimler. Many of those who do know about them laugh. The Smart is a tiny thing, comical in its styling and proportions: just 8.8 feet long. (It's about 40 inches shorter than a Mini Cooper, that road hog.) And then there are the very few who get a sort of funny smile on their faces. Not quite envy, but the look you got in high school from people who had realized that you really were going to jump from that 40-foot tower into the lake, and were waiting with pleasure to see if you'd make it.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Verizon’s earnings misstated its revenue for 2007 in some copies. It was $93.4 billion, not million.

A sports article on Saturday about optimistic comments by Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning regarding his brother Eli’s prospects for future Super Bowls with the Giants misidentified the location of the 2006 season opener between their teams. It was at Giants Stadium, not in Indianapolis.

An article in some editions on Sunday about a disabled American spy satellite that is likely to plunge to earth by late February or early March referred imprecisely to Jonathan McDowell, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who said it was fairly common for satellites to drop out of orbit. He is an analyst of various government space programs; he does not work for the government as an analyst of space programs.

Because of an editing error, a report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about a book to be released this spring that includes interviews with 11 stars of the game from the 1950s and ’60s attributed an incorrect distinction to four of the men. The former players Ralph Branca, Carl Erskine, Bill Rigney and Lew Burdette are not in the Hall of Fame.

The Big City column on Monday, about Derrick Braxton, a black student from a Brooklyn housing project now attending a small, mostly white college in upstate New York, referred incorrectly to his Brooklyn high school, Bedford Academy. It is a public school, not a charter school.

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 18 about “A A Bronson’s School for Young Shamans” at John Connelly Presents, in Chelsea, rendered part of Mr. Bronson’s name incorrectly. He uses “A A,” not A.A. The entry also misstated the former relationship between Mr. Bronson and the artist Terence Koh, who collaborated on a work in the show. Mr. Koh was Mr. Bronson’s studio assistant, not his student.

An article in Business Day on Friday about the management turnover at Interview magazine referred incompletely to the positions held by Sandra Brant at Brant Publications, which owns Interview. Ms. Brant is the chief executive, president and publisher of Brant Publications, and will continue in those roles until Feb. 22; she is not just the publisher.

The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the News Corporation blending its news and sports divisions to cover the Super Bowl and the coming Tuesday primaries, misidentified the location of the Super Bowl this Sunday. The game will be played at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz., not in Phoenix itself.

A dance review on Monday about the Cool New York 2008 Dance Festival, at the John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, misidentified the dancer who performed a solo by Darcy Naganuma. He is Kambi Gathesha, not Charly Wenzel (who is a woman).

An article in some editions on Sunday about a disabled American spy satellite that is likely to plunge to earth by late February or early March referred imprecisely to Jonathan McDowell, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who said it was fairly common for satellites to drop out of orbit. He is an analyst of various government space programs; he does not work for the government as an analyst of space programs.

An article on Jan. 23 about Senate debate on a plan to provide immunity for telephone companies that helped the National Security Agency with a wiretapping program misspelled the surname of the director of the Washington legislative office of the American Civil Liberties Union who criticized Senator Harry Reid’s strategy for handling the measure. She is Caroline Fredrickson, not Frederickson.
The Democratic primary generated extraordinary voter interest even though the result will have no practical impact and the candidates did not actively campaign in the state.

An obituary in some editions on Monday about Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, attributed an erroneous distinction to him concerning the number of years he spent in the church’s top leadership. Although he spent 46 years in leadership posts, he was not the longest-serving president; Brigham Young was. The obituary also described the church’s office of the First Presidency incorrectly. It encompasses the church president and his two advisers; it is not a two-man team that counsels the president. The obituary also rendered incorrectly the name of a fund Mr. Hinckley established to pay for needy church members to attend college and misstated its source of financing. It is the Perpetual Education Fund, not the Perpetual Loan Fund, and it is financed by contributions, not tithes.

Blood found throughout the apartment of Nixzmary Brown and under the fingernails of the man accused of killing her belonged to the girl, a representative of the chief medical examiner’s office testified.

The Bloomberg administration is overhauling the way that principals at New York City’s 1,500 public schools are evaluated and selected, taking centralized control of the initial screening of candidates.
LaQuita Owens scored a season-high 23 points and No. 12 West Virginia used a 21-4 run in the second half to beat No. 4 Rutgers, 63-54, on Tuesday night.
Kenny Hulshof of Missouri and Ron Lewis of Kentucky, have announced plans to leave Congress.

A Congressional subcommittee voted to subpoena former and current Food and Drug Administration investigators to testify about fraudulent clinical data that supported approval of the antibiotic drug Ketek.
The chief executive of Grady Memorial Hospital, Otis L. Story Sr., has resigned, ending a brief stint as the troubled hospital’s fourth C.E.O. since 2000.

Frustrated by ballooning costs for an ambitious plan to build a virtually emissions-free power plant, the Energy Department told federal lawmakers that it planned to pull its support for the $1.8 billion project in Illinois.
An arrest warrant has been issued in Mexico for a marine wanted in North Carolina for killing a fellow marine who had accused him of rape.
Congress approved a 15-day extension of the government’s authority to eavesdrop on suspected terrorists.
The historic Hotel Bossert, where the Brooklyn Dodgers celebrated their first and last World Series championship, is being put up for sale.
Kwame Brown’s career began as Eddy Curry’s did, with big shoulders and high hopes and premier position in the 2001 draft. But both have not lived up to expectations.

The trucks navigate a cumbersome stop-and-go route on the chaotic streets of New York. The workers — dozens of them simultaneously — move with precision, nailing wood, twisting metal reinforcements, smoothing cement and climbing narrow wooden frames on cue, hundreds of feet in the air, sometimes in the face of swirling winds. Neighboring high rises often sit a crane’s whip away.
Hundreds of former patrons protested the closing of Mexico’s oldest cantina, El Nivel, in Mexico City.

The Security Council abandoned efforts to adopt a statement on the crisis in Gaza after Libya and the United States were unable to agree on the wording. The 15-nation Council began talks on a nonbinding statement a week ago after Israel sealed all border crossings to the Gaza Strip, complicating delivery of aid to Gaza’s 1.5 million people in what Israel said was a response to Palestinian rocket attacks from Gaza. Diplomats said the deadlock was a result of irreconcilable Libyan and American demands on the statement’s content and phrasing.

A famous black felt hat and other personal objects worn by the former French president, François Mitterrand, were sold at a Paris auction. The sale fetched about $192,000, money that will be donated to a charity run by Mr. Mitterrand’s widow, Danielle. More than 300 items went under the gavel, including official gifts, like a miniature ceramic house from Barbara Bush and a crocodile-skin briefcase from Fidel Castro. The auction was the third organized by Mrs. Mitterrand since her husband’s death 12 years ago.

A 37-year-old man from Birmingham, in the English midlands, has pleaded guilty to plotting to behead a British soldier. Parviz Khan, who described himself to investigators as a Muslim charity worker, was heard in covert recordings made by Britain’s security services outlining a plan to kidnap a soldier from Birmingham’s nightclub district and have him beheaded, the court in Leicester was told. Nigel Rumfitt, the prosecutor, said Mr. Khan’s plan was to videotape the killing and release the tape “to cause panic and fear within the British armed forces and wider public.” Three other men, all Muslims, have admitted offenses in the case, one of them a Gambian citizen tasked by Mr. Khan to identify a Muslim West African soldier serving in the British Army as the victim for the beheading plot, according to the prosecution. Mr. Khan was said to have shown the other men videos of terrorist beheadings in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Prosecutors reopened the case of Erna Wallisch, 85, who ranks seventh on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals, after new evidence suggested that the woman might have taken part in the mass murder of inmates in the Majdanek concentration camp near Lublin, Poland. “We are trying to establish whether statements from Polish witnesses are sufficient to identify Mrs. Wallisch,” said Gerhard Jarosch, spokesman for the state prosecutors in Vienna, in a telephone interview. “Obviously this is very difficult more than six decades later.” The woman, who served as a guard in the death camp, is living in a small apartment in Vienna.
Despite the disappointing outlook, the company said it planned to invest aggressively in advertising technology as it tries to capture a larger share of online ad dollars.

President Óscar Arias of Costa Rica, below, said he would ask the United States to delay the start of a free-trade agreement to give the country time to pass several local laws. Costa Rica approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement in October, but its Congress has passed only 4 of 13 laws necessary to begin it, Mr. Arias said. The deadline for doing so is Feb. 29 and Mr. Arias acknowledged that his administration would not be ready by that date. The pact has already taken effect in the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

Deutsche Lufthansa, the German airline, reached an 18-month contract agreement with pilots to avoid further strikes. The airline’s 4,400 pilots will receive a 2.5 percent raise retroactive to Oct. 1 and an additional 3 percent increase retroactive to Jan. 1, Lufthansa said. The agreement runs through March 2009 and includes a one-time payment equal to 25 percent of a month’s wages.

The Luxottica Group, the Italian maker of eyeglasses, said fourth-quarter sales rose 7.1 percent after last year’s acquisition of Oakley. Revenue at the company, which operates Sunglass Hut and LensCrafter stores and makes Ray-Ban sunglasses, climbed to 1.19 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from 1.11 billion euros a year earlier. Fourth-quarter wholesale sales rose 16 percent to 479 million euros ($705 million). Sales fell 1.7 percent at retail stores open at least a year, reflecting Luxottica’s exposure in the United States. Luxottica bought Oakley for $2 billion in June.

NTT DoCoMo, the cellphone operator, had a 35 percent gain in quarterly profit as marketing costs dropped, but falling revenue showed the pain of a price war as it lost ground to rivals. Revenue at DoCoMo fell 1.4 percent to 1.2 trillion yen ($11 billion) in the quarter. DoCoMo said operating profit rose to 217 billion yen ($2 billion).

Extreme temperatures have frozen equipment and forced a shutdown at Syncrude Canada, the oil sands project. Most of the 350,000 barrels of oil produced daily at the project are sent to the United States. But temperatures in northern Alberta, where Syncrude is located, have dipped below minus 40 degrees at night this week. That has led to “several instrument freeze-ups,” the Canadian Oil Sands Trust, which owns about 37 percent of the project, said on Tuesday. Full production will probably not resume for several days.

The House voted on Tuesday to approve a $146 billion fiscal stimulus package, but the bipartisan deal is at risk as Senate Democrats forged ahead with their own, more expensive plan and jockeyed over what to include in it.

Japan’s industrial production rose less than expected in December and manufacturers reported falling output, recent data showed. Industrial output rose 1.4 percent in December from November, falling short of a consensus market forecast of a 2.0 percent increase. Manufacturers’ output, the core component of production, is expected to fall 0.4 percent in January and 2.2 percent in February, the ministry of economy, trade and industry said.
A group of teenagers, parents and elected officials from Greenwich Village is opposing a proposal to build what they call “Las Vegas on the Hudson.”
Politicians in France increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for Wednesday.
Defense lawyers described Mr. Snipes’ views on taxes as “kooky” and “dead wrong,” but said he had not committed a crime.
Andy Pettitte will provide the first account of conversations with Brian McNamee about Roger Clemens’s alleged use of performance-enhancing drugs in earlier years.
The Nets’ nine-game losing streak ended Tuesday night, thanks in part to the play of Jason Kidd over the final two minutes.
In four southern states that voted solidly for President Bush, voters are unhappy with both presidential fields.

With the Beijing Games only seven months away, the defending Olympic 400 meters champion Jeremy Wariner and his longtime coach have split over a contract dispute. Clyde Hart, who has coached Wariner for five years beginning with their days at Baylor University, said Wariner wanted to pay him less than in his previous contracts. Michael Johnson, the world-record holder in the 200 and Wariner’s agent, did not immediately respond to a telephone message seeking comment left with Wariner’s manager, Deon Minor.

The former Cowboys coach Dave Campo rejoined the staff Tuesday as the secondary coach. Campo was the only coach never to get Dallas into the playoffs — the Cowboys were 5-11 in each of his three seasons. He replaces Todd Bowles, one of several assistants who left to join the staff of the new Dolphins coach Tony Sparano, a former Cowboys assistant.

This year’s Hall of Fame Game between the Chicago Cubs and San Diego Padres on June 16 will be the last in the exhibition series. Officials at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum said Tuesday that Major League Baseball decided that keeping the game was too difficult because of the complexities of the major league schedule. The first Hall of Fame Game was played in 1940.

Barbaro, who won the 2006 Kentucky Derby and broke down two weeks later at the Preakness, will have his ashes interred at Churchill Downs. He was euthanized Jan. 29, 2007. The site will include a bronze statue commissioned by Barbaro’s owners, Roy and Gretchen Jackson. The statue will be loaned to the track.

Rutgers University approved spending $102 million to expand its football stadium by 14,000 seats. The plan approved by the university’s governing board will boost the stadium’s capacity to 56,000.The plan calls for borrowing $72 million that will be repaid through increased ticket revenues. Another $30 million is to come from private donations. The project is expected to be completed by 2009.

The former N.F.L. player Alonzo Spellman was arrested Tuesday in Tulsa, Okla., after a nearly 20-minute chase in which police fired pepper-spray pellets into his car. His bond was set at $10,700, and Spellman remained jailed early Tuesday evening. Spellman played nine seasons in the N.F.L. for the Chicago Bears, the Detroit Lions and the Dallas Cowboys.
Andy Roddick and James Blake will lead the defending champion United States against Austria in the first round of the Davis Cup in Vienna on Feb. 8-10.

John Obi Mikel and Yakubu Aiyegbeni scored to lead Nigeria over Benin, 2-0, on Tuesday in Sekondi, Ghana, and into the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations. Ivory Coast (3-0), which already was assured of advancing, defeated Mali, 3-0. Ivory Coast won Group B and will play the Group A runner-up, Guinea, on Sunday. Nigeria (1-1-1) will meet host Ghana.
Barack Obama selected El Dorado, Kan., the old oil town where his maternal grandfather was reared, to open a tour of states holding primaries and caucuses Feb. 5.
Eli Lilly & Company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $854.4 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with $132.3 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago.
Members of Congress sent a letter to the chief executive of Mattel, accusing the company of not living up to its promise to keep lead-tainted toys out of children’s hands.
Court documents and interviews with law enforcement officials provide an account of what happened the night an off-duty police officer was shot dead by other officers.
President Bush is sending signals that the troop reductions in Iraq may not continue past this summer.
A federal report says that the Army Corps of Engineers charged the government hundreds of millions of dollars for supervising projects in Iraq that have failed or fallen behind.
The attorney general said Tuesday that the harsh C.I.A. interrogation technique known as waterboarding was not clearly illegal, and suggested that it could be used against terrorism suspects again.
After a stunning cut one week ago, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.
The law would require all registered sex offenders to submit any e-mail addresses and other Internet identifiers to the State Division of Criminal Justice Services within 10 days of their creation.
In New Jersey, Democrats are finding themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.

The National Transportation Safety Board’s working theory about last summer’s bridge collapse in Minneapolis — that it was caused by a design error four decades ago — has run into a peculiar problem: it contradicts much public belief.

Avalanche centers in the West issued warnings Tuesday as new storms lined up following a system that buried many areas in heavy snow, closing government offices, causing havoc on roads and even shutting down a ski resort.
As the youthful-looking offensive coordinator for the New England Patriots, Josh McDaniels spent the season engineering the highest-scoring offense in N.F.L. history.
Wall Street advanced sharply Tuesday, as the Federal Reserve opened a two-day meeting at which it is expected to cut interest rates again to revitalize the economy.
Mrs. Daniel achieved renown as a concert singer, radio and television host, and author of best-selling biographies and mysteries.
A majority of Turks see the government’s decision to lift its ban on women wearing head scarves in universities as good for both Islam and the nation.
NEWARK — A 17-year-old will be tried as an adult for what prosecutors said was his “active role” in the killings of three young people in a Newark schoolyard last summer, a judge ruled on Tuesday.
Most people who manipulate elections usually try to pretend otherwise. Vladimir Putin does not even bother.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. (AP) — The nation’s largest chemical company, Dow Chemical, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 52 percent because of an overhaul effort and a $1.7 billion jump in spending on materials and energy.
The House deserves credit for passing a stimulus bill speedily, and the Senate does, too, for quickly improving on the effort.
In a major revamping of its sluggish clothing business, Wal-Mart Stores will shut two divisions at its headquarters in Arkansas.
Barack Obama’s first spot highlighting Caroline Kennedy’s endorsement features images of her father and the Moon landing.
The Supreme Court’s majority has been reading federal anti-discrimination laws far more narrowly than Congress intended.
Sidney Crosby is expected to miss six to eight weeks, the most serious blow in a series of setbacks for the Penguins, who were already without goaltender Marc-André Fleury.
With Florida behind them and 24 primaries looming, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with New York, where anything can happen to a campaign.
Three airlines — Northwest, JetBlue and AirTran Holdings — posted fourth-quarter losses on Tuesday as rising fuel costs erased gains from fare increases.
The latest signing statements offer evidence, as if any were needed, that President Bush never intended to end the war in Iraq.
The maker of corporate data storage equipment forecast better-than-expected 2008 revenue, but its shares fell after the VMware unit missed growth estimates.
In an unusual marketing move for a fashion and luxury goods brand, Louis Vuitton said it planned to advertise on television for the first time.
The Pepsi Bottling Group posted a profit on Tuesday that beat Wall Street estimates by a penny, despite flat volume.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — The 3M Company, which makes Scotch tape, Post-it notes and industrial adhesives, posted lower fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, compared with the quarter a year ago, which included a one-time gain.
CHICAGO (AP) — The Allstate Corporation, the property and casualty insurer, reported a 37 percent decline in fourth-quarter profit Tuesday on higher catastrophe losses and increased costs.
PITTSBURGH (AP) — United States Steel reported substantially lower fourth-quarter profits on Tuesday, as acquisition costs, European job cuts and lower prices weighed down results.

Black people in Lima, Ohio, from the poorest citizens to religious and business leaders, complain that rogue police officers regularly stop them without cause, point guns in their faces, curse them and physically abuse them.
Opponents of the George W. Bush Presidential Library at Southern Methodist University say church rules require that the elected delegates of the church’s South Central Jurisdiction approve any plans.
The federal investigation into looted Asian and American Indian antiquities has been expanded to include stolen artifacts from Central America.
Georgetown point guard Jonathan Wallace, who averaged 16.5 points a game as a senior at Sparkman High School, was a bit more Old McDonald than McDonald’s all-American.
Mr. Bradley’s best-selling first book, “No Place to Hide,” was an eyewitness account of the postwar atomic tests on Bikini Atoll in the South Pacific.
Mr. Barr was best known for representing the International Business Machines Corporation in a 13-year antitrust battle with the federal government.
President Bush reflected on his battle with alcohol abuse on Tuesday while speaking in support of his initiative to guarantee permanent government financing for religion-based groups.
The huge loss for Countrywide Financial Corporation was not expected to hinder its $4.1 billion takeover by the Bank of America.
Mr. Froehlich was one of the first distributors of high-tech Japanese cameras in the United States.
Fourteen firms are under scrutiny for possible accounting fraud, insider trading or other violations tied to loans made to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit.
The day that Société Générale said Jérôme Kerviel, a rogue trader, had cost it billions, it announced a large subprime-related write-down.
With the rebirth of the South Bronx has come at least a bit of rebirth at Herman Ridder Junior High School.
Home prices in 20 metropolitan areas fell in November for the 11th consecutive month, as foreclosures and a slump in sales added to the glut of unsold properties.
Galen Rupp says he will not win the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, but he expects to be in the fight.
A woman is suspected of setting her house in Colorado Springs on fire Monday night, killing her 16-month-old daughter and badly injuring her four other children.
Orders to factories for big-ticket manufactured goods jumped an unexpected 5.2 percent in December.
Stephen Chao, a hit maker fired from News Corporation, is starting an Internet video venture in how-to clips.
The United States is the largest single donor of food aid in the world, but it doesn’t provide enough of what young children really need.
A bill drafted by the New York City Council members could stifle the collection of environmental information vital to the public good.
Eager to cool its often rancorous relations with its neighbors in Greenwich Village, New York University has hammered out an accord over expansion with many of its fiercest critics.
The Mets beat out the Yankees and the Red Sox to acquire Johan Santana, a two-time Cy Young award winner.
Giants Coach Tom Coughlin’s theme for the season was “Talk is Cheap. Play the game.” But with five days still to go before Super Bowl XLII, receiver Plaxico Burress couldn’t help himself.
New York’s chic shopping districts seem to be teeming these days with foreign tourists taking advantage of the weak dollar. Foreign retailers are now joining them.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,924 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
The economy may be slowing down, but Washington think tanks are showing growth in size and influence.
HOBOKEN, N.J. — A four-alarm fire swept through an apartment building here early Tuesday, killing one man and leaving more than 60 people homeless.
The House oversight committee has postponed a deposition of Andy Pettitte as part of its investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

A Pakistani Senate committee has proposed an end to the four-decade ban on showing movies from India, Agence France-Press reported. In a statement on Tuesday, the committee referred to the films when it said, “The ban has practically become ineffective as these are being viewed uncensored in almost every household on cable TV as well as CDs and DVDs, necessitating a reappraisal to deal with the issue rationally.”.
A letter yesterday about Caroline Kennedy’s Op-Ed article endorsing Barack Obama was published under a false name. The writer was Joan Sommers, not Maggie Atwood.

An 84-year-old man whose family forged statues and paintings that were sold to museums including the Art Institute of Chicago received a two-year suspended sentence in London on Monday, The Associated Press reported. The man, George Greenhalgh, right; his wife, Olive, 83; and their son, Shaun, 46, pleaded guilty in 2002 to laundering money from the sale of forged artworks. In November a sentence of more than four years was imposed on Shaun, described by the authorities as the creator of fakes that supposedly ranged across the millennia, from gold and silver Roman and Anglo-Saxon works to sculptures attributed to Paul Gauguin and Henry Moore. Mrs. Greenhalgh received a one-year sentence. The police said the parents handled most of the sales. Detective Sgt. Vernon Rapley, chief of Scotland Yard’s art and antiques unit, said there was little doubt that some of the family’s forgeries were still circulating in the art world.

In a spat between partners who have shared a lot of success, NBC Universal has filed suit against Dick Wolf, the prolific producer of the network’s three “Law & Order” series. The suit, filed last week in Los Angeles County Superior Court, centers on complex terms in Mr. Wolf’s contract. NBC argues that Mr. Wolf, right, is misinterpreting them to demand millions of dollars in executive-producer fees for two years after his shows leave the air. NBC’s interpretation is that if the network produces a sufficient number of episodes it can fulfill the contract and not owe Mr. Wolf for work he is no longer doing. Mr. Wolf’s side contends that the contract guarantees the money as a kind of termination payment, or “kill fee.” No matter when NBC decides to end his series, Mr. Wolf argues, he is to be paid for 48 more episodes. NBC asks that if the court finds the contract language ambiguous, it direct that the errors be fixed rather than force NBC to pay the money. A representative of Mr. Wolf, who like other Hollywood writers is on strike, said he was traveling on Tuesday and could not be reached. But Mr. Wolf issued a statement last week saying: “NBC Universal is trying to rewrite an existing contract. Apparently, our partner is willing to commission rewrites during the strike.”.

In the extremely tight ratings race between the two leading evening news broadcasts, ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson” last week edged past its rival, NBC’s “Nightly News With Brian Williams,” for the first time in eight weeks. Nielsen estimated that the ABC newscast drew 9.8 million viewers, its highest average in nearly a year and slightly more than the 9.6 million who tuned in to NBC. ABC’s slim margin of victory was only modestly higher in the age bracket of adults 25 to 54, a demographic the two networks split evenly during the previous week. The last time ABC finished No. 1 was during the November sweeps period. Last week CBS’s “Evening News With Katie Couric” remained a distant third (7.13 million).

Oscar Hijuelos plans a companion novel to his 1990 Pulitzer Prize winner, “The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,” as well as a memoir that will recall his encounters with musicians including Rubén Blades and Lou Reed, The Associated Press reported. The new novel, “Beautiful Maria of My Soul,” and the memoir, “Thoughts Without Cigarettes,” were announced jointly on Tuesday by Hyperion Books, which will publish the novel in 2009, and Gotham Books, a Penguin Group (USA) imprint, which will release the memoir in 2010.

Jerome Robbins, below, will be celebrated by New York City Ballet in performances of 33 of his dances during its spring season, running from April 29 through June 29. The tribute at the New York State Theater, featuring 10 all-Robbins programs, each showcasing a different aspect of his work, will commemorate the 90th anniversary of his birth. Guest artists participating in the event will include dancers from American Ballet Theater, the Paris Opera Ballet and the Royal Ballet.

Singing in Damascus for the first time in more than 20 years, the Lebanese diva Fairuz, 73, electrified an audience that included Vice President Farouq al-Shara on Monday night as that Syrian capital celebrated its designation as Arab Capital of Culture 2008, Agence France-Presse reported. Fairuz, above, widely considered the greatest Arab singer after the death of Umm Kalthoum in 1975, is to give eight concerts, all sold out.

Carnegie Hall, whose mission to create programming looms even larger than its role as a stage for musicians to rent, has taken to creating festivals featuring events in various disciplines around the city.
To the Editor:.

The truculent rapper Foxy Brown will stay put — in jail — after Acting Justice Melissa C. Jackson of the New York State Supreme Court rejected her petition for early release to enable her to travel to California for an ear examination and repair of an electronic ear implant, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Brown, 29, right, whose real name is Inga Marchand, complained that her hearing problems were worsening in jail and that she faced serious harm unless her cochlear implant was repaired and reprogrammed. Prosecutors said she could get the treatment she needs in New York. She was sentenced in September to a year in jail for violating probation. She was put on probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004.

In a surprise move in his first appearance since taking over as his own lawyer, Anthony Pellicano, the embattled Hollywood private investigator, withdrew his request for a hearing into allegations that the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors violated his constitutional rights by using his former girlfriend to elicit confidential information, The Los Angeles Times reported. In withdrawing the request, Mr. Pellicano, who is facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, told Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court, “I don’t believe I had any chance of prevailing.” The accusation of prosecutorial misconduct was a crucial element in the defense of the lawyers who previously represented Mr. Pellicano. Thom Mrozek, a spokesman for the United States Attorney’s Office in Los Angeles, expressed satisfaction with the withdrawal and said, “We have always believed that the motion was unfounded.” The judge plans to begin the trial on Feb. 27.
In a move that will make it easier for small and medium-size public companies to raise money, federal regulators are about to the ease rules on the sale of restricted shares.
Neal Shapiro hasn’t been shy about putting his at times unorthodox stamp on WNET and his own team in place.
Sociologists identify a trend across the Balkans they call Yugonostalgia, in which young and old yearn for the past as they struggle with a legacy of wars and economic hardship.
Daniel Menaker, who left his post as executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group in June, is moving online in March to be the host of a new Web-based book show.
ABC would love to find a way to restore the still substantial “Lost” audience to near the blockbuster level it reached when the show first became a phenomenon more than three years ago.
Customers at Toscanini’s, a revered ice-cream shop in Cambridge, Mass., donated more than $30,000 in one week to help keep it open.
To the Editor:.
In part, the goal of the Center for Curatorial Leadership is that business people — or at least those with far more financial acumen than art training — do not end up running museums.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

This impassioned account of Southern resistance to Reconstruction reminds us that while the North won the Civil War in 1865, the peace would be lost, done in by Southern intransigence and Northern apathy.
Senator Barack Obama has denounced special-interest money, but is benefiting from millions of it nonetheless.
“Fabrik: The Legend of M. Rabinowitz” is a modest yet powerfully affecting production that takes puppetry to impressive heights.
Bagatelle, Padre Figlio and another Bar Veloce open this week, and more dining news.
Estonia has put members of the the Kremlin-backed youth group, Nashi, on an immigration black list, preventing them from traveling to most of the European Union.
Hundreds of Indians had their kidneys removed by a team of doctors running an illegal transplant operation, supplying kidneys to rich Indians and foreigners, police officials say.
“Sisters, Such Devoted Sisters” is a crudely effective solo portrait of the seedy gay underworld in Glasgow.
In recitals David Daniels does as he likes, and if that means opening a concert with a Brahms group, as he did on Monday evening at Zankel Hall, who will complain?
The title characters in “Three Travelers,” a comedy by Richard Abrons, aren’t lost, but the actors playing them seem to be.

In one of the stranger acts of globalism, the Chinese are writing Italian operas. Xiao Bai’s “Farewell My Concubine” from the China National Opera House is touring the United States and came semistaged to Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night.
Cocido is a soulful, slow-cooked stew of tender chickpeas, bacon, spareribs and chorizo.
Much of Abi Morgan’s play “Tender” seems overfamiliar — it’s “Sex and the City” on downers — and strains credulity. Do people really behave like this?
The arrest of an activist who spread information about politically touchy topics is cited as an example of a “cleansing campaign.”
The Wilson Sporting Goods Football Factory in a town of 5,500 in rural Ohio is the birthplace of every football thrown in the Super Bowl since 1969.
At a beefsteak, a raucous all-you-can-eat-and-drink banquet, all the major food groups are represented: beef, butter, salt, French fries and beer.

Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about residents of Martha’s Vineyard, Mass., who get most of their food in winter from the island’s farms, omitted a description about a protest that residents mounted regarding a 43-acre farm that had been leased to the island’s Community Sponsored Agriculture program. The protest was an attempt to keep the property from being sold to become a horse farm.
In his final State of the Union address, the president appeared to be preparing the country for a long stay in Iraq.
Some 500 Afghan women gathered Tuesday in the southern city of Kandahar to protest the kidnapping of an American aid worker and her Afghan driver.
Iran’s judiciary has executed an airport customs contractor accused of bribe-taking and other corruption and has issued death sentences for three other airport employees.

BULLEN--George H. 1946 -2008. George Bullen died on January 28th, after a brave battle with cancer. He was 62. George Bullen was Chairman of the Bullen Insurance Group of companies, which includes Geo. V. Bullen & Son, Inc., Geo. V. Bullen & Son Florida, Inc., and Jackson Hole Insurance LLC. As third generation head of the family firm, he molded the property and casualty insurance business into the successful and thriving practice it is today serving the unique insurance needs of America's wealthiest families. Clients of the firm range from several of America's founding families to hedge fund billionaires, with a modicum of Hollywood and New York celebrities. The firm, established in 1897 by his grandfather, has operation centers in Great Neck, NY, and Jupiter, FL, with additional offices in Locust Valley, NY, New York, NY, and Jackson, WY. Matthew Fox, his son-in-law serves as the fourth generation head of the firm. George served on the boards of several private clubs and charities, including president of the Grenville Baker Boys & Girls Club for six years located in Locust Valley, NY, and Senior Warden of All Saints Church, in Great Neck, NY, which his grandfather helped to build. He was also a founding Board Member of Privilege Underwriters Reciprocal Insurance Co. George Bullen lived in Locust Valley, NY, for many years and had a working cattle ranch outside of Jackson, Wyoming. More recently he lived in Hobe Sound, FL, spending summers in East Hampton, NY. He is survived by his wife Joyce, two daughters Melissa Johnson (Sargent) of Wayzata, MN, and Alicia Fox (Matthew) of Bedford, NY, six grandchildren, and his mother Mary McDonald of Hobe Sound, FL. A memorial service will be held on Jupiter Island, FL, on Friday, February 1st, at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Mesothelioma Center, c/o Dr. R. Taub Research Foundation, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, Room 922, New York, NY 10032. Services are by Martin Funeral Home.

A new Australian hot sauce might not please a real Tasmanian devil, a carnivorous marsupial with major teeth. But Down Under Tasmanian Devil Wing Sauce by Vic Cherikoff will suit a plate of chicken wings just fine: the tomato-based sauce is only moderately hot, but has a citric edge and a nice chunky texture. It could easily double as a salsa for chips. Mr. Cherikoff's Kakadu Wild Fire Pepper Sauce will not sear your palate either, despite its name. It has a somewhat muskier flavor and could also flatter chips or wings.

STRAUSS--Elliott MacGregor (Greg), 79, son of the late RADM Elliott B. Strauss and the late Lydia A. Foote, died suddenly Monday, January 28, 2008. He was a graduate of the Eaglebrook School, Choate School, Harvard College, and was a life-long resident of Paradise Avenue, Middletown. Husband, father, farmer, friend, accomplished horseman, and philanthropist, he was one of life's true gentlemen and will be missed by all who knew him. He was President of the Newport Reading Room, and on the Board of Directors of the Newport Historical Society, the Redwood Library and Athenaeum, and on the Board of Advisors of the Biltmore Company, Asheville, North Carolina. He was a member of the Union Club of New York, the Metropolitan Club of Washington, the Harvard Club of New York City, the Spouting Rock Beach Association, the Clambake Club of Newport, the Ida Lewis Yacht Club, and Quindecim. He is survived by his wife Luise, daughters Caroline Morris and Lydia Tower, sister Lydia Delaunay, brothers Armar and Christopher Strauss, nieces, nephews, cousins, and numerous godchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Newport Historical Society or the Redwood Library and Athenaeum. His funeral will be held Saturday, February 2, 2008, 11am at St. Columba's Chapel, Vaucluse Avenue, Middletown. Funeral services by O'Neill-Hayes Funeral Home.

ROGAK--Sidney. We mourn the loss of our beloved father, Sidney Rogak, who died the morning of January 29, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn (Dolly) Rogak, cherished father of Gary, Larry and Gina Rogak, adoring grandfather of Brendan and Rebecca Rogak, loving brother of Sally Kurman, devoted brother-in-law of Lana and Ben Hauben, beloved fatherin-law of Janice Jelaso and step-grandfather of Michael and Jessica Jelaso. Born August 28, 1916, Sid was a WWII Veteran who proudly served his country as a Naval officer and was recruited into the top-secret team that planned the D-day invasion for over two years. A lifelong lover and player of baseball, Sid hit and fielded well, but was a slow runner which earned him a nickname ''Speedy'', by which he was known the rest of his life. He was a man who knew the true meaning of friendship and his many loving friends including the surviving members of the Saratoga-Sutter Fraternal Organization, a club started in the 1940s by a group of guys who grew up together in Brownsville, Brooklyn, will miss him tremendously. The funeral service will take place on Thursday, January 31st, at 11am at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd, in Rockville Center, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please make a charitable donation to a worthy charity in his honor.

It can be a challenge to properly hard-cook an egg. Guess incorrectly on the timing and you might end up with either a soft-cooked egg or a piece of rubber. The guesswork is gone with this new microwave egg boiler. To cook, one needs to fill the bottom with tap water, replace the aluminum rack, add up to four eggs, cover, put the boiler in the microwave and set the timer. A guide suggests times according to oven power. I should have left the eggs in about a minute longer for hard-boiled on my first attempt. But I was guessing about the power on my fairly ancient microwave oven; newer ovens state the power on a sticker. The eggs were very easy to peel; I could even peel a medium-boiled egg to serve on a salad. It's important to leave the egg boiler in the oven for two minutes after the time is up and to use potholders (the outside gets hot).

BLANK--Ruth Saler, died peacefully at her home in Elkins Park, PA, on Monday surrounded by her loving family. She was 91. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1937. She was married to Samuel A. Blank, who was a prominent attorney in Philadelphia and founder of the Blank, Rome Law Firm. They had a glorious, loving marriage. Ruth's son Jeffrey died in 2004. She is survived by her son Robert and his wife Nancy, her daughter-in-law Carol; grandchildren Jill Aschkenasy (Paul), Wendy Chaikin (Lee), Sally Aronstam (Devin), Philip (April) Blank, Sam Blank, Matt Blank and Matt's fiance Lindsay Pio; and great-grandchildren Kate, Ben, James and Charles Aschkenasy, Grace Charles and Cecily Chaikin and Jeffrey and Elle Aronstam. She was deeply loved by all her family. In 1970 at age 60 Sam developed Alzheimer's disease and died five years later. At the time, people barely knew of Alzheimer's disease and there were no support groups. Ruth would later say that she took her worst nightmare and used it to give her life meaning and purpose. She became active in the Alzheimer's Association headquartered in Chicago becoming a Trustee, member of the Executive Committee and ultimately it's Vice-Chair. She became a world-class fundraiser raising many millions for Alzheimer's research. In 2002, she was honored with the Alzheimer's Association's first Lifetime Achievement Award. She visited the White House twice, meeting with President Reagan in the oval office in 1987 and with Barbara Bush three years later. Both times to advocate for greater federal funding for the disease. The family request that contributions in her memory be made to Ruth & Samuel Blank Research Fund, c/o Alzheimer's Association, Attn: Mark Hopkins, 225 North Michigan Ave, 17th Floor, Chicago, IL 60601.

ENGLE--Mary Allen, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Mary Allen Engle. Professor Emerita of Pediatrics and the former Stavros S. Niarchos Professor of Pediatric Cardiology at Weill Cornell Medical College, Dr. Engle served as the first director of pediatric cardiology at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, a position she held for thirty years, and was instrumental in creating our Division of Pediatric Cardiology, which was later named in her honor. A world-renowned pediatric cardiologist and pioneer in the field, she helped establish the subspecialty with the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Board of Pediatrics, and through her involvement on the boards of the American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology and several prestigious cardiology journals. With uncommon intelligence and dedication, she transformed the lives of thousands of patients. A humanitarian, she established a program for treating children in Greece with congenital heart defects. The recipient of New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell's highest honor, the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award, she was also named an honorary alumnus of Cornell University and received a Woman of Conscience Award from the U.S. National Council of Women during the International Year of the Child in 1982. Optimistic and cheerful, she was beloved by her colleagues, students and patients. Together with her husband, the late Dr. Ralph L. Engle, Jr., who also served on the medical center's faculty, she leaves a lasting legacy of benevolence and excellence. Our deepest condolences to the entire Engle family. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital

STURGIS--Marilyn Sugden,of North Chatham, MA, died after a brief illness on Wednesday, January 23, 2008 at her daughter's home in Duxbury, MA. Marilyn will be most fondly remembered by family and friends for her kindness, grace, devotion and generous spirit. Marilyn was the cornerstone of the family, and provided a warm and welcome haven to all those she held dear. Marilyn had a gift to adopt and embrace new friends in her community or resulting from her extensive travels. The motto she lived by was carpe diem. Marilyn was born on August 11, 1921 and was raised by her aunt and uncle Ida and Arthur Robinson in Forest Hills, NY. She graduated from Berkeley Institute in Brooklyn, NY, Bradford Junior College and Oberlin College, class of 1943. Marilyn taught kindergarten and coached sports at St. Agnes School in Albany, NY, and Green Vale School in Glen Head, NY. Marilyn married Robert Post Sturgis on June 12, 1948 and was married for 32 years, until his death in 1980. Marilyn and Bob raised their family in Woodbury, NJ, and Greenwich, CT. In Woodbury, she was an active volunteer for many organizations including the Presbyterian Church, the Boy Scouts, the library and the AAUW. In Greenwich, Marilyn continued her active volunteerism where she was the President of the Womens Volunteer Association for the Greenwich Hospital, the President of the Stamford Girls Club, the President of the Womens Association of the First Presbyterian Church and the President of the Darien Community Association. In 1982, Marilyn retired to the family's summer home in North Chatham, MA, where she lived for the remainder of her life. She was a member of the Pilgrim Congregational Church of Harwichport, the Chatham Community Garden Club, the Chatham Library Association, Eastward Ho Country Club, the Allens Harbor Yacht Club, the Monomoy Yacht Club, and the Chatham Beach & Tennis Club. Marilyn leaves her son and daughter-in-law Robert and Susan Sturgis of Sugarland, TX, and grandchildren Roman, Lindsley, Trevor and Callum, her daughter Kate Sturgis and her husband Robert Mustard, Jr. and granddaughter Cameron Burnham, and her daughter and son-in-law Joan and Paul Parsons and grandchildren Sarah and Tyler. Marilyn also leaves her longtime dear friend Robert Wilson of Palo Alto, CA, and West Dennis, MA. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 17, 2008 at 2pm at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Harwichport, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Jordan Hospital, 275 Sandwich St., Plymouth, MA.
