CHRISTOPHERSON--William Martin, M.D. 91, of Louisville, Kentucky, died December 21, 2007. Born in Salt Lake City the son of a mine supervisor, Dr. Christopherson was an undergraduate at the University of Utah, took his M.D. from the University of Louisville in 1942 and his residency in pathology at City Hospital of Akron. He was among a pioneering cadre of young pathologists who sought specialized training in neoplastic diseases under the celebrated Dr. Fred Waldorf Stewart at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (1949-50). Returning to the University of Louisville School of Medicine, Dr. Christopherson rose to Professor and Chairman of the Department of Pathology (1956-1974) and was named Distinguished Professor in 1979. His early investigations included novel research into the tissue biology of interstitial irradiation. He went on to contribute landmark cytologic and epidemiologic studies of precancerous lesions of the uterine cervix as well as experimental cervical carcinogenesis in animal models. His efforts proved invaluable in determining the impact of cytologic screening (the ''Pap test'') on the detection of cervical cancer and ''Dr. Chris,'' as he was affectionately known, came to be justly credited for a significant role in reducing the death rate due to this disease. He provided seminal descriptions of various human cancers, most notably the study, written with Drs. Stewart and Frank Foote, establishing alveolar soft part sarcoma as a distinct entity. The recipient of numerous awards, Dr. Christopherson served as President of The American Society of Cytology, The Arthur Purdy Stout Society of Surgical Pathologists and The International Academy of Pathology. In 1971, he was made Honorary Life Member of the Board of Directors of the American Cancer Society. A dedicated mentor, Dr. Chris continued to teach until his retirement in 2001. Our condolences to his wife of 64 years, Kathryn, and entire family. He is survived, as well, by many admiring colleagues, grateful students and an incalculable number of patients whose lives his labors helped preserve. Marc K. Rosenblum, M.D., Chairman, Department of Pathology MemorialSloanKettering Cancer Center Condict Moore, M.D., Emeritus Professor of Surgery Brown Cancer Center University of Louisville Health Sciences Center

BOCK--Elizabeth Harriet Frankel. A women of deep character and zest for life, Elizabeth Harriet Frankel Bock was taken from us suddenly Saturday evening. Elizabeth's many lifelong passions included her love for dance, the French language and traveling. Born in New Rochelle, New York to George and Elizabeth Frankel, Elizabeth grew up in New Rochelle and later in Greenwich, Connecticut, and was a graduate of Cedar Crest College in Allentown, Pennsylvania. Elizabeth and Norman found each other while Elizabeth was in college and were soon thereafter married and moved to start a new life in Houston in 1947. Elizabeth was one of the primary founders of the Houston Chapter of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation which was a personal endeavor to raise awareness and find a cure for a disease her beloved niece, Annie, was diagnosed with shortly after her birth. Elizabeth is survived by husband Norman A. Bock of Sharon, MA, son John Alan Bock and daughter-in-law Randa L. Bock of Houston, TX, daughter Patricia Sue Bock of Potomac, MD, sisters Doris Tulcin of White Plains, NY, and Geraldine Merksamer of Scarsdale, NY, and many cousins, nieces, and nephews who all adored her. Elizabeth's elegance carried her through life and she will always be ''Dancing with the Stars.'' Services will be held at 11:00 in the morning on Thursday, the 24th of January, at Beth Israel Memorial Gardens, 1111 Antoine, in Houston. The family requests that donations be made, in lieu of flowers, to the Cysic Fibrosis Foundation of Houston, 50 Briar Hollow Lane #

Calinoff, Secretary FULD--James J. The Trustees, Fellows and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of James J. Fuld. Jim, a long-time Morgan Fellow, was a brilliant and enthusiastic collector of printed music and related letters, programs, and other documents. We are honored that Jim wanted the extraordinary Fuld Collection to come to the Morgan. We will miss this warm, kind-hearted gentleman, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. S. Parker Gilbert, President FULD--James J., passed away peacefully at home on January 29, 2008 just before his 92nd birthday. He lived a long and wonderful life sharing the past 65 years with his loving wife, Elaine. He will be immensely missed by his three loving children, Joan, Jim and Nancy, and their three spouses, Frank, Lisa and Dan, and by his six adoring grandchildren, Jonathan and his wife Elizabeth, Jennifer, Jamie, Michael, Ryan and David, whom he loved and with whom he shared his life interests. He was a man of great talent with a wide range of interests. His extraordinary music collection will become part of the Morgan Library. He authored the most widely respected book of first edition sheet music. A graduate of Harvard College where he was Co-Captain of the varsity tennis team and Harvard Law School where he was editor of the Law Review, he joined the Proskauer, Rose law firm where he worked until his retirement, serving as managing partner. He was a Director of the UJA-Federation of New York Joint Campaign and Chairman of the Distribution Committee and was active in many other philanthropic organizations. His family, his friends, and all who interacted with him will dearly miss him. Services Thursday, January 31, Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St.

SMITH--Deirdre O'Meara, 61, of Dataw Island, South Carolina, wife of The Honorable Gerald Monroe Smith, died Saturday morning, January 26, 2008, at Beaufort Memorial Hospital. Born in New York City, she was a daughter of the late Thomas F. O'Meara and the late Mary Veronica Meehan O'Meara. Mrs. Smith was a communicant of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church. She graduated cum laude from Trinity College with a BA, from the University of Virginia with a M.Ed, and received her Juris Doctorate degree from the University of Missouri. Mrs. Smith was a retired attorney and court administrator for the Missouri Court of Appeals Eastern District. She served as President of the Dataw Island Owner's Association. Mrs. Smith was the current president of the Dataw Island Club and a former president of the Boys and Girls Club of Beaufort. Mrs. Smith was a member of the Bar Association of Metropolitan St. Louis where she served as president (1994-95). Mrs. Smith was a member of the American Judicature Society where she served on the board of directors, executive committee and as president (2001-03). She was listed in Who's Who of American Women, Who's Who of American Law, and Who's Who in America. Surviving are her husband, Judge Gerald Monroe Smith of Dataw Island, South Carolina; two sons, Dr. Thomas B. Ahr of St. Louis, Missouri, and Andrew T. Ahr of Miami Beach, Florida; one brother, Dr. Thomas O'Meara of Lakewood, Washington; two grandsons. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting memorials be made to the Boys and Girls Club of Beaufort, 17 B. Marshellen Drive, Beaufort, SC 29902. Copeland Funeral Home is in charge of the services.

A plan to thin Manhattan’s perpetual throngs of traffic by charging fees to drivers and increasing prices for on-street parking was approved by a 13-2 vote on Thursday afternoon by a state commission appointed to review different proposals. The plan to decrease traffic [pdf] in much of Manhattan, first proposed in a slightly different form by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last April, would charge drivers $8 to go below 60th Street from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. The commission, the Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission, also recommended imposing a $1 surcharge for taxi trips starting or ending in the area and increased parking rates below 60th Street.

We're at that stage of a campaign now where once serious contenders for the nominations of their parties are forced to cancel events and huddle with their families, to make those difficult calls to friends and supporters who already knew it was coming, to direct their own final scenes on the national stage. It is, in a sense, like planning your own funeral, and I'm sure it feels that way, or at least for a while. I can remember sitting with Bill Bradley in his bare campaign office just after his withdrawal speech in 2000. Everyone was already gone except for a few loyal staff members and the last two Secret Service agents guarding the door. All the noise from all the rallies had subsided, and all that remained were a few empty cubicles and the occasional unanswered phone. I will never forget how one of the agents, checking his watch, offered the candidate a ride home before the final shift came to an end. It's not just the candidate, though, who suffers the trauma. For all the people who work on a campaign, who share cramped apartments with other true believers and keep most of their belongings in a car, the end really does feel like The End. I stood in the Ohio headquarters of America Coming Together, the massive Democratic voter turnout operation, as John Kerry and John Edwards gave their concession speech the day after the 2004 election. A smart young organizer was weeping on her boss's shoulder. I knew that if she lived to be 90, no matter what else she did or how successfully, the memory of that moment would probably still feel like a kick in the gut.

Steve correctly points out that all through "The Moviegoer," Percy makes brief allusions to crazy or eccentric or just plain bad-acting women. But the truth is that especially in Percy's part of the world, those sorts of women do waft in and out of casual conversation in just such a way. It's another spot-on detail he gets exactly right. In my youth, women were forever collecting the equivalent of iron deer, or auditioning and being discovered and going off to Biloxi or maybe even New York or Busch Gardens. They certainly did - and do - a fair share of "going off to Natchez," of checking in and out of nuthouses, and all such activities were usually reported or repeated at the dinner table. Percy and his brothers believed that their own mother's accident was likely no such thing, that, despite the fact that youngest brother Phin was in the car with her, she drove off the road intentionally. I'm sure that whispered assumption was a brief aside at many a Delta dinner table.

According to one economist I spoke to this week, the housing meltdown has trickled into so many crevices of small business that it will take quite a long time for the overall performance of small business to improve even if there are positive signs in areas that have nothing to do with housing.
One of the most storied names in New York retailing plans to bail out another.
Alliance Data Systems filed suit against Blackstone Group on Wednesday in Delaware Chancery Court.
From The Sun of London:

The board of Société Générale, gathering Wednesday in a conference room on the 35th floor of the bank's headquarters outside Paris, tacitly agreed to grant the bank's chairman and chief executive, Daniel Bouton, a reprieve.
New accounting rules for mergers and acquisitions are likely to have some far-reaching consequences for what such deals cost and how they get done, Compliance Week reports.
Bruce Wasserstein is an important rainmaker at Lazard, the investment bank he runs.

Four more Chinese property firms plan Hong Kong initial public offerings this year to raise a combined $2.6 billion, Reuters said, as Beijing's clampdown on bank lending forces developers to brave stock market volatility.

Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that top executives, including Merrill President Gregory Fleming, will not receive bonuses for 2007 after the world's largest brokerage posted $12.1 billion in net losses during the second half of the year.
Wockhardt Hospitals cut the size of its initial public offering, the first Indian company to reduce a sale amid a plunge in equity markets.
Etsy, a site for buying and selling hand-made crafts, has raised $27 million in a round led by Accel Partners, with Accel's Jim Breyer joining the company's board of directors.
If deal making helped fuel the stock markets last spring, could a wave of fresh deals help send buyers back into the market?

Luxim, a Sunnyvale, Calif. company that boasts it produces one of the most efficient light sources on the globe - 144 lumens per watt - or almost twice as efficient as other sources, has raised $21 million more in financing, according to VentureBeat.
While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Street's nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.
While many big-name hedge funds prospered in 2007, Dow Jones notes that one notable group struggled: funds run by large Wall Street firms and traditional money managers.
Crosslink Capital has closed on a new $400 million venture capital-hedge fund hybrid fund believed to be the largest of its kind, the company announced Wednesday.
Japan's four biggest banks face 500 billion yen ($4.7 billion) in losses associated with U.S. subprime mortgages in the current fiscal year through March 31, according to a published report.
When UBS disclosed in October that it had written down $3.6 billion in mortgage-backed securities, it was praised for biting the bullet.

The original Warner Bros. studio in Hollywood, now home to KTLA-TV Channel 5 and other Tribune entertainment companies, was sold for $125 million Wednesday to a Los Angeles real estate investment firm.

Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, raised its stake in Chinese partner Harvest Fund Management Co. to tap growing demand for mutual funds and investment products in the world's most populous nation.

Private equity investors, including the Carlyle Group, are drawing up proposals to partner with Virginia for a rail line to Dulles International Airport as hope fades that the federal government will help fund the 23-mile Metrorail extension, according to The Washington Post.
The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan named the former head of the ACE insurance company, Brian Duperreault, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

Kesa Electricals, which owns Comet in Britain, is selling its its French furniture and electricals business BUT for 550 million euros ($814.4 million) to Decomeubles Partners, a company backed by a consortium made up of Colony Capital, Goldman Sachs and Merchant Equity Partners.

British insurer Friends Provident on Thursday said it would dispose of its controlling stake in F&C Asset Management, the U.K.-listed fund manager, and pull out of its other wealth management businesses as part of a restructuring that would see the life assurer cut costs and rebase its dividend.

In the latest example of the rush on Silicon Valley to grab talent and clients in the U.S. technology company center, Atlanta-based law firm King & Spalding is venturing into California, poaching at least eight attorneys from Perkins Coie's Silicon Valley office.

Tropicana Casino & Resort, which has been on the block since the New Jersey gaming commission stripped then-parent Columbia-Sussex of its operating license, is being sued by a major local bond trustee who blames its chief executive officer for losing the casino's gaming license.
Finding comfort in the little beige dresses and circle skirts of simpler times.

This has the ring of urban myth, but the number is so huge it seems worth repeating: API, the trade association for Spanish property agents, is reporting that 40,000 estate agents-half the estate agents in the country-closed down last year, in the wake of the slowdown in the market. As a result, it is believed that as many as 100,000 property agents lost their jobs last year.
When Eggie and Luis Perez’s home was destroyed by fire last fall, their after-school program stepped in to help.
California has long been viewed by presidential aspirants as a microcosm of the country, but its vastness and costs make campaigning difficult.
An audit by the city comptroller found widespread financial irregularities with record-keeping at the 79th Street Boat Basin in Manhattan.
How to shop, pack and dress as a creative fashion executive.
Images from the show at the Morgan Library & Museum.
Campaigns in both parties have come to the conclusion that working-class voters may be a key to victory on Tuesday.

After a second Kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on Thursday, riots exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge. In Limuru, 30 miles north of Nairobi, both ethnic Luos and Kikuyus coped with the aftermath of the continuing violence.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 31 column.

Atlanta's Ilya Kovalchuk left Wednesday night's game after a check by Penguins irritator Jarko Ruutu on a play for which Ruutu received a kneeing major. The play took place in the second period of a 4-1 Thrashers victory in Atlanta. Here are details from the Atlanta Constitution's account of the game, which describes the play as a knee-on-knee hit. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette described the game this way and said that Ruutu "checked Kovalchuk into the boards in front of the Atlanta bench." We'll post video as soon as it becomes available. ... And here it is:
Wednesday was heavy with media coverage of the Giants and Patriots as Super Bowl XLII approached.
A weekend in Cape Town narrated by Erik Olsen, taking in its history and natural beauty, from the historic Long Street all the way down to Cape Point.
A Canadian financier who traveled to Kazakhstan with Bill Clinton and won a big mining deal later donated millions to Mr. Clinton’s charitable foundation.
In a feat of optical alchemy, researchers have used ultrashort laser bursts to alter how metals absorb and reflect light, changing their appearance dramatically.
Electronic Arts swung to a loss because of restructuring charges and deferred revenue, but posted record revenue during the most brisk holiday season the video game industry has seen.
Google said that its profit jumped 17 percent in the fourth quarter, but the earnings fell short of analysts’ expectations, and the company’s shares fell after hours.
Battered by a downturn in the housing market, the company is laying off 500 workers at its headquarters in Atlanta, or about 10 percent of its work force there.

In a scathing report, Human Rights Watch blamed the U.S. and Europe for undermining human rights around the world by allowing autocrats to pretend they are democratic simply by holding rigged elections.
As numerous European banks assess whether to make a bid for Société Générale, regulators in Brussels warned France against any effort to thwart open competition.
This route on the L.I.R.R. doesn’t have the best reputation.
Sony said its profit rose in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games.
After an H.P. employee was raped and killed by a driver the company employed, India’s highest court may force international firms to do more to guard local workers’ safety.
Peter Staudhammer, a wide-ranging aerospace engineer and executive, helped design instruments and engines used by NASA in landings on Mars and the Moon.
Senator John McCain was endorsed by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger as Mitt Romney bought up advertising in California’s expensive media markets.
Democrats said they would have no choice but to adopt a less expensive stimulus package approved by the House.
Wall Street was sharply higher as investors shrugged off concerns about problems in the bond insurance industry.
Spending slowed in December and inflation continued to rise, leaving the Fed little leeway in the months ahead.
The electronic products maker said Thursday that its net income in the third quarter rose 25 percent to 200.2 billion yen ($1.9 billion).
A fund manager rattled investors by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.
A bond insurer struggling to maintain the top credit ratings necessary for its business, posted a quarterly loss  Thursday after huge writedowns.
The buzzer sounded, the ball clanged and the Knicks — drained, ill and foul-tempered — dragged themselves off the court and to the next city.
Seton Hall narrowly won the first round of the annual Big East battle of New Jersey and its fifth straight over all with an overtime victory over Rutgers.

Smoke filled the cockpit of an American Airlines flight from Puerto Rico on Wednesday, forcing an emergency landing, an airport official said. Seven people — the pilot, co-pilot, three flight attendants and two passengers — were taken to a hospital, but none of the injuries was life-threatening, The Palm Beach Post reported. The plane had left San Juan for Philadelphia and landed safely at Palm Beach International Airport, said Casandra Davis, an airport spokeswoman. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating.
The personal computer maker said it planned to sell its slumping cellphone unit so that it could focus on its personal computer business.
Montclair State University’s student government decided to temporarily restore financing that would allow the student newspaper to resume publication.
A police detective and his female companion kidnapped a runaway and forced her into prostitution with 20 men at private parties, the authorities said.
Michael Beasley scored 25 points and Bill Walker had 19 as Kansas State ended a 24-year home losing streak against its rival Kansas.

Brian Rolston, Marian Gaborik and Mikko Koivu scored less than two minutes apart in the second period, and the host Minnesota Wild beat the Anaheim Ducks, 5-1, on Wednesday night in the first game for both teams after the All-Star break.
The sophomore reserve Vernon Macklin scored a career-high 18 points and No. 6 Georgetown handed St. John’s its worst Big East loss, 74-42, on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

The truck maker Isuzu Motors said it would stop selling sport utility vehicles and pickups in North America in a year because of dwindling demand. Isuzu began selling S.U.V.’s in North America in the 1980s, and in 1999 its annual sales there topped 100,000 vehicles. Isuzu sold 7,000 vehicles last year in North America. In 2002, financial difficulties forced Isuzu to withdraw from a joint venture factory in Indiana with Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru vehicles, and instead sell S.U.V.’s built by General Motors.

E.On-Energie, the electrical unit of the energy giant E.On, was fined $56 million by the European Union for a broken seal that had been placed across an office door during an antitrust investigation. The European Commission said the broken seal meant E.On had the chance to remove documents after a raid in May 2006 — although it could not prove that the company had deliberately tampered with the seal or removed anything. E.On said it would appeal the fine. Regulators sealed the door to make sure no documents could be removed. When they returned the next day, signs of tampering showed that someone had removed the tape and tried to put it back, regulators said.

In a move that will make it the country’s largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be able to produce 550,000 barrels of oil a day when completed in 2012. The chief executive of Suncor, Richard L. George, said that with the new project, the company expects to generate a 15 percent return on investment at an oil price of $60 a barrel. The expansion will also allow Suncor to use an underground steam heating process rather than open-pit mining for about half of its tar sands oil production, which will reduce the effect on the environment.

The European Commission proposed simpler food labels highlighting fat, sugar and salt content in an effort to contain the spread of obesity and junk food. Under the proposals, six content elements will have to appear on packages: energy, total fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugar and salts. The labels will indicate what percentage of advisable daily intake they represent. “Consumers have to be able to make the right choice. They need the right information to plan their diet,” the health commissioner Markos Kyprianou, above, said. The proposals exclude beer, wine and spirits. They will now be taken up by the European Parliament and must be approved by member nations.

A sports article on Tuesday about the Giants’ arrival in Arizona for the Super Bowl misstated Coach Tom Coughlin’s history in the title game. This is his second Super Bowl appearance as a coach, not his first. (He was an assistant coach with the Giants when they won Super Bowl XXV in January 1991.).

Because of an editing error, a dance review in Weekend on Friday about New York City Ballet and the world premiere of “Oltremare” referred incorrectly to a dancer at one point. The dancer, Tiler Peck, is a woman.

The About New York column in some editions on Jan. 5, about a legal and public relations fight over allegations of short-selling between Institutional Credit Partners, a private investment bank with offices in Manhattan, and Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurance company, referred imprecisely to the bank’s charges against Fairfax. It claims that Fairfax operatives have a history of stealing garbage — which prompted bank executives to take “emergency measures” for protection — but it does not accuse Fairfax operatives of stealing garbage in this particular dispute.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a fellowship program intended to help art museum curators deal better with the business aspects of their jobs misstated part of the name of the institution where Eleanor Jones Harvey, who took part in the program, is chief curator. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum, not Gallery.

A headline on Wednesday with an article about efforts to block Southern Methodist University from housing the George W. Bush Presidential Library misstated an action of the library’s opponents. As the article noted, Methodists opposed to the library are lobbying members of a regional church conference to vote against the library; the opponents did not force the conference to hold that vote.

Because of an editing error, the On Religion column on Saturday, about “Lonely Man of Faith,” a film on Joseph Soloveitchik, the important 20th century Orthodox rabbi, referred incorrectly to its success rate at film festivals. Although it was turned down by the New York Jewish Film Festival, it did indeed appear at Jewish film festivals elsewhere; it was not turned down by all major Jewish festivals.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the difficulties facing the Federal Reserve misstated the federal funds rate after the Fed’s policy-making committee made a quarter-point cut in December. It was 4.25 percent, not 3.5 percent. (The Fed’s three-quarter-point cut last week reduced the rate to 3.5 percent.).

Because of an editing error, the On Religion column on Saturday, about “Lonely Man of Faith,” a film on Joseph Soloveitchik, the important 20th century Orthodox rabbi, referred incorrectly to its success rate at film festivals. Although it was turned down by the New York Jewish Film Festival, it did indeed appear at Jewish film festivals elsewhere; it was not turned down by all major Jewish festivals.

A report in the Slap Shot column on Sunday about the growing worth of Canadian N.H.L. franchises referred imprecisely to the interest of Alex Shnaider, a steel magnate, in buying the Toronto Maple Leafs and their properties. Although he is said to have expressed interest, and a price of $1.75 billion has been reported, Mr. Shnaider has not made such an offer.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about conservation planning in a warming world misstated the position of Healy Hamilton, who voiced concern about the future of protected areas. She is the director of the Center for Biodiversity Research and Information at the California Academy of Sciences; she is not the overall director of the academy.
LeBron James’s reverse layup with less than a second left Wednesday night gave Cleveland an 84-83 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers, the Cavaliers’ fifth straight road victory.
The departure of John Edwards and Rudolph W. Giuliani helped give focus to the contests in both parties.

A 78-year-old woman who was sexually assaulted in 1988 by Iorworth Hoare, a rapist who went on to win $14 million in the national lottery in 2004, is entitled to seek a share of his fortune, Britain’s highest court ruled. Courts had previously held that a claim for compensation in an assault case must be made within six years of the attack. Mr. Hoare, 53, spent 16 years in prison before buying the winning lottery ticket while on a day pass from prison. He was released in 2005 is said to live in a $1.4 million house near Newcastle.

The pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was allowed a rare respite from house arrest to meet with members of her party, the National League for Democracy. A party spokesman reported that she had criticized the series of meetings she has held since October with Aung Kyi, a senior junta official — they met for the fifth time after her meeting with party colleagues — for failing to set a deadline to achieve any real political change. She also cautioned the nation to “hope for the best but prepare for the worst,” the spokesman said.

Ao Man-long, the former transport and public works minister, became Macao’s highest-level official ever convicted of corruption and was sentenced to 27 years in prison. He was found guilty of takings tens of millions of dollars in kickbacks from developers in the casino resort construction boom that has allowed the former Portuguese colony, now a special administrative region of China, to overtake Las Vegas in gambling revenues.

Four Afghan road construction workers were discovered beheaded in Kamdesh, in northeastern Nuristan Province, the provincial governor said. The Interior Ministry confirmed the beheadings and said the men were kidnapped last week and a ransom had been demanded. It blamed the Taliban. The army recently mounted an operation in the Kamdesh area and killed a number of Taliban fighters, including a commander, the governor said, and he suggested that the beheadings were an act of revenge.

Doris Lessing, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature last year but was unable to attend the ceremony in Stockholm because of ill health, received her Nobel medal at a ceremony in London, where she lives. The frail-looking 88-year-old, wearing a long red velvet dress with her silver hair pulled back from her face, was typically irreverent at the Champagne reception in the main gallery of the Wallace Collection. “There isn’t anywhere to go from here, is there — unless, like some exemplars, recent ones, I could get a pat on the head from the pope,” she said in a short acceptance speech after being handed her prize by the Swedish ambassador. She did not say whom she was referring to, although Tony Blair, who she described in a recent interview as “a disaster for Britain,” had talks with the Pope Benedict XVI last year before his conversion to Catholicism.

Sign language interpreters in Thailand have run afoul of supporters among the governing party by holding their noses to refer to the new prime minister, Samak Sundaravej. Thai sign language interpreters often indicate prominent facial features as shorthand for dignitaries, and during a live broadcast of the parliamentary session on Monday that selected Mr. Samak, left, they held their noses between two fingers to refer to him. “It is not meant as a nose joke,” said one interpreter, Kanittha Rattanasin. “We have touched our noses for years to refer to Samak, but people noticed this time because we had to repeat the movement over 300 times.” Another interpreter, Juthamas Suthonwattanacharoen, said supporters of Mr. Samak, who is nicknamed Mr. Rose Apple Nose because many claim his nose resembles the long, Asian fruit, have called the National Association of the Deaf in Thailand to say the sign does not befit the country’s leader. For now, there are no plans to change it, she said.

The chief of the judiciary, Ayatollah Mahmoud Shahroudi, has ordered a halt to public executions unless they have his approval, his spokesman said. While those convicted of crimes like murder, drug smuggling and rape would still be hanged behind prison walls, the move appeared intended to lower the public profile of an increasing number of hangings in Iran. Ayatollah Shahroudi also barred the news media from showing or publishing television scenes or pictures of executions.

Snow brought Jerusalem and other cities around the Middle East to a grinding halt as icy weather conditions gripped the mainly desert region. Streets in Jerusalem were deserted during the morning rush hour, and classes were canceled. Snow blocked roads to the Jordanian capital, Amman, and schools, universities and banks in the kingdom were shut. Severe storms battered much of Lebanon, with torrential downpours and hailstorms hitting Beirut and heavy snow blocking roads in mountainous regions. In Syria, snow fell overnight on Damascus, and Syrian television reported the closing of secondary roads in the south.
The City Council has voted in favor of ending Madison Square Garden’s unusual tax deal with the city, which for 25 years has exempted the arena from property taxes.

A decision on whether to protect Alaska’s polar bears under the Endangered Species Act might not be made before the government opens a major bear habitat to oil leases next week, although staff recommendations are complete, the Fish and Wildlife Service chief, Dale Hall, said. Mr. Hall faced criticism at a Senate hearing from lawmakers who accused the Interior Department of stalling to make it easier for oil companies to obtain drilling leases in the Chukchi Sea, where a fifth of the Arctic’s polar bears depend on sea ice in their hunt for food. Another Interior Department agency, the Minerals Management Service, plans to open a large area of the Chukchi Sea to oil and gas leases on Wednesday. Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Environment and Natural Resources Committee, demanded “a commitment to take immediate action” to protect the bears.

Philadelphia’s new police commissioner promised to decrease gun violence in the city sharply by putting 200 more officers on the street, using “stop and frisk” searches in tough neighborhoods and installing 200 more surveillance cameras. The commissioner, Charles Ramsey, who spent eight years as police chief in Washington, set a goal of reducing killings by 25 percent this year, in large part by allocating more officers to the most violent neighborhoods. There were 392 killings in 2007 in Philadelphia, and 406 in 2006.
The Fed’s move on Wednesday was part of a one-two punch by Washington aimed at jolting the economy.

Detroit’s mayor emerged after nearly a week in seclusion and apologized to the city’s residents for having had an affair with his chief of staff and lying about it under oath. But the mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, said he would not step down. Mr. Kilpatrick was joined by his wife, Carlita. “I truly apologize to each and every one of you individually and to the whole city,” Mr. Kilpatrick said. Mr. Kilpatrick, 37, did not mention his former chief of staff, Christine Beatty, who quit her job Monday, nor did he address his potential exposure to perjury charges. The Wayne County prosecutor is investigating whether Mr. Kilpatrick or Ms. Beatty should be charged criminally.

A former autoworker from Cleveland who is accused of being a Nazi death camp guard lost another battle in his 30-year fight to maintain his American citizenship and residence. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit rejected a challenge from the man, John Demjanjuk, 87, above, to a final deportation order by the nation’s chief immigration judge. The order would send Mr. Demjanjuk to Germany, Poland or his native Ukraine. The government initially claimed Mr. Demjanjuk was the notoriously sadistic guard at the Treblinka camp known as Ivan the Terrible. Officials later concluded that he was not, but a judge ruled in 2002 that documents from World War II prove Mr. Demjanjuk was a Nazi guard.

The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee demanded that former Attorney General John Ashcroft testify about his appointment to oversee a Justice Department corporate settlement. The chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat, said Mr. Ashcroft had not returned calls inviting him to appear on Feb. 26 before a subcommittee that is reviewing the hiring of former government officials as corporate monitors. Mr. Ashcroft, who runs a consulting firm in Washington, is supervising a settlement between the government and Zimmer Holdings Inc., the world’s biggest maker of artificial hips and knees. For 18 months’ work, the company says it will pay him $28 million to $52 million.
The fine would settle a civil and criminal investigation into the company’s marketing of an antipsychotic drug.
The rest of the country may be transfixed by the presidential race, but in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s adopted hometown, people tend to be a little bit more blasé.
To ensure a good deal for the public, the new pay package should include an overdue tightening of the gift rules to bar corporate-sponsored junkets.
The task of reinforcing the regulatory apparatus of the nation’s economy is as formidable a challenge as managing the downturn.
Unfortunately for voters, a partisan standoff is preventing a new and vital election law from being implemented.
To a disturbing degree,  Attorney General Michael Mukasey has adopted his predecessor’s habit of saying precisely what the White House wanted to hear.
Concern over China’s use of surveillance technology  prompts new rules for U.S. exports.
The Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Street’s nerves on Wednesday, but a fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.
A federal judge threw out a crucial class-action lawsuit against the Army Corps of Engineers over flooding from a levee breach after Hurricane Katrina.
The Messenger spacecraft that zipped past Mercury two weeks ago found more evidence of the innermost planet’s turbulent past.
The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan named the former head of the ACE insurance company, Brian Duperreault, as its chief executive.
Fledgling charities are among the leading contenders for prizes in an experimental online fund-raising contest but more established nonprofit groups have struggled to attract support.
The jury in the trial of a Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter watched a surveillance video on Wednesday that prosecutors are hinting is crucial to their case.
Pending resolution of a potential radiator hose problem, the space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled for launching on Feb. 7 on a twice-delayed mission to the International Space Station.
The decision came as Starbucks reported anemic sales growth of 1 percent at stores open at least a year, the worst three-month performance in the company’s history.
The decision to keep Daniel Bouton at the helm of Société Générale baffled some people in the United States and Britain.
A man who shot a young police officer had recently been sent to a state mental institution, to be confined until he was no longer a danger to himself or others.

An article in the Itineraries section of Business Day on Tuesday reported on the increasing popularity of blogs written by or aimed at business travelers. The article reported that a directory of travel blogs that is known as BoardingArea.com, started by Randy Petersen, founder of the online forum FlyerTalk, would feature nine such blogs, including one by Joe Sharkey, who also writes the weekly business travel column On the Road for The New York Times. The article referred imprecisely to the terms of Mr. Sharkey’s participation. Mr. Petersen has offered a small payment to reprint Mr. Sharkey’s blog. While some of the blogs will seek advertising, referred to in the article as “sponsorships,” the one Mr. Sharkey writes is not among them, and he should have been asked what its relationship with BoardingArea.com was before the article was published.
The online retailer’s revenue was up 42 percent in its fourth quarter and its profits more than doubled, but its  profit margins were lower.
The text of a statement released after the Federal Open Market Committee decided to lower interest rates by half a percentage point.
A construction worker fell 12 stories to his death in Brooklyn when the scaffold he was standing on collapsed, apparently because of high winds.
Alliance Data Systems sued the Blackstone Group, seeking to force the private equity firm to complete its $6.4 billion buyout of the company.
The Energy Department canceled its main program for demonstrating how to use coal without adding to global warming, citing the program’s soaring costs.
Kellogg reported Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit dropped 3.3 percent, in part because of higher energy and costs, including for advertising. Its shares fell 51 cents, to $49.11.
Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey found himself caught in the debate that nearly derailed his confirmation last fall: whether waterboarding is torture.
Johnson, the N.B.A. legend and part owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, made the bold claim, but Isiah Thomas is not making such confident proclamations these days.
The damage to the cables knocked out Internet access to much of Egypt, disrupted the world’s back office in India and slowed down service for some Verizon customers.
Merck posted a $1.63 billion fourth-quarter loss on Wednesday as  charges for its Vioxx litigation settlement dragged down results and share prices.

New York’s Republican establishment rushed to embrace Senator John McCain, hoping that his appeal to independents could help fend off a Democratic sweep that might cost them the State Senate in November.
Few New Yorkers are surprised that Americans didn’t embrace former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his presidential bid.
A Writers Guild leader expressed wariness over modeling a deal on a new contract recently reached between production companies and the Directors Guild of America.
The owner of Lord & Taylor is close to buying the jewelry and housewares retailer in a $100 million deal.
Johan Santana finished last season poorly, which may raise some concerns as his contract is negotiated with the Mets.
Sunday’s game represents a bittersweet moment for Jeremy Shockey, who broke his leg against Washington in December, played most of the Giants’ games, only to miss the most important ones.

United Parcel Service Inc., the package delivery company, reported a quarterly loss on Wednesday because of a $6.1 billion pension-related charge. The company also forecast weak first-quarter earnings.
CHICAGO (AP) — Kraft Foods, the food and beverage maker, said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 6 percent, weighed down by record-high dairy prices.
Roger Clemens sidestepped a question about his coming appearance before a House committee investigating performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.
Federal authorities say that an antiquities dealer in California participated in the illegal importation and sale of antiquities.
Stuyvesant High School led the nation’s schools in finalists in the latest round of the Intel Science Talent Search, the country’s most celebrated high school science competition.
Run by three generations, a Yale institution has succumbed to the financial pressures of operating a restaurant in an increasingly gentrified college town.
The Altria Group said Wednesday that it would spin off its international tobacco business on March 28, freeing it to pursue cigarette sales more aggressively outside the United States.
The league frowns upon gambling on football, but close friends and founding fathers of the N.F.L., Art Rooney and Tim Mara were gamblers, and proud ones.
CHICAGO (AP) — Boeing reported a 4 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday, topping Wall Street’s expectations despite concerns over delays in the 787 Dreamliner.
North Dakota residents have (proudly) trailed the nation in large donations per capita to the presidential candidates, an analysis shows.
The Eastman Kodak Company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $215 million, a big increase from a year earlier.
A Fed rally on Wall Street abruptly fizzled Wednesday as excitement over an interest rate cut gave way to new  concerns about subprime mortgage woes.

The United States captain Paul Azinger is switching the Ryder Cup format with hopes of giving his team an edge, going back to alternate shot in the opening matches for the first time since 1999. The Ryder Cup will be played Sept. 19-21 at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Ky.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored two goals to lead Manchester United over visiting Portsmouth, 2-0, Wednesday and back into first place in the English Premier League. Manchester United (18-3-3) and Arsenal (17-1-6) each have 57 points; United leads on goal difference.

South Korea defeated Japan, 28-25, Wednesday in a replay of a qualifying match for the men’s handball tournament at the Beijing Olympics. The Asian qualifiers were initially held in September, when referees from Jordan and Iran were assigned at the last minute by the Asian Handball Federation to replace German referees.Their disputed calls helped Kuwait win the men’s tournament and Kazakhstan the women’s, qualifying them for the Olympics. In December, the International Handball Federation ordered replays of the qualifiers.The Asian federation has denied match fixing and has said it will punish countries taking part in the replays (Japan and South Korea). South Korea’s women’s team defeated Japan on Tuesday to advance to the Beijing Olympics.

The St. Louis Rams signed Al Saunders to a three-year contract as offensive coordinator, another step in an overhaul of the coaching staff after a three-win season. Saunders was fired by the Washington Redskins last Saturday after two seasons in the same job.

San Diego Chargers running back LaDainian Tomlinson withdrew from the Pro Bowl, paving the way for Baltimore Ravens running back Willis McGahee to make his first appearance in the game. McGahee earned a spot on the American Conference team because Tomlinson has a sprained knee.

Jordan Palmer signed a two-year deal with the Cincinnati Bengals on Wednesday that will give him a chance to play behind his brother, quarterback Carson Palmer, who was the No. 1 pick in the 2003 draft. Jordan Palmer, who is five years younger, set school records at Texas-El Paso by throwing for 11,084 yards and 88 touchdowns. Washington drafted him in the sixth round last year, but he was waived Sept. 1.

A former athletic manager for Hofstra University’s football team said in a federal discrimination lawsuit that players sexually harassed her repeatedly, including when an assistant played a sexually explicit film on a team bus. Lauren Summa, a 23-year-old graduate student, said that her complaints to coaches and university officials went unheeded, and that she was dropped from the team’s athletic staff after speaking out. PHOENIX -- While you wouldn’t exactly label metropolitan Phoenix as culture-drenched, there is at least a healthy handful of intriguing local attractions that you should ink into your itinerary if you’re out for the Super Bowl. Start with the Heard Museum on North Central Avenue, 10 minutes north of downtown Phoenix. Arguably the nation’s finest showcase for Native American culture, the Heard dishes out historical information and artistic works by Southwestern tribes such as the Apache, Hopi, Navajo and Zuni. Not to be missed are the lodging exhibits, which include a Navajo Hogan and an Apache wickiup. www.heard.org, 602-252-8848; admission, $10; open daily, 9:30 a.m.-5 p.m.
The bulls are rooting for Wall Street’s home team, the New York Giants. Or at least they should be if they believe football results influence the stock market.

Back in December 2004, Eli Manning had just taken over as the starting quarterback of the Giants, replacing Kurt Warner, a former most valuable player. Michael Lewis, a regular contributor to PLAY, profiled the elusive, private, and talented young quarterback for The New York Times Magazine, explaining how the team’s fortunes were tied to the youngest Manning:.

Even late into the regular season, Eli Manning’s erratic play prompted questions about whether he could take himself — and the Giants — to the next level. His game improved dramatically in the playoffs, which makes us wonder: Is Manning’s recent performance what we should we expect from him on Sunday and in the future, or just sudden and short-lived?.

Fellow football fans, let us acknowledge a truth: Much of the game is invisible and unknown to us in a way that our other sports passions are not. How did our our left offensive guard do? You know, the fat guy from Nebraska? No idea, unless he happened to pancake the middle linebacker a couple of times or draw serial flags for holding. That blown coverage coverage across the middle? Just for fun, let’s put that one on the nickel back lined up across from the slot. But really, we don’t know and we’re not meant to. Even the coach will say he has to check the film.

A film about the prisoner abuse scandal at the Abu Ghraib jail in Iraq will become the first documentary to enter the competition at the Berlin International Film Festival when it is shown next month, Agence France-Presse reported. Made by the Oscar-winning director Errol Morris (“The Fog of War”), above, the documentary, “Standard Operating Procedure,” uses film, re-enactments and photographs that were published around the world to shed light on the treatment of inmates. Twenty-one films will vie for awards during the 58th Berlin film festival, running Feb. 7-17.

The United States premiere of “Roman de Gare,” directed by Claude Lelouch (“A Man and a Woman”) and starring Dominique Pinon and Fanny Ardant, right, will open the 13th Rendezvous With French Cinema on Feb. 29 at the Walter Reade Theater. The movie, about a best-selling novelist whose plots bear similarities to the acts of a serial killer, will be one of 15 films shown at the Walter Reade and the IFC Center in Manhattan through March 9.

Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday, thanks to two popular shows, “American Idol” at 8 p.m. and “House” at 9. Those shows delivered 28.1 million and 22.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. A repeat of CBS’s “NCIS” at 8 attracted the night’s third-largest audience (11.7 million). CBS’s all-rerun lineup tied NBC for runner-up on the night, but NBC fared better among adults 18 to 49 with “The Biggest Loser” at 8 (8.3 million) followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (9.4 million). ABC finished fourth overall. On Monday President Bush’s final State of the Union address attracted the smallest audience of his two terms, 37.5 million viewers. That tally was 8 million fewer than a year ago, but 6 million more than President Clinton’s last State of the Union address in 2000. The speech was broadcast live at 9 p.m. on a total of nine network and cable channels.

Last week was another miserable one for music sales, but with one modest highlight: The indie-heavy “Juno” movie soundtrack rose one spot to the top of the Billboard chart, becoming the first album in Rhino Records’ three-decade history to reach No. 1. After the announcement of four Oscar nominations for “Juno,” including best picture, the soundtrack sold 65,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J), which moved 60,000, to No. 2. In the fourth straight week of very low sales, Natasha Bedingfield opened at No. 3 with 50,000 copies of “Pocketful of Sunshine” (Epic), Mary J. Blige’s “Growing Pains” (Geffen) sold 45,000 to reach No. 4, and Radiohead dropped one spot to No. 5 with “In Rainbows” (ATO), moving 35,000. Cat Power’s new “Jukebox” (Matador) reached No. 12 with 29,000 copies sold.

Sullivan as director of the National Portrait Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution, effective April 28, was announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sullivan, since 1999 the chief executive of the Historic St. Mary’s City Commission in Maryland, succeeds Marc Pachter, who retired on Jan. 25.

The Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, a winner of the Pritzker Prize for architecture, has been chosen to redesign the art displays in the State Hermitage Museum, right, in St. Petersburg, Russia, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Koolhaas and the museum will begin the six-year project by establishing a master plan for a new way of displaying about three million treasures in the museum’s roughly 2,000 rooms. He will also alter the displays in the Islamic and Chinese rooms and transform a section of the imperial general staff building into a space for contemporary art.

A three-judge panel in Mexico has ruled unanimously that Duane Chapman, known as Dog, right, who starred on the A&E television show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” cannot be extradited to that country to face criminal charges for seizing Andrew Luster, heir to the Max Factor cosmetics fortune, on a street in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chapman seized Mr. Luster in order to return him to the United States to serve a 124-year jail sentence for drugging and raping three women.

Viewers in Washington, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, among other big cities, moved a step closer on Wednesday to watching the simulcast of the Don Imus morning radio show on RFD-TV, a cable channel. Patrick Gottsch, the founder and president of RFD, which primarily chronicles life in rural America, said that he had signed an affiliation agreement with Comcast. With the agreement RFD-TV is authorized to begin negotiations with individual Comcast cable systems. Comcast is available in more than 24 million households. While RFD-TV is available in 30 million homes, many are in towns and small cities outside the Northeast; the exception are those that receive the channel via satellite. Jenni Moyer, a Comcast spokeswoman, confirmed the deal. In signing Mr. Imus last year after his firing by CBS Radio and MSNBC over a racial remark, Mr. Gottsch was hoping that Mr. Imus would become a lure for big-city cable operators. RFD is seeking a similar agreement with Time Warner Cable, which has systems in New York City and Los Angeles.

The Museum of Danish Cartoon Art in Copenhagen, part of the Royal Library of Denmark, is in discussions to buy the 12 caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad that ignited riots leading to 50 deaths around the world after they were published in a Danish newspaper in 2005, The Art Newspaper reported. “The caricatures have become a part of Danish history,” Jytte Kjaergaard, a spokeswoman for the Royal Library, said. Claus Seidel, one of the cartoonists and the chairman of a Danish cartoonists association, said, “We have generally agreed that we want a museum to have the works, but everyone still has to take a final decision for himself.”.

PETERSON--Vera Joseph, died peacefully Saturday, January 26, 2008, in Springfield, Massachusetts. She was 98. Born in a small village in St. Ann's Parish, Jamaica, WI, Dr. Joseph, as she was known professionally, came to the United States through Ellis Island in 1919. She attended George Washington High School in New York City and won a scholarship to Barnard. She was one of the first African-American graduates of Barnard College where she earned Phi Beta Kappa as a junior and graduated in 1932. Dr. Joseph earned her medical school degree at the College of Physicians & Surgeons at Columbia University graduating AOA in 1936. She subsequently did an internship at Harlem Hospital. In 1938, she married Dr. Jerome S. Peterson, also a graduate of Columbia University Physicians & Surgeons graduate of 1931. From 1940 to 1942, they lived in Puerto Rico where they managed several tuberculosis clinics. Returning to New York, Dr. Joseph was a physician and assistant to the director at the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Health Center. In 1950 the family moved to Beirut, Lebanon, where Dr. Joseph was an assistant professor of medicine at the American University of Beirut while her husband worked with the United Nations. The family relocated to Geneva, Switzerland, in 1953 when her husband accepted a position with the World Health Organization. In Geneva, Dr. Joseph was active with the Medical Women's International Association and served as its honorary secretary. She was a member of the Governing Board of the International School, and in 1958 became consultant to the European regional Office of WHO for the advisory group on public health and aging. The couple returned to the United States in 1964, settling in Amherst, Massachusetts. Dr. Joseph assumed a position with the Smith College Health Service, where she eventually rose to become Director. In 1974 she and her husband were co-recipients of the Ira Hiscock award for contributions in public health from the New England Public Health Association. She retired in 1975 from Smith College Health Service. Dr. Joseph served as a Trustee of the Jones Library and the Amherst Savings Bank, Board of Overseers of Williston-Northampton School and on the Health Services Advisory Council of the College of Physicians & Surgeons. Her husband died in 1987, and she founded the Vera Joseph/Jerome S. Peterson Fund for Minority Students at the College of Physicians & Surgeons to honor his memory. Dr. Joseph eventually moved from Amherst to Reeds Landing, a retirement community in Springfield. Vera Joseph Peterson is survived by three daughters; Jane Peterson of Seattle, Washington, Danna Peterson of Worcester, Massachusetts, and Carla Rosenbloom of Washington, D.C., four grandchildren; Claire Roberts of Spokane, Washington, Sarah Rosenbloom of New York City, Julia Rosenbloom of Philadelphia, and Philip Peterson of Worcester, and one greatgrandchild, Jacob Roberts of Spokane. A Memorial Mass will be held on Friday, February 1, at 11:00am in St. Brigid's Church in Amherst. Burial will follow in Wildwood Cemetery. Obituary and register at: douglassfuneral.com

To the Editor: ''Lessons of 1992,'' by Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 28), leaves the impression that there is no hope for change and that we are doomed to replay eternally the most partisan politics of the 1990s. This defeatist argument does a democracy no good, for it encourages apathy.

SIMPLE, pared-down furniture that takes inspiration from Shaker designs is now being produced by both small workshops and larger manufacturers. After all of the baroque curlicues and ornamentation seen in recent furniture, straight lines can offer a welcome change. ''The simplicity of the design fits into most décors,'' said Timothy Waite, a Burlington, Vt., craftsman, of the wooden pieces, which are made of light oak or maple, or of more exotic woods.

When Christie's announced last June that André Balazs, the New York hotelier, was the winning bidder in an auction for Maison Tropicale, the 1951 prefabricated house prototype by the French designer Jean Prouvé that was on view in Long Island City, the natural question was, What will he do with it? For now, Mr. Balazs is lending it for public view; beginning Tuesday, it can be seen outside the Tate Modern museum in London. One of only three such structures built by Prouvé for French colonial officers in Africa, the aluminum-paneled building, above, was originally installed in Brazzaville, the Congo Republic. Propped on stilts, it was intended for industrial manufacture as well as a tropical climate -- to which Mr. Balazs, who paid $4.97 million for the house, hopes to return it. ''The idea is it will eventually end up as the centerpiece of some sort of environmentally sound resort,'' said Mr. Balazs, who is planning to develop such a property in Central America. The house will be at the Tate Modern (011-44-20-7887-8888 or tate.org.uk) until April 13, in conjunction with a Prouvé exhibition at the Design Museum in London (011-44-870-833-9955 or designmuseum.org).

FED CUTS RATE AGAIN The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates for the second time in eight days, lowering the federal funds rate by half a percentage point and meeting Wall Street hopes for cheaper money. At the same time, Congress worked on a $160 billion economic stimulus plan. The economy expanded by a weak 0.6 percent annual rate in the last three months, the latest sign of a substantial slowdown, and perhaps a recession. [C4.]

The Steamboy Steam Floor Mop ($99) safely cleans all the floors in the house --stone, ceramic or sealed hardwood -- without chemicals, according to its manufacturer, Reliable. It begins to steam as soon as it is turned on and runs continuously for 30 minutes before it needs to be refilled with water. The machine has a swivel head that gets under appliances, furniture and into corners, and comes with a replaceable water filter. Information is at (866) 255-2726 or allbrands.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

ANTONOFF--Rubin. Beloved husband of the late Sarah Antonoff for 52 years, loving brother to the late Sarah ''Gypsy'' Platt, the late Bernard Antonoff and Sonny Antonoff, caring brother-in-law to Esther and Sima Antonoff, cherished father to Marla and Dr. Mark Novick and the late Linda Antonoff-Steinberger, adored and devoted stepgrandfather to Brett and Blake Novick, treasured uncle to his very special nephews and nieces, fun-loving confidante to his numerous cousins and loyal and caring friend to many. He retired as President and co-founder of B & R Amusement and IVCO Vending Corporation after 40 years. Ruby was truly admired for his contributions and integrity by various industry vending associations, distributors and customers throughout his successful career. He was a life-long benefactor and donor to a wide variety of charities. A man of incredible kindness and humility, we will miss his wonderful sense of humor and his ability to touch the human spirit. He was the ultimate role model for his children and step-grandchildren, who all adored him. His example of devotion, courage, honesty and love will be tenderly remembered and never forgotten among his family and friends. Donations in his memory may be made to the Weill Cornell Breast Cancer Genetics Program. In the memo portion donors should specify ''Antonoff Family Cancer Research Fund''. Checks can be mailed to: Weill Cornell Breast Center Att: Genetics, 425 East 61st Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10021.

Last week was another miserable one for music sales, but with one modest highlight: The indie-heavy ''Juno'' movie soundtrack rose one spot to the top of the Billboard chart, becoming the first album in Rhino Records' three-decade history to reach No. 1. After the announcement of four Oscar nominations for ''Juno,'' including best picture, the soundtrack sold 65,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Alicia Keys's ''As I Am'' (J), which moved 60,000, to No. 2. In the fourth straight week of very low sales, Natasha Bedingfield opened at No. 3 with 50,000 copies of ''Pocketful of Sunshine'' (Epic), Mary J. Blige's ''Growing Pains'' (Geffen) sold 45,000 to reach No. 4, and Radiohead dropped one spot to No. 5 with ''In Rainbows'' (ATO), moving 35,000. Cat Power's new ''Jukebox'' (Matador) reached No. 12 with 29,000 copies sold.

STRAUSS--Elliott MacGregor (Greg), 79, son of the late RADM Elliott B. Strauss and the late Lydia A. Foote, died suddenly Monday, January 28, 2008. He was a graduate of the Eaglebrook School, Choate School, Harvard College, and was a life-long resident of Paradise Avenue, Middletown. Husband, father, farmer, friend, accomplished horseman, and philanthropist, he was one of life's true gentlemen and will be missed by all who knew him. He was President of the Newport Reading Room, and on the Board of Directors of the Newport Historical Society, the Redwood Library and Athenaeum, and on the Board of Advisors of the Biltmore Company, Asheville, North Carolina. He was a member of the Union Club of New York, the Metropolitan Club of Washington, the Harvard Club of New York City, the Spouting Rock Beach Association, the Clambake Club of Newport, the Ida Lewis Yacht Club, and Quindecim. He is survived by his wife Luise, daughters Caroline Morris and Lydia Tower, sister Lydia Delaunay, brothers Armar and Christopher Strauss, nieces, nephews, cousins, and numerous godchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Newport Historical Society or the Redwood Library and Athenaeum. His funeral will be held Saturday, February 2, 2008, 11am at St. Columba's Chapel, Vaucluse Avenue, Middletown. Funeral services by O'Neill-Hayes Funeral Home.
He was too New York, too Italian, and he had too many wives. DOROTHY KALIADES, of Queens, on the problems with Rudolph W. Giuliani's presidential quest. [B4]

When Jean-Paul Viguier, a Paris architect, wants to woo clients, he does not show them detailed drawings. Instead, he creates tiny jewel-like models that represent ''the imagination of what the building is going to be,'' which he assembles in front of them. ''As the client watches what I am doing, little by little, I get into the concept of the project,'' Mr. Viguier said. ''If he loves it, he will never forget about it.'' Seven models, including the plexiglass and aluminum versions of the Sofitel Chicago Water Tower, top, and the proposed Franco-Chinese Centre for Education and Industry in Shanghai, above, will be part of an exhibition of his work, Feb. 4 to 29, at the French Embassy, 972 Fifth Avenue (78th Street), (212) 439-1417. ELAINE LOUIE

BLAUSTEIN--Gertrude (Bezansky), of New York City, NY, on Wednesday, January 30, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Norman Blaustein and Israel Perlstein. Devoted mother of Harriet Schick of Boston, MA, formerly of New York. Dear grandma of David J. Geltman and Paul L. Geltman, both of Boston, MA. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 2, at the Forsyth Chapel, Forest Hills Cemetery, Jamaica Plain, MA at 10:00am.

It's hard to consume news about celebrities these days without feeling dirty, but there's no scandal in ''Dressing the Home: The Private Spaces of Top Fashion Designers,'' a book by Marie Bariller (Abrams, $45). All of the participants, including Christian Louboutin and Catherine Malandrino, participated willingly. The lavish images, shot by Guillaume de Laubier, capture details of the interiors that reflect their owners' sensibilities: a close-up of tchotchkes in Agatha Ruiz de la Prada's Paris home, above right, shows the same joie de vivre as her children's clothing. Ms. Bariller's interviews leave much to be desired; she asked Diane von Furstenberg, If you were a piece of music, what would you be? The answer: ''Silence.'' But her choice of subjects and images is inspired. The French version of the book is already out; the American edition will be available in a few weeks. JULIE SCELFO

FINKELSTEIN--Dr. Leonard, 69, Former Rye Brook, NY resident died January 24, 2008, under the wonderful care of his family in the Jay Robert Lauer Hospice Center at JFK Hospital in Atlantis, FL. Dr. Finkelstein was born August 29, 1938, in NYC to Tillie and Sam Finkelstein. Leonard was a compassionate Doctor, world traveler, connoisseur of fine wine and fanatic fan of The New York Football Giants. He is survived by his wife Janet and three sons Lorin (Beth), Michael (Sonya), David (Debra) and grandchildren Eva, Oliver, Jed and Lilian.

THE Winter Antiques Show is a tidy, not to say sterile, affair, drawing rapt collectors turned out in equally immaculate style. Not so its Young Collectors' Night, sponsored by the design house Badgley Mischka. Young patrons filed into the Park Avenue Armory last Thursday night, a few subscribing reflexively to an uptown dress code. Some trotted out Audrey pumps, quilted bags and pearls, but many gave Park Avenue propriety a playful tweak. Leigh Wishner (top left) marked the occasion with a vintage ball-skirt, a multilayered confection of horsehair and tulle; Lief Anne Stiles (top right) took extravagance to extremes, wearing a J. Mendel coatdress with improbably plump fur sleeves.

The Conor McPherson drama ''The Seafarer'' will end its run at the Booth Theater on March 30 after 19 previews and 133 regular performances. ... ''Take Me Along,'' the musical based on the Eugene O'Neill comedy ''Ah, Wilderness!,'' will be presented by the Irish Repertory Theater beginning with previews on Feb. 20. Directed by Charlotte Moore, the show, with a book by Joseph Stein(''Fiddler on the Roof'') and Robert Russell and music and lyrics by Bob Merrill, opens on Feb. 28. ... Sullivan as director of the National Portrait Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution, effective April 28, was announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sullivan, since 1999 the chief executive of the Historic St. Mary's City Commission in Maryland, succeeds Marc Pachter, who retired on Jan. 25.

8 P.M. (ABC) LOST: PAST, PRESENT & FUTURE In preparation for Season 4, this hourlong special allows viewers to play catch-up by rehashing story lines affecting the passengers of Oceanic Flight 815. In the season premiere at 9, ''The Beginning of the End'' finds the survivors believing their rescue is imminent some 90 days after the plane crash but wondering whether there was anything to Charlie's final message that their liberators aren't who they seem. But then again, is anything on this series? 8 P.M. (CNN) PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE Democratic candidates discuss the issues at a forum in Los Angeles.

RUNNERS braving the cold have had to make do with gloves designed for other sports, like skiing or hiking or those meant for cold weather in general. But for the last few years, running-shoe makers have made running-specific gloves that warm the hands at the cold start of a run and adapt if the hands heat up a few miles later. Some of these gloves, generally thin instead of bulky (the better to stash in a pocket), feature rubber palm grips for better dexterity and soft areas on the thumb and forefinger designed for wiping wet noses.

The wake will be held on Friday, February 1, 2008, at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Global Table, a new collection from the interior designer Sheila Bridges, includes a cotton tablecloth with an appliquéd world map ($125), below; eight cotton napkins ($13 apiece), each hand-embroidered with a map of a different country and information on its government, population and currency; and a potholder shaped like the Earth ($10). ''Sheila designed it to show that we are one world,'' said Marsha Cutler, the director of design at Milli Home, the manufacturer. ''She felt very strongly that as people sat around dining room tables, the tablecloth would be provocative, and people could start to have a conversation about politics.'' Available in February at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street (Lenox Avenue), (212) 864-4500. Information: (212) 643-8850. ELAINE LOUIE

GOLDSTEIN--Kate... wife, mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother... died peacefully at home in Manhattan on January 27, 2008. Born in New York City on April 19, 1913, Kate's years were a passionate celebration of life. Bonding wit and compassion to courage and intelligence, she did not simply take the world as it is, but sought ceaselessly to make it a better place. She confronted both life and death with dignity and without fear. She will be remembered with love.

GREEN--Kate Connellan, 48, on January 27th peacefully asleep in her own apartment in Brooklyn Heights, daughter of Martha Manheim Green of Brooklyn Heights and Deer Isle, Maine and Walton Atwater Green of Sharon, Connecticut. A memorial gathering will be held at the Heights Casino this Saturday at 2:30pm.

TAYLOR--Marion G., 97, died Sunday, January 27, at her home in Essex, CT. She was born July 3, 1910, in Birmingham, Alabama, a daughter of Laznka Celeste Bridges and Dr. William Christopher Gewin. Surviving are her daughters Elizabeth T. Wall and Margaret T. Boyle, three grandsons, and a great-grandaughter. She was predeceased by her husband of 68 years, William R. Taylor, and another daughter Mary Gay Taylor of WCBS News Radio 88. She graduated from Smith College in 1931, having spent her junior year at the Sorbonne in Paris. She was both a competitor in and a judge for the American Daffodil Society. She specialized in miniature daffodils and won many awards. She was an accomplished golfer and was club champion at the Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, Vermont. There will be a memorial service at Essex Meadows, Hamilton Hall, on Sunday, February 17, at 4pm. Donations to The Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.

FULD--James J. To Elaine and the Fuld family, our deepest condolences. J.J was a wonderful husband, father and grandfather. Amy and Ron Finestone FULD--James J. A kind, gentle man who will be missed by all who knew him. Our condolences to his son Jimmy and the entire Fuld family. Judd and Wendy Meltzer and family FULD--James J. The Board of Governors and members on Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our Past President and esteemed member, James J. Fuld. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Elaine, children, Joan, Jim and Nancy, his grandchildren, Jonathan, Jennifer, Jamie, Michael, Ryan and David, and the entire family. Patricia Sumergrade, Pres. Richard J. Bronstein, Secrt'y FULD--James J. To a towering leader of the family, we will miss you. With love, Kathy, Jonny, Erica FULD--James J., passed away peacefully at home on January 29, 2008 just before his 92nd birthday. He lived a long and wonderful life sharing the past 65 years with his loving wife, Elaine. He will be immensely missed by his three loving children, Joan, Jim and Nancy, and their three spouses, Frank, Lisa and Dan, and by his six adoring grandchildren, Jonathan and his wife Elizabeth, Jennifer, Jamie, Michael, Ryan and David, whom he loved and with whom he shared his life interests. He was a man of great talent with a wide range of interests. His extraordinary music collection will become part of the Morgan Library. He authored the most widely respected book of first edition sheet music. A graduate of Harvard College where he was Co-Captain of the varsity tennis team and Harvard Law School where he was editor of the Law Review, he joined the Proskauer, Rose law firm where he worked until his retirement, serving as managing partner. He was a Director of the UJA-Federation of New York Joint Campaign and Chairman of the Distribution Committee and was active in many other philanthropic organizations. His family, his friends, and all who interacted with him will dearly miss him. Services Thursday, January 31, Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. FULD--James J. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of James J. Fuld, who held many leadership positions, including vice president, trustee, campaign director, and distribution committee chairman. James and his beloved wife, Elaine, past president of our Women's Campaign and board member of our thrift shop, strengthened UJA-Federation's ability to serve those in need and inspired their children with a profound commitment to caring. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elaine; their children Nancy Fuld Neff and her husband, Daniel; Joan Strauss and her husband, Frank; and James and his wife, Lisa; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Voters in New Jersey who cast absentee ballots for a candidate who has dropped out of the presidential race can vote again, a state judge has ruled. The ruling by the judge, Vincent J. Grasso of State Superior Court in Ocean County, dealt specifically with the Ocean County Clerk but has bearing statewide, according to the New Jersey attorney general’s office.

Updated, 5:27 p.m. | The notion that New York’s Jewish electorate could be easily characterized has long been debatable. But the looming primary election on Tuesday is raising new speculation about how strongly Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will appeal to Jewish Democrats.

Since the advent of the modern primary system in the 1970s, New York Republicans have largely avoided the fractious intraparty battles that have divided their Democratic Party counterparts in election years like 1976, 1980, 1984 and 1992. But the party did so in part by heavily favoring establishment candidates and making it hard for challengers to get on the ballot. In 1996 and 2000, the New York Republican leadership’s efforts to block party insurgents made its arcane rules the focus of national attention — and embarrassment.

With an eye toward the next campaign season in New York City when top offices will be up for election, Ray Rivera finds that donations from the real estate industry, traditionally a dependable source of campaign contributions, have soared to three and four times the rate of previous election cycles as part of an effort to beat strict new limits. The surge is driven in large part by a major overhaul in the city’s campaign finance law, which, starting this month, will cap contributions from people who do business with the city at less than a tenth of what is now permissible. That means many developers, brokers, landlords and contractors will be limited to giving $400 to a mayoral candidate, compared with $4,950 now.

Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx Borough president and mayoral candidate, dropped in to an East Side sports bar on Thursday night to kick off a Democratic debate-watching party organized by the Committee of Latinos for Hillary. The bar, Tonic East on Third Avenue in Murray Hill, was pumped with dance music and the raised voices of young professionals straining to chat. A mosaic of big-screen televisions flashed hockey and basketball games. But the high energy wasn’t for Hillary. Amid the regular Thursday night revelry, in a corner of a second-floor balcony, a small crowd of suit-clad Clinton supporters waited for the candidates to speak.

Lowen’s Pharmacy, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, closed early on Thursday evening for a wake for its owner, John Rossi. Mr. Rossi, whose store was under investigation in a wide-ranging steroid probe, was found dead in an office above the business on Monday with two apparently self-inflicted gunshot wounds. Bay Ridge has been buzzing about his death all week. The neighborhood, which stretches from 65th Street to 101st Street along Brooklyn’s eastern shoreline, is fairly big, geographically speaking. But, maybe because of its low-rise buildings and neat front yards, and maybe in part because it is hemmed in by expressways that clearly define its boundaries, Bay Ridge, where I went for this week’s Dispatches feature in the City section, can feel like a small town.

Alma Rangel, the wife of Representative Charles B. Rangel, has endorsed Barack Obama‘s presidential bid, Mr. Obama’s campaign announced today. Mr. Rangel, the dean of Harlem politics, is a leading supporter of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
