A federal appeals court ruled on Friday that a lower court was correct last year in tossing out a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project near Downtown Brooklyn. The decision, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, to uphold the dismissal of the suit was yet another blow to the plaintiffs in the case — more than a dozen property owners who stand to lose their homes and businesses under eminent domain as the project moves forward.

During the last five years, no movement has had as great an impact on progressive politics as the liberal blogosphere. Built from grassroots anger over Democratic leadership support for the Iraq war in 2002, liberal bloggers have chastised party leaders who backed President Bush, causing many prominent Democrats to reverse - and even recant - their positions on the war. Just as impressively, the blog voices on the left have played a critical role in pushing less visible issues -- like electronic voting machines, bankruptcy legislation and telephone companies' liability in wiretapping programs -- into the mainstream.

I want to be back in Africa, back in Ghana. Not here in Williamsburg, Va., trying to focus on the contours of probable cause with regard to the issuance of warrants and the definition of dependent relative revocation in Trusts and Estates law. Given the choice between my status quo reality and the next chapter of the African Cup of Nations...Fortunately, the rhythmic drum beats, songs and smiles of Ghanaians remain at the front of my consciousness after 10 sometimes hectic days in Accra, Kumasi and Sekondi. Even memories of long, hot bus trips, inhaling dust while walking along side roads and fighting through misinformation concerning transportation and tickets are fond memories. How I wish I were still there, especially with the drama of the quarter-finals, which start Sunday.

You've got to wonder what a guy like Kevin Tynan is thinking. Mr. Tynan is the former chairman of the Broward County Republicans, and on Monday, the day before the critical Florida primary, Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign sent out an e-mail trumpeting his endorsement. "Florida needs Rudy and I'm proud to support him," Mr. Tynan said in his statement, at a moment when it was pretty clear to just about everyone that it was actually Rudy who needed Florida and that he wasn't going to get it. The deathwatch on the Reddy Ice deal ended Thursday. In anticipation of the Feb. 5 termination date on its deal, Reddy Ice, a maker of packaged ice, announced that it had agreed to terminate its agreement to be acquired by affiliates of GSO Capital Partners. In connection with the termination, GSO agreed to pay Reddy Ice $21 million in cash on Feb. 5 -- the self-same termination date. In addition, Reddy Ice agreed to pay up to $4 million of fees and expenses incurred by GSO and its consultants in connection with the failed transaction.

Travel editors get bombarded with glossy imagery every day. No matter the destination - from Qatar to the Caribbean - there's some attendant glamor shot of a zero-edge pool or a honeymooning couple kicking at shells on the beach at dusk. It's mind numbing. Then the other day a book passed our desk called South Africa, by a new publishing venture called Well Souled. The volume is a hefty and, yes, glossy 312 pages: images of the country's people, landscape, architecture, food, fashion, iconography. The founder and editor Mital Shah, a 31-year-old former executive at Vera Wang, says she came across all her subjects solely through word of mouth. "I didn't cast a wide net. I just let one person lead to the next. And I tried to meet everyone, but I didn't try to cover everything." (To document her far-flung network, there's a "map" of her contacts at the end of the book.) The result is a seductive but not synthetic portrait of a place; we encounter musicians, athletes, and designers, along with children orphaned by AIDS, ordinary citizens, and pinup girls from the pages of 1950s Drum magazine. "I wanted this project to be about being well-traveled but always being soulful about how you travel," says Shah, who will release books on more countries and who has plans to apply the concept to other media, along with fashion and home design. "We want to offer luxury and culture at the same time - and always be giving back." To put its money where its passport is Well Souled will give 20 percent of the sales of South Africa to organizations that help AIDS orphans; the same percentage from a book about India will go toward rural education. "It's a big number, but we wanted to put that stake in the ground." We're feeling that. To order a copy, go to www.wellsouled.com.

Federal mine-safety regulators said they approved the first wireless tracking system to locate miners trapped underground. The Mine Safety and Health Administration said the technology was developed by Venture Design Services Inc., based in Liberty Lake, Wash., a subsidiary of the Venture Corporation of Singapore. After deadly mine explosions in 2006, Congress passed legislation that year requiring that mine operators adopt wireless communications and electronic tracking systems by June 2009. A January 2006 explosion in West Virginia killed 12 men. In May of that year, five men died in an explosion in a Kentucky mine. In August, nine people died in two cave-ins in Utah.

A man was sentenced to life in prison, with possibility of parole in 30 years, after pleading guilty to murder in the beating-death of a young woman hiking in the north Georgia mountains. District Attorney Lee Darragh of Dawson County said the murder resulted from a plan by the man, Gary M. Hilton, 61, above, to abduct the woman, Meredith Emerson, 24, in order to steal money using her A.T.M. cards. But Ms. Emerson, whose body was found Jan. 7 near Dawsonville, misled Mr. Hilton, giving him false numbers with the hope that the authorities would be alerted to efforts to gain access to her account, Mr. Darragh said. Mr. Hilton was indicted on one murder count.

Two Egyptian college students arrested near a Navy weapons station in South Carolina last year were carrying low-grade fireworks, as they claimed, not explosives as charged by federal prosecutors, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined. The men, Ahmed Abdellatif Sherif Mohamed, 26, and Youssef Samir Megahed, 21, engineering students at the University of South Florida, were indicted by a Tampa grand jury on charges of transporting explosives. The F.B.I. report was submitted to the court Wednesday by Mr. Megahed’s lawyer as part of a motion seeking bail. It said the items in the car — PVC pipe containing a mixture of sugar, potassium nitrate and cat litter — were ingredients for a “pyrotechnic mixture” that burned but did not explode. Mr. Megahed is a permanent resident of the United States; Mr. Mohamed was on a student visa.

A federal judge in Portland has postponed for a second time a deadline for a plan that meets his standards for balancing operations of Columbia River Basin dams with threatened or endangered fish runs. At a December hearing the judge, James A. Redden of Federal District Court, moved the deadline for a third biological opinion to March 18 from March 1 but threatened unspecified consequences if he rejected it. On Tuesday he extended it to May 5, said Brian Gorman, spokesman for the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration Fisheries in Seattle. Judge Redden has thrown out two opinions as inadequate and wrote in December that a draft of a third effort looked little better.

The pilots of two small planes did not move to avoid each other before colliding last week near Los Angeles, killing five people, investigators said. A preliminary report by the National Transportation Safety Board said a witness saw the planes cruising toward each other for at least five seconds without taking an evasive maneuver. The collision occurred about a mile south of Corona Municipal Airport, which does not have a manned control tower. The report said that a Cessna 150 was headed east on approach to the airport and that a Cessna 172 was traveling north. It did not blame either pilot. The collision on Jan. 20 killed two people in each plane and a person on the ground. A final report is expected by the end of the year.

Jeb Stuart Magruder, left, a Watergate conspirator, pleaded guilty to a traffic charge stemming from two crashes last summer in Columbus that happened as he had a stroke while at the wheel. Mr. Magruder had been charged with failing to maintain proper distance and leaving the scene of an accident, but pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of reckless operation. He was fined $300, placed on a year’s probation and lost his license for a year. He says he has no recollection of the crashes. Mr. Magruder was President Richard M. Nixon’s deputy campaign director, an aide to H. R. Haldeman and deputy communications director at the White House. He spent seven months in prison for his role in covering up the 1972 Watergate break-in.

Britney Spears, with a police escort of nearly a dozen motorcycles, two cruisers and two helicopters, was removed by ambulance from her home and taken to U.C.L.A. Medical Center, right, early on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Spears, 26, whose erratic behavior has made her a public spectacle and cost her the custody of her two young sons, was hospitalized to “get help,” said a Los Angeles police officer who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the matter. Allan Parachini, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Superior Court, said: “The way it works is a law enforcement agency or mental health professional can conclude that someone is a danger to self or others and undertake an involuntary commitment. To extend that for another 14 days there has to be a court hearing.” On Jan. 3, when Ms. Spears refused to return her children to her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, who has custody, the police had paramedics take her from her home to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where she was released after a day and a half.

DEEP IN THE SHED: A BLUES SUITE When the pianist Marcus Roberts recorded ''Deep in the Shed,'' his second album, at the close of the 1980s, he was best known as a sideman with Wynton Marsalis. In some ways the album seemed a natural outgrowth of the Marsalis credo. It was an earnest and self-conscious meditation on the blues, composed and loosely organized in suite form. Implicit in the music was an assertion that the blues is serious business, better understood as a feeling than as a form. And though he was trafficking in traditions, Mr. Roberts, then in his late 20s, made the argument feel contemporary as well as personal. (He had learned a lot from Mr. Marsalis, who appeared pseudonymously on the album.) These days ''Deep in the Shed,'' originally released on RCA, is out of print and unavailable on iTunes or other online services. And Mr. Roberts, above, is largely associated with a more historical approach to his craft. In the mid-'90s he released ''Portraits in Blue'' (Sony Classical), an interpretive orchestral reading of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' His efforts over the last decade have followed a similar course; he has probably been heard by more symphony and Pops subscribers than dedicated jazz fans. This isn't true of his old boss, now the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center.

'DOUBLE FEATURE' When the Tony Award-winning director and choreographer Susan Stroman returned to the New York City Ballet to whip her 2004 work ''Double Feature'' into shape for this season, there were many familiar faces at rehearsals, including those of the lead men Damian Woetzel and Tom Gold, who are reprising their roles in this two-act homage to silent movies. But the shimmering soloist Tiler Peck, still at the School of American Ballet when ''Double Feature'' had its premiere, was familiar from a far different relationship. Ms. Peck, something of a Broadway baby, played Gracie Shinn in ''The Music Man,'' which Ms. Stroman directed and choreographed in 2000. Now she will dance the lead role in the second-act ballet, ''Makin' Whoopee,'' opposite Mr. Gold as a Buster Keaton-type character (right). Alexandra Ansanelli, now a principal at the Royal Ballet, originated the role, but Ms. Peck is perfect for it, Ms. Stroman said. ''She learned the choreography so quickly that she has time to feel the character,'' she said, adding that ''I remember her being quick to learn.'' Ms. Stroman had no idea that Ms. Peck was classically trained during ''The Music Man.'' Seeing her ''now as a ballet star was actually emotional,'' she said. While Ms. Peck's star is rising, Mr. Woetzel, who stars in the first-act ballet, ''The Blue Necklace,'' is retiring this spring. Ms. Stroman, like many others, said she will miss this wonderfully nuanced principal dancer. But she also has plans for him.

A group of drug-testing and medication experts Thursday endorsed a Dec. 31 deadline for nationwide adoption of rules regulating anabolic steroids in racehorses. The Racing Medication and Testing Consortium and Racing Commissioners International are calling for the regulation of four androgenic anabolic steroids and a ban on any other anabolic steroids in racehorses.The four steroids -- stanozolol, boldenone, nandrolone and testosterone -- can be regulated through blood and urine testing. Nandrolone and boldenone are naturally occurring in ungelded males, and testosterone occurs in all horses. All four steroids are permitted for use in horses by the Food and Drug Administration.

ZIMMERMAN--Veva H., M.D. The faculty, staff and students of NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Veva H. Zimmerman, M.D. Dr. Zimmerman, a graduate of Tufts Medical School, served as Special Advisor to the Dean on Minority Affairs at NYU School of Medicine in 1975 and later became a tenured Associate Professor of Psychiatry and Associate Dean for Student Affairs. She remained at NYU until her retirement as Professor of Psychiatry in 2002. Her tireless efforts on behalf of minority students lead to the creationin collaboration with the NYC Department of Education-of the Salk School of Science, a unique Manhattan middle school. She will be fondly remembered for her warmth, generosity, dedication, and compassion. Dr. Zimmerman is survived by her husband David, two sons and two grandsons. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Zimmerman family. Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean Steven B. Abramson, M.D. Vice Dean

ATANASIO--Joseph F., M.D., on January 31, 2008. Passed away at home after a lengthy illness at the age of 93. Dr. Joe, as he was fondly known by his patients who numbered in the thousands, was a highly respected and renowned physician in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn for over 50 years. In WWII, Dr. Joe served as a physician, attaining the rank of Major, in the 106th Evacuation Hospital which was a part of Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army. In 1994, Dr. Joe was a recipient of the Normande Liberte, a special medal issued by the French government to honor all U.S. servicemen who supported the D-Day invasion. Dr. Joe was predeceased by his wife Margaret (nee McAloon). He is survived by his children Peggy Colucci (Bill), Kathe Hanna (Tom), Joseph, M.D. (Miriam, M.D.), Paul, Robert (Kathy), Regina DiGiovanna, M.D. (Lawrence), Patricia Griffith (Perry), Donna Andrea (Tim), and Clare. Dear brother of Peter Atanasio and the late Marie Leonard. He is also survived by 24 grandchildren and 19 greatgrandchildren. Visiting Saturday 2-4 and 7-9pm and Sunday 2-6pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Monday, 10:30am at Our Lady of Angels Church. LEVINSON--Barbara S., 81, died on Wednesday, January 20, 2008 at her home in Palm Beach, Florida. Barbara was a woman of intelligence, passion, creativity and style. She was widely appreciated for her many institutional involvements and contributions, including the Weizmann Institute of Science, which she and her family have supported for over 60 years, the New School University, UJA-Federation, the Israel Museum, the Jewish Museum and Grace Cottage Hospital in Townshend, VT. Barbara attended the University of Chicago and Boston University. She shared a wonderful life for over 30 years with her husband Morris, until his death in 1993. Barbara is survived by their children and spouses, her beloved son John (who predeceased her), Nancy Machinist, Judith Levinson Oppenheimer (John Oppenheimer), Robert B. Machinist (Diane Nabatoff), Joshua Levinson (Shoshana), Adam Levinson (Kimberly), and twelve grandchildren: David and Michael Machinist; Solomon and Abraham Silber; Eve Levinson. Funeral services on Sunday, February 3rd, 1:45pm, Temple Israel, 1901 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL. The family will be receiving on Sunday after the interment at 318 N. Woods Road, Palm Beach, FL, and on Tuesday, February 5th, 5-8pm at the Oppenheimer home, 1095 Park Ave. New York, NY. LEVINSON--Barbara. It is with great sadness that the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of our dear friend and treasured leader, Barbara Levinson, a member of the Board of Governors of the Weizmann Institute and of the Board of Directors of the American Committee, and a longstanding and passionate supporter. Barbara's vision guided the Institute as it opened its doors to the general public and communicated its message to the world. Her deep appreciation of the Institute's scientific work culminated in the establishment of the Barbara and Morris Levinson Visitors Center, the first stop for guests at the beautiful Rehovot, Israel, campus. Together with her late husband Morris, Chairman Emeritus of the American Committee and former Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Institute, Barbara gave her time and energy, helping establish the American Committee as one of the most effective philanthropies supporting science research. A member of the American Committee President's Circle, Barbara credited her father, Lou Salvage, for her early interest in the Weizmann Institute. She passed on her enthusiasm to her own family, including her son, Robert Machinist, who served as Chairman of the American Committee. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Levinson family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. We will miss Barbara greatly, but her guiding presence in the Weizmann Institute family will always be felt. Lawrence S. Blumberg Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman President Weizmann Institute LEVINSON--Barbara. The board of directors and management of Deerfield Capital Corp. and managers of Trian Management record with sorrow the passing of the mother of our esteemed board member of Deerfield Capital Corp., Robert Machinist. Our thoughts and best wishes are extended to Bob and his entire family. LEVINSON--Barbara S. To the Levinson and Machinist family: Barbara was one of a kind and will be missed! Amy & Hal Kaplan Eckman

An unlicensed fireworks factory in Istanbul exploded accidentally, leaving at least 22 people dead and at least 100 injured, Turkish officials said. The building that housed the unlicensed factory, in Davutpasa, an industrial neighborhood, partly collapsed. Muammer Guler, the governor of Istanbul, said the initial blast might have ignited a second explosion in one of the boilers on the building's lower floors.

INTRODUCING BERT WILLIAMS Here's to movies and records! Without them the vaudeville comedian Bert Williams would have a secure place in theater history, but he would be present to us only through the rapturous descriptions of critics and contemporaries like W. C. Fields, who called him ''the funniest man I ever saw and the saddest man I ever knew.'' Williams (1874-1922), above, is generally considered America's first black star. He broke vaudeville's color line and recorded hit after hit for Columbia, though he made only a few movies. Two Biograph shorts from 1916 -- ''Fish,'' a dramatization of one of his comic stories, and ''Gambler,'' which ends with one of his famous vaudeville bits (a wonderful pantomimed poker game) -- are basically it. But if you haven't seen them, get yourself to the Museum of Modern Art, which is showing new 35-millimeter prints on Saturday, along with a special treat: unedited footage from a mysterious romantic comedy featuring Williams. (Steven Higgins, the MoMA curator organizing the show, said not much was known about this film, from who made it to whether it was released.)

'MEDIEVAL CHILDREN' Childhood in the Middle Ages tended to be short. If calamity didn't end it (remember the Black Death?), adult responsibilities often did. At a stage when many contemporary little ones are still working on their A B C's, some medieval children were mastering difficult Latin texts. ''Can you imagine memorizing all the psalms in Latin by age 5?'' asked Lauren Mancia, a lecturer at the Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum. That was the lot of oblates, children whose parents gave them to monasteries, where they were raised to follow a religious life.

Jon Tenuta, the defensive coordinator at Georgia Tech the past six seasons, joined Notre Dame's staff Thursday as assistant head coach for defense. Tenuta will work with the defensive coordinator Corwin Brown to try to improve a Notre Dame unit that finished 39th in the nation in total defense, giving up 357 yards a game.

A SNOWSHOE race is a heart-pounding, high-intensity experience bearing little resemblance to the traditional snowshoer's nature hike. Some races are grueling events for top athletes: In Vermont, the Pittsfield Snowshoe Marathon on March 8 (www.peak.com/snowshoe.html), for example, involves 7,200 feet in elevation changes over 26 miles. These races can bring their winners significant cash. At the Jeremy Wright North American Snowshoe Championships, in Beaver Creek, Colo., Feb. 10 (www.bcsnowshoe.com), there is $5,000 in prize money, with the men and women's 10-kilometer-race winners getting $1,200 each.

LUNAR NEW YEAR CELEBRATION With the new moon next week, the city is gearing up for Lunar New Year, celebrated by the Chinese, the Koreans, the Vietnamese and all those who appreciate this joyous holiday devoted to defeating evil spirits and cultivating good luck. Recognizing the symbolic role of plants and flowers in these festivities, which herald the coming of spring, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is offering a family celebration on Sunday highlighting horticultural gems, along with an art show and performances that demonstrate rich cultural traditions. ''A holiday observed with plants is commensurate with our mission as an urban botanic garden,'' said Scot Medbury, the garden's president, who brought the Lunar New Year celebration with him when he arrived in 2005 from the San Francisco Botanical Garden. Visitors wishing to deck their homes will be treated to a vast flower market at Prospect Heights High School, across the street, featuring buckets of fresh-cut flowers and blooming quince branches, as well as potted plants. (Those in the citrus family guarantee good fortune and wealth.)

'COLLAGE: THE UNMONUMENTAL PICTURE' ''Unmonumental: The Object in the 21st Century,'' the inaugural exhibition at the new New Museum of Contemporary Art, seems to be widely, and unfairly, unloved. But the addition of its second phase, ''Collage,'' with works by 11 more artists, to the museum's previously bare walls may change a few minds. It certainly warms up the galleries. The works affirm the show's focus on artists who work by hand, usually with salvaged materials, to make explicitly mongrel artworks that don't need electricity. Several of the collages aren't so unmonumental at all: Thomas Hirshhorn's vehement ''Tattoo Series'' climbs the wall, linking violence, pornography and tattooing in a scary mélange of bodies, drawings and ideological symbols. Wangechi Mutu has turned one long wall and part of the floor into an immense desert landscape, with a possibly environmental subtext, overseen by a bulbous, found-object moon. Mark Bradford has contributed a mural-size circulation system (map? skin? ant tunnels?) layered with eroded posters (above, on large wall).

The lawyer for an Australian resident who had been a suspect in connection with the bungled bombings in London and Glasgow last June will not be subject to any disciplinary action for leaking the transcript of the police interview with his client, a state agency reviewing the matter said on Friday. While the lawyer, Stephen Keim of Queensland, was guilty of a technical violation of rules governing lawyers, by making public a document that had not been submitted to the court, his action was justified by the ''exceptional circumstances'' of the case, the state agency, the Queensland Legal Services Commission, said. The commission also said it was ''in the public interest'' to dismiss the complaints against Mr. Keim.
Correction Appended HANNAH MONTANA

HACKENSACK, N.J. — It was Groundhog Day today, when Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, returned to New Jersey. Like the famous weather-caster, sporting a similar mane of silvery hair, Mr. Warner said his piece and made a hasty retreat. But instead of his shadow, Mr. Warner, who stumped for Senator John McCain at a Bergen County Republican forum here, saw a sea of Ron Paul supporters.

WESTBURY, N.Y. — The war in Iraq remains highly unpopular among Americans, even as evidence suggests that the “surge” in American forces has helped to improve stability and decrease political violence. So it was notable that former Senator Alfonse M. D’Amato invoked the war today in urging his fellow New York Republicans to support the candidacy of Senator John McCain for the White House.

Updated, 7:37 p.m. | For all the rhetoric of national unity and bipartisanship, presidential political strategy is still centered around coalitions of various constituencies: labor, religious groups, youth, retirees, African Americans, Latinos — and women. Women, African Americans and Hispanics are among the most strategically important and closely scrutinized demographic groups in a campaign where two historic first candidates are going head to head, especially in a city where blacks comprise one quarter of the population and women make up 60 percent of registered Democrats.

Lowey, a Democrat who represents parts of Westchester and Rockland Counties, collapsed this afternoon during a campaign rally for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in White Plains, according to witnesses. Ms. Lowey, who was conscious and joked that she “got too excited,” was taken to a hospital as a precaution, and the rally continued with remarks by the headline speaker, Madeleine K. Albright, the former secretary of state.

Updated, 11:38 p.m. | There was an awkward moment on Wednesday when former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was abandoning his presidential bid and endorsing Senator John McCain of Arizona, told Mr. McCain: “I’m going to campaign with John McCain as much as he wants — or not, depending on if I’m in trouble or not at that particular point.” Mr. McCain smiled, uncomfortably. Evidently the McCain campaign has concluded that Mr. Giuliani is more of an asset than a liability, if their frequent joint appearances are any indication.Now comes word that the former mayor is heading home to help his ally. Mr. McCain told reporters in Birmingham, Ala., today that Mr. Giuliani will be campaigning with him on Monday and Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. McCain is scheduled to speak at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., at 1 p.m. on Sunday.

More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Feb. 2:

One thing I've written about a number of times, but becomes especially worth emphasizing now that John McCain is the presumptive Republican nominee, is the myth of runaway federal spending under the Bush administration. McCain has said on a number of occasions that he doesn't know much about economics -- although, straight-talker that he is, he has also denied having ever said such a thing. But one thing he thinks he knows is that the Bush administration has been spending like a drunken sailor. Has it?
Okay, maybe I've been skeptical about some of the alarms over global warming. Mea culpa, mea culpa. Now I'm truly frightened.

The premiere of the fourth season of "Lost" delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season's debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series's complicated back story (13.1 million).
An avalanche of coverage drives us into the weekend and on to what many are calling Tsunami Tuesday.
Will Leitch is the editor of Deadspin.com and a frequent contributor to Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine. His latest book, "God Save the Fan," was released last week.

ACCRA, Ghana - Manucho, the young Angolan striker, is quickly earning his celebrated one-name status. During the group stage here at the 2008 Africa Cup of Nations, he terrorized opposing defenses, scored three goals and silenced anyone who doubted Sir Alex Ferguson's decision to sign him to a three-year deal at Manchester United. (He'll first be on loan in Greece.)
SAN FRANCISCO - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's big fund-raiser here got off to a great start on Friday night. And then, well, the air went a bit out of the balloon.

Where very, very large men prepare to be Giants.

Regal luxury is a concept foreign to New York’s financially troubled early-music world. But the Clarion Music Society and its artistic director, Steven Fox, made a decent show of it at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday.
Underachieving even by the standards of stoner comedies, “Strange Wilderness” is so inert that it doesn’t so much unreel on screen as loiter there.
“The Eye” is the latest Western deconstruction of a successful Asian horror movie and it is louder and more literal than its inspiration.
The authorities were seeking a man they say shot five people inside a strip mall clothing store in Tinley Park, Ill.
Informal talks have eliminated the major roadblocks to a new contract, people briefed on the situation said.
The presidential nominating fight carried the intensity normally reserved for the closing days of a general election.
Hamas said that it would cooperate with Egypt to close the breached border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip on Sunday.
There were reports of 1,000 to 1,500 rebels in Ndjamena and gun battles around the presidential palace.
Playing against his former team for the first time, Zach Randolph had 25 points and 13 rebounds, but he also committed two costly turnovers in a overtime loss.
Richard Jefferson scored 25 points, Josh Boone added 15 and the Nets snapped a seven-game road losing streak Friday night by defeating the Miami Heat, 94-85.
Playing bitter division rivals on back-to-back nights, the Rangers may have given their up-and-down season a major jolt Friday night with a 3-1 victory over the Devils at Prudential Center.
Bernard Lagat ratcheted up the pace two laps from the finish, spurred on by the crowd of 12,647 at Madison Square Garden, to win the meet’s marquee event in 3 minutes 57.51 seconds.
There is little Zach Randolph can do now, short of realigning the stars, space and time, to validate the trade that sent him to New York last June.
Connecticut guard Doug Wiggins has been reinstated to the team, but the starting guard Jerome Dyson is still suspended indefinitely, Coach Jim Calhoun said Friday.

Tiger Woods managed it all — the wind blowing, the sand swirling and the photographers clicking.He shot a one-under-par 71 Friday, making birdies on two of the last three holes, for a one-stroke lead halfway through the Dubai Desert Classic. Woods was at eight-under 136. He also won in Dubai in 2006. Damien McGrane, who is ranked 319th and has never won as a professional, shot a 69 and was a stroke behind. He will be paired with Woods in the third round Saturday at Emirates Golf Club.Wind gusts reaching 30 miles an hour shook the bunkers and desert terrain. Sand flew in faces and created a haze masking many of the skyscrapers usually seen towering over the course. Woods wore sunglasses but said he was still “chewing sand all day.”The defending champion, Henrik Stenson of Sweden, shot a 70 and was two strokes behind. He shared third place with Thomas Levet of France, who had a 71.

South Carolina’s board of trustees approved a tax-deferred retirement package Friday for the football coach Steve Spurrier that would pay him $1 million if he remained with the Gamecocks for the next four seasons. Spurrier makes about $1.75 million a year.

The free agent Sean Casey reached a preliminary agreement on a one-year, $800,000 contract with the Boston Red Sox, giving them an experienced backup at first base to Kevin Youkilis. Casey hit .296 with four homers for the Detroit Tigers last season.

Third baseman Casey Blake avoided arbitration by agreeing to a one-year, $6.1 million contract with the Cleveland Indians. Blake, who can become a free agent after this season, hit .270 with 18 home runs last season.

Rich Rodriguez’s lawyers argued Friday that opening the financial records of West Virginia University’s private fund-raising arm is the only way to determine if his abrupt resignation as coach had harmed the university financially. The filing, part of an official response Friday to the university’s lawsuit, largely restated arguments that Rodriguez’s lawyers had previously made in response to the lawsuit over a $4 million buyout clause in his contract. Rodriguez asked the court to make the fund-raising group, the WVU Foundation, a third party to the lawsuit.

J. B. Holmes shot a six-under-par 65 to share the clubhouse lead with Doug LaBelle II at nine-under 133 among the players who finished the second round Friday at the FBR Open in Scottsdale, Ariz. LaBelle shot a 64. A 90-minute frost delay to start the day left 45 golfers on the course when play was halted because of darkness.One of them, Camilo Villegas, was tied for the lead at nine under through 12 holes. Two were at eight under on the course: Bill Haas through 13 holes and Ben Crane through 14. They will complete the round Saturday before the cut is made.

The organizers of the French Open filed a lawsuit Friday to prevent online gambling companies from offering bets on the tournament. The complaint, which was filed in courts in Liège, Belgium, and in Paris, seeks injunctions against the companies Betfair, Bwin and Ladbrokes.

The Dodgers avoided arbitration with the left-handed reliever Joe Beimel, agreeing Friday to a one-year, $1,925,000 contract. Beimel appeared in a career-high 83 games last season. He was 4-2 with a 3.88 earned run average and a save.
Serena Williams has pulled out of next week’s WTA Paris Open for medical reasons, according to a report on the tournament’s official Web site. Williams won the Paris Open in 1999 and 2003.

Kobe Bryant scored 46 points and the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the host Toronto Raptors, 121-101, on Friday night, hours after acquiring the 7-footer Pau Gasol in a trade with the Memphis Grizzlies.

The On Education column on Jan. 16, about overcrowding at Richmond Hill High School in Queens, described the status of a nearby high school, Franklin K. Lane, incorrectly, and because of an editing error, referred imprecisely to its location. It is scheduled to be phased out over four years; it has not closed. And although Franklin Lane is near the Queens border, it is in Brooklyn, not in Queens.

The Public Lives column in some editions on Jan. 25, about Judge Margarita López Torres of Surrogate’s Court in Brooklyn, whose legal challenge to the way New York picks its judges was rejected by the United States Supreme Court, referred incorrectly to her background. She was born in Puerto Rico and moved to New York City as a child; she did not immigrate.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the dismissal of the final claim in a lawsuit brought by a violinist against the Seattle Symphony and its music director, Gerard Schwarz, referred imprecisely to members of the orchestra who have said they were targets of vandalism. They are supporters of Mr. Schwarz, who has faced opposition from players, not his opponents.

A sports article on Friday about the excitement surrounding this week’s FBR Open golf tournament at the T.P.C. Scottsdale in Arizona misstated the given name of the event’s director. He is Tim Louis, not Phil.

A chart on Monday omitted one of the 24 states holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday. The West Virginia Republican Party is holding a state convention that day. And an article on Thursday about New York State Republicans’ embrace of Senator John McCain for the presidential nomination after Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped out referred incorrectly to the 21 Republican contests on Tuesday. In addition to the West Virginia convention, there are 15 primaries and five caucuses; not all 21 Republican events are primaries.

A chart on Monday omitted one of the 24 states holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday. The West Virginia Republican Party is holding a state convention that day. And an article on Thursday about New York State Republicans’ embrace of Senator John McCain for the presidential nomination after Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped out referred incorrectly to the 21 Republican contests on Tuesday. In addition to the West Virginia convention, there are 15 primaries and five caucuses; not all 21 Republican events are primaries.
The Q&A column in Science Times on Jan.15, about the elements the Sun produces, misidentified the heaviest stable element. It is lead, not iron.

Schedule information in Weekend on Friday with a film review of “Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert” misidentified the theaters where the film is playing. As the review noted, it is a 3-D film, and it is being shown in digital 3-D theaters, not on Imax screens.

A picture caption in some editions last Saturday with a sports article about Jerome Collins, a backup tight end for the Giants, misidentified the player shown hugging running back Brandon Jacobs. It was David Diehl of the Giants, not Collins.

A front-page article last Saturday about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of college preparatory schools in the United States. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., founded in 1781, is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. Older boarding schools are West Nottingham Academy in Colora, Md. (1744); Linden Hall in Lititz, Pa. (1746); the Governor’s Academy in Byfield, Mass. (1763); Salem Academy in Winston-Salem, N.C. (1772); and Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. (1781). Older day schools include the Collegiate School in New York City (1628), Roxbury Latin School in Boston (1645) and Hopkins in New Haven (1660). The article also gave an incomplete name for a boarding school in Wallingford, Conn. It is Choate Rosemary Hall, not just Choate.
A New York appellate court ruled Friday that valid out-of-state marriages of same-sex couples must be legally recognized in New York.

An obituary on Monday about Suharto, the former dictator of Indonesia, misstated the number of islands in the Indonesian archipelago that are inhabited. It is about 6,000 — not “more than 17,000,” which is the approximate number of islands that make up the country.
Forward J. P. Dumont signed a four-year, $16 million contract with the Nashville Predators on Friday.
A heavy, wet winter snowstorm on Friday made travel treacherous, and even deadly, in the Midwest.
The country’s birthrate for 2007 was highest since 1991, the government said.

Simon Mann, the British soldier of fortune accused of masterminding a botched 2004 coup attempt against the authoritarian president of Equatorial Guinea, was sent there from prison in Zimbabwe to face charges.

Israeli Arabs staged big protest strikes after a government decision last weekend to drop an inquiry into a 2000 police shooting that killed 13 people as the police were trying to put down riots in favor of the intifada.
Wilber Alirio Varela, a leader of the Norte del Valle drug cartel in Colombia, has been found shot to death in a hotel in Mérida, in Venezuela’s Andean region.
The French medical charity Doctors Without Borders said it had withdrawn its 87 foreign employees from Somalia.
A Boeing 727 flown by Lloyd Aéreo Boliviano and carrying 155 passengers crash-landed in a forest clearing near the eastern city of Trinidad.
The explosion was blamed in the Tamil Tiger rebels.
A New Zealand concern called Crop and Food Research said on its Web site that it had created a tearless onion.

A 79-year-old nun was sentenced to one year in a county jail for sexually abusing two teenagers when she was their principal four decades ago in Milwaukee. Sister Norma Giannini avoided a trial by pleading no contest in November to two felony counts of indecent behavior with a child. The two male victims told the authorities they had dozens of sexual encounters with Sister Giannini, including intercourse, while attending St. Patrick’s School in Milwaukee during the 1960s, according to a criminal complaint. Sister Giannini, who lives with other Sisters of Mercy in a Chicago suburb, has been retired from active work for five years because of failing health.

A twin-engine plane crashed as it tried to land amid low fog at a small airport in Mount Airy, killing all six people on board, officials said. No one on the ground was hurt, said Warren Woodberry, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The King Air C90A took off in Cedartown, Ga., Mr. Woodberry said, and the passengers were on their way to Primland, a hunting and golf resort in Meadows of Dan, Va., about 25 miles north of the Mount Airy airport, said Kelvin Boyette, the airport manager.

Education Secretary Margaret Spellings said she would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to reconsider a ruling that revived a legal challenge to the federal No Child Left Behind law.

Regulators said Pfizer’s antismoking drug Chantix appeared increasingly likely to be linked to serious psychiatric behavior, and called for stronger label warnings. After an analysis of reports of suicidal thoughts and behavior potentially linked to the medication, the Food and Drug Administration said it was calling for Pfizer to strengthen the label warnings on the drug.

More than two million gallons of partially treated sewage and storm water were dumped into the San Francisco Bay on Thursday night, and officials in Marin County, north of San Francisco, were trying to determine the extent of environmental damage. According to the county sheriff’s office, the spill occurred at a sewage treatment plant in Mill Valley after a pump, and an alarm system meant to monitor it, both failed after several weeks of near-constant rain. Warning signs were posted at several beaches, and tests were being conducted to determine whether any hazardous sewage escaped. Public health officials were also warning boaters and fishermen to avoid contact with the water near Richardson Bay, near Sausalito. The spill comes three months after a Chinese container ship struck the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel.
Roving teams of city police officers armed with automatic rifles and accompanied by bomb-sniffing dogs will patrol the city’s subway system daily, beginning next month.
The leading antiwar group endorsed Senator Barack Obama on Friday, saying his opposition to the war would make him a stronger general election candidate.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the white-haired liberal legend, is drawing raucous crowds.
With only four days before a virtual national primary on Tuesday, Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney both had urgent reasons for wooing conservative voters.

An arbitrator ruled that the Players Club broke its agreement with a union by getting rid of workers and bringing in a catering company.

The Best Friends Animal Society sanctuary in Kanab, Utah, is a new home for 22 of Michael Vick’s former dogs.
Automakers got off to a rough start in 2008, but General Motors served up a surprise on Friday with higher sales in January on strong demand for its new car models.

A South Korean court found the private equity fund and one of its executives guilty of manipulating stock prices. The executive, Paul Yoo, was sentenced to five years.
Wall Street set aside anxiety over news that the economy lost jobs last month and focused on Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo.
David A. Paterson has been a stalwart supporter of Hillary Rodham Clinton and is seen as a leading contender to fill her Senate seat should she become president.
Voters in New Jersey who cast absentee ballots for a candidate who has dropped out of the presidential race can vote again, a judge has ruled.

While Israel does not deny that it killed the four United Nations observers in Lebanon, it says the episode was unintentional.

“Puppy Bowl IV,” a three-hour extravaganza in which a cast of 46 dogs frolics, chases, pants, sniffs, rolls, tail wags and occasionally picks up a ball  on a set resembling a football field, will be broadcast at 3 p.m. on Sunday.
The suspect was charged with raping the boy at the New Bedford public library, just feet away from his mother, who was working on a computer.
The country’s largest newspaper publisher said Friday that its fourth-quarter profit dropped because of a decline in broadcasting revenue and weak newspaper ad sales.
How can we expect anyone to care about melting glaciers in the abstract when even in the face of their stupendous presence we remain careless?
A January report by JPMorgan Chase said growing revenues from online advertising would in part lead to a great year for Internet stocks.
The banks are considering injecting capital into the Ambac Financial Group and assuming some of the risks associated with guarantees written by the company.

Arts Council England, the government-financed body that provides subsidies to the arts, announced a 9.5 percent budget increase over the next three years and maintained financing of 17 recipients that had been scheduled for cuts, Bloomberg News reported. Those cuts had caused an uproar, drawing hundreds of actors to a protest at the Young Vic Theater last month. Christopher Frayling, chairman of the council, said that 888 arts groups would share £1.3 billion ($2.6 billion) between now and 2011. Another 185 groups, though, will no longer get financing, including the London Mozart Players and the City of London Sinfonia.
Numbers of unaffiliated voters have surged in Colorado by 14 percent, even as the numbers of registered Democrats and Republicans sagged or stagnated.

Paul McCartney called recent reports that he had a heart procedure last year “entirely untrue,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. McCartney, 65, wrote in a letter posted on his Web site (paulmccartney.com) that during a routine medical examination more than a year ago, “there was a minor irregularity which I needed to have tests for and which I have now been assured is completely fine.” Reports that he had had an angioplasty “completely distorted the story,” Mr. McCartney said.

The premiere of the fourth season of “Lost” delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season’s debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series’s complicated back story (13.1 million).Fox and NBC ranked second and third on the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was fourth in that demographic but managed to finish second in total viewers. And CNN’s broadcast of the debate between Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton drew an average of 8.3 million viewers, the most ever for a primary debate on cable news.

James Spears, the father of Britney Spears, was named her temporary conservator, putting him in control of her welfare a day after she was hospitalized for a psychiatric evaluation, The Associated Press reported. In addition, after a hearing in California Superior Court he was named a conservator, along with the lawyer Andrew Wallete, of the singer’s estate. The court also issued a restraining order against Ms. Spears’s friend and sometime manager, Sam Lutfi, and gave permission to change the locks on her estate and remove anyone there. Ms. Spears, shown above outside a hearing last month regarding visitation rights for her two children, will be under conservatorship at least until Monday, when another hearing will be held.

The Spice Girls said Friday that they had canceled concerts planned for China, Australia, South Africa and Argentina, shortening their reunion tour, Agence France-Presse reported. The group pulled out for “family and personal commitments,” a spokesman said, though there have been reports of poor ticket sales. Concerts in Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Sydney, Cape Town and Buenos Aires are off, and the tour is now set to finish in Toronto on Feb. 26. The Spice Girls, who last toured almost 10 years ago, sold more than 50 million albums worldwide and had nine British No. 1 singles in the 1990s.

A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by five authors against Eagle Publishing, the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington-based conservative imprint. The authors had charged that the company deprived them of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company. Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle of United States District Court in Washington ruled on Wednesday that because the authors had contracts with Regnery, not Eagle, and those contracts included binding arbitration clauses, the lawsuit was invalid. “We are very pleased with the judge’s dismissal of the lawsuit,” Marji Ross, president and publisher of Regnery, said. Richard Miniter, one of the authors, said they would file an arbitration case next week.
If your grandmother played the market, she probably invested in utilities for safety and income, not capital gains. She would need to adjust her strategy today.
Robert J. Ulrich is donating millions of dollars to establish the decidedly unglamorous Musical Instrument Museum.
The state’s top securities regulator accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments.

If New York’s status and the currency that backs it are more contested than they once were, that only makes the opening of the Museum of American Finance on Wall Street last month more urgently intriguing.
A federal appeals court ruled that a lower court was correct in tossing out a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project near Downtown Brooklyn.
Bless Susan Stroman and New York City Ballet. With Ms. Stroman’s “Double Feature,” august ballet audiences can indulge in an unaccustomed Broadway-style laugh riot.
Under the leadership of Steven C. Preston, the Small Business Administration — the chief advocate for small business owners — is trying to revitalize itself.

Tomislav Nikolic, a 55 year-old former cemetery worker known as the Undertaker, edged past the pro-Western incumbent in the first round of elections last week.
Joanna Newsom’s perpetual-motion harp playing provides settings that encompass madrigals, Appalachian ballads and African griot songs, and her voice can sound piercing or intimate.
“212,” a symphony in homage to Manhattan by the composer and native New Yorker Robert Sirota,  was played impressively on Thursday by the Manhattan School of Music Symphony.
After receiving a two-hour extension, the Mets completed negotiations Friday with Johan Santana on what may be a contract worth nearly $140 million.
Six accused of conspiring to join forces with Al Qaeda to blow up the tower went on trial Friday, seven weeks after the jury in the first trial deadlocked on those defendants and acquitted a seventh.
A major loan exhibition of Bernini’s sculptures, paintings and drawings is headed for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles this summer.
More than 160 counties and cities in central China suffered blackouts and water shortages because of continued bad weather that has caused a humanitarian crisis.

By Thursday night, when Trio M made their New York stand in the mezzanine lounge of the Kitano Hotel, their rapport felt noticeably deeper than on the record, and the music covered a broader dynamic range.
The dancers and actors who participated in the 1974 recordings and workshops that were the foundation of “A Chorus Line” have been granted a financial interest in the current Broadway revival.
The cellphone-network equipment maker said that it would cut up to 4,000 jobs, about 5.4 percent of its work force, after profit plunged 42 percent in the fourth quarter.
The dollar may gain a bit against other currencies in 2008, Bloomberg Markets reports, but its long-term prospects are bleak.
Giants Coach Tom Coughlin, an N.F.L. head coach for more than a decade,  made his final public appearance before the Super Bowl, answering questions at the game’s final pregame news conference.

Commissioner Roger Goodell said he was willing to meet with Senator Arlen Specter to explain the destruction of tapes from the N.F.L.’s investigation of the Patriots.

Viviane Hagner’s violin recital with the pianist Tatiana Goncharova at the 92nd Street Y on Thursday was mostly Brahms but mainly about Bartok’s Sonata for Solo Violin.
Japanese officials said the dumplings contained an agricultural pesticide used in China but not common in Japan.
Kenya’s countryside seems to be settling into a state of lawlessness that is more reminiscent of the checkpoint culture in Somalia or Darfur, Sudan.
In just a few days, it seems, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin has managed to undo most of the reputation as a single-minded disciplinarian he had built over nearly two decades.
Mauritanian officials claimed that the target of the shooting against the embassy was actually a nearby nightclub.
The rebels are seeking to force the country’s president, Idriss Déby, to share power or step down.
Chuck Knoblauch gave 90 minutes of closed-door testimony to Congressional staff Friday and told reporters he wanted to do his part to clean up drugs in baseball.
Two women strapped with explosives killed dozens of people in the deadliest day in Baghdad in months.

Because of an editing error, an article on Page 38 of The Times Magazine this weekend about voting patterns among women referred incorrectly to the questions in a Norman Lear Center/Zogby International poll used to help discern those patterns. Respondents were asked to indicate their degree of agreement with certain statements; the questions were not true-or-false or open-ended.
Senator Barack Obama said Friday that the top priority of the next president should be to create a more lasting and equitable prosperity than achieved by either President Bush or even Bill Clinton.
Polls show that nearly two years after he was voted out of the prime minister’s office, Silvio Berlusconi would probably win it back.
Democratic voters have not been asked about their religious affiliation by pollsters as often as Republicans have.
A plunge in construction spending threatens to drive the American economy into recession.
Roberto Mangabeira Unger, a Harvard law professor, serves as the country’s minister for strategic affairs.
Rent-A-Center, a chain of appliance and furniture rental stores, offers a deal that is much like a subprime mortgage for pull-out sofas and television sets.
Several analysts from Goldman Sachs and Citigroup contributed $189,260 to the Neediest Cases Fund.
Marriage proposals are becoming increasingly elaborate and expensive, with proposal planners, proposal photographers and others getting into the act of helping men.
An increasing number of American parents want their children to be bilingual if not multilingual.

The sense of being an outsider still drives Ted Nolan, the coach of the Islanders, whose mystique includes nine full seasons without a job in the National Hockey League, amid rumors that he was blackballed.
The lowlight of Josh Miller’s eight-year minor league umpiring career was the discomfort he experienced over participating in baseball chapel services every Sunday morning.
Advertising and media executives said that Google has become so dominant in the online advertising market that a combined Microsoft and Yahoo might be the only way to produce a legitimate competitor.
Google’s dominance has forced Microsoft to concede that it did not get its Internet business right.
The Irish have embraced the use of cloth bags to carry groceries, encouraged by a 33-cent tax on plastic ones.
If consummated, the deal would instantly redraw the competitive landscape on the Internet and escalate the battle between Microsoft and Google.
The proposed Yahoo deal is a confirmation that Microsoft has become exactly what Bill Gates used to fear — sluggish and bureaucratic.
Barack Obama says that he and Hillary Clinton are friends forever. Which is actually more than we, the voters, require.
No one can compete with Google on their own anymore. There has to be consolidation among the major players. JON MILLER, the former chairman and chief executive of AOL. [A1]

SIEGEL--Herbert Allen , died peacefully at home on January 31 of cancer, surrounded by his beloved wife, Martha, his loving children, Noah and Miranda, and his devoted brother, Lloyd. Herbert grew up in the Bronx, where he formed life-long friendships. At an early age he showed scholarly interests and demonstrated superb athletic ability. In his youth he played a competitive match against the young Arthur Ashe and went on to play varsity tennis in college. He had a Ph.D. in classics and taught at The City University of New York and at NYU. An impresario of life, his interests were as eclectic as his wide group of friends. He was passionate about opera, orchids and cacti, travel, foreign cultures and languages. His nature was deeply empathetic and he did his utmost to alleviate the suffering of others. Herbert touched the lives of all who knew him and will be remembered for his independent spirit, his tenacious mind, his joyous zest for life, his delightful wit and, most of all, his deep devotion to family and friends. He passed on his love of chess to his son, Noah, who early on became a chess Master and he engendered in his daughter, Miranda, his talent for language and writing. He was translating an Argentinean Gaucho Epic, working as a dramaturge for Aida and mentoring Ph.D. candidates up until the time of his death. Funeral services will be held on Sunday February 3 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at 91 St) at 12 noon. The family will receive visitors on Sunday February 3 from 7 to 9pm and on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday (February 4, 5, 6) from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm, at the home of Martha Siegel, 134 East 93 St. Donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Association Education Fund in memory of Herbert Siegel, 30 Lincoln Center, NYC 10023.

Honie and Jerry GOLDBERG--Adrienne 63, died on January 31, 2008 surrounded by her loving husband and daughter. Adored wife of Lawrence, devoted mother of Alexis, and a cherished friend of many, she lived her life in joy and beauty. A dedicated wife and mother, she was deeply committed to her family. Her forty year marriage was a rare gift of constant love. A passionate artist, Adrienne's work dazzles and inspires her audiences. Her most recent series of paintings, Mindscapes, engage the conscious mind with their stark beauty and provoke deep contemplation. Her art has been acknowledged with numerous awards and critical praise, including prizes from the NOHO Art Walk, and the UNIFEM Benefit Show. Her art can be seen at her website, adrienneart.net. Her involvement in the Greenwich Village community was widely appreciated and she will be remembered for her work as Community Director of the Poe House, on the Board of Directors of the Caring Community, and on the Board of Directors of Friends of LaGuardia Place, where she was in the process of developing a Children's Garden. Adrienne lived every moment of her life with verve and enthusiasm, and she will be remembered with great love and celebrated with great joy. In addition to her husband and daughter, she is survived by her father, Hyman Rosen, and her sister, Linda Prince. The fund-raising arm for House Republicans said it might have been the victim of fraud and has notified the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission. 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ASTRONAUT FARMER (2007) Fly me to the moon: Billy Bob Thornton, left, plays Charles Farmer, a space-obsessed rancher who builds a rocket in his barn and plans to blast himself into orbit. Virginia Madsen is Audie, the adoring wife who supports his far-flung dreams long after a more sensible woman would have left. Not so enchanted with Farmer's scheme: the Federal Aviation Administration, the F.B.I. and NASA. The film's director, Michael Polish, demonstrates a ''taste for odd, resonant images,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The opening shots, of Farmer on horseback in his space suit, hint at a strangeness that the rest of the movie never quite lives up to, but it does have a visual freshness that makes the bromides and clichés palatable.'' 8 P.M. The retrial of six construction workers accused of conspiring to join forces with Al Qaeda and blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago began in Miami, seven weeks after the jury in the first trial deadlocked on those defendants and acquitted a seventh. In opening statements, prosecutors and defense lawyers hewed to essentially the same arguments they had made in the first trial, the outcome of which was widely regarded as a significant defeat for the government. Prosecutors insisted that even though the plot did not evolve beyond initial planning stages, the men avidly sought backing from Al Qaeda and demonstrated a determination to carry out their plan. The men, who lived in the Liberty City neighborhood of Miami, were indicted after a nine-month investigation in which a paid informant for the F.B.I. posed as a Qaeda operative sent from the Middle East to help them plan and carry out attacks. Defense lawyers said the whole plot was scripted by F.B.I. agents determined to make a terrorism case at any cost in the charged post-9/11 environment.

F.D.A. APPROVES STENT Medtronic said it had received federal approval to sell its drug-coated stent, the first to enter the United States market since safety concerns sank their popularity two years ago. The Food and Drug Administration said it cleared the company's Endeavor stent for use in patients with clogged arteries. Medtronic said it expected to ship 100,000 units to hospitals in February. Endeavor is one of a new generation of stents the industry hopes can rejuvenate demand for the drug-oozing devices, sales of which plummeted to $2 billion last year, down from a peak of $3.1 billion in 2005 (AP) QUESTIONS OVER CHINESE STAKE A House committee is seeking information about the government's review of a Chinese company's bid to acquire a stake in 3Com Corporation, according to a letter given to reporters. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and the panel's ranking Republican member, Joe L. Barton of Texas, said in the letter to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. that they were concerned about possible ties between the company, Huawei Technologies, and the Chinese military.

Updated, 11:15 p.m. | The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the pastor at Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and one of New York’s most influential clergymen, endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton two weeks ago, on the eve of the holiday marking the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday. Speaking to the congregation that day, Mrs. Clinton paraphrased Frederick Douglass, the 19th-century black abolitionist, telling the congregation: “Right has no sex and truth has no color.” But at the church this morning, there was little agreement on who would be the best candidate to carry the Democratic flag into the general election in November.

FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Hoping to repeat the success he had here in the 2000 primary, Senator John McCain drew a crowd of supporters to a gymnasium on the campus of Sacred Heart University on Sunday afternoon, in an event that seemed as much a celebration of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as it was a campaign rally.

A group of Hispanic politicians, led by Miguel Martinez, a Dominican-American city councilman, drove cars in a caravan through heavily Hispanic sections of Upper Manhattan this morning in an effort to drum up support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The Latino Caravan, as it was billed in Mrs. Clinton’s campaign literature, made its way from 155th Street and Broadway, in Washington Heights, to 215th Street and 10th Avenue, in Inwood, where it ended with a small rally.
JERSEY CITY – The dozen or so Obama faithful who gathered here just after noon on Sunday were up against the clock. They had hundreds of doors to knock on and only five hours to do it.

At Columbus Circle around 3 p.m. this afternoon, about 100 supporters of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stood just a few dozen feet from about 10 volunteers for Senator Barack Obama. One passer-by quipped, “I think you guys should have a cat fight.”

Supporters of Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton targeted houses of worship on Sunday morning as they waged a final push to get voters to support their candidate on Tuesday, when New York holds its Democratic and Republican presidential primaries. “We’re not looking for the reverends to endorse,” said one Obama volunteer, Giovanna Judge, 42, of Staten Island. “We just want the parishioners to know what’s going on.”

Representative Charles B. Rangel, Harlem’s leading politician, visited three Manhattan churches today to stump for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. He was joined at one of them by David N. Dinkins, who was New York City’s first black mayor. But the appearances, intended to bolster Mrs. Clinton’s standing among black and Latino voters, highlighted the extent to which many New Yorkers — even members of the same family — are torn between Mrs. Clinton and her rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Barack Obama.

Well, Super Tuesday is finally upon us, and it must be comforting to Democrats in their 22 primary states to know that their votes will, you know, count. As you're no doubt aware, Florida and Michigan, also known as "the bad boys of statedom," moved their primaries ahead of Feb. 5 to gain influence and campaign dollars. Tragically, they were punished by the Democratic National Committee by having their delegates denied seats at the party's national convention. (Even more tragically, they lost the chance to sample D.N.C. chairman Howard Dean's homemade ice cream in either of its two flavors, Facial Pink and Grassroot.) But all this could have been avoided if Michigan and Florida hadn't miscalculated the real reason that Super Tuesday carries so much clout: its cool name.

The Serbian publication Sahovski Informator (Chess Informant) recently marked 42 years of operation with its 100th volume. Appearing three times a year (twice a year over most of its run), Informant provides hundreds of deeply annotated games, as well as combinations and endings. To render the commentary internationally understandable, the editors invented a language of symbols to evaluate moves and positions (e.g., "+=" means white has a slight advantage) still in wide usage today. The chess community is particularly grateful for the openings classification system known as ECO codes, after its five-volume work "Encyclopedia of Chess Openings."

Expect a few more posts on "The Moviegoer" before the lights come up and everyone floods out of the theater. But while you're still in your seats, here's a brief announcement: next up is "August: Osage County," by Tracy Letts. It's a brand new work, a three-act play about a large family in total crisis. In his Times review, the theater critic Charles Isherwood called it "flat-out, no asterisks and without qualifications, the most exciting new American play Broadway has seen in years." And we've put together a great panel to discuss it: the playwright Marsha Norman, the novelist Eliza Minot, and the Times's Frank Rich, who was the paper's chief theater critic before becoming an Op-Ed columnist. We'll start in on February 18, and I'll be moderating the discussion.

[UPDATE 5/29: Matt Wald has just written the latest story in our Energy Challenge series -- a sobering update on the lack of progress in the United States (and elsewhere) on pursuing ways to affordably capture and store carbon dioxide from coal-burning power plants. It's a technology that's on everybody's wish list -- from environmental groups to coal companies. But full-scale tests are years away, and nobody yet knows whether it can be done anywhere near the necessary scale in a world with tens of billions of tons of such emissions each year already, and much more to come.]

When you pass through the Prussian-blue door of the Blue Bakery, the first aroma you’ll notice is likely to be coffee, not bread. That’s because the Blue Bakery brews plenty of joe, as well as half a dozen types of latte, but doesn’t bake any bread.

A review on Jan. 13 about “They Knew They Were Right: The Rise of the Neocons” repeated the book’s erroneous date for a view about World War II once expressed by Irving Kristol, who later became a founder of neoconservatism. It was in 1943, when Kristol was 23, that he published an article referring to a “near hysterical insistence upon the pressing military danger” posed by the Axis powers; it was not “as late as 1944,” when he was 24.

An article on Jan. 20 about rising hotel rates around the world misstated the number of rooms in New York City in a comparison with those in India. The city has about 74,000 hotel rooms — not 100,000, which is the estimated total for India.

An article and a caption on Jan. 13 about four places to eat in Amman, Jordan, that reflect different cuisines of the Middle East misstated the main ingredient in the pita sandwich sold at Reem Cafeteria. It is lamb, not roast beef.

Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Jan. 20 about airport parking misstated the number of airports served by AirportParkingReservations.com, which allows travelers to reserve parking spots through the Web site. It is more than 65, not 200. (The service does offer reservations at more than 200 lots at those airports.).

To the Editor: I was dismayed to learn from your article on Kilimanjaro, “On Africa’s Roof Still Crowned With Snow” (Jan. 20), that a veritable ants-trail of tourists climb “my” mountain each year. When I climbed it in 1961, my group met only three other parties in five days, and our guide refused to take us beyond Leopard Point on the rim of the crater around to the actual summit, then still called Kaiser-Wilhelm-Spitze, because the snow was too deep and dangerous!.

To the Editor: I read, with interest, your Practical Traveler column “No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate” (Jan. 20), about the lack of parking at airports around the nation. One suggestion: Airports should consider offering valet parking at airports. This would be a help to those who miscalculate and are in a rush to park their cars but can’t find spots, and to travelers who are not taking advantage of other long-term parking options. Valet parking could ease anxiety among travelers and generate some additional revenue for airport operations.
To the Editor: Your 36 Hours column on Breckenridge, Colo. (Jan. 20), reminded me of my stay there a few years ago.

Protect Brady The Patriots allowed Tom Brady to be sacked only 21 times in the regular season and only 1 to the Giants in their regular-season finale. But the Giants have three of the best pass rushers in the N.F.L., and they are sure to go after Brady to test his sprained right ankle. The Patriots may have the best offensive line in the game, so inside pressure from Justin Tuck will be critical if the Giants hope to collapse the pocket and force Brady to throw quickly. The problem for the Giants is that Brady is brilliant at reading defenses and quickly finding an open receiver like Wes Welker if the rush is coming. The Patriots could put Brady in the shotgun to give him a bit more time. This will be the most important matchup of the game.

MALOTT--Mary, Myart also known as Mary McIntyre: 1928-2008. Mary was an Austin, Texas and New York City painter, sculptor, assemblage artist, art critic, and diarist whose artistic bent also led her into unpredicted success in real estate development. She died January 21, 2008, at the age of 79 at the Cobble Hill Nursing Home in Brooklyn, NY after a protracted period of suffering from Alzheimer's. Born Mary Eleanor Harrell in Indiana, she was the daughter of Mary Evans Harrell and Samuel Runnels Harrell who once ran for governor of Indiana. Ms. Malott graduated from Radcliffe College, studied at the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture and got her MFA from the University of Texas. Mary served as trustee and volunteer Director of the Laguna Gloria Art Museum and was active in the Junior League, the Travis County Medical Auxiliary, and the Colonial Dames. Her work was exhibited in numerous solo and group shows in Texas and New York. Ms. Malott wrote a weekly column as an art critic for three years for the Austin American-Statesman. From 19801981 Mary provided weekly commentary for Artbeat, a show on KLRU-TV in Austin. She also taught art classes at colleges in Austin and for Laguna Gloria Art Museum. Ms. Malott ventured into real estate with her award-winning preservation and development of Austin's Pecan Square. Next, with her daughter Sylvia she rehabilitated the historic Gilfillan House. In the early 1980's, after a divorce from her second husband, Dr. Frances McIntyre, Ms. Malott moved to New York City's SoHo. Ms. Malott's longtime companion in New York was Tim Yohn. ultimately incapacitated by Alzheimer's, Ms. Malott painted her last large painting, a Slices of the Forrest painting, in 1993 at her Marcel Breuer country residence and studio in Clinton Corners, NY. Mary Myart Malott is survived by her two brothers, Evans Malott Harrell, of Georgia, Samuel Macy Harrell, of Florida, three daughters, Barbara McIntyre of Portland, Oregon, Sylvia McIntyre (Mrs. Larry Crook) of Gainesville, Florida, and Carolyn McIntyre (Mrs. Michael D. D. White) of NYC, and five grandchildren, Ethan McCooper, Vanessa and Alexander Crook, Eve and Audrey White. A spring New York City memorial service is planned. More about Mary's life and the transformations as she defined herself through her art is available at http://www.carolynmcintyre. com/ MaryMyartMalott .htmlbel

DiGIA--Ralph. WWII conscientious objector, lifelong pacifist and social justice activist, and beloved staffer at the War Resisters League for 52 years, died February 1. A hero without pretensions is gone, who for peace and justice went through countless arrests, federal prison time, hunger strikes, thousands of meetings and hundreds of demonstrations, a bicycle ride across Europe, and relief work in Bosnia. The staffs and boards of WRL and the A.J. Muste Memorial Institute, in our deep sorrow, reach out to Ralph's family and wife, Karin, in theirs.

Devoted grandfather of Liam, Aidan, Grace and Natalie. Reposing at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue, NYC, NY 10010. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10am, Immaculate Conception Church. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Cremation at Greenwood Crematory. Among Joe's accomplishments, he was most proud of being Chairman of the Hall of Fame of the National Wheelchair Basketball Association. In lieu of flowers, family would appreciate donations in the memory of Joseph Luceri to: National Wheelchair Basketball Association, 6165 Lehman Drive, Suite 101, Colorado Springs, CO 80918.

Maria Sharapova defeated Tzipi Obziler, 6-0, 6-4, in her first Fed Cup match, helping Russia, the defending champion, to a 1-1 tie with Israel in the first round in Ramat Hasharon, Israel. Earlier, Israel's Shahar Peer defeated Dinara Safina, 0-6, 6-2, 6-2.In other Fed Cup matchups, Nuria Llagostera Vives of Spain upset Francesca Schiavone of Italy, 7-6 (4), 3-6, 6-2, and Anabel Medina Garrigues followed with a 6-2, 6-3 win over Flavia Pennetta in Naples, Italy. That puts Italy, the 2006 champion and last year's runner-up, on the verge of elimination.In Beijing, Li Na defeated Alize Cornet of France, 6-3, 6-1, and Peng Shuai outlasted Virginie Razzano, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, to put China one victory from its first appearance in the Fed Cup semifinals.

KUCZYNSKI--Dr. H. June (Jadwiga) of Bloomfield Hills, MI passed away on January 31, 2008. Beloved wife of Edward for 52 years. Loving mother of Yvonne Sesi (Joe), Ed, and Barbara. Adoring grandmother of Eddie Kuczynski and Katie Sesi. Born in Wilno, Poland on February 20, 1929 she was deported as a child to a Siberian labor camp by the Soviet Union during World War II. Her family eventually settled in Tanzania, Africa, where she completed high school. Subsequently, she emigrated to England, where she completed her nursing and midwifery training. In 1957, June and her new husband arrived in the United States on the Queen Mary. June continued her nursing education, earning a Doctor of Philosophy from Wayne State University in Detroit, MI. Dr. Kuczynski was tenured faculty in the School of Nursing at Wayne State University for almost 30 years. She received many accolades and awards including The President's Award for Excellence in Teaching. Cardinal Karol Wojtyla (the future Pope John Paul II) visited her home in 1977. She has been to the White House on numerous occasions. Her warm smile and kind heart will be missed by family, friends and her dear students. View obituary and share memories at www.Desmond FuneralHome.com

SILVER--Kate, age 101, of Palm Beach, Florida died Wednesday at her home. Born in Atlanta, Georgia she resided most of her life in Woodmere, NY before moving to Palm Beach 25 years ago. Mrs. Silver was active in many charitable organizations, most notably the UJA and ADL. She was a member of the Brandeis Womans Division and a member of the Woodmere Club. She was predeceased by Dr. A. G. Silver, a prominent plastic surgeon in 1983. She is survived by her two loving sons, William and daugher-in-law Adrianne Silver of New York, and Dr. Carl and daughter-inlaw Toni Silver of Grantham, New Hampshire; her six devoted grandchildren, James, Scott, Audrey, Karen, Elizabeth and Catherine and great - grandchildren Elise, Daniel, and Elora; and 18 nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be Friday (February 1) in King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. Donations can be made to the Tradition of the Palm Beaches, 4920 Loring Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida 33417, attention: Linda McClamma. Services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.
