GOLDSTEIN--Kate... wife, mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother... died peacefully at home in Manhattan on January 27, 2008. Born in New York City on April 19, 1913, Kate's years were a passionate celebration of life. Bonding wit and compassion to courage and intelligence, she did not simply take the world as it is, but sought ceaselessly to make it a better place. She confronted both life and death with dignity and without fear. She will be remembered with love.

NECARSULMER--Henry, life long New Yorker, loving husband of Elizabeth Louise and adored father of Susan N. Goldsmith and John B. and Peter B. Necarsulmer, passed away peacefully on January 31, 2008 in his Manhattan home at the age of 93. A man who combined integrity, precision and the highest personal standards with great wit and an extraordinary commitment to family and friends, Henry was respected by all who knew him as a gentleman in the truest sense of the word. His family, and most especially Betty, his life partner for 61 years, celebrate in Henry a life well lived as husband, father, grandfather, family patriarch, respected role model and trusted friend. In 1935, Henry began his distinguished 62 year career on Wall Street as an investment banker with Kuhn, Loeb & Co., where he served as Managing Partner from 1969 to 1977. He was an architect of the creation of Lehman Brothers, Kuhn, Loeb, Inc. in 1977, one of the earliest mergers of two major Wall Street investmentbanking institutions. From 1977 until 1990, Henry served as a Managing Director and Advisory Director of Lehman Brothers, Kuhn, Loeb, Inc., and as a Consultant to Lehman Brothers, Inc. until 1997, when he retired at the youthful age of 82. During his career, Henry was the principal investment banker for, among others, Westinghouse Electric, Bethlehem Steel, Rockwell, Polaroid, Uniroyal and GATX. He served on many corporate boards, but none gave him more pleasure than his two decades of service to Polaroid where he was also a valued friend of inventor and company founder Dr. Edwin H. Land. Henry graduated from Dartmouth College in 1934, and served to Captain, Finance Department, in the U.S. Army from 1942 to 1946. Like his father Edward before him, he served for many years as a Director of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York. Henry was the son of Edward Necarsulmer and Manuela Maas, and brother of Edward Jr. and Robert, previously deceased. In addition to his wife and three children, he is survived by son-in-law John S. Goldsmith, daughters-in-law Helene Calvet and Susan A. Thurman, grandchildren Alison B. Ferrer, Matthew A. Dallin, Amanda M. Necarsulmer and Alexis M. Necarsulmer, and many loving nieces and nephews. Henry's life will be celebrated at a family gathering. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, friends of Henry consider making a donation either to the Jewish Child Care Association, 120 Wall Street, NY, NY 10005, or to Dartmouth College Alumni Association, 6068 Blunt Alumni Center, Hanover, NH 03755.

ONE SEASON it was a fractured collage of New York City; the next, rolling hills with a river made from 600,000 pieces of candy, a homage to the late conceptual artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres. Then came a neoclassical villa plucked from Bernardo Bertolucci's movie ''The Conformist''; and last season, a giant video installation with models trooping down the runway in sync to a film by the artist Charles Atlas that showed them doing so in lingerie.

A review on Jan. 13 about ''They Knew They Were Right: The Rise of the Neocons'' repeated the book's erroneous date for a view about World War II once expressed by Irving Kristol, who later became a founder of neoconservatism. It was in 1943, when Kristol was 23, that he published an article referring to a ''near hysterical insistence upon the pressing military danger'' posed by the Axis powers; it was not ''as late as 1944,'' when he was 24.

TAMMARO--John Anthony, formerly of Spring Lake and Plainfield, NJ, died on January 25, 2008, in his home in Louisville, CO. John was born in Plainfield, NJ on June 23, 1917, and married Elizabeth Marie Pfaff of Westfield, NJ in 1947. Before moving to Colorado in 1987, he resided in Spring Lake. He was employed at NL Industries for 34 years where he served in both Management and Engineering capacities. He was a WWII veteran who served in the Corps of Engineers and the Army Air Force after studying at Upsala College and Rutgers University. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

ON THE BUS FROM OSLO TO STOCKHOLM, JUNE 6, 2007 Mary Ahlgren, right, a 60-year-old librarian from Sanbornton, N.H., with her daughter, Kerstin, 26, a graduate student at Columbia University. ''My daughter and I wanted to see the Swedish countryside, and a bus is a good way to do it. My family spent three weeks in Sweden when I was about 11. I had met a lot of family then, but they were my fat old great-aunts that I was a little scared of. Well, on this trip we visited my second or third cousins, because the fat old great-aunts are no longer around. One cousin took me to where my grandmother had been born, a very small house up in the woods. It was the highlight of the trip. I really got a sense of why the whole family had to leave Sweden in the early 1900s: there was no way to make a living.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Informal talks between representatives of Hollywood's striking writers and production companies have eliminated the major roadblocks to a new contract, which could lead to a tentative deal as early as next week, according to people who were briefed on the situation. The agreement may come without renewed formal negotiations between the television and movie writers and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, though both sides still need to agree on specific language of critical provisions. If that process goes smoothly, a deal may be presented to the governing boards of the striking Writers Guild of America West and Writers Guild of America East by the end of next week.

At left and below, women in shapely designs by the Parisian couturier Azzedine Alaïa, who first showed the ballerina silhouette last year.

Get to Brady A tantalizing race will begin every time Tom Brady steps back to pass. Can he find an open receiver against the Giants' weak spot, the secondary, before he is consumed by the Giants' greatest strength, the pass rush? With a relentless front four and a dizzying mix of blitzes, the Giants led the N.F.L. in sacks. But the Patriots often deploy five receivers, which will strain the secondary. When the teams played in December, the Patriots had only 44 rushing yards on 26 rushes but still rolled up 38 points and 27 first downs. Brady completed 76.2 percent of his passes for 356 yards and 4 touchdowns. The Giants, who sacked him only once in 43 pass plays, cannot afford a repeat performance.

KOSTEN--Andrew, Ph.D., 86 years, died peacefully on January 20, 2008 with his family in White Twp, NJ. He is survived by wife Patricia (Donnellan), children: Constance of Missouri; Diana of Texas; Paul of New Jersey; Charles of West Virginia; seven grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, many brothers, sisters, nieces and nephews. A graduate of University of Michigan, Dr. Kosten worked for the US Navy as aeronautical engineer during WWII. Study for the ministry at Princeton University led to pastorships in NJ Presbyterian churches. A doctorate from Temple University and AIPP of NYC prepared him for his treatment of patients at Central Park Center for Psychotherapy and Teaneck, NJ offices. He was a published author of serious works and award-winning composer of music and song. As a student of worldfamous painters and sculptors at the Art Students League, NYC he excelled in both disciplines. Lifelong pursuit of knowledge and creativity inspired his students at Fairleigh Dickensen University and all who had the privilege of knowing him. Contributions in his name may be made to: Karen Quinlan Hospice, 99 Sparta Ave., Newton, NJ 07860.

MILBRATH--Margaret Ripperger, died in Gainesville, Florida, on January 26, 2008 at the age of 88. Margaret was born in New York and grew up in Brooklyn Heights until her marriage to Robert in Buenos Aires, Argentina. During their 68-year marriage, the couple also lived in Columbia, Peru, Connecticut, New York, Vermont, Florida, and London. In Connecticut, Margaret was an active member of the Inland Wetlands Committee and the Colonial Dames of America. Before her marriage, she danced at Martha Graham's Dance Studio. Later in life she became an accomplished sculptor working in clay and stone and graduated with honors from Colombia University. She is survived by her husband Robert, a son Robert, two daughters, Constance and Susan, and four grandchildren.

GOGOLAK--David 36, of Whitefish, MT, formerly of Darien, CT, died instantly in an avalanche while skiing in Montana recently. Gogolak, nicknamed ''GoGo'', cofounded Asqew Grill, a highly successful San Francisco restaurant chain specializing in food served on skewers. The 2008 Zagat San Francisco Guide predicted that the Asqew chain is the 'next to go national'' thanks to its ''creative'' ''healthy fast food concept.'' Mr. Gogolak is survived by his wife, Nicole, two children, Graylin, five, and John, three, parents Peter and Kathy of Darien, CT, and younger brother Thomas. His father Peter was the NY Giants placekicker between 1966 and 1975 and is the team's all-time leading scorer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ''The Cottage in Darien'' (a home for the mentally handicapped) c/o Kelly Associates 780 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820 or to Whitefish Christian Academy 820 Ashar Ave., Whitefish, MT 59937.

SIEGEL--Herbert Allen, died peacefully at home on January 31 of cancer, surrounded by his beloved wife, Martha, his loving children, Noah and Miranda, and his devoted brother, Lloyd. Herbert grew up in the Bronx, where he formed life-long friendships. At an early age he showed scholarly interests and demonstrated superb athletic ability. In his youth he played a competitive match against the young Arthur Ashe and went on to play varsity tennis in college. He had a Ph.D. in classics and taught at The City University of New York and at NYU. An impresario of life, his interests were as eclectic as his wide group of friends. He was passionate about opera, orchids and cacti, travel, foreign cultures and languages. His nature was deeply empathetic and he did his utmost to alleviate the suffering of others. Herbert touched the lives of all who knew him and will be remembered for his independent spirit, his tenacious mind, his joyous zest for life, his delightful wit and, most of all, his deep devotion to family and friends. He passed on his love of chess to his son, Noah, who early on became a chess Master and he engendered in his daughter, Miranda, his talent for language and writing. He was translating an Argentinean Gaucho Epic, working as a dramaturge for Aida and mentoring Ph.D. candidates up until the time of his death. Funeral services will be held on Sunday February 3 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at 91 St) at 12 noon. The family will receive visitors on Sunday February 3 from 7 to 9pm and on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday (February 4, 5, 6) from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm, at the home of Martha Siegel, 134 East 93 St. Donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Association Education Fund in memory of Herbert Siegel, 30 Lincoln Center, NYC 10023.

WHITTELSEY--Frank C. III, of Vero Beach, Florida, and Sun Valley, Idaho, passed away peacefully on January 29, 2008, after a heroic fourteen-year battle with cancer. THE NEWS With sales, profit and stock price plunging at Sears, its chairman removed himself from daily oversight and pushed out the retailer's chief executive. BEHIND THE NEWS The changes by the hedge fund manager Edward S. Lambert, who orchestrated the combination of Sears and Kmart in 2005 and now leads Sears Holdings, followed a drop in share price that wiped out $14 billion in value in nine months. Analysts complained that Sears starved its stores for money while raising prices, a mishmash that alienated shoppers. Will the moves be enough? ''We just can't avoid the cliché 'rearranging the deck chairs on the Titantic,' '' said one analyst.

REBATE checks stole the headlines when the economic stimulus plan was announced last month, but for many residents of the New York City area, the plan could bring a more lasting gift: lower mortgage rates. The financial relief comes from the redefinition of jumbo loans, a category that currently includes all mortgages greater than $417,000. Because area home prices are so high, jumbo loans have often been the only option for buyers. But such mortgages carry interest rates of at least half a percentage point more than smaller loans.

ROWLAND--Stanley James Jr., 79. Former NY Times Assistant Editor for Religion; author of books and articles on nascent religious and ethical movements post-WWII, died January 28, Norwalk, CT. Jim Rowland was son of muralist, Stanley J. Rowland and educator, Harriet Rowland. Born 1928 in NYC, graduated King School, served in US Merchant Marine; attended Carleton College, earned his B.A. in English in 1952. His books include Land In Search Of God; Men For Others; Ethics, Crime And Redemption; Mission As Decision and Choose This Day. In 2006 he published his first novel, My Yankee Girl. Jim is survived by Nancy Rowland, his beloved wife of 25 years, by his brothers Jere and David, by six children and nine grandchildren. His wisdom, sense of humor, affection for family and friends and skill as storyteller will be treasured always by all who knew him.
Pop Kelefa Sanneh

ROSEN--Barbara Jane Middendorf. May 8, 1914-January 26, 2008. Barbara, 93, passed away peacefully at home. She was born in LA, CA, but grew up in Kansas City, MO. She graduated from the University of Missouri, (Kansas City) in 1936 with a B.A. in Sociology. In 1942, she received a MSW from Columbia University, worked in Manhattan, and married Max Rosen M.D. They raised their their five children in Rye, NY and Springfield, MO. Barbara spent the latter part of her life living with her sister in Prairie Village, KS. Barbara's beauty, wit, intelligence, generosity, compassion, friendship and creative abilities were legendary. She was an extremely talented artist in several media and a gifted poet. ''Elegy'' is a fitting excerpt from Thin Mask, a book of her poems (published by Crown, New York in 1939): ''When you are dead. I say. I shall not weep. I say that I shall be as I have been before. I wonder if I shall. I shall remember vividly, I know, The many little things you did, And I shall wonder, Ceaselessly, If you are laughing now, If you at last are glad. Forever.'' Barbara's life is not defined by the list of her accomplishments, but rather by the many lives she touched and influenced. She loved her parents, Karl Middendorf and Ethel Bown Middendorf and her stepmother, Olive. She treasured and loved her friends Jane Blaffer Owen, Frank Kelly and Philip Hughes. She is survived by her sister Martha Middendorf; her children: Janet Pearson of Springfield, MO, David Rosen of College Station, TX, Bill Rosen of Springfield, MO, Marti Olesen of Ponca, AR, and Nancy Rosen of Prairie Village, KS; her grandchildren: Jonathan Meyer, Jake, Mike, Joel and Josh Pearson, Sarah (Garrett), Laura, and Rachel Rosen, Meganne and Max Rosen, Nonah Olesen; and great-grandchildren: Ursula and Solomon Meyer, Aidan and Benjamin Garrett, and Maya Pearson. Barbara will be missed by her family and friends. A memorial is planned for March 15, 2008, in Springfield, MO. Donations can be made to The Barbara Rosen Creative Arts Program. Please contact drosen@psych.tamu.edu for more information.

Because of an editing error, an article on Page 38 of The Times Magazine this weekend about voting patterns among women refers incorrectly to the questions in a Norman Lear Center/Zogby International poll used to help discern those patterns. Respondents were asked to indicate their degree of agreement with certain statements; the questions were not true-or-false or open-ended.

FREEMAN--Josephine (Dody), January 31, 2008. The partners and entire family of the Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz LLP note with great sorrow the passing of Dody Freeman, the wife of our dear partner and founding member, John L. Freeman. Dody, married to John for 61 years, has been a part of the Wolf Haldenstein family throughout the years. Mother of David, Bill, and the late Betsy, Dody will be missed by all. Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz LLP FREEMAN--Josephine W. (Dody), 84, of Rye, on January 31, 2008. For 61 years the beloved wife of John L. Freeman. She is also survived by her son David and his wife Ellen of Larchmont; her son Bill and his wife Beth of Hillsborough, CA; her son-in-law Robert Garafola of New York City; her grandchildren Matt, Julie, Laura and Scott Freeman; and many nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her daughter Betsy. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, Dody was educated in London and Scarsdale, and graduated from Wheaton College, with which she remained involved throughout her life. She had many extraordinary talents; she was a gifted writer, gardener, poet and photographer. She served as the President of Family Service of Westchester and the YWCA of White Plains and was active with the Friends of Sarah Neuman. She believed deeply in the importance of education and sponsored scholarships at her alma mater. Always in charge at home, and always gracious, welcoming and warm to all who knew her. We will miss her deeply. Memorial services at 2:00pm Sunday at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th St. Contributions to the Josephine W. Freeman '44 Fund, Wheaton College, Norton, MA. FREEMAN--Josephine W. (Dody). The Board of Trustees, Management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital Lifecare System mourn the passing of dear friend and longtime supporter Dody Freeman. Wife of Life Trustee and former Board Chairman John Freeman and mother of current Trustee David, Dody's involvement centered at the Westchester Division (Sarah Neuman Center). She was an original member of the Friends of Sarah Neuman, an auxiliary dedicated to ensuring a high quality of resident life. She served as the group's historian and on numerous special event committees. She brought style, humor and intellect to all she did. Dody will be warmly remembered by all who had the pleasure to know and work with her. For over 70 years, the Freeman family has provided a legacy of support and leadership to Jewish Home. They have made many wonderful contributions and for that, we are grateful. Our thoughts will be with John, David and Ellen William and Beth, Robert Garafola and the entire Freeman family during their time of loss. Gene Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey Weiner, DSW President/CEO
Art Randy Kennedy

To the Editor: Re ''Green Buildings Don't Have to be New'' (Square Feet, Jan. 27):

GALPIN--Ruth Schwab, 84, of Southport, Conn., died January 31, after a sudden stroke. Daughter of the late Hermann C. Schwab and Ruth Bliss Bleecker and stepdaughter of Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker, she was the wife of Stephen K. Galpin, mother of four, a dedicated gardener, seamstress and leader of diverse charitable organizations. Mrs. Galpin served as president of the Sterling Widows' Home in Bridgeport, Conn.; on the Board of Managers of the Osborne Home, Rye, N.Y.; vestry member of Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport; and a Director of the Southport Conservancy and of FSW (Family Services Woodfield), Bridgeport. She had been president of two garden clubs: Rye Garden Club of Rye, N.Y., and Sasqua Garden Club of Southport, Conn., affiliates of the Garden Club of America. The Sasqua Garden Club established the Ruth Galpin Propagation Award in 2007 in her honor and awarded her its Horticulture Award three times. GCA awarded her its Club Medal of Merit, given for contributions of exceptional merit to the Club, in 2005; the Marcy Crutcher Zone Award for Horticultural Excellence in 2003; and in 1983 the Katherine B. Pitney Award. Born in New York City, she attended Chapin School there and graduated from Garrison Forest School in Garrison, Md. She and her family lived in Rye, N.Y., for 15 years before moving to Southport, Conn. 36 years ago. She is survived by her husband, Stephen K. Galpin; one son, Stephen K. Galpin, Jr. of Bernardsville N.J.; and three daughters, Mary G. Barnes of Guilford, Conn., Priscilla G. Twombly of Easton, Conn., and Susan G. Knowlton of Old Tappan, N.J., as well as 10 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She is survived as well by two brothers, Hermann C. Schwab of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., and Walter B. Schwab of Providence, R.I., and a sister, Anne Bleecker Corcos of Berkeley, Calif. A sister, Mary S. Brett, predeceased her. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, at 11 a.m. on Thursday, February 7, 2008. Contributions in her memory may be made to FSW (Family Services Woodfield), 475 Clinton Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06605.

He led the major leagues with 88 appearances.

The 18-year-old Sabine Lisicki, ranked 130th, stunned Lindsay Davenport, 6-1, 7-5, in the opening singles match of the Fed Cup quarterfinal between Germany and the United States on Saturday in San Diego. Davenport was playing in the United States for the first time in her comeback after the birth of her son in June. Davenport had won 19 straight Fed Cup singles matches.But Ashley Harkleroad, playing her first Fed Cup match, defeated Tatjana Malek, 6-1 6-3, to even the teams at 1-1 in the best-of-five series, which will be completed Sunday.

He is survived by parents Dr. Louis and Virginia Vaughn of Rochester, MN, beloved wife and best friend Susan Rottunda, daughter Rachel of Big Sky, MT, brothers Scott of Red Wing, MN, John of McLean, VA and Sam of Conifer, CO, two grandchildren Seasal and Trewyn. Deeply loved, Deeply missed. For 30 years Tim traveled the world on behalf of Medtronics Corporation assisting doctors as they implanted heart devices. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to YMCA of St. Paul, 2125 East Hennepin Ave, Minneapolis, MN 55413 or Centro Legal, 2610 University Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55114 or Nature Conservancy Minnesota, 1101 West River Parkway, Minneapolis, MN 55415. VAUGHN--Tim. We will miss your impish smile, your unconventional views, your boundless enthusiasm for new adventures and experiences, your keen and colorful recollections of life on the West Bank in the 60s and 70s, and, more than anything else the pleasure of your company. What a wonderful and loving man! You reached out graciously to all, friend and stranger alike. It's not true we sought your company for golf, squash or handball because we knew we could beat you, and winning was not as important to you as the companionship. We secretly always rooted for you. Friends like you are rare, Tim, and we will miss you dearly. Jonathan Harris, Tara Fujimoto Harris

FERRARI--Frank. Frank Ferrari passed away in early January of prostate cancer. Elsewhere, according to Ted Smyth, the Chief Administrative officer of Heinz World Headquarters, ''He was a courageous giant of diplomacy, who did so much to end the scourge of apartheid and to promote good relations between the United States and Africa.'' Born in 1928 in Jersey City, NJ, Frank Ferrari received a degree in business from New York University and settled in the Town of Mamaroneck in 1960. For 30 years he worked for the African-American Institute retiring as the vice president of the non-profit organization that promotes development in Africa, primarily through education and training. At the time of his death he was the president of Proventures, Inc., an international advisory group, which he had founded in 1995. ''We have lost a dear, a wonderful friend in the passing of Frank Ferrari,'' said Bishop Desmond Tutu. ''I seem to have known him forever. He was deeply committed to struggle against injustice and racism and was a superb ally in our anti-apartheid struggle. As a Vice President of the AfricanAmerican Institute he knew many of Africa's current crop of leaders, having known most of them when they were fighting against their colonial masters. He used to advise me about strategies for our own struggle and would arrange for me to see the UN Secretary General in NY and then set up meetings with Congressional leaders in Washington, D.C. I would have been totally out of my depth without him as my chaperone.'' Mr. Ferrari's international work brought him in contact with those fighting for independence in Zambia, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Namibia and South Africa and also with those fighting for civil rights in the United States. His son said he knew everyone--John Lewis, Julian Bond, Jesse Jackson, David Dinkins, Andrew Young, and Harry Belafonte. ''Everybody went to him, including Senator Ted Kennedy.'' President Thabo Mbeki wrote: ''For many of us, Frank's departure seems to mark the end of a particular epoch in the evolution both of our country and Africa. This is because as Africans, we have had the privilege of working with Frank over many decades.'' Mr. Ferrari is survived by his wife of 53 years, Mary Selby Ferrari; his four children: Paul, Maryann, John and Jim; and five grandchildren. Memorial donations may be sent to The Desmond Tutu Peace Foundation, 205 East 64th Street, Suite 503, NY, NY 10021 (tel: 212-750-5504) and Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10001-5004 (tel: 888392-0392).

POSPISIL--Ray, colleague of journalists and poets, is remembered dearly by them after his death last week at home in Brooklyn. Pospisil, 54, was born in Bogota, Colombia, and early in his life moved with his parents to Union, New Jersey. He spent most of his life in New York City. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Rutgers University in 1975, Pospisil began his career in energy and environmental journalism in 1981 working for Fairchild Publications. In 1984 he joined McGraw-Hill and later became a free lance journalist, working for two years in the early 1990s in San Francisco before returning to New York. Until his death, he worked chiefly for McGraw-Hill's stable of energy publications, although throughout his career he worked for other publishers in the United States and the United Kingdom. It was poetry, though, that was his passion. Pospisil's poems, which he often read for audiences in the East Village and elsewhere in Manhattan, were intensely personal, filled with vivid imagery and ranging from the humorous to the harrowing. His work has been published by Lyric, Iambs & Trochees, The Newport Review, Rogue Scholars and others. In 2006, his chapbook of poems, Some Time Before the Bell, was published by Modern Metrics Press. A collection of his work is scheduled to be published in Ireland by Seven Towers Publishing in 2009. In recent years, Pospisil enjoyed tutoring immigrants in how to read and write English at the Brooklyn Public Library. He is survived by a brother, Carl, sister-inlaw Mary, niece Brook and nephew Bryan, all of Daytona Beach, Florida. Other survivors include cousins Scott Fisher, of Hollywood, Florida; Joe and Irene Pospisil of New Jersey; and Sue Arave, of Columbia, South Carolina. The date for a memorial service has not been set.

CAMPAIGN STOPS For decades, presidential primaries have been settled by momentum. That is unlikely to happen on the Democratic side. Super-Duper-Looper Tuesday will almost certainly not settle the Democratic race because each side will emerge with many delegates. But how do you campaign in this environment? Do you try to win states? Do you focus on Congressional districts with high turnouts? Do you care about the national aggregate numbers next Tuesday?

The New York papers, not surprisingly, provide heavy coverage of the Giants’ improbable 17-14 victory in the Super Bowl, which denied the New England Patriots (and their quarterback with the supermodel girlfriend, Tom Brady) a chance at historic perfection and gave the New York team its first Super Bowl championship since 1991. The New York Post praises them as “Supermen!” while The Daily News blares “Champs” on their front covers. Giants quarterback Eli Manning, arguably played more like Brady than Brady himself, and was awarded the most valuable player award only a year after his older brother, Peyton Manning, won it while leading the Indianapolis Colts to the championship.The newspapers dissect the heart-stopping game (the lead switched three times during the final quarter). The Patriots defense crumbled in the fourth quarter, which proved telling given that the Giants’ aggressive defense shut down what was perhaps the best offense in the history of football. While the Giants were universally deemed the underdog, Plaxico Burress, who caught the game-winning touchdown, exhibited prescience in his pre-game prediction of a low-scoring game with a small margin of victory in favor of the Giants (off by the winning margin, off by the exact score, but close enough that everyone is praising him). The Giants had walked away with a sense of confidence and strategy after their 38-35 loss to the Patriots in December, feeling perhaps they knew how to beat the undefeated Patriots.

Then at 7 a.m. Tuesday, Mr. McCain is scheduled to appear with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a rally at Rockefeller Center Plaza. The candidates for the Democratic nomination are also in the New York region today.

In my job as associate editor at The Weekly Standard, I must get half a dozen e-mails a day from conservative readers who say they will never vote for John McCain for president. Conservative talk radio hosts and bloggers raise the idea that they will not support Senator McCain if he is the Republican nominee in the fall -- even if that means a Clinton Restoration. When Senator McCain speaks at this year's Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in a couple of weeks, it's likely he'll be booed in person, just as he was booed in absentia last year. I hate to turn every discussion of "The Moviegoer" into a discussion about New Orleans. It minimizes Walker Percy to perceive him as purely a Southern writer, or someone who just happened to write the greatest book about the city. But I can't resist pointing out in this final posting just how much of a love poem this book is to New Orleans, which could use one just about right now. "The streetlights make golden spaces inside the wet leaves of the live oaks," he writes, describing a parade night Uptown. "A south wind carries the smell of coffee from the Tchoupitoulas docks." Here's Percy on nightfall in Gentilly: "The sky is a deep bright ocean full of light and life. A mare's tail of cirrus cloud stands in high from the Gulf. High above the Lake a broken vee of ibises points for the marshes; they go suddenly white as they fly into the tilting salient of sunlight."

There's been talk here about what "The Moviegoer" generated. But I think it's also worth considering how it represents the end of something. As we've seen, Aunt Emily - standing in for William Alexander Percy - stands for the end of the Southern Way, for a certain noblesse oblige that had already been swept aside by history by the time the book was written, and which Percy can only salute in passing. And Binx himself represents a certain kind of self-conscious Southern protagonist who isn't quite an anti-hero but is self-conscious, well aware of his limitations and foibles - if he doesn't in fact revel in them. He's wounded and he knows it and he loves himself for it - he's a noble Confederate junior officer ill-equipped for life in the squalid Union, and proud of it. He too has been swept away by the tides of progress - and Percy's later fiction, from the perfectly-titled "The Last Gentleman" on, bears witness to his noble, doomed trajectory.

The 2008 presidential race has featured an early field of candidates in both parties, and a monumental block of early primaries. Those factors have produced an unprecedented level of fund-raising and spending in the year leading up to the election. President Bush, the only Republican candidate in 2004, was able to spend conservatively through 2003. A competitive field of Democratic candidates was reflected in earlier fund-raising and more aggressive spending through early 2003. Increased receipts may also be partly due to contribution limit increases. In 2004, individuals could give a candidate up to $2,000 in the primary; for 2008, the limit is $2,300.

While Eli Manning, a New Orleans hometown hero, was the Giants in the Super Bowl, hundreds of thousands of conflicted Carnival revelers tried to balance their desire to see the big game with watching the big parade.

Tiger Woods birdied his last two holes, and five of his last seven, for a seven-under-par 65 at the Dubai Desert Classic to start his season with two wins.

Steady rain washed out matches at the Fed Cup quarterfinal between Germany and the United States in San Diego, forcing organizers to try again Monday. The best-of-five series was tied, 1-1. The winner will move on to face defending champion Russia, which reached the semifinals by beating Israel. China and Spain also reached the semifinals.

Tyler Hansbrough had 22 points and a career-high 21 rebounds and No. 4 North Carolina beat host Florida State, 84-73, in overtime Sunday. The Tar Heels lost their starting point guard, Ty Lawson, four minutes into the game when he sprained his left ankle.
Todd Sowell had 19 points and 13 rebounds to lead St. Peter’s to a 78-68 victory against visiting Manhattan.
Shani Davis won the 1,500-meter race in Baselga di Pinè, Italy, at a speedskating World Cup event. Davis finished in 1:46.85, ahead of Simon Kuipers, the World Cup leader, and Mark Tuitert.

Eddie Sutton became the fourth N.C.A.A. Division I coach to win 800 games as San Francisco came back from a 19-point second-half deficit to beat host Pepperdine, 85-82, on Saturday. Sutton joined a group that also includes Bob Knight, Dean Smith, Adolph Rupp and Jim Phelan. He trails only Knight among active coaches.

Emily Brydon of Canada won a super-G for her first World Cup victory, while Lindsey Vonn just missed a top-three finish in St. Moritz, Switzerland. Vonn, who missed the podium by 0.01, is second in the World Cup standings, 89 points behind Nicole Hosp.

Bode Miller clinched his third super-combined World Cup title with a victory Sunday after Jean-Baptiste Grange failed to finish the second leg in Val d’Isère, France. Grange’s misstep gave Miller the win in the discipline standings before Miller finished first with a combined time of 2 minutes 18.45 seconds. Miller won his fifth World Cup event of the season and increased his lead in the overall World Cup standings.
Candace Parker dunked for the seventh time in her career and scored 20 points to help No. 2 Tennessee overcome a sluggish first half in a 79-51 victory against visiting Kentucky.
San Antonio bolstered its backcourt, signing point guard Damon Stoudamire. He negotiated a buyout with Memphis last week after falling behind two young players in the rotation.
Host Ghana and Ivory Coast reached the African Cup of Nations semifinals, staying on course to meet in the final next Sunday. Ghana beat Nigeria, 2-1, and Ivory Coast routed Guinea, 5-0.
Diplomats and analysts in the region worried that the escalating violence could lead to a civil war in Chad and a war between Chad and Sudan.
Expectations that circumcision among men would reduce the risk of their female sexual partners becoming infected with AIDS were refuted by a new study.
Losing five games in four states last week probably wrecked whatever chance the Knicks had of making a playoff run, but it did not douse their newly discovered self-esteem.
The Chinese government in the last week has worked as hard at public relations and crisis management, faced with the crippling effects of some of the most important snowfall in 50 years.
American forces acknowledged what appeared to be one of the deadliest cases of mistaken identity in recent weeks.
Some NATO diplomats indicated that the background of the new Hungarian secret services chief might make member countries less willing to share intelligence with one another.
Fayrouz, the great Lebanese diva, returned to Damascus for the first time in three decades, a performance some considered a betrayal.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,936 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:.
Peter Staudhammer was a wide-ranging aerospace engineer and executive who helped design instruments and engines used by NASA in landings on Mars and the Moon.
A taxi driver kept his sandwich warm underneath the hood of his cab in one of this week’s stories.
The hostages to be released are three former Colombian lawmakers that the rebel group said were in poor health.
What looked to be turning into a blowout victory for Montreal became a free-for-all in the second period as the Rangers stormed from three goals behind to claim their fifth victory in six games.

The network’s charge for access to content over the Internet has been troubling.
Some fear a less lucrative future for writers as studios turn to alternatives.
A serious discussion on pressing national issues may be good for the country. But it isn’t necessarily good television.
The Mac may be the cooler computer, but aren’t there more PC users in the world?
The British bank could face nationalization should an effort being led by Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s government fail to find a buyer.

Emergency construction needed to spare the historic Bolshoi Theater in Moscow from collapse has delayed its restoration for a year, and it is not scheduled to reopen until November 2009, Reuters reported.
Darius Danesh has been chosen to portray Rhett Butler in the London production of “Gone With the Wind.”
Richard Hatch, winner of $1 million in the first “Survivor” competition on CBS, has lost an appeal of his tax-evasion conviction, The Associated Press reported.
“Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour” ran away from the competition to capture the No. 1 ranking at North American box offices over the weekend.
The revival of “The Country Girl” finds its Broadway home, and James Gandolfini joins the cast of the film “Sexual Healing.”
“No Country for Old Men” received another major honor when it was selected best feature film by the Producers Guild of America.
German schools will begin distribution this week of a comic book intended to teach children about the Nazi era and the Holocaust, Reuters reported.
Anne Frank’s last living relative has voiced his disapproval of plans for a Spanish musical based on her renowned diary.
With its endorsement of Barack Obama, Rupert Murdoch and The New York Post tack in a different direction.
A battle royal shaping up between Barry Diller and John C. Malone over IAC/Interactive is not about their personal differences, despite the juicy material this provides.
CityDance Ensemble presented an impressively varied program of work by nine choreographers.
Report cards are in, and the grades are not good: New York City private schools have given The New York Sun an F.
In an industry that favors start-ups, a faint stodginess clings to Microsoft and Yahoo that could impede their  ability to draw top engineering talent.
Mad magazine enlists the talents of 10 Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonists for its two-page exposé, “Why George W. Bush Is in Favor of Global Warming.”
Name-squatting on the Internet is nothing new, but one public relations firm has found a novel use for it in promoting a nascent awards and networking program.
G.M.’s international strategy isn’t about focusing on a single brand. Instead, it wants its consumers to be able to choose from a fleet of them.
The rapper All $tar has been Nashville’s next big hip-hop thing for so long that the title has stopped seeming like a compliment.

Recent raids on museums in Southern California have stirred questions about why three federal agencies would devote four years to investigating what seems to be low-level smuggling and penny-ante tax fraud.
New albums by K. D. Lang, Nada Surf and Cuong Vu, among others.
Brooke Berman’s “Hunting and Gathering” is a slim and winsome comedy of urban nomads in search of stability.
James Levine conducted the Juilliard Orchestra in the “Symphonia: sum fluxae pretieum spei” and the Cello Concerto, a very large mouthful of Elliott Carter’s art.

The Queensland Gas Company, an Australian producer of natural gas from coal seams, and the BG Group of Britain plan to invest about 8 billion Australian dollars ($7.2 billion) in an export project in northeastern Australia to tap rising demand for the fuel.

Jay Leno has maintained his customary position atop the ratings in late-night television despite the Hollywood writers’ strike.

The album Marcus Roberts recreated from start to finish at the Allen Room is 18 years old, but its mannerisms don’t come from any particular era.
The “American Experience” documentary “Grand Central” is such an entertaining wallow for New York PBS viewers that it’s disconcerting to note that it was produced in Boston.

Diapers, wipes and formula — the basics — draw in other more lucrative purchases.

Ascendia Brands, Hamilton, N.J., named two agencies to handle assignments for brands like Baby Magic, Binaca, Calgon, the Healing Garden and Mr. Bubble, which the company acquired in 2005 and 2007. Hillman & Partners, New York, will handle advertising, with spending estimated at $10 million during the next 12 to 18 months, and Corbin & Associates, New York, will handle public relations.
A 32-yard pass by Eli Manning, the M.V.P., to David Tyree during the final minutes kept alive a drive that will live forever in Giants’ lore.
Manning’s game-winning scoring drive late in the fourth quarter gave the Giants a surprise victory in the Super Bowl, spoiling the Patriots’ perfect season.
There may be no stronger emotional current running through men’s fashion now than that offered by Tim Hamilton: personal nostalgia, a longing for what men wore as boys.

A longing for fresh faces and new ideas has overtaken Knox County so much so that many people here cannot wait to vote in the Super Tuesday primary. And it has nothing to do with who might be the next president.

In the unlikeliest of championship runs, the Giants hurdled a team that was supposed to be one for the ages.
The image-conscious N.F.L. got the matchup it wanted for Super Bowl XLII: two popular teams and two attractive quarterbacks with compelling stories.
No network can get a multihour pregame show right, and Fox didn’t, thanks to turning it into an “American Idol” promotion. But Fox did the football game very well.
New Yorkers have a history of gritting their teeth to the sound of cheerful celebrity safety exhortations. Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC anchor, is the latest in the trend.
As popular as Bill Clinton is among Democrats, there are warning signs that he needs to be managed.
Hobbled through much of the season, quiet through much of Super Bowl XLII, Plaxico Burress made good on his guarantee of a victory when it mattered most.
There was a glitch in the Patriots’ high-speed connection Sunday night. Because of increased traffic in the backfield, Tom Brady to Randy Moss was not working.
After a stellar first half in which New England limited the Giants to a field goal, its defense surrendered two touchdown passes to Eli Manning in a dramatic fourth quarter.
From the Patriots’ first possession, it was clear the Giants’ intention was to batter Tom Brady every chance they had. For much of the game, they succeeded.
As much as the 17-14 final score will be remembered, so too will the way the Giants managed to win a game that few expected them even to reach.
John McCain was striving to end the Republican race on Tuesday, while polls showed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead over Barack Obama was narrowing.
What might seem a mundane debate over health policy has taken on outsized importance because it is one of the few substantive differences between the two leading Democratic candidates.
There is more consensus than disagreement in the parties over tax, health and Iraq proposals, though the presidential candidates do disagree over means, priorities and each other’s sincerity.
Google is making an unusually aggressive effort to block Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid for Yahoo.
The subject of communism seems about as riveting and relevant to post-wall German high school students as the Holy Roman Empire.
The difference between the health care plans of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama could well be the difference between achieving universal health coverage and falling far short.
To the Editor: Re ''Instant Nutrition,'' by Susan Shepherd (Op-Ed, Jan. 30):

To the Editor: In ''So Many Places to Live, but So Far Out of Reach'' (news article, Jan. 27), you address one of New Orleans's recovery paradoxes: a housing shortage in a city filled with empty homes.

KAHN--Ezra, 84, of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved companion of Yona Lee Silverberg. Loving husband of the late Sheila Kahn. Devoted father to Howard and Meg Kahn; Kenneth and Amy Kahn; and Douglas Kahn. Adoring grandfather to Zachary, Danielle, and Rachel. Services are Tuesday, February 5 at 11am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY.

Within the family, for the first time you have different opinions. I've been in the family 30 years, and I've never seen that. GOV. ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER, on divisions in the Kennedy family over endorsing a Democratic presidential hopeful. [A17]

KARDON--Nataline Berman, M.D. Beloved sister, wife, mother, grandmother and physician lost her second battle with cancer January 25, 2008. Born in Los Angeles in 1942, she graduated from UCLA and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. She trained in Pediatrics and Genetics at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York. She was an Associate Clinical Professor in the Department of Genetics of the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine through her final illness. Her sister Jacqueline Blatt, her husband Stephen, her children David, Brian and Aaron, daughters-in-law Karen, Tali and Lisa and her grandchildren Jason, Jeremy, Rivka, Yair, Louis, Alissa and Noah mourn her loss. Contributions to Chai Lifeline in her honor will be appreciated.

An article on Friday about a federal judge's ruling absolving the Army Corps of Engineers of liability in the flooding of New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina misspelled the name of an activist group whose founder commented on the decision. It is Levees.org, not Leeves.org.

SEXTON--Gerald A., of Scarsdale died peacefully at home on February 1, 2008. Mr. Sexton was born in New York City on August 29, 1918 to Jere A. Sexton and Helen McCabe Sexton. Mr. Sexton was raised in New Rochelle where he attended Iona Grammar School and Iona Prep. In 1940 he graduated from the University of Notre Dame with a B.A. in Philosophy. He was a Captain in the Army during World War II. Mr. Sexton was a member of the American Stock Exchange where he worked as a Specialist with Sexton and Smith for 35 years. He raised his family in Mt. Kisco, NY, where he coached Little League, Babe Ruth League, and CYO basketball and in Larchmont, NY where he was active in the parents' associations of both Iona Prep and the School of the Holy Child, Rye. He was an active member of Our Lady of Fatima Parish in Scarsdale. He was an avid golfer and tennis player. Mr. Sexton was predeceased by his loving wife of 64 years Jeanne. He is survived by six children, Donna McGuane of Franklin, MA, Jeanne Nolan (Richard H. Nolan) of Bronxville, NY, Patricia Costello (Dennis R. Costello) of Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY, Katherine Stundis of East Greenwich, RI, Gerald A. Sexton, Jr. (Mary Pat) of Ridgefield, CT. and Michael R. Sexton (Janice) of North Attleboro, MA. Mr. Sexton is survived by 20 grandchildren and 15 greatgrandchildren who adored him. He is also survived by one brother William Sexton (Joan) of White Plains, NY, and one sister Mary Sexton of New Rochelle, NY. Calling hours are Monday, February 4th from 2:00pm-4:00pm and 7:00pm-9:00pm at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. The funeral mass will be 10:00am on Tuesday, February 5th, at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Lyndsey TLC Foundation, 25 Blackthorn Lane, White Plains, NY 10606.

HIMMEL--Arthur B., 84, of Chappaqua, NY, died Monday, January 28, 2008 in Sarasota, Florida. He was born on May 14, 1923 in Cleveland, Ohio, to Harry and Helene Himmel. Mr. Himmel served in the Marine Corps in World War II and graduated from Penn State. After the war, he started a business selling military surplus steel, which grew over the years into an international steel trading house called Artco Industrial Company. Mr. Himmel served on the Board of Directors of the American Institute for International Steel. His passions included tennis, horseback riding, travel and a fierce devotion to friends and family. He will be missed by his many friends and business associates around the world. Mr. Himmel is survived by his wife, Betty, his four children, Tony and Andrew of New York City, Jeffrey of New Canaan, Connecticut, and Carol Gibson, of Boulder, Colorado, six grandchildren, and a sister, Berenice Lutsker, of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

PARTEL--Rubin. Born May 11, 1919 in Czestochowa, Poland, died February 1, 2008 in New York, New York. Survived slave labor and the loss of his family in the Holocaust before immigrating to the United States in 1947 to begin a new life and family with his wife (of blessed memory), Frances Partel. A man of immense energy and kindness, he was admired and adored by his daughters, Harriet (Leonard) Schleifer and Helene (Harvey) Kaminski, and by his grandchildren, Adam and David Schleifer, and Frances and Philip Kaminski. They will forever mourn his loss and celebrate his legacy. Donations may be made to the American Jewish Committee and UJA-Federation.
WEINER--Sylvia Greenfield, on February 1, 2008 at the age of 95. Beloved wife, sister, aunt, companion, and friend. Services were held at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Center, NY.

ZAMBETTI--Felice L. (Phil) Former President, CEO of Stella D'Oro. Loving husband of Ada. Beloved father of Audrey Zinman, Jonathan, Claudia Fouty and the late Marc Zambetti. Devoted grandfather of Amanda, Katherine and Emily Zinman, Nicholas and Lindsey Fouty. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church on Tuesday, February 5, 2008 at 10am. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Ninety minutes after the game, Giants linebacker Antonio Pierce walked toward the exit, still dressed in his game pants and cleats. In lieu of his game jersey, he was wearing a championship T-shirt, but that was the only discernible change of clothing he bothered to make for the team bus back to the team hotel in Chandler. ''I'm not going to take my uniform off,'' Pierce said.

NARDELLI--Palma, born in New York City in 1912. Traveled as a young woman to Italy where she met and married Vito. A pioneer in her own country. She returned to the America she was so proud to call home. She landed Christmas Day, 1937, after a cold ocean voyage with her infant boys, Eugene and Camillo, bearing Laura born one week later. Her husband followed and they had one more son, Vito. This woman of faith and family kept an immaculate home and raised her children to be always impeccable in appearance and manner. Mass of Christian Burial was held today, 9:30am at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Ave, NY, NY 10021, would be appreciated.

8 P.M. (Sundance) MARC JACOBS & LOUIS VUITTON Fashion critics agree that Marc Jacobs -- at 44, the creative force behind both his own American line and the French house of Louis Vuitton -- may well be the most influential designer of his generation. This documentary by Loïc Prigent follows Mr. Jacobs, above, as he works on his spring 2007 ready-to-wear collections for the two labels and finds connections between such disparate themes as cookies and Cubism. The film is part of ''Ready to Watch,'' a six-night salute to Fashion Week; highlights include ''Karl Lagerfeld Is Never Happy Anyway,'' a profile of the Chanel designer, at 7:30 on Wednesday, and ''Yves Saint Laurent: 5 Avenue Marceau 75116 Paris,'' which trails the designer around his atelier for eight weeks, at 7:30 on Thursday. 7 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE The singer John Boutté joins Emeril Lagasse in the kitchen for a meal of New Orleans classics, including ''debris'' po' boys and Creole white beans with shrimp. In ''Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations'' at 10 on the Travel Channel Mr. Bourdain gnaws his way through the same city.

Set in 1984, the French director André Techiné's latest film, ''The Witnesses,'' is the story of four friends -- gay, straight, and in-between -- who deal with the recent arrival of AIDS. But it's not a didactic message movie, writes Stephen Holden. Moving at romantic comedy pace, the film ''sidesteps most of its opportunities for high drama, political sermonizing and the jerking of tears,'' he writes. ''In its light-handed way, 'The Witnesses' is profound.''

SHERIDAN--Wilhelmina S. (nee Heimgartner), 90, of Pearl River, NY, on February 2, 2008. Survived by children, Wilhelmina (Hanna) Sheridan of Rainbow Lake, NY, William Hanna of Marco Island, FL, Raymond Sheridan of Orangeburg, NY, Marion Arcamone of Nanuet, NY, Gerard Sheridan and Timothy Sheridan of Blauvelt, NY. Predeceased by husband Raymond Sheridan and first husband William Hanna. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10:00am, at St. Aedan's R.C. Church, Pearl River, NY. Burial at St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet, NY. Visiting is Tuesday from 7 to 9pm and Wednesday from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9pm at Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River, NY.
HELD--Jamie. Nine years, we miss and love you more than ever. Mom and Patty

For Microsoft, buying Yahoo and then trying to build a new Internet enterprise will be akin to trying to make a new spaceship out of an old Soyuz capsule and Skylab while hurtling through the cosmos. The parts are temperamental, the systems are delicate and the risk of catastrophic failure is ever-present. Here is a look at the important assets that would need combining: WEB SEARCH Microsoft and Yahoo have taken different technical approaches to search, and merging the best features from both would take years. Would Microsoft be willing to throw out its multibillion-dollar investment in search to go with Yahoo?

The director Richard Foreman is celebrating his 40th year as ''one of the most enduringly fertile bastions of the New York avant-garde,'' as Ben Brantley wrote in a review of his latest work, ''Deep Trance Behavior in Potatoland.'' (''As disciplined as a Balanchine ballet.'') If you've seen any of his phantasmagoric plays -- and if you're not as psychopharmacologically adventurous as he is -- you know they could use some explication. Tonight at the Housing Works Bookstore, Mr. Foreman will talk with his fellow downtown stalwart Eric Bogosian about remaining wild and weird and artistically potent after all these years. ''Reflections on Life as a Shaker-Upper,'' by Erik Piepenburg

ROTH--Jack M. Our sincere condolences to the Roth family in memory of Jack M. Roth who passed away Friday, February 1st. As President of our subsidiary, Clark & Wilkins Industries over four decades, Jack brought his devotion and leadership to the service of our company and our customers. We are as proud to have known and worked with Jack as our father Roy M. Flowers was when he invited Jack to serve as President in 1971. We are especially thankful for the support the entire Roth family provided to Jack and his work. Jack's accomplishments are truly theirs too. William E. Flowers, Board Chairman Kenneth F. Flowers, President The Clark & Wilkins Company ROTH--Jack M. Our sincere condolences to the Roth family in memory of our President, Jack M. Roth, who passed away Friday, February 1st. We gratefully express our appreciation for Jack's leadership and devotion to the company over four decades of service. As President, Jack not only burnished the legacy of his predecessors, but also created his own measure of success and accomplishment. He directed the growth of the company tenfold while extending its business lines, nurturing its employees and enriching its customer base. His stature in his vocation is exemplified by the trust we all held for him. We will miss Jack immeasurably. William E. Flowers, Board Chairman Kenneth F. Flowers, Treasurer Clark & Wilkins Industries, Inc.

The Guggenheim's Works & Process series, which gives artists the chance to talk and perform, gets an uptown/downtown meld tonight. The cellist Fred Sherry, a 40-year veteran and longtime supporter of contemporary composers, plays the music of John Zorn, who'll be on hand for the show-and-tell. So will Erik Friedlander, whom Ben Sisario recently called ''the premier cellist on the downtown music scene.'' The program includes the world premiere of Mr. Zorn's ''777,'' As well as an untitled work for the artist Joseph Cornell. Suitably arty fare, after all. ''An Avant-Gardist's View of America, as Seen From the Back Seat,'' by Ben Sisario

ECONOMIC INDICATORS The flow of economic news slows down this week. Reports will include factory orders for December (Monday), the Institute for Supply Management's service index for January (Tuesday), fourth-quarter productivity (Wednesday), consumer credit for December (Thursday) and wholesale trade for December (Friday). COMPANY REPORTS Media and consumer companies dominate earnings data this week. Reports will come from Archer Daniels Midland, Clorox, Humana, News Corporation, Wendy's International and Yum Brands (Monday); Ace, Avon Products, Boston Scientific, BP, NYSE Euronext, Toyota, Tyco International, Walt Disney and Whirlpool (Tuesday); Biogen Idec, Cisco Systems, Electronic Data Systems, Hyundai, IAC/InterActiveCorp, McClatchy, MetLife, Sara Lee, Time Warner, Tyco Electronics, Warner Music Group and Wrigley (Wednesday); Aetna, Aon, D. R. Horton, Deutsche Bank, Embarq, International Paper, PepsiCo and Unilever (Thursday); and Alcatel-Lucent and Weyerhaeuser (Friday).

NEHRER--Arthur, M.D. We mourn the passing of Dr. Arthur Nehrer, as the period of Sheloshim draws to a close. Arthur died on January 2nd after bravely battling illness for many months. He is deeply missed by both family and friends. As a devoted pediatrician on the Lower East Side, he cared for New York's children for several decades. He was also lovingly devoted to his late wife Naomi Lamport Nehrer, and to his parents, Joseph and Beatrice. He was the proud father of Dr. Jonathan (Sarah) and Roger (Robin). He adored his grandchildren, Joshua, Esther, Tovah, and Jennifer, who brought him much joy. He held deep affection for and countless conversations with his cousins Paul, Jerry, Joseph, Vicki, and Birchie. He leaves us with sweet and loving memories that will last all of our days.

The top-selling movies on DVD are often children's films, like ''Happy Feet,'' above, ''Ratatouille'' and ''Night at the Museum,'' which will be watched again and again by their young fans. Sequels to popular series, like Spider-Man, Harry Potter and Shrek, are also perennial best sellers. The DVDs that earned the most in rental revenue in 2007 were not the same as those that sold the most. Last year's top rentals included ''Blood Diamond,'' ''Shooter'' and ''The Illusionist,'' but only two from the best-seller list: ''Night at the Museum'' and ''The Departed.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN
SWANN--Christine Downey. Remembered with love, joy and laughter. Eleanor Downey Cooper

To the Editor: ''Combat Trauma Takes the Witness Stand'' (''War Torn'' series, front page, Jan. 27) brings welcome compassion to veterans trained to kill and who commit murder here at home. Now let's extend this type of understanding to other forms of violence racking our society.

Members of the Kalenjin ethnic group clashed yesterday with a rival group in the Sotik region of Kenya during a weekend of unrest. About 900 people have died since the ethnic fighting began in the aftermath of the nation's disputed presidential election in late December.

GREENBERG--Jordan Scott, beloved son and brother, a beautiful soul, past away unexpectedly on February 1st, at age 30. Jordan was employed by Morgan Stanley as a System Analyst. He was a graduate of Wesleyan University and Chapter Officer of Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Contributions in his memory to Doctors without Borders. He will live forever in our hearts and dreams. Liliane, Steven and Jennifer GREENBERG--Jordan. The New York City Trial Lawyers Association mourns the tragic loss of Jordan Greenberg, loving son of Liliane and Steven Greenberg.

LANTHIER--Margaret Sharon Tracey, of Melbourne, FL, died peacefully on February 2, 2008. Born March 22, 1918, she was predeceased in 1971 by her husband, Romuald G. Lanthier. She is survived by her son, Tracey, and daughters Toni (Russ) Pells, and Tina (Claude) Johnson, six loving grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. The family requests that donations in her memory be made to Wuesthoff Brevard Hospice, 8060 Spyglass Hill Road, Viera, FL 32940.

QUIGLEY--Charles Godfrey, on February 1st, 2008 at Alexandria, VA. A Brooklyn native and 50 year resident of Parkchester in the Bronx where he was an active member of St. Helena's Parish. Retired second VP of Chase Manhattan Bank where he was employed for 48 years. Graduate of the American Institute of Banking. Beloved husband of the late Margaret. Dear father of Robert and the late Gerard. Loving grandfather of Jeanne and Caroline of Alexandria, VA, Michael and great - grandson Langdon Charles of Wake Forest, NC. Visitation on Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9pm at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Ave, Bronx, NY. Funeral mass on Thursday, St. Helena's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

MAGNETTI--Donald. The Fordham Law School community mourns the loss of beloved teacher, colleague and friend, Donald L. Magnetti, who was taken from us on Saturday after a two year battle with illness. Donald served on our faculty for more than 25 years. He was warm, kind and generous of spirit. In quiet and always discreet ways, he performed countless acts of kindness for all of us. Donald was a giant in the classroom, who packed in students eager for the experience of studying with him. He graduated from Fordham College in 1963 and earned his Ph.D. in Near Eastern Studies from Johns Hopkins in 1969. He held a degree from the Woodstock Theological Center and served as a Catholic priest. Donald returned to Fordham to earn his law degree in 1979. After two years of practice at the law firm of Coudert Brothers, he joined our faculty in 1981. In addition to being a brilliant teacher of torts, Donald was a legendary authority on trusts and estates and an expert in Islamic Law as well. He is survived by his sister, Sister Joan Magnetti, rscj. The funeral mass will be held at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Connecticut on Saturday, February 9th at 11am. Additional details will be posted on the Fordham Law School website. We will miss him beyond words. William Michael Treanor Dean Fordham Law School MAGNETTI--Rev. Donald L., of New York City, died peacefully on February 2, 2008. Born August 6, 1940 he was a loyal and devoted son to his predeceased parents, Margaret Maher Magnetti and Gerald Charles Magnetti. He is survived by his sister, whom he loved dearly, Sister Joan Magnetti, rscj, Headmistress of Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, CT. Ordained a priest in 1970, he received his Ph.D. in Near Eastern Studies, Phi Beta Kappa from Johns Hopkins University, taught Old Testament and Semitic languages and served generously with Catholic Near East. Receiving a law degree from Fordham Law, he practiced with Coudert Brothers and joined the teaching Faculty at Fordham Law School. A brilliant and active professor of torts and trusts, he was admired by generations of lawyers, colleagues and friends. Most precious to him was his priesthood which allowed him to touch the lives of others with compassion and deep faith. Memorial Mass will be held at Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1177 King St., Greenwich, CT at 11am Saturday, February 9. Donations may be made to your charity of choice in Donald's memory.

PINCUS--Jan Strass. We mourn the loss of Jan Strass Pincus, former President of the Alumni Association of F.I.T. Tireless champion of education, gifted designer, with fabulous personal style and a formidable sense of humor. The Association thanks her for raising the organization's profile within the New York philanthropic community. Donations for a scholarship in her name can be made to the F.I.T. Alumni Association, 227 West 27th Street C204, NY, NY 10001. FITAA Executive Board John R. Jones Carrie Beylus Carole D'Arconte Gloria Maccaroni Ilene Glantz Vicki Guranowski PINCUS--Joanna Strass, on February 1, 2008, Jan died peacefully after a long and courageous battle with brain tumors. Amazing and vibrant to the end she was deeply loved and is survived by her husband Edward K. Pincus, retired State Supreme Court Justice, her son David, her daughter Andrea and son-inlaw Andrew Multer, and two adored grandchildren Jake and Sam Multer. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday February 6, 2008 at 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell 81st St. and Madison Ave. Jan served as President of the Alumni Association of F.I.T. for over a decade and continued to act as President Emarita until her death. In lieu of flower, donations may be made to the F.I.T. Alumni association for a Scholarship in her memory. Checks should be made payable to the F.I.T. Alumni association, 227 West 27th St. building C room 204 New York, NY 10001 Attn: Jan Strass Pincus Fund.

Later this week, the New Yorker writer George Packer will explore the lives of Iraqi translators in his new play, ''Betrayed.'' For a fuller picture, head to the Bleecker Street Theater where it's the last night to catch ''At War: American Playwrights Respond to Iraq.'' This is an interwoven story created by 10 young writers, including Jessica Blank and Erik Jensen (of ''The Exonerated'') and Rajiv Joseph ( of the recent ''Leopard and the Fox''). And the cast is just as extensive, with a rotating roster of TV and film stars like Bobby Cannavale, Bebe Neuwirth and Josh Hamilton. Some of the proceeds from ticket sales go to benefit Iraq and Afghan war veterans. ''A Reporter Finds Drama in Iraqis' Heartbreak,'' by Dexter Filkins

NECARSULMER--Henry, life long New Yorker, loving husband of Elizabeth Louise and adored father of Susan N. Goldsmith and John B. and Peter B. Necarsulmer, passed away peacefully on January 31, 2008 in his Manhattan home at the age of 93. A man who combined integrity, precision and the highest personal standards with great wit and an extraordinary commitment to family and friends, Henry was respected by all who knew him as a gentleman in the truest sense of the word. His family, and most especially Betty, his life partner for 61 years, celebrate in Henry a life well lived as husband, father, grandfather, family patriarch, respected role model and trusted friend. In 1935, Henry began his distinguished 62 year career on Wall Street as an investment banker with Kuhn, Loeb & Co., where he served as Managing Partner from 1969 to 1977. He was an architect of the creation of Lehman Brothers, Kuhn, Loeb, Inc. in 1977, one of the earliest mergers of two major Wall Street investmentbanking institutions. From 1977 until 1990, Henry served as a Managing Director and Advisory Director of Lehman Brothers, Kuhn, Loeb, Inc., and as a Consultant to Lehman Brothers, Inc. until 1997, when he retired at the youthful age of 82. During his career, Henry was the principal investment banker for, among others, Westinghouse Electric, Bethlehem Steel, Rockwell, Polaroid, Uniroyal and GATX. He served on many corporate boards, but none gave him more pleasure than his two decades of service to Polaroid where he was also a valued friend of inventor and company founder Dr. Edwin H. Land. Henry graduated from Dartmouth College in 1934, and served to Captain, Finance Department, in the U.S. Army from 1942 to 1946. Like his father Edward before him, he served for many years as a Director of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York. Henry was the son of Edward Necarsulmer and Manuela Maas, and brother of Edward Jr. and Robert, previously deceased. In addition to his wife and three children, he is survived by son-in-law John S. Goldsmith, daughters-in-law Helene Calvet and Susan A. Thurman, grandchildren Alison B. Ferrer, Matthew A. Dallin, Amanda M. Necarsulmer and Alexis M. Necarsulmer, and many loving nieces and nephews. Henry's life will be celebrated at a family gathering. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, friends of Henry consider making a donation either to the Jewish Child Care Association, 120 Wall Street, NY, NY 10005, or to Dartmouth College Alumni Association, 6068 Blunt Alumni Center, Hanover, NH 03755.

With deep hearts and hugs and kisses Love, Howard, Jimmy, and Bobby EMDEN--Jeffrey. Our ''cooldude'' who danced to his own beat and lived life his way. You fought hard, and left us all too soon. You were very special to us all in many different ways. our wacky crazy times brought us close together although separated by great distance. You left this world with dignity and pride and we will always respect and love you. Steven P. Jobs of Apple said last month that the Kindle electronic book reader from Amazon was dead on arrival because Americans have largely abandoned reading. Now, Amazon wants the naysayers like Mr. Jobs to listen up -- literally. On Thursday, Amazon said that it had agreed to buy Audible, the Web's largest provider of downloadable audiobooks, for $300 million. Amazon isn't saying much about what it will do with the company, but bringing audiobooks directly to its Web site and to the Kindle is the obvious first step.

FEISS--Gertrude L., died February 2, 2008. Born in Cleveland, OH in 1919. Studied at Smith and Cranbrook. Served in the Marine Corp. in WWII. Long resident near, and a friend of, Gramercy Park. Artist, illustrator, teacher, longtime member of her local Democratic club, lover of gardens, the Founding Fathers, Jane Austin. Friends wishing to remember her might make a donation to Children of Bellevue at Bellevue Hospital Center.

The 2008 presidential race has featured an early field of candidates in both parties, and a monumental block of early primaries. Those factors have produced an unprecedented level of fund-raising and spending in the year leading up to the election. President Bush, the only Republican candidate in 2004, was able to spend conservatively through 2003. A competitive field of Democratic candidates was reflected in earlier fund-raising and more aggressive spending through early 2003. Increased receipts may also be partly due to contribution limit increases. In 2004, individuals could give a candidate up to $2,000 in the primary; for 2008, the limit is $2,300.

LEVIN--Martin, born in Newark in 1918, of South Orange, NJ, died on February 2nd at home, surrounded by his family in Palm Beach, FL. He was a prominent real estate developer and philanthropist who shared his business success with the Jewish community and the community at large. He exemplified the best of philanthropy. Locally, he provided generous support of the Metrowest JCC, of which he also served as president. Martin was a major benefactor of the Jewish Federation. The Joint Distribution Committee was one of his most cherished causes the helps Jews in need in Israel and worldwide. While president of the Metrowest Jewish Community Foundation, he helped transform annual gifts to planned gifts and endowments and was a trustee of St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, NJ. He graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1940, and was a Major in the US Army Air Corps during WWII. He was a great bridge player and a talented weaver. He and his wife Vivian endowed the Martin & Vivian Levin Center for the Normal & Psychopathological Development of the Child & Adolescent at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. He is survived by his wife, Vivian, son Alan, son David and daughter - in - law Roberta, daughter Susan, stepdaughter and son-in-law Jan and David Ball, stepson Richard Frieland, grandchildren Tara Levin, Matthew and Rebecca Levin, Jonathan and Jessica Ball, Abe Wortman and Lily Levin, and great - grand daughters Maya and Lucy Mack. Funeral services will be at Congregation B'nai Abraham, 300 East Northfield Rd., Livingston, NJ at 10:00am Monday, February 4th. Donations may be sent to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, 561848-5200.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — Primary day in Chappaqua. It feels like Transylvania with a thick soupy fog hugging the ground. There’s a winter display at Hillary Rodham Clinton’s polling place at Grafflin Elementary School that says “Let It Snow,” surrounded by snowmen. It has the doleful air of one of those global warming winter days, but the mild weather is something of a blessing for the Clinton faithful, about 30 or so who show up with their blue Hillary signs to greet the candidate when she arrives to vote shortly before 8 a.m. The Clintons show up — Hillary in a brown suit, Bill in blue, Chelsea in a dark coat — to enthusiastic applause and are greeted by Evan Norris, a retired doctor turned volunteer firefighter who has been taking pictures of the assembled cameras waiting to take pictures of the Clintons.

This week I'm introducing the first article in what will be an occasional series about mutation. And yes, I admit it: I'm obsessed with mutation (which is why I've already alluded to it in a couple of earlier articles). The reason is that mutations to DNA form the raw material for evolution. It's wondrous to think that mutations, accumulated over billions of years through the action of natural selection and the other forces of evolution, have produced such diverse life forms as vampire squid, coconut palms, death cap mushrooms, giant Gippsland earthworms, Etruscan pygmy shrews, E. coli - and us.

Welcome to Bitten, a blog about food and cooking that will also use food as a window into the world. We're going to look at great food made with everyday ingredients and readily achievable techniques -- as The Minimalist has been doing for a decade -- not food as something to be admired from afar, but as a part of daily life.

In today's Minimalist, I 'fess up to having been an idiot when it comes to sun-dried tomatoes. But the pendulum has swung: I am now such a fan that I put them in anything with water, or any other liquid.

Once you understand that the batter essentially holds the more important ingredients of this pancake together, and once you get the hang of what that batter looks like, you're free to start adding food almost at will, as you would with a soup or salad.

Or, do Brussels sprouts and plantains make sense together? I'm not big on fusion food, at least when it's contrived, but I'm huge on spontaneity, and this sure counts for that. The "recipe" is based on what was sitting in the refrigerator and on the counter, along with my new and profound love for poblanos and my belief that garlic helps almost everything. It works: you have different textures, the odd sweetness of the plantains and the grassiness of the Brussels sprouts, and the mild but distinctive heat of the poblanos. I may never make it again, but I enjoyed it.

I'm glad we have a show in New York that's generating some debate-Halston, of course. There's nothing in my review tomorrow about Jil Sander, though I did wonder if the tulle-veiled tweed and embroidered skirts, etc. at Herrera and Oscar started with Raf Simons' transparency collection for spring. I think the only point of comparison between Sander and Halston is that both designers had to clean house a bit with their brands, find the main points. (I hate that dreaded word DNA; I expect to find bodies.) After two or three seasons of establishing a line and his tailoring, as well as the great dresses, Simons has felt free to do more with Jil. I suspect Marco Zanini will do the same thing. The guy is smart, and not affected by the side-show dramas. And look at all the boxy, flaring and embellished jackets we've seen on the runways this week-the oversized grunge plaid at Preen, the A-line shapes at Herrera, the tweed numbers at Oscar. And who does a super-simple, sharp-shouldered, one-button jacket with a slim skirt (on Freja) and makes it look new? Mister Zanini. That was my favorite look in the show. It's all about knowing what to eliminate. I agree with Marco about the 70s context thing, though I looked at it differently in the review. Halson was not about the furnishings; he was about the architecture: line and cut, and color for visual impact and warmth. So what was Liza M. doing in the front row? Why do the new owners feel they have to sell Halston by telling the history? It's such an old approach.

KUMASI, Ghana - African soccer fans love goals. This may seem self-evident - who doesn't love goals? But Africans have a unique desire to see joyful, attacking soccer that leads to bunches of goals. And they dread a scoreless affair. CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. -- Primary day in Chappaqua. It feels like Transylvania with a thick soupy fog hugging the ground. There's a winter display at Hillary Rodham Clinton's polling place at Grafflin Elementary School that says "Let It Snow," surrounded by snowmen. It has the doleful air of one of those global warming winter days, but the mild weather is something of a blessing for the Clinton faithful, about 30 or so who show up with their blue Hillary signs to greet the candidate when she arrives to vote shortly before 8 a.m. The Clintons show up -- Hillary in a brown suit, Bill in blue, Chelsea in a dark coat -- to enthusiastic applause and are greeted by Evan Norris, a retired doctor turned volunteer firefighter who has been taking pictures of the assembled cameras waiting to take pictures of the Clintons.

Last week I wrote about Ireland's plastic bag tax, enacted in 2002, which now requires consumers to pay 22 euro cents at the cash register for every plastic bag they take out of the store. It has cut down on plastic bag use in that country by well over 90 percent. Consumers I spoke with - not at all green types - said the "plas tax" had helped cure them of a bad habit. Retailers, at first resistant, now love it, too: They no longer have to buy and store millions of plastic bags. Revenue from the tax is used for environmental enforcement and cleanup.
