PHOENIX -- Perhaps it was inevitable, given the stakes and the presence of thousands of Giants and Patriots fans side by side, that some of the energy in the ??-seat University of Phoenix stadium would funnel into the intense Boston-New York sports rivalry. Chants of “18-1” increased Sunday night as the Giants’ Super Bowl upset became secure, a mockery reminiscent of the “1918” chant Yankee fans inflicted for so many year on their Red Sox counterparts. There were predictable retorts: “Yankees Stink”, or its equivalent. When they played “New York, New York” over the loudspeaker after the award presentation, it must have reminded New Englanders of the swagger that accompanied so many Yankee victories over the years.

The Giants 17-14 victory on Sunday was an instant classic, a history-making and history-breaking game that sports fans will place alongside the greatest N.F.L. dramas of all time. We can’t get enough of it, and that’s why we put together this special edition of the newsletter. Enjoy, and see you on Thursday.

The ability to be flagrantly wrong, after all, is a skill set that ought to travel particularly well to new and unfamiliar territory.

Zach Parise scored 37 seconds into overtime to cap a furious late rally by the Devils on Monday night in a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Prudential Center in Newark.

James Wright, the president of Dartmouth College, will step down in June 2009, the college announced. Mr. Wright, 68, has been Dartmouth president for 10 years and a member of the college’s faculty since 1969. A professor of history, he also served as dean of the faculty and provost. During his tenure, the number of black and Latino students increased at Dartmouth, as did the number of undergraduates from low-income households.

The police in Virginia Beach plan to drop a misdemeanor obscenity charge filed against the manager of an Abercrombie & Fitch clothing store that displayed two photos of scantily clad men and a woman, a city attorney said. The police said they confiscated the photos from the Lynnhaven Mall store on Saturday after some customers complained and Abercrombie management did not heed warnings to remove the images of three shirtless young men, with one man’s upper buttocks showing, and of a woman whose breast was mostly exposed. Deputy City Attorney Mark Stiles said the photos might technically meet the nudity portion of city code. But he said it would be difficult to meet the other standards of the law: that the display had to appeal to prurient interests, lack redeeming artistic merit and be offensive to prevailing community standards.

A body found in western North Carolina is a missing hiker believed to be a victim of the man who pleaded guilty in a Georgia killing, a sheriff said. The skeletal remains found Saturday by a hunter in Macon County were identified as belonging to John Bryant, who disappeared in October with his wife, Irene, while they were hiking in the Pisgah National Forest, Sheriff David Mahoney of Transylvania County said. Irene Bryant’s body was found near a hiking trail in November. Sheriff Mahoney has said he believes the person responsible for their deaths is Gary M. Hilton, 61, who pleaded guilty last week to murdering a hiker in Georgia. After that plea, Mr. Hilton was immediately sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole after 30 years.

Two skiers missing for two days near Lake Tahoe after a winter storm were rescued after they burrowed into snow caves and huddled together for warmth, the authorities said. The men, described as expert skiers, were spotted by the crew of a Placer County Sheriff’s Department helicopter about seven miles from the Alpine Meadows ski resort, just west of Lake Tahoe. The men, Patrick Frost, 35, and Christopher Gerwig, 32, both of San Francisco, were picked up near Hell Hole Reservoir and taken to Sutter Auburn Faith Hospital, where a spokeswoman said they had suffered “really minor, minor” frostbite.

Nearly five years after the emaciated body of a little boy was found in a trash bin in Houston, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the case, releasing an autopsy photograph and a sketch, left, of the child’s face and increasing the reward for information to $25,000. The victim was possibly Hispanic, between 3 and 6 years old, with a surgical scar on his neck suggesting possible hospitalization and two scars on his abdomen, the F.B.I. said. He was wearing a disposable diaper and was wrapped in a gray blanket inside a red-and-white checkered plastic bag. The cause of death was malnutrition and dehydration, but the autopsy found no signs of other abuse or injuries, the F.B.I. said. The public appeal was born of desperation, Andrew R. Bland III, the bureau’s special agent in charge of the Houston Division, acknowledged. “Quite frankly,” he said, “this is a cold case.”.
After a 93-76 victory over Duke, coupled with a double-overtime victory against Maryland last month, the Tar Heels are the only undefeated team in the conference.

An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at the French bank Société Générale, misstated the number of workers dismissed in connection with the scandal. Only one of the employees mentioned — Luc François, global head of equities and derivatives activities — will leave or move to another position as a result of the investigation. Two other employees, Marc Breillout and Grégoire Varenne, left for reasons unrelated to the scandal and a third, Christophe Mianné, remains at Société Générale — they were not dismissed as a result of the Kerviel inquiry.
Edgar Sosa scored 18 points, Jerry Smith added 12 and the Cardinals locked up the Golden Eagles again, winning, 71-57, Monday night to end No. 16 Marquette’s 14-game home winning streak.
The Nets acquired Memphis Grizzlies forward Stromile Swift on Monday for center Jason Collins and financial considerations.

The Detroit Tigers and Curtis Granderson agreed to a five-year, $30.25 million contract that includes a club option for 2013 that could make the deal worth up to $43.25 million.Granderson, 26, had a breakout season last year, hitting .302 with 23 home runs and 74 runs batted in.

In separate races Tuesday, 160 men and 64 women will sprint from the lobby of the Empire State Building to the 86th-floor observation deck in the 31st annual Empire State Building Run-Up, covering 1,576 steps along the way. “I run it just for fun,” said Suzy Walsham, a world-class runner in the 800 and 1,500 meters who won last year’s women’s race. “But it’s not that much fun while I’m running it. But once you get to the top, it’s an amazing view.”Thomas Dold, a 23-year-old economics student from Germany, is the defending men’s champion.

Shaking off nerves, the 22-year-old United States Fed Cup rookie Ashley Harkleroad rallied from a 4-1 deficit in the second set to beat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki, 6-4, 7-5, in San Diego to clinch the quarterfinal match.Harkleroad’s victory followed Lindsay Davenport’s 6-1, 6-2 victory against 19-year-old Julia Goerges in reverse singles, sending the United States into a World Group semifinal road match against Russia, the defending Fed Cup champion, in April.The United States finished 4-1 against Germany after Davenport and Lisa Raymond won the doubles, 6-2, 6-0, over Tatjana Malek and Anna-Lena Groenefeld.

Alan Webb, the American record-holder in the mile, will run his first race of the year March 15 in the Central Park Challenge, the New York Road Runners announced. The race will also serve as the United States 8-kilometer men’s championship. The Road Runners said a women’s 8K (4.97 miles) invitational race for top American and international runners would precede the men’s race. The total prize money will be at least $70,000, plus $10,000 to anyone who establishes a United States 8K record.

Maurice Greene, the former Olympic and world champion in the 100 meters, announced Monday that he was retiring. He cited nagging injuries for his decision. “It’s a little sad for me but it’s happy at the same time because I’ve had a great career,” Greene, 33, said. “For the last couple of years, I’ve had nagging injuries that have stopped my training. So I think it’s better to just call it quits.”Greene was the top sprinter of the late 1990s and early 2000s. He set a then world record for the 100 meters in 1999 (9.79 seconds) and won the 100 at the Sydney Games in 2000. He still holds the indoor 60-meter world record at 6.39 seconds.

Stephane M’Bia and Cameroon needed extra time to beat Tunisia, 3-2, and reach the semifinals at the African Cup of Nations in Kumasi, Ghana.Defending champion Egypt also advanced, beating Angola, 2-1. Cameroon will face host Ghana and Egypt will play Ivory Coast in Thursday’s semifinals.

Formula One’s governing body, FIA, said the racial abuse aimed at Lewis Hamilton, Formula One’s first black driver, during testing in Barcelona, Spain, over the weekend could result in sanctions.Under FIA’s statutes, punishment can include removing races from the Grand Prix calendar. The Spanish Grand Prix is April 27 in Barcelona, and the European GP at Valencia, Spain, is Aug. 24.Formula One said it could take legal action against the spectators involved in the taunts.

Cyril Ramaphosa, a South African businessman who led the African National Congress’s negotiations to end apartheid in his country in the 1990s, withdrew as a mediator in crisis talks in Kenya after the government of President Mwai Kibaki said he would not be impartial because he had had business dealings with the top opposition leader, Raila Odinga. Mr. Ramaphosa denied that. He arrived in Nairobi on Friday to help Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, broker talks between Kenya’s opposing politicians. Talks continued without him. The sides pledged to help people return to their homes and to provide food and shelter for those displaced by the ethnic violence that broke out after with the Dec. 27 presidential election. The government also lifted a monthlong ban on live television broadcasts.

Both houses of Parliament met in joint session at the Palace of Versailles and approved a revision of the constitution necessary for ratification of the new, simplified European Union treaty. The vote paved the way for parliamentary ratification of the treaty on Thursday. France’s rejection of a proposed European Union constitution in a 2005 popular referendum paralyzed the union. The constitution has since been streamlined and renamed a treaty, and is being put before member nations. President Nicolas Sarkozy decided that this time Parliament would vote on the charter, diminishing the risk of rejection.

China’s main north-south highway, the Zhuhai-Beijing Expressway, reopened and was expected to ease the logjams that have stranded millions of bus and rail passengers after a series of exceptional snowstorms. Rail service was slowly returning to normal. About 80 trains left southern Guangzhou on Sunday with 210,000 passengers aboard, said the state-run newspaper The Southern Metropolis Daily. But a river of new travelers trying to get home for the Lunar New Year holiday this week flowed into the city on Monday, and the area around the main train station was still packed with people.

A 13-dish Mexican dinner in her honor. Then shark fin soup at a top Chinese restaurant. Next, a French meal featuring black truffles. Princess Masako, the wife of Crown Prince Naruhito, has been eating well, and being criticized in the tabloid press for violating the standards of imperial austerity as the economy shows signs of faltering. The lavish private outings have also prompted the tabloids to ask why the 44-year-old Harvard-educated princess, in whom depression was diagnosed four years ago, is still opting out of most of her official public duties.

Five men were convicted by a suburban London court of assisting in the failed terrorist attack on London’s transportation system on July 21, 2005, which sought to repeat the attacks that on July 7 that killed 52 people. The five — all Muslim immigrants from Africa between 25 and 30 — were sentenced to prison terms from 7 to 17 years for providing safe houses, passports, clothing and food after bombs planted in three subway stations and on a bus failed to explode. The two given the longest sentences, 12 and 17 years, were found guilty of knowing about the plot in advance. The court found that one lived above the “bomb factory” and helped dump incriminating evidence, including empty bottles of hydrogen peroxide, used in making the bombs, in bins outside his apartment complex. The judge, Paul Worsley, said laws setting the maximum sentences he imposed were “woefully inadequate for the enormity” of the plot. Four bomb-carriers in the failed attack were sentenced to life last year.
Relatives of the only survivor of a weekend shooting inside a clothing store said that all of the women inside the shop had been bound and then shot in the back of their heads.

UNITED ADDS A CHECKED-BAG FEE Saying that it was offering customers a “new, simplified checked-bag policy,” United Airlines said that it would charge $25 to check a second bag, starting May 5, for customers who travel domestically on advance purchase nonrefundable fares. The vast majority of coach passengers buy such fares, as opposed to the more expensive, fully refundable walk-up fares. United said the fee would generate more than $100 million a year “in cost savings and new revenue.” Most competitors allow coach passengers to check a second bag without charge. United’s fee policy also applies to travel to and from Canada; San Juan, P.R.; and St. Thomas, V.I., for tickets purchased starting this week. Passengers with Premier status or higher in United’s Mileage Plus frequent-flier program and those with Silver status or higher in the Star Alliance program will be exempt from the fee.

The police said the items, recovered during a search, may have been stolen. A spokesman said: “The value of the items is not known, but they look genuine. And if they have been stolen, then we hope that the original owner will recognize them and contact us.”.

The soprano Anna Netrebko, pregnant and engaged, has withdrawn from this summer’s Salzburg Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. She was scheduled to sing at the festival opposite the tenor Rolando Villazón in Gounod’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Ms. Netrebko, 36, a Russian-born Austrian citizen (right, with her finacé, the Uruguayan-born baritone Erwin Schrott, 35), is in Vienna, filming Puccini’s “Bohème” with Mr. Villazón as her leading man. She also was to sing in Massenet’s “Manon,” opening on April 4 at the Vienna State Opera, The Associated Press reported. Her manager, Jeffrey Vanderveen, said she “will keep her engagements as long as her doctors permit it.” Helga Rabl-Stadler, president of the Salzburg Festival, said: “The nicest reason for a cancellation is a child. Anna will receive the most beautiful bouquet of flowers from us.” The Metropolitan Opera said Ms. Netrebko has withdrawn from 10 performances of its revival of “Lucia di Lammermoor,” beginning Oct. 3, but said her seven performances in Massenet’s “Manon” in December and January remained undecided.

On a night in which Fox’s Super Bowl coverage won a resounding victory in the ratings, ABC, CBS and NBC struggled to attract even meager audiences during prime time. CBS fared best, finishing a very distant runner-up thanks in part to the strength of “60 Minutes,” which drew 5 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimate. This veteran news magazine followed a news special on the National Guard at 7 p.m., “CBS Reports” (3.3 million), while repeats of CBS’s “Shark” and “Cold Case” attracted 4.2 million and 6.1 million viewers, respectively, at 9 and 10 p.m. ABC, in third place for the night, outpaced CBS in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, getting a boost later in the night from the 2004 movie with Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro, “Meet the Fockers,” which averaged 4.1 million viewers from 9 to 11. NBC ranked fourth over all with four repeat hours of “The Biggest Loser,” which averaged 2.3 million viewers.

America’s tweens are going to get more of what they love. Disney Studios has decided to extend the run of “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour,” the 3-D movie that sold an estimated $29 million in tickets over the weekend, Variety reported. The run of the concert film, originally scheduled for one week, will be extended market by market, said Chuck Viane, Disney’s president for distribution. In some cities it may play two more weeks; in others only one. The film stars Miley Cyrus, the daughter of the country music singer Billy Ray Cyrus. She stars on the Disney Channel in the series “Hannah Montana,” for two years the top-rated cable show among children 6 to 14. In “Hannah Montana” Ms. Cyrus plays a teenager who lives a secret life at night as a pop star.

Sylvester Stallone, below, who has achieved new popularity in “Rambo,” has signed an agreement to direct and star in two more action films for the same producers, Reuters reported. Last year “Rocky Balboa,” the sixth of Mr. Stallone’s “Rocky” films, grossed $70 million and cost an estimated $24 million. ... The seventh annual Tribeca Film Festival will take place from April 23 to May 4. Tickets will be priced at $15 for evening and weekend screenings and $8 for daytime weekday and late night screenings. Some screenings, with panel discussions, will be priced at $25; and ticket packages, will also be available. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

As Britney Spears remained in a psychiatric ward in Los Angeles, court hearings on Monday dealt with the custody of her two small children and with the conservatorship of Ms. Spears and her estate that were granted last week to her father, James, and her lawyer, Andrew Wallete, The Associated Press reported. The news agency also reported that a person close to Ms. Spears said her stay had been extended for two weeks under a California law that allows patients to be kept for medical treatment if found to be gravely disabled or a danger to themselves or others. The closed-door custody hearing, involving Ms. Spears’s lawyers, conservators and her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, was continued until Feb. 19.

To encourage participation by people older than 60 in New York City’s arts offerings, a $1 million partnership between cultural organizations and centers for the elderly was announced yesterday by the city’s Department for the Aging, the Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York City Council. About 60 arts organizations will team up with more than 150 centers for the elderly in all five boroughs to provide a variety of programs, like jewelry design, storytelling, circus arts, horticulture, blues cabaret, creative writing, intergenerational theater and cinema. By 2030 one-fifth of the city’s population will be over 60, outnumbering school-age children, city officials said.

We extend our most sincere condolences to Dr. Norton, his wife, Rachel, and their daughters Julia and Margot; and to his sister, Dr. Karen Norton, her husband, Dr. Louis Sobel, and their children. NAPOLEON--Marie ''Bebe'' (nee Giordano), of Glen Cove, devoted wife of 66 years to Marty Napoleon, passed away peacefully on February 4th, 2008. Cherished mother of Jeanine Goldman and husband Steve, Marty Napoleon and wife Teresa; adoring grandmother of Cherie Goldman and husband Alex Inoa, Todd Goldman, Marty Warren and Brent Napoleon; adoring great-grandmother of Alexander Napoleon Inoa. Born May 15, 1921 in Brooklyn. Sister of Elizabeth Martorello, Richard Giordano and the late Philip Giordano. Services to be held February 5th, from 3-5 and 7-9pm at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, 220 Glen Street, Glen Cove, NY 11542, (516) 676-8600. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Foundation for Parkinson's Research, ATTN: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, NYC 10008-0780, (800)708-7644.

Four undersea communication cables in the Middle East have been cut in the last week, raising questions about the safety of the network that handles most Internet and telephone traffic. Most telecommunications specialists and cable operators say that sabotage seems unlikely, but it is unclear how the cable systems were damaged or whether the incidents were related. Two cables in the Persian Gulf were interrupted on Friday, and two cables in the Mediterranean were cut last week.

NEWMAN--Alvin L. On behalf of the Board of Directors, staff, volunteers, friends and supporters of the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, we mourn the passing of our benefactor, colleague and friend, Alvin L. Newman. Mr. Newman was a longtime member of Federation's Board of Directors and the Chair of its endowment program, The Foundation. His contributions of time and resources to Federation will benefit the lives of thousands for generations to come. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Frances, and their entire family. Arlene Kaufman, President Jeffrey L. Klein, Chief Executive Officer Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County NEWMAN--Alvin L., of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, (formerly of Great Neck, NY) died at home on February 3, 2008, two weeks shy of his 90th birthday. Adored husband of Frances (Staff/Greif); cherished brother of Charlotte; beloved father of Lloyd, Chuck, Peggy and Skip, Lillah, Ellen and Louise and fatherin-law of Donna, Libby, John and Rhonda, Steven and Charlie; treasured grandfather of Jeff, Dave, Shira, Danny, Pam, Michael, Jessie, Debbie, Sam, Ben, Tricia, Amy and Liza; dear brotherin-law, uncle and friend. Al will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Al graduated from the University of Iowa, Phi Beta Kappa. He served his country in WWII, rose to the rank of Major in the First Infantry Division and earned a Purple Heart. He married Patricia Rosoff in 1942. For three decades after the war he owned and operated Rosoff's Restaurant and Hotel, a Times Square landmark since 1899. In 1977 he married Frances. He fulfilled a lifelong dream at age 62 by earning a Juris Doctor from Fordham University Law School. He practiced law in New York and Florida. A founding member of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, he served as its president. He was instrumental in the construction of Temple Beth Am's new synagogue building in Jupiter, FL. His devotion to Judaism, Israel, social justice and educational opportunity was evident in his extensive work for Federation of Palm Beach County and other charities and organizations. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, February 7 at 11 am at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. A memorial service will be scheduled in Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, 4601 Community Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33417.

KAPLAN--Philip, died peacefully at home at age 78, on Sunday, February 3, surrounded by those who loved him. His larger than life presence touched those in both his private and professional lives. He was proud of his 50 year membership in the American Bar Association and the New York Bar Association. During the Civil Rights Era he traveled to the South to provide needed legal services. His law firm won thousands of draft resister cases during the Vietnam War. Phil was passionate about improving schools and served as president of Community School District 15 and then as President of the New York City Association of School Boards. He was the force behind closing New York City schools on Martin Luther King's Birthday before it was a national holiday. Phil was a wonderful husband to Esna Kaplan and Hindy List, a loving father to Karen and Michael Lefkowitz and David Kaplan, an adoring grandfather to Lee and Jaime Lefkowitz and Calli, and Sydney Kaplan. He will be sorely missed.

REED--Joan. The Executive Board, local presidents, staff and members of District Council 37, AFSCME, AFLCIO are deeply saddened by the sudden death of the longtime past president of Local 2054 New York City College Assistants. Reed was born in New Orleans, Louisiana and attended elementary and high school there. She also attended Louisiana State University before pursuing a career in retailing, rising to a position of Assistant Buyer in a large specialty store in New Orleans. After marrying and moving to New York, she stopped working long enough to raise three sons before working part-time at Queens College of the City University of New York. A dedicated trade unionist, Reed became the first Shop Steward of Local 2054 New York City College Assistants when District Council 37 of American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) organized CUNY part-time employees. In 1973, she was elected President of the local representing College Assistants throughout CUNYs 19 colleges. During her presidency and leadership, the membership of Local 2054 has grown from 300 to over 5,000. She held that position until retiring February 28, 2007. She was also a Vice President of DC 37. Joan Reed has served AFSCME as a member of the Judicial Panel and has helped organize clerical employees at the University of Connecticut and at Harvard University. She was a founding member of the District Council 37 Women's Committee,and was chair of the Education Committee. At the time of her death she was serving her first term as an AFSCME International Vice President. We will miss her unwavering devotion to the union and her gracious and generous spirit and our heartfelt sympathies go to her husband Michael, her three sons Jack, Marc and Adam and their wives and her beloved grandchildren. Lillian Roberts, Executive Director District Council 37 AFSCME, AFL-CIO

LEDERBERG--Joshua S. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Joshua S. Lederberg, fifth President of The Rockefeller University and recipient of the 1953 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. His seminal discovery, while a doctoral student, that a form of sexual reproduction occurs in bacteria, demonstrated that bacteria possess a genetic mechanism similar to that of higher organisms, including humans. This work earned him the Nobel Prize at the age of 33 and helped lay the foundation for the current revolution in molecular biology and biotechnology. He was President of The Rockefeller University from 1978 to 1990. During that time, the University recruited many world-class faculty, created the University Fellows Program, which brought outstanding young scientists to campus, and constructed a major new research building. Throughout his career, Dr. Lederberg took on important advisory roles in government. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Medicine. He served as scientific counselor to nine U.S. presidential administrations and many world leaders on issues ranging from cancer and emerging infectious diseases to space exploration and biological weapons disarmament. He was honored with the National Medal of Science and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Dr. Lederberg was a gifted teacher and mentor, and he will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife of 40 years, Dr. Marguerite S. Lederberg, his children, Anne Lederberg and David Kirsch, and his many colleagues on campus. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Frederick Seitz and Torsten N. Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti LEDERBERG--Joshua. The Ellison Medical Foundation, its Scientific Advisory Board, its staff and its more than 300 present and former Ellison Scholars mourn the loss of Dr. Joshua Lederberg. Dr. Lederberg died Saturday, February 2, 2008 at the age of 82. Dr. Lederberg was instrumental in the creation of The Ellison Medical Foundation. His great foresight and creative approach to scientific progress and his close relationship with Larry Ellison, Founder and CEO of Oracle Corporation led Mr. Ellison to fund scientists in basic research whose approach was innovative, often risky, and under-funded, but which would prove beneficial toward eliminating human disease and disability. In a series of wide ranging conversations Mr. Ellison and Dr. Lederberg discussed different fields of scholarship as a focus for the nascent foundation -''and aging was one that stuck,'' Dr. Lederberg said. ''It was clear it was an area that was not quite integrated into what most molecular biologists were doing.'' The result of these conversations was the creation of The Ellison Medical Foundation, the single largest philanthropic funding source for research on aging. Dr. Lederberg served as Chair of The Ellison Medical Foundation from its inception in 1998. The program has funded promising junior investigators as well as leading senior investigators, a number of whom, such as the late Seymour Benzer, were new to this field of research. Ellison Scholars have produced exciting new findings and have trained outstanding new investigators dedicated to research on basic mechanisms of biological aging. Dr. Lederberg, more than most of his contemporaries, realized that an understanding of these mechanisms had the potential to lead to rational preventive and therapeutic interventions for a very large number of major diseases of aging. He recruited a stellar group of fellow scientists for this effort by exhorting them ''Our job is to fund the new, the unconventional and to take chances that others won't. Our only criterion will be the best science and the best of scientists.'' Dr. Lederberg was President - Emeritus and Sackler Foundation Scholar at The Rockefeller University, New York. His life long research, for which he received the Nobel Prize in 1958, was on the genetic structure and function of microorganisms. Among his many honors, he was a member of the National Academy of Science, and was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1989. He long had a keen interest in international health, and was actively engaged in the building of international collaboration and collective defenses against emerging infections of global impact. His numerous awards, in addition to the Nobel Prize, included membership in the National Academy of Sciences, The National Medal of Science, and a Research Award of Distinction from the American Federation for Aging Research. He was particularly pleased to have been awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian award in the United States. The text of the formal citation presented at a ceremony held in the White House on December 15, 2006, succinctly summarized his amazing versatility and legacy: ''Dr. Joshua Lederberg has devoted his life to the advancement of human knowledge across a remarkable range of scientific endeavor. His work in bacterial genetics earned him a Nobel Prize and laid the groundwork for future progress in the study of genetics. He has helped develop advanced computer technology, worked with NASA in the search for life on Mars, and served as a distinguished scientific advisor to our Nation's policymakers. The United States honors Joshua Lederberg for his achievements in scientific discovery and his commitment to improving the lives of others.'' (From The White House, Office of the Press Secretary, December 15, 2006) The Ellison Medical Foundation will miss Josh's vision and great humanity. We convey our most sincere condolences to his wife, Dr. Marguerite Lederberg, whom we all love and admire, and his children, Anne Lederberg and David Kirsch. George M. Martin, M.D. Acting Chair, Scientific Advisory Board The Ellison Medical Foundation Richard L. Sprott, Ph.D. Executive Director, The Ellison Medical Foundation

KWITTKEN--John, M.D., Died on Saturday, February 2, 2008 in Scottsdale, AZ. John Kwittken was born in Brooklyn on February 4, 1930 to Alice and Harry Kwittken. He was a graduate of Indiana University, both undergrad and medical school. From 1957-59, he served as a captain in the United States Airforce as a pathologist, in Wiesbaden, Germany. Dr. Kwittken was an internationally renowned and respected dermatopathologist. He was the author of several landmark articles which were published in leading medical journals throughout his career. Dr. Kwittken had both a successful dermatology practice in Englewood, NJ, and a medical laboratory in Tenafly, NJ, for 16 years. He also taught at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City for several years. His later life was spent in Scottsdale, Arizona, where he worked as consulting pathologist and medical educator for the local Veterans Administration hospital, up until the time of his death. Dr. Kwittken is survived by his former wife, Marianne Renner Kwittken of Englewood, NJ, his children: Pamela Kwittken, M.D. of Kent, CT, Deborah Renner of New York City, Ilan Kwittken of Englewood, NJ, and Aaron Kwittken of Armonk, NY, son-inlaw Stephen Yu, M.D., daughter-in-law Tessa Kwittken, and daughter-in-law Sarah Weston. Survived by his grandchildren: Timothy and Jennifer Yu, Anna Kaufman, Renner and Lucy Kwittken. Survived by his brother Herb Kwittken, M.D. of Scottsdale, AZ, and sister Estelle Immerblum of Las Vegas, NV. Survived by nephews Andrew Kwittken of San Diego, CA, and Alex Immerblum of Pasadena, CA, and nieces Leslie Kwittken of Columbia, SC, and Susan Immerblum of Las Vegas, NV. In lieu of flowers, condolences may be expressed by making a donation in Dr. Kwittken's name to the American Heart Association by visiting: honor.americanheart.org.

An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at the French bank Société Générale, misstated the number of workers dismissed in connection with the scandal. Only one of the employees mentioned -- Luc François, global head of equities and derivatives activities -- will leave or move to another position as a result of the investigation. Two other employees, Marc Breillout and Grégoire Varenne, left for reasons unrelated to the scandal and a third, Christophe Mianné, remains at Société Générale -- they were not dismissed as a result of the Kerviel inquiry.

There was a hearing Tuesday on the complaint that Alliance Data Systems filed against Blackstone Group related to their faltering buyout agreement. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. set a tentative trial date for March 24, though it was a very slippery date.

It wasn’t a full-fledged victory party, but Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s supporters cheered each and every victory on Tuesday night from the packed ballroom of the Manhattan Center Studios on West 34th Street. Sitting on bleachers or mingling on the carpeted ballroom floor, with Bruce Springsteen and Tom Petty blaring from the speakers, hundreds of people watched returns from a large television screen tuned to CNN. Some clutched beer or wine, though many people may have been scared away from the prices at the cash bar ($8 for a Corona, for instance).Terry McAuliffe, the campaign chairman, hustled through the room wearing a tight smile and trailed by nervous-looking aides. Mrs. Clinton’s spokesman, Jay Carson, chatted with reporters and tried to play down expectations, suggesting that Senator Barack Obama was poised to win New Jersey.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton easily won in New York and New Jersey, but lost in Connecticut — a state she once expected to win easily — by a narrow margin to Senator Barack Obama. (Senator John McCain swept the Republican races in all three states.) Michael Powell of The Times credits Clinton’s coalition of women voters, Latinos and Democrats who say experience is the most important factor, but he notes surprising weaknesses in parts of that base. For example, Mr. Obama came within less than 2 percentage points of winning Brooklyn, one of the biggest Democratic counties in the nation.
So, did the “Obama Girl” actually vote for Barack Obama on Tuesday?

To honor a new Chinese zodiac cycle, the United States Postal Service has commissioned a series of 12 stamps — one for each of the dozen animals in the zodiac — from a Chinatown-born artist, Kam Mak. The stamps are being unveiled annually (a more slow-paced version of the United States Mint’s quarter collection) until 2019 and the first one, for the Year of the Rat, has recently been released for the Lunar New Year on Thursday.

This is a keeper. On the way home yesterday, I scored some lovely sea bass fillets, Savoy cabbage, and one of my favorite winter vegetables, sunchokes. I cooked the sunchokes as I often do: thin-sliced, in olive oil, thyme, garlic, and parsley (in the picture, the sliver of orange is a piece of habanero, which I was too timid to mince, but it contributed something). The cabbage I cut poached in meat stock, steamed the fish on top of that, and seasoned it with nothing but salt and pepper. Could not have been better.

Switching to the Republicans, the liberal Washington Post columnist Harold Meyerson is oddly giddy about John McCain's strong showing. "A more direct affront to the Republican strategy devised by Karl Rove -- to build support within the party's right-wing base and then try to win over just enough moderates to carry elections -- cannot be imagined," he insists. "McCain's whole campaign is anti-Rovian. His core supporters are Republican moderates and Republican-inclined independents, and then he picks off enough conservatives to prevail. Even if he didn't have a history of rocky relations with various right-wing leaders, the very trajectory of his campaign would pose a threat to the conservative movement, notwithstanding that McCain is philosophically an heir to Barry Goldwater."

Sure, Hillary Clinton had a better night than Barack Obama. But the biggest headline of the night was not her successes, it was a trifecta of good news for the Democrats.1. Turnout, Turnout, Turnout. It's almost become cliche in this primary season to note that Democratic turnout in primary states is topping G.O.P. turnout, but the difference on Tuesday was unbelievable, and especially noteworthy in some key battleground states for the fall. The Democratic vote exceeded the Republican vote by more than 200,000 in Missouri, by almost 100,000 in Georgia and by more than 50,000 in Tennessee -- all states that went Republican in the 2004 presidential election. And in what were once known as competitive states in American politics -- California, New Jersey and Illinois -- fuggetaboutit.

How many times in American history has a candidate won the black vote in a state, roughly split the white vote, and still lost the state by a whopping 10 percentage points? That's what happened to Barack Obama in California. He did well among whites, thanks to his support from white men. He won African-Americans. But he lost Asians and he lost by two-to-one margins among Latinos, who make up nearly a third of the Democratic vote.

Asian markets plunged after a new signal of U.S. recession prompted steep declines on Wall Street.
Epiphanny Prince scored a career-high 33 points, including 27 in the decisive second half, to lead Rutgers to a 73-71 victory Tuesday over top-ranked and previously unbeaten Connecticut.
The Kings, the worst team in the Western Conference, scored two goals before the Rangers could take two shots Tuesday night.
Tornadoes swept across Arkansas, Tennessee and Mississippi on Tuesday, killing at least five people.
LeBron James scored 33 points and barely missed a triple-double as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat visiting Boston for the second time this season, downing the Celtics, 114-113, on Tuesday night.
Teemu Selanne, a 37-year-old Finnish forward, put off retirement and rejoined the Ducks on Tuesday night just in time to help the Ducks defeat the Islanders.
The Democrats are facing a long nomination battle; Republicans are closer to rallying around a nominee.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about “African-American Lives 2,” a PBS series that explores the genealogy of prominent African-Americans, included an incomplete address for the genealogy Web site co-founded by the host of the series, Henry Louis Gates Jr. It is www.AfricanDNA.com, not AfricanDNA.com. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly at one point to the actor whose white great-great-grandfather sold land to his biracial sons. He is Morgan Freeman, not Mr. Morgan.

An article in Business Day on Monday about a French government report on risk controls at banks gave incorrect dates for the sale of the holdings built up at Société Générale by a rogue trader, Jérôme Kerviel. The bulk of the holdings were sold off on Jan. 21-22, not Jan. 20-21.

An article in Business Day on Friday about the business of buying and selling Internet domain names described incorrectly the investments of one private equity firm that has backed companies in the field. The firm, Oak Hill Capital Partners, invested in one such company, Oversee.net, but it did not invest in another, Demand Media. (A similarly named company, Oak Investment Partners, invested in Demand Media.).

A front-page article on Jan. 26 about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of prep schools in the United States, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the founding date of one of those schools. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. And Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., was founded in 1778, not 1781. An accompanying article about prep schools’ hiring of professionals to invest endowments and run capital campaigns misstated the given name and the surname of a New York consultant who helped the Children’s School in Stamford, Conn., raise $7 million. He is Timothy L. Hogen, not Tom Hogan.

A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about the Democratic presidential campaign misstated the given name of the president of CNN, who was in the control booth for Thursday’s Democratic debate. As the article noted, he is Jonathan Klein, not Joe. The article, in likening the lack of intensity in the debate to a brown bag lunch at a certain Washington policy research organization, misstated part of the organization’s name. It is the Brookings Institution, not Institute.

An obituary on Tuesday about Barry Morse, the actor who played the relentless detective in the 1960s television hit “The Fugitive,” misstated the name of the Canadian network he joined after moving to Canada in the early 1950s. It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not Company.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about a ruling giving absentee voters in New Jersey the right to cast another ballot if their candidate quit the presidential race misidentified, in some copies, the political affiliation of two candidates who dropped out. Representative Dennis Kucinich of Ohio and Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico are Democrats, not Republicans.

A front-page article on Jan. 26 about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of prep schools in the United States, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the founding date of one of those schools. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. And Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., was founded in 1778, not 1781. An accompanying article about prep schools’ hiring of professionals to invest endowments and run capital campaigns misstated the given name and the surname of a New York consultant who helped the Children’s School in Stamford, Conn., raise $7 million. He is Timothy L. Hogen, not Tom Hogan.

A music review in Sports on Monday about Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, who performed at halftime of the Super Bowl, and Alicia Keys, who performed before the game, referred incorrectly to Ms. Keys’s current album, “As I Am.” It fell to No. 2 on last week’s Billboard chart; the soundtrack for the movie “Juno” was No. 1.

The Shortcuts column in Business Day on Saturday, about elaborate marriage proposals, misspelled the residence of Elaine Pursey, a British woman whose husband proposed on the Wollman Rink in Central Park in Manhattan. She is from Berkshire, England — not Barkshire (though it is pronounced BARK-shire in England).
John McCain's strong performance on Tuesday is only the latest part of one of the most remarkable resurrection stories in recent American politics.
Breaking free of their traditional political obscurity, voters from around the New York region turned out to vote.
Congress can provide the necessary muscle to help the underfinanced and understaffed Consumer Product Safety Commission.
The re-election of Boris Tadic is a hopeful sign that many of Serbia’s voters are prepared to embrace a more constructive future.
A merger between Microsoft and Yahoo would boost competition online and create a more effective competitor to challenge Google’s dominance.
Any candidate — and any party — who presumes to unite this country, must first unite their own. That is how democracy is supposed to work.
Barack Obama is the Pied Piper of the race, walking off with more young voters than any other recent presidential candidate.

The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said that Bangladesh and Ethiopia had offered to lend helicopters to the new African Union-United Nations force for Darfur and that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan had dropped objections to Thai and Nepalese troops. Just 9,000 of the projected 26,000 troops are in Darfur because of the Sudanese government’s reluctance to approve non-African soldiers and the unwillingness of military powers to meet repeated requests from Mr. Ban for the 18 attack and 6 transport helicopters the force will need. John Sawers, Britain’s ambassador to the United Nations, said the developments were welcome but added, “Anyone who dealt with Sudan over the last several years will be wary of announcements of progress.”.
Honored at the 28th annual Thurman Munson Awards dinner at a Midtown hotel, Alex Rodriguez chatted up a surprise guest — defensive end Justin Tuck of the Super Bowl champion Giants.

The Turkish government added to the pressure on German officials to determine whether a deadly blaze in an apartment building in the southwestern German city of Ludwigshafen could have been a premeditated hate crime. The Turkish Foreign Ministry called for an “extensive investigation” into the disaster on Sunday, in which nine people, five of them children, were killed, and a baby was tossed from a third floor window to save its life. All were Turks. The German Interior Minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, accepted the Turkish government’s offer to send its own fire experts to take part in the investigation. A police spokesman said investigators had not been able to enter the building because it was so badly damaged that it was in danger of collapsing. Arson has not been ruled out. Investigators were interviewing two girls who said they saw a man start the fire. The police said the building was the target of an attack with Molotov cocktails in August 2006.

The eve of the Lunar New Year, the biggest holiday of the year, is Wednesday, and millions of people in cities that have had their electricity cut off for more than a week after blizzards and a deep freeze are expected to spend it without power. Chenzhou, a city of about four million in Hunan Province, began its 11th day without power or water on Tuesday. Even around cities that are now receiving electricity, officials say, many villages in the countryside remain without power, and it could be many days or weeks before it is restored.
President Bush called the Mexican president, Felipe Calderón, to talk about bilateral relations and give him a pat on the back for his efforts to stamp out drug cartels.

President Nicolas Sarkozy and his wife, Carla Bruni, won a lawsuit against Ryanair, the European low-cost airline, for the unauthorized use of their photograph in an ad. A judge in Paris ordered the airline to pay Mr. Sarkozy one euro in damages, the sum he had asked for. Ms. Bruni, a former model, was awarded 60,000 euros, about $88,000. She had sought 500,000 euros, or $732,000, what she said she would expect to earn for appearing in an ad. The couple filed the suit against the airline after the ad appeared in the newspaper Le Parisien last week, just days before they married on Saturday. A cartoon bubble above Ms. Bruni read: “With Ryanair, my whole family can come to my wedding.”.
The AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am will be only Padraig Harrington’s third tournament in the last 10 weeks, although he is working harder than ever to refine and slightly retool his swing.
Isolated problems were already cropping up as polls opened, and election officials were bracing for a long, exhausting night.
Sean Avery, acquired from the Los Angeles Kings one year ago, was probably one of the biggest factors in the Rangers’ furious drive to a playoff berth at the end of last season.
Sixth-ranked Georgetown used a strong first-half surge to defuse an upset bid by South Florida, earning a hard-fought 63-53 victory at home.
In his first game in a Lakers uniform, Pau Gasol scored 24 points and grabbed 12 rebounds in 35 minutes to help Los Angeles defeat the Nets on Tuesday night.
Dick Vitale’s health concerns are fading and he is preparing to call Wednesday night’s Duke-North Carolina game in Chapel Hill, his first broadcast in two months.
During a 10-minute conference call Tuesday, which began shortly after 3 p.m., Bill Belichick did not care to reflect much on Sunday’s events, or anything, for that matter.
The director of national intelligence said Al Qaeda is gaining in strength from its refuge in Pakistan.

Two companies, Japan Tobacco and Nissin Food Products, said that they would scrap a planned merger of their frozen food businesses in the wake of a food scare involving poisoned dumplings imported from China by Japan Tobacco. Chinese-made dumplings contaminated with pesticide have made 10 people in Japan sick and set off a food scare. The police in Japan have set up a joint task force to investigate the case on suspicion of attempted murder. Japan Tobacco has been seeking growth opportunities in the food industry to reduce its reliance on stagnating tobacco sales.
Pat Knight was too busy preparing for his opening game as the new coach at Texas Tech to show up for his first news conference since replacing his father.
Interviews across the country produced anecdotal evidence that some younger people carried their enthusiasm into the polling place.
CBS plans to announce on Wednesday that it is trying one of the first serious experiments with cellphone advertising that is customized for a person’s location.
Documents related to a whistle-blower lawsuit that led to a text-messaging sex scandal involving the mayor of Detroit must be released to the public, a judge ruled.
A state board unanimously rejected two private bids to buy about 9,200 acres of rugged state land in West Texas.
A lawsuit was filed over a Dallas suburb’s latest effort to keep out illegal immigrants by barring home rentals to people who cannot prove they are in the country legally.
The No. 2 commander in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, left, has been chosen to be the next Army vice chief of staff.

After and audit, the Education Department has allowed seven student loan companies to resume submitting bills for payments under a government subsidy program that was created to promote access to higher education.

Patients given the blood-clot preventer Plavix after a heart attack or after receiving a stent have a far higher risk of heart attack or death in the three months after they stop taking the drug, researchers said.
The “Red” campaign launched a year ago by rock star Bono has generated more than $22 million to fight H.I.V. and AIDS in Rwanda, but critics say not enough money is getting to clinics.
Sania Mirza’s immense popularity has brought with it intense and often hostile scrutiny both from fringe religious groups and from India’s newly aggressive television and print media.
Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday issued a replacement for a contentious Good Friday prayer, removing language that many Jewish groups found offensive but still calling for their conversion.
Roger Clemens arrived on Capitol Hill to give a sworn deposition that he hopes will help restore his reputation as the most decorated pitcher in baseball history.
Mr. Illy, who as chairman of Illycaffè, maker of an expensive brand of coffee, was renowned as a scientific perfectionist of coffee and as an evangelist of espresso.
Sioux Manufacturing of Fort Totten agreed to settle the suit that contended it had repeatedly shortchanged the armor in up to 2.2 million helmets for the military.
The bank solicited business from companies it knew had been accused of telemarketing crimes, documents show.
New York State tax officials have settled their case against the Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter, who they said owed three years’ worth of resident income taxes.

Birgit Fischer, a kayaker who won eight Olympic gold medals, will skip the Beijing Games because she has not trained enough. Fischer, a 45-year-old German, has competed at six Olympics. She also has four silver medals from the Olympics and 27 world championship titles.

Arkansas will ask the N.C.A.A. to allow the transfer quarterback Ryan Mallett to play immediately for the Razorbacks without sitting out a year. Mallett transferred from Michigan after Rich Rodriguez replaced the retiring coach Lloyd Carr. Mallett has three years of eligibility remaining.

The Macquarie Group, the securities firm, said that its chief executive, Allan Moss, would retire and be succeeded by Nicholas Moore. Mr. Moore is currently head of Macquarie Capital. The firm also forecast a 23 percent gain in full-year profit to 1.8 billion Australian dollars ($1.62 billion) on higher trading volumes. Mr. Moore, 49, who runs the division that generates more than 50 percent of profit, takes the top job May 24, the company said in a statement.

The free-agent first baseman Sean Casey completed an $800,000 contract with the Boston Red Sox to be their backup first baseman. Casey hit .296 with 4 homers and 54 R.B.I. in 143 games for Detroit last season.

The Monsanto Company said Japan, the Philippines and Taiwan had approved imports of its first new genetically modified soybeans in more than a decade. The seeds, Roundup Ready 2 Yield, increase yields by 7 percent to 11 percent compared with the first-generation Roundup Ready soybean seeds that have been sold since 1996, Monsanto said. The new plants, which resist Roundup weed killer, won regulatory approval in the United States and Canada in July, the company said. The product remains under review in the European Union, China and other export markets, Monsanto said.

Second baseman Freddy Sanchez, a two-time All-Star, signed a two-year, $11 million contract Tuesday with the Pittsburgh Pirates that included a 2010 option that could make the deal worth $18.4 million. Sanchez, 30, made $2.75 million last year and was seeking $4.9 million. The team offered $4.1 million.

The defending champions won again in the 31st annual Empire State Building Run-Up. Thomas Dolt, 23, of Germany won the men’s elite race for the third consecutive year, covering the 1,576 steps from the lobby to the 86th floor observation deck in 10 minutes 8 seconds. Rickey Gates of Boulder, Colo., was second. Suzy Walsham, 34, of Australia repeated as the women’s champion in 12:44.

The German truck maker MAN said its profit increased by 33 percent in the fourth quarter, powered by strong demand for its commercial vehicles, and forecast that earnings would continue to rise this year. MAN, which is based in Munich, said it earned 331 million euros ($490 million) in the October-December quarter, up from 248 million euros a year earlier. Total group sales rose 35 percent, to 5.23 billion euros ($7.7 billion) from 3.88 billion euros a year earlier. Sales of commercial vehicles rose 42 percent, to 3.6 billion euros ($5.3 billion). MAN said its fourth-quarter operating profit was up 78 percent, to 631 million euros ($935 million) from 354 million euros a year earlier.

Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter- point to an 11-year high, saying a “significant slowing in demand” is needed to cool the fastest inflation since 1991. The bank increased the target for the overnight cash rate to 7 percent and the bank’s governor, Glenn Stevens, said annual inflation, which has overshot the bank’s target, might accelerate further before moderating in 2009. Core inflation in Australia has breached the central bank’s 2 percent to 3 percent target for two consecutive quarters, forcing the Australian bank to raise rates for the third time in six months.

Industrial production in Spain posted the biggest contraction in more than five years in December as slower European growth curbed demand for Spanish goods. Production at factories, farms and mines fell 2.4 percent from a year earlier after adjusting for the number of days worked, following a 1 percent drop in November, the National Statistics Institute said.

A French court ordered the budget airline Ryanair on Tuesday to pay damages to President Nicolas Sarkozy and his new wife, Carla Bruni, left, for using their picture in an advertisement but the sum was less than Ms. Bruni had sought. The court ordered Ryanair to pay symbolic damages of 1 euro to Mr. Sarkozy and 60,000 euros ($88,870) to his wife. Ms. Bruni had been seeking damages of 500,000 euros. The pair’s lawyer said she planned to give the money to a charity providing food for the poor. Mr. Sarkozy and Ms. Bruni sued Ryanair, which is based in Ireland, over an ad for low-price tickets published last week in the Parisien newspaper.

Scott Podsednik, the catalyst of the White Sox’ world championship run in 2005, agreed to a minor league contract with the Colorado Rockies. Since leading Chicago to the championship, Podsednik has been slowed by injuries. He batted .243 with 12 steals and 30 runs in 62 games last season. In 2005, he batted .290 with 59 stolen bases, and hit 2 home runs in the playoffs.
Stocks plummeted after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession.

The defending champion Nadia Petrova was upset by Kateryna Bondarenko, 7-6 (4), 3-6, 6-4, in the first round of the Open Gaz de France in France. Amélie Mauresmo, a two-time winner, cruised past the American qualifier Julie Ditty, 6-1, 6-2.

Relief pitcher Brian Bruney and the Yankees agreed to a one-year, $725,000 contract. Bruney, a right-hander who turns 26 on Feb. 17, asked for $845,000 in arbitration and was offered $640,000. He made $395,545 last year, when he went 3-2 with a 4.68 earned run average in 58 appearances.
The opening night of Chinese New Year Splendor at Radio City Music Hall was seen as too political by some audience members.
The corner of Broadway and Wall Street turned into party central for legions of Giants fans.
Two entwined cases on the rights of Guantánamo detainees may converge in the Supreme Court.
The company that produced a commercial featuring two animated pandas speaking with what were intended as Chinese accents is withdrawing the ads after complaints.
The Bush administration hit a business tycoon linked to Myanmar’s military rulers with more financial sanctions on Tuesday.
Three times now, the photographs of Nixzmary Brown’s body have brought jurors to tears.
Several hundred Pakistani retired generals, admirals and servicemen gathered Tuesday and demanded that President Pervez Musharraf step down.
Terrelle Pryor, a quarterback considered by many to be the best player in the country, is expected to disclose his decision between Michigan and Ohio State on Wednesday.
In a sport in which tradition and recent success are among the most important springboards for recruiting, Old Dominion is trying to establish its program without benefit of either.
In a battle pitting two California passions — cars and beaches — against each other, a state panel will consider whether a highway can be built through a popular oceanfront state park.
A woman was killed and a man was critically injured in a fire that swept through an abandoned Harlem apartment building where they were squatters.
Congressional Democrats said they would not bow to pressure and simply make modest changes to the less expensive stimulus plan that was approved by the House last week.
The plans call for five additional floors of apartments above the 12 floors to be designed within the old building, built in 1884.
On a cold and snowy Feb. 6, 1958, a twin-propped charter flight carrying Manchester United home from a European Cup quarterfinal match in Yugoslavia crashed on its third takeoff attempt.
The diversified manufacturer said its fiscal first-quarter profit fell 54 percent from a year earlier, when it still owned its health care and electronics businesses.
The editor of Vanity Fair, Graydon Carter, said canceling its annual affair was the right thing to do, whether or not there was a breakthrough in the writers’ strike.
The title of a new Russian movie might well be “Love Story: The Putin Chronicles,” yet the producer is curiously adamant that it has nothing to do with Vladimir V. Putin and his wife.
Senator John McCain of Arizona captured the California primary and its windfall of delegates on Tuesday night, capping an evening of impressive victories.

A former Dow Jones & Company director and three associates will pay more than $24 million to settle charges that they traded illegally on inside knowledge of the News Corporation’s takeover of Dow Jones.
Alabama and Florida, which depend on water from Lake Lanier, argued Georgia had no legal right to go ahead with its plans to use more water from the reservoir.

NEWARK — When Kevin M. Ryan took over the child welfare system he had critiqued so persistently as New Jersey’s child advocate, he was seen as the white-hat reformer who just might be able to turn around a flawed system that faced a federal takeover. The “big question” at the time, said Richard Wexler, executive director of the National Coalition for Child Protection Reform, was: “Will he be allowed the time to do the job?”.
If approved, the local police in Danbury would work with the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency in rounding up workers who are in the country illegally.
The battle over Rio Tinto intensified after BHP Billiton increased its takeover offer to about $147 billion after a Chinese rival bought a stake last week.
Hurt by the housing slump, the home mortgage lender said  it lost $724 million in the fourth quarter.
Ukraine joined the World Trade Organization on Tuesday after 14 years of negotiations, a milestone for the former Soviet republic.
Excluding cancellations, 2007 was the worst on record for flight delays, with 24.2 percent of flights arriving late, compared with 23.9 percent in 2000.
New York University’s ambitious plan to merge with Polytechnic University in Brooklyn and acquire an engineering school is suddenly facing a rebellion.
The company said its net income rose to $156 million, or 59 cents a share, from $45 million, or 29 cents a share in the period a year earlier.
Frank Gehry’s problematic Santa Monica, Calif., shopping mall won’t be razed, but it’s losing its roof.
An Andy Warhol painting that a man tried to consign to Christie’s auction house turned out to be listed as stolen.
LaVaughn Robinson was a tap-dance virtuoso on the big-band circuit in the 1940s and ’50s who became a master teacher and a major force in tap’s revival.
Ritchie Capital will pay $40 million to settle investigations into its trading practices from 2001 to 2003, regulators and the company said.
About 100 pending cases were dismissed after the Rhode Island ruling, but they can still be refiled in juvenile court.
Last week, a football player from Nevada announced his commitment to play for the University of California. Then the university announced it had made no such offer.
The twice-delayed flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a major addition to the International Space Station, is set for liftoff Thursday.
The fee increase would help cover the cost of processing offering plans submitted to the attorney general’s office; such filings grew to 929 in 2006 from 299 in 2002.
We should hasten the enfranchisement of the generation born between 1980 and 1995 by lowering the voting age to 16.
Two new museums and a new traditional gate marking the city’s Chinatown will be completed this year, acknowledging the role minority groups have played in shaping Seattle and the region.
The strong presidential system that Afghanistan’s 2004 Constitution embodies has not served the country well.
The British oil giant said it would cut an additional 5,000 jobs by the middle of next year in an effort to slim management and make the company more efficient.
If banks of all sizes could regain their capital immediately and easily, it would be a tremendous benefit to the American economy.
Disney posted a quarterly profit far ahead of Wall Street targets on strong results at its theme park, media and consumer products groups, sending shares up 5 percent.
Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.
The candidates can now look forward to a comparatively relaxed schedule before the next big round of contests, on March 4.
Toyota said its profit rose 7.5 percent in the October-to-December quarter as its strategy of shifting its focus to emerging markets appears to be paying off.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,938 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:.
Once Tuesday’s voting is behind them, the candidates can look forward to a comparatively relaxed primary and caucus schedule ahead.
The Whirlpool Corporation said its fourth-quarter profit climbed 72 percent, helped by its acquisition of Maytag, an improved product mix and the weak dollar.
A review of the Chris Benz, Doo.Ri, Proenza Schouler, Thakoon fall collections in New York.
Andrea Chasanow and Nick Gentle picked last summer to search for a house, and that turned out to be a challenging time.

The rapper Snoop Dogg, below, who was denied a visa to enter Britain last year, said the ban had been lifted, the BBC reported. Speaking on “Larry King Live” on CNN last week, Snoop Dogg, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, said a judge “found me innocent, and now I’m able to go back there.” The Home Office said it was unable to comment on individual cases. The entertainer was arrested in 2006 in a disturbance at Heathrow Airport. ... The British singer Amy Winehouse left a rehab clinic in London on Monday to meet with officials at the United States Embassy about obtaining a visa to enter the United States to perform at the Grammy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday, the BBC reported. Her spokesman said “no decision” had been made about her application. Ms. Winehouse, 24, has been nominated for six Grammy Awards.

Days after becoming a United States citizen, Craig Ferguson will get a chance to zing President Bush. Mr. Ferguson, host of the “Late Late Show” on CBS, said he had been booked as the entertainer at the annual White House correspondents’ dinner in Washington on April 26. Mr. Ferguson, born in Glasgow, was sworn in as an American citizen on Friday. Customarily attended by the president, the dinner, described by Mr. Ferguson as “like the Oscars for politicians,” is a gathering not without pitfalls for comics. Barbed political jokes led to criticism of Don Imus and Stephen Colbert.

An oil company’s plan to begin exploratory drilling near the remote site of Robert Smithson’s “Spiral Jetty” along the Great Salt Lake in Utah has stirred an impassioned response from artists and others who fear that the project could endanger that massive artwork. The jetty, a 1,500-foot-long curlicue of salt crystals, rocks and mud jutting into the lake, was completed by Smithson in 1970, three years before he died in a plane crash. The State of Utah, which must approve any plan for drilling in the area, decided recently to extend a period for public comment on the proposal until Feb. 13. John Harja, who runs the state’s public land policy coordinating office, said on Tuesday that the office had received 900 letters, e-mail messages and calls about the issue in the last several days. Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, issued a statement calling the jetty “a significant cultural site” and saying that the trust was “deeply concerned about the potential harm that energy development could bring” to it.

Lyrics about drugs, alcohol and tobacco pervade popular music in the United States, according to a study published in the journal Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, Reuters reported. The report of a team led by Dr. Brian Primack of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine and released on Monday calculated that Americans from ages 15 to 18 listening to 2.4 hours of music a day hear 84 references to substances daily and more than 30,000 annually. About two-thirds of the references put drugs, alcohol and tobacco in a positive light by associating them with sex, partying and humor, the study said. Some genres, like rap and country in comparison with pop, have more references than others. The team used Billboard charts to identify the most popular songs of 2005, based on sales and airplay. They selected the 279 most popular from country, pop, R&B, rap and rock to examine for references to drugs, alcohol and tobacco. One third had explicit references; 42 percent had some kind of substance abuse reference. Jonathan Lamy, a spokesman for the Recording Industry Association of America, said, “While we have not had the opportunity to thoroughly assess the study, it’s important to note that music is generally a reflection of society.” He noted that albums carry parental advisory logos.

The Canadian singer Feist has won the Seventh Annual Shortlist Music Prize for her album “The Reminder” (Cherry Tree/ Interscope). The prize was established in 2001 to honor innovative and underground performers who had not yet achieved mainstream commercial success. ... Claudia Bonn, executive director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center since 2003, is leaving after 15 years with the organization to become executive director of Wave Hill, the 28-acre public garden and cultural center in Riverdale, the Bronx. She will succeed Kate French, who announced in June she would leave in the spring.
Paul Newman will make his debut as a theater director when he stages a production based on John Steinbeck’s novella “Of Mice and Men.”

Pearl Jam, Metallica, Kanye West, B. B. King, Jack Johnson and Alison Krauss and Robert Plant (both below) will be among the more than 100 acts at the seventh annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts festival this year, the organizers announced. Taking place from June 12 to 15 at its regular spot, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn., south of Nashville, the festival will also include Willie Nelson, Phil Lesh, the Mars Volta, Sigur Ros, Jack White’s Raconteurs, My Morning Jacket, Death Cab for Cutie, Levon Helm and the list goes on. Bonnaroo was one of the first rock festivals to specialize in broad, eclectic programming, but along with Coachella in California, it has faced stiffer competition as similar events have sprung up around the country.

The death of the influential Southern rapper Pimp C, below, has been ruled an accident attributable to an overdose of drugs celebrated by Three 6 Mafia and the Pimp C group Underground Kingz in the 2000 single “Sippin’ on Some Syrup,” The Associated Press reported. The Los Angeles County coroner’s office identified the drugs as codeine and promethazine, essential ingredients of “syrup.” The coroner’s office said Pimp C, whose real name was Chad Butler, had sleep apnea, an ailment that can cause breathing during sleep to stop for as long as 30 seconds. Capt. Ed Winter of the coroner’s office said that sleep apnea, combined with large amounts of prescription-strength cough syrup, killed Pimp C on Dec. 4 in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 33.

Commissioner Reva Goetz of Los Angeles County Superior Court appointed a physician on Monday to determine if Britney Spears, 26, is competent to make decisions, The Associated Press reported. While Ms. Spears continues to be held in a psychiatric ward, the judge also barred that troubled singer from contact with her friend and sometime manager Sam Lutfi, and extended until Feb. 14 the conservatorship over her personal and financial affairs granted last week to her father, James Spears, and her lawyer Andrew Wallet.
A recent exhibition of contemporary Romany art in Budapest was the latest nod to Europe’s most despised, and Hungary's largest, minority.
The magnitude of the proposed cuts in federal funds for public broadcasting put forth this week  sent public broadcasters scrambling.
To the Editor:.
Separating the salt and pepper shakers or worrying whether the cutlery is clean enough are just some of the woes that can befall obsessive-compulsive diners.
In brief remarks to photographers, Jérôme Kerviel said that while he took responsibility for booking billions of euros in fictitious trades, he was “singled out” by Société Générale.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
For three years “Altar Boyz,” the little musical about a Christian boy band, has been a classic example of commercial Off Broadway’s struggles.
Expanding its Monday-night residency to a full headlining engagement, the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra is toasting its own legacy.
The Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam is at Carnegie Hall this week, showing off its chief conductor and offering three concerts of classical music’s greatest hits.
Michael Psilakis, a chef and an owner of two Manhattan restaurants, Anthos and Kefi, has redrawn the city’s map of Greek cuisine.
After a six-year dry spell, the Brooklyn author Gabriel Cohen has hit on a writer’s hat trick: three books in three genres from three publishers, all reaching the shelves within a year.
Prime Minister Vojislav Kostunica said a plan for closer ties with the European Union would lure Belgrade into rubber-stamping independence for Kosovo.
