ROMIGUIERE--Annalee Kiernan Cutrone, ''Lee'', traded the catwalks of Paris for a diner under the viaduct on 125th street. Afterall she was born and raised on the Upper Westside, the eldest of nine, daughter to Bertha and Peter, a NYC fireman. Her glamorous escape to the city-of-light merely set the scene for her homecoming and marriage to a streetwise local boy. A ''creature des reves,'' to debonair Frenchmen, Annalee Cutrone became a familiar face in the neighborhood as both a mother and entrepreneur. When she wasn't volunteering at Columbia Greenhouse Nursery, the April 1962 Playboy covergirl could be found slinging hash at her 125th St. Diner, or up the block pouring a stiff drink at her bar the 712. When a small, below street level location at the corner of Amsterdam and 116th opened up, Annalee's The Restaurant moved in. Across from the Columbia gates, Annalee's was a crossroads where students could afford to dine with the likes of Edward Said and Zbigniew Brzezinski to name a few. Annalee herself was a true neighborhood personality; not the sort broadcast indiscriminately and everywhere, but one who is well known to you if you happened to have been there. Any passerby seeing such a classic beauty stepping out of the AMC Pacer she won in a Fuji Photo contest had in their memory an unforgetable snapshot. We shall always remember Annalee moving blithely among us, an ethereal blonde with a delicate toeto-heel gait, gliding, it seemed, a feather's breath off the ground. Her soothing voice and blue-eyed gaze touched with a loving caress, so tangible were the affections she held in her heart. Indeed, Annalee was the very personification of the gentlest love to the families Agnez, Attardo, Cutrone, Dajani, Drelich, Duff, Kiernan, Romiguiere and Sadlon, and to her dear friends Madeleine, Ingrid, Joyce and Rosemarie. She leaves behind a husband and an ex-husband both devoted to her and remaining steadfastly by her side until her passing in Connecticut where the family used to spend their summers. Her daughterOona and her son Don were also her neighbors, as adoring of her as her grandsons Drew and Shane. Annalee, a woman of pure grace, always seemed a diamond in the rough where the rough, in her mind, could glisten just as brightly as the streetlamps along the Champs-Elysses. And so she passed kissing her husband with a last breath while he sang the same Estonian lullaby her mother used to sing while rocking infant Annalee to sleep. Remember Annalee as you will, and always.
STEIN--David. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns his loss, and extends sympathy to his wife Helen, and family.

MALOTT--Mary Myart, also known as Mary McIntyre: 1928-2008. Mary was an Austin, Texas and New York City painter, sculptor, assemblage artist, art critic, and diarist whose artistic bent also led her into unpredicted success in real estate development. She died January 21, 2008, at the age of 79 at the Cobble Hill Nursing Home in Brooklyn, NY after a protracted period of suffering from Alzheimer's. Born Mary Eleanor Harrell in Indiana, she was the daughter of Mary Evans Harrell and Samuel Runnels Harrell who once ran for governor of Indiana. Ms. Malott graduated from Radcliffe College, studied at the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture and got her MFA from the University of Texas. Mary served as trustee and volunteer Director of the Laguna Gloria Art Museum and was active in the Junior League, the Travis County Medical Auxiliary, and the Colonial Dames. Her work was exhibited in numerous solo and group shows in Texas and New York. Ms. Malott wrote a weekly column as an art critic for three years for the Austin American-Statesman. From 19801981 Mary provided weekly commentary for Artbeat, a show on KLRU-TV in Austin. She also taught art classes at colleges in Austin and for Laguna Gloria Art Museum. Ms. Malott ventured into real estate with her award-winning preservation and development of Austin's Pecan Square. Next, with her daughter Sylvia she rehabilitated the historic Gilfillan House. In the early 1980's, after a divorce from her second husband, Dr. Frances McIntyre, Ms. Malott moved to New York City's SoHo. Ms. Malott's longtime companion in New York was Tim Yohn. ultimately incapacitated by Alzheimer's, Ms. Malott painted her last large painting, a Slices of the Forrest painting, in 1993 at her Marcel Breuer country residence and studio in Clinton Corners, NY. Mary Myart Malott is survived by her two brothers, Evans Malott Harrell, of Georgia, Samuel Macy Harrell, of Florida, three daughters, Barbara McIntyre of Portland, Oregon, Sylvia McIntyre (Mrs. Larry Crook) of Gainesville, Florida, and Carolyn McIntyre (Mrs. Michael D. D. White) of NYC, and five grandchildren, Ethan McCooper, Vanessa and Alexander Crook, Eve and Audrey White. A spring New York City memorial service is planned. More about Mary's life and the transformations as she defined herself through her art is available at http://www.carolynmcintyre. com/ MaryMyartMalott.html

MASSACHUSETTS A Generation Gap Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York won in a tight race that was marked by sharp generational divides, with voters ages 45 and older supporting Mrs. Clinton, and younger voters choosing Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, according to exit polls. Many voters had waited until the last minute to make a decision about whom they would support, with about one-third saying they did not decide whom to vote for until the final week of the campaign. Although Mrs. Clinton had held a lead for months, Mr. Obama appeared to get a significant bounce after receiving the backing of the state's senior senator, Edward M. Kennedy. One local poll this week showed Mr. Obama slightly edging ahead of Mrs. Clinton. The state's 93 pledged delegates are allocated proportionally between the two candidates, with 31 based on the statewide results and the remainder divided based on the vote in each of the congressional districts. Each candidate had raised considerable money in the state -- Mr. Obama $1.98 million, and Mrs. Clinton $1.88 million.

MASSACHUSETTS Favoring the Favorite Son Mitt Romney won in his home state, with both the party faithful and independents flocking to his side, according to exit polling. Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, matched Senator John McCain in attracting voters who identified themselves as moderate and took the vast majority of those who identified themselves as conservative. Mr. McCain surprised many by making a campaign stop in Boston on Sunday, where he watched the Super Bowl in a hotel lobby. Polls showed the contest tightening, and Mr. McCain told audiences that he believed he had a chance of winning the state's 43 delegates. Mr. Mc- Cain won the primary in 2000, defeating George W. Bush by nearly two to one. But Mr. Romney dismissed the 11th hour visit by Mr. Mc- Cain, saying, ''I've got a lot of friends there.'' Many observers had said that if Mr. Romney lost his home state, it would signal the end of the campaign. Although state officials had said they expected a record turnout, rain throughout the day seemed to temper that.

The Munich air crash is perhaps the most well-known air disaster involving a soccer team, but the date that is viewed by many as one that forever changed the game in Italy is May 4, 1949. A plane carrying the Torino A.C. team home from a testimonial match in Portugal crashed into the Basilica of Superga, which is on a hill above the city, on a foggy and stormy night. The crash killed all 31 people aboard, including 18 players, club officials, journalists and the plane's crew.

MULLER--John Herman, 49, of New York City and Diamond Point, NY, on February 5, 2008 at Memorial SloanKettering, New York City, after a protracted struggle with kidney cancer. Born November 8, 1958 at New York Hospital, John attended the Brick Church School, St. Bernard's, the Harvey School, and Deerfield Academy. In 2000 he co-produced ''The Oldest Gig in Town'' a documentary finalist in the Tribeca Film Festival. An authority on internet marketing, John was Chairman and President of Inhaven Online. He was also President of Edax Realty and worked in the Commercial Real Estate division of Prudential Douglas Elliman for the past six years. John was a member of the Lake George Club, the Union League Club and a longtime member of Kane Lodge #

Commerce, a contemporary American restaurant that is to open tomorrow at 50 Commerce Street (Barrow Street), has inherited a legacy. The building dates from 1911; the restaurant space was a speakeasy during Prohibition, and in 1941 it became the Blue Mill Tavern. In 1992, it was sold to restaurateurs who turned it into Grange Hall. In 2004, under more new owners, it briefly reverted to Blue Mill Tavern. Now the space will incorporate design elements that reflect its past. The owners, Tony Zazula and Harold Moore, commissioned David Joel, who had painted a mural in 1993 for the owners of Grange Hall (which they removed when they left), to create a new one. In oil and gold leaf, and measuring 4 by 16 feet, it is similar to the previous work, depicting sleepy workers after a harvest. Mr. Zazula also found a 1941 Art Deco bar.

McENTEE--Warren, of La Palma, California, and Garden City, New York, went to his eternal home on February 3, 2008. He was 82. Born and raised in Garden City, New York, Warren received a B.A. from Wesleyan University and graduated with an M.B.A. from New York University, while working at the municipal bond firm on Wall Street, since 1951, that his father had co-founded in 1932. His memberships included: Sons of the American Revolution, New York's Economic Club, The University Club of New York and his local church club, in the summer colony of Point O'Woods, New York. Warren's civic activities included having served on his local board of education for six years, president and treasurer of his local property owners association and treasurer of his summer home's association and Trustee and Director of Development at the historical Fraunces Tavern Museum in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, a daughter and a son, three grandchildren and a sister residing in Louisiana. Visitation will be held at Forest Lawn Memorial Park on Lincoln Ave, in Cypress, on Wednesday, February 6, 2008 from 10:00am to 9:00pm with the service planned for 2:30pm on Thursday at Hope Chapel, Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Cypress, California. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Cathedral of the Incarnation, 50 Cathedral Ave, Garden City, New York 11530. Please phone: 516-746-2955.

LEDERBERG--Joshua S. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Joshua S. Lederberg, fifth President of The Rockefeller University and recipient of the 1953 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. His seminal discovery, while a doctoral student, that a form of sexual reproduction occurs in bacteria, demonstrated that bacteria possess a genetic mechanism similar to that of higher organisms, including humans. This work earned him the Nobel Prize at the age of 33 and helped lay the foundation for the current revolution in molecular biology and biotechnology. He was President of The Rockefeller University from 1978 to 1990. During that time, the University recruited many world-class faculty, created the University Fellows Program, which brought outstanding young scientists to campus, and constructed a major new research building. Throughout his career, Dr. Lederberg took on important advisory roles in government. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Medicine. He served as scientific counselor to nine U.S. presidential administrations and many world leaders on issues ranging from cancer and emerging infectious diseases to space exploration and biological weapons disarmament. He was honored with the National Medal of Science and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Dr. Lederberg was a gifted teacher and mentor, and he will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife of 40 years, Dr. Marguerite S. Lederberg, his children, Anne Lederberg and David Kirsch, and his many colleagues on campus. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Frederick Seitz and Torsten N. Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti LEDERBERG--Joshua. The Trustees and staff of the New York Hall of Science mourn the passing of Joshua Lederberg. A superb scientist, he was one of our first Distinguished Science Sponsors. Together with his wife, Marguerite Lederberg, he was the recipient of a 2007 Distinguished Leadership Award. LEDERBERG--Joshua. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Joshua Lederberg, and send condolences to his family. LEDERBERG--Joshua. The Council is saddened by the loss of Joshua Lederberg, University Professor and president emeritus of The Rockefeller University. A dedicated member of the Council for more than 29 years, Dr. Lederberg served on the Board of Directors from 1989 to 1998. The Council has been honored by our association with him. We offer our sympathy to his wife, Dr. Marguerite S. Lederberg, his children, Anne Lederberg and David Kirsch, and other members of his family. LEDERBERG--Joshua. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member Joshua Lederberg. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Michael W. Schwartz, President LEDERBERG--Joshua. The Board of Trustees, scientists, and staff of the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) in Woods Hole, MA, mourn the loss of Nobel Laureate Joshua Lederberg, a member of the MBL Corporation since 1956. Dr. Lederberg advocated the development of the MBL's Biology of Aging and Biology of Parasitism courses and, as chairman of The Ellison Medical Foundation, was an important part of the Foundation's annual colloquium at the MBL. We join many in remembering his innovative thinking and wise leadership. On behalf of the entire MBL community, we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. John W. Rowe, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees Gary G. Borisy, Ph.D., Director and CEO LEDERBERG--Joshua. We are saddened by the death of our dear friend and esteemed colleague, Dr. Joshua Lederberg, a distinguished Scientist, devoted supporter of The Advancement of Scientific Research in Israel and member of our board for many years. To the Editor: I was disappointed by the coverage of fish in the Dining section on Jan. 30. You missed an opportunity to discuss the intersection of possible detriment to human health (mercury) and detriment to fish population (severe overfishing). These two factors seem to add up to making changes in the way we eat. And yet Nick Fox, in ''Taking Worry Off the Plate,'' gave only a passing mention to a fact that is pretty much undisputed: we are depleting our oceans of fish, maybe forever.

Ice cream après ski? When it's a snowy scoop of WhiteFace Mint Chip, tasting of peppermint and studded with chocolate slivers, why not? This flavor, named for one of New York's highest mountains, is among eight made by Adirondack Creamery, and was first sold in that region. The ice cream, now made in Kingston, N.Y., near the Catskills, is made from local milk and cream, without gums and other thickeners. The coffee bean and vanilla flavors are quite intense; the kulfi-pistachio cardamom offers a touch of the exotic, and, like the mint, has no green coloring. The Barkeater, a translation of the Mohawk word Adirondack, is studded with toffee.

To design a good Bill Blass collection you have to get into the psyche of Bill and not his archive-and Bill let very few people get that close to him. He constantly pushed people away, men and women. At the same time, he was constantly sketching people (at least in his prime). He noticed things about women's style, things he liked, and then he adapted them. He had a pretty good judgment about what was too much, whether in a house or in a design. Yet he liked the big gutsy gesture-why else did he shop at Axel Vervoordt, the Antwerp decorator and antiques dealer? No one in New York made a better little black dress.

I am a migraineur. I use the noun with care, because after a lifetime of headaches, I have come to think of migraines as a part of me, not as some force or plague that infects my body. Chronic headaches are my fate, and I have adopted a position of philosophical resignation. I am aware that such a view is resoundingly un-American. Our culture does not encourage anyone to accept adversity. On the contrary, we habitually declare war on the things that afflict us, whether it's drugs, terrorism, or cancer. Our media fetishizes the heart-warming stories of those who, against all odds, never lose hope and fight their way to triumph over poverty, addiction, disease. The person who lies back and says, "This is my lot. So be it," is a quitter, a passive, pessimistic, spineless loser who deserves only our contempt. And yet, the very moment I stopped thinking of my condition as "the enemy," I made a turn and began to get better. I wasn't cured, wasn't forever well, but I was better. Metaphors matter.

The modern nomination system was designed to prevent us from getting to exactly where we are right now; the point of moving up the first few contests every four years, soon followed with a Super Tuesday payoff, was to try to head off the kind of protracted fights to the convention that had doomed the Republicans in 1976 and the Democrats in 1980. And for the last few decades, at least, it worked. But here, once again, come the chaotic winds of democracy to derail the efficient engine of party politics. The Democratic race, in particular, could go all the way to Denver, and it could end ugly-perhaps with super delegates hijacking the convention, or with lawyers arguing about whether Florida and Michigan should be seated.The accepted wisdom about such drawn-out, titanic clashes-and the reason that insiders have worked so hard to preclude them-is that they are ruinous for a party. The failures of sitting presidents like Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter (as well as challengers like Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale) are said to have proven that parties riven by internal disputes in the summer are incapable of reuniting in the fall; a nominee needs time before the convention to soothe feelings, raise money and recast himself for the general election. This year, though, the accepted wisdom is at least half wrong. That is, it probably still holds true for Republicans, but it could be a mistake to assume the same about Democrats.
(AP)

Here's a quick roundup of notable developments related to perceived or projected links between dramatic events and global warming. While the greenhouse basics remain clear (more CO2 = warmer world), the connection between the trend and dramatic events on short time scales -- the kind that catch our attention -- remains murky, at best. None of this means global warming is unimportant to address. All of this, though, does illustrate the challenge facing those trying to jog the public to respond now to limit a long-term risk. There is no single smoking gun. It remains more a Seurat-style pointillist canvas of evidence. And pointillism does not have the potent punch of, say, "The Scream."Tornadoes: There was a spate of Instanet attacks on Senator John Kerry yesterday for discussing projections of stronger storms in a warming world in the context of the catastrophic tornado strikes. His comment was nuanced, but by even bringing climate policy into a conversation on severe weather, he was probably destined to get roughed up. The reason? The science remains utterly equivocal on how global warming might boost the longstanding peril from tornadoes in the storm belt.

Last night's fundraiser at the U.N. for Unicef and Malawi was a wild end to an eventful day. At one point yesterday I was in a café on 10th Avenue, having a lonely bowl of minestrone and listening on the phone to a designer rant (didn't like the review: O.K.), and the next I was squeezing into the throng at the United Nations behind Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes. This was a little surreal. I mean, I've seen Cruise and Holmes at other parties. I remember seeing Cruise at a Vanity Fair Oscar party when he was married to Nicole Kidman. But it was funny seeing him last night, because Demi Moore swept up with Ashton Kushner and gave Cruise a big bear hug. I stepped around them, and saw Gwyneth Paltrow. People had that deer-in-the-headlights look: "It's Gwyneth." I thought she looked beautiful. I saw Narciso Rodriguez and Diane von Furstenberg, who was with her husband Barry Diller. The place was packed. The dinner crowd moved into a tent set up on the U.N. lawn, and, as Madonna reminded everyone, when she made her speech, we weren't technically in the United States anymore.
(Don Ashby)

In my Book Review column last weekend, I looked at some issues that arise when genre authors best known for their adult fiction try their hand at writing for younger readers. Of course, science-fiction, fantasy and horror writers have been publishing YA fiction for decades: everyone from Robert A. Heinlein to Ursula K. Le Guin has done it; even Clive Barker has his own YA franchise; and there are those who argue that Orson Scott Card shouldn't be writing it.

As some of you may have read, the Bagger is trapped in a bubble not of his own making and is celebrating his imprisonment by watching and musing about all five best pic nominees. If you want to read a real review of "Michael Clayton," a smashing one in fact, click here. The Bagger's take is more about oxygen-enhanced atmospherics.

When Ford asked owners of its trucks and utility vans which work-related problems drove them nuts, forgetting to bring crucial tools to a job was high on the list. On Wednesday at the Chicago Auto Show, Ford demonstrated radio frequency identification technology that should allow its 2009 F-150 trucks and E Series vans to instantly advise owners if they have every tool on their checklist with them when they set out or, for that matter, before heading home.

As Japanese officials disclosed more evidence that may point to deliberate poisoning of the China-made dumplings that sickened at least 10 people here. Diageo said it had abandoned a potential bid for the Swedish brand Absolut Vodka and formed a joint venture with the owners of a rival Dutch vodka, Ketel One. Diageo said that it would pay $900 million (611 million euros) in a deal with the Nolet family for ”perpetual exclusive global rights to sell, market and distribute” Ketel One vodka. The Nolet family, distillers since 1691, will continue to own the brand rights for Ketel One and the Nolet distillery in Schiedam in the Netherlands. That leaves three rivals — Pernod Ricard, Bacardi and Fortune Brands, the United States distributor of Absolut — in the auction, for Absolut’s owner, Vin & Sprit, which is being sold by the Swedish government. Analysts have estimated the sales price at $6.3 billion.

France Telecom said 2007 net profit rose 52 percent on better margins and lower taxes, with its mobile phone businesses fueling sales. Net profit increased to 6.3 billion euros ($9.28 billion) from 4.14 billion euros a year earlier. The 2006 figure was reduced by a write-down of 2.8 billion euros for good will, but the rise in profit was attributed also to lower taxes and financial charges and improving margins. Revenue rose to 52.96 billion euros ($77.99 billion) from 51.7 billion euros in 2006, helped by growth in France Telecom’s mobile phone operations across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.

LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury-goods maker, posted a 12 percent increase in second-half profit but said the economic outlook was “worrisome.” Profit in the half was 1.19 billion euros ($1.75 billion), up from 1.06 billion euros a year earlier, LVMH said. Second-half sales rose 9.3 percent, to 9.07 billion euros. The chairman, Bernard Arnault, left, said the company, which is based in Paris, faced a “likely” recession in the United States, where it was raising prices to counter a weak dollar.
An article on Tuesday about President Bush’s 2009 budget misstated the cost of a scholarship program named for Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. It is $40 million, not $40 billion.

The Damascus Journal article on Monday, about the political implications of a performance by a well-known Lebanese singer in Syria, misstated the title of Hassan Abbas, who was briefly involved in planning the cultural festival at which the singer performed. He is a researcher at the French Near East Institute in Damascus, not its director.
The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the Giants’ relationship with New York City, misidentified the franchise’s founder. It was Tim Mara, not his son Jack.

A report in the On Baseball column on Sunday comparing the Super Bowl appearances of the brothers Eli and Peyton Manning with the World Series pitching performances of the half brothers Liván and Orlando Hernández misstated the number of consecutive World Series in which the Hernándezes were starters. It was six, not five. (A picture caption repeated the error in some editions.).

A picture caption on Sunday with an article about a film industry apprenticeship program for wounded marines referred incorrectly in some editions to a man shown working at a computer in a film editing class. Like all of the people in the group photograph, he was an unidentified student; the man was not Nick Popaditch, a marine quoted in the article.

A front-page article on Jan. 17 about a study on a new DNA test that can help predict the risk of prostate cancer, whose findings were published online by The New England Journal of Medicine, misstated the scheduled date of publication in the journal’s print edition. It is Feb. 28; it was not published last Thursday.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Jan. 25 about “Electric Fountain,” an artwork that will go on display in the plaza at Rockefeller Center on Feb. 27, misstated the history of public artworks by its creators, Tim Noble and Sue Webster. They have made such works before; “Electric Fountain” will not be their first.
A Brooklyn man has been charged with raping two women after DNA evidence linked him to a June attack and a victim’s description of his 400-pound physique.

A former child care provider sent to prison in the fatal shaking of a baby was freed, six days after an appeals court ruled the latest research into shaken baby syndrome might prove her innocence. The woman, Audrey Edmunds, left, 46, had been incarcerated at a prison in Waupun, serving a sentence of 18 years after being convicted in 1996. The court overturned her conviction and ordered a new trial. It said new research into shaken baby syndrome presents alternate theories on what happened to the baby, 7-month-old Natalie Beard, after she was dropped off at Ms. Edmunds’s in-home day care in Waunakee. A debate has developed, the court said, over whether babies can be killed by shaking alone, how long they can live with traumatic head injuries and whether similar symptoms can be caused by other factors.

One of several white people charged with kidnapping and torturing a black woman in September has been indicted on a hate crime count. Prosecutors say the woman, 20, was held captive for days at a trailer in Big Creek. Six people were arrested after she was rescued. The defendant charged with a hate crime, Karen Burton, 46, left, of Chapmanville, was indicted Tuesday on charges of committing a hate crime, kidnapping and malicious wounding. Three other defendants, Bobby Brewster, Danny Combs and Mr. Brewster’s mother, Frankie Brewster, were indicted on counts including kidnapping, sexual assault and conspiracy. Ms. Burton’s daughter Alisha Burton, 23, and another defendant, George A. Messer, 27, both of Chapmanville, pleaded guilty and were sentenced to concurrent prison terms of 10 years for kidnapping and 2 to 10 years for assault. They will testify against the others.
The American Red Cross, the biggest operator of American blood banks, was fined $4.6 million after regulators found it failed to properly screen blood donations.

Congress put the final touches on two bills to make permanent a program to protect consumers from unwanted phone calls from telemarketers. Its hallmark is the national do-not-call list. The Do Not Call Registry was initiated in 2003, and some 150 million people have listed their phone numbers on the registry. The House passed by voice vote and sent to President Bush a bill to make permanent the authority of the Federal Trade Commission to collect fees to run the program. Telemarketers pay annual fees of up to $17,050 and must search the registry every month and drop the numbers of registered consumers. The Senate also prepared to approve by a voice vote and send to the White House a bill to make the list permanent, overturning an trade commission rule that people reregister their phone numbers every five years.

Shaun Wright-Phillips scored a tie-breaking goal in the 62nd minute of a 2-1 exhibition victory over Switzerland in London on Wednesday, and Fabio Capello got off to a winning start as England’s new coach.Jermaine Jenas also scored for England, which played without the former captain David Beckham. Beckham, the Los Angeles Galaxy star, was denied the chance to become the fifth player to make his 100th appearance for England when Capello left him off the roster.Eren Derdiyok scored the equalizer in the 58th minute for Switzerland.“I must say that we were quite nervous at the start, worried,” Capello said. “We probably have still at the back of our minds our failure to qualify for Euro 2008, and Wembley always generates pressure on the players and they couldn’t play as they wished to at first.”.

Brazil defeated Ireland, 1-0, in an exhibition in Dublin.Robinho scored the deciding goal in the 66th minute when he sidefooted a ball through the legs of Lee Carsley and past Ireland’s diving goalkeeper, Shay Given.Ireland had a chance to tie the game in the 88th minute, but after a series of quick passes inside the box and a deft flick by Kevin Kilbane, Robbie Keane could not get a touch before Julio César smothered the ball.

Nolan Ryan was hired as president of the Texas Rangers, reuniting him with the struggling team he pitched for at the end of his career.The Rangers introduced Ryan, a 61-year-old Texas native, with the fanfare of a major free-agent signing, taking him into a packed stadium hall that cheered after a highlight video trumpeted the return of the Ryan Express.“I’ve known since I was a player that I’d like to be involved in the shaping of an organization,” said Ryan, the major league’s career strikeout leader. “This gives me that opportunity.”Ryan threw seven no-hitters and won 324 games in a record 27 major league seasons. The last five of those were with the Rangers and included his final two no-hitters and 5,000th career strikeout.Ryan replaces Jeff Cogen, who was moved by the owner Tom Hicks to the Dallas Stars during a shake-up of his N.H.L. hockey team in November.

The Museum of the Moving Image, right, in Astoria, Queens, will close on March 23 for a $65 million reconstruction that will double its size. “The back wall of the building has to be demolished, and in order to do that, there’s a huge amount of vibration and noise,” Rochelle Slovin, the director of the museum, told Reuters. “It would not be a good idea to have the public in the building at that time.” When the work is completed, the first floor of the museum will be transformed, and the structure will have a new three-story addition. The building will house a 262-seat theater, a 71-seat screening room, an education center, expanded gallery space and a courtyard. Groundbreaking for construction is scheduled for Feb. 27, with reopening expected in late 2009. In the meantime no full-time employees are to be laid off, Ms. Slovin said, and museum members will continue to have access to screenings and programs in all five boroughs.

The Academy Awards telecast may have Jon Stewart as its host, but the Kids’ Choice Awards, in which the favorite performers of teenagers and tweens are honored (and then doused onstage with green slime), will have Jack Black, above. Nickelodeon, which will broadcast the 21st annual edition of its so-called “Kiddie Oscars” from Los Angeles on March 29, is expected to announce its selection of Mr. Black formally on Thursday.

Question: What’s the connection between an abandoned bathing suit and three cows? Answer: Nicole Kidman. The story goes this way: a bathing suit left by Ms. Kidman at a pool in Sweden is to be auctioned on Saturday to raise money to buy cows for poor families in India, Agence France-Presse reported. The suit, now owned by Zlatko Nedanovski and on display in a second-hand store in Eslov, a town in southern Sweden, will go to the highest bidder when the sale finishes on Saturday. Mr. Nedanovski, 32, bought the swimsuit for $778 after the staff at the pool turned it over to a local radio station. Ms. Kidman, an avid swimmer, forgot the suit at a pool she had reserved for her use in the town of Vanersborg in 2002 while in Sweden to film Lars von Trier’s “Dogville.” Mr. Nedanovski said he hoped to raise $1,400 to buy five cows through the Swedish aid organization Erikshjaelpen. “Today,” he said, referring to an early bid, “we have enough for three cows.”.

Tuesday might have been an important night for the presidential primary process, but Fox came away the big winner in the television ratings race, easily outpacing its rivals’ election coverage. As usual, “American Idol” led over all, drawing 27.8 million viewers at 8, according to Nielsen’s estimates. At 9, Fox’s “House” earned a similarly dominant 23.2 million viewers. Meanwhile, ABC, the only network to broadcast three full hours of election returns, ranked fourth over all with an average of 5.3 million viewers during prime time. CBS, which broadcast presidential primary results from 9 to 11, finished third (4.7 million). NBC’s election coverage won the 10 o’clock time slot (5.6 million), possibly benefiting from higher ratings leading into the hour. NBC’s “Biggest Loser” averaged eight million viewers in second place from 8 to 10, behind Fox. NBC also led Monday night’s ratings, thanks to “American Gladiators” (nine million) followed by “Deal or No Deal” at 9:30 (13.2 million). Also on Monday, at 10 p.m., ABC’s “20/20” special on the death of Natalee Holloway drew 12.7 million viewers, the largest audience for “20/20” in more than a year.

Amy Winehouse, right, has been questioned by the British police about a video that appeared to show her smoking crack cocaine, The Associated Press reported. The police said that no charges had been filed, but that the investigation was continuing. The Metropolitan Police in London said that detectives had interviewed a 24-year-old woman on Tuesday about allegations of drug possession. Although it is police policy not to name suspects who have not been charged, an officer read out a statement about the matter in response to a question about Ms. Winehouse. Last month The Sun published still images from a video that showed her inhaling from a small pipe. The video was said to have been made during a party at her home in London. Ms. Winehouse has since been admitted to a rehabilitation clinic in London but has said she is hoping to attend the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday. She has been nominated in six categories.
With a record-breaking 11 nominations, the musical “Hairspray” leads the competition for the Laurence Olivier Awards in London.

Having a No. 1 album just isn’t what it used to be. This week Alicia Keys is back atop the Billboard chart with “As I Am” (J), but the 61,000 copies it has sold is barely above the historic low for a No. 1 album, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The “Juno” soundtrack, on Rhino, fell to No. 2, with 55,000 sold. New releases dot the chart this week. The Mars Volta, which revels in head-spinningly complex progressive rock, opened in the third spot with 54,000 sales of “Frances the Mute” (Universal); the Welsh heavy metal band Bullet for My Valentine reached fourth place with “Scream Aim Fire” (Jive), selling 53,000; and the “2008 Grammy Nominees” compilation (Hip-O/Universal) moved 50,000, opening at No. 5. The remix album “Hannah Montana 2: Non-Stop Dance Party” (Disney) bowed at No. 7, and Vampire Weekend, the acclaimed New York indie band, reached No. 17 with its self-titled debut on the XL label.

The first exhibition devoted solely to the furniture of Eero Saarinen, the architect and designer known for organically shaped pieces like the 1948 Womb chair and sofa, below, and the 1957 Tulip pedestal tables and chairs, is currently at the Museum of Design Atlanta. The show includes nearly all the furniture Saarinen designed between 1931 and 1958, represented in drawings, photographs of historic installations, vintage pieces from the Knoll Museum in Pennsylvania and the Cranbrook Art Museum in Michigan and pieces still in production. ''The Furniture of Eero Saarinen: Designs for Everyday Living'' continues through May 5 at 285 Peachtree Center Avenue, Atlanta; (404) 979-6455. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

What's nice about existential longing is its one-size-fits-all quality -- how universal it is and how elastic it can be. Case in point: Linda Hesh's Desolation Doorknob Hangers, little flags of ambiguous dread or sorrow that began life as a public art project, but can now be purchased to decorate your home inside or out. Ms. Hesh, an artist who lives in Hollins Hill, Va., printed signs with phrases like ''I feel so lost'' and ''I want what we had,'' above, and hung them on doorknobs in a Washington neighborhood (14th Street between P and V Streets), photographing the results for a recent public art project and an installation at her Web site, lindahesh.com/gallery.

Starting today, the Kithaus, an instant freestanding room manufactured by a Southern California company of the same name, is available through Design Within Reach. The 9-by-13-foot aluminum structure, above, has a clean, modern look, with decking, louvers, canopies and interior finishes made of sustainably harvested ipe. Insulated and wired for electricity, it ships flat in four to six weeks, ready to be assembled for any number of uses. A range of furniture kits make it easy to turn the Kithaus into an office ($18,427), a pool house ($7,345, available in March), or a bedroom or dining pavilion (available this summer and fall). The Kithaus is $44,900, or $29,500 for a pared-down version without louvers, canopies or decking. Information is at (415) 676-6648 or www.dwr.com/kithaus. ARIC CHEN

Visiting will be Friday 3-7pm at the Sheenan Funeral Home, 233 Dunellen Ave., Dunellen. There will be a funeral service Saturday, time pending, at Trinity Reformed Church, North Plainfield. Cremation will be private.

Whether you are a Democrat or a Republican, Given Campbell, a designer based in Tampa, Fla., has a wallpaper pattern that will turn your home into a declaration of party loyalty. Ms. Campbell's new Election Wallpaper comes in two patterns, Democrat Donkey and G.O.P. Elephant, both of which would look smashing in a White House powder room. ''I care about the issues -- the war, education, health care,'' Ms. Campbell said. ''And you can't help but get excited about this election, so I felt obligated to do something.'' The wallcovering is available only through Nov. 4, for $80 per roll, half Ms. Campbell's usual price; for an extra $150, independents can choose custom colors. Information: (866) 681-7014 or givencampbell.com. SABINE ROTHMAN

Few people can afford antique prints, but a company called Natural Curiosities makes it possible to purchase copies of images from an archive of 7,000 original plates collected by the company's owner, Christopher Wilcox. Selections called Curiosity Boxes each contain 14 prints on acid-free paper treated with tea to make them look old. Four new volumes will be available next month, three with Latin-sounding names invented by Mr. Wilcox: Vox di Sator Propono Partum (zoophytes of the sea); Marie Buendia (jellyfish), above; and Imperator Historia di Insectorum (insects). The fourth, Hortus Eystettensis, bears the authentic Latin name of an important 1613 collection of engravings of every species in the palace garden of Prince Bishop of Eichstätt in Bavaria. The boxes, in limited editions of 450, are $168. Information is at naturalcuriosities.com. JULIE SCELFO

PENNINGTON--Samuel Charles, III, of Waldoboro, died February 2, in Maine. In November 1973 Sam and Sally Pennington launched the Maine Antique Digest from the kitchen of their Waldoboro home, and he served as publisher until his death. The antiques trade paper now runs about 300 pages monthly and has a readership of some 25,000 dealers, auctioneers, and collectors. Survivors include his wife, Sally Pennington; children, Katherine Pennington and husband, Nicholas Azzaretti, Nellie Pennington and husband, Nathan Hine, Sarah McCleary, Samuel Pennington and wife, Shane, and Mary Pennington and husband, David O'Connor; 11 grandchildren; and a brother, Christopher Pennington. Donations to Southern Maine Community College, SMCC Foundation, General Scholarship Fund, 2 Fort Road, South Portland, ME 04106; the Waldoboro Food Pantry, 97 Friendship Rd., Waldoboro, ME 04572; or the Waldoboro Public Library, P.O. Box 768, Waldoboro, ME 04572. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Services are entrusted to the Hall Funeral Home, 949 Main St., Waldoboro, ME.

You've heard of the Florida recount (of 2000, Bush v. Gore, hanging chads, etc.). But how about the Florida revote? Democrats in Florida and Michigan are increasingly concerned that their primaries, held in January, will not factor into the nomination fight between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. The Democratic National Committee stripped delegates from both states after they violated party rules by moving up their primary dates.

AN infatuation with geometry inspired Michael Gwaltney's radical chop -- a razed effect straight out of a sci-fi movie (left). Mr. Gwaltney, a makeup artist, showed off his austere half-bowl cut backstage at the BCBG Max Azria show last Friday at the start of New York Fashion Week. He shared with the models and the armies of stylists a penchant for barbershop architecture. Many seemed to personally favor precision-cut bangs, squared crowns, spiky flattops and wildly cresting mohawks, that last looking oddly fresh on Carlos Sanchez (above). One visitor to Bryant Park (right) updated his classic Prince Valiant bob by having it streaked the color of flax and shearing the ends into wisps. Brenna Wallace (below left), a fashion designer, dispensed with the rigors of upkeep by shaving one side of her head. She liked the look's asymmetry, she said, ''but really I did it because I was bored.''

AMONG other themes, a new restraint was evident at last week's Maison et Objet, the twice-yearly trade show held outside Paris. Unlike shows in the recent past, where home furnishings followed fashion, and color palettes were bright and changed radically from season to season, many of the products at last week's show seemed to suggest a desire for staying power. Fewer designers and home furnishings manufacturers were covering their work in explosions of chartreuse and orange or pink and turquoise, colors that would look outdated after a single season. Instead, there was plenty of black and white, and a few shades of gray, though what inspired the sudden sobriety was unclear.

PARLEY--Harry, passed away February 6, 2008 in Delray Beach, Florida, at age 87, of cancer. Harry was a lifelong resident of the Bronx until his retirement in 1982. Predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Florence, he is survived by his son, Michael (wife Lisa Gould), daughter Judith Paley (her husband Bill), and grandsons Adam and Matthew Paley. Known for his wicked and irreverent sense of humor, Harry was much beloved by family and friends. Harry was particularly proud of his service in WWII, having served in the U.S. Army's 29th Infantry Division and having landed in the first wave at Omaha beach in the Normandy Invasion of D-Day. Up from the beachhead, he moved across France in combat and was severely wounded in Belgium in November 1944. Later asked why he never went back to visit, he said, ''I walked across France once. Had I received better treatment, I might have gone back.'' Back home after the war, he quietly and diligently worked hard to raise and support his family, just like many vets who preferred to put their horrific war experiences behind them. Upon retirement, he reconnected with his ''Band of Brothers'' whom he loved as family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that comparable donations be made in his memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407-2387.

Voters went to the polls Tuesday in historic numbers, with Democrats setting records in 12 states and Republicans in 11. Over all, turnout was 27 percent of eligible citizens, breaking the record of 25.9 percent set during the 1972 primaries, according to the Center for the Study of the American Electorate at American University.

Standing near First Avenue and looking down East 117th Street toward the East River, a shiny new glass-and-metal condo building can be seen, and in the distance, there are the beginnings of the East River Plaza shopping center, future home of a Home Depot store. Two of the buildings that can also be seen in East Harlem make up Pleasant East, a set of four apartment buildings with a troubled history of neglect and violence and resident discontent. The New York branch of the Acorn Housing Corporation, which now owns the buildings, held a ceremony last week to mark the end of more than two years of renovations there. Meeting with some residents for the Dispatches feature in The City section this week about the state of the buildings, I saw a neighborhood in transition — the kind of transition that can make people with low incomes, struggling to find a place to live with affordable rent, nervous.

Updated, 10:59 p.m. | A dispute over second-hand smoke between neighbors at the Ansonia, a majestic Beaux-Arts building on the Upper West Side, has resulted in litigation and more unwanted attention for the luxurious building.The Ansonia faced a lawsuit last October from residents who said their home in the edifice — which is listed in the National Register of Historic Places — had become infested with “a horrific plague of roaches.” The building, which upon its completion in 1904 was well-known as the first air-conditioned hotel in New York, is now becoming equally well-known for the litigiousness of its residents.

Just before Mitt Romney made his exit yesterday, Laura Ingraham introduced him to a crowd of conservatives by asserting that Republicans had made a fateful mistake at their tumultuous convention in 1976 by nominating the incumbent President Gerald Ford, a moderate, over Reagan. Mr. Romney then took the stage and picked up on the same analogy, putting himself in the role of Reagan. "There is an important difference between now and 1976," he said. "Today we are a nation at war." And for that reason, he said, he had to withdraw now so that the party could unify against the Democratic threat to withdraw prematurely from Iraq.

No question where to look for this week's top college matchup - Oxford, Ohio. The town of just over 21,000 is home to the nation's top team: the Miami RedHawks. No, not *that* Miami. This one. How does a little school like Miami (Ohio) have the No. 1 team in college hockey?

PARIS -- The Citroën 2CV, whose role in France was like that of Ford's Model T in America, started celebrating its 60th birthday on Friday at the 10-day Rétromobile show in Paris. Inside exhibition hall no. 4, the 2CV display may be surrounded by prettier cars, but none more lovable.Rétromobile, held annually at the Porte de Versailles, celebrates any car that deserves preservation by collectors, and around 320 exhibitors are on hand this year. Some have books, spare parts and key chains. But at the heart of the show are the classic cars displayed by clubs, dealers, and auctioneers: Bugattis, Hispano-Suizas, Amilcars, and Panhards share floor space with Hondas, Mercedes-Benzes, BMWs, Peugeots, Renaults and Citroëns.

Wall Street's woe - falling stock prices and a shaky economy - may be affecting campaign fund-raising. The Center for Responsive Politics reports a big drop in campaign contributions from Wall Street in the fourth quarter, just as the markets began to tumble. In the first quarter of 2007, Wall Street gave a total of $10 million to all presidential candidates. That fell to $4.5 million by the last three months of the year.

Alliance Data Systems on Friday dropped its lawsuit against its would-be buyer, the Blackstone Group, leaving open a path to settlement talks. Alliance Data, a credit card services provider, filed a motion to dismiss its case in Delaware's Court of Chancery.

For most traditionalists, almond macaroons are the standard. But to me, killer macaroons are made from coconut. What could be better than the simple and sublime combination of unsweetened coconut, egg whites, sugar, salt, and vanilla?

The American Conservative Union's annual C.P.A.C. meeting in Washington was always going to be a Scylla and Charybdis moment for John McCain - if he was going to try and play to the crowd and burnish his right-wing credentials, would he risk losing his moderate Republican and independent support? Well, he caught an early break with Mitt Romney's departure from the race. So what did he make of his moment of emergence as the de facto nominee?

Randy Quaid, last seen in Oscarville during the "Brokeback" campaign, is being tagged out by his union. The Actor's Equity Association has pulled his card and fined him $81,000 for his behavior during the Seattle production of "Lone Star Love," which was supposed to come to Broadway, but was allegedly derailed by his bullying.

Anne Thompson points at Funny or Die, highlighting a set piece of David Spade as Daniel Day-Lewis as Daniel Plainview, giving a Socratic discourse on why there must be an Oscar ceremony this year. It's a reminder that just a small touch of funny would not hurt the ceremonies one bit this year. Funny is hard, but Spade makes it look pretty easy.

A front-page article on Thursday about deadly tornadoes in the South omitted reporting credits in some editions. Cynthia Howle reported from Jackson, Tenn.; J. Michael Kennedy from Macon County, Tenn.; Jim Noles from Birmingham, Ala.; and Andrew C. Revkin from New York. The article, datelined Atkins, Ark., was written by Shaila Dewan in Atlanta and Brenda Goodman in Atkins.

Banco Santander said fourth-quarter profit fell 6 percent as the bank took a $1.08 billion write-down in its main United States investment, Sovereign Bancorp. Santander said quarterly net profit fell to 2.49 billion euros ($3.64 billion) from 2.65 billion euros ($3.87 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2006. With Sovereign shares down 50 percent over the past year, Santander is realizing a big paper loss on its 25 percent stake in the bank. Sovereign this year reported a $1.3 billion (890 million euro) net loss for all of 2007, partly as a result of fallout from the subprime lending crisis.

A front-page article on Thursday about deadly tornadoes in the South omitted reporting credits in some editions. Cynthia Howle reported from Jackson, Tenn.; J. Michael Kennedy from Macon County, Tenn.; Jim Noles from Birmingham, Ala.; and Andrew C. Revkin from New York. The article, datelined Atkins, Ark., was written by Shaila Dewan in Atlanta and Brenda Goodman in Atkins.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about financial problems in the newspaper industry misstated the circulation declines for The San Francisco Chronicle, The Los Angeles Times and The Boston Globe, which is owned by The New York Times Company. They have lost 20 to 30 percent of their circulation since 2003 — not 30 to 40 percent. (Some of the loss came from eliminating “sponsored” copies that were distributed in bulk.).

A sports article on Wednesday about a high school football player’s commitment to a university that had not actually offered him a scholarship described national signing day incorrectly. It is the first day recruits can sign letters of intent committing to college programs; it is not the deadline for doing so.

Air Canada reported fourth-quarter profit of 35 million Canadian dollars ($34.8 million), reversing a year-earlier loss, helped by a stronger Canadian dollar and higher domestic demand. Net income was 35 cents a share, the airline said. A year earlier, Air Canada had a net loss of 144 million Canadian dollars. Revenue increased 3.7 percent, to 2.51 billion Canadian dollars ($2.5 billion). Air Canada, which generates a fifth of its revenue from flights to the United States, had been shifting capacity to domestic routes to avoid a slowdown in the United States. Air Canada’s stock rose 18 percent after the results were released.

A picture caption in The Arts on Dec. 27 with the continuation of an article about the photographer Dan Eldon, using information provided by his mother, carried an erroneous credit, and a correction in this space on Jan. 1, also using information provided by Mr. Eldon’s mother, misspelled the surname of the photographer. The picture, of Mr. Eldon in Somalia, where he was killed in 1993, was by Yannis Behrakis, not Bechrakis. (Mr. Eldon’s mother, Kathy Eldon, pointed out the misspelling in an e-mail message on Sunday.).

An article in Business Day on Jan. 28 about The Washington Post Company’s plans to start an online magazine aimed at blacks referred imprecisely to the formative years of Henry Louis Gates Jr., a Harvard professor who will be its editor in chief. Mr. Gates grew up in Piedmont, W.Va., not “a small town in western Maryland.” (As a child, he spent considerable time with his father’s family in nearby Cumberland, Md., and it was that town he was referring to when he spoke of reading newspapers in black barbershops.).

A headline on Wednesday with an article about a proposal to build a toll road through a state park near San Diego misstated the path the road would take. It would cut through the park, known as San Onofre State Beach; the plan is not to build “a new road across a beach.”.

Japan’s core private-sector machinery orders, a gauge of corporate capital spending, fell a more than expected 3.2 percent in December from November, government data showed. That compared with economists’ forecast for a 0.9 percent drop and followed a 2.8 percent fall in November. Compared with a year earlier, core orders fell 3.3 percent, against a median forecast of a 1.0 percent fall.
The bond insurer MBIA raised $1 billion on Thursday by selling shares at $12.15 each in an effort to protect its AAA insurance rating.
A man in the center of a case that led to the United States Supreme Court’s banning executions of the mentally retarded will remain on death row for now.

A man charged into a school in Portsmouth where his estranged wife was teaching, firing a gun before stabbing her as her fifth-grade class watched, the police said.

Mayor Lou Barletta of Hazleton, whose local crackdown on illegal immigration made him a national hero among those seeking tighter borders, said he would try to parlay that celebrity into a seat in Congress.

In its effort to bolster commercial logging, the Bush administration proposed giving managers of the nation’s 155 federal forests greater discretion in letting timber companies cut down more trees on the federally controlled land.

NEWARK — Thursday night’s State of the City speech was the annual occasion for Mayor Cory A. Booker to highlight his accomplishments and broadcast his grand plans, but for many here — including, to a significant extent, Mr. Booker himself — the actual state of the city can be summed up in a single digit: 2.

Paul Hamm was in first place after the opening session of the Winter Cup Challenge on Thursday in Las Vegas, the first United States men’s meet this year on the road to Beijing, and his first full meet since he won the all-around gold medal at the Athens Olympics four years ago. Hamm, who took a two-and-a-half-year break from the sport after Athens, had 92.8 points, 3.8 better than second-place Raj Bhavsar. Hamm also outscored the last two national champions: Sasha Artemev (88.9) and David Durante (88.7). The finals are Saturday.

The N.C.A.A. is asking the presidents and chancellors of Division III universities, already the association’s largest membership group, about the feasibility of splitting the division or creating a new Division IV. Surveys were mailed Thursday to the 440 Division III members.Division III already is projected to grow to 480 members in the next 12 years. The N.C.A.A. last year formed a working group on membership issues, and the Division III group recommended the creation of a fourth division for the association’s smallest institutions.

Egypt, the defending champion, and Cameroon advanced Thursday to the final of the African Cup of Nations in Ghana. Amr Zaki scored two second-half goals as Egypt defeated Ivory Coast, 4-1. Earlier in the day, Cameroon beat host Ghana, 1-0, on a 71st-minute goal by Alain Nkong. The final will be Sunday in Accra.

President Bush asked the Senate to swiftly approve an agreement ratified by more than 70 nations to fight the use of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs in sports. In a statement, the White House said the agreement’s principles were already reflected in United States law and policy.

The 20 teams in the English Premier League agreed to examine proposals to expand the regular season and play 10 games overseas starting in 2010-11. The matches would be played at five sites around the world over a single weekend in January 2011. Each city would play host to one game on Saturday and one on Sunday. The international round would be in addition to the traditional 38 home and away matches each of the clubs currently play.

The veteran Nascar driver Mark Martin will share the No. 8 Chevrolet with the rookie Aric Almirola in the 2008 Sprint Cup season. Martin and Almirola take over for Dale Earnhardt Jr., who left Dale Earnhardt Inc. after last season to join Hendrick Motorsports.

"I know I have a responsibility if I am, as I hope to be, the Republican nominee for president, to unite the party and prepare for the great contest in November, and I am acutely aware that I cannot succeed in that endeavor ...without the support of dedicated conservatives ... Many of you have disagreed strongly with some positions I have taken in recent years. I understand that. I might not agree with it, but I respect it for the principled position it is. And it is my sincere hope that even if you believe I have occasionally erred in my reasoning as a fellow conservative, you will still allow that I have, in many ways important to all of us, maintained the record of a conservative. ... One of the biggest critics of Black Entertainment Television says she will make a public apology Friday to Debra L. Lee, the network’s chairwoman and chief executive, for supporting a protest, right, outside Ms. Lee’s home in Washington. The cyberspace mea culpa comes from Gina McCauley, a lawyer whose site WhatAboutOurDaughters.blogspot.com has admonished BET for misogynistic and racially insensitive programming. But Ms. McCauley said on Thursday that the five months of protests led by a group calling itself Enough Is Enough now lacked specificity and impact. “I thought this was more like the Montgomery bus boycott, but going into the sixth month, this looks more like the Salem witch trials or ‘The Scarlet Letter,’ ” Ms. McCauley said in an e-mail message. The protests are led by Baptist ministers who say that BET broadcasts music videos that degrade women and black and Latino men. After focusing on Ms. Lee, the protest rallies spread to the Upper East Side home of Philippe Dauman, the president and chief executive of Viacom, which owns BET. The Rev. Delman L. Coates, pastor of the Mount Ennon Baptist Church in Clinton, Md., and the protest organizer, said on Thursday that the rallies brought attention and were one weapon in their battle.

Though it sounds like an oxymoron — personal training in a group? — it is a growing trend at large health clubs and small gyms alike, The Times reports today. Besides the significant cost savings — depending on the size of the group, it can cost as little as $20 a session, compared with as much as $100 for individual training — the group dynamic can help foster camaraderie and lure more people into the club. While trainers and patrons say that it’s a lot of fun, group training sessions can also feel a bit like being back in the proverbial sandbox. Competitive streaks can turn friendly companions into huffy ones. Those hoping to impress the trainer cut corners to complete assignments first. And a “boys against the girls” dynamic explains quite a bit of the behavior.

'THE BUTTERFLY' Sevrine, a child during World War II, never became a famous historical figure. Unlike Anne Frank, she did not keep a diary about her experiences as a Jew in hiding. Her life has never been a subject for Broadway. But her story and that of Monique, a Roman Catholic girl who befriended her, is finding a widening audience, thanks to Patricia Polacco and the organization Making Books Sing. Ms. Polacco, a children's author, knows the background well: Monique is her aunt. The girls' entwined histories first appeared in Ms. Polacco's book ''The Butterfly'' (Philomel, 2000), and they have come to the stage through Making Books Sing, which turns literary works for the young into musicals. In the midst of a three-week run across New York City, ''The Butterfly,'' directed by David Schechter, is a Holocaust drama that moves and inspires but does not lead inexorably toward heartbreak: Sevrine survived the war.

RACKSTRAW DOWNES Plein air painting is not a radical enterprise these days -- not as it was in the 19th century, when working outdoors meant escaping the stuffy confines of the academy. So what makes Rackstraw Downes's plein air painting so gripping? He is impressively skillful. His panoramic views of New York streets with steel bridges looming overhead or of sunbaked Southwestern landscapes are so thoroughly detailed and faithful to light and atmosphere that they could be mistaken for copies of wide-angle photographs. (At right is his ''Pulaski Skyway Crossing the Hackensack River,'' 2007.)

MYERS--Kenneth Holston. ''I Think I Can'' July 11, 1919 to February 1, 2008. Kenneth Holston Myers (Ken), longtime Ithaca, NY resident passed away peacefully on February 1, 2008. Ken is survived by his three children, Jim, Susan and Jon and his six grandchildren, who reside in Boulder, CO; Redmond, WA; and San Rafael, CA. Ken was a devoted husband, father and grandfather and found great joy and nourishment in his marriage and family. Ken's beloved wife, Bee, whom Ken lovingly referred to as his ''soul mate'', passed into eternity, January 13th, 2006. Ken's life reflects his belief that one can do what one puts one's mind to. Ken loved the book intended for young children, ''The Little Engine That Could''. The story's message is: ''I think I can, I think I can''. Ken's life is characterized, in large part, by Ken's indomitable will to succeed and contribute. Ken and his family lived in Illinois, Japan, California, and Massachusetts, before finding their true home in Ithaca, NY in 1973. The Ithaca community became very dear to Ken, Bee and the Myers family. Ken wrote in 1975, ''We have arrived. We are only too glad to spend all four seasons right here in our home overlooking Cayuga Lake''. Ken contributed greatly to the Ithaca community. Such contributions included his service as President of Citizens Savings Bank, President of the Cayuga Lake Intermunicipal Water Commission, Founder and President of Ithaca Memorial Society, President of Ithaca Housing Authority, Board member of Ithaca City School District Board of Education, and member of Ithaca Rotary Club, City Club of Ithaca, and the First Congregational Church of Ithaca. Ken's pursuit of an Engineering degree from the Illinois Institute of Technology was cut short by two years due to the onset of World War II. He enlisted in U.S. Naval Reserve in 1938. His Reserve unit was mobilized in 1940. Ken's primary service in the War was aboard the destroyer, USS Madison, on which he served as the ship's Chief Engineer and Lieutenant Commander, until the War ended in 1945. The USS Madison was awarded five combat stars for her courageous service in European-African-Middle Eastern Campaigns, including courageous service in the invasion of Southern France in August of 1944. After the War, Ken finished his college degree at Harvard in 1947, graduating with a B.A. in American Government. Upon attainment of his undergraduate degree, Ken enrolled in the Harvard Business School from which he received an MBA with distinction in 1949. He thereafter returned to the city of Chicago, where he had spent the majority of his childhood. He elected to return to school and attended Northwestern University, where he was granted a Ph.D. in Business Administration University in 1956. His primary courses of study in the Doctorate program included Economics, Industrial Management and Operations Management. He authored and published several books including his thesis which was titled, ''Design for Digging, the First Seventy-Five years of the Bucyrus-Erie Company''. He also authored numerous scholarly articles and case studies appearing in a number of scholarly Business Journals. Ken became full Professor at Northwestern in the School of Business just three years after completing his Ph.D. In 1959, Ken split time between his professorship at Northwestern University and his post as Program Director for the Japan Productivity Center in Tokyo. The Center was associated with the University of Tokyo. There he developed the first Japanese Executive Program for Presidents and Directors of major Japanese corporations. Ken later served as visiting full professor at University of Southern California School of Business, where he was responsible for the Executive Development Programs. In 1966, Ken took the position of Dean of the School of Business at Southern Illinois University (SIU) at Edwardsville, where he was responsible for the development of graduate and undergraduate programs in Business Administration. While serving at SIU he also was Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago. Ken's consulting and government service as Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago from 1968-1970 led to his decision to leave academia and accept a position to become President of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Boston, where he served from 1970 to 1973. Ken and Bee concluded in 1973 that their family may find greater fulfillment in a smaller community. Thus it was fortuitous that Ken was approached by the Board of Citizens Savings Bank located in Ithaca, NY. The Bank was seeking to replace the outgoing President, who was retiring. Ken accepted the position and served until his retirement in 1985. Ken will be remembered by his loved ones for creating a good life for his family. His children will further remember him for his empathy for those who are underserved by their communities, for his progressiveness, his long range thinking, his questioning of and not infrequent dissatisfaction with the status quo, his memory, the precision with which he used language, his expansive knowledge and interest in the social sciences, law, business, medicine, history, philosophy, religion, anthropology and other fields of study. His friends will remember him for his far-ranging intellect and kindness. The community will remember him for his compassionate action directed to those less fortunate. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, February 10th, at 2pm at the First Congregational Church in Ithaca, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hospicare of Tompkins County, or to the First Congregational Church of Ithaca. Please share thoughts, condolences, and memories by emailing to: Kennethmyers1@gmail.com.

falling stock prices and a shaky economy -- may be affecting campaign fund-raising. The Center for Responsive Politics reports a big drop in campaign contributions from Wall Street in the fourth quarter, just as the markets began to tumble. In the first quarter of 2007, Wall Street gave a total of $10 million to all presidential candidates. That fell to $4.5 million by the last three months of the year. Some of those titans of finance may have been tapped out, having already given the legal maximum of $2,300 in the primary races.

'76 KISSES' Cynics, stop reading now. The new exhibition at the City Reliquary, a museum devoted to New York artifacts and ephemera (think vintage seltzer bottles, trolley parts, the old 2nd Avenue Deli sign), is ''76 Kisses,'' a series of found photographs of people in various states of lip lock. The images, from the turn of the last century to the 1980s, are from the collection of Lori Baker and David E. Brown, a Brooklyn couple who met three years ago via the photo-sharing Web site Flickr.com. ''There was no romantic intention,'' Ms. Baker said. ''We just had admired each other's work, and e-mailed.'' But they quickly discovered that each had been trolling flea markets, yard sales and eBay for amorous snapshots. ''Then when we finally met, it was that little bit of fireworks,'' Ms. Baker said.

AHARONIAN--Natalie G. Past Chairman, Armenian Students Association of America (ASA), University Director of Admissions, Pianist , Newton Massachusetts Natalie Aharonian died at her home in Newton on February 1. Ms. Aharonian served the Armenian General Benevolent Union of America and the ASA in several capacities in the sixties and seventies, and was appointed ASA's first woman chairman. A graduate of Wellesley College, she attended Juilliard and Yale for post-graduate studies in piano and continued studies in England where she received a fellowship for piano studies with Denise Lassimone, and was offered a scholarship provided by Dame Myra Hess. Ms. Aharonian served as Director of Undergraduate Admissions for Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey and supervised the entire undergraduate admissions activity of the four-campus university. In 1985, Ms. Aharonian left Rutgers to assume the position of Director, Board of Admissions, at Wellesley College. Natalie Aharonian was born in Haverhill, Massachusetts, in 1929. The daughter of Harry and Diana Aharonian, she will be missed by her mother, her Braman, Tashjian, Simsarian, Movsesian, and Rivers families, as well as her many devoted friends. A memorial service for Ms. Aharonian will be held at the convenience of the family. Donations in Ms. Aharonians memory may be made to Rutgers University Foundation Armenian Studies Program, 7 College Avenue, New Brunswick, New Jersey 08901; and ALS Association, MA Chapter, 75 McNeil Way, Suite 310, Dedham, MA 02026.

A conclave of 74 Orthodox bishops elected Metropolitan Ieronymos of Thebes, left, a 70-year-old bishop who has avoided conflict, to be the new leader of the Greek Orthodox Church. He succeeds Archbishop Christodoulos, who died last month and whose strong views sometimes brought criticism. The archbishop-elect was one of four candidates, and he received 45 of the 74 votes on the second ballot and won. Four hours after the conclave began at the main cathedral in Athens, bells pealed and the lights of an ancient lantern outside flashed on to signal the election of a new leader. Minutes later, wearing traditional black robes, Archbishop-elect Ieronymos appeared on a balcony as thousands of the faithful flooded the sprawling courtyard to cheer. His enthronement ceremony is expected to be held on Feb. 16.

'JULY RAIN'/'WALKING THE STREETS OF MOSCOW' After the first 15 minutes of Marlen Khutsiyev's ''July Rain'' you may be tempted to pack a suitcase and catch a plane to Moscow, 1966. Like Godard and Truffaut's black-and-white Paris, it's where the cool kids seem to be -- talking, arguing, dancing to jazzy records and trying to construct modern lives. Showing in the invaluable ''Envisioning Russia'' series at the Walter Reade Theater, ''July Rain'' has a loose, improvisatory style, influenced by the Nouvelle Vague and punctuated with lyrical passages in which the camera restlessly probes city streets. About a group of young intellectuals, in particular Lena (an expressive Yevgeniya Uralova, above, with a Julie Christie bob) and her boyfriend, Volodya (Aleksandr Belyavsky), the film has more parties and picnics than plot. But like many Russian movies from the 1960s, it tries to paint an honest picture of daily life and real people. You can feel its internal tug of war between optimism and melancholy: the filmmaking may be exciting -- there's always something interesting to look at -- but melancholy wins hands down. (Not surprisingly, it was criticized for being too dark. Mr. Khutsiyev's previous film, the brilliant ''I Am Twenty,'' had to be reshot and edited after Khrushchev attacked it.)

DAVID YAZBEK The demands of musical theater -- beeline storytelling and transparent prosody among them -- usually crush indie-rock songwriters into miserable bits of limp pulp. If David Yazbek has been an exception (his scores for ''The Full Monty'' and ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'' are superbly cut gems), that's partly because he sees his Broadway work, including his next project, ''Bruce Lee: Journey to the West,'' as an exacting if lucrative day job. ''When you write for the theater, some of it comes from the gut,'' he said recently, ''but often it's someone else's gut.'' Fans of his Frank Loesser dexterity and Jule Styne savvy will find that Mr. Yazbek's night job has a rather different cast. At his American Songbook concert on Saturday night, he shares the stage not only with the longtime backup band he calls His Warmest Regards but also with special guests who exemplify his range: from the world of opera, the adventurous soprano Lauren Flanigan, and from the world of bizarro, the singer-songwriter Nellie McKay. When it comes to inspiration, Mr. Yazbek, above, half Jewish and half Arab, is something of a pantheist, drawing on sources as diverse as Captain Beefheart, the German group Can, early Godard movies and Tin Pan Alley.

9:30 P.M. (Animal Planet) ESCAPE TO CHIMP EDEN Cozi spent nine years crammed into a 4-by-4-foot cage, resulting in legs so atrophied that he is still learning how to climb trees. Jao became addicted to alcohol and cigarettes, which were given as treats to performing circus acts. And Thomas can untie any kind of knot, as he did for years trying to escape the rope tied around his neck. That was before Eugene Cussons, a chimpanzee rescuer, liberated them from human captivity and provided them with a safe home in the Mpumalanga region of South Africa. This new series follows Mr. Cussons, above with Sally, to Chimpanzee Eden, part of the Jane Goodall Institute, where he tries to give these chimps lives as close as possible to what they would have experienced in the wild. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) LEMUR KINGDOM Girls rule! Juno and Electra are what you'd call alpha females, and though they're only 20 inches tall, they've got enough moxie to lead the Graveyard Gang and the Furies, respectively, two rival groups of ring-tailed lemurs living in the protected reserve of Berenty in Madagascar. This new series, the heir apparent to ''Meerkat Manor,'' follows these tiny tyrants, their duplicitous offspring and the not-so-nice males in their lives over the course of a year.

'THE SLUG BEARERS OF KAYROL ISLAND (OR, THE FRIENDS OF DR. RUSHOWER)' The cartoonist Ben Katchor, best known for his urban tales ''The Jew of New York'' and ''Julius Knipl, Real Estate Photographer,'' once dropped a princess telephone to the floor. In the wreckage he found a small lead weight, a slug, and wondered where it had come from. The thought prompted a short comic strip that he later expanded into a story about ''an ethical question of what happens when you make things in the world,'' he said. He teamed up with the composer and performer Mark Mulcahy, and eventually the tiny slug and the random query that it inspired led to a genre-defying musical that's unconventional in several ways. ''Even operas have recitatives, but this has singing from one end to the other,'' Mr. Katchor said. ''Everything is elevated to song. Nothing is just stated as words.'' The language is unusual too (one character is obsessed with the poetry he finds in instruction manuals), and so is the scenery, all projected, animated images of Mr. Katchor's drawings. In scenes like the one above, the audience essentially watches actors and musicians navigating onstage with -- and seemingly within -- a graphic novel.

With a look ahead to Valentine's Day and a nod to Rodney Dangerfield, the classical music critics of The New York Times find themselves in a confessional mood and have decided to reveal some of their secret musical passions: works and performances they listen to for sheer pleasure -- but perhaps not loudly when neighbors are around to hear. They may be works deemed trivial by the lofty day-to-day standards of the art, performances that are dated and thus scorned or condescended to, manifestations of musical personalities that attract a fascination bordering on unseemly obsession. In any case, these are items that get no respect from the critics' high-minded colleagues, their families, even their pets. Or at least not enough respect.

Senator Barack Obama's second win of the evening is the day's biggest prize: the Washington caucuses. The Times is calling for the Illinois Democrat with percent of 42 precincts reporting; he has so far received 67 percent of the vote.
The Times is officially calling Nebraska for Senator Barack Obama. As of this posting, he received 69 percent of the vote in the state's Democratic caucuses, with 73 percent of precincts reporting.

My Sunday column focuses on the challenges that women leaders face in a democracy. There is the basic difficulty (as demonstrated in psychology experiments) that women, though not men, face a trade-off between competence and likability. If she's perceived as competent, then she's also perceived as unpleasant. Likewise, self-promotion by men leaves people with the perception that he's a smart guy; self-promotion by women leaves people thinking that she's full of herself.

Slap Shot's Lew Serviss reports from Arizona that Wayne Gretzky's rebuild of the Coyotes is showing immediate results. Going into a game with Nashville on Sunday, Phoenix is just a howl from a playoff spot in the Western Conference.
