The fees for re-use of scripted programming on new media platforms were widely believed to be a key sticking point between the Writers Guild of America and the Hollywood studios during the three-month-old strike. The tentative contract language released by the guild includes several compromises between the two sides.

The tentative agreement between the writers' guild and the Hollywood studios also attempts to define how "made-for-new-media" programming would be handled. The guild would be identified as the exclusive bargaining representative for Internet and mobile phone programming.

"The union representing Hollywood's striking writers said it reached a 'tentative deal' with studios and will meet members later on Saturday to discuss ending a three-month walkout that has crippled television production and overshadowed the awards season," Reuters reports.

East Coast members of the Writers Guild of America will meet in New York at 2 p.m. Saturday to discuss the tentative contract language released early Saturday morning. West Coast guild members will meet at 7 p.m. in Los Angeles.

This week we celebrate the centennial of the 22,000-mile New York to Paris race of 1908. It was a test of man, machine and where to find gasoline. It was tough enough to locate a gas station in the rural United States back then; imagine how much more difficult it was in Japan - where they had never seen an automobile - or the uninhabited expanses of Siberia.

More than 100 Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents raided a printer supply manufacturer Thursday in the San Fernando Valley, taking into custody about 120 employees accused of being in the country illegally and arresting eight on federal criminal charges, the authorities said. The raid was at the offices of Micro Solutions Enterprises, said Virginia Kice, a customs spokeswoman. The eight people were arrested on suspicion of providing fraudulent information to get their jobs, Ms. Kice said.

Almost 5 percent of the flu samples tested in the United States this season were resistant to the antiflu drug Tamiflu, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. Tamiflu resistance has been previously almost unknown in the United States. It is more common in Japan, where the drug, also known as oseltamivir, is heavily prescribed. The reason for the increase in resistance is “still under investigation,” said Dr. Joseph Bresee, chief of prevention in the agency’s flu division. All strains tested were susceptible to a related drug, Relenza, or zanamivir. After a slow start to the flu season, the illness is now being reported in all 50 states, Dr. Bresee said. Doctors’ visits and deaths attributable to flu are slightly above normal and increasing, but “not atypical” compared with some of the last 25 years, he said.
The space shuttle Atlantis appears to have made its fiery trip to orbit without any obvious signs of damage to its delicate heat shield, NASA officials said.

The popular antiwrinkle drug Botox and a competitor have been linked to dangerous botulism symptoms in some users, the Food and Drug Administration warned, in some cases so bad that a few children given the drugs for muscle spasms have died. The warning includes Botox, a wrinkle-specific version called Botox Cosmetic and its competitor, Myobloc, drugs that all use botulinum toxin to block nerve impulses, causing them to relax. In rare cases, the toxin can spread beyond the injection site, paralyzing or weakening the muscles used for breathing and swallowing, a potentially fatal side effect, the agency said. Botulinum toxin is widely used for a variety of muscle-spasm conditions.

The nation’s underground coal mines must have better trained and equipped rescue teams within an hour away — cutting the maximum response time in half — under rules issued by the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration. The agency said the rules applied to 653 underground coal mines with more than 50,000 employees and contract workers. Each mine must have two rescue teams and a person familiar with how to respond to mine emergencies on each shift. The rules also require teams to practice 96 hours a year, up from 40.
Laura Harper had 25 points and 15 rebounds Friday night as No. 4 Maryland held off Virginia, 86-80, to improve to 17-0 at home.
Nick Scandone, a member of the United States Stailing Team, is anticipating the race of a lifetime in China at the end of the summer.
A fire engulfed the building in the western town of Egg, and its cause is under investigation.
Soldiers searching a house near Miguel Alemán, near the Texas border, on Thursday night discovered a huge cache of arms and nine tons of marijuana.

The far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen was given a three-month suspended prison sentence for saying that the Nazi occupation of France was “not particularly inhuman” and that “excesses” were inevitable.
The Serbian minister for Kosovo, Slobodan Samardzic, said his government had received “relevant information” that the province’s Albanian leadership would declare independence on Feb. 17.
An inquest was opened into the death of an elderly man whose body lay on the sofa of his Bristol apartment for at least eight years while another elderly occupant continued to live there.
President Thabo Mbeki apologized in his annual State of the Nation address for the electricity shortage that has caused widespread, crippling blackouts over the last month.

A chart on Thursday about senators who have sought the presidency omitted one such candidate and erroneously included another. Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon sought the 1960 Democratic nomination, but eventually withdrew. And although Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, explored presidential runs in 1988 and 1992, he never formally entered the races. A picture with the chart was also published in error. The photograph was of William J. Martini, a former congressman from New Jersey, who never sought the presidency; it was not of Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who did seek the Republican nomination in 1996.

Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 19 about a major natural gas deal that Russia signed with Bulgaria misstated the quantity of Russian natural gas that is to be transported each year in a pipeline across Bulgarian territory. It will be one trillion cubic feet, not one billion cubic feet.

The Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday, about the February art auctions in London, misidentified the nationality of the artist Rudolf Stingel, whose three paintings offered at a Christie’s auction went unsold. He was born in Italy and holds Italian citizenship, and recently became an American citizen. He is not German.

A picture caption in Business Day on Thursday with an article about Wal-Mart’s plans to install several hundred new medical clinics misspelled the surname of the senior director of health business development for the retailer. She is Alicia Ledlie, not Ledie.

A front-page chart on Thursday misstated, in some copies, the number of delegates for the Democratic presidential candidates. According a tally of delegates kept by The Times, Hillary Rodham Clinton had 892 delegates at the time, not 905; Barack Obama had 716 delegates, not 703. (The totals now stand at 912 for Mrs. Clinton and 741 for Mr. Obama.) An article examining discrepancies in delegate counts by various news organizations appears on page A11 today.

A sports article on Friday about the investigation of pitcher Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, for suspected doping misidentified the lawyer who defended Mr. McNamee’s decision to keep medical supplies from the case. It was Richard Emery — not Earl Ward, another lawyer for Mr. McNamee. (Both men spoke at a news conference.).

A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about modest signs of progress for the new African Union-United Nations force for Darfur misstated the composition of the helicopter fleet the United Nations says is needed. It is 18 transport helicopters and 6 attack helicopters, not the other way around.

Chicago Bears linebacker Brian Urlacher recently had minor neck surgery. He is expected to be fully recovered when training camp starts in July. Urlacher, who will be 30 in May, said he had an arthritic back condition that forced him at times to play in pain.

Kirby Hocutt was hired as Miami’s athletic director, replacing Paul Dee. Hocutt had been the athletic director at Ohio University since 2005. Hocutt, a former Kansas State linebacker, also spent six years in Oklahoma’s athletic department. Dee, Miami’s athletic director since 1993, announced plans to resign in May and was expected to join Miami’s faculty on June 1.

The Indy Racing League is offering team owners in the rival Champ Car World Series free cars and engines in a bid to reunite the two open-wheel racing circuits. Owners who move to the I.R.L. would also receive $1.2 million in cash, the same compensation offered to all teams that commit to race the full season.

The Colorado Rapids acquired Christian Gómez, one of the top scorers in Major League Soccer, from D.C. United for a first-round pick in the 2009 SuperDraft and future considerations. The Rapids signed Gómez to a two-year deal worth about $400,000 a season. Colorado finished second-to-last in scoring last season, averaging less than a goal a game. The 33-year-old Gómez, who was the league’s most valuable player in 2006, ranks first in the league since 2005 with 99 points, and is second during that time in goals (35) and assists (29).

Florida added the former Iowa State coach Dan McCarney to its defensive coaching staff Friday. McCarney, 54, coached Iowa State for 12 seasons before spending 2007 at South Florida as an assistant head coach. He will have that title with the Gators, as well. He led Iowa State to five bowl games and was the Big 12 coach of the year in 2004.

Thomas Morgenstern of Austria won a World Cup ski jumping meet in Liberec, Czech Republic, his third consecutive victory and his 10th of the season. He jumped 132.0 and 128.5 meters for a total of 272.4 points. Morgenstern improved his lead in the overall World Cup standings to 1,555 points. Gregor Schlierenzauer of Austria was second with jumps of 130.5 and 129 meters. Andreas Kuettel of Switzerland was third.

The former national figure skating champion Christopher Bowman died from an accidental drug overdose and an enlarged heart, according to a coroner’s report. Bowman, 40, was found dead on Jan. 10 inside a motel room near Los Angeles. The chief coroner’s investigator, Craig Harvey, said Bowman, a two-time champion, had a blood-alcohol level of 0.12 percent. Harvey said the toxicology tests also showed the presence of cocaine, Valium and marijuana. Also present was the prescription medicine Seroquel, which is used to treat bipolar disorder.

The CW network will stop broadcasting the long-running World Wrestling Entertainment show “Friday Night Smackdown” at the end of this broadcast season, the two companies said. Neither company gave any reasons for ending the partnership, though WWE said it was in negotiations to find a new home for the show. “Smackdown,” which had its premiere on UPN in 1999, moved to CW in 2006 when UPN merged with WB. The show has averaged 4.9 million viewers this season, second to “America’s Next Top Model,” CW’s most popular program. But among the 18-to-34 viewer group, the show is only seventh. Last month WWE extended its contract with the USA channel for another show, “Raw,” through 2010.

Amy Winehouse, right, the British soul singer, will perform via satellite for the 50th annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday despite an unexpected reversal of the State Department’s rejection of her visa, her spokesman said Friday. Officials at the Department of Homeland Security issued a waiver that in effect overturned a decision by the United States Embassy in London to deny her visa request, according to an administration official. But the shift came too late for Ms. Winehouse, who recently entered a rehabilitation clinic after a video purporting to show her using drugs surfaced online, to prepare for a live performance in Los Angeles. Her spokesman, Chris Goodman, said, “Unfortunately, due to the logistics involved and timing complications, Amy will not be traveling to the U.S. to perform at the Grammys in person.” Ms. Winehouse, who is nominated in six categories, including album of the year for “Back to Black,” will join a long list of performers on the broadcast, which grew longer on Friday with the announcement that Kanye West, whose eight nominations are the most for anyone, will take the stage at the ceremony. John Mayer and Bebe Winans will also perform on the live CBS broadcast. Organizers previously announced a lineup including Beyoncé, Rihanna, Kid Rock and the Foo Fighters.

Pat O’Brien, a host of “The Insider,” has entered a rehabilitation center for treatment of alcohol abuse, his show’s syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, announced on Friday. Mr. O’Brien acknowledged his alcoholism in an interview on CBS in 2005. The “Insider” correspondent Thomas Roberts is expected to be co-host with Lara Spencer in Mr. O’Brien’s absence.

The 16th edition of the CBS series “Survivor” made its debut on Thursday with the lowest ratings for a premiere in the show’s eight-year history. Nielsen estimated that the show, set in Micronesia, drew 13.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., short of the 15.4 million who tuned in for the start of “Survivor: China” in September (which matched the previous all-time low, set by the series’s first episode in 2000). Still, “Survivor” easily won its time slot, helping CBS deliver the most viewers on average for the night. The runner-up, ABC, led the night among adults 18 to 49, with “Lost” at 9 (15.1 million) taking first in that demographic. ABC’s “Eli Stone” (9.4 million) also managed to lead the 10 p.m. time in that group, although CBS’s “Without a Trace” rerun in that hour had more viewers (10.2 million). Also at 10, the premiere of NBC’s “Lipstick Jungle” drew a disappointing 7.6 million viewers; in January, ABC’s similarly themed “Cashmere Mafia” attracted 10.6 million viewers. NBC ranked fourth for the night but tied Fox for third among the 18-to-49 set.
Fra Andrew Bertie was the 78th grand master of the 900-year-old charitable order of laymen. He was elected to lead it in a secret conclave in 1988.

Neil Young said on Friday that he had lost all hope that music can change the world, as he presented a documentary about 2006 antiwar concert tour by Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young at the Berlin film festival, Agence France-Presse reported. “I know that the time when music could change the world is past,” Mr. Young said. “I really doubt that a single song can make a difference. It is a reality.” Mr. Young made no distinction between the Vietnam War, during which Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young earned a reputation for political activism, and the war in Iraq, which their tour condemned with songs like “Let’s Impeach the President.” “It is all the same war, and it hurts everybody,” he said. “It’s a wrong way to solve a problem,” he said, adding that Americans were deluded if they thought they were liberating Iraq.
Separated since the late 1700s,  two pieces were reunited on Friday in one frame for the first time for “Poussin and Nature: Arcadian Visions,” an exhibition that opens on Tuesday at the Met.

FISHER--Liliane (nee Kaworsky) . Linette died unexpectedly on February 5th after a brief illness. She will be sorely missed by Arthur, her devoted husband of over 50 years, her son, Anthony, and her many friends. Linette was a talented speech pathologist for the Board of Education of the City of New York. In her retirement, as private practitioner, she helped many severely handicapped children. Linette was a pillar of her community, and an active participant in the betterment of Castle Village cooperative in Washington Heights, her home for nearly half a century. FISHER--Linette. Linette was an intelligent and witty presence at the bi-weekly gatherings of the quilting group. We loved her and we miss her. Gail Berson, Toni Bernstein, Carole Ferster, Julie Gantcher, Natalie Levy, Nancy Sosnow

(HBO) BERNARD AND DORIS (2008) In 1987 Bernard Lafferty, a penniless Irish butler fresh out of rehab, showed up on the doorstep of the tobacco heiress Doris Duke, at the time the richest woman in the world. Six years later Mr. Lafferty had been put in control of Ms. Duke's billion-dollar fortune. In this drama starring Susan Sarandon and Ralph Fiennes in the title roles, the writer Hugh Costello imagines a courtship between two people from different worlds. Bob Balaban directed.

LANDAU--Herbert , 90. Loving husband of 66 years of Ruth Landau, proud father of Marcia Landau Burkett, and husband Zack Burkett, Kathy Landau Hess and husband Jared, Jill Landau Reich and the late Ron Reich, Philip Landau and wife Lori Landau, and passionately dedicated grandfather to Rachel and Abhaya Hess, Sarah and Nathan Reich and Jake, Eli and Samara Landau. Mr. Landau is also survived by his brother Gerald Landau and wife Miriam and eight nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his brother Martin and sister Bernice Landau Golden. Mr. Landau, who was born in Brooklyn, New York, was the founder and president of Suffern Plating Corporation, until his retirement in 1987. An enthusiastic and upbeat family man, Mr. Landau lived his life to the fullest, declaring his only regret to be that life had to end. When asked what his purpose in life was, he said ''to get everyone to read War and Peace.'' He brought an irrepressible sense of joy and humor to his love for golf, collecting contemporary art, music, history and politics. Mr. Landau, who had a gift for making everyone around him feel good about themselves, was an unashamed and masterful cheater at scrabble who took great pleasure in teaching his grandchildren to play poker, encouraged them to read great literature, and set an example for how to engage in life's many gifts. To be in his presence was to understand the art of emphasizing the positive. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 10th at Temple Beth Haverim Shir Shalom, Ramapo Valley Road in Mahwah at 2:30pm. Donations can be made to Amnesty International or MoveOn.org. LANDAU--Herbert. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Ruth, Philip, Lori and the entire family. Jill B. Greiss, President LANDAU--Herbert. We have lost a wonderful friend and grieve with Ruth and the whole family. Bette and Jerry Lorber

To the Editor: Re ''Utilities Turn From Coal to Gas, Raising Risk of Price Increase'' (Business Day, Feb. 5):

CROWDED WAREHOUSES Wholesalers' inventories in December grew at the highest rate in more than a year as sales plunged, an indication that unsold goods were piling up. Wholesale inventories increased 1.1 percent, after rising a revised 0.8 percent in November, the Commerce Department said. Originally, inventories in November were reported as 0.6 percent higher. The 1.1 percent increase in December inventories exceeded analyst expectations for a 0.3 percent climb. The increase was the biggest since a matching advance in August 2006. (DOW JONES/AP) POLAROID QUITS INSTANT FILM The Polaroid Corporation, the company that pioneered instant photography, is exiting the film business and closing plants in Massachusetts, Mexico and the Netherlands as it focuses on digital photography and flat-panel televisions. Polaroid will cut 150 jobs in Massachusetts by the end of the quarter, the chief operating officer, Thomas L. Beaudoin, said. Polaroid will make enough instant film to last into 2009, and plans to license its technology to third-party companies for diehard customers. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
To the Editor: Re ''The Next Step to Safety'' (editorial, Feb. 6):

Members of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform were given a three-page memo Friday that will help prepare them for Wednesday's hearing at which Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee are scheduled to testify. The memo cites the March 17, 2005, hearing before the panel when Mark McGwire declined to answer most questions. It notes the Mitchell report's findings of substantial use of steroids within Major League Baseball, then addresses the three players -- Clemens, Andy Pettitte and Chuck Knoblauch -- who were linked to the personal trainer Brian McNamee in the report.

SILVER SPRING, Md. -- After losing two caucuses and a primary to Senator Barack Obama Saturday, Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign seemed like it might need a prayer. Or two. And so Bill Clinton started off his day of Potomac Primary campaigning with a stop at the Temple of Praise, an African-American church in Washington, DC.

Senator Barack Obama scored impressive weekend victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in several Democratic presidential nomination contests. He is well positioned for this week's voting in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. But neither candidate has achieved what is most important for deciding their battle. That is breaking the pattern of voter preferences that has structured their competition so far.

The responses to my column on Hillary Clinton-hating have been both voluminous (the largest number in the brief history of "Think Again") and fascinating. The majority of posters agreed with the characterization of the attacks on Senator Clinton as vicious and irrational, but in not a few posts the repudiation of Hillary-hatred is followed by more of the same. Lisa (No. 17) nicely exemplifies the pattern. She begins by saying "I agree that there is a rabid nature in the manner in which numerous conservative groups attack Hillary Clinton,", but in the very next sentence she declares that "most of Hillary's reputation is well earned" and then she spends nine paragraphs being rabid. A significant minority of posters skipped the ritual disavowal of hatred and went straight to the task of adding to it.

Sixty-three Republican delegates and 83 Democratic delegates are up for grabs at the Virginia primary on Tuesday. Recent polling shows Senator John McCain with a two-to-one advantage over former Gov. Mike Huckabee, and Senator Barack Obama with a strong lead over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The poll was conducted Thursday and Friday by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research and included 400 likely Democratic primary voters and 400 likely Republican primary voters.

There's a fine story in our Sunday Styles section today by Alex Williams examining the environmental costs of suburban life, which evolved around the highway system, cheap oil, and the automobile and now typically consumes several times more energy per person (and thus fossil fuels) than urban living. There's all that driving. There are the chugging mowers and fertilizers and pesticides used to keep all those lawns lovely. Lighting, heating and cooling those ballooning homes consumes vast amounts of energy compared to a city apartment -- or a house half a century ago.

Pyro showed he is one of the top 3-year-old colts with a powerful victory in the Grade III $300,000 Risen Star Stakes at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans, the final prep for the Louisiana Derby. Pyro, who has been working out in the mornings with the horse of the year, Curlin, for the trainer Steve Asmussen, is a top Kentucky Derby contender. Last at the top of the stretch, Pyro angled out for running room under Shaun Bridgemohan and came roaring down the center of the track in the final furlong to win by two lengths over his stablemate Z Fortune.

Lindsey Vonn won her ninth career World Cup downhill Saturday in Sestriere, Italy, matching the American record set by Picabo Street and Daron Rahlves.The victory propelled Vonn back to the top of the overall World Cup standings, 3 points ahead of Nicole Hosp of Austria. “It’s awesome,” Vonn said. “I was superpsyched about that, and I still have more this season, so hopefully I can get another one under my belt.”Vonn used a much straighter line than the other skiers to cover the 1.84-mile Kandahar Banchetta course in 1 minute 38.86 seconds. It is the same downhill course the men used at the 2006 Turin Olympics.

The Dallas Cowboys have hired Reggie Herring as linebackers coach. The hiring comes a little more than a month after Herring, the former Arkansas interim coach, was named the defensive coordinator at Texas A&M. Herring filled the last of the positions that opened in Dallas after Tony Sparano became the Dolphins’ new coach and hired three Cowboys assistants for his staff.

Reinfried Herbst of Austria put together the fastest times in each run to win a World Cup slalom in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. The overall leader, Bode Miller, failed to finish.Herbst had a combined time of 1:42, and Manfred Moelgg of Italy followed in 1:42.65. Miller straddled a gate halfway down the slope and did not finish the first run. His closest challenger, Benjamin Raich of Austria, finished 11th to gain ground in the overall standings.Although Herbst led by nearly a half-second after the first run, he did not hold back in the second heat in earning his second World Cup victory.

The Washington Redskins hired Jim Zorn as their coach Saturday night, a surprise ending to a monthlong search for a replacement for Joe Gibbs.“I’ve always dreamed of being a head coach with a franchise rich in tradition like the Redskins,” Zorn said in a team news release. “As a player who had to fight Redskins teams at R.F.K. as well as at our home field, I know about the history of this franchise as well as the passion of its fans. I won’t let you down.”The Redskins said Zorn, 54, agreed to a five-year contract.Zorn, a former Seattle quarterback, has been the Seahawks’ quarterbacks coach for the last seven years. The Redskins hired him to be their offensive coordinator Jan. 26 while continuing their search for a head coach. Zorn replaces Gibbs, who resigned Jan. 8.

Ghana claimed third place at the African Cup of Nations in Kumasi, Ghana, rallying past Ivory Coast, 4-2, with two late goals Saturday. Cameroon will play Egypt in the African Cup final Sunday. Cameroon failed to qualify for the 2006 World Cup when it was held to a 1-1 tie at home by Egypt in its final qualifier.

To the Editor: Regarding “Can Darwin’s Lab Survive Success?” (Jan. 27): You could not have picked a more appropriate setting to begin the Green Traveler series on travel and the environment than my native Ecuador’s Galápagos Islands. These truly enchanted islands, which were the inspiration and the basis for Darwin’s theories, are one of the ultimate destinations for nature lovers and eco-tourists and one of the most treasured, fragile and endangered ecosystems on our planet.

To the Editor: I’ve been to Cape Town twice, and the highlight of each trip was two days spent touring the townships. They were the most memorable of all of Cape Town’s extraordinary sights and experiences but were omitted from your 36 Hours (Jan. 27) itinerary.

To the Editor: The article “Hawaii on a Dime” (Jan. 27), on how to enjoy the islands of Hawaii and Kauai cheaply, missed a few important points in regard the north shore of Kauai. We have been visitors to Kauai for the past 30-plus years, always staying in the stretch of paradise between Hanalei and Kee Beach, at the end of the road. I’m surprised there was no mention of Kilauea Point National Wildlife Refuge with boobies, shearwaters and other birds, plus spectacular coastal views.

A picture caption with the Next Stop column on Jan. 27 about Ellicottville, a ski town in western New York, misstated the name of a ski resort there. As the article noted, it is Holiday Valley, not Holiday Mountain.

The Heads Up column on Jan. 27, about the Ciudad Universitaria in Mexico City, with its sites of interest for tourists, misspelled part of the name of the university with which it is affiliated. It is the Universidad Nacional Autónoma (not Autónomo) de México. The article also misspelled the name of one of the artists whose sculptures can be seen on the grounds. He is Mathias Goeritz, not Matías Goertiz.
The Choice Tables column on Jan. 27, about casual restaurants in Vienna, and a picture caption misspelled part of the name of a cafe in the city’s Stadtpark. It is Steirereck Meierei, not Meirerei.

THOMAS--Raymond Dwight, of Naples, Florida and formerly of Cherry Hill, New Jersey, died suddenly on January 25, 2008 in Naples, just before his 87th birthday. The third child of Eugenie Hattie Beardsley and Cecil Calvert Thomas, he was born on February 5, 1921 in Chico, California, and raised in Washington, DC. He received a B.S. in Agricultural Economics in 1942 from Cornell and an MBA in 1947 from the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. He served as a deck officer aboard the USS Whipple on convoy escort duty from 1943 to June 1945, when as a Lieutenant (senior grade), he took command of an LSM. After a career in international marketing at the Studebaker Corporation, Avco and Philco International, he started a second career in banking in 1963 at the Fidelity Bank, from which heretired in 1981 as the Executive Vice-President of the Bank and head of the Trust Department. He was predeceased in 2001 by his wife of 58 years, Sara Thomas. He is survived by his sons, Thomas R. Thomas, of Farmington, New Hampshire and Floyd D. Thomas, of Lawrenceville, Georgia, his daughter, Ann F. Thomas, of New York City; nine grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. He is also survived by the beloved companion of his later years, Vicki Slawson Barbash, of Naples, Florida. A quietly committed crusader for social justice, gender equality, and political freedom throughout his entire life, he will be deeply missed by all those whose lives he touched. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 16, 2008, at 11am at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Greater Naples, Florida. Donations may be made in his memory to the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Greater Naples or the the Shelter for Abused Women and Children, P.O. Box 10102, Naples, Florida 34101.

Q The board of managers of our condominium issued a ruling that any owner who is delinquent in paying the monthly common charge cannot vote at the annual meeting. Our bylaws state that each unit owner is entitled to one vote. Doesn't this ruling require a change in the bylaws? And doesn't a change in the bylaws require a two-thirds vote of unit owners? A Steven Sladkus, a Manhattan co-op and condominium lawyer, said the letter writer is correct. While the bylaws provide that each unit owner is entitled to one vote, he said, they apparently do not impose any restrictions on, or qualifications for, voters.

ELSKUS--Albinas. Aug. 21, 1926-Feb. 8, 2007. Stained Glass Artist who loved his work. Wonderful husband and father who enjoyed life. Life with Albin was an adventure, never knowing what each day would bring. ''The stars tonight are so very beautiful, wake up Ann and see this wonderful sight. How about going to the beach with the children -in February?'' His sketchbook was with him at all times and he loved painting watercolors. We miss you so very much. Your stained glass windows, along with your sketches, watercolors and oil paintings are here to help keep our memories alive. With our love, Ann, Adria, Arilda and Dooie

TABER--Gerald Patrick, on Wednesday, February 6, 2008, following a sudden illness, Gerald Patrick Taber died at Kingston General Hospital, with his family by his side. He is survived by Joan, his wife of 52 years, his son Geoff (Jacquie Gardner), his daughter Shelagh Walsh and his grandchildren, James, Stephen and Phoebe Walsh and Scott and Andrew Taber. Gerry was born in Saskatchewan to Russell and Dorothy Taber (nee Haslam). He was predeceased by his older brother Harry in 1995. He came east to attend Queen's University (where he received degrees in Arts and in Commerce in 1949) and then Harvard Business School (1952). Gerald worked in Ottawa, Toronto, Montreal and New York City before returning to Kingston in 1999. His family and friends will remember a man of great good humour, gentleness and generosity. Friends are invited to join the family at their home in Kingston, Ontario, on Monday, February 11 from 4 to 6pm. In accordance with Gerald's wishes, a private burial service will be held at a later date. If desired, donations in Gerald's memory may be made to the Salvation Army.

CAMPAIGN STOPS If Mike Huckabee didn't exist, John McCain would have had to invent him. First, Mr. Huckabee won the Iowa caucuses, sending Mitt Romney into a tailspin that gave Senator McCain the opening he needed to win New Hampshire. Mr. Huckabee then took enough votes from Mr. Romney in South Carolina and Florida to allow Senator McCain to win both states with scant support from conservative Republicans.

SOCHET--Marvin, died February 4, 2008 at 791/2. He was a lover of life, fought for justice, and changed the world in ways big and small. A passionate native New Yorker and Westside activist, Marvin ran for City Council and was a lifelong advocate for middle-income housing. He chaired the Westside Committee on Vietnam and co-founded the peace and children's rights non-governmental organization, Perhaps Kids Meeting Kids Can Make a Difference. President of Monolith Interiors, Marvin also owned several properties on the Upper West Side and was unusually well liked by tenants. He also published the first co-op newspaper in New York and created a cable TV program, ''What's Wrong and Right with New York.'' An iconoclast and a humorist, he was a devoted member of the Jewish community. He is survived by his wife Mary; his children David and Melorra; his sister and brother-in-law, Miriam and Rabbi Will Shuchat; and many nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends. Donations in his memory may be made to Kids Meeting Kids, 380 Riverside Drive, NY, NY 10025.

HOBSON--Edward P. A Vice President at National TeleConsultants (Glendale, CA, and NY, NY) since 2002, Mr. Hobson passed away Monday, January 28, in Nevada City, CA. The cause of the death was cancer. He was 59. Born in Trenton, NJ, Mr. Hobson graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1971 with BS in Electrical Engineering. Mr. Hobson worked for Grass Valley Group, Graham-Patten Systems, Sony Electronics, and was co-founder of Omneon Video Networks. He was also a Past President of the SMPTE. He is survived by his wife Judy Seabridge, parents, and family. An East Coast memorial service will be held at 2pm Saturday, February 16 at Grace St. Paul Episcopal Church, 3715 East State St, Extension Mercerville, NJ. ESPENSHADE--Edward B. Jr Edward Bowman Espenshade Jr., Ph.D. died January 26, 2008. Ed was an outstanding educator and cartographer, devoted and loving husband and father. Born Chicago, IL, October 23, 1910 to Edward B. and Mary E. (Jones) Espenshade. Married Dorothy Barrows, June 17, 1939. Predeceased in death by his parents, siblings (Esther, Ada, Bob, and Paul) and his wife. Survived by his daughters, Jean E. Espenshade (Don Jones) of Madison, WI, and Nancy E. Espenshade (Rev. David Kyllo) of Evanston, IL; sister-in-law, Peggy McCormick; nieces and nephews. Dr. Espenshade received BS and MS degrees in geology and a Ph.D. in geography from the University of Chicago. During WWII, he served as Foreign Map Editor for the Army Map Service, then as intelligence specialist for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. He returned in 1945 to teach geography at Northwestern University, chairing the department from 1958 to 1975. He retired in 1978 and was appointed professor emeritus. Dr. Espenshade is best known for his editorship of ''Goode's World Atlas'' from 1949 to 1994. His contributions to the fields of geography and cartography, through teaching and publication, were extensive. He was chairman of the Earth Sciences Division of the National Research Council - National Academy of Sciences and served as president of the Association of American Geographers. A former president of the Geographic Society of Chicago, he was elected as its first lifetime director. He received numerous awards, including the Undergraduate Teaching Award at the University of Chicago, the Distinguished Service Award from the Geographic Society of Chicago, the George J. Miller Award for Distinguished Service from the National Council for Geographic Education, and the Distinguished Geographic Educator Award from the Illinois Geography Society. In retirement, he took advantage of every opportunity to play golf and fish. Ed will be remembered by his family and friends for his genuine interest in others, his wonderful wit, and his dedication to geography education.

OSSIP--Andrea Seixas Forster, died in her sleep of lung cancer on February 8, 2008 at age 64 in her Hartsdale, NY home. Born in Lincoln, Nebraska, she was predeceased by parents Jean Seixas and Irwin Forster, and sister Lee Seixas Forster. She will be deeply missed by the family she loved so much: her loving husband, Al, her devoted children and stepchildren and their spouses, Jessica Lee Seixas (John) Fulton, Joshua Seixas Howard Fausty (Edvige Giunta), Robert (Kathleen) Ossip and Ron (Amy) Ossip; and by her grandchildren, who added so much joy to their Bubbe's life: Big Emily, Little Emily, Samantha, Muriel, and Matteo. She was a devoted cousin, niece, friend; a trusted advisor, mentor, confidant. A graduate of Dean Junior College and Suffolk University, Boston, she did graduate work at the Bank Street School of Education. An early childhood educator, she helped raise dozens of children in her home childcare center and kept in close contact with many. In sickness, she lived her life as she always had: nurturing and cherishing relationships, old and new, with her large circle of family and friends. The family wishes to thank the wonderful friends and relatives who loved and supported her during her illness. Her love is all around us. Memorial Services today, 5pm, at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, New York. Family and friends will gather at 4:30pm.
FORD--Charles Henri. Father of American Surrealism February 10, 1908-September 27, 2002. Today you would be 100 years young. You still inspire me. Indra Tamang

EMDEN--Jeffrey. You were the second of our Four pack and we loved you very much. Although we didn't see you often we always felt very close. We will remember you as the cool one and think of you always. We only wish we could bring you back. Love Howard Emden and family.

BURDEN--William Douglas, Jr., ''Doug''. Aged 76, of Aspen, CO, died Saturday, January 26, 2008 of terminal cancer. He was born August 13, 1931 in NYC, son of William Douglas Burden, and Katharine Curtin White. Doug grew up in Bedford Village and NYC. He attended North Country School in Lake Placid, Eaglebrook School, Proctor Academy, and Middlebury College where he captained the ski teams. He became one of America's top ski Racers and competed internationally until a near fatal ski racing accident in Italy in 1954 ended his career. Despite his injury, he was a beautiful, natural athlete who played superb tennis and golf and became ''coach'' to friends and family. Doug served in the Navy. He was a development entrepreneur. He is survived by his son James, brothers Andrew and Christopher, sister Wendy B. Morgan, stepmother Betsy, and devoted partner, Marilyn Hodges Wilmerding. A memorial is planned for spring. Contributions may be made to the Steadman Hawkins Research Foundation, 181 West Meadow Dr., Suite 1000, Vail, CO 81657.

RUESCH--Gladys R., 93, of Great Neck, Massapequa, NY, and Catawissa, PA, died peacefully at Grace Plaza Nursing Center on February 3, 2008. As a founding member of the Community Church of Great Neck, Gladys was known for her beautiful voice and accomplished piano playing. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Alfred S. Ruesch. Gladys is survived by her son Alfred (Ann) of NYC, son Robert (Eileen) of Southampton, sister Muriel Hartley, niece Susan (Tom) Adams, nephew Leon (Kim) Hartley, grandchildren Devon, Lisa, Matt, Christine, great - grandchildren Max, Theodore, Michaela, Emma. A memorial service will be held in April at the family plot in Catawissa, PA. Donations may be made to the Vigilant Fire Company, 83 Cuttermill Road, Great Neck, NY 11021.
FRIEDMAN--Matthew. A wonderful dear friend for over 55 years. We will always miss you. Our love and sympathy to Steven, Robert, Andrew, and Thomas. Marje and Sid

GERSTL--Tibor, 87, of Croton-on-Hudson, died peacefully February 3, and is survived by his life-companion and love Ida Secllecaerts. Tibor was a Holocaust survivor, resistance leader and Hungarian water polo champion and came to the US in 1956. An avid author and artist he spent his business career at Leviton Manufacturing Company where he rose to the position of Vice President of Marketing Communications. A Memorial service will be held at a later date.

RESNICK--Ralph, died February 4th. Beloved husband of Caroline. Devoted father of Jane and Robert (Barbara). Proud loving Poppa Ralph to Michael and David. Cherished brother-in-law of Allen and Connie. Loving uncle of Amy, Susan (Scott) and Nancy (Mark). Greatuncle of Max, Melissa, Andrew. Surrogate father of the Conlons and Parkers. Will be missed by so many. World War II air transport command pilot in North Africa. He loved to write poetry and sing. He was a man of great intelligence and humor. Donations may be given to Charles House, 919-967-7570.

VIEW OF THE KREMLIN FROM THE SOPHIA EMBANKMENT, JAN. 20, 2008 ''The supreme moments of travel are born of beauty and strangeness in equal parts: the first panders to the senses, the second to the mind; and it is the rarity of this coincidence which makes the rarity of these moments. Such a moment was mine as I walked up the side of the River Moskva late in the afternoon of my second day in Russia. The Red Capital in winter is a silent place. Like black ghouls on the soundless snow, the Muscovites went their way, hatted in fur, lamb, leather, and velvet, each with a great collar turned up against the wind that sweeps down the river from the east. ... This, at last, was Red Russia; this horde of sable ghosts, the Bolshevists, the cynosure of an agitated world. It was more than Russia, it was the capital of the Union, the very pulse of proletarian dictatorship, the mission-house of Dialectical Materialism. I looked across the river. Before me stood the inmost sanctuary of all: the Kremlin.''

TAX season is never pleasant, but this one could have been much worse for many taxpayers. An estimated 20 million Americans were spared additional tax burdens by the Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2007, known less formally as ''the A.M.T. patch,'' signed by President Bush on Dec. 26. The change means that they will escape the alternative minimum tax, though it is still expected to snare more than 4 million other taxpayers. The patch is effective only for the 2007 tax year, however. A major overhaul of America's complex tax system isn't likely at least until a new Congress and a new president have been elected.

LORINI--John C., a 20-year resident of Grass Valley, CA, died February 5. The cause was complications from prostate cancer. Mr. Lorini was born in Yonkers, NY, on July 22, 1924. He grew up in Mahopac, NY, graduating from high school in 1941. He then entered Middlebury College, in Middlebury, VT. He withdrew from Middlebury in 1942 and served in the Merchant Marine for the remainder of World War II. In the Merchant Marine, Mr. Lorini was a member of the Engine Department in a number of tankers and dry cargo vessels on the North Atlantic run, the Mediterranean and Indian Oceans, and the Southwest Pacific. After the war, Mr. Lorini entered Cornell University and graduated in 1948. He was married to Anne Aulbach, also a Cornell graduate. That marriage ended in divorce. They had two children, Thomas and Martha, who live in Grass Valley and New York City, respectively. In 1948, Mr. Lorini went to work for The Port of New York Authority. In 1955 he joined Booz Allen and Hamilton, a major international management consulting firm, working in New York before and after a stint in Zurich, Switzerland, with a final transfer to San Francisco in 1964. He was elected a Partner in 1963 and became head of the western region Operations practice, retiring in 1990. In 1984, Mr. Lorini and Karen Borrego were married in the Bay Area and lived on the Peninsula until building a house and moving to Grass Valley in 1989. The couple participated actively in competitive skeet shooting. After moving to Grass Valley, Mr. Lorini served as Foreman of the Civil Grand Jury, 1992-1993, and later served on the Nevada County Planning Commission. Earlier, he had been a director and then Chairman of the Shaklee Corporation, also serving on the board of Energy Factors, located in San Diego. He was a member of The Massachusetts Society of Mayflower Descendants and the Kappa Delta Rho fraternity. He is survived by his wife, Karen, son Thomas, daughter Martha, daughterin-law Victoria, and sister, Margaret L. Gunkel (of New Jersey). Plus Roy (the red dog) and Zeus (the Mini Schnauzer). Donations may be made in Mr. Lorinis name to The National Liberty Ship Memorial; Pier 23, The Embarcadero; San Francisco, CA 94111-which supports the S.S. Jeremiah O'Brien, a liberty ship similar to those on which he served.

ANTONELLI--Dr. Dominick D., age 84, of Manhattan, Psychoanalyst, Artist, WWII Veteran, Model Airplane creator, and equestrian, passed away December 7, 2007. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Eugene and Letitia Antonelli, and is survived by sisters, Fausta Weir of Ridgewood, NJ and Rita Viverito of Toms River, NJ, former wife, Dr. Mildred Antonelli of Manhattan, and son, David Antonelli. Dom received his Ph.D. at N.Y.U. and was a practicing psychoanalyst all his life; was renowned for his work with children and adults and for his expert judicial testimony. A prolific artist, Dom studied at the Art Students League, Silvermine Art School, Vermont Studio Center and worked with Evsa Modell, Sue Crile, Larry Poons, Jules Olitski, and Leo Manso. His works were shown at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Noah Goldowsky Gallery, Hunter College, Lincoln Center and The Betty Parson Gallery. An avid airplane model designer, longtime member of the Metropolitan Sports Squadron Model Airplane Club, Dom had several articles published in hobby publications to advance his craft. A Memorial Service will be held at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., Saturday February 16th, 2-5pm. Eulogies are welcomed.

MITTELMAN--Arnold, M.D., died February 3, 2008. He received his degrees from Columbia University, and worked at Roswell Park Cancer Institute (RPCI) in Buffalo, NY, beginning in 1961. He combined brilliant research with compassionate patient care as Chief of Colorectal Service at RPCI, and Research Associate Professor at the University of Buffalo. In 1991 he was named Professor Emeritus. In 2001 he moved to Willmington, DE, and worked with his close friend Dr. Nicholas Petrelli, Medical Director of the Helen Graham Cancer Center. He shared his life with Edith Sproul, M.D., Associate Professor at New York Presbyterian Hospital, and Associate Chief Cancer Research Pathologist at RPCI. Dr. Mittelman, deeply loved and respected, is mourned by two daughters and granddaughters, a sister and her family, and numerous friends and colleagues.

MARCUS--Lloyd, died on February 3, 2008. Loving husband of Alice, father of David and John, grandfather of Sarah, Daniel, Benjamin and Tatiana. Also survived by his brother James, sister-in-law Ellen, niece and nephew Lauren Hughes and Gary Marcus and sister-in-law Betty Marcus. His brother Robert predeceased him. A memorial service will be held March 29, 2008 at Westchester Ethical Culture Society, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Human Rights Watch, Children's Rights Division or the charity of your choice.

MELAMED--David (Jack). Veteran movie industry executive, 96, died peacefully at home in Los Angeles. Survived by Pearl Flaster Melamed, wife of 65 years, sons Vincent, of Nashville, TN (Meredith), Andrew, of Hanalei, HI (Christine), and grandchildren Mia, Dylan and Nage. A native of New York City, Melamed worked in the movie business from 1933 to 1998. His integrity, leadership, and love of family will be missed by all.

MILLER--Gloria. Gloria Bley Miller, 86, of New York City, died January 17, 2008. She was a beloved friend and a best-selling author. Without fanfare, she gave generously of her time, ingenuity and resources to the people and institutions she valued. Mrs. Miller was born November 12, 1921 in New York City. She received a bachelor of arts degree in art from Hunter College and a masters degree in education from the Bank Street College and had a varied career that included editing, comic book writing, bookkeeping, publicity direction, and occupational therapy, but found her true calling in writing. In 1962, she married the late Richard McDermott Miller, the prominent sculptor, and they enjoyed a loving and mutually supportive marriage until his death in 2004. Mrs. Miller's classic The Thousand Recipe Chinese Cookbook, published in 1966, remains in print. Craig Claiborne wrote that it should be treasured by anyone with a serious interest in the Chinese cuisine and named it to his Recommended Cookbook Library. She wrote or collaborated on several other books, including, with her dear friend Freddie Mae Baxter, The Seventh Child in 1999, and was at work on her latest, her own memoir of her friendship with the writer Grace Paley, at the time of her death. Mrs. Miller traveled extensively throughout her life and collected art and crafts from around the world. She was a fixture in her West Village neighborhood and in her beloved Chinatown, which she visited weekly to shop and eat. She was a benefactor to several non-profits, but especially valued the Authors Guild, of which she was a member since 1977. Her friends loved her for her kindness, humor, intelligence and loyalty, and they miss her tremendously. A memorial service will be held at a time and place to be determined. In lieu of flowers a donation can be made to the Authors Guild Foundation (31 East 32nd Street, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10017). Information about the memorial will be available at the Foundation: 212594-7931.

The Heads Up column on Jan. 27, about the Ciudad Universitaria in Mexico City, with its sites of interest for tourists, misspelled part of the name of the university with which it is affiliated. It is the Universidad Nacional Autónoma (not Autónomo) de México. The article also misspelled the name of one of the artists whose sculptures can be seen on the grounds. He is Mathias Goeritz, not Matías Goertiz.

DALTON--William Joseph, entered into eternal rest on Thursday, January 31, 2008 in Charleston, South Carolina. The funeral service will take place at 10:00 am on Monday, February 4th in the Chapel at Bishop Gadsden. Funeral services are being handled by Palmetto Cremation Society. Bill was born in Orange, New Jersey on March 14, 1924 to Thomas and Margaret Dalton. Left to cherish his memory are his wife of 58 years, Jeanne Foote Dalton; son Mark, wife Susan of Scarsdale, New York, and grandsons Erik, Kurt (Michele) and Chris; son Roger, wife Lynn of Kettering, Ohio, and grandchildren Katie and Joe; daughter Denise, husband Rob Schneider of Hinsdale, Illinois, and grandchildren Elizabeth, Emily, and Will; and his sister Mary Theresa, husband Joseph Fitzgerald and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins. Bill attended Pratt Institute prior to his appointment in October 1942 to the US Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, NY, where he was commissioned in June 1944 as an Ensign in the US Naval Reserve and received a BS degree in Naval Science. Bill served in the Atlantic and Pacific, the latter with the Pacific Fleet and was involved in the war in the Philippine Islands and Japan. He served on the USS Neshoba and the USS Franks in the battles of Leyte Gulf, Iwo Jima, and Okinawa. He was present on the USS Neshoba at the surrender ceremony in August 1945 in Tokyo Bay. He earned three battle stars during this period. Bill left the USS Neshoba and was assigned to the office of Naval Research and Invention at Sands Point, Long Island in January 1946. He left active duty and assumed Naval Reserve status in September 1946 when he entered Georgetown University in Washington, DC. He received a BS degree International Economics at the Foreign Service School at Georgetown in june 1948. He joined WR Grace & Co. in 1948 and then was recalled for the Korean Conflict by the Navy and served from 1950-1952. During Korean Service, he was Aide and Flag Lieutenant to Admiral Robert Briscoe, who was Commander Naval Forces, Far East. Bill served aboard the USS Wisconsin, the Admiral's flagship, during the period. In 1952 bill joined General motors corporation, the beginning of a 32 year career which included executive and senior executive positions in the GM Truck and Coach Division, the Corporate Manufacturing Staff, the Frigidaire Division, the Terex Division, and I.B.H (UK). Since his retirement in 1984, Bill and Jeanne have been residents at Seabrook Island and Bishop Gadsden Retirement Community. Bill has at various times been a member of many boards and committees, including the Medical University of South Carolina President's Advisory Committee, the Storm Eye Institute Advisory Board, the College of Charleston, Board of Visitors and Foundation Board, President of The Club at Seabrook Island and Chairman of Bishop Gadsden's Residents Council Administration and Finance Committee. Memorials can be made to Bishop Gadsden Residents Assistant Fund, 1 Bishop Gadsden Way, Charleston, SC 29412 or Medical University of South Carolina Foundation, 261 Calhoun St., Suite 306, Charleston, SC 29425.

DESPITE mounting publicity about ways to avoid foreclosure, most borrowers who are struggling to keep up with mortgage payments remain unaware that their lenders are willing to help them. A report released late last month by Freddie Mac, one of two government-sponsored businesses that acquire mortgages from lenders and sell them to investors, said that 57 percent of delinquent borrowers did not know about workout options from lenders and companies that service loans on a lender's behalf.

One very rushed president, 50 community leaders, dozens of concerns and fewer than 30 minutes of face time: that, in a nutshell, is what characterized the meeting this afternoon between President Felipe Calderón of Mexico and a group of Mexican activists from across the New York region, held behind closed doors at the New York Marriott Downtown Hotel in Lower Manhattan.

Another day in Albany, another skirmish in the budget wars. Over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzer began floating some changes to his proposed budget for the coming fiscal year, including a projected $384 million in state revenue because of the worsening economy climate.
What we’re looking at on the Web today…

Updated, 12:37 p.m. | Addressing the United Nations General Assembly this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reiterated his call for a carbon tax in the United States, suggested that congestion pricing could be a model for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in other world cities and announced a plan to reduce the city’s use of tropical hardwoods, calling tropical deforestation an “ecological calamity.” And of course, he managed to throw in a boast about the city’s 311 line.

Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nation’s economy, Danny Hakim reports. To keep the budget in balance, the governor is proposing several new spending cuts, including further paring back increases in Medicaid reimbursements and dipping into the state’s environmental protection fund. While the changes represent a fraction of New York’s $124 billion budget, they are a sign of how rapidly shifting economic forecasts are causing havoc with the state’s fiscal planning. It is rare for a governor to second-guess his own budget, especially so soon after releasing it.

New York City’s 18,000 foreclosure filings last year accounted for more than half of state foreclosure filings in 2007. Now one out of every 40 homes with a mortgage in New York City had a filing as of the end of September 2007, more than twice the rate for the rest of New York State.

This is not the kind of buzz typically sought by Yellow Rat Bastard, the trendy SoHo clothing retailer: It has agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a lawsuit over unpaid wages and overtime, according to the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. The apparel and shoe chain, which takes its name from Frank Miller’s “Sin City” crime comics and cultivates an edgy notoriety with its pierced staff and graffiti decor, is no stranger to controversy.

Updated, 10:56 p.m. | The Landmarks Preservation Commission is expected on Tuesday to schedule a hearing on whether to designate Silver Towers/University Village, a concrete complex designed by I. M. Pei that was part of Robert Moses’s vast urban renewal program, as a historic landmark. Preservationists have urged such a move, arguing that New York University’s proposed campus expansion could some day threaten the towers, which sit at the edge of the university’s campus in Greenwich Village.

Yes, I know the image of sitting down to coffee and cakes in the afternoon, a German and Austrian tradition especially, has the feel of something your grandparents do. You totter over to the table in your Sunday best and linger for lack of anything better to do in retirement. But soft! Doesn't a ritual built around good coffee and delicious pastries deserve more respect than that? As a matter of fact, it does.

LONDON - Toby Silverton, chairman of Bristol Cars, is terribly disappointed. Sitting with him in Bristol's only showroom in the world, on Kensington High Street, I've explained that 50 percent of my friends and car-loving colleagues had no idea who or what Bristol was when I mentioned my plan to visit the company - horrible news for any other car manufacturer.

The Bagger wrote about the Writers Guild awards ceremony at the Hudson Theater last Saturday night and suggested that the "head writer" for "The Daily Show" had a rugged time during his tour at the mic. While the would-be funny guy in question does work for "The Daily Show," he is not the head writer. That guy's name is Steve Bodow and he was at home taking care of his newborn daughter. He was nowhere near the mic or the Hudson Theater. The Bagger and David Carr both apologize for the error.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- With less than a minute left in warmups before the Tennessee-Rutgers game, the Volunteers' Candace Parker was still wearing her long orange warmup pants. Parker, the reigning national player of the year, injured her left knee Feb. 7 in a victory over Mississippi State and was carried off the floor.

Ding, ding - Soft Serve is served. ... New York Fashion Week ends, London Fashion Week begins. Fashion editors should be careful when exercising their expense accounts. A very wealthy restaurant patron in London suspects he was served a fake bottle of 1961 Chateau Pétrus (cost: about $35,000). To crack the case, the restaurant has called the Bloodhound Gang of the wine world, the Pétrus Police. ... Talk about rip offs, a van Gogh, Monet, Degas and Cézanne were reported stolen a private collection (cost: about $100 million) ... Usually Gucci is getting knocked off, not the other way around. The heat is on the luxury brand for its new campaign, an unauthorized homage to Milton Glaser's I heart NY... Also in legal hot water is Croc, the un-chic shoe manufacturer. The family of a girl whose Croc got chewed up by an escalator is suing for $7 million. Croc has acknowledged, "a long-existing issue that we think is very important - escalator safety." ... For less serious scrapes and cuts, look forward to Band-Aids 2.0, with build-in microchips ... Speaking of painful, this week New York Magazine's Best Bets goes rummaging for 40-year-old junk. ... Count us in, maybe, for a round of retail therapy at Damien Hirst's London "Art Shop." We can't afford the $100 million diamond skull, but a second mortgage might afford us a $50,000 painted cranium. ... We guess Londoners like to blow their cash on tighty whities. After the hunky David Beckham billboards were erected, Emporio Armani saw a 150 percent sales increase. Must be the packaging ... Closer to home, Posh got a similarly jubilant reception last night from the gay crowd at Hiro nightclub. One solitary dissenter, the porn actor and activist Michael Lucas, poo-pooed Posh on dermatological grounds, saying, "I think I would commit suicide if I had her skin... her skin is yellow with big pores." Major meanie! ... Soft Serve will spice up your life tomorrow, when we return.

Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor, is turning up the heat on Wendy's International, which he wants to add to his fast-food holdings.
ABC announced pick-ups for nine series on Monday, including five returning hits and four new programs.

Prices hikes don't get much smaller than this: The United States Post Office has decided to raise the price of stamps from 41 cents to 42. The new price will take effect in May, a year after a two cent increase. Other post office services will cost slightly more as well, but not more than the rate of inflation over the past 12 months. More details at the official site. --MN

Jorge Posada swung, his bat shattered and, for a millisecond, everyone around the batting cage gasped. After Posada's bat broke, a large chunk of it ricocheted off the backstop netting, the same side of the backstop where Derek Jeter was standing, and hit Posada in the right leg.

The Ottawa Senators and Carolina Hurricanes have broken the ice, swinging the first major deal of the trading season, with two weeks to go to the Feb. 26 trade deadline.

I don't go to very many industry tastings. These are large, invitation-only events where an importer or distributor generally will show its roster of wines, often with winemakers themselves pouring samples. You can taste dozens if not hundreds of wines at these events, if you spit and work efficiently. Mostly, they're useful to retail and restaurant buyers who have to stock their stores and wine lists. They're rarely useful to somebody like me, unless I can target specific wines that I want to taste for one reason or another, or find specific people whom I want to speak with. I don't learn much about wines in that kind of context.
Mere days/hours/seconds (how excited are you?) before Valentine's Day, BBC News brought most unwelcome news: Regulators raid chocolate firms.

Derek Jeter's rookie season in 1996 coincided with Joe Torre's first year as the Yankees' manager and ended with a World Series title. Jeter had a strong relationship for 12 seasons with the man he called Mr. Torre or Mr. T.

The Kellwood deal took a slight turn this weekend. On Friday, Sun Capital amended its tender offer to include a new condition "that, upon the closing of the tender offer, Sun Capital representatives on the Kellwood Board of Directors will constitute a majority of the directors and be proportionate in number to Sun Capital's percentage shareholding in the Company."

CBS's broadcast of the "50th Annual Grammy Awards" was the highest-rated program on Sunday night, both among overall viewers and within the choice demographic of adults 18 to 49. But the good news for the program pretty much ends there.

The Grammy Awards helped CBS finish No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 p.m. hour prior to the Grammy's with "60 Minutes" (13 million viewers). ABC ranked second for the night thanks to a two-hour "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" at 8 p.m. (15.8 million) followed by "Brothers & Sisters" at 10 p.m. (8.6 million).

William Lerach, a former partner at a prestigious New York law firm, was sentenced Monday to two years in federal prison for his role in a lucrative kickback scheme involving class-action lawsuits against some of the nation's biggest corporations.

Updated Senator Barack Obama's campaign has confirmed that he has canceled a meeting scheduled for today with former Senator John Edwards in North Carolina. The two have been talking on the phone and will meet soon, people close to both men say, but for now the media attention has become too intense and is out of control, with stake-outs at Mr. Edwards's home.

I sincerely hope that the moronic idea of hiding food that kids don't like in foods they do -- see "The Sneaky Chef" and "Deceptively Delicious" -- is a passing phase. (The funniest thing about these two books is that the public uproar wasn't over their approach to cooking but over which author had the idea first.) This does a real disservice to kids and -- not that this is my bailiwick -- is evidence that today's parents will do anything to avoid a confrontation.

The race for the White House isn't the only news story that is enriched (or perhaps not-so-enriched) by polls. Over the weekend, a poll conducted in Japan showed how seriously consumers are taking a recent food scare.

The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on The New York Times Company's board has more than doubled its stake in the company, to at least 10 percent of the regular shares, according to federal records filed Monday.

Panera!) under construction. I'm a creature of habit, and as long as the weather is good, the iced tea at Camille's is cold and the storylines are intriguing, I'm a happy camper. "Better than nothing" is the best thing that can be said about the economic stimulus bill passed by Congress last week and soon to be signed by President Bush. Yet congressional leaders are full of self-congratulation over the bill, because they passed it swiftly with bipartisan support.

Cable networks have not felt the pinch of the writers' strike to the extent the broadcast networks have. After all, they rely more extensively on repeats, reality shows and movies. Also, many of their series premiere during the summer months, against the grain of the September-to-May broadcast season.

On the drive down to Port St. Lucie, Fla., from his home in southeastern Virginia, David Wright stopped to play 18 holes at the famed TPC at Sawgrass course in Ponte Vedra Beach, outside Jacksonville. The golf nuts among us will know it as the home to the Players' Championship, but even the casual followers have probably seen its most recognizable hole, the par-3, 132-yard 17th that is known as the Island Green. Getting a chance to play that hole was, Wright said, his whole reason for stopping.

Microsoft has already shown its skill in crafting a "bear hug" letter. Now Yahoo has tried its hand at the bid-rejection letter, and the result is remarkably, well, nice -- especially when compared with the much harsher rejections that some other companies have issued in recent years.

A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the electric company to patch things back together. The New York shows were that fast-receding train; suddenly, on Saturday morning, they were no more.

For this recipe, steer clear of anchovies that come in two-ounce tins, usually packed in "vegetable" or other non-olive oil. The right ones are packed in jars, in olive oil from Spain or Italy, or packed in salt. The ones packed in salt require rinsing, de-boning and, preferably, a bit of marinating in olive oil before use. They're really good but obviously far more work.

The Bagger has a small admission to make. While the writer's strike has been storming along, it's been a little difficult to get excited about the micro and macro aspects of the Oscars. As long as people were out of work and both the outcome and the future were in doubt, the correct answer to the question of whether another film could sneak through for best picture if "No Country" and "There Will Be Blood" split the voters, was, "Who cares?"
To Planet Earth, that is -- though I wouldn't be surprised if all this eventually affects the International Space Station, too.

On Saturday night, the Bagger came in for the Writers Guild Awards at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan. He showed partly because there was news of a possible strike settlement, and partly because he has a soft spot for the event, which has little of the sizzle and none of the gloss of the other awards dealibops.
After another busy weekend on the campaign trail, both parties' candidates will be canvassing the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia today ahead of Tuesday's primary there.
CCMP Capital Advisors said that it had hired two executive advisers to help the private equity firm find investments in the consumer and healthcare sectors.
The continuing clash between Democrats and Republicans over national security will play out in Congress this week through a terrorist surveillance bill.

A private equity fund run by Goldman Sachs has acquired about 20 percent of Capula Investment Management, a $3 billion hedge fund, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources. The stake could be worth as much as $100 million but carries no voting rights, the newspaper said.
A look at the fashions at the 2008 Grammy Awards.

Lynn Hirschberg of the New York Times magazine muses on where fame comes from and anoints a new crop of the soon-to-be- famous in a remarkable portfolio of photos. The nascent pantheon includes a few folks who have been seen around Oscar-town this season.

The life and mysterious death of Seth Tobias, the hedge fund manager found floating lifelessly in his pool last September, has fascinated the press for months. How could it not? The rogues gallery includes Mr. Tobias's wife; a former assistant to Mr. Tobias (and reputed former pimp) named Bill Ash; a male go-go dancer named Tiger; and a mysterious Internet psychic who goes by the name Mama.

The Bagger is not a huge podcast fan -- they're not searchable, for one thing, and it's pretty obvious, listening to them, why most of the writers being recorded type for a living. But he made an exception for the gab session between Tom O'Neil, he of the Gold Derby, and Sasha Stone, empress of Awards Daily. Among other juicy bits, they fire back at some of the mainstream journalists who are in such a snit about the rise of the blogocrats. And they do a fine job of explaining how "No Country," a film with lots of rough edges, ended up leading the Oscar pack.

At last night's Orange British Academy Film Awards, otherwise known as the BAFTA's, "Atonement" won best picture, the Coens won best director(s), Javier Bardem and Daniel Day-Lewis assumed their usual positions. But there were a few curves in the women's category, with best lead going to Marion Cotillard for inhabiting the character of Edith Piaf in "La Vie en Rose" and best supporting going to British actress Tilda Swinton for her riveting portrayal of an American businesswoman with a taste for lethal solutions in "Michael Clayton." Diablo Cody picked up another chit for conceiving "Juno," while the adapted category went to Ronald Harwood for "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly."

The police investigating the trading scandal at Société Générale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed, The New York Times reported.

Société Générale, the French bank reeling from a rogue trading scandal, started a rights issue at a steep discount on Monday, intending to raise 5.5 billion euros ($7.97 billion) to bolster its balance sheet.
Air Canada's depressed share price might put it in play for privatization or partnership with a carrier in the United States, the airline's parent company, ACE Aviation Holdings, said Friday.

After getting a $55 million injection from Technology Crossover Ventures last November, TheStreet.com is using some of that cash to roll out mainstreet.com today in a bid to expand beyond its pure-play financial focus and add celebrity news with a personal finance angle.
The auction of Getty Images, the distributor of pictures and video, appears to be in jeopardy, The New York Times reported Monday.

As the courts sort out a struggle for control of IAC/InterActiveCorp and its planned five-piece breakup, the company has reshuffled its in-house dealmakers.

As the famed class-action lawyer William S. Lerach steps before a federal judge in Los Angeles on Monday to learn his sentence in a wide-ranging fraud and conspiracy probe, his misdeeds and those of his former colleagues might be helping to alter the way securities law is practiced, according to The Los Angeles Times.
A steel producer, the Nucor Corporation, is buying one of the biggest scrap metal companies in the United States for $1.44 billion.

WestLB, a state-owned German bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

Ernie Accorsi and then Jerry Reese made enough wise decisions to give the Giants a chance to win the Super Bowl. Now Reese must continue to make sound choices for an opportunity to repeat. One of those decisions has a name: Jeremy Shockey.

Building up its arsenal before facing off against the CME Group, an upstart and still unnamed electronic futures exchange backed by a dozen financial players is considering Archipelago founder Jerry Putnam for its chief executive, The Chicago Tribune reported.
Smart, tough and above all a dealmaker, the Macquarie Group's new chief executive, Nicholas Moore, draws plaudits befitting the head of a global investment bank.

Last year, as governments in Asia and the Middle East started to buy stakes in financial institutions in the West, the Bush administration called for an international code of conduct by sovereign wealth funds. The purpose was to get the funds to disclose more of their activities and not play politics with their investments.
When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsoft's $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsoft's sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.
The co-founder of Active Endeavors, an upscale clothing retailer, and two other investors who are owed $936,200 apparently have blocked, at least temporarily, the sale of the company.

If hedge funds are, as is often claimed, the investment vanguard, their latest moves appear to be telling financial markets it is time to take a break from the trading patterns that have dominated since mid-2007.

A solar cell maker, Suniva, has raised $50 million in its second round of funding to be used for a new manufacturing facility near Atlanta. The financing was led by New Enterprise Associates and Advanced Equities.

A mobile phone coupon company Cellfire has raised $12 million in a third round of funding. The round includes a new investor, Silver Creek Ventures, and existing ones, including Menlo Ventures and Storm Ventures.
HSBC, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, according to press reports.

A hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, is teaming up with EchoStar and other investors to inject $300 million into TerreStar to help develop a land and satellite mobile broadband communications network.

The Credit Suisse Group is earning more than UBS for the first time in almost a decade after it avoided the write-downs that forced UBS to report the biggest-ever quarterly loss by a bank, according to Bloomberg News.
A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.
Yahoo is seeking to restart merger talks with AOL as a means of defending itself against Microsoft's unsolicited $44.6 billion bid, according to the Times of London.

"It is not quite peace that has broken out here in Hollywood. But emotions are finally settling down in the entertainment industry's bubbling cauldron of labor disputes," Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

Another expat couple is facing heavy fines and the possible demolition of their home in Spain, after the local government declared it illegal.

The second major outage of BlackBerry service in less than a year is an embarrassment for Ontario-based Research in Motion, the maker of Blackberry devices.

In its annual report to Congress, the Bush administration acknowledged that deepening problems in the housing and credit markets will lead to slower growth than last year.
The risk of a terrorist attack on a nuclear research reactor on a college campus has been underestimated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, according to Congressional auditors.
The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on The New York Times Company’s board has increased its stake in the company to at least 9.96 percent of the regular shares, records show.
Primaries in both parties will be held on Tuesday in Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia.
Six Guantánamo detainees accused in the 2001 attacks will be shown all the evidence against them, the Pentagon said. The death penalty will be sought.
Sales of US Weekly and a new competitor, OK! Weekly, climbed sharply in the second half of 2007, even as price increases contributed to a drop in overall sales of celebrity magazines.
