Andrea Fischbacher of Austria and Fabienne Suter of Switzerland shared a victory in a super-G that was shaped by varying wind and several crashes. It was the first World Cup victory for Fischbacher and Suter, who each finished in 1 minute 21.06 seconds on the Kandahar Banchetta course in Sestriere, Italy. The American Lindsey Vonn, Saturday’s downhill winner, finished 16th and dropped into a tie for the overall World Cup lead with Austrian Nicole Hosp, who placed 14th.Julia Mancuso was the top finisher for the United States, coming in eighth. She was faster than the winners through the first interval but lost time on the bottom as the course shifted to the other face of the Banchetta mountain and into the wind. Maria Riesch of Australia finished third, 0.24 back, to maintain her lead in the super-G standings.

An ailing Novak Djokovic retired despite leading in the first reverse singles match, giving Russia a 3-2 win over Serbia in Moscow and a spot in the Davis Cup quarterfinals.Djokovic was leading Nikolay Davydenko, 6-4, 6-3, 4-6, when he quit, allowing Russia to take an insurmountable 3-1 lead.Djokovic withdrew from the opening singles Friday because of flulike symptoms but paired with Nenad Zimonjic on Saturday to give Serbia a point by beating Mikhail Youzhny and Dmitry Tursunov.In other matches Sunday, Sweden rallied to beat Israel, 3-2, winning both reverse singles; and Philipp Kohlschreiber gave Germany the winning point in a 3-2 win over South Korea in the best-of-five series by beating Lee Hyung-taik, 6-0, 4-6, 6-1, 7-6 (1).

Manchester City completed a Premier League sweep of its crosstown rival Manchester United, beating host United, 2-1, amid commemorations for the 50th anniversary of the Munich air disaster.Before the match, the eight players on Matt Busby’s team that died in the 1958 plane crash were recalled on electronic billboards featuring all 23 victims. The five remaining survivors of the crash attended the match at Old Trafford, where a minute’s silence was observed. The loss kept United from moving past idle Arsenal at the top of the Premier League standings. Arsenal leads with 60 points and plays Blackburn on Monday. United is second with 58 points.

The United States completed a 4-1 first-round Davis Cup victory against Austria in Vienna on Sunday, a day after securing a quarterfinal spot with a doubles victory.The United States was competing for the first time since winning the Davis Cup in December.The teams split the meaningless reverse singles matches. The United States team captain Patrick McEnroe rested Andy Roddick and James Blake and let the doubles partners Bob and Mike Bryan play.Mike Bryan withdrew with an injured left hamstring in the second set against Stefan Koubek, giving Austria its only point. Bob Bryan posted a 6-0, 3-6, 7-6 (3) victory over Werner Eschauer, who substituted for Jürgen Melzer.The United States will play host to France, which beat Romania in the first round, on April 11-13 for a place in the semifinals.

LAWRENCE--George E. The Board of Directors and staff of Marien-Heim of Brooklyn mourn the loss of their longtime Board Officer and friend, George E. Lawrence. George served with distinction on our Board for over 3 decades. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, children and grandchildren. Robert J. Walsh, President

RE-UP GANG ''We Got It for Cheap: The Mixtape, Volume 3'' (mixtape) After a successful major-label debut, ''Lord Willin' '' (Star Trak/Arista), in 2002, the Virginia duo Clipse went underground. On a pair of startling mixtapes -- ''We Got It 4 Cheap,'' Volumes 1 & 2 -- the pair emerged sounding meaner, slicker and smarter than ever. The two members, Pusha-T and Malice, rhymed almost exclusively about selling crack. They were criminal-minded formalists, and it wasn't exactly clear how their obsessions fit together. Did they care only about selling cocaine and making money? Or did they care only about rhyme schemes and wordplay? And was there a connection?

THE WHIGS ''Mission Control'' (ATO) Parker Gispert, the Whigs' guitarist and songwriter, never sounds complacent. His songs are ruthlessly concise, geared to what guitar, bass and drums can play onstage. The Whigs' new album, ''Mission Control,'' rarely digresses from its hooks -- tightly chorded guitar parts and tense but tuneful vocals -- as it dips into rock from the 1960s to the 2000s, from garage-rock to post-punk. Mr. Gispert yowls with a torn, raspy edge in rockers, and when he decides to croon more smoothly, in the same register as Neil Young or Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, there's still an inner agitation. Underneath, Julian Dorio wallops his drums and splashes cymbals all over the place, making the dynamics erupt.

CHUMACEIRO--Harold. American Friends of the Salzburg Easter Festival is deeply saddened by the loss of our founding President, Harold Chumaceiro. Harold was an extraordinary gentleman possessed of great personal dignity and kindness. He and his beautiful wife Matilda Elena shared a deep love of music and enthusiasm for the support of young musicians. They set an example for all of us to follow. We shall all miss the presence of these two elegant patrons of the arts and all of us shall think of them as we attend operas and concerts around the world for they will surely be there with us! Our deepest sympathy to their children and grandchildren who have suffered such devastating losses so quickly. Sir Simon Rattle, Chairman Pamela Rosenberg, President Stephen Stamas, Susan Bender, H. Alexandra Kauka, Raul Gutierrez, James B. Sitrick, Craig Henderson, Jocelyn Kress

Verizon Rejects Traffic Cop Role More often than not, companies in similar positions have similar views. But when Hollywood asked the two big phone companies to help with its fight against movie piracy, they responded in opposite ways. AT&T is talking about developing a system that would identify and block illicitly copied material being sent over its broadband network.

PRINCE--Augusta Dabney, an actress best known for her extensive career in daytime soap operas, died on February 4, 2008. A graduate of U. C. Berkeley, Ms. Dabney made her stage debut in ''Abe Lincoln in Illinois'' in 1938 where she met her first husband, actor Kevin McCarthy. Ms. Dabney appeared on Broadway, in regional theatre, feature films and on television. She starred in nine soap operas, including as Isabelle Alden on ''Loving'' for twelve years . She met her second husband, actor William Prince, on ''Young Dr. malone''. In the days of live television, Ms. Dabney appeared on Kraft Television Theatre and Robert Montgomery Presents. On Broadway, she starred in ''Children of a Lesser God'' and ''Seascape'' among other plays. Her film credits include ''Running on Empty'' and ''The Paper''. She is survived by three children from her first marriage: James Kevin McCarthy, Lillah McCarthy and Mary Dabney McCarthy, and four stepchildren from her second marriage: Jeremy Prince, Liza Alldredge, Nicholas Prince and Dinah Daly, and six grandchildren. The family suggests donations be made to the National MS Society.

LAURA MARLING ''Alas, I Cannot Swim'' (Virgin UK) For a teenager, the 18-year-old songwriter Laura Marling has some unusual fixations: permanence, divinity, death and the ways the past occludes the present. ''Old stone, 10,000 years and you're still on your own/Don't you love me that way,'' she sings in a haunted ballad.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the results of the Democratic primaries in New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate and a supporter of Senator Barack Obama. He is not chairman of Mr. Obama's campaign in New Jersey. (That post is shared by two mayors, Cory Booker of Newark and Jerramiah T. Healy of Jersey City.) Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the position held by Lowell P. Weicker, the Connecticut Republican, in 1992, the year that Connecticut voters chose Jerry Brown, the long-shot candidate from California, in the Democratic primary. At the time, Mr. Weicker was governor of Connecticut, not its senator.

LEVINE--Larry, on February 9, 2008 in Sarasota, FL of natural causes. Born May 10, 1926 in Bensonhurst, NY. He is the founder, designer and manufacturer of The Larry Levine line of women's clothing. He served in the US Navy during WWII. In his youth he was a welder on Liberty Ships in Fall River, MA, and became a long shoreman on the docks, working for the United Fruit Company. Honorary Chairman of the LAM Treatment Alliance, a member of the Asolo Theater Board. Survived by his wife of 48 years, Emily Hosley Levine (of Sarasota), daughter Anne Hall Levine (of Cape Cod), predeceased by his daughter Elena Esther, and his son Richard Henry. Two stepsons Joseph (Kathleen) and Jeffrey Brillinger, two nieces, one nephew and one great-grandson. Also predeceased by his sister, Frances Tucker of Scottsdale, AZ. Memorial Service will be held at Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Sarasota, FL, Thursday February 14, at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The LAM Treatment Alliance, Care of The Gulf Coast Community Foundation of Venice, 601 Tamiami Trail South, Venice, FL 34285.

Sixty-three Republican delegates and 83 Democratic delegates are up for grabs at the Virginia primary on Tuesday. Recent polling shows Senator John McCain with a two-to-one advantage over former Gov. Mike Huckabee, and Senator Barack Obama with a strong lead over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The poll was conducted Thursday and Friday by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research and included 400 likely Democratic primary voters and 400 likely Republican primary voters.

TABER--Gerald Patrick, on Wednesday, February 6, 2008, following a sudden illness, Gerald Patrick Taber died at Kingston General Hospital, with his family by his side. He is survived by Joan, his wife of 52 years, his son Geoff (Jacquie Gardner), his daughter Shelagh Walsh and his grandchildren, James, Stephen and Phoebe Walsh and Scott and Andrew Taber. Gerry was born in Saskatchewan to Russell and Dorothy Taber (nee Haslam). He was predeceased by his older brother Harry in 1995. He came east to attend Queen's University (where he received degrees in Arts and in Commerce in 1949) and then Harvard Business School (1952). Gerald worked in Ottawa, Toronto, Montreal and New York City before returning to Kingston in 1999. His family and friends will remember a man of great good humour, gentleness and generosity. Friends are invited to join the family at their home in Kingston, Ontario, on Monday, February 11 from 4 to 6pm. In accordance with Gerald's wishes, a private burial service will be held at a later date. If desired, donations in Gerald's memory may be made to the Salvation Army.

IT sounds like a recipe from the Internet's cookbook for business disasters. Sell bulky commodity items at prices low enough to compete with grocery stores, and ship them free to consumers. The recipe vaporized businesses like Pets.com, Webvan and other giants of the dot-com bust, but now it is being revived, successfully, in at least one category, baby supplies.

The Republican-led Senate held its fourth so-called Troopergate hearing today, the latest chapter in its investigation of efforts by Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. After nearly two and a half hours of testimony from experts from Research In Motion — the company that makes the Blackberry — and from two computer forensics experts and the state’s lead archivist, the senators learned what might seem a no-brainer to others: You can’t really cover your electronic tracks in the digital age (including old e-mail messages).

It was a bit like the great-grandson having a party for the patriarch. On Monday night, the six-year-old conservative blog Power Line gathered a group of luminaries — including Henry A. Kissinger, William Kristol and Paul D. Wolfowitz (with his companion, Shaha Ali Riza, in tow) — to honor Norman Podhoretz with a book award.

Updated, 3:09 p.m. | The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission voted this afternoon to designate as a landmark what is believed to be the oldest structure in Queens built as a synagogue. Estée Lauder once worshiped there, and Madonna once lived at a former yeshiva nearby. The commission is also expected to vote to protect the historic Jamaica Savings Bank building, which the body has twice previously voted to designate as a landmark, only to be overturned by higher powers.

A D train was delayed at the West 125th Street stop in Manhattan this morning around 9:30 a.m. when a large (though skinny) dog ran onto the subway car and began frolicking under the seats, through the poles and between commuters’ legs. It was unclear how the dog got to the station, and who its owner was, but from the looks of things, it was not a Westminster Kennel Club show escapee.

The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously this afternoon to grant landmark status for a third time to the former headquarters of Jamaica Savings Bank, a 110-year-old Beaux-Arts style building that has been a subject of dispute for decades. Twice before, the commission’s votes to grant landmark status to the building have been overturned: once by the Board of Estimate in 1975 and again by the City Council in 1992.
Video

Tuesday afternoon’s snowfall in New York City, however modest, represents the first accumulation of snow in the city since Dec. 16, when an inch was recorded in Central Park, according to the National Weather Service.As Anthony Ramirez reported on Feb. 2, last month was the least snowy January since 1933. January 1890 had no observed snow at all.

The State Senate today unanimously passed a bill, proposed by New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, that is intended to increase protections for children and teenagers from sexual predators on the Internet. The bill, known as the Electronic Security and Targeting of Online Predators, or E-Stop, would require convicted sex offenders to register their e-mail addresses and the online names they use to identify themselves on social networking sites, which would then use that information to block those users from access to their sites.State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Long Island Republican who sponsored the measure, said it represented an updating of Megan’s Law, which required sex offenders to register with the authorities, for the Internet age.

Erin Sheehan, the community editor for UrbanBaby, took questions from readers during the week of Feb. 11 about parenting in New York City and other urban areas. UrbanBaby is one of the more popular Web sites for parents seeking peer-generated content and word-of-mouth information.
What we’re looking at on the Web today…

New York City’s hospitals — public and private, large and small — are spending hundreds of millions of dollars renovating, rebuilding and expanding their emergency rooms, Sarah Kershaw reports in a front-page article. They are dividing them into treatment areas for the sickest patients with the most dire injuries and using quieter corners for the growing number of patients using emergency rooms for routine medical care. And an increasing number are taking steps to bring civility and even hospitality to the emergency room, in part because, for all their turmoil, they remain vital points of entry for paying patients whose eventual admission accounts for needed revenue.
Images of nominees for best short at the 80th annual Academy Awards.

The New York Times's Jay Schreiber looks back at the last time Congress held a public hearing concerning steroids and baseball, and previews Wednesday's hearing featuring Roger Clemens and his former trainer, Brian McNamee, regarding accusations contained in the Mitchell report.

"Hollywood's writers made it official on Tuesday night, ending their bitterly fought strike at the 100-day mark by an overwhelming margin," Michael Cieply reports. "Of 3,775 writers who cast ballots, 92.5 percent voted in favor of ending the strike. Officials of the Writers Guild of America West and the Writers Guild of America East disclosed results of the tally an hour after voting had closed at 6 p.m. here."
The Writers Guild of America strike ended at the 100-day mark after a vote by guild members. Here is how the strike commenced and concluded:
As noted earlier today, "Saturday Night Live," the only late-night television show that stayed off the air during the entirety of the writers' strike, is expected to return on Feb. 23.
Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, puts an exotic twist on an old-fashioned dish.

If Charles Darwin were alive today, he'd be turning 199: like Abraham Lincoln, he was born on Feb. 12 1809.
When Paul Stastny went down Jan. 17 with an appendicitis in the middle of a brilliant sophomore season, the prognosis was grim for the Colorado Avalanche.

10:57 p.m. | Wrapup: Here's all you have to know about tonight, beyond Mr. Obama's landslide wins that washed out Mrs. Clinton in Virginia, Maryland, and the District: Mr. Obama beat Mrs. Clinton among women in both Virginia and Maryland. (There were no exit polls in the District.) And Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton were running about even among white voters. He's also pulled ahead a bit in the race for delegates by the Associated Press's count. It's serious retrenchment time in the Clinton camp. And it's time to see if Mr. Obama can turn this series of wins since Super Tuesday into the Big Mo.

Mike Henry, a deputy campaign manager for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, has resigned from the Clinton team, writing in his farewell letter to the staff that he was stepping aside out of respect for the "new leadership team" led by Maggie Williams, who was installed as campaign manager on Sunday.
The scene at the second day of the Westminster Dog Show in New York City.

When Net-a-Porter announced it planned to sell two styles from the Halston runway the day after the show, I thought it would be interesting to test drive the concept. After all, this was the first time, to my knowledge, that a look from a designer runway would be immediately available to consumers. The plan was for Net-a-Porter to have two shirt dress styles, in chocolate brown or teal blue, and a draped silk jersey shift with a low back. The Halston show was last Monday, and Net-a-Porter planned to go live with its sale within 24 hours of the show. I felt like Betty Crocker, testing a new concept.

These are trying days for everyone at Yahoo -- not just for Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive. As Mr. Yang and his board try to keep Microsoft from buying Yahoo -- or try to get it to raise its offer before they agree to sell -- the ax came down Tuesday on some 1,000 employees.

Last week, one of my New York Times colleagues canceled a lunch meeting because he was sick and wanted to go home to rest. It was a Friday, and it was raining heavily outside. Even though I was looking forward to that meeting, I was delighted. His canceling meant that I didn't have to leave my apartment. (I work from home.) And I also wouldn't be at risk of catching his cold.

When I interviewed Yankees Manager Joe Girardi in Coral Springs, Fla., last Wednesday, we set 9 a.m. as the meeting time. I figured I would get to the coffee shop early to scout out a quiet place to sit. I arrived at 8:40 a.m., and Girardi was already there.
The City Council speaker offered modest cost-saving proposals offset by new spending and tax-cutting initiatives aimed at improving the economy.
Rudolph W. Giuliani may no longer be a candidate for the presidency. But at least he has a law firm bearing his name to return to.

Sure, the Potomac primaries today are pretty important, especially Virginia, but many observers see the real showdown for the Democrats coming up on March 4 in Texas. The Lone Star state could be make or break for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign, and Senator Barack Obama would, of course, prefer the latter.

Remember that GQ article about Hillary Clinton that the Clinton campaign successfully scuttled by threatening to restrict access to Bill Clinton for another planned piece? The author of the scuttled article was Joshua Green, a senior editor for The Atlantic, who now says it "focused on the inner workings of Clinton's presidential campaign" and in particular on the "controversial role" of Patti Solis Doyle, the campaign manager whom Mrs. Clinton recently replaced.

CBS announced today that CSTV, the college sports media company that the network bought two years ago, will be renamed the CBS College Sports Network in March.

Devoted to the Middle East, broadly defined, Bidoun is one of the more intriguing literary magazines on the international scene. Its name means "without" in both Arabic and Farsi, which its editors say "connotes the statelessness in which many of us find ourselves-sometimes voluntarily, sometimes not."

Teenagers need their rest, so the New York Red Bulls on Monday sent home to Florida their 18-year-old rising star, Jozy Altidore, until the club leaves for training in Austria on Feb. 25.

Lazard said Tuesday that it has hired Tetsuya Kawano as the chairman of its Japanese investment banking unit. Mr. Kawano, 49, who most recently worked as vice chairman of J.P. Morgan Asia Pacific, will work alongside Yasu Hatakeyama, the chief executive of Lazard's Japanese unit.

The anger in the Hispanic community over the ousting of Patti Solis Doyle as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign manager continues to unfold, with two Hispanic legislators from Mrs. Clinton's home state sending an open letter to her expressing their concerns. (They're not the only ones voicing concerns.)

Backpackers, expats and Diesel devotees can start paying cash. At certain wine and antiques establishments in New York's East Village, customers can now pay in Euros. ... The worldly Andre Balazs's new hot property is a prefab home. He paid $5 million for the Jean Prouvé classic, "Maison Tropicale," which will be relocated to South Beach Miami just in time for Art Basel next year..."Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles" isn't a work of art like the original Terminator film but we suspect it's inspiring creativity. Brian Holm, a designer for Danish label Wood Wood, said he "started thinking about the apocalypse" for his latest collection. (Do they get Fox in Denmark?) ... In Beijing, the Chinese are looking to the future for their architecture. The new "Water Cube" sports facility, which cost $100 million and consists of an LED system capable of 16.7 million tones, looks totally sci-fi, like it's made of bubble wrap. ... Since everything is cheaper in Chinatown, Esquire recommends flying to Singapore's Chinatown for a custom-made suit. Feroz Abdul of Eurobest Tailor "can copy the patterns of Armani, Christian Dior, whatever you'd like" Sally Hershberger (of $800 haircut fame) is giving ladies on a budget the awkwardly-named Supreme Head line of hair products, which will be sold at Walgreen's for $9.50-$12.50. Keep your head full of fluffy news from consumer land; come back tomorrow for Soft Serve.

Valentine's Day came a little early this week for donors to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who sent them a thank-you email this afternoon that had a higher sugar count than a box of Godiva.

Yahoo is buying Maven Networks, a company that helps outfits like CBS and Sony put their video online. Its press release is full of all sorts of ways this will help Yahoo: It gets video technology. Yahoo will be able to use its sales force to sell video ads on partner sites. And it will be able to syndicate its content to other sites and bring other video content onto Yahoo.

Updated SPRINGFIELD, Va. -- John McCain's military expertise was cited by several people casting their ballots at Washington Irving Middle School here in this Washington suburb just beyond the Beltway in growing Fairfax County.

A 90-minute edition of "Deal or No Deal" lifted NBC to another No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen's estimates, 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the game show from 9:30 to 11 p.m., making it the night's top-rated broadcast. NBC also fared well earlier in the night as "American Gladiators" won its 8 to 9:30 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, though it drew a modest 8.8 million total viewers.

After I wrote about my dinner of sea bass last week, a number of you asked whether sea bass was endangered. The short answer is no. But it's something I always try to consider, and because these things can shift quickly, it's worth checking before you buy.

So we're headed into a downturn or a recession -- maybe we're already in one -- and as goes the economy, so goes technology spending. The latest confirmation of this came on Monday when Forrester Research lowered its 2008 estimates for the growth in spending on technology goods and services, down to 2.62.8 percent from 4.6 percent in the United States. Globally, says Forrester, growth will be 6 percent, down from a previous estimate of 9 percent.

The World Chess Federation has announced terms and conditions for proposals to host a match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria. The match is part of the current world championship cycle. The winner of the match will play a match against the winner of another match this October in Germany between Viswanathan Anand of India, the current world champion, and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the previous champion. The winner of that subsequent match will be the new world champion.

As analysts and investors try to handicap Microsoft's chances of clinching Yahoo, we thought it was a good time to consider the track record for large, hostile bids. Though many think that Yahoo's odds of staying independent are slim, Dealogic informs us that, at least by one measure, more big-ticket hostile bids have failed than succeeded in recent years.

In response to our coverage of eBay, we've had hundreds of commenters, mainly sellers, talking about how the changes in the site's rules make it harder to do business. You cannot say enough about falafel. These seasoned fritters are among the best things you can make with chickpeas, they're easy and rewarding to fry (perfect for novice deep-fryers) and they are vegetarian. For a fast tahini sauce, mix equal amounts of tahini and yogurt, and season to taste with a little salt, pepper, cumin, raw garlic if you like, and lemon juice. Not-too-hot chili paste is another good accompaniment.

If there remain any doubters that video games have hit the mainstream, witness wine hour at the Hotel Monaco in downtown Seattle. Daily, from 5 p.m. to 6 p.m., the hotel has had a tradition of offering wine and beer tasting. Now, on Friday afternoons, it is offering patrons some new fare: a sampling of Guitar Hero III.

The war of words between Yahoo and Microsoft has begun.
Microsoft has been justifying its $44 billion bid for Yahoo as a way to build sufficient scale in the search and advertising business to counter the Google juggernaut.

The Alliance Data Systems buyout imbroglio took another turn Monday as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn let the two sides know that he is now on the scene.

The $23 billion buyout of radio and outdoor advertising giant Clear Channel Communications could get antitrust approval from the Department of Justice as early as Wednesday, according to The Deal.com.

Xstrata has flatly rejected an informal cash and share takeover approach from the Brazilian mining group Vale, pitched at just under 40 pounds a share, or 39 billion pounds ($76 billion), for its entire equity, according to The Financial Times.

America Movil, the wireless operator, said that it would feature YouTube.com videos on its cellphones in a drive to increase customers. An America Movil spokeswoman said YouTube videos would be first available on all 3G equipment — the latest take on wireless communications — in Mexico but that they would extend to company operations in other parts of Latin America. Diego Molina, head of business development for Google in Latin America, said YouTube would be available to customers in Brazil by the end of April. YouTube has local sites in over 15 countries, including Mexico and Brazil. As part of YouTube’s two-year deal with America Movil, the video Web site plans to share advertising revenue with the Mexican company.
This week, there was no upset for the Scarlet Knights, just despair as another chance to beat their nemesis, the Lady Vols, was pulled away in the final seconds of a 59-58 defeat.

A German antitrust agency raided offices of several confectionery giants, including Nestlé, Kraft Foods and Mars, last week, suspecting that the companies had colluded to raise the prices of their products. Authorities also seized documents at the headquarters of a local favorite, Ritter Sport, whose square chocolate bars are ubiquitous in Germany and gaining popularity in the United States. The chocolate makers blame the rising cost of commodities for the price increases.

The European Union’s telecommunications commissioner said she would seek limits on the price Europeans pay to send short text messages when traveling outside their home countries, unless operators lower the charges by July. The commissioner, Viviane Reding, said the rates are four to five times domestic messaging rates. If prices were not reduced by July, Ms. Reding, left, said she would ask the European Parliament and Council of Ministers to enact price limits, which could take effect by the summer of 2009. Operators reacted coolly to her threat. Craig Ehrlich, the chairman of the GSM Association, which represents 700 mobile operators, said competitive pressure among operators was already bringing down prices, and further regulation was not needed.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Huggies diapers and Scott paper towels, plans to build two plants in Peru as part of a plan to make the country its South American hub. The company, based in Dallas, will double its personnel in Peru to 1,200 workers and invest about $60 million in a paper mill and a diaper factory in Lima, according to Kimberly-Clark’s country manager, Blanca Quino, who at a news conference at the presidential palace in Lima said the move will be the company’s largest investment so far in Latin America.
Andre Miller scored 21 points Monday night to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to an 84-76 victory against the visiting Dallas Mavericks.

Gazprom, the Russian gas company, agreed to delay by eight hours a deadline for Ukraine to negotiate a settlement for $1.5 billion in debt before shutting off a quarter of that country’s natural gas supply. In this latest dispute between the company and Ukraine, Gazprom threatened to shut the valves on Russian-sourced gas supplies to Ukraine after 10 a.m. on Tuesday. Gazprom, Russia’s largest company, relies on Ukraine to ship about 80 percent of the gas it exports to Europe. By late afternoon Monday, though, the two companies had not reached an agreement, and Gazprom issued a statement saying it would delay the deadline until 6 p.m. on Tuesday.
Fire damaged the buildings of several wholesale meat suppliers in the Hunts Point Cooperative Market in the South Bronx causing tens of millions of dollars in damage.

A headline on Monday with an article about pressure on the Israeli government to respond more forcefully to rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza misstated the condition of two brothers, ages 8 and 19, after an attack on their town, Sderot. They were seriously wounded; they are not dead.

An article on Friday about a Scotland Yard investigation into the assassination of Pakistan opposition leader Benazir Bhutto misidentified the location of the school attended by her 19-year-old son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari. He attends Oxford University in Oxford, England, about 60 miles northwest of London. He is not a student in London.

An article on Saturday about a resolution by Conservative rabbis critical of a prayer on Good Friday referred incorrectly to that prayer. It is part of a service on Good Friday, but not part of a Mass. (No Mass is said on Good Friday.).

An article in some editions on Dec. 18 about a Bronx woman who received financial help through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund after she was mugged misspelled her surname. She is Laura Pinto, not Pintos. The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, the agency that helped Ms. Pinto, pointed out the error in an e-mail message late last month.

An article on Feb. 3 about three people helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during the 2005-2006 campaign misidentified the employer of one of them, Walter Morris, a refugee from Hurricane Katrina and a former drug abuser. It was the FEGS Health and Human Services System, a social services agency, not the UJA-Federation of New York, one of the beneficiary agencies of the Neediest Cases Fund.
A report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about the growth of spring training in Arizona’s Cactus League reversed the initials of the league president. He is J. P. de la Montaigne.
An article on Saturday about the aftermath of a shooting rampage at City Hall in Kirkwood, Mo., misspelled the name of the neighborhood where the gunman lived. It is Meacham Park, not Meachum.

A music review on Monday about the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, referred incompletely to a work that was performed. It was Stravinsky’s 1919 version of his “Firebird” suite; not the full ballet score.

An obituary on Jan. 4 about the Abstract painter Michael Goldberg referred incorrectly to his Army service in World War II. Under his original name, which was Sylvan Goldberg, he served in the China-Burma-India Theater, where many of the soldiers styled themselves as Merrill’s Marauders, after the commando unit headed by Brig. Gen. Frank D. Merrill. But there is no indication that he served in the unit itself, according to the records of Robert Passanisi, a historian and archivist of the Marauders who served with them. Mr. Passanisi pointed out the error last week, and this correction was further delayed for research.

A music review in Weekend on Friday about the Spice Girls, at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, misidentified a song performed by Melanie Chisholm, who is known as Sporty Spice. It was “I Turn to You” by Ms. Chisholm, not the song of the same title recorded by Christina Aguilera and written by Diane Warren.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Thursday about a proposal for an urban farm that was chosen in a competition to transform the courtyard of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, for a summer misstated the number of years the annual competition has been held. It is eight years old, not seven.
Representative John Shadegg, Republican of Arizona, announced that he would not seek re-election.

Carolina finally ran out of patience with the injury-prone linebacker Dan Morgan. The Panthers released Morgan, their former first-round pick, after seven seasons. He was dominant when he played but was on the field for only 59 of 112 games. The Panthers also released the veteran Mike Wahle, who started 16 games at left guard last season.

Quarterback Trent Green was acquired by Miami last year as part of a plan to turn around the franchise. But in the Dolphins’ first major player purge since Bill Parcells took charge, the team parted ways with Green, wide receiver Marty Booker and seven other players Monday — ushering in the start of what is expected to be a massive off-season roster shake-up. Other notable cuts were offensive tackle L. J. Shelton and the massive defensive tackle Keith Traylor, both of whom were starters.

Louisiana State defensive end Kirston Pittman was granted a sixth year of eligibility by the N.C.A.A., the university announced. Pittman, who missed the 2005 and 2006 seasons with foot and ankle injuries, formally applied for an extension in early January. Pittman, who played 13 games as a freshman and helped lead L.S.U. to a national title, returned to the field in 2007 to help the Tigers win another championship. He started all 14 games and led the team in tackles for a loss.
As much as Omar Minaya and his staff have lauded Mike Pelfrey during the off-season, there is no place for him in the Mets’ rotation.

Ryan Hall, who won the United States men’s Olympic marathon trial in November, and Dan Browne, a 2004 Olympian in the marathon, joined the field for Saturday’s United States cross-country championships in San Diego. The first nine finishers in the men’s 12-kilometer race will qualify for the world championships March 30 in Scotland. But if the 25-year-old Hall qualifies, he said he was unlikely to go.In a telephone call from his training base in Big Bear Lake, Calif., to the New York Track Writers Association, he said, “I don’t think I would go because I don’t think it would fit into my buildup.”The buildup is for the London Marathon on April 13. Last April, Hall ran London in 2 hours 8 minutes 24 seconds, the fastest marathon debut ever by an American. In November, he ran 2:09:02 over a more difficult course in the Olympic trials in Central Park. He said he was pleased to become one of the world’s elite runners. “The Olympic trials were the highlight of my career so far, and I’m happy to be able to enjoy it,” he said. “It really opened up my mind to what I could do.”.

Arsenal opened a 5-point lead in the English Premier League with a 2-0 victory over Blackburn on goals by Philippe Senderos and Emmanuel Adebayor. Senderos scored his second goal of the season off Eduardo da Silva’s corner kick in the fourth minute. Blackburn goalkeeper Brad Friedel made a string of saves before Adebayor got his 19th goal of the season in injury time, tying Manchester United’s Cristiano Ronaldo for the league lead. Seeking its first league title since 2004, Arsenal (19-1-6) has 63 points with 12 games remaining but still must play league matches at Manchester United and at Chelsea, its two closest challengers.

Non-Europeans would need to submit biometric data like fingerprints and facial scans before being allowed to enter Europe, according to a draft proposal expected to go before the European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union, this week. The planned measure, drafted by the European commissioner for justice and home affairs, Franco Frattini, left, would apply to citizens of the United States and other countries who can now enter Europe without visas. The United States now routinely requires European travelers to submit fingerprints. If approved by the commission, the measure would still need the approval of all 27 European Union nations.

A court in St.-Nazaire ordered two companies to pay $13.8 million in damages for their roles in a shipyard accident that killed 16 people and injured 29 when a gangway leading to the Queen Mary 2 collapsed in 2003 when workmen were finishing the ship. The court convicted the companies, Chantiers de l’Atlantique, which built the ship, and Endel, of manslaughter and involuntary injuries. They were also fined $255,000 each.

The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs appealed for $89 million to aid 449,000 people in Mozambique, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe hit by flooding. Halfway through the rainy season, thousands have seen their crops ruined and homes destroyed.

After a yearlong study by the Health Ministry that included using laser scans to measure more than 10,000 female volunteers aged 12 to 70, the government hopes to persuade the fashion industry to devise a new standard for clothing sizes that would fit most women. The study concluded that Spanish women were not the very skinny tall types that designers idealize, but rather fell into three main body types: hourglass, pear shape and cylinder. It also found that 4 of 10 women had trouble finding clothes to fit, mainly because sizes varied from store to store and because what was on the racks was too small.

The United States Soccer Federation completed plans for exhibition games for the American national team at Poland on March 26 and at Spain on June 4. The game at Poland will be played in Krakow, the U.S.S.F. said. The site for the game in Spain has not been set.
President Hugo Chávez is sending a team of 15 Venezuelans on an expedition to Antarctica to carry out research into global warming.

The police said they had arrested a 69-year-old man suspected of setting the fire on Sunday that destroyed the country’s most prominent landmark, the 610-year-old wooden structure in Seoul known as the Namdaemun, or Great Southern Gate. Citing police officers, the Yonhap News Agency said the suspect had confessed to the arson and indicated that it was because of a land compensation grievance. Hundreds of stunned South Koreans gathered near the charred structure Monday night. “My heart is burning,” Lee Il-soo, who runs a small business, said as he fought back tears.
Donald J. Trump may join his former opponent in developing a $700 million resort with thousands of slot machines at the old Concord Hotel, just a few miles from Monticello raceway.
With 171 pledged delegates at stake on Tuesday, the candidates were making last-minute pitches.
A $2 billion hedge fund fails, and there will be more, analysts say.
Richard Zednik, who sustained a serious cut on his neck from a skate blade, benefited from “luck,” said one of the doctors who performed emergency surgery to repair Zednik’s common carotid artery.
Under a new school financing law the state’s 31 Abbott districts will no longer receive special financial consideration, leaving them wary of layoffs and program cuts.
Accounting flaws at the insurance giant that understated the company’s losses raised new questions about the deteriorating health of financial companies.
Prosecutors insisted Monday that five former executives from the American International Group deliberately mounted a fraud to manipulate its financial statements.
Kosuke Fukudome — who would not know Steve Bartman from Batman — will try to learn English, hit major league pitching and help conquer the Cubs’ curse this season.
Several initial public offerings have been withdrawn in India in recent weeks as once-resilient investors rethink their commitment to India’s volatile stock markets.
The state attorney’s office in Palm Beach County, Fla., said Monday that no charges would be filed in the drowning of Seth Tobias, 44, a hedge fund manager and regular commentator on CNBC.
Safety experts say the influx of electronics is turning cars into sometimes chaotic moving family rooms.
The cases of those accused with roles in 9/11 represent a major part of President Bush’s “unfinished business.”
Mr. Lantos, who represented a district in California, was chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the only Holocaust survivor ever to serve in Congress.
The federal government has failed its tribal trust obligation to deal with what has been termed “an American tragedy.”
It is time to think about cutting back — but not for some in the New York State Legislature, who have been quietly pushing a pay raise for themselves.
Astronauts placed the crown jewel of Europe’s contribution to the International Space Station into its permanent setting on Monday with the attachment of the Columbus science module.
Microsoft said it would acquire Danger, a maker of consumer smartphones, an indication that the software giant is quickly moving to expand its mobile strategy.
In one corner of Wall Street, money is still gushing. Early shareholders may be protected, but long-term investors may be the suckers.
The announcement of a cease-fire against one of Pakistan’s most wanted men has raised questions about the government’s commitment to combating militancy.
Some of the euphoria about the history-making aspects of the Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama campaigns is giving way to anxiety.
New York hospitals are spending hundreds of millions of dollars rebuilding and expanding their emergency rooms.
The Indianapolis 500 and IndyCar Series champion last year, Dario Franchitti is part of an influx of drivers from open-wheel racing into Nascar’s Sprint Cup this year.
The fact that Defense Secretary Robert Gates was permitted the candor that he demonstrated last week is a measure of how bad things have gotten in Afghanistan.
A law that aims to diminish the influence of special interests on city campaigns would make it more difficult for minority candidates to run, according to a lawsuit.
The Best Buy Company, the consumer electronics chain, and the online video rental company Netlfix both announced their commitment to stock Blu-ray DVDs.
The White House predicted the economy would escape a recession and unemployment would remain low this year, though it acknowledged growth had already slowed.
The second major outage of BlackBerry service in less than a year is an embarrassment for Ontario-based Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry devices.
William S. Lerach was sentenced to two years in prison and ordered to forfeit $7.75 million for concealing illegal payments to a plaintiff in class-action lawsuits.
Yankees Manager Joe Girardi has heard criticism about how he handled his young pitchers in Florida and said he will limit the innings of Joba Chamberlain, Phil Hughes and Ian Kennedy.
A new investigation offers a model for attacking what has become a flood of fake drugs, which threaten to undermine the global fight against malaria.
The weakening economy coupled with recent curbs on illegal immigration are steering immigrants away.
A tax research group went to court Monday, arguing that the Internal Revenue Service was not complying with federal court orders to release data on its audit practices.
You would never know a recession might be under way from looking at Intuitive Surgical, the leader in medical robot technology.
Nixzaliz Santiago, the mother of Nixzmary Brown, will not have to testify in the murder trial of her husband, Cesar Rodriguez, a judge in Brooklyn ruled Monday.
The risks and potential consequences of a terrorist attack on a nuclear reactor on a college campus have been underestimated, Congressional auditors say in a report.
A Defense Department analyst and a former engineer for Boeing were charged in separate spy cases for allegedly selling military secrets to the Chinese government.
For the first time since Nov. 10, 1998, Newark had gone four weeks without a homicide, a milestone that may suggest a corner had finally been turned.
Just minutes before he was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in prison a 60-year-old defendant blamed the judge that he had nearly killed for his predicament.
Madison Avenue is optimistic that there can be long-term benefits from the disruptions caused to the broadcast television season by the writers’ strike.
Facing a huge backlog of visa applications, authorities will allow some immigrants to become permanent residents without F.B.I. background checks, officials said.
No state beats New Jersey when it comes to congested highways even though it has the second-highest percentage of mass transportation use.
New Jersey Transit suspended all scheduled repair work on Monday, one day after a track welder was struck and killed by a train.
The Tolkien Trust joined a private family trust of Tolkien heirs and the British arm of HarperCollins Publishers in suing New Line Cinema for breach of contract.
A major maker of heparin, a blood thinner used widely in surgery and dialysis, has stopped making it after hundreds of patients reported severe allergic reactions to the drug.
Dr. Jastrow led a major space science institution and helped to bring space down to earth for millions of Americans.
Last year, Johnny Avello, director of race and sports operations at the Wynn Las Vegas, started setting odds on the Westminster as a novelty for which there is no wagering.
Barack Obama is expected to energize blacks, while Hillary Rodham Clinton expects to do well in suburbs and the state’s rural southwest.
There is a fortune to be made from selling naming rights to New York’s five Mafia families.
Sales of US Weekly and OK! Weekly climbed sharply in the second half of 2007, even as price increases sparked a drop in overall celebrity magazine sales.
The strong show of support was in response to demands for his resignation over his call for Britain to accept some aspects of Shariah, the legal code of Islam.
Elected last year as the president of the sport’s governing body in Europe, UEFA, Michel Platini has quickly brought a player’s sensibility and perspective to the world of European soccer.
Civilian opponents of Chad’s president, Idriss Déby, say that the world has given him too much latitude to crack down on dissent within his own country.
If present trends continue, within two decades the nation’s foreign-born population will account for 15 percent of all residents by 2025, according to projections released Monday.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine is telling thousands of people that his plan to ease New Jersey’s fiscal woes will hurt a lot. But not adopting it, he warns, will hurt a lot more.
The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on the board of The New York Times Company has more than doubled its stake in the company.
In 15 enforcement sweeps, state investigators found $19 million in wages that were not reported to the state and $3 million in underpayments to workers.
The Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation sold an unwanted firetruck on Craigslist to a fire company in southern Pennsylvania for more than $75,000.

PLAYER In Germany, the 22-year-old Brazilian midfielder Diego scored a goal in Werder Bremen’s 1-1 tie with Bayern Munich on Sunday. Diego denied reports last week that he was contemplating a summer move to Juventus of Italy.
The Berkeley City Council is retreating from its proclamation that the Marine are not welcome to run their three-person recruiting office downtown.
A helicopter on Monday dropped 250 gallons of river water onto a fire at a gutted sugar refinery where six workers died, and sand will be used to if the water drops do not work.
A high school student who was arguing with another shot him during a gym class on Monday, critically injuring him, before handing the gun to a coach, the authorities said.
On the eve of Tuesday’s primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign increasingly believes that she must win in Ohio and Texas in March.
The addition of Bank of America Corporation and the Chevron Corporation will be the first change to the blue-chip stock index in almost four years.
Yellow Rat Bastard, a trendy apparel retailer based in SoHo, has agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a lawsuit over unpaid wages and overtime.
Shares of retailers and home builders rose on expectations of more interest rate cuts, but those of banks and insurers fell on worries about further mortgage debt troubles.
Each day before dawn about 50 to 70 riders take the X32 bus to Bronx Science. It is the only public line that delivers students directly to one of the city’s nine specialized high schools.
President Nicolas Sarkozy’s spokesman has abruptly withdrawn from the race to be mayor of an affluent Paris suburb. And it was the president’s own son who forced him out.
One traveler’s strategies for keeping insects out of his luggage and his cash in his pocket while working in rugged outposts.
Andy Pettitte’s recusal came amid growing indications that he had given evidence against Roger Clemens in his deposition. Chuck Knoblauch and Kirk Radomski will also not testify.
To effectively ensure that Kenya’s leaders treat the mediation with utmost seriousness, the United States must maintain consistent and strong pressure .
Daily life is a constant kaleidoscope of languages for those of us who are of mixed ethnic heritage. We must gauge what sort of street we are in and speak the “correct” tongue.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

LAST YEAR’S DELAYS Last year was the second worst ever for airline delays, with 73.4 percent of flights arriving on time, according to the United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Only in 2000 did the domestic airline industry post a worse record, with 72.59 percent of flights on time. Meanwhile, major domestic airlines continue to reduce the number of domestic seats they are putting into the skies, as measured by a metric called available seat miles. In January, United Airlines had 10.7 percent fewer available seat miles than in the previous January. For other airlines these are the figures: US Air, minus 5.4 percent; Delta and Northwest, each minus 4.4 percent; Continental, minus 2.7 percent; and American, minus 1.5 percent. But Southwest Airlines bolstered its January capacity by 5.3 percent.
BERLIN — Once dubbed the Frankenphone by unimpressed mobile phone aficionados, Nokia’s oval, game-focused N-Gage model quietly disappeared from the market not long after its introduction in 2003.
Fring, a mobile-phone version of Skype, uses peer-to-peer Internet technology to send calls from mobile phones over the Internet at no charge.

BERLIN — The engineers at Challenger Mobile, a software company in Stockholm, worked for more than a year to create an Internet telephone system with the goal of selling digital voice service to homes and businesses in Scandinavia. Two years later, Challenger’s software is sitting on a shelf.

MILAN — Mobile e-mail, until recently the exclusive terrain of business executives, is breaking out of its niche market even as cellphone operators remain ambivalent about a service that will cut into their lucrative text messaging market.
Publish or perish has long been the burden of every aspiring university professor. But the question the Harvard faculty will decide on Tuesday is whether to publish — on the Web, at least — free.
“River: The Joni Letters,” by Herbie Hancock can be understood as a celebration of the academy’s more high-minded pop impulses.
Christopher Hitchens, Richard Dawkins and the many others railing from the best-seller lists about the global plague that is religious belief have a staunch ally in the title character of “Grace.”

Dolly Parton, below, citing a back injury, has postponed a United States tour that was to have begun on Feb. 28 in Minneapolis. An announcement said the concerts, promoting her “Backwoods Barbie” album, to be released on Feb. 26 on Dolly Records, would be rescheduled for late April and May. ... A show arrives: “Shrek the Musical,” so far starring Sutton Foster, Christopher Sieber and Kecia Lewis-Evans, is to begin previews on Nov. 8 at the Broadway Theater with an opening on Dec. 14. The title ogre and Donkey have yet to be cast. ... And a show leaves: “The Farnsworth Invention,” which opened on Dec. 3, will end its run on March 2. It will have played 34 previews and 104 regular performances. ... Julia McKenzie, 67, will be the new Miss Marple, succeeding Geraldine McEwan, who said last month that she was leaving “Marple,” the British crime series. Ms. McKenzie will be the seventh actress to portray this character, created by Agatha Christie, the BBC reported.

“Atonement,” adapted from the Ian McEwan novel and starring Keira Knightley and James McAvoy as suffering lovers, was named best film at the British Academy of Film and Television Awards (popularly known as the Baftas) on Sunday night in London, The Associated Press reported. Daniel Day-Lewis, above, came away with best actor honors for his performance as the oilman in “There Will Be Blood,” and Marion Cotillard was named best actress for her portrayal of Édith Piaf in “La Vie en Rose.” Joel and Ethan Coen won the award for directing for “No Country for Old Men,” and the prize for best original screenplay went to Diablo Cody for “Juno.”.

Dr. Robert Ferrell, a University of Pittsburgh geneticist, has been sentenced to a year of unsupervised release and fined $500 for providing Steven Kurtz, an artist friend, with bacteria to use in his biotech-theme artwork, The Associated Press reported. Dr. Ferrell pleaded guilty in October to a misdemeanor count of “mailing an injurious article.” Mr. Kurtz, a member of the faculty of the University at Buffalo, faces trial on federal mail and wire-fraud charges. Prosecutors say Dr. Ferrell sent away for the relatively harmless bacteria for Mr. Kurtz because he could not have obtained it on his own. His defenders maintain that Mr. Kurtz was merely trying to provoke discussion through art and that government prosecution stifles debate. The case began as an antiterrorism investigation after the police saw laboratory equipment in Mr. Kurtz’s home after the death of his wife, but suspicions of terrorism were swiftly ruled out.
For Ronald K. Brown, the choreographer and dancer who formed Evidence Dance Company in 1985 at 19, evidence is a twin concept.

Ian Rankin may be best known for his Inspector Rebus mysteries. Alexander McCall Smith, right, may be best known for chronicling the exploits of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. So what have they been up to lately? Writing 15-minute operas. They are participants in “Five:15,” a Scottish Opera initiative intended to attract young audiences by joining authors and composers like Craig Armstrong (“Love Actually”) to create 15-minute operas. The results range from Mr. Rankin’s “Gesualdo,” about the murderous 16th-century composer Carlo Gesualdo, to “Queens of Govan,” about a 15-year-old girl who works in a kebab shop in a gritty Glasgow neighborhood, The Independent of London reported. Mr. McCall Smith’s work is based on “Dream Angus,” his collection of Celtic myths. The five operas will be presented in March in Glasgow and Edinburgh. The performances are sold out.
The Williamstown Theater Festival’s new season includes productions of “She Loves Me” and “Three Sisters.”

Seems like a lot of people want Neil Gaiman, the fantasy novelist, short-story and comics writer, to give away his books. On Saturday Mr. Gaiman invited readers of his blog to select the book they would give to a friend who has never read his work before. More than 16,500 votes have been cast for one of eight titles highlighted at neilgaiman.com. Mr. Gaiman will select a winner next week, and a free electronic copy of that book will be posted on the Web site of HarperCollins Publishers, harpercollins.com, later this month. The book will be one of six, including a novel by Paulo Coelho and a cookbook by the Food Network star Robert Irvine, that HarperCollins is making available free online for a month each. Readers will not be able to download or print the books. In Mr. Coelho’s case the publisher will upload a different title each month until the end of the year.

The Grammy Awards achieved Sunday night’s top ratings despite falling almost two million viewers short of the show’s audience a year ago. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 18.2 million tuned in to CBS’s broadcast of “The 50th Annual Grammy Awards,” down from 20.1 million a year ago. Although the awards show outpaced all other programming for the night among adults 18 to 49, the preliminary overnight numbers suggest that it may be the lowest-rated Grammy show in more than a decade. CBS finished No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 o’clock hour before the awards show with “60 Minutes” (13 million). ABC ranked second for the night, thanks to a two-hour “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (15.8 million), followed by “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (8.6 million). Fox was third with coverage of the National Football League’s Pro Bowl, followed by a lineup of comedy repeats and a new episode of “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (6.1 million). NBC finished fourth with reruns of “American Gladiators” at 7 (3.6 million) and 8 (3.7 million), followed by a two-hour special “100 Most Outrageous Moments” (8.2 million).
To the Editor:.
“Jericho” may be remembered as the postapocalyptic drama canceled by CBS and only temporarily revived by vocal and Internet-savvy fans, but its executive producers would have it otherwise.
On Tuesday, 50 space experts and advocates are gathering to ask whether the United States is on the right track with its plans for space exploration.

After more than 15 years with New York City Ballet, Nikolaj Hübbe danced his farewell performance on Sunday  not as if he were delivering the last word on his roles, but as if they were brave new worlds he was still exploring.
To the Editor:.
The French bank offered millions of new shares to investors at a fire-sale price Monday, seeking to replace the more than $7 billion it lost in a trading scandal.
Iran celebrated the 29th anniversary of its Islamic revolution as the government appeared to be taking steps to bury the chances of parliamentary reform.
There was very little that could be called pioneering or avant-garde about the program presented by Kim Robards Dance on Friday night at the Joyce SoHo.
Iraq’s foreign minister won a long-sought agreement to write off most of Iraq’s $12.9 billion in debt to Russia.
The violinist Joan Kwuon and the conductor André Previn, who also collaborate in chamber repertory, reunited at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday.
The songwriter David Yazbek is a daredevil juggler catching spiked pins in the traveling carnival of his imagination.
The Budapest Festival Orchestra — formed by Ivan Fischer in 1983 and conducted by him twice over the weekend at Avery Fisher Hall — enticed us with two of Bartok’s rare adventures into the theater.
A discovery may provide insights about the farmers and some answers to the questions of how, why and when Egyptians adopted farming.
Swallowing a magnet the size of a watch battery is unlikely to cause health problems, but swallowing two can be fatal.
Comparing saxophone sounds from an amateur, a pro and a giant:.
In an unusual educational experiment the Curtis Institute of Music has established Beethoven’s String Quartet No. 11 in F minor (Op. 95) as the touchstone of the academic year for its 160 students.
Trying to decode the subtle cues that lead to human rapport, scientists have trained their focus on mimicry.
According to a senior Sudanese official, the army officer was the ring leader of a small cell of terrorists, and was not acting on behalf of the Sudanese government.
In his musicals, Ernst Lubitsch’s precise, highly stylized direction of actors and his masterful sense of ellipsis helped to characterize “the Lubitsch touch.”
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Scientists are reporting that they have determined why muscles get tired and devised, for mice, an experimental drug that can eliminate fatigue.
Basra has repeatedly been the venue of attacks on both Iraqi and Western journalists.
Israeli officials hope to reach agreement with the Palestinians on a “declaration of principles” for peace by the end of the year, but not on a detailed peace treaty, said a senior Israeli minister.
The blasts erupted around noon just before the American defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, left Iraq after an overnight visit.
The Manhattan Sinfonietta, a new-music ensemble led by Jeffrey Milarsky , took over Merkin Concert Hall last weekend for two concerts that explored competing notions of contemporary musical language.
The results of a new study indicate that when Parkinson’s patients took tango classes, their balance improved.
Second opinions can be awkward, to say the least, for doctor and patient, and surprisingly little is known about them.
The antioxidants vitamin E and lutein, from both food and supplements, may reduce women’s risk for cataracts, researchers report.
A sound-measuring device plumbs a mystery of jazz.
Dr. Carla Pugh builds anatomical models to help medical students learn to perform exams that might make them uncomfortable.

BARRETT--Harold E. The Reverend Harold Elliott Barrett, former Rector of Grace Church in New York, died on February 8, 2008 in Charlottesville, Virginia. He was 82. Born August 9, 1925 in Charleston, South Carolina, The Reverend Barrett served two and a half years in the U.S. Army in World War II in the European theater and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Subsequently, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from The University of the South, Sewanee, Tennessee, in 1949 and the Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 1952. He was ordained to the Priesthood on November 17, 1952 in the Diocese of South Carolina. The Reverend Barrett began his ministry as a Vicar at Trinity Church, Pinopolis, South Carolina with four yoked rural parishes and then became Assistant to the Dean at Trinity Cathedral, Columbia, South Carolina as Chaplain to Episcopal students at the University of South Carolina and the Columbia School for Girls. From 1955-1971, he served as Rector of the Church of the Holy Communion in Memphis, Tennessee. His tenure at Grace Church was from 1980-1991. The reverend Barrett served as a member of the Board of Trustees of The University of the South, Sewanee, Tennessee, and the Episcopal Radio-TV Foundation, Atlanta, Georgia. His professional memberships include (Diocese of Tennessee) Bishop and Council, Commission on Ministry; Board of Examining Chaplains, Department of Ministries of Higher Education, Chairman of the Diocesan Committee, ''Nuclear Energy and the Church''. He was a Member of the Board of Trustees of St. Mary's Episcopal School, and the Boards of Directors of Trezevant Episcopal Manor, University Inter-Faith Center, and the Heart Fund. The Reverend Barrett was married to the former Margaret Pinkney Lucas of Charleston, South Carolina, who was deceased in 1976. On November 24, 1978, he married Louisa Condon Strubing in Memphis. He is survived by his five children: Harold Elliott Barrett, Jr., Ellen Barrett Fitch, Elizabeth Barrett Turner, Margaret Barrett Bennett, Selina Barrett Vaughn and his stepdaughter Alexandra Strubing Paradise as well as thirteen grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his stepson John Phillip Strubing in 2003. A service in celebration of the life of The Reverend Harold Barrett will be held at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Greenwood, Virginia, at 2:00pm, Tuesday, February 12. A reception following the service will be held in the Parish Hall. An additional service will be held at Grace Church in New York City, at 2pm, Tuesday, February 12. The family request that in lieu of flowers, memorials be made to Episcopal Relief and Development, 815 2nd Avenue, New York, NY 10017 www.e-d.org or The Reverend Harold Elliott Barrett Award for Excellence in Literature at The University of the South, 735 University Avenue, Sewanee, TN 37383.

BROWNING--Kirk. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our dear friend Kirk Browning, who directed 28 telecasts for us, including the Met's first live telecast on PBS, ''La Bohme'' in 1977. A pioneer in the field of directing opera for TV, he was also a cherished and much-admired colleague. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, his sons David and Jeremy, and all his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director BROWNING--Kirk. Dearest Kirk, Play It By Ear cherished your friendship so. You have enhanced all of our lives. We send all our love and sympathy to Barbara and the entire family. Rhoda Levine BROWNING--Kirk. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. are deeply saddened by the passing of Kirk Browning, the groundbreaking, multi Emmy Award-winning director of Live From Lincoln Center (LFLC). A longtime cherished colleague, Browning directed 185 LFLC broadcasts, dating back to the inaugural telecast in 1976. His superb talents and marvelous wit will be greatly missed. Our sincerest sympathies to his wife Barbara, and his sons David and Jeremy. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. BROWNING--Kirk. It is with deep sadness that New York City Opera notes the passing of our dear friend and colleague Kirk Browning, and with it, the end of an era. He debuted at City Opera in 1959, directing the company premiere of Menotti's Maria Golovin, followed by productions of Hoiby's The Scarf (1959), as well as The Marriage of Figaro (1961) and La travita (1963). But it is as a brilliant, trailblazing, and award winning televison director that he is best remembered. He began his TV career at NBC, directing live telecasts of the NBC Symphony under Toscanini. He went on to helm 27 televised operas for City Opera, as well as the world premiere of Amahl and the Night Visitors (the first opera written expressly for television), and hundreds of other live musical and dramatic telecasts. Director of Live From Lincoln Center until his sudden death, he leaves a rich legacy of live classical music performances expertly captured for posterity. We offer our condolences to his wife Barbara, his sons David and Jeremy, and his many friends and colleagues. Susan L. Baker, Chairman of the Board Jane M. Gullong, Executive Director

EPEL--Dr. Joseph N. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Dr. Joseph N. Epel of Detroit and Highland Beach, Fla. A warm, caring and intelligent individual who was larger than life, Dr. Epel was a leading light in our organization, inspiring many others to support the ATS and the Technion through his accessibility and brilliance. A Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of support, Dr. Epel was a devoted supporter for more than 60 years and an ATS national leader for more than a quarter century. He was a member of the Board of Directors and the International Board of Governors, receiving an honorary doctorate from the Technion in 1994 and an honorary fellowship in 1987. Prior to assuming national leadership roles, he was active in the ATS East Central Region, twice serving as Detroit Chapter president and chairman. His first involvement with the ATS came in 1947, when he attended the first meeting of the Detroit Chapter. Splitting his time between South Florida and Michigan, Dr. Epel was an influential figure in both regions for his excellence in leadership and exemplary support. Among the many projects he supported were the Beatrice & Joseph N. Epel Michigan Dormitory, the Salman & Evelyn Grand Dormitory, and the South Palm Beach Chapter Endowed Doctoral Fellowship Fund. The former president and CEO of Duralistic Products, Dr. Epel held a Ph.D. in polymer chemistry and was an inventor and developer of plastics and other materials for the transportation industry. He was a member of several professional organizations and supported numerous Detroit-area and national organizations. To his loving wife Beatrice, his five children Dan, Dena, Joshua, Julia and Naomi, his two brothers, Bernard and David, and the entire Epel family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Jerome J. Kanter, Detroit Chapter President Jo Rosen, Detroit Chapter Director Stanley H. Sussman, South Palm Beach Chapter President Jessica Feldan, South Palm Beach Chapter Director

WEISKOPF--Daniel Kramer, II, of New York, NY, died on February 11, 2008 at the age of 71. The son of the late James Weiskopf and the late Elsa Dryfoos. Beloved husband of Victoria Vance. Loving father of Brandon, Whitney, Daniel III (Allison) and Karin (Jean Claude Sherman). Grandfather of Chloe, Luke and Christopher Sherman, Victoria and William Weiskopf. Brother of Joan Rosenthal, Robert Friedman, and Janet Karasick. Doting son - in - law of Geraldine Vance. He is also survived by the family's three dogs that he loved, Coco, Penny, and his favorite Marley-O; they brought him great joy, comfort and companionship. Danny was a lifelong resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan where he loved to scooter along Madison Ave. He was a graduate of Admiral Farragut Naval Academy and attended Tulane University before enlisting in the United States Marine Corp. He was a founder and partner of Weiskopf Silver & Co., specialists on the American and New York Stock Exchanges. He was a member of the American Stock Exchange for over 30 years where he was a trader. Since leaving the floor of the Exchange, he has managed Weiskopf Silver Investment Partnership. His passion has always been the stock market and he has instilled that love of the market in his sons. His love of life, his biting wit, and spirit will be missed. He was deeply loved and will always be remembered. He lived his life to the fullest; he did it his way. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, New York on February 13, 2008 at 5:00pm.

LANTOS--Tom. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are saddened by the death of Rep. Tom Lantos, a member of our Board of Directors and Overseers since 1989. At the time of his death, Rep. Lantos was serving his 14th term representing the Bay Area of California in the House of Representatives. The only Holocaust survivor ever elected to Congress, he was a staunch defender of human rights the world over and was a particularly effective advocate for refugees fleeing persecution. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Annette, herself an ardent and accomplished human rights advocate; their daughters Annette and Katrina; and their 18 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Alan Batkin and Jonathan Wiesner Co-Chairs, IRC Board Tom Brokaw and Maureen White, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President LANTOS--Tom. America has lost a great patriot, the American Jewish Congress has lost a close friend and humanity, a great champion. Congressman Lantos' public life was forged in the Holocaust, and he took from his own experience the urgency to protect human rights and democracy and confront bigotry and hate. His contributions were many and lasting. May his memory be a blessing. Richard S. Gordon, President Jack Rosen, Chairman Neil B. Goldstein, Exec. Dir. LANTOS--Tom, Congress man. We shared the suffering of the Holocaust and bonded with gratitude in the Land of Freedom. A friend of over 40 years, he will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy to Annette, his beloved life partner, children Katrina and Richard Swett, Annette and Timber Dick, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur and Elisabeth Schneier LANTOS--Tom, Congress man. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns Congressman Tom Lantos, a passionate defender of human rights and freedom. A Holocaust survivor, he steadfastly worked for a world of peace, justice and tolerance. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, President Card.Theodore E. McCarrick Archbishop K. Barsamian Vice Presidents

KINSOLVING--Jacqueline W. Vogelstein. Her incandescent smile dimmed forever on Sunday, February 10, after a brave two year fight with lung cancer. Jackie was the adored wife of Charlie Kinsolving, the devoted mother of Fred and Andrew Vogelstein and their wives Evelyn and Monica, and her five worshipping grandchildren: David, Beatrice, Sam, Natalie and Matthew. She was much beloved by all members of the Kinsolving family. Born in Luxembourg in 1936, she came to this country in 1941 aboard the troop ship USS Exeter, sailing from Lisbon. Returning to Europe after World War II she attended the American School in Paris and then studied art in a Parisian atelier for three years. She later taught art at the Dalton School in Manhattan. Living in New York and East Hampton, she earned her B.S. in Political Science from Columbia University's School of General Studies and was a tireless fundraiser for the school. She served on the board of her apartment building and on the board of the Art Barge in East Hampton. Her many friends will remember her shining smile, her impish smirk, her generosity of spirit, her diplomacy, her steadfast support of those in need, her sense of humor, her boundless energy and optimism and her cosmopolitan sophistication. Services Wednesday, February 13, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. KINSOLVING--Jacqueline W. Vogelstein. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member Jacqueline Vogelstein. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary

The Food and Drug Administration failed to block people convicted of crimes, including fraud and selling unapproved medicines, from working in the pharmaceutical industry, according to a Congressional investigation. The agency should have acted, and failed to do so, in 40 cases in a three-year period ending in 2005, according to a report by Republican investigators for the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The investigation was prompted by the F.D.A.'s handling of a Sanofi-Aventis antibiotic called Ketek, according to a statement from Republicans on the panel. While a clinical researcher was convicted of mail fraud in connection with a Ketek study and sentenced to prison, she has not been banned by the agency. ''F.D.A.'s failure to take action in a timely manner increases the risks of criminals continuing to operate in, and undermine, the drug regulatory process,'' the report said.
