A headline on Monday with an article about pressure on the Israeli government to respond more forcefully to rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza misstated the condition of two brothers, ages 8 and 19, after an attack on their town, Sderot. They were seriously wounded; they are not dead.

KELLOGG--John G. After a truly remarkable life, John ''Jack'' Kellogg, 97, died peacefully on Thursday, February 7, at the University Medical Center at Princeton. Born 1910 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, he was preceded in death by his parents R. Gardner Kellogg and Elizabeth Fuller. Jack was prepared at St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, and then graduated in 1932 from Princeton University. Jack then followed his father, and owner, in the Square D Company. Upon retirement, 1967, Jack devoted much of his remaining life to the university he dearly loved, Princeton. He has been Class Agent since 1970, Class Secretary since 1992, and Class President 1977-1982. Jack was member of Springdale Golf Club, Bedens Brook Country Club, and also a member of the Nassau Club since 1966, where he was President from 1974-1976. Jack was also the first Honorary Member of the Plainsboro Rescue Squad. Jack was preceded in death by his first wife Anne Dumont. He is survived by his daughters Judy Medina and Prudence Krause, four grandchildren, and five greatgrandchildren. In 1987, Jack married Babs Covey, a Princeton University 1939 widow. Jack is survived by Babs and her sons, Bill Beim, John Pierson, daughter Barbie Russell, 14 grandchildren, and 15 great-grandchildren. Respuiescat in Pace, Old Friend, Rest in Peace. Memorial services will be held 11:00am Saturday, March 1, at the Princeton University Chapel. Reception to follow at the Nassau Club, Mercer Street, Princeton, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please send all donations to the Class of '32, Princeton University.

CHUMACEIRO--Harold and Matildelena. Manhattan School of Music and its Board of Trustees are deeply saddened by the loss of Harold Chumaceiro and his wife Matildelena, both cherished friends of the School. Mrs. Chumaceiro passed away on December 23 and Mr. Chumaceiro on January 7, both following long illnesses. Harold Chumaceiro was a member of Manhattan School of Music's Board of Trustees since 2000, and a founding member of the School's International Advisory Board; in both capacities, his thoughtfulness, judgment and dedication were greatly valued by his colleagues. Both persons of great charm and civility, Mr. and Mrs. Chumaceiro possessed a deep and abiding love for music, and were devoted, generous, and constant supporters of the School's many programs. We are grateful for all that they did to encourage and support the enrichment of our young musicians. With heartfelt sorrow, we extend our condolences to their daughter Thelma Elena and the entire Chumaceiro family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

FRANKS--Andrew, M.D., of New York City and Pelham, New York, on February 10, 2008, age 100 years, peacefully after a brief illness, surrounded by his loving family. Former Professor of Dermatology at his beloved New York University Skin and Cancer Unit where he taught and was a Chief of Service at the Clinic for many years. Dr. Andrew Franks celebrated his hundredth birthday on June 12 with more than 150 family and friends in Pelham, NY, where he lived with his family, and was an active member of the American Legion, Pelham Post 50, and the Senior Citizens Center. Dr. Franks was born 1907 in the coal mining town of Leckrone, PA, the son of Italian immigrants from Pisa, Italy. Despite his humble beginnings as a coal miner's son, he became a legend in Dermatology. He attended West Virginia University in Morgantown for his pre-medical studies, and because of his extraordinary academic excellence was recruited by New York University School of Medicine into an accelerated six year program graduating in 1932. That year he married Lydia Benigno his beloved wife for 70 years, who died in 2002. Throughout his career, he contributed to three textbooks and over 60 peer-reviewed scientific articles. Dr. Franks served as a medical officer in the United States Army as Colonel and was stationed at Lawson General Hospital in Atlanta, Georgia, during WWII. While performing his medical service during the day, he completed a law degree at night upon the Army's request at Woodrow Wilson College of Law (now part of Emory University) in order to best represent those wounded and disabled during the war. He was recently awarded the Greatest Generation Medal in acknowledgement of his service for World War II. As one of the first M.D., LLB graduates in the United States, he and his colleague, and friend, Howard Rusk, along with others, founded the American Academy of Occupational Medicine in the United States where he served as Governor and was a medical legal expert in occupational medicine. He was also active in the Dermatologic Society of Greater New York and hosted its 50th anniversary, and published its Proceedings of 50 years. This past April he received a wonderful recognition from the NYU Alumni Association Annual Meeting for his 75 years of service to the Medical School. Dr. Franks was predeceased by his wife Lydia in 2002 and his daughter Norma in 1998. He is survived by his daughter Joy Catapano, his son and daughter-in-law Drs. Andrew G., Jr. and Linda K. Franks, who both practice in his original office at Gramercy Park, the longest operating family Dermatology practice in the United States. He is also survived by his 11 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. In his most recent years as a resident of Pelham, NY, he was active in the community and neighborhood, and loved by all, both young and old. In 2005, he was honored as the Grand Marshall and led the Memorial Day Parade. He will be remembered for his unwavering optimism, integrity, compassion, and boundless sense of humor which inspired not only his family, but all those who came in contact with him. In celebration of his life, viewing will be at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave. on Wednesday, February 13th, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, 914-738-1060 and services held at at Parish of Christ the Redeemer at 10am, 1415 Pelhamdale Avenue in Pelham on Thursday morning, February 14th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology, New York University School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, New York, New York 10016. FRANKS--Andrew, M.D. To our wonderful grandfather, you lived 100 years and gave 100%. Athlete, scholar, doctor, lawyer, colonial, professor and most of all loving grandfather. Your legacy will live on forever in our lives and in our hearts. We will miss your warm smile and words of encouragement. Your spirit will always guide us. We'll save you a seat at the game. We love you pops. Joanne, Andrew, Joy, Frank, Lydia, Marina, Renalda, Katie, Lisa, Jackie, Caroline and Skippy. FRANKS--Andrew, M.D. To our wonderful great-grandfather. You have inspired us on so many levels of our lives. Your achievements will motivate us to strive for the best. You always knew how to make us laugh and always had faith in all of us. We'll save a piece of apple pie for you, and you'll live in our hearts forever. We love you ''Gramps''. Jonathan Taylor, Charlie, Michael, Eric, Milan, Lydia, Dylan and Logan
WHALEY--Joan. September 14, 1951-February 12, 2007. Dearest sister, aunt, and friend. We miss your charm, wit, charisma, enthusiasm for life, love for learning and sincere warmth of character.

In an effort to increase security and weed out potential terrorists, workers at seven airports will undergo more vigorous screening beginning in May. The additional checks are part of a 90-day test program run by the Transportation Security Administration. People who work at airports across the country already receive some screening, like background checks and random searches, before they are given access to secure areas, said a T.S.A. spokesman, Christopher White. The screening tests will be conducted at airports in Boston; Denver; Kansas City, Mo.; Jacksonville, Fla.; New Bern, N.C.; and Eugene and North Bend, Ore.

A woman found in her home with the decomposing bodies of her four daughters will remain in custody while a grand jury investigates, a judge ruled. The woman, Banita Jacks, 33, is being held on murder charges. The bodies of the girls, ages 5 to 16, were found Jan. 9 when United States marshals served an eviction notice at the family's apartment in southeast Washington. The medical examiner's office has said that there is evidence that the oldest girl had been stabbed and that the other three girls had markings on their necks and other signs of trauma. Mayor Adrian M. Fenty fired six child welfare workers shortly after the girls were found, a move criticized by union officials who say the employees have excessive caseloads and other problems. A school social worker initially raised concerns about the family in April 2007 after she visited the home and thought Ms. Jacks was holding the girls hostage.

From his perch at the Manhattan Institute, the right-leaning research group, Sol Stern, 72, has reveled as the city’s cantankerous provocateur against liberal education policies, criticizing reading curriculums that de-emphasize phonics as well as public schools that focus on social justice, Jennifer Medina writes. Like many of his intellectual allies, he had ardently supported school vouchers as a way to give poor and minority children better educational choices and to create competition that would help improve public schools. Although colleagues long thought they had him pegged, he made an abrupt about-face on vouchers in the most recent issue of City Journal, the institute’s magazine, saying there was little evidence they had done much to improve public education across the country. In the circles Mr. Stern inhabits, such a sentiment is a kind of heresy, and his essay has set off a firestorm. But he is relishing the attention.

In our media-saturated culture, everyone is a picture-taker and image-maker, adding a new wrinkle to the work of those who practice the time-honored tradition of street photography.“It’s harder and harder to take a picture without somebody in the picture who’s also taking a picture,” the Brooklyn-based photographer Gus Powell said on Tuesday evening, explaining that the mere act of taking a photo hardly makes him stand out in a crowd. “We all take pictures — that’s what we do. It’s more that your camera doesn’t look like a phone — that’s the bigger issue.”

“Get some” or “Put it on”? Both messages — one in English, the other in Spanish — are part of the new ad campaign for New York City’s redesigned official condom wrapper.On Valentine’s Day last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene unveiled the city’s first official condom. The letters “NYC CONDOM” were printed in white or black letters against colorful circles, evoking the letter symbols the Metropolitan Transportation Authority uses to represent subway lines. This year’s redesign — by Yves Behar, a noted product and industrial designer — features the letters “NYC” on black letters against three interlocking circles, with the word “CONDOM” underneath, each of the six letters in a different color.

State officials have announced a final deal — really — to extend New York’s state horse racing franchise another 25 years. Most of the details remain unchanged from what was in the works on Monday night.The New York Racing Association, which has run the tracks at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga Springs since 1955, will continue to run them for the next quarter-century, with an overhauled board of trustees and under the supervision of a new, five-member oversight board dominated by appointees of Gov. Eliot Spitzer. That board will review the association’s performance every five years against a predetermined set of benchmarks, including attendance and financial measures.

Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president and candidate for city comptroller, is expected to name two co-chairmen for his campaign: former State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Leo J. Hindery Jr., a longtime media executive, according to advisers to Mr. Carrión.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals never shies away from publicity-seeking provocation (and media, including this blog, often cover it). This week, the group is starting an advertising campaign in New York and other cities that advocates dog population control, including one commercial that likens dog breeders to the Ku Klux Klan. In New York, like many other places, about half the dogs and cats taken into animal shelters are euthanized.One of the commercials shows a hooded Ku Klux Klan member walking into a meeting of the purebreds-only American Kennel Club, where the members eye him suspiciously. He gets the group to concede that they both believe in the “sanctity of pure bloodlines” and a master race. He sits down, saying, “I’ll fit right in here.” Then the message “All dogs are created equal” flashes on the screen.

I have had migraines for most of my life; the first attack I remember occurred when I was 3 or 4 years old. I was playing in the garden when a brilliant, shimmering light appeared to my left - dazzlingly bright, almost as bright as the sun. It expanded, becoming an enormous shimmering semicircle stretching from the ground to the sky, with sharp zigzagging borders and brilliant blue and orange colors. Then, behind the brightness, came a blindness, an emptiness in my field of vision, and soon I could see almost nothing on my left side. I was terrified - what was happening? My sight returned to normal in a few minutes, but these were the longest minutes I had ever experienced.

This week's guest blogger is the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. Sagmeister is known for his stunning and original approach to the design of album art, magazine spreads, advertising and installation works. He often takes a renegade, D.I.Y. approach to type; in 1999 he made a poster by photographing words he had scratched onto his torso. (His design for the Talking Heads box set earned him a Grammy award.) Sagmeister's work as been exhibited around the world; his current solo show, "Things I have Learned in my Life so Far," is showing at Deitch Projects in New York. Academics build entire careers trying to figure out why we vote the way we do, whether we make our decisions with our heads or our hearts. Right now, it's the hearts that are getting most of their attention, and two scholars who stress the role of emotions in political behavior, George Lakoff and Drew Westen, have become darlings of the Democratic party. People think with their guts, Westen says. Well, none of us really likes to believe that (is Westen thinking with his gut when he votes?), but what's a poor rationalist to do? Politics is hard. Consider health care.

Wellspring Capital Management has decided to take a Dallas-based restaurant chain Dave & Buster's to market months after an initial attempt to sell the company was pulled, The Deal.com reported.
Liz Claiborne, the fashion apparel company, is close to selling its Ellen Tracy brand to a private investment consortium for $50 million, The New York Post reported Wednesday.

Canada's private equity deal makers showed resiliency in the face of the deepening credit crunch in the fourth quarter of 2007, but the quarter exposed the beginnings of a slower era facing the sector in 2008.
Inflows to hedge funds investing in emerging markets has increased more than 40 percent in two years to $9 billion, fueled by volatility in commodities and foreign exchanges.
New Enterprise Associates rallied around The Point with $4.8 million in funding for the company, a social networking site that was started late last year.

InterOil, which is seeking to develop a liquefied natural gas project in Papua New Guinea, appears to have lost a believer, as a hedge fund run by one of the richest men in the United States has sold all of its shares in the company.

Alpha Mom, the popular parenting blog, has sold a minority stake to Fahrenheit 212, a consultancy, in exchange for its help in developing products and services to expand the brand nationally, The New York Post reported.

Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, the powerful Canadian pension fund, is supporting the TSX Group's proposed 1.3 billion Canadian dollar takeover of the Montreal Exchange, provided that some operations stay in Montreal and its governance concerns are met.

The European Commission conducted antitrust raids Tuesday at the Munich offices of Intel, the world's largest chip maker, and of retailers selling products made by the company, the commission and the chip maker said.

The DBS Group, Southeast Asia's biggest bank, said Wednesday that it had hired Richard Stanley, the chief executive of Citigroup China, as chief executive to revive its China business and expand outside Singapore.
A deeply discounted $8 billion rights issue from Société Générale, seen in part as a bid by the scandal-hit French bank to remain independent, has not convinced analysts that it will deter predators.

Citigroup said on Tuesday it plans to provide a $3.5 billion facility to support six of the seven structured investment vehicles it took onto its balance sheet last year to shore up their debt ratings and protect creditors.

MySpace plans to announce as soon as Wednesday 13 that it has formed a business incubator called SlingShot Labs to spawn Internet start-ups for News Corporation's growing empire of Web properties, which now includes The Wall Street Journal's WSJ.com as well as the video game site IGN, according to BusinessWeek.

The $6.1 billion plan to bring auto-parts supplier Delphi out of bankruptcy protection may be in jeopardy as bank lenders face trouble syndicating loans to other lenders, The Wall Street Journal reported.
The lawyer defending the former chief executive of General Reinsurance against fraud charges pointed the finger Tuesday at the investor Warren E. Buffett.

Dell, the computer maker, said on Tuesday that it would buy the business e-mail services provider MessageOne, which was co-founded by Michael S. Dell's brother, in an effort to compete with similar services provided by Microsoft and Google.
A family bakery still going strong in Queens, DeBragga & Spitler offers meats to retail customers and condiments for the Year of the Rat.
We commend to you profootballoutsiders.com and their compilation of the season's top quotations:

Just as Tom Lemming, Allen Wallace and other football recruitnics are being put into hibernation for a long winter's nap (at least until Terrelle Pryor announces where he'll play his college ball), the bracketologists are waking up. Well, they've actually been awake for a while. But now we can start paying legitimate attention to them. There's just over a month remaining until Selection Sunday, which means that the bracket is coming into clearer focus.
Barack Obama celebrated wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. (Video: NBC News)
John McCain spoke to supporters after winning contests in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia. (Video: NBC News)
Hillary Clinton addressed supporters in Texas after losses to Barack Obama in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C. (Video: NBC News)
“Ezra” is a scorching portrait of an African child who is kidnapped and turned into a soldier for a rebel militia.
Wherever vintages matter in the wine-producing world, consumers are infatuated with the great ones while paying little attention to wines from good vintages.
The discussions stem from an approach that Yahoo’s bankers made to News Corporation in an effort to find a “white knight” and avoid a hostile takeover by Microsoft.
The proportion of students taking the courses has grown slowly but steadily over the last five years.
The prohibition would restrict all American interrogators to techniques allowed in the Army Field Manual, which bars the use of physical force.
One returning Hollywood writer asked, “Can anyone remember what we were working on three months ago?”
The attorney general is looking into whether insurers forced patients to overpay for out-of-network doctors.
The United States has won a preliminary ruling in a World Trade Organization case over Chinese tax policies that restrict imports of foreign auto parts, a U.S. trade official said.
New York State is looking at allegations that insurers manipulated reimbursement rates to defraud consumers.
The candidates offered critiques of the opposition party, perhaps signaling a new dynamic in the presidential race.
President Bush’s remarks came after the Senate handed the White House a major victory in a vote on spy powers.
In heated testimony, Roger Clemens said that Andy Pettitte “misremembers” two conversations about human growth hormone.
Stocks rallied for the third day in a row as investors embraced the first positive economic news in weeks: an unexpected 0.3 percent climb in retail sales in January.
A man armed with a suitcase full of knives fatally stabbed and slashed a well-known psychologist in her office.

Two people were killed and two others were injured on Tuesday night when a garbage truck jumped the curb on West 35th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, in Manhattan about 10:30 p.m., the police said. Investigators were looking into whether the driver may have had a medical problem.
Uno became the first beagle to win best in show in the 100 times the Westminster Kennel Club has picked a winner.
A man armed with a suitcase full of knives fatally stabbed and slashed a well-known psychologist in her office.
Shan Foster scored 20 points and A. J. Ogilvy added 19 points and 12 rebounds as No. 24 Vanderbilt handed visiting Kentucky one of its worst losses in decades.
Bostjan Nachbar’s back-to-back 3-point plays — he was fouled on two dunks — stirred the Nets to a victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

After starting as a police officer in the raucous Prohibition era, and serving another 47 years as a firefighter during Atlantic City’s rise and decline before the advent of casinos, Edward Jordan was a legendary local character.
MSNBC has a vein of bratty, adolescent insensitivity, but on Tuesday the network tried very hard to be on its best behavior.
Chauncey Billups came through when it mattered, scoring 12 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter to rally the Detroit Pistons to their ninth win in a row.
Trent Hunter had a goal and two assists for the Islanders, who won at home Tuesday for the first time this year, defeating the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-3.
Hollywood’s writers made it official, ending their bitterly fought strike at the 100-day mark by an overwhelming margin.

Wholesale prices rose at the fastest pace in a quarter-century, led by higher oil and wheat costs that are causing inflation. Producer prices climbed 3 percent in January from a year earlier, after a 2.6 percent gain in December, the Bank of Japan said. Consumer prices rose the most in almost a decade in December, which, combined with falling wages, drove household sentiment to a four-year low. The current-account surplus narrowed for the first time in a year in December as oil pushed the nation’s import bill to a record, a separate report showed. The gap shrank 4.7 percent to 1.69 trillion yen ($15.7 billion) from a year earlier, the finance ministry said.
The freshman Maya Moore scored 25 points Tuesday night to lead No. 2 Connecticut to an 80-48 rout of Georgetown in Storrs, Conn.

Darryl Strawberry, a former Mets and Yankees slugger, must pay the Internal Revenue Service more than $430,000 in back taxes, penalties and interest, according to a judgment signed Tuesday by a United States District Court judge in West Palm Beach, Fla.Strawberry was convicted of tax evasion in 1995 over income from autographs and memorabilia. He is agreeing to pay the I.R.S. for tax years 1989 and 1990.
With his lopsided victories, Barack Obama has an opening to urge Democrats to coalesce around his candidacy.
Barack Obama extended his winning streak over Hillary Rodham Clinton, while John McCain countered recent victories by Mike Huckabee.

An obituary on Monday about the actor Roy Scheider erroneously included the daughter from his first marriage among his survivors. The daughter, Maximillia Connelly Lord, died in 2006. The obituary also misspelled the surname of Mr. Scheider’s wife. She is Brenda Siemer, not Seimer.

A front-page Inside summary on Feb. 5 for a sports article about Coach Bob Knight’s resignation at Texas Tech referred imprecisely to his place in major college basketball history. As the article noted, Mr. Knight won more games than any men’s coach, not more than any coach — a distinction that belongs to Pat Summitt, the women’s coach at Tennessee.

An article on Friday about efforts by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama to outdo each other in campaign fund-raising misstated the month that the totals for February will be made public by the Federal Election Commission. It is March, not April.

An article on Saturday about the future of the Gambino crime family, whose entire leadership was arrested in federal raids last week, misidentified the boss of the Luchese family who was indicted in 1985 after a secret recording device placed in his Jaguar picked up incriminating conversations. It was Anthony Corallo, not Anthony Salerno. (Mr. Salerno, who was also indicted that year, was a leader of the Genovese family.) The error also appeared in a caption with a picture of Mr. Salerno.

A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about record voter turnouts in the Feb. 5 nominating contests referred imprecisely to the turnouts in Utah and New York, and the Jan. 8 primaries in New Hampshire. In each case, the turnout figures represented the percentage of all eligible citizens who voted in each primary, not the percentage of registered Democratic or Republican voters who did so. Turnouts in the three states were: 28.5 percent in the New Hampshire Democratic primary and 23.3 percent in the state’s Republican primary; 7.8 percent in the Utah Democratic primary and 18 percent in its Republican primary; and 13.6 percent in the New York Democratic primary. (The turnout figure for New York’s Republican primary was 4.8 percent.).

An article in Business Day on Monday about young journalists who follow presidential candidates for television networks to blog and file frequent video clips misspelled the given name of one such journalist, hired by ABC and assigned to John McCain. He is Bret Hovell, not Brett.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about a production of Peter Handke’s play “The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other,” at the National Theater in London, referred incorrectly to the play. While it is new to the National Theater, it was written in 1992. It is not a new play.

A picture caption in Weekend on Feb. 1 with an art review of “Picturing New York: The Art of Yvonne Jacquette and Rudy Burckhardt,” at the Museum of the City of New York, included a title provided by the museum that misidentifies the Manhattan site shown in a Rudy Burckhardt photograph. While the title is “34th Street,” the photograph shows the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 50th Street, not 34th Street. (According to the museum the photograph, in which a store with the sign “A&K Deli Market” can be seen in the background, had an alternate title, “Deli Market.”).

A theater review on Saturday about a concert production of “Applause” at City Center, starring Christine Ebersole, misstated the year Ms. Ebersole won a Tony for her performance in “Grey Gardens.” It was 2007, not this year.

The president of the College of William and Mary, Gene R. Nichol, who drew heavy criticism for removing a cross from the nation’s oldest college chapel, resigned after the board of the public college told him his contract would not be renewed. In October 2006, Dr. Nichol removed the cross from permanent display in Wren Chapel to make students and visitors of non-Christian faiths feel more welcome at the nation’s second-oldest college, which is in Williamsburg. The cross was returned to the chapel in August in a case near the altar.

Specialists arrived in Port Wentworth to help extinguish a five-day-old sugar refinery fire that is burning too intensely and deeply for standard firefighting to douse, and officials feared that the deadly blaze could again burst into explosions. Thick masses of molten sugar were smoldering at temperatures as high as 4,000 degrees, even after a helicopter dropped thousands of gallons of water on the fire. “We’re dealing with a dormant volcano full of lava,” said Capt. Matt Stanley from the Fire Department in nearby Savannah. Six people are confirmed dead in Thursday’s fire and two other workers remained missing Tuesday.

Some of the thousands of trailers sitting unused since they were bought by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in 2005 for Gulf Coast hurricane victims may finally be put to use: to help victims of last week’s tornadoes, officials said. Some members of Congress have accused FEMA of playing down the danger of possible formaldehyde contamination in the trailers, 7,200 of which are stored at the Hope airport, but an agency spokesman said the trailers were safe. The decision to use some of the trailers for Arkansas and Tennessee twister victims comes after requests by state officials and members of Arkansas’s Congressional delegation, who have criticized the trailers in the past as a sign of federal ineptitude after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. David Maxwell, head of the Arkansas Department of Emergency Management, said the number of trailers released would depend on the number of people who called FEMA and requested help, as opposed to simply releasing a blanket number.

Trying to reduce the number of animals the city’s shelters kill each year, the Los Angeles City Council voted to require sterilization of cats and dogs at age 4 months or older. The ordinance, which passed 14 to 1, is also meant to curb illegal breeding and dog fighting, said Councilman Richard Alarcon, the sponsor. One of the ordinance’s biggest supporters was the retired game show host Bob Barker, above, who for 25 years concluded the “Price Is Right” by urging viewers to spay or neuter their pets. He has put about $35 million of his own money toward programs that subsidize those operations. Mr. Barker, who will be named by Mr. Alarcon to an outreach committee, said the statute would not be a burden on poor residents because the city offered about 11,000 vouchers for free operations a year and 20,000 for discounts. The bill has seven categories of exemptions, including licensed breeders and show, guide and law enforcement dogs.

American and European astronauts inaugurated the Columbus science laboratory, the newest addition to the International Space Station and Europe’s largest contribution. The 14-ton module, which cost about $2 billion, was delivered last weekend and installed Monday during a spacewalk. It will expand the range of zero-gravity experiments aboard the station. NASA also said a section of thermal blanket that pulled free during the shuttle’s climb to orbit last week did not need repair and would adequately protect the shuttle during re-entry next week.

New charges have been filed against a former night-shift nurse who the authorities say admitted abusing nearly 100 patients, but prosecutors say many of the cases have been tough to investigate. Many of the patients the former nurse, John Riems, claims to have assaulted are unable to speak, some are dead, and some of the cases go back two decades. A grand jury in Sandusky indicted Mr. Riems, 49, on Monday on charges of rape, sexual battery and patient abuse. Mr. Riems told investigators after his arrest last month that he had abused almost 100 patients since the 1980s, but that he could remember specific information on only about two dozen, the police said. So far, police investigators say that they have found that Mr. Riems abused 14 patients and that they are looking into 10 other suspected assaults.
The lawyer defending the former chief executive of General Reinsurance against fraud charges pointed the finger Tuesday at the investor Warren E. Buffett.
The vote, a major victory for the White House, would also give legal protection to phone companies that cooperated in a program of warrantless eavesdropping.
It’s unclear why the Bush administration believes that urging the mortgage industry to do more is the most effective way to cope with the foreclosure crisis.
Run by a prominent Republican fund-raiser in Nevada, the school has left students in 18 states responsible for hundreds of thousands of dollars in uninsured student loans.
Analysts said President Bush’s plan to aid troubled homeowners facing foreclosure fell short of the broad reforms needed to help people meet mortgage payments.
A South Texas mayor, Grace Saenz-Lopez, and her twin sister are accused of dog rustling.
Credit Suisse is weathering the credit crisis better than its larger rival, UBS, which wrote down $14 billion in the same period.
Scientists say the lake, located in Nevada and Arizona, has a 50 percent chance of becoming unusable by 2021.
American commanders fear that security may rapidly deteriorate in Iraq if the U.S. overestimates the capability of the country’s forces to keep the peace.
Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have already run Spanish-language ads three weeks ahead of the Texas primary.
The proposal aims to provide stability for the New York horse-racing industry as it seeks to overcome years of declining attendance, financial problems and scandal.
An airline success story in an otherwise grim industry tries to keep its inner quirk.
A civilian employee of the Department of the Army Forces Command is accused of accepting bribes to direct government contracts to a Tennessee company.
New York City argued that a 1974 desegregation order for a middle school in southwest Brooklyn was outdated and no longer reflected the racial mix of the neighborhood.

The sprinter Dwain Chambers will run for Britain at the world indoor track and field championships next month in Spain after winning a legal fight to be placed on the team.The British selection committee said Tuesday that it reluctantly agreed to put Chambers on the team. He earned a spot on the team by winning the 60-meter race at Sunday’s qualifier.He served a two-year suspension, from 2003 to 2005, after testing positive for the steroid THG, and returned to the sport only six weeks ago.Britain’s governing body for track and field had said he could not run until he had spent a year proving he was drug-free, but Chambers challenged that ruling. One of his lawyers, Nick Collins, said UK Athletics had no legal case to bar him.

An appeals court in Seattle has reinstated a lawsuit against the University of Washington by a woman who said she was raped by a football player. The university is accused of sex discrimination.The woman is a former equipment manager who says she was assaulted by Roc Alexander in 2001, after they ended a relationship. Alexander denies the rape accusation. He now plays for the Houston Texans.A lawyer for the university, Andrew Cooley, said that the woman never told the university that she had been raped and that he considered the matter closed after mediation.Rebecca Roe, a lawyer for the woman, said that using mediation was inappropriate because it suggested shared responsibility.

The right-hander Liván Hernández agreed to a one-year, $5 million contract with the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday. The deal could earn him an additional $2 million in performance bonuses.Hernández, who has never pitched in the American League, made $7 million last season with Arizona, going 11-11 with a 4.93 earned run average in 33 starts. He has played for Florida, San Francisco, Montreal, Washington and Arizona since his major league debut in September 1996.
With demand soaring abroad and droughts crimping supply, the world’s wheat stockpiles have fallen to their lowest level in 30 years.

Blaine Wilson, a five-time national champion, earned a spot on the United States men’s team Tuesday, and will receive funding for three months. He is attempting a comeback at 33, trying to make his fourth Olympics.

Nascar placed the drivers Kurt Busch and Tony Stewart on probation for six races Tuesday, beginning with the Daytona 500. The punishment resulted from a confrontation between the two after a wreck in practice last week.Nascar officials came into this season saying that drivers would be given more latitude to show emotion this year, and the relatively light nature of Tuesday’s punishments would seem to support that.No one would confirm that Stewart punched Busch at a meeting with officials, but Robin Pemberton, Nascar’s vice president for competition, said that how they conducted themselves after the accident, “from there through the rest of the evening, is why the penalties were equal.”But the Nascar spokesman Ramsey Poston noted, “If you are on probation for an altercation with another driver, and you have a second incident during that probation period, we are going to take action.”.
Several arrests in Hong Kong for posting sexually explicit images of what appear to be some of Asia’s best-known pop stars has led to a debate over free speech on the Web.
The New York Times Company, under pressure from hedge funds that want to gain representation on its board, nominated two candidates of its own, Robert E. Denham and Dawn Lepore.
Uno became the first beagle to win best in show in the 100 times the Westminster Kennel Club has picked a winner.

The Campbell Soup Company said it planned to team up with a Russian meat supplier, Joosten Products, to make broths at a factory outside Moscow. The company plans to start selling the locally made broth in Russia by the end of the year. “The opening of local production goes in line with Campbell’s strategic plans for the Russian market: to provide maximum accessibility of high-quality products in one of the world’s most promising markets,” Campbell said. The company, based in Camden, N.J., began selling imported broths in Russia in October.
The creator of the timing system used in the controversial Tennessee-Rutgers women’s game Monday night said he suspected that human error led to the clock’s stopping.

The Swiss money manager Julius Baer said it planned to float its asset management business in the United States this year, giving it more cash to invest in its booming business for wealthy clients. The divestment of the unit, which will be renamed Artio Global Investors before the initial public offering, is Baer’s next move to overhaul its business after an acquisition in 2005 that almost doubled its size. The sale of the unit would give Baer more leeway to acquire rivals and invest in its quickly expanding business in Asia. A regulatory filing showed the sale could yield up to $1 billion. The United States division said it planned to list its Class A shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

The state-run oil company said it had stopped selling crude to Exxon Mobil and had suspended commercial relations with it. The state-run Petroleos de Venezuela said it “has paralyzed sales of crude to Exxon Mobil.” It said the decision was made “as an act of reciprocity” for the company’s “judicial-economic harassment.” President Hugo Chávez has shaken oil markets with threats to cut off oil supplies to America. His threats came in response to a drive by Exxon Mobil to seize Venezuelan assets through the courts in a dispute over the nationalization of its ventures in Venezuela.

Axa, Europe’s second-largest insurer, agreed to buy part of the ING Groep’s insurance business in Mexico for 1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), the Dutch-based financial services group said in a statement. ING, based in Amsterdam, said it was selling the business, Seguros ING, and its subsidiaries.
The case arose out of accusations that Bush administration officials sought to remove some federal prosecutors so they could be replaced with ones more in line with administration ideology.

The Brazilian banking company Itau said net profit rose 58 percent in the fourth quarter, lifted by strong credit growth and the sale of assets. Banco Itau, Brazil’s second-largest private-sector bank, posted net income of 2.03 billion reais ($1.13 billion), up from 1.28 billion reais a year earlier. The bank said its quarterly results benefited from the sale of its stake in the local BM&F commodities and futures exchange and in the São Paulo Stock Exchange, which contributed 241 million reais in gains. Itau’s loan portfolio swelled 36 percent last year to 127.59 billion reais, led by a 35 percent increase in lending to individual borrowers.

The Monsanto Company and Bayer received final government approval in Brazil to start selling genetically modified corn seeds that resist insects and herbicides. The National Biotechnology Council gave final approval for Monsanto’s insect-resistant YieldGard Corn Borer and Bayer’s herbicide-resistant Liberty Link corn, a council spokesman, Rafael Godoi, said.
In America, cockfighting is considered cruel and is illegal. But in the Dominican Republic, cockfighting is celebrated as a symbol of the country’s warrior spirit.
A charitable campaign created last year by a New York boutique agency is arriving next month in more than a dozen other cities.
After trying unsuccessfully to prod China to do more to try to end Sudan’s attacks in the Darfur region, Steven Spielberg said he was withdrawing as an artistic adviser to the 2008 Summer Olympics.
Despite its fourth-quarter loss, the pharmaceutical giant’s results topped Wall Street estimates, and its shares rose more than 5 percent.
Competitors say the industry leader, Nokia, is still vulnerable to the vagaries of the cellphone business, with its fickle consumers and aggressive challengers.
Sol Stern, New York City’s cantankerous provocateur against liberal education policies, is relishing the controversy surrounding his recent reversal on the school voucher issue.
According to Wall Street’s forecasters, the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable. That is, if you read between the lines of their predictions.
Facebook modified its help pages to tell people that if they wanted to remove their accounts entirely, they can direct the company by e-mail to have it done.
Justice Antonin Scalia said Tuesday that some physical interrogation techniques could be legally used on a suspect in the event of an imminent threat.
A jury in Texas has ruled that Boston Scientific’s drug-coated stents infringed a 1997 patent issued to a radiologist and has awarded the inventor $431 million.
The trials of six detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, will proceed under deeply flawed procedures that violate this country’s basic fairness.
Restoring political and economic stability in Russia does not justify the setbacks to the rule of law and the systematic hounding of rivals and critics.
Use of the web-based system, known as E-Verify, has been growing by 1000 employers a week in the past year.
John McCain’s campaign hired a former Bush fund-raiser, a signal that the president’s political apparatus was moving into action for Mr. McCain.
Interviews with soldiers and mental health providers at Fort Drum show an unusual level of stress among soldiers and an overburdened system unable to provide adequate care.
Drivers of 4x4s, high-powered sports cars and other high-emission vehicles will have to pay $49 a day to enter central London, triple the current charge.

England’s commissioner for children, Sir Albert Aynsley-Green, and a civil liberties group opened a campaign to ban the Mosquito, a device that emits an annoying high-frequency sound that can be heard only by people younger than 20. They say about 3,500 of the devices, which went on sale in 2006 and are intended to stop teenagers from congregating outside stores and other places, are in use across the country and infringe on the rights of the young. Sir Albert said they are “indiscriminate and target all children and young people, including babies, regardless of whether they are behaving or misbehaving.”.

A trial with a jury was held at a local court in Taegu, the first in Korea’s legal history. The nine-member jury heard the case of a 27-year-old man accused of assaulting a 70-year-old woman while trying to rob her house. After hours of deliberation, most jurors recommended a two-to-four year suspended prison sentence. Their verdict, and others to follow, was not binding; the final say still rests with a judge. “Still,” a court spokesman said, “the introduction of a jury will enhance the people’s confidence in court verdicts in our country.” In the trial on Tuesday, the judge later announced a four-year suspended sentence. “The judge concluded the jury’s decision was logical,” the spokesman said.

A much-anticipated tiger census report found that their numbers had dwindled to 1,411 from 3,642 in 2002, the last census year. The report confirmed the fears of conservationists that India’s tigers are fast declining because of poaching and the loss of their natural homes.
The $155 million cash deal is the latest in a wave of acquisitions for the computer maker.

President Nicolas Sarkozy’s 21-year-old son, Jean, will not be a candidate for local office next month in Neuilly, the wealthy Paris suburb that his father ran as mayor from 1983 to 2003, according to news reports. Speculation that he might run came after he turned against the president’s handpicked but unpopular candidate for mayor, David Martinon, after a poll suggested Mr. Martinon would lose the race, and he withdrew.
The ruling party, ZANU-PF, formally expelled a former finance minister who announced last week that he would run against Robert G. Mugabe for the presidency.
America’s image in the Middle East is as low as it has ever been. Yet generally speaking, Iranians like Americans — a sentiment that has become much more pronounced.
Mr. Browning’s unusual career path took him from chicken farmer to television director of “Live From Lincoln Center.”
The buyout offer, which covers G.M.’s entire unionized work force, came as G.M. announced a $722 million fourth-quarter loss.
Fire marshals investigated the cause of the Hunts Point blaze which caused millions of dollars in damage.
Christopher J. Christie is under scrutiny for awarding tens of millions of dollars in no-bid contracts to his friends and political allies.
IndyMac Bancorp, one of America’s largest independent mortgage lenders, posted a $509.1 million fourth-quarter loss and suspended its dividend indefinitely.
Dr. Dixon’s penetrating studies of how misdirected responses by the immune system can cause diseases that damage the kidneys and other organs won him an Albert Lasker Award in 1975.
The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, a drug maker, named its chief executive, James M. Cornelius, as board chairman, succeeding James D. Robinson III.
Administrators at the State University of New York at Old Westbury are trying to seize upon dorm living as a motivational tool.
Joe Falcone’s company pays garment workers abroad bonuses, and provides them medical, environmental or educational programs.
At the United Nations Conference on Disarmament on Tuesday, the United States rejected a Russian-Chinese draft treaty banning weapons in space.
At least one piece of correspondence by officials of the Rudy Giuliani Presidential Committee painted what appeared to be a bleak picture of the campaign’s financial situation.
Research In Motion blamed a flawed software upgrade for shutting down wireless e-mail messages to millions of its North American subscribers on Monday.
The Molson Coors Brewing Company reported a 75 percent increase in its fourth-quarter profit, crediting a tax benefit and favorable exchange rates.
The advertising services company reported a 13 percent rise in quarterly profit, but the company also issued cautious comments about the economy.
The San Francisco-based company said that it earned $267 million during its fiscal fourth quarter, which ended Nov. 25, up from $96 million at the same time in 2006.
The Marsh & McLennan Companies said its profit fell 62 percent in the fourth quarter as competition reduced the commissions the insurance broker charged.
Helped by increased volume and higher prices in North America and Europe, Coca-Cola Enterprises posted higher-than-expected quarterly earnings.
President Bush denounced racially charged incidents involving nooses and called the era of lynchings from the 19th to the 20th centuries “a shameful chapter in American history.”
Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers’ union in New York City, is in line to succeed Edward J. McElroy as the head of the American Federation of Teachers.
Christine C. Quinn proposed a mix of modest cost-saving initiatives, spending plans and tax-cutting proposals, saying the measures would stimulate the city’s economy.
Small businesses, in particular, may get the biggest lift indirectly — from consumers spending the tax rebates they will start receiving in May.
Australia will not increase its troop levels in Afghanistan until “underperforming” NATO members shoulder their fair share of the burden, the country’s defense minister said Tuesday.
The telephone company reported an 89 percent increase in quarterly profit, aided by an income tax benefit and an increase in high-speed Internet subscribers.
The new Mets stadium, Citi Field, more than a year away from opening, has taken shape in Flushing and can easily be envisioned complete.
Six months before the Games begin in Beijing, Speedo staged its version of an “upfront” to introduce what the company is describing as “the world’s fastest swimsuit.”
Many major hospitals in Israel regularly treat both Palestinians and Israelis and thus are no strangers to mixed feelings or incongruous scenes.
Drafted by a Capitals franchise with so little success, Alex Ovechkin arrived from Russia with much fanfare and has quickly become Washington’s pied piper of hockey.
Where I come from, dating in the Western sense is not acceptable, either socially or religiously.
Having survived typhoons, Japanese conquest and war, the religious traditions of Miyako Island in Japan are losing ground to an increasingly urban life.
Andre Miller is never the player with a colorful or catchy quote, and that is fine with the Sixers as long as he keeps finding ways to help the team win.
The only way to keep the economy going over the long run is to increase the wages of the bottom two-thirds of Americans.
Clint Malarchuk watches tape of Richard Zednik’s throat being slashed and is thrown back almost two decades, when he had his own gruesome moment on the ice.
This season’s heavy snows highlight Colorado’s continuing problem of crowding on roads accessing high-country ski resorts.
The restoration of the Blackstone, a fabled but long vacant hotel, is evidence of a reviving lodging market in one of the country’s largest convention cities.
Accelerated expensing and bonus depreciation are two provisions in the stimulus legislation approved by Congress that will benefit businesses.
The tin-can-shaped Columbus science laboratory is the newest addition to the International Space Station and Europe’s largest contribution.
Although Americans are spending more money than ever to treat spine problems, their backs are not getting any better.
The results from the new clinical trial could increase the chances that the Food and Drug Administration will approve the drug for that use.
To ensure that each of its students can attend the school on full scholarship, Cooper Union has made very savvy moves in the thorny world of Manhattan real estate.

The rapper the Game was sentenced on Monday to 60 days in jail after pleading no contest to felony possession of a firearm in a school zone, The Associated Press reported. Under a plea agreement, two other counts against him were dropped, but his sentence also includes 150 hours of community service and three years of probation. The Game, 28, above, whose real name is Jayceon Terrell Taylor, was accused of pulling a gun on an opposing player during a pickup basketball game at a south Los Angeles school nearly a year ago. ... A three-judge court in Los Angeles has denied an appeal by the R&B singer Ronald Isley of his 37-month federal sentence for tax evasion. Mr. Isley, 66, a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and one of the Isley Brothers, whose hits included “Twist and Shout,” argued that his sentence was unreasonable because of his age and poor health. The appellate court said the trial judge correctly “balanced the need to sanction Mr. Isley’s ‘pathological’ tax evasion against the need to accommodate Mr. Isley’s poor health.” Mr. Isley is in the Federal Correctional Institution in Terre Haute, Ind. His projected release date is April 2010.

A 90-minute edition of “Deal or No Deal” lifted NBC to another No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the game show from 9:30 to 11 p.m., making it the night’s top-rated broadcast. NBC also fared well earlier in the night as “American Gladiators” won its 8 to 9:30 time slot among adults 18 to 49, while attracting a modest 8.8 million viewers. ABC’s “Dance War” delivered slightly more viewers during the time period (9.2 million), but it lagged far behind in the 18-to-49 set, falling to its lowest ratings to date in that demographic. ABC finished a distant fourth over all as both “Notes From the Underbelly” at 9:30 (4.3 million) and “October Road” at 10 (4 million) continued to struggle. Fox was second in the 18-t0-49 set with “Prison Break” at 8 (7.9 million total viewers) and “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 (8.3 million). CBS fared slightly better in total viewers with its comedy lineup, which included strong ratings for a “Two and a Half Men” repeat at 9 (11.9 million).

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to give landmark designation to Congregation Tifereth Israel (1911), believed to be the oldest structure in Queens built as a synagogue. Estée Lauder attended services there as a young woman, and in 1979 and 1980 Madonna lived nearby in a building that used to be a yeshiva affiliated with the congregation. The two-story, wood-frame synagogue, right, designed by Crescent L. Varrone, at 109-18 54th Avenue in Corona, combines Gothic and Moorish design elements with Judaic ornaments: pointed-arched windows, a roundel with a Star of David in colored glass, and a gabled parapet. The original wooden stoop and railing have been replaced with a brick porch with an iron railing, and the wood clapboard siding has been covered with stucco. The design was modeled after synagogues on the Lower East Side, where the founders of the congregation, established in 1907, had originally lived. In 2002 the building was placed on the National Register of Historic Places. Also on Tuesday, the commission voted for a third time to designate the Jamaica Savings Bank building, an 1898 Hough & Duell Beaux-Arts structure at 161-02 Jamaica Avenue, in Jamaica, as a landmark. Twice previously, the commission’s landmark designation for that building has been overturned: by the Board of Estimate in 1975, and by the City Council in 1992. The building’s owner has agreed to support the current designation, which is expected to meet with Council approval.

New chapters in the everlasting George Lucas “Star Wars” saga will turn up on Turner Broadcasting’s Cartoon Network in the fall. The network broadcasts of the new computer-generated animated series, “Star Wars: The Clone Wars,” will be followed by broadcasts on TNT. Lucasfilm Animation has produced more than 30 half-hour episodes about the battle of Jedi Knights against villains seeking control of the galaxy. The series will follow the premiere of a film of the same title on Aug. 15.

Emmylou Harris, right, Tom T. Hall, the Statler Brothers and Ernest Stoneman, who died in 1968, are bound for glory in the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Their selection was announced on Tuesday; formal induction takes place later.

The Arc de Triomphe in Paris reintroduced its museum, right, with a new permanent exhibition highlighting the history of the site. More than $1.45 million was spent to clean and refurbish the museum in the first major makeover since it opened, in 1929, Jean-Paul Ciret, director of cultural development for France’s national monuments, said in a telephone interview. “The arc is the most symbolic monument of France, like the Eiffel Tower is a symbol of Paris,” he said. The exhibition, officially inaugurated by culture officials on Monday, includes video images showing famous arches throughout Europe and details of the monument’s frieze. The arch, which opened in 1836, was visited by 1.3 million people last year, more than 80 percent of them foreigners.

Lucette Lagnado, a senior special writer and investigative reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has won the $100,000 Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature for her memoir, “The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit: My Family’s Exodus From Old Cairo to the New World” (HarperCollins/Ecco). Ms. Lagnado was chosen by the Jewish Book Council for “her demonstration of a fresh vision and evidence of future potential to further contribute to the Jewish literary community.” ... Tom Sleigh of Brooklyn, a teacher in the creative writing program at Hunter College, has won the $100,000 Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award for his collection “Space Walk” (Houghton Mifflin). The annual award, established in 1992 in honor of the poet Kingsley Tufts and administered by Claremont Graduate University in Claremont, Calif., recognizes a poet “who is past the very beginning but has not yet reached the acknowledged pinnacle of his or her career.”.

A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about record voter turnouts in the Feb. 5 nominating contests referred imprecisely to the turnouts in Utah and New York, and the Jan. 8 primaries in New Hampshire. In each case, the turnout figures represented the percentage of all eligible citizens who voted in each primary, not the percentage of registered Democratic or Republican voters who did so. Turnouts in the three states were: 28.5 percent in the New Hampshire Democratic primary and 23.3 percent in the state's Republican primary; 7.8 percent in the Utah Democratic primary and 18 percent in its Republican primary; and 13.6 percent in the New York Democratic primary. (The turnout figure for New York's Republican primary was 4.8 percent.)

The new army chief of Pakistan has ordered the withdrawal of military officers from the government's civil departments, officials said Tuesday, an action that reverses an important policy of his predecessor, President Pervez Musharraf. The order by the army chief, General Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, was the boldest step he has taken to disentangle the military from the civilian sphere of the government since President Musharraf stepped down as military chief in November and General Kayani replaced him.

BROWNING--Kirk. Lentils and Cotechino on New Year's Eve and Pumpkin Flan on Thanksgiving will always be. Love to Barbara and the family. Barbara and Ira Sahlman BROWNING--Kirk. We remember Kirk Browning at work: ''...and disoollvve...'' The shot would be climactic, or full of tension. It would set up an expectation that flowed from the music. Then would come the payoff: the next shot that seemed to arise organically, naturally; and the path from one shot to the next was illuminated by that gentle, soothing voice, caressing the transition: ''...and disoollvve...''; and sometimes we would all join in, six or eight people in the TV truck, all crooning along with our Maestro: ''...and disoollvve...'' To us he was our touchstone, our benchmark. He was the way we measured ourselves. Everything we do from now on will bear his imprint. He showed us the way for more than 30 years, and now we have to mark a path without him, but the path ahead would not exist without the path behind. We were his ''darlings'', and the touch of his hand on our shoulders told us of his faith in us. With his gentle voice he moved us to the creation of beauty. The sounds and sights of the great performers of the age were somehow magnified by his craft and dedication. Now his next great transition is ready, and we hear him as we call the next shot: ''...and disoollvve... Great job, Kirk. Rest well.'' Live From Lincoln Center John Goberman Marc Bauman Clare Avery Carl Samet Cheryl Fusco

ROTH--Joseph. December 4, 1914-February 9, 2008. He was born in New York and died in San Francisco surrounded by his loving family. Joe Roth had a deep and uncompromising commitment to social justice and equality. He conducted his life with a sense of universal respect, appreciation and enjoyment of all people, from his experiences as a social worker to the relationships he had with his family and the world. He was a director of fieldwork and a professor of social work at Adelphi University in New York. Joe helped run Camp Meadowbrook Lodge in Massachusetts with his family for 15 years. He had a lifelong love of music, singing and the arts. Joe had a quality that drew everyone to him as a friend, mentor and role model. He is survived by his beloved wife Martha, to whom he was married for 67 years, his sons Robert and Daniel, his daughters-in-law Judith Mirkinson and China Brotsky, his extended family Allan and Muriel Brotsky, Leslie Mullin and Terry Forman, his grandchildren Ona, Gemma, Max, Jack and Corey, and numerous nieces and nephews. We will miss his sharp wit and tender spirit.

Danny was a lifelong resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan where he loved to scooter along Madison Ave. He was a graduate of Admiral Farragut Naval Academy and attended Tulane University before enlisting in the United States Marine Corp. You will always be more than just a best friend, a great mentor and a most special human being. We will miss your sincerity, wonderful sense of values and the special charisma you brought to our lives. Our hearts go out to Victoria, Whitney, Brandon and to the Weiskopf and Sherman families. For decades, when restaurants were buying, not serving, meat in the meatpacking district, DeBragga & Spitler was dedicated to accommodating New York's top chefs. Marc Sarrazin, a French butcher who became the president of the company in 1973, had his finger on the pulse of the New York restaurant world, as adviser and friend as well as purveyor. His son, Marc John, joined him about 15 years ago, and in 2006 George W. Faison, a founder of D'Artagnan, became a partner. Several months ago the company began selling to retail customers through its new Web site, www.debragga.com, where restaurant-quality beef, lamb, pork, veal, poultry and sausages are sold. Especially worth noting are high-quality grass-fed beef strip loins (four 12-ounce steaks for $54.95; four 16-ounce ones, $73.95). They're deeply flavorful and though they are not quite as buttery as the company's dry-aged prime strip loins, they are about a third the price.

A 15-year-old boy was shot and wounded in a junior high school computer laboratory in Oxnard and another eighth-grader was taken into custody, the authorities said. Worried parents gathered outside the 1,150-student E. O. Green Junior High School, which was locked down. Students were released classroom by classroom. The wounded boy had improved since arriving at St. John's Regional Medical Center in extremely serious condition, a police spokesman said. The 14-year-old suspect was being booked for investigation of attempted murder, said the Oxnard police chief, John Crombach.

FRANKS--Andrew, M.D., of New York City and Pelham, New York, on February 10, 2008, age 100 years, peacefully after a brief illness, surrounded by his loving family. Former Professor of Dermatology at his beloved New York University Skin and Cancer Unit where he taught and was a Chief of Service at the Clinic for many years. Dr. Andrew Franks celebrated his hundredth birthday on June 12 with more than 150 family and friends in Pelham, NY, where he lived with his family, and was an active member of the American Legion, Pelham Post 50, and the Senior Citizens Center. Dr. Franks was born 1907 in the coal mining town of Leckrone, PA, the son of Italian immigrants from Pisa, Italy. Despite his humble beginnings as a coal miner's son, he became a legend in Dermatology. He attended West Virginia University in Morgantown for his pre-medical studies, and because of his extraordinary academic excellence was recruited by New York University School of Medicine into an accelerated six year program graduating in 1932. That year he married Lydia Benigno his beloved wife for 70 years, who died in 2002. Throughout his career, he contributed to three textbooks and over 60 peer-reviewed scientific articles. Dr. Franks served as a medical officer in the United States Army as Colonel and was stationed at Lawson General Hospital in Atlanta, Georgia, during WWII. While performing his medical service during the day, he completed a law degree at night upon the Army's request at Woodrow Wilson College of Law (now part of Emory University) in order to best represent those wounded and disabled during the war. He was recently awarded the Greatest Generation Medal in acknowledgement of his service for World War II. As one of the first M.D., LLB graduates in the United States, he and his colleague, and friend, Howard Rusk, along with others, founded the American Academy of Occupational Medicine in the United States where he served as Governor and was a medical legal expert in occupational medicine. He was also active in the Dermatologic Society of Greater New York and hosted its 50th anniversary, and published its Proceedings of 50 years. This past April he received a wonderful recognition from the NYU Alumni Association Annual Meeting for his 75 years of service to the Medical School. Dr. Franks was predeceased by his wife Lydia in 2002 and his daughter Norma in 1998. He is survived by his daughter Joy Catapano, his son and daughter-in-law Drs. Andrew G., Jr. and Linda K. Franks, who both practice in his original office at Gramercy Park, the longest operating family Dermatology practice in the United States. He is also survived by his 11 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. In his most recent years as a resident of Pelham, NY, he was active in the community and neighborhood, and loved by all, both young and old. He will be remembered for his unwavering optimism, integrity, compassion, and boundless sense of humor which inspired not only his family, but all those who came in contact with him. Though many neighborhoods have lost treasured food establishments, Sugar Bun Bake Shop in Howard Beach, Queens, which opened in 1964, is still going strong. Andrea Rigie Kay, right, who runs it, is the third generation in the business, which her grandfather, Albert Moss, a Polish immigrant, started in Flatbush, Brooklyn. His son-in-law, Rubin Rigie, Ms. Rigie's father, relocated the bakery to Queens. It caters to traditional New York tastes with rugelach, cheesecakes, black-and-white cookies and coffeecakes. Now there is a Web site, www.sugarbunbakeshopry.com, so many of the specialties can be shipped fresh overnight by Federal Express. Notable among them is the meltaway coffeecake, above, swirled with nuts and spices, and the unusual chocolate babka, a ring with a crumb topping and a creamy chocolate filling that is more a dessert cake than coffeecake, each $24.95. Sugar Bun is at 156-22 Cross Bay Boulevard, Howard Beach, Queens, (718) 843-9233.

BARKER--Walter G. ''Bud,'' 67, formerly of Garden City, died peacefully February 7, 2008 at home in Orinda, CA. Graduated Chaminade High School, 1958; College of Holy Cross, 1962; Harvard Business School, 1970. Track star and lifelong competitive runner. Pioneered and refined real estate sale and leaseback transactions that earned him national prominence in the real estate and finance industries. DeMASI--Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael DeMasi, associated with The Times from November 8, 1978 until the present.

KINSOLVING--Jacqueline W. Vogelstein. Her incandescent smile dimmed forever on Sunday, February 10, after a brave two year fight with lung cancer. Jackie was the adored wife of Charlie Kinsolving, the devoted mother of Fred and Andrew Vogelstein and their wives Evelyn and Monica, and her five worshipping grandchildren: David, Beatrice, Sam, Natalie and Matthew. She was much beloved by all members of the Kinsolving family. Born in Luxembourg in 1936, she came to this country in 1941 aboard the troop ship USS Exeter, sailing from Lisbon. Returning to Europe after World War II she attended the American School in Paris and then studied art in a Parisian atelier for three years. She later taught art at the Dalton School in Manhattan. Living in New York and East Hampton, she earned her B.S. in Political Science from Columbia University's School of General Studies and was a tireless fundraiser for the school. She served on the board of her apartment building and on the board of the Art Barge in East Hampton. Her many friends will remember her shining smile, her impish smirk, her generosity of spirit, her diplomacy, her steadfast support of those in need, her sense of humor, her boundless energy and optimism and her cosmopolitan sophistication. Services Wednesday, February 13, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St.
SILVERMAN--Madeline. One year in Heaven, 1/23/07. Strong in spirit. In our hearts always. Love, Sherry, Jeff, Benjamin and Andrea

The top story of the day is the police search for a man who fatally stabbed a psychologist, Kathryn Faughey, then attacked a psychiatrist, Kent D. Shinbach, in a medical office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The man — described as middle-aged, with a black cap and sneakers — came in from the freezing rain, toting two pieces of black luggage and saying he was there to see Dr. Shinbach. But Dr. Shinbach had another patient, a woman, waiting for him, so the man sat on a couch and made small talk. Then he disappeared into the office of the other doctor, Kathryn Faughey, and stabbed her in the head, face and chest. Hearing her screams, Dr. Shinbach rushed in and saw her lying still and bleeding on the tan carpet by her desk.

There was no talk, either, of the sanctity of the record books, and no earnest invocations of The Children, those poor souls sent down a wayward path because Nook Logan might've dabbled with growth hormone. Feel up to testing your wits? These are interactive problems based on positions from recent tournament games. In each case, click on the chess board and wait for the viewer to load, then make a move on the chess board by clicking and dragging a piece and wait for the computer to respond. The problems range in difficulty from easy to fairly hard. This feature will appear periodically.

This week's guest blogger is the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. Sagmeister is known for his stunning and original approach to the design of album art, magazine spreads, advertising and installation works. He often takes a renegade, D.I.Y. approach to type; in 1999 he made a poster by photographing words he had scratched onto his torso. (His design for the Talking Heads box set earned him a Grammy award.) Sagmeister's work as been exhibited around the world; his current solo show, "Things I have Learned in my Life so Far," is showing at Deitch Projects in New York. Stefan's book, by the same name, will be in stores next week. To read all of Stefan Sagmeister's prior blog posts, click here.

MILWAUKEE - Lincoln Chafee, a former Republican Senator from Rhode Island, said today that he is changing party registration - at least on primary day next month - and endorsing Senator Barack Obama's presidential candidacy.
Last month I posted about my new Smart car -- or, rather, the Smart car I hope to buy. I put my $99 down to reserve one last March, when the reservations first opened up. And I waited.
During his final annual press conference as President of Russia today in Moscow, Vladimir V. Putin offered a tantalizing sound bite, especially for his critics:

In what may be a sign that its investor base is growing restless, Yahoo sent a letter from its chief executive, Jerry Yang, to shareholders Wednesday explaining the Web company's decision to turn down a takeover offer from Microsoft and laying out its turnaround strategy.

After I reviewed digital picture frames in last week's column, I just could not believe the number of readers who wrote to say, "Why buy an expensive frame just to show pictures? My computer has a screensaver that does the same thing! Why not just buy a cheap old Dell and dedicate it to showing your pictures?"
CNBC coverage of Senate testimony by Ben S. Bernanke, Federal Reserve Chairman, on the state of the economy.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

There have been some requests for a basic tart crust recipe since my column on making walnut tart, so here you go. It's obviously very buttery, but it's even richer than that because it contains an egg, too. This makes it almost like shortbread; you might think of it as a large cookie.
Happy V-Day!

Shelley Duncan, who has played 34 games in his career with the Yankees, was left to be a spokesman for the team on Wednesday. Since Derek Jeter and Jorge Posada had the day off, Duncan was the only Yankee who stopped to talk to the news media. Duncan fielded questions about Roger Clemens and the Congressional hearings in Washington, D.C.
Say it with chocolate this Valentine's Day. How much you say is up to you.
The Canon Pixma IP90 is an extremely tiny, sleek, flat color inkjet printer, not much bigger than a hardbound book lying on the desk.
There's a whole genre that says they are, of course, but in my experience the most intimate literary moments don't necessarily come from love stories.
There is only one way to describe Ronaldo's brief appearance for AC Milan Wednesday against Livorno: disaster!

In the highly volatile world of options trading, minutes count. And it was one particular minute on Wednesday morning -- one second, actually -- that caught the eye of Jon Najarian, the co-founder of OptionMonster.com.

In response to my review of the Second Avenue Deli, a writer who contributes frequently to the Times e-mailed me with an interesting assertion to which some of you may have equally interesting reactions. So I throw it out there for discussion.

The quintessential American quick bread is corn bread, and this points us in the direction of wholesome, fast, savory breads that can anchor a hearty vegetarian dinner or serve as a side dish at a more conventional meal. This one, made predominantly with whole wheat flour, does it all -- and with almost no work.
Nothing says Valentine's Day like long-stemmed roses, dark chocolate and a sweet love note from Hillary Rodham Clinton:
Supporters of an anti-Syrian coalition marked the third anniversary of the assasination of Rafik Hariri on the same day of the funeral of Hezbollah leader Imad Mugniyah.

Chess players eagerly keep track of celebrities devoted to the game, with Will Smith, Howard Stern and Madonna prominent on the list. But in clubs, at tournaments and on Internet forums, I never heard any players talk about Heath Ledger. The Australian actor, who died Jan 22 at age 28, apparently enjoyed the game as much as anyone in Hollywood. But the depth of his passion has only come out post-mortem.
Dogs and their owners sports some all kinds of looks at the Westminster Kennel Club show.

Imagine you are a gorilla who has just made a momentous discovery: having sex while facing your partner. What is going through your mind? What do you say to your partner? (Hint: Think Barry White, not Dan Hill.)
A spatial exploration of food processing, sharing, cooking and disposal at the Dunefield Midden campsite in South Africa performed by Brian Stewart and Giulia Saltini-Semerari.
The eventful life of galaxies in low density environments performed by Ruth Gruetzbauch and Jesús Varela.

Shaila Dewan has a great piece today about the Soul Food Museum, which had an official opening of sorts in Atlanta yesterday. The museum is the creation of Kenneth Willhoite, whose expansive vision of soul food can accommodate both Smokey Robinson's seafood gumbo mix ("The Soul is in the Bowl") and Lucille Ball's Predic-a-mints.
Joel Surnow, the creator of "24," is clocking out.

Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poor's reports that St. Valentine's Day tends to be a poor day in the stock market, with the S.&P. 500 rising only 39 percent of the time, and fallling 57 percent of the time.
There's no love lost between CSX, the railroad operator, and The Children's Investment Fund, the hedge fund battling for seats at the company.
Do you think Roger Clemens's testimony at Wednesday's Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?

It's that time of the year when velvet boxes get opened -- perhaps with some candlelight and a fancy dinner, just to seal the deal -- and the question gets popped. In recent days, some were expecting that even Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines might feel the romance and choose Valentine's Day to announce a merger agreement. Frank Boroch, an analyst at Bear Stearns, suggested last week that a Feb. 14 merger announcement would play up the friendly aspects of any proposal, as opposed to the ugly situation with Delta's previous suitor, an unabashedly hostile (and ultimately unsuccessful) US Airways.

So the Dakar Rally is moving to South America. Whether it will continue to be called the Dakar Rally is still up in the air, in part because the event's organizers are holding out hope that the 30-year-old cross-continent rally might someday return to its Lisbon-Dakar route.

Things are proceeding more slowly that I sort-of-but-didn't-really predicted. But current events -- in which every week or two some important market you never heard of seems to collapse -- bear at least a family resemblance to the scenario I laid out a year ago.
No matter which way you calculate the delegate count, that score is dictating the shape of the Democratic race these days.
