Did you hear that sound Wednesday? It was a big sigh of relief among the arbitrage community as the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman completed its acquisition of Goodman Global.
The NBC dramas "Heroes," "Chuck," and "Life" will return for the next television season, the network said Wednesday.

The New Republic's Jonathan Chait tries to arbitrate the campaign dispute over whether Barack Obama has a firm enough grasp on policy matters to be president. "Well, it's certainly true that Obama can't match Hillary Clinton's grasp of policy detail," Chait writes at The Plank, his magazine's staff blog. "Clinton is a true policy wonk." He continues:
This being Valentine's Day, the Bagger has to have a Hallmark moment and salute some of the great romances in the year's movies.

Some of you have already started filling in your ballots for the Oscar pool, beginning with the easy ones, like Diablo Cody for original screenplay. Sasha Stones takes a hard look and smells a rat than might sneak up on her.

The Spidey sense of Scott Feinberg, who follows the race closer than most, is tingling. He says that "Michael Clayton" is "surging across the board," perhaps even "threatening Day-Lewis and Bardem." Tilda Swinton is on a roll as well, according to Pete Hammond.

Shares of UBS, the Swiss bank, fell in Europe on Thursday after it confirmed its previous warning of a big fourth-quarter loss and said it expects 2008 to be "another difficult year." The bank also revealed $26.6 billion in exposure to risky United States mortgages distinct from the now-infamous subprime loans, increasing its vulnerability to the global credit crisis.

The Bagger visited the preview Oscar luncheon in New York at the Carlyle Hotel where the chef came up with a plate to mirror each movie. There will be video of this momentous event, but in the meantime, Grub Street conjured a list of drinkables to match the nominees, including:

I get some pretty harsh comments. But they're nothing like what I used to get when criticizing Dear Leader, back when he had an 80% approval rating, and -- this is new to me -- nothing like the comments people leave on financial blogs when they say a good word about short-sellers.

Whenever I write about finding passion in our careers, the naysayers show up to say that passion really doesn't belong at work. So in honor of Valentine's Day, I ask why was this advertisement one of the most popular videos on YouTube a week after it aired on the Super Bowl? Is it just a case of clever ad copy and animation? Or is it that people really do want something resembling passion in their careers? Either way, enjoy it if you haven't yet seen it.

Today's obituary page notes the passing of Steve Gerber, who created Howard the Duck, the dour, dyspeptic, utterly disagreeable and therefore wildly popular comic-book hero of the 1970s (too bad the movie was a bomb). But folks at Disney were not among Howard's fans, as the obit notes:
Coming soon to a theater near you ...
Why does football get a pass?

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Big news for us, the writers' strike is finally over and I just want to say personally it's great to have them back. In fact, they wrote that. That was the first thing they wrote. "Say it! Say it! Or we'll leave again."

Solutia, a bankrupt chemical company, won't be sending any Valentine Day's goodies to Citigroup's chief executive, Vikram Pandit, but it will head to a Manhattan court on Thursday to try to persuade a judge to allow it to depose him.
Can Yahoo avoid being gobbled up by Microsoft? Many analysts say it is increasingly unlikely.

Freescale Semiconductor, the chipmaker that was acquired by a group of private equity firms in 2006, named Rich Beyer as its new chief executive on Wednesday. Mr. Beyer was most recently the chairman and chief executive of Intersil, another semiconductor company.
MBIA, the world's biggest bond insurer, is planning to hit back at the hedge fund heavy William A. Ackman, who has long been betting against the insurers' shares.
The $19.5 billion sale of Clear Channel Communications to two private-equity firms cleared its final regulatory hurdle Wednesday with approval by the Justice Department's antitrust division.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):

Bonuses for 2007 rose or were unchanged for 80 percent of London's financial-services employees as a second-half market slump failed to bite until this year, Bloomberg News reported, citing British recruitment company Morgan McKinsley.
Could a sale be in the future for the California power company Calpine?
On Friday, billions of dollars in restricted stock will become eligible for trading on the open market as new Securities and Exchange Commission rules take effect.

Planktos, a California company that is trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, canceled planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds, The New York Times reported. At the company's Web site, planktos.com, a notice blamed a "highly effective disinformation campaign" for the cancellation.

The banking industry is proposing to members of Congress and the White House that some of the risk of troubled mortgages should be shifted to the federal government, according to The Wall Street Journal.

NBC Entertainment's co-chairman, Ben Silverman, on Wednesday sold his television production company, Reveille, to London-based Shine, owned by the media baron Rupert Murdoch's daughter Elisabeth, for $125 million.

Hewlett-Packard has agreed to a financial settlement with The New York Times and three BusinessWeek magazine journalists in connection with the company's spying scandal that stemmed from surreptitiously obtaining private phone records.

It could be argued that the maxim "nice guys finish last" was created with private equity titans in mind. The industry is littered with tales of cutthroat buyout competitions. The rivalry between Blackstone's chief, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, chieftain, Henry R. Kravis, alone has been been the subject of oceans of spilled ink.
Rio Tinto again rebuffed a hostile takeover bid by its larger rival, BHP Billiton, saying that there was "clear water" between BHP's sweetened $147 billion bid and its fair value.
The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned. The executive, William T. McKinnon, left on Feb. 8, the company said in a regulatory filing.
Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware won court approval on Wednesday to sell its business for $80 million to the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners, barring higher offers at auction.
A group of investors have agreed to try on Ellen Tracy for size.

Bragster, a London-based site "for dares and social bets," announced Wednesday that it had secured $3.5 million in Series A venture cash. The funding round was led by none other than Intel Capital, Intel's investment branch.
The Air France-KLM Group, Europe's biggest airline, plans to invest in a combined Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines carrier, according to news reports.

AstraZeneca said Thursday it is spinning off its Swedish gastrointestinal research operations into a new company called Albireo, backed by a consortium of investment firms led by Nomura Phase4 Ventures.
Commerzbank's bill from the subprime crisis crept up towards 800 million euros ($1.2 billion) in 2007 but the bank still managed a record profit for the year as bad debt provisions fell.

The German government said on Wednesday that it would participate in a third bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the lender whose near-collapse in July heralded the arrival in Europe of the crisis stemming from the faltering subprime mortgage market in the United States.

Money managers in the United States would have to provide online brochures describing their services, fees, investment performance and potential conflicts of interest under a proposal approved Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Securities and Exchange Commission may free some foreign companies from the agency's oversight as long as they make financial disclosures widely available to investors over the Internet.
A Chinese department store operator, Maoye International Holdings, has hired two more investment banks to underwrite its postponed Hong Kong initial public offering, according to Dow Jones.
This comes from Craig Custance of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution at Thrashers Blog via the ubiquitous Kukla's Korner.
With the $15 billion construction project officially over, the promised transformation of downtown Boston finally seems within reach.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 14 column.
Playwright and television writer Diana Son goes back to work after the  Writers Guild of America ended its three-month-long strike.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers made it clear that they were prepared to take potentially incendiary steps to build her delegate count.
“Step Up 2 the Streets” posits a universe where racial and class differences are minor obstacles to fun and pretends its clichés aren’t clichés.
Instead of the kind of inspired imaginative synergy that distinguished the “Lord of the Rings,” “The Spiderwick Chronicles” feels more like a sloppy, secondhand pander.
“Definitely, Maybe,” written and directed by Adam Brooks, is a nimble and winning little romance.
“Jumper” is a barely coherent genre mishmash about a guy who transports himself across the globe at will.
William Harvey’s handmade house in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is a unique perch from which to watch a changing neighborhood.
Witch hazels light up a gray wall, the bare woods or even a pot on a terrace, long before anything else is in bloom.

The man walked into an ocean sciences class on the campus of Northern Illinois University and opened fire from the stage. Four women and one man were killed, and 16 others were wounded by the gunman, who then killed himself.
Russ Stanton, who has been running the newspaper’s Web site, was named to the post three weeks after the previous editor, James E. O’Shea, was forced out for resisting staff cuts.
Lawmakers said government intervention may be needed to ease financial strains in the bond industry that are unsettling other areas of the economy.
The resolution cites Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel, and Joshua B. Bolten, the president’s chief of staff, for refusing to testify about the firing of federal officials.
It is the first planetary system that really looks like our own, with outer giant planets and room for smaller inner planets, astronomers say.
The Pentagon plans to shoot down a disabled 5,000-pound spy satellite before it enters the atmosphere in early March, a Pentagon official said.
Detectives interviewed a man in Bethlehem, Pa., in connection with the killing, an official said.
The newspaper will bow to growing financial strain and cut 100 newsroom jobs this year, primarily through attrition and buyouts, but layoffs are a possibility, the executive editor said.
Lawmakers said government intervention may be needed to ease financial strains in the bond industry that are unsettling other areas of the economy.
Prosecutors accused Klaus Zumwinkel, chief executive of Deutsche Post, with tax evasion after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.
The bank offered no hope for a near-term turnaround after it posted a fourth-quarter loss of 12.5 billion Swiss francs ($11.3 billion) and warned that 2008 would be a difficult year.

Last week, a famous pitcher likely bound for the Hall of Fame was reportedly injected with a steroid in an effort to prolong his career. This news, however, was not greeted with any widespread clutching of pearls. There were no calls for Congressional meddling and no inquiries about any palpable growths on his hindquarters. There was no talk, either, of the sanctity of the record books, and no earnest invocations of The Children, those poor souls sent down a wayward path because Nook Logan might’ve dabbled with growth hormone. In fact, it was all perfectly legal. The pitcher’s injection, according to the Boston Globe, was part of a “conservative treatment plan” laid out by his team’s medical staff. The headline: “Schilling receives shot of cortisone.”.
Jerry Yang explained his company’s rejection of Microsoft’s buyout offer in a letter to shareholders late Wednesday outlining why he believed the bid was too low.
While continuing to avoid predictions of a recession, Ben S. Bernanke told a Senate panel on Thursday that the economic outlook had worsened.
The United States trade deficit shrank in 2007 for the first time in five years, buoyed by a surge in exports.

Want your teenager to be trim as an adult? Give in to the whining and buy that skateboard he craves. That’s the message of a major longitudinal study of adolescence and weight gain published last month in the journal Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine. In the study, led by researchers at Johns Hopkins University, 3,345 adolescents were asked about their daily physical activities, both in physical education classes and on their own. The kids reported their weights, which were used to calculate theirbody mass indexes. Most -- 72 percent -- were average weight or below.

Goggles might not help you ski faster, but they can help you see icy spots and protect your eyes against the elements, making them a crucial component of any downhill adventure. Because most major manufacturers make goggles with interchangeable lenses, picking a frame is the easy part. Glen Traylor of Cole Sport, a retailer in Park City, Utah, frequented by both novices and members of the U.S. Ski Team, tells customers, “If you like the way it looks, and if it fits well, then you’ve found your goggles.”.
Do you think Roger Clemens’ testimony at yesterday’s Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?.

Cramps are common among endurance athletes, who get taken by surprise when they hit and the muscle contracts violently, as if prodded with a jolt of electricity. But as Gina Kolata writes in The Times today, cramps remain a medical mystery despite their ubiquity. Medical textbooks skirt the topic, and few scientists have studied them. That hasn’t slowed the advice circulating on how to avoid them.
Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson acknowledged the United States is experiencing a “significant” housing market downturn but the economy should avoid recession.
Isiah Thomas was ejected, and the Knicks trudged into the All-Star break as dizzy and disoriented as they have ever been.
Uno, the 15-inch beagle, vindicated the extraordinary adoration that enveloped him at Madison Square Garden and became the first beagle to win best in show at Westminster.
Production of the blood-thinning drug heparin was suspended this week after 350 patients reported ill effects from it.
In overtime, Brian Gionta, the Devils’ energetic right wing finally had room to move — and to try a maneuver that would result in a victory.

A federal appeals court has overturned a Texas statute outlawing sales of sex toys, essentially leaving Alabama as the only state with such a ban. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled that the Texas law making it illegal to sell or promote obscene devices, punishable by up to two years in jail, violated the right to privacy guaranteed by the 14th Amendment.

The authorities say a 17-year-old who was already detained on related charges was the gunman in the November 2007 shooting death of a University of Chicago graduate student from Senegal. The suspect, Demetrius Warren, is one of three teenagers and a 21-year old who have been charged in a series of crimes that culminated in the killing of the student, Amadou Cisse, 29, outside his apartment just off campus. Before killing Mr. Cisse, the authorities say, the group drove around looking for people to rob, mugging university students and shooting at an employee.
Manu Ginóbili made a career-high eight 3-pointers and scored a season-high 46 points as the visiting San Antonio Spurs defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 112-105, on Wednesday night.

The body of a seventh victim has been found in a second-floor break room of a sugar refinery near Savannah where an explosion and fire occurred Thursday, said Capt. Todd Heil of the Savannah Fire Department. One worker is still missing. Victims’ names have not been released.

Conservative Judaism’s international assembly of rabbis voted Tuesday to approve a resolution criticizing Pope Benedict XVI’s revision of a Latin Good Friday prayer. The prayer calls for God to enlighten the hearts of Jews “so that they may acknowledge Jesus Christ, the savior of all men.” The resolution adopted by the rabbis said the prayer could set back Jewish-Catholic relations. Most Catholics worship in the vernacular, and their prayers will not be affected.
Alan Voskuil scored a career-high 30 points and host Texas Tech beat No. 18 Kansas State, 84-75, on Wednesday night to give Pat Knight his first win since taking over for his father.

A New Jersey garbage truck driver was charged with manslaughter on Wednesday after a truck he was driving in Manhattan on Tuesday veered out of control, jumped a curb and killed two tourists from England, the police said.
Police said Rakeem Gartrell, 22, walked into a station house in Newark, approached the front desk and said, “I just killed three people.”

ABB, the electrical engineering company, announced the abrupt departure of its chief executive, Fred Kindle, because of “irreconcilable differences” after he helped the company recover from near bankruptcy. The company also said its earnings report, to be released Thursday, would show that in the fourth quarter its profit surged to $1.8 billion (1.2 billion euros), up from $422 million in the year-earlier period, on the sale of a noncore unit. Mr. Kindle, left, has headed the company for three years as it rebuilt from a near collapse related to asbestos claims in 2002 against ABB’s acquisitions in the United States. ABB said it had begun its search for a successor. The chief financial officer, Michel Demare, will lead the company in the meantime.

The digital camera and medical equipment maker Fujifilm Holdings Corporation said it would take control of the Toyama Chemical Company for up to 155 billion yen ($1.45 billion) to gain a foothold in the pharmaceuticals market. Fujifilm has made a string of acquisitions in the last few years to cultivate new sources of growth while shifting away from unpromising businesses like film. Japan’s pharmaceuticals sector is realigning as drug makers, struggling under mounting costs to develop new products, look for ways to split research and development expenses.

The French oil company Total said fourth-quarter profit rose 62 percent as oil prices surged and new projects in Angola and Qatar increased production. The company, based in Paris, said profit rose to 3.6 billion euros ($5.23 billion), from 2.23 billion euros a year earlier.

The United States has won a preliminary ruling in a World Trade Organization case over Chinese tax policies that restrict imports of auto parts, a United States trade official said. The final report in the case is expected to be made public this year. The United States and the European Union filed the case in March 2006 and were later joined by Canada. They complained that China’s tax treatment of auto imports discouraged Chinese automobile manufacturers from using them. China’s commitments to the trade organization require it to set a lower tariff on imported auto parts than it does on finished vehicles, but it had been charging the same tariffs, the United States trade representative’s office said at the time it filed the case. Once a final report is issued, China can appeal the decision.

An article on Tuesday about the theft of four masterwork paintings valued at $163 million from a Zurich gallery misspelled the name of the French village in the title of one painting, an 1879 Monet. It is “Poppies Near Vétheuil,” not Vertheuil.

An article on Tuesday about the theft of four masterwork paintings valued at $163 million from a Zurich gallery misspelled the name of the French village in the title of one painting, an 1879 Monet. It is “Poppies Near Vétheuil,” not Vertheuil.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a new study on muscle fatigue and what could prevent it misidentified the exercise scientist at Appalachian State University who collaborated with the principal investigator, Dr. Andrew Marks. He is David Nieman — not Dr. Stephan Lehnart, who works in Dr. Marks’s laboratory. The article also misstated the name of the North Carolina town where Appalachian State is located. It is Boone, not Boonetown.

An article in Business Day on Feb. 6 about the addition of Ukraine to the World Trade Organization referred incompletely to the reasons that Georgia, another former Soviet republic and W.T.O. member, opposes Russia’s quest for membership. While Georgian officials have objected to Russian membership in part because Moscow has banned imports of Georgian wine, the republic is also insisting on the removal of Russian customs checkpoints in the separatist territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

A headline on Tuesday about presidential campaigning leading up to three primaries that day referred incorrectly to the contests. They were held in two states and the District of Columbia, not in three states.

A picture credit in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about Joel Berger, an expert on moose and other hooved animals, misidentified the newspaper that supplied a photograph of a moose crossing a road. It was The Peninsula Clarion, of Kenai, Alaska — not The Pennsylvania Clarion.

An article on Wednesday about Senator John McCain’s decision to hire Mercer Reynolds, one of President Bush’s major fund-raisers, misstated the position of Senator Barack Obama on using public financing for the general election. Although the Obama campaign has been raising private contributions for that election, Mr. Obama is still open to returning those contributions and abiding by the limits of the public financing system if the Republican nominee agrees to do the same. Mr. Obama has not definitively ruled out using public financing.
A lawsuit charged that the government agency that owns the Deutsche Bank building and several contractors knowingly created dangerous conditions.
The real estate broker Linda Stein might have been “alive and well” for at least 45 minutes after the personal assistant who is accused of killing her left her apartment, the assistant’s lawyer says.
New York’s attorney general is looking into whether insurers overcharged patients for out-of-network doctors.
Many Yahoo shareholders are waiting for a higher bid than that offered by Microsoft, but analysts say it is increasingly unlikely.
The General Mining Law of 1872, a relic of the boisterous era of westward expansion, is now an environmental disaster and should be reformed.
The Bush administration will have to press a lot harder to make sure that the new laws approved by Iraq’s Parliament are translated into action.
Stocks rallied on Wednesday, sending the Dow Jones industrials up nearly 180 points, after reports of an unexpected climb in January retail sales.
If Congress fails to enforce its own subpoenas, it would be giving its tacit consent to the dangerous idea of an imperial president.
If report cards are weighed down with educational jargon, it is fair to ask who the school administrators are really reporting to.
A contentious relationship between the senators has been percolating on Capitol Hill for more than two years and is now being thrust to the forefront.
The Senate voted to ban waterboarding and other harsh interrogation methods that have been used by the Central Intelligence Agency against high-level terrorism suspects.
One returning Hollywood writer asked, “Can anyone remember what we were working on three months ago?”

Kansas officials were investigating the refusal by a school to let a female referee call a boys’ high school basketball game. The Kansas State High School Activities Association said referees reported that Michelle Campbell was preparing to officiate at St. Mary’s Academy near Topeka on Feb. 2 when a school official insisted that Campbell could not call the game. The reason given, according to the referees: Campbell, as a woman, could not be put in a position of authority over boys because of the academy’s beliefs. Campbell walked off the court with Darin Putthoff, the referee who was to work the game with her.

A.C. Milan forward Ronaldo ruptured a tendon in his left knee in a 1-1 tie with Livorno on Wednesday and was carried off the field in tears. The injury occurred two minutes after Ronaldo entered the game during a play that earned Milan an equalizing penalty kick. Ronaldo was taken to a hospital, and the club said the full extent of the damage was unknown. He has played sparingly since joining Milan from Real Madrid in January 2007. Wednesday’s match was only his fifth in Serie A this season.

A former women’s coach at Fresno State said she would accept a $6.62 million award so she could put an end to her high-profile sex-discrimination case against the university. A jury originally awarded the coach, Stacy Johnson-Klein, a $19.1 million judgment, but a judge last week ordered a new trial unless she accepted the smaller amount. She was the third woman in the university’s athletics department to sue for discrimination under Title IX.

Lidiya Grigoryeva of Russia, who won the Boston Marathon women’s race last year, and Rita Jeptoo of Kenya, who won the year before, will compete April 21 in the 112th running of the event. Marathon officials also announced that Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia, the runner-up the last two years, would be back. The women’s field will include three young Ethiopians: Askale Tafa Magarsa, 23, who won in Paris and Dubai last year; Dire Tune, 22, the Houston winner last year and this year; and Robe Tola Guta, 21, who won in Hamburg, Germany, two years ago. Other entries include Tetyana Kuzina-Hladyr of Ukraine, Magdaline Chemjor of Kenya, Alevtina Biktimirova of Russia and Bruna Genovese of Italy.The best American women will race on a different course the day before in the United States Olympic trials.
The gas could be used to make the fissile core of nuclear warheads but diplomats emphasized Iran was working with minute amounts of the product.

The Hendrick Motorsports cars had major engine problems during practice for the Daytona 500. The two-time defending Nascar champion and Daytona pole-sitter Jimmie Johnson, the four-time series champ Jeff Gordon, Dale Earnhardt Jr. and Casey Mears were forced to change engines because of a lifter problem probably caused by a bad batch of coating.In all, five of the nine Hendrick-powered cars had problems. The engine swaps will send those five Chevrolets to the back of the field in their 150-mile qualifying races Thursday, which will help set the starting lineup for the Daytona 500.

At least 17 Danish newspapers published a cartoon depicting the Prophet Muhammad wearing a bomb as a turban, a day after the arrest of three men accused of plotting to kill the man who drew the cartoon.
The investigation into Madeleine McCann, the British girl who disappeared last May in the southern Algarve region, is “approaching the conclusion”, the country’s justice minister said.
A tanker truck carrying 30 tons of sulfuric acid overturned in Yunnan Province, spilling the corrosive chemical into a drainage ditch that feeds into the Xinsi River, the state news media said.
An Ankara court sentenced Alparslan Arslan, a lawyer who shot at judges inside the Council of State, the top administrative court, in 2006, killing one and wounding four, to life in prison.
Walter Veltroni resigned as mayor of Rome to focus on his campaign to become Italy’s prime minister in the April national election.

Two men arrested last week in connection with the assassination plot that killed Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader, admitted that they provided a suicide jacket and pistol to her attacker.

After painfully slow sales last month, the music industry finally has a hit: “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire), by Jack Johnson, above, sold 375,000 copies last week — more than six times the sales of the top album the week before — to reach No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It set a record for the most digital sales in a single week, with 139,000 copies, or 37 percent of its total, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week busy with high-profile releases, Sheryl Crow’s “Detours” (A&M) opened at No. 2 with 92,000 sales; Lenny Kravitz moved 73,000 copies of “It Is Time for a Love Revolution” (Virgin) to bow at No. 4; and K. D. Lang is No. 8 with her new “Watershed” (Nonesuch), selling 41,000. Last week’s No. 1, Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J), dropped two spots with 80,000. Any sales bumps after last Sunday’s Grammy Awards would be reflected in next week’s chart.

“Hollywood Week” on “American Idol” had a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of that Fox talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Tuesday’s “Idol” audience grew by 2 million compared with last week’s, the first installment of “Hollywood Week” last year attracted 31.2 million viewers. Trailing far behind Fox in the night’s ratings, CBS drew the second most viewers, earning a solid 11.7 million at 8 p.m. for a rerun of “NCIS.” Later in the night, however, a more modest 7.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 for the premiere of “Big Brother: ’Til Death Do You Part,” the first winter edition of that CBS summer mainstay. At 10 the second season debut of “Jericho” attracted 7.2 million viewers, tying ABC’s “Boston Legal,” but trailing a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (8.3 million). NBC finished third for the night while edging past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49 thanks to “The Biggest Loser,” from 8 to 10 (7.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth overall.

The Guerrilla Girls, a group that protests what it calls “sexism and racism in politics, the art world, film and the culture at large,” sent an open letter to the philanthropist Eli Broad saying that female and minority artists are inadequately represented in the exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Mr. Broad’s private foundation. In a posting on the group’s Web site, guerrillagirls.com, the organization claims that of the 30 artists in the inaugural exhibition at the Broad Museum, 97 percent are white and 87 percent are male. Similarly, the group says that of the 194 artists in the collection of the Broad Foundation, the nonprofit organization that acts as a “lending library” for Mr. Broad’s art holdings, 96 percent are white and 83 percent are male. That, the group said, is “an insignificant number of women and artists of color.” A spokeswoman for the Broad Foundation did not immediately return phone calls or reply to an e-mail message requesting comment.

The honor, recognizing distinguished lifetime service to American poetry, will be bestowed on April 21 at the society’s 98th annual awards ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York. ... The rapper Lil Wayne, right, has been indicted on felony drug and weapons charges by a grand jury in Yuma, Ariz., The Associated Press reported. Lil Wayne, 25, whose real name is Dwayne Michael Carter Jr., pleaded not guilty when arraigned on Friday. His lawyer, James Tilson, said on Tuesday that Lil Wayne’s tour would continue as scheduled. He is next due in court on March 7.

The virtuoso instrumentalist and sometime model known as “the David Beckham of the classical violin” couldn’t have done more damage if he had kicked his Stradivarius past a goalkeeper. The musician, David Garrett, was leaving the Barbican Center in London after a concert at Christmastime when he fell down a flight of stairs and landed on his violin case. Inside was his 290-year-old Stradivarius, an instrument known as the San Lorenzo. Mr. Garrett, 26, who was 14 when he became the youngest artist ever signed by Deutsche Grammophon, opened the case. Inside, he told The Independent, the London newspaper: “The violin was in pieces. I couldn’t speak, and I couldn’t get up. I didn’t even know if I was hurt — I didn’t care. I’ve had that violin for eight years. It was like losing a friend.” Repairs will take eight months and cost close to $120,000, and the violin may never sound the same. Mr. Garrett is scheduled to perform a Bruch violin concerto on Thursday night at the Barbican on a borrowed Stradivarius. A three-member security team will be helping him watch his step.

China has blocked production of “Shanghai,” a Hollywood film about an American who investigates a friend’s death in Japanese-occupied Shanghai, The Associated Press reported. Luan Guozhi, the director of international cooperation at the Chinese Film Bureau, declined to reveal the government’s concerns, but said the filmmakers could alter the script and resubmit their application. The Japanese invasion of China during World War II remains a sensitive topic, and other filmmakers have had difficulty winning approval from China for projects set in the same era. Variety has reported that the cast includes John Cusack, Gong Li, right, and Ken Watanabe. Hundreds of thousands of dollars have already been spent on production, and the director, Mikael Hafstrom, has been in China since September preparing to film. Variety reported that he planned to move the production to Hong Kong.

BRUCE--Amelia Finch, (nee Weiss), of Lakewood, NJ, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away peacefully February 10 at age 95. Amelia was graduated from Adelphia College in 1933. She was predeceased by husbands Lawrence Finch and William Bruce. She leaves her sons Lawrence (Wanda) Finch of Maywood, NJ, and Wesley (Madeline) Finch of Boca Raton, FL, three granddaughters, Abigail of Maywood, Tracey (Gabe) Grossman of Boca Raton, Liza of Manhattan and a great-grandson, Noah Lev Grossman. Please honor her memory by a contribution to your favorite charity.

WEISKOPF--Daniel Kramer, II. Weiskopf, Silver & Co. mourns the passing of its cofounder. We will miss his decades of valued guidance. We extend our condolences to his wife, Victoria; his children, Karin (Sherman), Daniel III, Brandon and Whitney; and his five grandchildren. WEISKOPF--Daniel. Dear Dan, you were larger than life as a father, grandfather, husband, and friend; and true to form, you fought to the end in keeping with your zest for life. Your large persona is forever etched in our hearts and memories. Beth, Jim, Katie, and Leah WEISKOPF--Daniel, II. We will miss your biting humor, supreme generosity, and overwhelming hospitality. Seafield Lane will never be the same without you there, but we will honor and cherish your spirit forever. Allen, Courtney, Matt, and Michael

FARBER--Irving. Forever my Valentine. I will miss you dearly. Maxine FARBER--Irving. We are eternally grateful for the love and companionship you gave our mother, Maxine. Sweet dreams dear friend. You were precious to us and to our children. Peggy, Marc, Nancy, Don

What makes for cutting-edge décor in a law office? A reception area with sharks frolicking in an oversize tank? The offices of Alters, Boldt, Brown, Rash, Culmo, in Miami's Design District, are not that extreme, but they are pretty neat. Surfboards line the hall; comforting throws suitable for wrapping oneself in are tossed over sofas and chairs, right. (Great idea: juries can be so fickle.) In the conference room, above, there is a six-foot beaded chandelier and a large painting that shows Batman, lost in thought about some weighty matter, in the offices of Edward R. Murrow.

The Arne bathtub, which bears a resemblance to Arne Jacobsen's midcentury modern classic Egg Chair, will be available next month from Rapsel, an Italian company. Designed by Nada Nasrallah and Christian Horner for their Viennese company, Soda, the resin tub is perfect for those who enjoy reading in the bath or just listening to music. (It sells for $18,150, but can be ordered with built-in stereo speakers for an additional cost.) Rapsel is also introducing Coup de Foudre ($21,900), a sink/vanity combination designed by Shiro Kuramata and handmade of Murano glass. Available at AFNY Architectural Fixtures, 22 West 21st Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 243-5400. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Some of the best sources for home furnishings are tucked away in hard-to-find places. Annie Hayes, who lives and works in a farmhouse in Delhi, N.Y., high up in the Catskills, makes hooked wool rugs based on 19th-century designs. Many of them are small -- Crossing the River, top left, is 20 by 30 inches ($600), and Blue Diamond ($1,100), bottom left, is 28 by 40 inches -- so they also make appealing wall hangings. Ms. Hayes sells rug-making supplies and do-it-yourself kits online or in her shop, by appointment. Kits, which start at $22.50, include a pattern on burlap, instructions and the necessary supplies.

GOLDSTEIN--Stanley James, FAIA, Architect, 81, of West Orange, NJ, noted architect and engineer, devoted alumnus of MIT, and former member of the MIT Corporation. Funeral Service: Friday, February 15, 2008, at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ; call (800)938-6372 for information.

WEINGART--Marvin, on February 12, 2008, after a valiant fight. He is survied by Ruth Weingart, his wife of 63 years; his children Steven Weingart (Ellen), Diane Weingart, and Wendy Weingart (Perry); beloved grandchildren Rebecca Kaplan, David Weingart (Katherine), and Eric Weingart (Emily). A devoted husband, father and grandfather, he will be missed by family and friends. He enjoyed a successful career as an educator with the NYC Board of Education, having served as teacher, principal, member of the Board of Examiners and superintendent of District 26 in Queens, NY. He retired in 1987 as Assistant Deputy Chancellor. He went to graduate from Brooklyn Law School, Class of '88, after which he served as a hearing officer and arbitrator for education matters. His greatest pleasure was to travel with his family, surrounded by those he loved and who loved him. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Forest Hills at 10am, February 14, 2008.

BARR--Irving. Died peacefully on February 11, 2008 at home in West Palm Beach, FL at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Miriam; father of Richard (Linda), Cantor Kathy (Ed Weissman) and Jeffrey; proud grandfather of Johanna and Abby, Sara and Nora Fantry, Lizzie and Jacob; devoted brother of Edith Panzer and the late Frances Arbitman; uncle of Michael Arbitman, the late Leslie Weingarten, David, the late Jonathan, and William Panzer, and their spouses, children and grandchildren; beloved cousin; treasured friend and colleague to an enormous array of people, all of whom, like his family, were treated to his very special blend of love, kindness, generosity, good humor and insight. Irving was deeply committed, from his youth, to ideals of a just society. This world view, from which he never wavered, was an inspiration to his family. President of Paris Lace, Inc. until his retirement at 85, it was his great good fortune to enjoy a fulfilled life and robust health almost to the last of his days. Memorial celebrations will be held in West Palm Beach on Wednesday February 20, and in New York at a later date.

MYERS--Rem Van Aiken, of Southbury, CT, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, NY, died February 12 of natural causes. Born in 1916 in East Orange, New Jersey, Mr. Myers attended Princeton University and graduated from Brooklyn Law School. He practiced law for 40 years, primarily with the Huntington law firm of Toaz, Buck. Mr. Myers was predeceased by his wife, the former Marion Parker, in 2005. Survivors include four children; Marion M. Johannsen of Wellesley, MA; Stephen G. Myers of Wantagh, L.I.; Phyllis P. Hewitt of Falmouth, Maine; and Rem V. Myers Jr. of Swampscott, MA; 13 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

Types of Kiss In his 1901 study ''The Kiss and Its History,'' Kristoffer Nyrop, the Danish philologist, attributes to an unknown 18th-century German jurist this splendidly PowerPoint-esque taxonomy of the different varieties of osculation: LAWFUL KISSES A. Spiritual kisses. B. Kisses of reconciliation & peace. C. As customary kisses; partly, a. By way of salutation. 1. At meeting. 2. On arrival. 3. At departure; partly, b. As mark of courtesy. c. In jest. D. As kisses of respect. E. As kisses on festive occasions. F. As kisses of love, between: i. Married people. ii. Those engaged. iii. Parents & children. iv. Relations. v. Intimate friends; or, UNLAWFUL, when they are given: A. Out of treachery or malice. B. Out of lust.

MILLER--Gloria. Gloria Bley Miller, 86, of New York City, died January 17, 2008. She was a beloved friend and a best-selling author. Without fanfare, she gave generously of her time, ingenuity and resources to the people and institutions she valued. Mrs. Miller was born November 12, 1921 in New York City. She received a bachelor of arts degree in art from Hunter College and a masters degree in education from the Bank Street College and had a varied career that included editing, comic book writing, bookkeeping, publicity direction, and occupational therapy, but found her true calling in writing. In 1962, she married the late Richard McDermott Miller, the prominent sculptor, and they enjoyed a loving and mutually supportive marriage until his death in 2004. Mrs. Miller's classic The Thousand Recipe Chinese Cookbook, published in 1966, remains in print. Craig Claiborne wrote that it should be treasured by anyone with a serious interest in the Chinese cuisine and named it to his Recommended Cookbook Library. She wrote or collaborated on several other books, including, with her dear friend Freddie Mae Baxter, The Seventh Child in 1999, and was at work on her latest, her own memoir of her friendship with the writer Grace Paley, at the time of her death. Mrs. Miller traveled extensively throughout her life and collected art and crafts from around the world. She was a fixture in her West Village neighborhood and in her beloved Chinatown, which she visited weekly to shop and eat. She was a benefactor to several non-profits, but especially valued the Authors Guild, of which she was a member since 1977. Her friends loved her for her kindness, humor, intelligence and loyalty, and they miss her tremendously. A memorial service will be held at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd St., NYC on March 19th at 5pm. In lieu of flowers a donation can be made to the Authors Guild Foundation (31 East 32nd Street, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10016).

Fernando and Humberto Campana, Brazilian brothers who run a design studio in São Paulo, are known for weaving recycled objects like stuffed animals and garden hoses into furniture. For a show opening Thursday at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, they were asked to assemble a selection of woven or weaving-related antiques from the museum's collection. ''We spent two days at the museum looking through everything from the most precious, detailed handcraft to the most banal and ordinary objects,'' Fernando Campana said. Forty-four objects, including Victorian hair jewelry, an 1880s armchair made of steer horns, above, and 1920s prints of insects with intertwined legs, will be shown along with the prototype for a new Campana chair -- ''a nonserious criticism of the loss of the wicker-making tradition,'' Mr. Campana said, created by wrapping dried vines around plastic objects retrieved from the trash. Through Sept. 28 at 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 or cooperhewitt.org.EVE M. KAHN

O'BRIEN--James Michael, longtime resident of Larchmont, NY, died on January 10, 2008, in Poughkeepsie. Son of the late James and Honora Moran O'Brien, he was born on January 29, 1934, in the Bronx. He is survived by his daughters Lauren and Suzanne, their mother Ellen, his sisters Margaret and Eileen, and his three grandchildren. Prior to his retirement, he was a distributor for American Greetings. He was a selfeducated man and a voracious reader. He especially enjoyed the New York Times crossword puzzles and obituary section.

Casa Del Bianco, a linen store owned by former Frette employees, now runs a studio favored by designers for its custom-made sheets. To match a headboard, Bunny Williams designed a set of sheets with a garland motif ($1,400), top. Diane Paparo, another designer, created a pattern called Hydra, above, for clients with a Zen-like décor ($1,730 a set). Casa Del Bianco produced both using hand-guided machine embroidery, which works for everything but asymmetrical patterns. Machine embroidery starts at $700 a set, but ''you cannot do flowers, leaves or scrolls,'' said Fabrizio Biasiolo, an owner. Hand embroidery can replicate anything, he said; it starts at $1,700 a set. Casa Del Bianco, 866 Lexington Avenue (65th Street), (212) 249-9224. ELAINE LOUIE

EVEN though many of the new fabrics at the recent Maison et Objet home furnishings trade show outside Paris were in neutral colors, there was nothing bland about them. Some, especially those made for curtains and draperies, were embellished with texture. They were puckered, smocked, scrunched or appliquéd; some were punctuated with metallic threads that created a sheen. 1. Flowers sewn onto a wispy silk organza, called Nymfa and designed by Ulf Moritz for Sahco, a German company, make it look fluffy; $470 a yard (to the trade) from Bergamo, (914) 665-0800 or bergamofabrics.com for showroom locations.

TOMAL--George, one of New Jersey Ballets founding directors, passed away on February 11 after a long illness. He was 83. Tomal danced with American Ballet Theatre, Roland Petits Ballet, Igor Schwezoffs Ballet Concerts Company and New Jersey Ballet. He choreographed more than 100 dance works for NJB including 16 operas and the company's production of Nutcracker, now in its 38th season. Mr. Tomal leaves a brother, Carl, sisterin-law Rose and niece Ann Marie, all of Chicago. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New Jersey Ballet, 15 Microlab Road, Livingston, NJ 07039.

PETERSON--Aubrey Weymouth, 70, of East Hampton, New York, beloved husband of Elizabeth Telfer Harbison, father of Aubrey Hawley Peterson, Erik Baekeland Peterson and Oliver Weymouth Peterson and brother of Karen Peterson Earle. He died at home in East Hampton surrounded by his family. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Born in Flushing, New York, the son of Arnold Hawley Peterson and Medora Weymouth Peterson, he attended Buckley Country Day School in Great Neck, graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1955 and Yale University in 1959. He served in the U.S. Army reserve for six years. He was the grandson of Marie Peterson and Andrew Herman Peterson, who was captain of the racing schooner Atlantic that held the west to east record across the North Atlantic from 1905 to 2005, and of Alice Weymouth and Aubrey Weymouth, who was the structural engineer for many of the great New York City skyscrapers including the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building. He was a descendant of Frank Marion, the Revolutionary War Swamp Fox. He worked as a shipping broker in New York City for twenty years. In 1986, he moved with his children and former wife, Paula Minnick, to East Hampton where he became a real estate agent. In 1992 he joined Dunemere Associates, now Brown Harris Stevens. He was devoted to Phillips Exeter where he served in alumni positions as well as on the Board of Trustees as President of the Alumni Association. He treasured his education at Exeter and the friends he made there. He was a member of the Maidstone Club in East Hampton and the Yale Club of New York. He will be remembered for the love he gave to his family and friends, his gentle soul, high ethical standards, sense of humor, and independence. He played by the rules. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Aubrey William and Stella Sophia. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 16, at 1pm, St. Luke's Church, East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, Attention Dr. David Ryan, Mass General Hospital Development Office, 165 Cambridge St, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114 .

LANTOS--Tom. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem (HU) are saddened by the passing of Congressman Tom Lantos. As the only Holocaust survivor to serve in U.S. Congress, he will be remembered as a proponent of human rights committed to Israel and the Jewish community. He received an honorary doctorate posthumously from HU for his achievements. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Annette and daughters, Annette and Katrina. The Hebrew University President Menachem Magidor AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman of the Board George A. Schieren, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

A common saying in Mexico about police investigations and government inquiries goes ''no pasa nada,'' or ''nothing happens.'' Investigations often start with great fanfare only to die quiet deaths. The National Human Rights Commission was supposed to change that when it was created in 1990 and given a large budget and staff. But a new report by Human Rights Watch says Mexican officials regularly ignore the commission's findings or begin investigations that go nowhere.

E-mail messages and phone records led detectives to a Pennsylvania man who was questioned for eight hours and then released as part of the investigation of the killing of an Upper East Side psychologist, Kathryn Faughey. The man, William Kunsman, had met Dr. Faughey and her husband at a guitar camp six years ago and had recent contact with her via e-mail, according to Al Baker. While newspapers observed that Mr. Kunsman had little resemblance to the man in the videotape (Mr. Kunsman appeared to have a full head of hair, while the killer had a bald spot), he had been identified in a picture lineup by Dr. Faughey’s colleague, Kent D. Shinbach, a psychiatrist who was in the office during the murder and was critically injured. A patient who was in the office and tried to stop the assailant as he was leaving did not identify Mr. Kunsman.

Standing in front of the old site of the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in Ozone Park, Queens, you can see a few immediate differences between its appearance now and its appearance when it was home base for the John J. Gotti and his associates in the Gambino crime family. First, the space, at 98-04 101st Avenue, has been divided into two businesses, a medical supply store and a pet groomer, and it looks a lot more welcoming now than it used to. Second, there was some faded graffiti on the front of the building. That is the kind of thing, people in the neighborhood said this week, that would not have flown when Mr. Gotti, who died in prison in 2002, was still around.

Updated, 1:38 p.m. | The morning after the shootings at Northern Illinois University, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rattled off a grim list of gun rampages across the country that have left at least 18 people dead in February alone, not counting the gunmen who in some cases killed themselves or were killed by police. Mr. Bloomberg’s comments on his weekly radio call-in were part of his crusade to get illegal guns off the streets.“This month John, so far, has just been wretched,” the mayor told John Gambling, his host on WABC-AM (770). He said he had asked his press secretary, Stu Loeser “to get me a list of things that occurred just this month alone. Yesterday, Northern Illinois University, six people, another one died this morning, six people killed. Last Friday in Baton Rouge, a college student shot and killed two people then took his own life. Last Thursday, a gunman shot and killed five people in Kirkwood, Mo., in the City Hall, killed two City Council members and two police officers, and the mayor was very seriously wounded, and he’s hanging in there. And Feb. 2, just a week ago, in the Lane Bryant store in Illinois, a gunmen shot and killed five customers and employees, all in their 20s and 30s.” (The Lede blog has a list of recent campus rampages.)

The University of Michigan consumer sentiment index plunged today, to a 16-year low. But as I go over the details, I find some contrary indications to the gloom and doom that has become so prevalent.

OK, not really. But the plunge in consumer confidence in recent weeks is pretty startling. The chart below shows the University of Michigan index; consumer confidence is now lower than it ever was during the 2001 recession and aftermath, and close to its worst levels during the early 90s, when the unemployment rate went well above 7 percent.

This week's guest blogger is the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. Sagmeister is known for his stunning and original approach to the design of album art, magazine spreads, advertising and installation works. He often takes a renegade, D.I.Y. approach to type; in 1999 he made a poster by photographing words he had scratched onto his torso. (His design for the Talking Heads box set earned him a Grammy award.) Sagmeister's work as been exhibited around the world; his current solo show, "Things I have Learned in my Life so Far," is showing at Deitch Projects in New York. Stefan's book, by the same name, will be in stores next Tuesday. To read all of Stefan Sagmeister's prior blog posts, click here.

Michael Cieply reports that Sid Ganis, president of the Academy, and Gil Cates, the producer of this year's show, are wiping the flop sweat out of their eyes after months of wondering whether they were going to have to come up with a work-around and are now full steam ahead with Plan A. And there will be no shortage of A-Listers.

Awards Daily points us to AOL, where people are voting their little hearts out. It turns out that "No Country," the presumptive favorite so far this year, has pulled ahead of "Juno" in the battle for best picture.

The Bagger has to admit that there seems to be a bit of an energy crisis around Oscar town. At this time in the previous seasons, there would be missiles flying back and forth from various camps and people would be genuinely frantic about who was going to win what.

Clive James's most recent book is "Cultural Amnesia."
The artist Cai Guo-Qiang creates a gunpowder drawing.
CNBC interviews Eric Dinallo, New York State Insurance Superintendant, on what he plans to do to overhaul the bond insurance industry.

It has a reputation for being one of the mysteries of international cuisine, but chili paste is really about as easy to make as applesauce. Take dried chilies, soak them until they are soft, combine them with a spice or two (or not) and purée.

Lynn Hirschberg, T Magazine's editor at large, has a remarkable nose for Oscar nods. She plays a featured role in selecting the actors and actresses who will be photographed for the covers of T's fashion issues, then interviews them for the magazine and for T's "Screentest" films. One of her criteria: Is their work in the coming season Oscar worthy? As the 10 covers shown on the new home page of our mothersite, nytimes.com/tmagazine, show, she's frequently right. Among the T talent hoping for gold at the Hollywood ceremony on Sunday Feb. 24 are Marion Cotillard and Tilda Swinton. Good luck, ladies.

Partisan Democrats may suspect his motives, but Newt Gingrich sounds sincere when he calls, on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, for a "do-over" in the Democratic primaries in Florida and Michigan.
Ben Bernanke has cut interest rates a lot since last summer. But can he make a difference? Or is he just, as the old line has it, pushing on a string?
Trista Baldwin’s three-actor play about American soldiers in an unnamed war zone exposes the difficulty of writing freshly about war.

Watching "There Will Be Blood" in his bubble, unable to hear every word of dialogue or note of Johnny Greenwood's much-lauded contemporary soundtrack, was a bit of a revelation to the Bagger. The experience helped explain why he was never knocked down by this movie like other, more learned colleagues.
Is there anything they can’t do? That is the question after watching the multitalented cast of “Traces” for 90 intermissionless minutes.
Three of the top four presidential candidates will campaign across Wisconsin today, all hitting Milwaukee at some point, ahead of the state's Tuesday primary.
The American premiere of Lars Noren’s “War” offers clues to why the Swedish playwright is hardly known here.

Bear Stearns and Citic Securities, China's largest investment bank, are discussing a "reciprocal adjustment" of the stake-swap deal they negotiated in October, when Bear's stock was much higher, The Financial Times reported Friday, citing a person familiar with the matter. Under the new terms, Citic's stake in Bear is likely to reach 9.9 percent, up from 6 percent under the October agreement.
Citigroup has barred investors in one of its hedge funds from withdrawing their money, and a new leveraged fund lost 52 percent in its first three months, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

Shares in UBS fell again on Friday as fears of more massive losses mounted after equity analysts at Citigroup said UBS could need up to $18 billion in additional write-downs in 2008, Reuters reported.

United Airlines is in advanced negotiations to combine with Houston-based Continental Airlines and is poised to quickly seal a deal if Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines merge, The Chicago Tribune reported.
Medical device maker Avedro has raised an $8 million round of venture capital funding, according to a federal filing.

The Carlyle Group has promoted 30 executives to senior positions in the company, eight to managing director - the most senior role below those of senior adviser, founder and chairman - and 22 to director.

Where is it written that new-media leviathans shall have benign-sounding if not silly names? There's Microsoft, Yahoo, Google and now, with the prospective combining of the first two, quite possibly Microhoo -- yes, if the media have their way. Brings to mind the giant Stay Puft Marshmallow Man ravaging New York at the end of "Ghostbusters," doesn't it? Some recent indicators:

As Macrovision seeks to shore up support for its $2.8 billion Gemstar-TV Guide acquisition, the company announced on Thursday that it is selling its software business to a unit of private equity firm Thoma Cressey Bravo.

Cerberus Capital Management's Stephen Feinberg said in a letter to his fund's investors that GMAC, the auto and mortgage lender that it controls, may run into "substantial difficulty" if credit markets don't improve, Bloomberg News reported.

In what amounts to a rerun of sorts, Hollywood producer Oren Koules is again on the verge of purchasing pro hockey's Tampa Bay Lightning four months after the original deal he was a part of fell through.

As scads of firms are pulling their initial public offerings due to volatile market conditions, yet another special purpose acquisition vehicle continued merrily on its way to market. The I.P.O. of GHL Acquisition Corporation, backed by the boutique merger advisory firm Greenhill & Company, priced late Thursday at $10 per unit, raising about $400 million before commissions and discounts.

The Mets' pitchers and catchers reported to spring training Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Florida. Ben Shpigel, The New York Times's Mets beat writer has been there for a few days, updating fans here on the Bats blog and in The Times's baseball coverage.

Someone well acquainted with the trading controls at Société Générale told The New York Times that it was "inconceivable" that Jérôme Kerviel's immediate supervisors were not alerted after his trades set off alarm bells at Eurex, the derivatives exchange based in Frankfurt.

Fly Aeroflot? Are you kidding? At least that used to be my reaction. The very name was enough to induce fear of flying. It wasn't so much for safety concerns - although that was a factor in the 1990s after a pilot allowed his children to take a spin at the controls, prompting his Airbus to crash in Siberia. Historically, the general chaos and surliness of the carrier and its staff were unsurpassed.

Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Valentine's Day started out as an ancient Roman fertility festival. What would happen is a young nobleman would charge through the street naked, striking people with a leather thong for good luck. It is like a party at Elton John's house.

The Northern Illinois University shooting rampage joins a string of similar incidents to hit the headlines in recent years -- one of them less than a week ago.

Top-seeded James Blake beat Paul Capdeville of Chile, 6-1, 6-4, to become the sixth American to reach the quarterfinals of the Delray Beach International in Florida. Blake joined third-seeded Sam Querrey, sixth-seeded Vince Spadea, eighth-seeded Mardy Fish, the wild-card entrant Robby Ginepri and Bobby Reynolds as second-round winners. The last time six Americans reached the quarterfinals at an ATP event was at Memphis in 2003.

The Florida State football squad will join other university sports teams on self-imposed probation for two years, and some students will lose scholarships due to an academic cheating scandal. The university said in a report that about 60 student-athletes have lost or will lose some eligibility. Two staff members have been fired. The cheating occurred mainly through online testing for a music history course in the fall of 2006 and the spring and summer semesters last year.

An obituary on Feb. 6 about Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, who introduced transcendental meditation to the West and gained fame as the spiritual guru to the Beatles, described incorrectly those who may bear the title of Maharishi, Hindi for “great seer,” and misstated his own eligibility for it. The title may be bestowed on people of any caste, not only Brahmins. He was not ineligible because he was from a lower caste.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about government assistance for a struggling German bank, IKB Deutsche Industriebank, misstated part of the name of a political party that has criticized the rescue effort. It is the Christian Democratic Union, not the Christian Democratic Party.

A sports article on Wednesday about cockfighting in the Dominican Republic referred imprecisely to the legal status of the practice in the United States. Although all 50 states have voted to ban cockfighting, it is not yet illegal in all of them. (Cockfights can continue in Louisiana until the state’s prohibition takes effect in August.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about voters in Virginia in the lead-up to the Democratic primary that day misstated the distance between Lexington and Roanoke, two cities in the state where Senator Barack Obama was receiving strong support from young people. They are about 45 miles apart, not 100.

An article on Tuesday about efforts to find the source of fake ingredients in Chinese antimalarial medicine misstated the official name of the geographic area of southern China where Guilin Pharmaceutical, a company that discovered the fakes in 2006, is based. It is the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous region; there is no Guangxi “Province.”.

An article on Monday about efforts by the operators of E-ZPass in New York to track down highway toll evaders referred incorrectly at several points to the technology used to identify and match E-ZPass tags as a car passes through a lane. The tags are identified via radio frequencies, not optical scans.

An art review in Weekend last Friday about “Jasper Johns: Gray,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, referred incorrectly to the orange, green and purple in the painting “Céline.” They are secondary colors (made by mixing primary colors), not tertiaries (made by mixing secondary colors).

A film column on Thursday about the Film Comment Selects series, at the Walter Reade Theater, misstated the given name of the director whose films “10 Rillington Place” and “Mandingo” will be shown. He was Richard Fleischer, not Robert.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about cellphone trends misstated the title of Daniel Moloney of Motorola, who commented on competition in the industry. He is president of the company’s home and networks mobility business, not its cellphone business.

A headline in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about a lawsuit filed against New Line Cinema by heirs of the author of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy misspelled the author’s surname in some editions. He was J. R. R. Tolkien, not Tolkein.

An article on Monday about the sentencing of Army Sgt. Evan Vela to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee described his relationship to the Army Rangers imprecisely. While he graduated from Ranger school and earned the qualifications to serve with the Rangers, he was not assigned to a Ranger battalion at the time of the incident or sentencing and therefore was not considered an Army Ranger.

Adam Sandler is in big, big trouble. Or at least he should be, if not for ''50 First Dates,'' then surely for influencing what will become the legacy of young comics working in the new millennium: the Ridiculous Song. Oh, what ''Put on your yamulke!/It's time for Hannukah!'' has wrought. If I were to engage in some speculative biography, I'd say that the five young men who make up the Whitest Kids U'Know, a comedy troupe with a new sketch show bearing its name (Sundays on IFC), grew up on Mr. Sandler's dopey, brilliant cultural-pride lyrics and thought: ''Law school? No stinking way!'' The Ridiculous Song is an art form with certain conventions, and the cast members are obsessed with it even if they don't always abide by the rules.

MEET THE OSCARS When Gary Cooper took the stage 66 years ago to accept an Oscar for portraying a reluctant war hero in ''Sergeant York,'' he had little to say. First he credited the person he had depicted on screen, then followed with an economical 34 words: ''Shucks, I've been in the business 16 years and sometimes dreamed I might get one of these things. That's all I can say. Funny, when I was dreaming, I always made a good speech.'' Then he walked off the stage, accidentally leaving his trophy behind. Starting Friday at noon, you can try to one-up Mr. Cooper with an Oscar acceptance of your own. His statuette, the one that Thelma Schoonmaker was awarded last year for her editing of ''The Departed,'' and dozens of others have made their way to New York as part of the ''Meet the Oscars'' display at Times Square Studios, an exhibition that ends with a podium and the chance to pose with an Oscar.

LEE--Morris, R. The Board of Directors of the HIP Health Plan of New York is deeply saddened by the death of Morris R. Lee, a friend and colleague, after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and resided in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. We will miss his sound advice and cheerful personality in service to the board and to HIP members since 1991. He was born and raised in Tuscaloosa. After serving in the United States Air Force for 10 years, Mr. Lee and his family came to New York and settled in Cambria Heights, Queens, NY in 1968. He earned a B.A. and Masters Degree in economics from Queens College. Mr. Lee served on the board of the Health Systems Agency of New York City. Active in many community activities, He was a founding member of the Cambria Heights Kiwanis Club; served as treasurer of the Queens County Overall Economic Development Corporation; vice president of Community Planning Board #

'DON JUAN' Yehuda Duenyas plays the great seducer in this latest iteration of the 17th-century Molière play, as envisioned by the Obie Award-winning National Theater of the United States of America. It may be the way Mr. Duenyas, above, hops about and gurgles with glee after a conquest. Or maybe it's his mildly crazed eyes, or the pale, flat expanse of his stomach, which seems to be entirely muscle free. Whatever the reason, he's irresistible, as is the play. It is possible that you, an ardent New York theatergoer, are not aware that this great country possesses a national theater company, just as it is within the realm of possibility that you have yet to visit the Chocolate Factory, in Long Island City, Queens, where ''Don Juan'' is running. You might be forgiven for such oversights, as both the troupe and the theater are only a few years old. No matter. Now is your chance to make amends.

MODELL--William D. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the passing of our beloved Chairman of the Board. Bill Modell was more than a brilliant businessman; he was an enlightened leader who not only created the largest, privately owned sporting goods chain in America, but created a business environment that respected and cared for all its associates. Bill's word was his bond and his integrity was legend. He encouraged the best in each of us and mentored the careers of many. By example, he taught us to care for our city, our country and our fellow citizens. With unquenchable optimism and humor, he worked tirelessly to heal the suffering of others through philanthropic work. He was deeply committed to Gilda's Club New York and Worldwide, which he helped to found, and raised millions of dollars for research, especially for the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. When our co-president and his son, Michael, died, he took up the reins and led us with unassuming courage. Throughout his own painful battle with cancer, he continued to work for Modell's and for the many research foundations that he co-founded. With kindness, dedication and goodwill, Bill made our world a better place in which to live. Our friend and colleague has been taken from us, but the inspiring legacy of his life will remain with us forever. The Officers and Associates of Modell's Sporting Goods MODELL--William D. The love of my life is gone. We began our journey together with laughter. Now it has ended in tears. My precious, beloved husband devoted his life to me, our children and grandchildren, and his sister and brother-in-law and gave us the most precious gift of all, his love. He became a legend in his own time, building Modell's Sporting Goods into the largest, privately owned sporting goods chain in the country. His brilliant business acumen earned him many honors and awards. Yet, his greatest pleasure was seeing all those he mentored succeed in their careers. During World War II, he proudly served in the Army's Ninth Air Corps and continued to serve his country and New York City throughout his life, as a member of the negotiating committee for the Panama Canal Treaty under President Jimmy Carter, as New York City's Commissioner of Public Affairs for Mayor Abe Beame, and as a founding patron of the Metropolitan Opera House and Lincoln Center for Performing Arts. Though he met world leaders, celebrities and many of America's greatest athletes, he was at heart a down-toearth man, who cared deeply about his family, friends, and . Associates. A humble and gentle man, he helped countless individuals in their time of need. He was the founder of American Digestive Disease Society, a co-founder of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation for Immunological Research and the Hewlett House for breast cancer survivors, and was especially dedicated to Gilda's Club of New York and Worldwide which he helped found. No cause meant more to Bill than finding a cure for Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. In 1967, when our son Michael was diagnosed with Crohn's disease, he co-founded the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and raised many millions of dollars for research. Bill never realized his dream to find a cure, and we lost our darling Michael to complications caused by Crohn's disease six years ago. Yet, despite his unspeakable sorrow, Bill never gave up hope. He continued to raise millions to save others from the suffering that our son endured. For me, his children and grandchildren, his friends, and all those who knew him, Bill was a man who filled the world with his vibrant presence, his compassion and love, his sense of humor, his wisdom and integrity, his quiet courage, and his abundant goodwill. The services will be held on Sunday, February 17, 2008, 11am, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St., New York. I have lost my best friend and partner in life and I am shattered with sorrow. Billy, you were and always will be my soul mate. I will love you and miss you forever. Your Shelby

'READY FOR ACTION!' For a parent Sesame Street Live doesn't have quite the charm of ''Sesame Street'' on television. You lose the intimacy of the close-ups with the cheery characters, and the noise -- including the loud bangs of containers of confetti bursting over the audience's heads -- may make you long for a remote control. But enough Oscar-like grouchiness. None of this seems to bother the energetic toddlers who throng Madison Square Garden every year for the 90-minute live extravaganza. The latest, ''Ready for Action!,'' begins with a topic dear to small children: superheroes. Grover, whose self-description as Super Grover is treated tongue-in-cheek on TV, has lost his ''superness''; when he tries to fly, he collapses in a heap (hilarious if you're under 6). Some of his fellow Muppets -- Telly, Zoe (and her pet rock), Elmo and Rosita -- step in as the Fabulous Five (above, flanking Grover), accepting assignments from the Big Cheese (a talking cheese wedge, of course) until Grover recovers.

National Co-Founders, Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America William D. & Shelby Modell Irwin M. and Suzanne Rosenthal HAGGERTY-BLOHM-Marilyn. The Board of Trustees, Chapter President, staff and volunteers of the Greater New York Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America (CCFA) mourn the passing of our esteemed Executive Director and friend, Marilyn Haggerty-Blohm. Marilyn was a force...a brilliant fundraiser and truly an inspiration to all of us. Her guidance and commitment to our organization and mission made an impact on all who knew her and worked with her. Shelby and Bill Modell, Suzanne and Irwin Rosenthal, National Co-Founders, CCFA Richard J. Geswell, National President Howard L. Swarzman, Greater New York Chapter President Greater NY Chapter Staff and Board of Trustees National Staff and Board of Trustees HAGGERTY-BLOHM-Marilyn. Our hearts go out to Marilyn's husband, John, and to her children, John and Kevin Blohm on the loss of their beautiful wife and mother. We were privileged to know and love Marilyn and deeply mourn her passing. A young woman with great intelligence, sensitivity and outstanding capabilities, Marilyn was quick to offer encouragement and assistance to people of all ages who sought a better quality of life as they faced the terrible consequences of Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis. With effective and dedicated volunteers and Marilyn's Executive leadership, the Chapter remains CCFA's most financially successful. Marilyn was our dear friend upon whom we relied for her excellent judgement. We express our deepest condolences to her husband John and children John and Kevin Blohm.
