RICHARDSON--Joseph Chambers, Jr., age 80. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, March 8, 2008 at 11:00am at Polk Street United Methodist Church with Rev. Marty Hamrick officiating. Private family interment will be held in Llano Cemetery. Funeral services are entrusted to Schooler Funeral Home, 4100 South Georgia, Amarillo, Texas 79110. Proud native son of Texas and descendant of the founders of Chambers County, Texas, Joe was the son of J.C. Richardson, Sr. and Ruby Corley Richardson (deceased). Treasured and cherished husband of 20 years of Susan Dixon Richardson of La Jolla, CA and Amarillo, TX. Joe graduated with the class of 1949 at Texas A&M University with Bachelor of Science degrees in petroleum engineering and mechanical engineering. In 1950 he started his career with Shamrock Oil & Gas Company in Amarillo. In 1961 he formed an oil and gas refining and compressor fabrication company, and in 1968 he co-founded a public oil and gas company which was later merged with Worldwide Energy, Inc. He has been an officer and/or director of several successful public and private energy companies which are NYSE or NASDAQ rated. Joe has been an independent oil and gas producer since 1974. His company, JCR, Jr. Operating, Inc. offices in Amarillo. Serving as a Regent of the Texas A&M University system (1981-1987), he championed the effort to fulfill the mission of a great period of expansion of the engineering sciences. In 1990 the new state of the art Petroleum Engineering building at Texas A&M University was so named the Joe C. Richardson, Jr. Petroleum Engineering Building. Joe was honored in 1989 with the University's Distinguished Alumni Award. He was also past President of the Texas A&M Twelfth Man Association. This distin guished gentleman lived his life with grace, charm, duty and a sense of humor. Joe was a faithful friend and to his family and friends gave anchorage, perspective and direction. An inveterate optimist, he made life richer for all whom he met. Joe's life was an example of devotion, decency, courage and generosity which will be tenderly remembered by his family and many friends. Also survived by his sister Mary Ann Hanson of Fort Worth, daughters Mary Lynn Holder of Fort Worth, Elise Wilkes of Atlanta, GA and son James Smith Dixon of La Jolla, CA; seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild survive him as well as his loyal business associate of 27 years, Cheryl Lee Berg. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions made to either the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. Patrick Hwu, Melanoma Research Fund, P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX, 77210 (1-800-525-5841) or The Joe C. Richardson, Jr. Fund, Acct #
KATI HECK Mary Boone

'NINA IN POSITION' Maybe as fallout from last summer's liberatingly eccentric Documenta 12, we've seen a handful of intriguing and enigmatic group shows in New York this season, spun around opaque themes and designed to generate psychic atmosphere. The persuasive ''Nina in Position'' at Artists Space, organized by Jeffrey Uslip, is the latest. The title, characteristically oblique, is a line in the film ''Point of No Return,'' the American remake of ''La Femme Nikita,'' Luc Besson's cult film about assassination, government surveillance and shape-shifting identities, set in a world -- much like our own, Mr. Uslip suggests -- where amorality rules, and nothing is quite what it seems. Pretty little stainless-steel tabletop sculptures by Marco Rios are cast from beefsteaks. A vivid abstract floor piece, below, by Anya Gallaccio isn't all that abstract: it is made of animal blood poured over salt. A Barkley Hendricks photograph of a Ku Klux Klan gathering was shot, not in the deep South, but in the artist's home state, Connecticut.
AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites

'GAUGUIN/SAVAGE LIGHT' Occasionally a musical will find new life through replacement casting. George Fischoff has taken things a step further with his pocket musical ''Gauguin/Savage Light'': he has eliminated the cast entirely. Mr. Fischoff first staged the show, a biographical sketch of the artist Paul Gauguin, in May 2006 with a cast of six and his own piano accompaniment. Last fall he offered a streamlined version with a three-member cast, but two weeks into that run, he said, his leading man left abruptly for another prospect. With no understudy and a performance looming, Mr. Fischoff made a radical decision.

UDEL--Jane Manna, died peacefully at home among family and friends on February 8, 2008. A native New Yorker, Ms. Udel studied at Hunter and Smith Colleges, earning an M.A. in English. Devoted Mother, ardent feminist, erudite reader and poet, she loved politics and music. Mourned by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and sister Eleanor Parker. We will miss her outrage at social injustice, her wonderful sense of humor, and her unfailing compassion.

ADDIS--Bernice, adored wife, mother and grandmother; booklover, crossword puzzle whiz, 85, of Medford, NJ, formerly of Westbury, NY, died on February 13, 2008, at Lankenau Hospital in Wynnewood, PA. Beloved wife and best friend for 65 years to Henry Addis, whom she met at a Valentine's Day dance in wartime, married three months later, and remained ''welded to'' for the rest of her life. She was a devoted mother to Joan Gordon, Paul Addis, and Deborah Madison and a cherished grandmother to Gina Gordon, Victoria, Michael, Claire, and Robert Addis, and Kimberly, Charles, and Emily Madison. One of five sisters, she was predeceased by Eleanor Gordon and Selma Waldman and is survived by Marion Rose and Shirley Chesney. Born on January 20, 1923 in Philadelphia, PA, to the late Samuel and Fannie Chesney, she grew up in Atlantic City, NJ. Bernice was valedictorian at Atlantic City High School. She graduated in 1943 from Mount Sinai School of Nursing in Philadelphia, PA. For many years she worked as an intensive care and emergency room nurse at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, NY, carefully scheduling her hours around her family, for, most important, she dedicated her life to her husband, children, and grandchildren. She instilled in her family a life-long passion for reading, words, and the importance of living a moral and full life. She touched everyone she met with her goodness, warmth, wit, and intelligence. An avid crossword puzzler, she only used ink to complete the weekly New York Times Sunday crossword puzzle. Bernice Addis was an inspiration to her adoring family, and she will live on in our hearts. Relatives and friends are invited Sunday, beginning 10:30am, to Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Rd., Cherry Hill, where funeral services will begin promptly at 11:00am. Interment Locustwood Memorial Park. The family will return to the home of Deborah and Ronald Madison and respectfully requests contributions in her memory be made to the Free Library of Philadelphia, 1901 Vine Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103 or Lankenau Hospital, 100 Lancaster Avenue, Wynnewood, PA 19096.

CARINI--Lillian, on February 11th, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Anne Pidoriano and Peter. Dear sister of Jay Clemente. Proud grandmother of 12 and great-grandmother of 28. Funeral was private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Regina M. McGinn, M.D., Education Center at: Office of Development, 475 Seaview Ave., SI, NY, 10305 are appreciated. (Checks payable to: Staten Island University Hospital Foundation).

FAUGHEY--Kathryn, a woman defined as much by her caring as by her accomplishments, on February 12, 2008. She is survived by her husband Walter, whom she loved and cared for over the twenty-five years of their marriage. She also leaves a tightknit family of six siblings: Kevin, Owen, Mary, Eileen, Michael, Bernadette, their spouses, seven nieces and nephews, and a grand-niece. Kathryn grew up in Sunnyside, Queens and moved to Manhattan where she established her Clinical Psychology practice, after obtaining her doctorate in Psychology from Yeshiva University. Kathryn's choice of career in a helping profession benefitted her patients, to whom she had an unfailing dedication. She was a spiritual person with a wide variety of interests, including music, writing, and art. Her love of the excitement of Manhattan was matched by her love of the beauty of Paris, which she visited often. Anyone who knew Kathryn was truly blessed. She would not want us to lament her death, but to rejoice in her life. Visitation on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Chas Peter Nagel, Inc, 352 East 87th St. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 10am at St. Monica's R.C. Church on East 79th St. between 1st and 2nd Ave. Family requests donations to Cabrini Hospice.

Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been putting on a charm offensive of phone calls and personal visits to woo the undecideds among superdelegates, the 796 elected Democrats and party leaders whose votes may eventually determine the party's nominee. Beyond that, both senators, through their political action committees, have already given some of the elected officials among the superdelegates a considerable sum in campaign contributions. Superdelegates have received more than $890,000 in campaign contributions from Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton in the last three years, according to Capital Eye, a newsletter published by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan group that analyzes campaign finance data.

RYAN BLOTNICK Ryan Blotnick, a guitarist in his mid-20s, plays with a warm tone, a relaxed cadence and a smart but unassuming air. Born and reared in Maine, he made his run at New York only after graduate studies at a conservatory in Copenhagen. (He was the first American to complete the program.) More recently, from a home base in Brooklyn, he has made inroads within the increasingly amorphous zone that now represents the modern jazz mainstream, earning respectful endorsements from John Abercrombie and Ben Monder, guitarists whose thoughtful styles he has effectively absorbed. On his engagingly pensive debut, ''Music Needs You'' (Songlines), Mr. Blotnick, above, presents a handful of original compositions for contemporary jazz quintet. He seems to write his music as a means of exploring images or ideas -- in the album notes he describes the opening track, ''Winter Melt,'' as ''a portrait of a sunny February morning through a coffee shop window'' -- but the results don't feel plotted or excessively conceptual. There's a sense of something natural unfolding as he and his band mates, notably the alto saxophonist Pete Robbins, elaborate on his themes. That same feeling is likely to prevail next week, when he celebrates the album's release in the company of Mr. Robbins, the pianist Jacob Sacks, the bassist Eivind Opsvik and the drummer R. J. Miller.

SASSA--Shigeru. The Rockefeller University community mourns, with deep sadness, the loss of our distinguished colleague and beloved friend Shigeru Sassa. A biochemist, cell biologist, and physician, Dr. Sassa made important contributions to understanding heme, a pigment that gives blood its red color, carries oxygen, and plays a role in metabolizing drugs and environmental chemicals. His work led to major advances in the diagnosis of heme related disorders, such as lead poisoning and the porphyrias. For more than 30 years, Dr. Sassa was a vital member of our community, and he held a number of key positions at The Rockefeller University Hospital. He also served as the University's ambassador to Japan, graciously helping to initiate and strengthen our ties with colleagues in Japanese academic institutions and corporations. We will miss this man of great talent and integrity, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Reiko; his son, Osamu; and his daughter, Junko. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell L. Carson, Chairman Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Attallah Kappas, Sherman Fairchild Professor Emeritus

There was a time - in distant history to you and me, but to those who lived through that time very much a modern one - when, with nothing more than quill, parchment, gaslight and inkwell, Victorians, as they were called then, who thought themselves clever enough to take up the mighty yoke of language, crafted marvelous, dignified, soaring, melodic sentences that danced about the periphery of comprehension, through the very soul of the English language, down so many twists and turns and inlets and eddies that a reader, inundated by an onslaught of language as such, would be forced to compose himself and begin the tedious, but ultimately rewarding, process of returning to the start of such a sentence and piecing its meaning together word by word, clause by clause, until said reader felt satisfied and knowledgeable of the material written therein.

Corrections

An article in some copies of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend about the state of public broadcasting misspells the surname of a host whose show is distributed by Public Radio International. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson.

An article in some editions on Thursday about a decision by the owner of the General Motors building in Manhattan to license naming rights for the tower misstated the name of the building where Bloomberg LP has its headquarters. Its official name is 731 Lexington Avenue; it is not named after the company.

A Public Lives profile in some editions on Friday about Michael Winship, the president of the Writers Guild of America East, misstated the purpose of a union vote on Tuesday night. The vote was to decide whether to end the strike; it was not to ratify a contract.

Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Thursday about a new soul food museum in Atlanta referred incorrectly to Smokey Robinson’s Seafood Gumbo, a product on display at the museum. It is frozen gumbo, not a gumbo mix.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column in Weekend on Friday about the response by the Broad Art Foundation to criticism that female and minority artists were inadequately represented in an exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Eli Broad’s private foundation reversed the given name and surname of the foundation’s spokeswoman. She is Karen Denne.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about a British musician who fell down a flight of stairs and damaged his violin, using information from the London newspaper The Independent, misidentified the maker of the violin. He was Giovanni Battista Guadagnini, not Antonio Stradivari. The report also misstated the age of the violin. It is 236 years old, not 290.

Because of an editing error, a classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Meredith Monk, at Symphony Space, misstated the date of the second concert, at which two members of her group will present works of their own. As noted elsewhere in the entry, the concerts were scheduled for Friday night and next Thursday night — not Friday and today.

A picture in some editions last Saturday with a sports article about Trindon Holliday, a world-class sprinter who plays football at Louisiana State University, was published in error. The photograph, supplied by Getty Images, was of Early Doucet, another player — not Mr. Holliday.

HOLLISTER HELPS ITS PARENT Abercrombie & Fitch said that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 9 percent on increased sales from its expanding Hollister chain that cater to teens and its stores for children. The apparel retailer said it earned $216.8 million, or $2.40 per share, for the quarter ended Feb. 2, compared with a profit of $198.2 million, or $2.14 per share, a year ago. Fourth-quarter sales rose 8 percent to $1.23 billion, from $1.14 billion. The year-ago quarter had an extra week. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected profits of $2.36 per share excluding one-time items on revenue of $1.25 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year, considered to be a key indicator of a retailer’s strength, were down 1 percent for the quarter. . (AP).

A Valentine’s Day charity auction at Sotheby’s in New York raised more than $42.5 million to benefit H.I.V./AIDS relief programs in Africa, far above the presale estimate of about $29 million, The Associated Press reported. Organized by Sotheby’s, Bono, Damien Hirst (whose “Where There’s a Will There’s a Way,” above, was among the works sold) and the Gagosian Gallery, the event set sale records for 17 artists, including Howard Hodgkin, Marc Quinn and Keith Tyson, and included pieces by Jasper Johns, Jeff Koons and Ed Ruscha. Proceeds will go the United Nations Foundation and will support programs run by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

The BBC’s historical costume and wigs department has been forced to shut down after a deal to sell the department to a rival props company collapsed, The Times of London reported. The failure of the sale, part of a cost-saving drive, has created a crisis for period-drama productions. The BBC’s costume vault houses about one million outfits and 12,000 hairpieces. But BBC Resources, as the operation is called, has announced that it is shutting down. The costumes and wigs will be moved from London to Oxford and held in storage until their future becomes clear. The shutdown comes after the BBC announced a series of period pieces, including productions of “Tess of the D’Urbervilles” and “Little Dorrit.” A permanent closing would also hit film production. Sofia Coppola’s 2006 film “Marie Antoinette,” which won the Oscar for costume design, used 400 items rented from the department.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday announced the creation of the Samuel H. Scripps BAM Scholarship Fund, for students who pursue a higher education in arts administration, dance or theater. Awards will range from $4,500 to $20,000 and are open to any student who has taken part in the academy’s education program between kindergarten and the 12th grade. Roughly $45,000 will be disbursed yearly. Application details are at bam.org.

The estates of some of American music’s biggest names, including Count Basie, Benny Goodman and Sarah Vaughan, have sued Universal Music Group for more than $6 million, claiming the company cheated them out of royalties, The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, which was also filed on behalf of some living artists, asserts that the company withheld record royalties, engaged in self-serving schemes with record clubs and suppressed payments from Apple’s iTunes and other digital distributors. The court papers accuse Universal of breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment. The 14 plaintiffs are Patti Page, Tony Martin, Dick Hyman, Richard Hayman, Kitty Kallen and the estates of Basie, Goodman, Vaughan, Woody Herman, Les Brown, the Mills Brothers, Jerry Murad, Frankie Laine and the gospel singer Sister Rosetta Tharpe. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, says Universal has been using questionable accounting practices since at least 1998. “We believe that these claims are baseless, and we are confident that we will prevail in court,” said Peter Lofrumento, a spokesman for the Universal Music Group.

Tom Scholz, the chief songwriter and founder of the band Boston, has written to Mike Huckabee, complaining of his use of the group’s 1976 song “More Than a Feeling” in his presidential campaign without permission, The Associated Press reported. A former band member, Barry Goudreau, has played the song with Mr. Huckabee at campaign events. Mr. Scholz, who supports Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, for president, objects to the implication that the band has endorsed the candidacy of Mr. Huckabee, a Republican. “You have taken something of mine and used it to promote ideas to which I am opposed,” Mr. Scholz wrote. “In other words, I think I’ve been ripped off, dude!” In response, Fred Bramante, who was chairman of Mr. Huckabee’s New Hampshire primary campaign, said: “Governor Huckabee plays ‘Sweet Home Alabama.’ Does that mean Lynyrd Skynyrd is endorsing him?”.

Gnarls Barkley, the duo consisting of Danger Mouse and Cee-Lo, has set April 8 as the release date for “The Odd Couple” (Atlantic), the follow-up to its platinum-selling, Grammy-winning 2006 debut album, “St. Elsewhere,” Billboard reported. The two plan to support the album with a summer tour.

The earliest known recording of Allen Ginsberg reading from his epic poem “Howl” has been found at Reed College in Portland, Ore., the British newspaper The Guardian reported. It had been thought that Ginsberg, right, first recorded the work in Berkeley, Calif., in March 1956. But according to The Oregonian, the recently discovered recording was made several weeks earlier. Ginsberg, having hitchhiked to Portland with his fellow Beat poet Gary Snyder in the winter of 1956, gave a reading at a student hostel, the Anna Mann Cottage, that was recorded on a reel-to-reel machine on Feb. 14. The tape was found by John Suiter, a biographer of Mr. Snyder, in a box in the college archives labeled “Snyder Ginsberg 1956.” It contained a 35-minute tape of Ginsberg reading the first section of “Howl” and other poems. The recordings can be heard at reed.edu.

“Survivor: Micronesia” helped CBS draw the most viewers on Thursday night, though ABC fared better with adults 18 to 49. ABC also had the top-rated show, “Lost,” which led at 9 with 13.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “Survivor” won the 8 o’clock time slot with 13.1 million viewers; NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” had 12 million. Trailing “Lost” at 9 were CBS’s “CSI” repeat (11 million) and NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” (9.1 million). NBC tied CBS for second among the 18-to-49 set and tied ABC for second in total viewers. Fox finished fourth over all.

A court has ruled that Jamie Spears, the father of Britney Spears, will retain control over her affairs for about three more weeks, Reuters reported. Mr. Spears was granted temporary conservatorship over his daughter’s affairs two weeks ago when she was in a Los Angeles hospital for psychiatric evaluation. Los Angeles Court Commissioner Reva Goetz has extended that conservatorship, giving Mr. Spears control over her business, finances and some personal affairs until March 10.

Missy and Brittany MODELL--William D., We note with deep sadness the passing of a giant in our industry and mark with profound sorrow the loss of a dear friend. Bill Modell was a brilliant entrepreneur who built a business that was a showplace of ingenuity and creativity. While he established the largest, privately owned sporting goods chain in the country, he created an enterprise that was known for its integrity and honesty, its service to its customers, and its concerns for its associates and employees. Bill was an extremely caring and compassionate individual whose myriad acts of charity and tzedokah are legend. He single handedly raised millions of dollars for numerous charitable causes, most particularly The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America which he founded in memory of his dear son Michael who succumbed to that dreaded disease, and to which he devoted every fiber of his bountiful energy. Bill was a captain of industry and a role model to all who dealt with him in business; a devoted husband to his dear wife Shelby whom he adored; a loving father to his children and grandchildren; and a dear and dedicated friend to all who were fortunate enough to know him. We send our sincerest condolences to his life's partner Shelby; to our dearest friend and business associate, his son Mitchell who carries forward his father's legacy in commerce and kindness, in business and philanthropy, with dignity and grace; his sister Doris; his daughter Leslie and to all the members of the Modell Family who we know will feel an emptiness and a void that has been created by the passing of a very special human being who graced this Earth and all of us with his presence. Bill, we too will miss you greatly. Sol and Esther Werdiger & the entire Outerstuff Family MODELL--William D. A giant of a man and a legend in his own time has left this earth for greener pastures. Our beloved friend ''Billy'' will be remembered always as a maven in the retail business. He represented the best values as a husband, father and grandfather. He was loved and admired by those who worked for him. He was loved and admired by those who did business with him. He was loved and admired by those who knew him. He had a big heart, always willing to help others. Along with his wife, Shelby, they created charitable organizations to help those with disease and those less fortunate. He had a wonderful, dry sense of humor and knew how to put a smile on your face. Our entire family will mourn the loss of this dear, wonderful, loving giant of a man. Our condolences are extended to Shelby, Leslie, Mitchell, Doris, and Bill's entire family. Evelyn and Benjamin Kerr, Carol and John Harrison, and Susie and Michael Kerr MODELL--William D. The love of my life is gone. We began our journey together with laughter. Now it has ended in tears. My precious, beloved husband devoted his life to me, our children and grandchildren, and his sister and brother-in-law and gave us the most precious gift of all, his love. He became a legend in his own time, building Modell's Sporting Goods into the largest, privately owned sporting goods chain in the country. His brilliant business acumen earned him many honors and awards. Yet, his greatest pleasure was seeing all those he mentored succeed in their careers. During World War II, he proudly served in the Army's Ninth Air Corps and continued to serve his country and New York City throughout his life, as a member of the negotiating committee for the Panama Canal Treaty under President Jimmy Carter, as New York City's Commissioner of Public Affairs for Mayor Abe Beame, and as a founding patron of the Metropolitan Opera House and Lincoln Center for Performing Arts. Though he met world leaders, celebrities and many of America's greatest athletes, he was at heart a down-toearth man, who cared deeply about his family, friends, and . Associates. A humble and gentle man, he helped countless individuals in their time of need. He was the founder of American Digestive Disease Society, a co-founder of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation for Immunological Research and the Hewlett House for breast cancer survivors, and was especially dedicated to Gilda's Club of New York and Worldwide which he helped found. No cause meant more to Bill than finding a cure for Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. In 1967, when our son Michael was diagnosed with Crohn's disease, he co-founded the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and raised many millions of dollars for research. Bill never realized his dream to find a cure, and we lost our darling Michael to complications caused by Crohn's disease six years ago. Yet, despite his unspeakable sorrow, Bill never gave up hope. He continued to raise millions to save others from the suffering that our son endured. For me, his children and grandchildren, his friends, and all those who knew him, Bill was a man who filled the world with his vibrant presence, his compassion and love, his sense of humor, his wisdom and integrity, his quiet courage, and his abundant goodwill. The services will be held on Sunday, February 17, 2008, 11am, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St., New York. I have lost my best friend and partner in life and I am shattered with sorrow. Billy, you were and always will be my soul mate. I will love you and miss you forever. Your Shelby MODELL--William. Presidential politics are plenty contentious, but they are nothing compared to band breakups. Mike Huckabee found himself caught in the middle of one this week. In October, Mr. Huckabee and his band, the Capitol Offense, joined a former member of the band Boston, Barry Goudreau, at the Surf Ballroom in Clear Lake, Iowa, for a gig.

He is survived by his loving wife, Arlyne, daughter and son-inlaw Peggy and Steven Kahn, son and daughter-in-law Evan and Debi Mittman; seven grandchildren Jarrod and Jenna Kahn, Jaymee and Rob Hurvitz, Marissa, Tricia and Jayson Mittman; three great-grandchildren Henry, Ava and Jake. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Murray and Gloria Mittman. The funeral will be held in Tamarac, Florida at The Star of David on Wednesday, February 13 at 11:45 am. Shiva will also be observed on Saturday, February 16 from 7 to 9pm and Sunday, February 17 from 4 to 8pm at 101 Cross Ridge Road, Chappaqua, NY. Donations can be made to Foundation Fighting Blindness, P.O. Box 17279, Baltimore, MD 21203-7279 www.fightblindness.org

Senator John McCain will travel to Houston on Monday morning to receive the endorsement of former President George Bush, a Republican official familiar with the plan said. When he was asked if this was a sign that the Republican Party is rallying around his candidacy, Mr. McCain replied: ''I hope so, because former President Bush is one of the more respected, most respected, people in our party. He is certainly maybe the finest gentleman in our party in the view of one and all. He's a great man, a great American hero going all the way back to World War II, so I'd be honored to be in his company at any time.'' (And, in addition to a broad grin, he allowed himself a wink.)

Levon Brooks, who was serving life in prison for raping and murdering a 3-year-old girl in Noxubee County in 1990, was released from prison, two weeks after the arrest of a man, Justin A. Johnson, who confessed to that crime and the similar rape and murder of a young girl in 1992. The unraveling of the case against Mr. Brooks began after a DNA test showed that the man convicted in the 1992 case, Kennedy Brewer, was not responsible for the rape. A later test showed that the DNA from the rapist matched that of Mr. Johnson. There is no DNA evidence in the Brooks case. Lawyers for Mr. Brooks and Mr. Brewer have argued that both men were the victim of investigators and prosecutors who trumped up evidence against them while ignoring other leads. Officials deny those accusations. All charges against Mr. Brewer were dismissed, seven years after the DNA test that cleared him.

A chart in some editions on Feb. 6 about possible nominees for vice president referred imprecisely to the work that one of them does now. Tom Daschle, a former senator who has been a mentor to Senator Barack Obama, is a consultant on public policy in the Washington office of a law firm; he is not a lobbyist.

IRGANG--Joyce Iris, died February 13, 2008 peacefully at Lenox Hill Hospital. Dearly beloved wife of Jay, married 49 years, mother of Mark, grandmother of Caren, Evan, and Jordan, mother-in-law to Orli. She will be missed forever. May her memory be blessed. Funeral Sunday morning at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

ZARIN--Fay Copellman, 88, of Southbury, Connecticut, died Thursday February 14, 2008. She was the beloved wife of Harry Zarin and adored mother of Michelle, Judith, Nancy and Deborah. Mrs. Zarin was born May 28, 1919 in Boston, Massachusetts to Sarah and Jacob Copellman. She was a graduate of Girls Latin School, Simmons College and Case Western Reserve School of Social Work. During her lifetime, Mrs. Zarin worked at several medical institutions in the New York area, including Yale New Haven Hospital, Creedmoor Psychiatric Center and Long Island-Jewish Medical Center. While raising a family and working, she also devoted herself to the Cystic Fibrosis Association, League of Women Voters and Planned Parenthood. She was an early proponent of women's rights and obligations and was a strong role model for her family. Besides her loving husband and daughters, she is survived by her sister-in-law Beverly Zarin, brother-in-law Sol Zarin, sons-in-law Gerald Rosenfeld, Carl Salter and Jeffrey Marqusee, 10 remarkable grandchildren and step-grandchildren and two adorable great-grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. All services are at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Foundation for a SmokeFree America, PO Box 492028, Los Angeles, CA 90049. The Southbury Funeral Home of Munson Lovetere, 235 Main St. North, is in charge of services. To send an online condolence, please visit www.munson loveterefuneralhome.com.

UDEL--Jane Manna, died peacefully at home among family and friends on February 8, 2008. A native New Yorker, Ms. Udel studied at Hunter and Smith Colleges, earning an M.A. in English. Devoted Mother, ardent feminist, erudite reader and poet, she loved politics and music. Mourned by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and sister Eleanor Parker. We will miss her outrage at social injustice, her wonderful sense of humor, and her unfailing compassion.

HAGGERTY-BLOHM-Marilyn. It is with profound sorrow that we acknowledge the untimely passing of Marilyn Haggerty-Blohm, Executive Director of the Greater New York Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. A young woman with great intelligence, sensitivity and outstanding capabilities, Marilyn was quick to offer encouragement and assistance to people of all ages who sought a better quality of life as they faced the terrible consequences of Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis. With effective and dedicated volunteers and Marilyn's Executive leadership, the Chapter remains CCFA's most financially successful. Marilyn was our dear friend upon whom we relied for her excellent judgement. We express our deepest condolences to her husband John and children John and Kevin Blohm. National Co-Founders, Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of Ameica William D. and Shelby Modell Irwin M. and Suzanne Rosenthal HAGGERTY-BLOHM-Marilyn. Our hearts go out to Marilyn's husband, John, and to her children, John and Kevin Blohm on the loss of their beautiful wife and mother. We were privileged to know and love Marilyn and deeply mourn her passing. She was a beloved friend who offered tenderness, compassion, and caring support to our family and to those who suffer with Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis. As the brilliant and dedicated Executive Director of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America's New York Chapter, she helped raise millions of dollars for research to find a cure for inflammatory bowel disease. She faced her own terrible illness with grace and courage and was an inspiration to all who knew her. We will miss her wonderful warmth and friendship and will cherish her memory forever. Shelby, Bill, Leslie, Mitchell, and Abby Modell and the entire Modell Family
BARTH--Edith, 2 - 16 - 1997. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved. Your Family

WEITZNER--Walter H., born June 29, 1920, died February 14, 2008. SASSA--Shigeru. The Rockefeller University community mourns, with deep sadness, the loss of our distinguished colleague and beloved friend Shigeru Sassa. A biochemist, cell biologist, and physician, Dr. Sassa made important contributions to understanding heme, a pigment that gives blood its red color, carries oxygen, and plays a role in metabolizing drugs and environmental chemicals. His work led to major advances in the diagnosis of heme related disorders, such as lead poisoning and the porphyrias. For more than 30 years, Dr. Sassa was a vital member of our community, and he held a number of key positions at The Rockefeller University Hospital. He also served as the University's ambassador to Japan, graciously helping to initiate and strengthen our ties with colleagues in Japanese academic institutions and corporations. We will miss this man of great talent and integrity, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Reiko; his son, Osamu; and his daughter, Junko. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell L. Carson, Chairman Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Attallah Kappas, Sherman Fairchild Professor Emeritus

Another weekend, another shakeup in college hockey. It seems like every week one team either makes a big jump or a steep plunge in its NCAA Tournament standing, and this week was no different. If there's anything everyone is against in these election times, it's "identity politics," a phrase that covers a multitude of sins. Let me start with a definition. (It may not be yours, but it will at least allow the discussion to be framed.) You're practicing identity politics when you vote for or against someone because of his or her skin color, ethnicity, religion, gender, sexual orientation, or any other marker that leads you to say yes or no independently of a candidate's ideas or policies. In essence identity politics is an affirmation of the tribe against the claims of ideology, and by ideology I do not mean something bad (a mistake frequently made), but any agenda informed by a vision of what the world should be like.

Not every migraine has a prologue or "aura," and not every aura is followed by a headache. Nevertheless, these overtures to pain or isolated events are the most peculiar aspect of the illness and may offer insights into the nature of perception itself. As a child I had what I called "lifting feelings." Every once in a while, I had a powerful internal sensation of being pulled upward, as if my head were rising, even though I knew my feet hadn't left the ground. This lift was accompanied by what can only be called awe - a feeling of transcendence.

"August" is about an unwelcome reunion of the Weston family. For those of you who haven't read or seen the play, here's the setup: After the patriarch, Beverly, disappears, his far-flung and largely out-of-touch clan gathers together around Violet, the mother, at the family home in Pawhuska, Okla. As the grown Weston daughters arrive, it's one confrontation and crisis after another. Ivy, the dutiful one who still lives close to home, is having a secret affair with her cousin Little Charles. Barbara and her husband, Bill, are trying to keep their impending divorce under wraps. Karen flies in from Miami with her lowlife fiancé, Steve - and he immediately devotes himself to seducing Jean, Barbara's teenage daughter.

Kelly Pavlik, who holds the World Boxing Council and World Boxing Organization middleweight titles, beat Jermain Taylor for the second time in four and a half months, winning a unanimous decision at the MGM Grand Garden in Las Vegas. An article last Sunday about the trend in New Jersey toward more liberal policies referred imprecisely to measures passed in the state’s capital, Trenton, and in Maryland that address the allocation of electoral votes in the presidential election. The measures would deliver the states’ entire allocation to the winner of the national popular vote if enough states — those with a majority of votes in the Electoral College — agreed to do the same. The measures do not take effect unilaterally.

An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report about tips for preparing a tax return referred incompletely to the limit on claims for refundable alternative minimum tax credits resulting from the exercise of incentive stock options. While it is $5,000 under one calculation method, some taxpayers may claim more than that under a second method if their income is not too high.
Despite a decline on Thursday and Friday over worries about the economy, the stock market gained ground last week.

An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report, about income taxes that must be paid by athletes who travel out of state, misstated the estimated New York tax liability of a hypothetical Boston Red Sox player making $20 million a year who appeared in nine games at Yankee Stadium. It would be about $60,000, not $100,000. (While such a player would be liable for New York State taxes, there would be no New York City tax due.).

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about loan losses at Citibank during the 1990 recession, misstated the history of stock prices for the bank’s parent, then called Citicorp. The stock traded as low as $11.125 in October 1990, not $1.39. After the Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates, the price rose to $15.625, not $2.50, by March 6, 1991; it climbed to $67.25, not $10, by the end of 1995. (The lower prices were for Travelers, a company that later merged with Citicorp.).

The Fair Game column on Feb. 3, about problems at mortgage lenders, misstated the circumstances surrounding a bankruptcy filing related to the home mortgage lending unit of NovaStar Financial. An involuntary petition to force the unit into bankruptcy was filed with the court on Jan. 24 by a creditor who won a $49 million judgment against the unit; the unit did not file for bankruptcy. (On Feb. 7, the judge overseeing the case ruled against the petition.).

CORN--Patricia. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. DUNKAK--William H. Jr. passed away on January 11, 2008 in Scottsdale, AZ. He was born in NYC May 4th, 1926, son of William H. and Gladys Renouard Dunkak. He enlisted in the Navy in 1944 and became an ensign in the US Naval Reserve. He graduated from Yale in 1947. He is survived by dear friend Corrine Brooks, as well as four children and five grandchildren. He retired from Merrill Lynch as Vice President in 1985. He lived in Honolulu for 23 years and Scottsdale since 1991. He endowed a chair in Finance at Bucknell University in his father's name. Private services were held.

JAHN--Dorothy, 84, died peacefully on January 15, 2008. Loving wife of the late Dale Jahn. Surviving are her children Tim, Geoff and Debbie. Graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College. She will be greatly missed and never forgotten. A memorial service will be held at St. Peters Episcopal Church in Bay Shore, NY on February 23rd.
STARR--Lee, died February 7, 2008. He was a good and caring friend. He will always be remembered by Joan.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Feb. 2, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

ANDERSON--Carleton J. Jr., 35 year IBM executive, member of Emmanuel Church, Weston, CT. Born Tulsa, OK, July 6, 1930 to Helen and Carleton Sr. Died after a battle with cancer on February 8, 2008. Survived by Peggy Ann, four children and 12 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Emmanuel Episcopal Church, Weston, CT Whittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk, CT or Wm Stoutenburg Historic Home Site, PO Box 156, Hyde Park, NY 12538.

REDLICH--Mickey. Beloved husband of Fran, father of Wayne and Lynn, grandfather and great-grandfather, died February 14, at age 91. Services 11:45am Monday February 18, Sinai Chapel, Queens 718-445-0300

TEICHMAN--Arthur Harvey, on February 14, 2008, age 821/2. Loving husband of Sylvia, father of Richard Teichman and Beryl Donenfeld (Jack), grandfather of Jeffrey, Jill and Jason. He will be remembered as a kind, compassionate and honest man who loved his family. Service Sunday 1pm at the ''Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

ACKERLEY--James Albert, born on February 26, 1931, in Osceola, Iowa, and died on February 13, 2008 in Floral Park, New York. Beloved husband of Mildred Clegg Ackerley. Cherished dad to the children of his only brother, Leland Drennen Ackerley who died on January 4, 1964: Dr. Mary Beth Ackerley (Alexander Casler) of Tucson, Arizona; Robert Ackerley (Nora) of Houston, Texas; Leland Ackerley (Carmen) of Houston, Texas; and Anne Ackerley (David Lewis) of Riverdale, New York. Beloved father of Margaret Lee Ackerley (Mark Bollinger) of McLean, Virginia. Adored grandfather of Benjamin, Sydney, Eve, Alexis, Andrew, Leland, and Will Ackerley of Houston, Texas; Jack and Juliet Lewis of New York; and James and Caroline Bollinger of McLean, Virginia. A passionate scholar of history, mathematics and literature throughout his life, Jim made his living as an aerospace engineer for the Bendix, Unisys, and Harris corporations. In retirement he was thrilled to create the computer systems for the company founded by his sons, N.F. Smith and Associates International of Houston, Texas. Deeply principled, profoundly loyal, self-effacing and truly kind, Jim was a learned and gentle man in every respect. The family will receive friends on Monday, February 18 from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9:30pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home in Floral Park. A church service will be held on Tuesday, February 19 at 10am at The United Methodist Church of Floral Park. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make donations to The Ackerley Scholars Program, Graceland University, Lamoni, Iowa 50149, a college founded by Jim's great - grandmother, Marietta Walker, in 1895.

RAAB--Harold J., 88, on February 12, 2008, in Berkeley, California. He is survived by his beloved wife Theo, three daughters; Sylvia, Jamie and Victoria, his sons-in-law; Peter Dworkin and Dennis Dalrymple and by four grandchildren he adored; Kate and Meredith Dworkin, and Ian and Lola Dalrymple. He will be deeply missed by his friends and family.

PRENTICE--Grayson I. (Greg), 85, Monroe Township, NJ passed away on February 10, after a long battle with leukemia. He will be greatly missed and never forgotten by his wife Mary, his two children, Evelyn Stubing and husband Rick, and Drew Prentice and wife Cristina. He also leaves behind four grandchildren, Lynn, John, Julia, and Jessica and greatgrandson Tristan. He is also survived by sister, Priscilla Fowler of Canada and nieces and nephews. He received many degrees over the years from American International College, Columbia, and Long Island University and became a beloved educator in the New York School system. Prior to this he served in the Navy during WWII. He will best be remembered for his warm and humorous stories, his many adventures and travels, and his compassion, love, and zest for life. Private memorial service was held.

THE early verdict on the federal economic stimulus plan signed on Wednesday by President Bush is that it will offer mortgage borrowers some relief but less help than industry executives expected when the House of Representatives passed the initial version in January. While the final plan vastly raises the size of a mortgage that a borrower can take out without its being categorized as a jumbo loan, the new limit could be lower than initially proposed.

SPRUCE--Barbara Blue Spruce, ''New Mexico Farm Girl'', dies at 74. Barbara Blue Spruce, a native of Santa Fe, NM and a longtime resident of Staten Island, NY, died recently on Staten Island at the age of 74. Barbara died in the early morning on February 13, after being afflicted with ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease). Barbara, the daughter of Carmel Lujan and Amalia Gomez, was born in Jaconita, NM. After her father died when she was very young, she was also raised by her stepfather, Paul Martinez. Some of her fondest memories were of her life as a ''farm girl'' on her family's farm near El Rancho. Her well-known love of roosters could be traced to the rooster pattern on a favorite childhood dress that was given to her by her uncle. Shortly after graduating from Loretto Academy, Barbara married George Blue Spruce Jr. at the Santa Fe Cathedral and they moved to Omaha, NE where George was attending dental school at Creighton University. After his graduation from Creighton, they lived in Santa Fe, NM, Vallejo, CA and Harlem, MT, before settling on Staten Island in 1960. They were divorced in 1968. Once in New York, Barbara took advantage of all of New York's cultural offerings and shared these with her three children. Barbara began working at the U.S. Public Health Hospital (later Bayley Seton Hospital) in the mid-1960's. She worked as a receptionist, administrative assistant and director of volunteers. With her lively personality and wide range of interests, she was beloved by all the people who came in contact with her at the hospital. She retired in 1999 at age 65. Outside of work, Barbara's many interests included opera and classical music, ballet and modern dance, art, architecture, gardening, sewing, knitting, baking, reading books and newspapers, cutting out articles for family and friends, watching tennis, figure skating, basketball and almost anything on PBS. Barbara loved, and is survived by, her two daughters, Sharon Blue Spruce and Reni Siefer, her son, Duane Blue Spruce, her sister, Gloria Holladay, her brother, Leo Martinez, four grandchildren, Shaylyn and Alli Siefer and Miles and Milena Blue Spruce as well as nieces and nephews. For information about the memorial service, flowers, cards and donations, please contact Marble Collegiate Church (212-686-2770).

ZINGMAN--Rita, 1924-2008. A dedicated wife, mother, grandmother and sister, passed away on February 15 at Peninsula Hospital Center on the same day her late husband, Walter, was buried. Rita Zucker married Walter Zingman in 1955. They started their married life in Brooklyn. In 1960 they moved to the Rockaways where they lived until their deaths. Mrs. Zingman was an avid Mah Jongg and Bingo player. She also enjoyed playing cards and word games with her children and grandchildren. Rita is survived by three children, two daughters-in-law, a sister, and five grandchildren. Contributions to the Walter Zingman Scholarship Fund.

ROSENZWEIG--William. Sutton Place Synagogue mourns the loss of our longtime member and benefactor. A Holocaust survivor who through his strength and intelligence created a beautiful life for his family. Sincere condolences to his beloved wife Frieda and the entire family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Roger Cohen, President ROSENZWEIG--William, on February 15, age 85. Adored husband of 60 years to Frieda. Loving father of Charles and the late Jeffrey, father-in-law of Rya and Lizanne. Devoted grandfather of Jessica, Erica, Steven, Kenny and David. Proud great-grandfather of Zachary. Raised in Czernovitz, then Romania and now Ukraine, William was a Holocaust survivor who was fluent in six languages. He came to New York in 1949 and shortly afterwards founded Fashion Ribbon Company, a textile and intimate apparel company, now active with affiliates in six countries. A generous and active supporter of those in need and of many charitable causes. He was most proudly a loving and generous family man. He will be missed terribly by all who knew him. Services today, 12 noon at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st St., New York, NY.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

MIGRAINE Though migraine causes great suffering for millions of people, there has been much success, in the last decade or two, in understanding what goes on during attacks, and how to prevent or minimize them. But we still have only a very primitive understanding of what, to my mind, are among the most intriguing phenomena of migraine -- the geometric hallucinations it so often evokes. As a child, I was fascinated by patterns, starting with the patterns in our house -- the square colored floor tiles on the porch, the tessellation of small pentagonal and hexagonal ones in the kitchen; the herringbone pattern on the curtains in my room, and the pattern on my father's check suit. When I was taken to the synagogue for services, I was more interested in the mosaics of tiny tiles on the floor than in the religious liturgy.

Q I am an owner in a small co-op in New York City. The building was built in the early 1900s. We need to modernize the elevator, which rides on wood rails. Some elevator companies say we need to replace them with steel rails, an expensive proposition. Others say we don't have to. Who is right? A ''This question comes up frequently,'' said Martin A. Walsh Sr., president of Walsh Associates, an elevator company in Manhattan. Mr. Walsh recommends that wood rails be replaced for a couple of reasons.

What were you are looking at here is different from the ''lingerie dressing'' of seasons past, a formula of satiny slip dress, fishnet stockings, maybe a bit of lace or fur trim, that left little to the imagination and required still less imagination to conjure in the first place. No, the new reveal as proposed by designers as far apart in their thinking as Akris and Rodarte does not trade in those sorts of sexual clichés. It doesn't even have much to do with actual nudity; it merely offers it up as a suggestion. For the Dutch artist Arno Nollen, who took the photographs on these pages, a series of random intimate encounters provided the basis for a book of portraits published in 2004. Those portraits, of ordinary young women on the streets of European cities, are considerably more revealing than what we can show here. But if there were ever a season to re-examine our ideas of what is considered risqué, indecent or even just plain sexy, it is spring 2008. As the New York Times fashion critic Cathy Horyn wrote of the designer Marc Jacobs, whose collections both for his own label and for Louis Vuitton perhaps raised the most eyebrows, ''There is more beauty and modesty in the way Mr. Jacobs exposes a bra strap than you see most days on the subway.'' ALIX BROWNE

RICHARDSON--Joseph Chambers, Jr., age 80. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, March 8, 2008 at 11:00am at Polk Street United Methodist Church with Rev. Marty Hamrick officiating. Private family interment will be held in Llano Cemetery. Funeral services are entrusted to Schooler Funeral Home, 4100 South Georgia, Amarillo, Texas 79110. Proud native son of Texas and descendant of the founders of Chambers County, Texas, Joe was the son of J.C. Richardson, Sr. and Ruby Corley Richardson (deceased). Treasured and cherished husband of 20 years of Susan Dixon Richardson of La Jolla, CA and Amarillo, TX. Joe graduated with the class of 1949 at Texas A&M University with Bachelor of Science degrees in petroleum engineering and mechanical engineering. In 1950 he started his career with Shamrock Oil & Gas Company in Amarillo. In 1961 he formed an oil and gas refining and compressor fabrication company, and in 1968 he co-founded a public oil and gas company which was later merged with Worldwide Energy, Inc. He has been an officer and/or director of several successful public and private energy companies which are NYSE or NASDAQ rated. Joe has been an independent oil and gas producer since 1974. His company, JCR, Jr. Operating, Inc. offices in Amarillo. Serving as a Regent of the Texas A&M University system (1981-1987), he championed the effort to fulfill the mission of a great period of expansion of the engineering sciences. In 1990 the new state of the art Petroleum Engineering building at Texas A&M University was so named the Joe C. Richardson, Jr. Petroleum Engineering Building. Joe was honored in 1989 with the University's Distinguished Alumni Award. He was also past President of the Texas A&M Twelfth Man Association. This distin guished gentleman lived his life with grace, charm, duty and a sense of humor. Joe was a faithful friend and to his family and friends gave anchorage, perspective and direction. An inveterate optimist, he made life richer for all whom he met. Joe's life was an example of devotion, decency, courage and generosity which will be tenderly remembered by his family and many friends. Also survived by his sister Mary Ann Hanson of Fort Worth, daughters Mary Lynn Holder of Fort Worth, Elise Wilkes of Atlanta, GA and son James Smith Dixon of La Jolla, CA; seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild survive him as well as his loyal business associate of 27 years, Cheryl Lee Berg. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions made to either the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. Patrick Hwu, Melanoma Research Fund, P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX, 77210 (1-800-525-5841) or The Joe C. Richardson, Jr. Fund, Acct #

LAST December, after President Bush signed a 35-mile-a-gallon-fuel economy standard into law, General Motors quickly shelved a new V-8 it was designing to replace Cadillac's long-serving Northstar engine. The timing of these developments prompted a flurry of obituaries for V-8 engines, a breed with a reputation for speed, power -- and lately, environmental insolence. But as Mark Twain might have put it, reports of the V-8's death were greatly exaggerated.

WADSWORTH--John (''Jack'') Taylor of Delhi, NY (formerly of Manhattan), passed away on February 9 following complications of lung cancer. Born on February 4, 1940 in New York City, he was the son of the late Robert L. and Elma Taylor Wadsworth. He received his primary and secondary education at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, his bachelors degree from New York University (mathematics) followed by graduate studies at Columbia University (linguistics). He served two years in the Army. Before his retirement, Jack had been an executive with Bankers Trust Company / Deutsche Bank in New York for 35 years. A true Renaissance man, he held positions there first in computer programming, then in finance and, finally, in corporate taxation, ultimately becoming Managing Director and head of the Bank's Tax Department. He was largely self-taught in all these fields. Despite possessing a towering intellect and being extremely articulate, he was unpretentious, giving equal respect to all, from the Chairman of the Board to the most junior employee. He was known for his easy wit, business savvy, dedication, and a mind that was a storehouse of knowledge on virtually every topic under the sun. Jack's devotion to his passions of music, woodworking, gardening, literature, and the wider worlds of the arts and sciences brought him and those around him much enjoyment and enlightenment, and gave him, during his retirement, incredible value as a member of many Delhi area non-profit organizations. He served as president of the Little Delaware Youth Ensemble, Friends of Music, and Delaware County Historical Association, as well as on the board of directors of Honest Brook Musical Festival, Delhi Senior Housing, and the Meredith Dairy Fest Committee. Surviving are his wife of 40 years, Rose Cupaiuolo Wadsworth, three nieces-in-law, other relatives and numerous friends. He was predeceased by a fosterbrother, Theodor Bicos, who is survived by his wife, Maria, and family of Utah. Jack was dearly loved by his wife, his extended family and his friends, all of whom will greatly miss him. A memorial service will be held later in the spring. Contributions in Jack's memory to Little Delaware Youth Ensemble, P.O. Box 206, Oneonta, NY 13820 will be appreciated.

THE NEWS Military prosecutors said they will seek the death penalty for six Guantánamo detainees accused of central roles in the Sept. 11 terror attacks. BEHIND THE NEWS The decision should increase international interest in the case and the troubled military commission system that has yet to begin a trial. The White House says it is confident the charges will survive expected defense arguments that they are based on unreliable statements obtained using harsh interrogation methods. One of the accused, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, above, who has described himself as the mastermind of the attacks, was subjected to waterboarding, considered by many legal authorities to be torture.

RYAN--Dale W. The New York Freudian Society mourns the loss of Dale W. Ryan, beloved colleague and talented clinician. Her energy, sparkle, and loving commitment to patients and friends will be dearly missed. RYAN --Dale Ware, February 14, 2008, after a long and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Born in Chicago, Illinois in 1942, Dale was a graduate of New Trier High School (1960), Vassar College (1964), and Hunter College School of Social Work (1978). She was a member of the International Psychoanalytical Association, the Association for Child Psychoanalysis, and Chair of the Child and Adolescent Psychoanalysis Training Program at the Training Institute of the New York Freudian Society. A truly gifted psychoanalyst, teacher and supervisor, Dale will be profoundly missed by her beloved family, friends, professional colleagues and patients. Dale was married for 44 wonderful years to Peter F. Ryan, who survives her. Also surviving her are her loving children, Paul Ryan and his wife Maria, Kimberly Servin and her husband John, Gregory Ryan and his wife Mary-Shannon, Mason Bragg and Lily Bragg, and five beautiful grandchildren, Kayla, Jane, Julian, Nina and Matthew. A Memorial service will be held at a date to be determined. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Central Park Conservancy.

BARR--Irving. Died peacefully on February 11, 2008 at home in West Palm Beach, FL at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Miriam; father of Richard (Linda), Cantor Kathy (Ed Weissman) and Jeffrey; proud grandfather of Johanna and Abby, Sara and Nora Fantry, Lizzie and Jacob; devoted brother of Edith Panzer and the late Frances Arbitman; uncle of Michael Arbitman, the late Leslie Weingarten, David, the late Jonathan, and William Panzer, and their spouses, children and grandchildren; beloved cousin; treasured friend and colleague to an enormous array of people, all of whom, like his family, were treated to his very special blend of love, kindness, generosity, good humor and insight. Irving was deeply committed, from his youth, to ideals of a just society. This world view, from which he never wavered, was an inspiration to his family. President of Paris Lace, Inc. until his retirement at 85, it was his great good fortune to enjoy a fulfilled life and robust health almost to the last of his days. Memorial celebrations will be held in West Palm Beach on Wednesday February 20, and in New York at a later date.

NEBENZAHL--Paul at 86 of New York, NY passed away on February 16, 2008 of complications from a cerebral hemorrhage and Alzheimer's. Born on August 9, 1921 to Meyer and Ethel Nebenzahl in Far Rockaway, NY, Paul grew up a devoted son and a loyal older brother to Kenneth Nebenzahl. Paul was the grandson of A. Louis Nebenzahl, founder of the Nebenzahl Department Store. Mr. Nebenzahl began his career in advertising at age 16 working as a mail clerk. Self educated after graduating from Lawrence High School, his career was interrupted by his distinguished service as a paratrooper and a member of the SF during WWII. Just before D-Day Mr. Nebenzahl participated in a covert operation led by the French underground to destroy all avenues of transportation available to the German's, thus preventing them from reinforcing the western front. He was decorated for heroism by the United States, France, and China. He retired from advertising as the Chairman of Harrison Services after 56 years in the business. He spent his retirement traveling around the world spending time with his beloved family on Twin Lakes and at the Hodge Podge Lodge, campaigning for the Democratic party, taking gorgeous photographs, volunteering as a docent at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and occasionally enjoying a game of golf. He married Nancy Baar Nebenzahl, deceased, in 1947 and together they raised three children: Marcie, James, and Andrew. He is remembered as the most gracious man with a happy and warm smile. He leaves behind a legacy of great values, intellectual curiosity, political activism, commitment to family, and they hunger for adventure. His greatest gift to his family is the love they have for each other. Mr. Nebenzahl is survived by his children: Marcie Aiuvalasit, James Nebenzahl, and Andrew Nebenzahl, their spouses: Tony Aiuvalasit, Maureen Nebenzahl, and Sue Moulinda, his seven grandchildren: Sharon, Jason, Alethea, Tony, Amelia, Christopher (Bubs), and Adam, his wife, Judith Nebenzahl, his brother, Kenneth Nebenzahl, and sisters-in-law, Jocelyn Nebenzahl and Susan Baar Rose. Funeral services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue at 84th Street on Tuesday, February 19th at 3:30pm. Shiva to follow at the home of James Nebenzahl at 1175 York Avenue, apartment 6D. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Alzheimer's Association.

REEDY--Margaret, beloved mother, cherished grandmother, adored great-grandmother and wife of the late Charles G. Reedy, passed from this world peacefully on February 11, 2008. She was 97. The cause was kidney failure. Mrs. Reedy was born in Brooklyn, NY on April 4th, 1910. Always a New Yorker at heart, Mrs. Reedy resided in Queens, NY and Nassau County, LI before moving to the Leesburg, FL area in 1980. Margaret and Charles were married for over 51 years at the time of his death in 1984. A voracious reader and lively conversationalist, Margaret was most interesting and wonderful company. She was a sought after bridge partner. Politically astute until the end of her long life, she had a knack for picking the winning candidate in most political contests. Mrs. Reedy leaves, to cherish her memory, her daughter Eileen Divone of Tequesta, FL and Ramsey, NJ, son Rev. Gerard Reedy, S.J. of Fordham University, Bronx, NY, two grandsons, Paul Divone of New York, NY and Charles Divone (Caroline) of Great Falls, VA and three great-grandchildren Oliver, Sophia and George. The Mass of the Resurrection was said for Margaret by her son at St. Paul's Catholic Church in Leesburg, FL. If you wish to make a gift in Margaret's memory, please think of the Divone Memorial Fund, Fordham Development, 888 Seventh Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10019 or online at http:// www.fordham.edu.

ROBINSON--C. David FAIA-passed away at his home in Sausalito, CA on February 2, 2008 surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of 43 years to Mary Leonard; devoted father of Annie, Ward and Steven and grandfather of three. Born New York on June 12, 1936, graduate of St Paul's (1953), Princeton (1957, Magna Cum Laude) and Penn (Masters of Architecture, 1965). Captain of the Princeton Ice Hockey and Crew teams. Served in the USMC as a commissioned officer 1958-1961. The renowned architect founded Robinson, Mills and Williams with Matthew Mills and David Williams in 1970; went on to found C. David Robinson Architects in 1997. David had many noted projects to his credit including: Charles Shultz Museum, Temple Emanu-El, San Francisco Cliff House, Center for the Arts Yerba Buena Gardens, San Jose Museum of Art, Cantor Museum at Stanford University and The California Academy of Sciences. With Mary, was an avid collector of 19th century photographs. The National Gallery acquired 150 of their photographs for their permanent collection in 1995. The collection was the subject of ''73 Photographs'' a book he published with The Fraenkel Gallery in 2007. Robinson was a patron of the arts and a discerning and important collector of contemporary art who had a leadership role with many organizations including the SF Art Institute, NEA, UCB Art Museum, SFMOMA, CCAC, SPUR, Friends of Photography, Metropolitan Museum Photo Department (Visiting), and the International Council NY MoMA.

ZINGMAN--Walter I. 1921-2008. A retired New York Times printer, WWII veteran and card-carying member of the ''greatest generation,'' Walter Zingman of Rockaway Beach passed away on February 13 at Peninsula Hospital Center. Zingman began his printing apprenticeship prior to joining the Army where he served in the Medical Corps, including assignments as a ''army medic'' on several merchant ships. Following WWII, he returned to printing and obtained his B.A. at City College. He worked in a variety of printing capacities, concluding his career as a proofreader at The New York Times. His first wife, Esther Remin, passed away in 1952, and he married Rita Zucker in 1955. Walter and Rita have lived in the Rockaways since 1960, where Walter was proud to engage in several community activities. He was an activemember of Seaside Jewish Center and the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, and had served as a little-league coach and volunteer member of the New York City Police Auxiliary. Walter was devoted to his family and his (recently deceased) wife, three children, two daughters-in-law, a sister-in-law, and five grandchildren. Contributions to the Walter Zingman Scholarship fund at The Brooklyn School for Career Development should be sent to his daughter Barbara Silverman, 37 Belmar Drive West, Staten Island, 10314.

George was a retired editor with Met Life and an active volunteer for Channel 13. George leaves behind Lila Cummings, his brother Donald R. Stoddard of Crofton, MD, and many nieces and nephews. STROLLING ALONG THE BEACH AT SUNRISE, JAN. 14, 2008 Gengquan Liao, 26, a student of food sciences at Penn State University, from Guangzhou, China. ''I'm very curious about what's going on outside of China, so I travel a lot; I'm hoping to visit all the corners of the earth someday. I was in Mexico for three weeks, and while I was there I went to Xcaret and swam with the dolphins, I went to Cancún, and I went snorkeling in a cenote, which is like an underground water cave. But I went to Mexico mostly to visit Mayan cultural ruins, which I've been interested in for a long time. Several years ago, I went to Cambodia to see the ruins at Angkor Wat, and after I went back to China I realized that there were actually three places in the world with these kinds of pyramid ruins: Cambodia, Mexico and Egypt. I'm going to visit all of them one day.'' As told to Austin Considine

BROWN men's shoes, popular with the aristocracy in the 1930s, when they were championed by the Prince of Wales and Hollywood movie royalty, are being revived in Manhattan. After World War II, the conventional black shoe returned, except among upper-class European men, who continued to wear brown suede wingtip styles with their business suits. The Italian industrialist Giovanni Agnelli popularized this Continental style of brown shoes in many shades, highly polished to achieve an aged patina. Today the shoes are worn with business suits and casual weekend blue jeans.

HAFT--David J., 85, a philanthropist and father of four passed away peacefully at his home after a long battle with Parkinson's disease on February 10, 2008. Born in New York to Fannie and Morris Haft, he attended Syracuse University and served in the Army Air Corps as a pilot in the Pacific on Saipan and Iwo Jima. David was President of House of Swansdown, a New York women's ready-to-wear manufacturing business. In 1966 he moved to London to work in motion pictures and television production on a corporate level. David invested in real estate in London, New York and California. After marrying Roberta in 1973, the family moved to Beverly Hills, California. David enjoyed tennis, skiing, world travel and supporting the Arts and Medicine. He was the Founder and President Emeritus of The UCLA Center on Aging, where he was the recipient of the ICON Award. He served as a Board Member of the Mattel Childrens Hospital at UCLA and past Chairman of the Louis B. Mayer Foundation. David loved the arts and served as past Chairman of the Board and President Emeritus of the Center Theatre Group (Ahmanson Theatre, Mark Taper Forum) and was a Former member of the Board of Governors of the Los Angeles Music Center and Music Center Operating Company. He was a Trustee at Syracuse University, on the Board of Governors of the Tel Aviv Museum and past member of the Rotary Club, Beverly Hills Chapter. David is survived by his children, Amanda, Claudia, David and Derrek, his grandchildren, Alexis, David, and Shannan and his former wife, Roberta. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The UCLA Center on Aging (310) 794-0676. 10945 Le Conte #

GLENN--Jules, M.D. Clinical Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry of the New York University School of Medicine and former president of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York, the Long Island Psychoanalytic Society, and the Association for Child Analysis, died of multiple myeloma February 13 in Nashua, NH. He was 86 years old. Dr. Glenn, a psychoanalyst, practiced in New York City and Great Neck, New York, for more than 50 years before retiring to Nashua three years ago. Upon his retirement, the NYU Psychoanalytic Institute cited him for his ''commitment to educating and inspiring a new generation of psychoanalysts.'' He was the Associate Editor of the Journal of the American Psychiatric Association and the author of more than 70 articles and reviews on subjects such as twins, masochism, applied analysis, and countertransference. He was the editor and a contributor to the text ''Child Analysis and Therapy'' and four other books on aspects of psychoanalysis. Dr. Glenn was a member of the faculty of the NYU School of Medicine and its Psychoanalytic Institute for more than 20 years, and previously had been on the faculty of the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York. He was a graduate of Columbia College and the NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Glenn is survived by his wife, Sylvia; four children, Russell Glenn, Mel Glenn, Laura Glenn and Janet Glenn, his sister, Harriet Ferziger, eight grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. He will be remembered for his wonderful wit, his many enthusiasms, his works, and his love of family and friends, who will miss him dearly. Funeral services will be private. GLENN--Jules M.D. We are saddened by the death at age 86 of our esteemed colleague and dear friend in New Hampshire. An outstanding psychoanalyst of both adults and children and a creative author, his wise counsel will be missed.Samuel Herschkowitz, MD, Director, NYU Psychoanalytic Institute; Milagros Picon, MD, President, Psychoanalytic Association of New York; Joseph Reppen, PhD, Secretary, PANY GLENN--Jules, M.D. The Long Island Psychoanalytic Society mourns the loss of its highly respected member, clinician, teacher and friend. We offer our condolences to his family. Martin Blum, M.D., President

KRECH--Dr. Shepard Jr., of Easton, MD, died February 11, 2008, at the age of 89. The son of the late Dr. Shepard and Mary Stevens Chapin Krech, he was born in New York on April 24, 1918. He graduated from Groton School in 1937, Yale College in 1941 where he was a member of Scroll and Key and the 150pound Football Team, and the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, in 1944. Following service as a Lieutenant in the Medical Corps, U.S. Naval Reserves, 1943-1945, and further medical training at Presbyterian, Roosevelt, Bellevue and Lenox Hill Hospitals from 1944-1948, he moved with his family to Easton, MD where, except for 1953-1954 in the Naval Reserves stationed in Guam, he was a general practitioner and family doctor until he retired in 1974. An avid sportsman and dedicated conservationist, he spent the years following his retirement from the medical profession working on behalf of non-governmental organizations and on gubernatorialappointed commissions. Dedicated to the preservation of farmland and the health of the Chesapeake Bay, he was an early proponent of minimizing the use of herbicides and insecticides, buffering their impact on watersheds, and controlling residential development along the shores of the bay and its tributaries. In 1995, the Maryland Chapter of the Nature Conservancy awarded him its Conservation Achievement Award for extraordinary contributions to Conservancy goals. A cofounder of the Maryland chapter of the Nature Conservancy, he served as trustee and chairman of that organization, president of the Wildfowl Trust of North America, chairman of Ducks Unlimited in Talbot County, and trustee of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, the Chesapeake Wildlife Heritage, and the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy. In the 1970s he was appointed to the Wye Island Advisory Committee after the state of Maryland halted a major developer's plans for a dense waterside village on this island (his role in the controversy is detailed in the book Wye Island), and from 1984-1996 he served as a member of successive Chesapeake Bay Critical Areas Commissions. He also served as President of the Talbot County Board of Education during the implementation of Brown v. Board of Education, chief of staff of the Memorial Hospital, Easton, Vice-President of the Interstate PostGraduate Medical Society, and he taught anatomy and physiology at the School of Nursing at Memorial Hospital, Easton. He was a member of the American Medical Association, Blue Hill Country Club, Boone and Crockett Club, Chesapeake Bay Yacht Club, and a founding member of the Legal Limit Dove Club. For over 20 years he was president of the Board of Trustees of the American Memorial Hospital in Reims, France, and in 1976 was awarded the Legion of Honor. He will be remembered as a physician who opened his office to all regardless of race when he arrived in Talbot County in 1948, and who worked with others to make Memorial Hospital in Easton available to black people in its entirety, not just in the basement; as a family doctor who took great pride in house calls at all hours, by boat if necessary, and who accepted payment in kind; as an accomplished fisherman who, on the Spey River, unfailingly paid his bar bill with salmon; as a crack shot, second to none in his prime on upland and water birds as well as big game; as fiercely competitive in sports, games, and life, and never shy about voicing opinions; and as a tireless and passionate advocate for the environment. His wife Nora Potter Krech, whom he married on August 14, 1940, predeceased him, as did his sister, Mary Krech Gould and his brother Alvin W. Krech. He is survived by a brother, Merrill Chapin Krech of Coral Gables, FL, a daughter, Amy K. Knowles of Islamorada, FL, a son, Shepard Krech III of Washington, DC, Providence, RI and Sedgwick, ME, four grandchildren -Barnes and Carter Knowles, Kerry Morrison, and Teal Paynter -and six great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be at Old Wye Church, Wye Mills, MD on Saturday February 23 at 2pm. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Chesapeake Bay Foundation, 162 Prince George Street, Annapolis, MD 21401; or Pickering Creek Audubon Center, 11450 Audubon Lane, Easton, MD 21601

The National Board of Trustees, staff, and volunteers of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America mourn with profound sadness and admiration, the loss of our committed co-founder, supporter, and friend. Bill Modell was a humble man who set out to make a difference in people's lives through his leadership in business, public administration, and philanthropy. His devotion to finding a cure for Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis helped bring critical research, education, and support to the millions suffering around the country. We pay tribute to the great distance he helped bring the organization in finding a cure and carry on his quest. We express our deepest condolences to Shelby, Mitchell, Leslie, Abby, and the rest of the Modell family and friends.
