It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Bill Modell. Our relationship with Bill Modell, his family and business extends back over thirty years. It was with great friendship and admiration that we watched Modells Sporting Goods grow and prosper under his watch. To those of us who worked with him, he was always a bright, hard working, creative gentle man. He was always interested in the people around him and a delight to do business with. His contributions to New York City and those charities so dear to him will preserve his memory for years to come. Bill, we enjoyed your company and you will be sorely missed. With deepest sympathy to Shelby, Leslie and Mitchell Modell and to all the rest of Bill Modell's loving family. The Partners and Staff at Janover Rubinroit, LLC Certified Public Accountants MODELL--William D. The love of my life is gone. We began our journey together with laughter. Now it has ended in tears. My precious, beloved husband devoted his life to me, our children and grandchildren, and his sister and brother-in-law and gave us the most precious gift of all, his love. He became a legend in his own time, building Modell's Sporting Goods into the largest, privately owned sporting goods chain in the country. His brilliant business acumen earned him many honors and awards. Yet, his greatest pleasure was seeing all those he mentored succeed in their careers. During World War II, he proudly served in the Army's Ninth Air Corps and continued to serve his country and New York City throughout his life, as a member of the negotiating committee for the Panama Canal Treaty under President Jimmy Carter, as New York City's Commissioner of Public Affairs for Mayor Abe Beame, and as a founding patron of the Metropolitan Opera House and Lincoln Center for Performing Arts. Though he met world leaders, celebrities and many of America's greatest athletes, he was at heart a down-toearth man, who cared deeply about his family, friends, and . Associates. A humble and gentle man, he helped countless individuals in their time of need. He was the founder of American Digestive Disease Society, a co-founder of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation for Immunological Research and the Hewlett House for breast cancer survivors, and was especially dedicated to Gilda's Club of New York and Worldwide which he helped found. No cause meant more to Bill than finding a cure for Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. In 1967, when our son Michael was diagnosed with Crohn's disease, he co-founded the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and raised many millions of dollars for research. Bill never realized his dream to find a cure, and we lost our darling Michael to complications caused by Crohn's disease six years ago. Yet, despite his unspeakable sorrow, Bill never gave up hope. He continued to raise millions to save others from the suffering that our son endured. For me, his children and grandchildren, his friends, and all those who knew him, Bill was a man who filled the world with his vibrant presence, his compassion and love, his sense of humor, his wisdom and integrity, his quiet courage, and his abundant goodwill. For months, I have known that I would be starting jury duty on February 19th. And for months I have been approaching this date with a mixture of anticipation and anxiety. The part of me looking forward to it hopes that I get selected for a jury. The part of me that is anxious has been hustling to get ahead on work and dodging meeting requests so that I am free in case I am out of commission for a week or longer. (I know that I can defer the jury duty to a more convenient time, but I have already deferred once and, in truth, there aren't more convenient times.)

I've just come from the Jil Sander show, at the end of a long, drab, shifty day. This may be the Milan season in which great significance is put on a pleat. The shift or sack dress seems a dominant trend (at Burberry, Alberta Ferretti, Ferre), at least on the first full day of the Milan shows. Dresses and full skirts have inverted or tacked-down pleats, all carefully placed but oh-so tedious--and not helped by the doll-like vague models lurching on high shiny heels.

In the years since I worked as a drama critic - a period that ended in late 1993, just after the premiere of the second half of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" - I've seen few new plays as invigorating as "August: Osage County," let alone on Broadway. Though it's hard to separate the text from the extraordinary production and cast sent to New York by Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre Company, the virtues of Tracy Letts's drama should be apparent to readers as well as theatergoers. (Which is not to say you shouldn't rush to catch one of the remaining performances, if at all possible. Letts had most of these actors in mind when writing the play for the company, and when they disband after their limited run, now scheduled to end in mid-April, that's it.)

Although I am holding an invitation to Giorgio Armani's show today, at noon, I know I am not expected. Yesterday, shortly after I pulled the covers over my head for a little nap, I received an email from Robert Triefus, who is Armani's head of communications. It was marked urgent and inquired if I had received a letter from Armani. I had not, but it didn't take a genius to know what the letter was about. Armani had decided not to invite me to his show and, of course, that was the intent of the letter, once I had read it. He didn't like the tone of my comments about his January couture show in Paris; specifically, he thought I was "belittling" of his family and friends. I had described their appearance and manner in the moments before the show. It was pretty innocuous stuff. Armani, though, didn't think so. I asked Triefus why Armani had waited until just before today's show to say something; the couture reviews had come out two or three weeks ago. Triefus said Armani had become preoccupied with his ready-to-wear show-we're up to fall 2008-and hadn't had time to return to the matter until now. "That's our fault," Triefus said.
(Matt Ross)

We all know basic tomato sauce, and we're aware that the variations are nearly infinite. But one of my favorites, which requires considerably more time but almost no extra effort, adds the wonderful depth of flavor, silken texture and satisfying chewiness of slow-cooked meat, bone and marrow. Southern Italian in origin, it begins with bony meat (or meaty bones) and requires lengthy simmering.

Two friends recently asked me for career advice using their companies' e-mail accounts, something I thought we all knew was a no-no by this point in the electronic age. The first friend wanted to know if I thought she was revealing too many details about her employer on her blog. (She was.) The second asked me to review her résumé, which was attached. Shortly after these two incidents, I heard about a senior manager losing his job for revealing proprietary information about his firm, something he had done through the firm's e-mail.

Despite Senator Barack Obama's strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clinton's previous supporters are now undecided.

I handed a five to the waitress for one more virgin scotch-and-soda with a twist as the final wannabe comedian walked onstage. He was tall, thin and bearded, wearing a stovepipe hat and looking at notes scribbled on the back of an envelope. The qualifier Kei Nishikori became the first Japanese man to win an ATP title in 16 years by upsetting top-seeded James Blake, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the International Tennis Championships final in Delray Beach, Fla., on Sunday.“I still can’t believe it that I beat James Blake,” the 18-year-old Nishikori told the crowd, which included a dozen Japanese fans chanting “Nippon! Nippon!” high up in the stands. “I’ve only seen him on TV. This is my best tournament ever.”The 244th-ranked Nishikori is expected to move to a No. 122 ranking. He is the youngest player to win an ATP title since Lleyton Hewitt won the Adelaide event as a 16-year-old in 1998. Shuzo Matsuoka was the last tournament champion from Japan. He won his lone career title at the Seoul tournament in April 1992.

Justine Henin won her second tournament of the year, beating Karin Knapp of Italy, 6-3, 6-3, at the Diamond Games in Antwerp, Belgium. The top-ranked Henin rarely produced sparkling tennis during a week in which she did not play a seeded player, but her experience seemed to help carry her as she won her home tournament in front of 13,600 fans at the Sports Palace.

He made an 8-foot birdie putt on the last hole of regulation to get in a four-way playoff, then made another 8-footer on the first playoff hole to win The ACE Group Classic in Naples, Fla. Tom Jenkins, Tom Kite and Brad Bryant had already made their pars before Hoch putted.

The joint bid by Belgium and the Netherlands was the first accepted for the 2018 World Cup, the FIFA president, Joseph S. Blatter, said.The 2018 host will be selected at an executive committee meeting in 2011 with the United States, Mexico, Japan, China, Russia, Spain-Portugal, England and Australia all interested, according to Blatter.South Africa will be the host in 2010, and Brazil will be the host in 2014.

Natalie Coughlin broke her world record in the 100-meter backstroke in a preliminary heat at the Missouri Grand Prix in Columbia. She won in 59.21 seconds, lowering her previous mark by 23-hundredths of a second, to finish ahead of Kirsty Coventry of Zimbabwe, who set a world record in the 200-meter backstroke Saturday.Katie Hoff set her second American record in two days when she cruised to victories in the 200 freestyle and the 400 individual medley. Michael Phelps, the six-time Olympic gold medalist, also won easily in the 200 freestyle and 400 individual medley.Hoff set an American record in the 200, finishing in 1 minute 56.08 seconds to defeat Coughlin for the second time in two days. Coughlin had set the previous mark. In Sunday’s medley, Hoff beat Coventry. With two events remaining on the final day of the Grand Prix on Monday, Hoff has won four races.

Mario Matt of Austria won the inaugural men’s World Cup slalom in Zagreb, Croatia, putting a damper on the homecoming of Ivica Kostelic, who learned to ski on the Sljeme hill outside Zagreb.Kostelic was only three-hundredths of a second behind Matt after the first run and had his family among the 20,000 spectators. He took the lead after his second run even though he made a few mistakes on the long, icy course. But on his second run, Matt navigated the 69 gates without a major error to finish with an aggregate time of 1:51.36. It was Matt’s third victory of the season.

Portsmouth advanced to the quarterfinals of the FA Cup by beating Preston, 1-0, on an injury-time own goal. Middlesbrough was held to a 0-0 tie by Sheffield United in Sunday’s other fifth-round game.Sheffield United largely dominated against Middlesbrough, which missed a chance to score in injury time when Emanuel Pogatetz’s header was blocked. The match will be replayed to determine which club will advance. Manchester United, Chelsea, Bristol Rovers, Barnsley, Cardiff and West Bromwich Albion are the other quarterfinalists.

Eamon Sullivan of Australia broke the 50-meter freestyle world record, finishing in 21.56 seconds to better the mark set by Alexander Popov of Russia in 2000. Sullivan took eight-hundredths of a second off the previous record at the New South Wales Open meet, held at the Sydney Olympic Park Aquatic Center. Sullivan took nearly a half-second off his personal-best time.

FISCH--David Benjamin, 28 years of age, passed away suddenly on February 14th, 2008 in New York City. David was raised in Indianapolis and graduated from Park Tudor High School in 1998. He matriculated to Columbia College where in he graduated in 2002. He had lived in New York City ever since, working first at Hunton & Williams law firm, then International Biometric Group, and was currently employed with Inductis consulting firm. David was an avid figure skater throughout his childhood and adolescence; he won a United States Figure Skating Association gold medal in 1997. He enjoyed attending rock concerts, was a Phishhead and follower other contemporary jam bands. David had a voracious appetite for literature, especially the novels of Kurt Vonnegut. He loved following professional sports and was the first to own the latest video-game system, at heart he was real techie. David was very close with his loving family, including his parents, Gary and Barrie, his brothers, Mark and Adam, his sister-inlaw, Kate, his grandmother, Margot Katz, and late grandparents, Harry Katz and Charles and June Fisch. David had a real love of family and will be missed by his aunts, uncles, and cousins. The light of his life was soulmate Jen Shoenthal of New York City. He had formed great friendships with so many good people throughout his life; he never knew a stranger. David was loved by all and will be sincerely missed. Funeral services will be held on Monday, February 18th, 2008 at 1:00 pm in the sanctuary at Congregation Beth-El Zedeck, 600 West 70th Street, Indianapolis, IN 46260. Memorial contributions may be made to Congregation Beth-El Zedeck, where a fund is being established in David's memory. Following committal services the family will gather in the Borns Multipurpose Room at Beth-el Zedeck for a brief memorial Service. Upon conclusion the family welcomes friends to join them for a traditional shiva meal and reception in David's honor. To place an online message for the family please visit arnmortuary.com

PRINCESS ''Class Is in Session'' (Jaywerks) Surely you haven't forgotten Crime Mob, the finest coeducational hip-hop wrecking crew from Atlanta? The group broke through in 2004 with ''Knuck if You Buck,'' a thrillingly simple but chaotic track that sounded like a homeroom riot. (The members were teenagers when it was released.) And last year Crime Mob scored another hit with ''Rock Yo Hips,'' built on the mesmerizing sound of booming timpani.

Loving grandfather to Austin Finley and Nicole Plumley. Brother of Nancy Renehan and Brian Wiegand. A gentleman, loyal friend, mentor and ardent Villanova man. Memorial service Wednesday, February 20th, 6pm, Holy Cross R.C. Church, 329 West 42nd St., NYC.
LANDAU--Eva J. February 18, 1982. Who found well deserved rest and peace 26 years ago today. Your loving son, Robert

LEVOWITZ--Bernard S., M.D. age 81, passed away peacefully on February 14, 2008. He is survived by his beloved daughters Lisa and Joyce, son-in-laws Alan Hurwitz and Jim Maffezzoli, adoring grandchildren Grace and Joy Hurwitz and Daniel, Gabrielle, Michael and Emily Maffezzoli. After graduating Bronx High School of Science and New York Medical College, Dr. Levowitz served in the Navy Medical Corp. He was a long standing practitioner in the Brooklyn Surgical Community and served as Chief of Surgery at several hospitals. Most recently he was a senior member of the surgical staff at Long Island College Hospital. Throughout his 53 years as a cardiovascular thoracic surgeon, he was passionate about teaching both in and out of the operating room and continued lecturing until a few days before his passing. Funeral services will be held at 1:30pm on Monday, February 18th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Brooklyn Surgical Society. He will be in our hearts forever.

NEUBAUER--Peter, M.D., was a founding spirit and member of the Board of Directors of the Viola W. Bernard Foundation. His talents were effervescent and led to pioneering contributions in psychiatry which, over time, expanded the roots of psychotherapy. He was always open to innovations in neurophysiology, therapy and scientific advances for the Bernard Foundation. A singular aspect of his talent was as an expert in articulating complex ideas clearly. He was a scholar who left a legacy through publications. His lifetime commitment to patients was legion and we will miss him sorely. Hopefully, we can retain Peter's wisdom which never diluted psychoanalysis into shallow concepts or faddish thinking. Perry Ottenberg, M.D., President Viola W. Bernard Foundation NEUBAUER--Peter, M.D. The Child Development Center acknowledges the passing of Dr. Peter Neubauer, its former director. He was a leading figure in building developmental theory and practice knowledge to enhance the lives of very young children. NEUBAUER--Peter B., M.D. ''The Psychoanalytic Study of the Child'' is saddened by the loss of Peter B. Neubauer, M.D., a distinguished Editor of the annual volume for nearly two decades. Dr. Neubaur was a loved and respected member of the Editorial Board. He was both an astute editor and an active contributor to its many volumes, providing stimulating papers, particularly in the areas of child development, research, and psychoanalytic treatment. Robert A. King, M.D. Managing Editor NEUBAUER--Peter B., M.D. The Anna Freud Foundation joins in the expression of sadness at the death of Peter B. Neubauer, M.D., who served on the Foundation's Board for several decades and as its Secretary and its chairman for many of those years. He provided the Foundation with a thrust and direction that assures its influence for many years to come. Samuel Abrams, M.D. Chairman Claudia Lament, Ph.D. Secretary NEUBAUER--Peter, M.D. You are my mentor, my guiding light and my inspiration. I shall miss you dearly, your legacy will never fade. Bonnie Stern

CARROLL--Martin J., Red Bank, NJ retired Executive Vice President of Moran Towing and Transportation died Friday, February 15, 2008. Surviving are his nine children and spouses Cathleen Carroll, Ocean Grove, NJ, Edmund and Sharon Carroll, Leesburg, VA, Martin and Hilary Carroll, Holmdel, NJ; Lederle and Kent Eberhardt, State College, PA; John and Lisa Carroll, Phoenix, AZ; Karen and Ben Yang, Medford, NJ; Tim and Marianne Carroll, Fair Haven, NJ; Marie Louise and Bob Lutkewitte, Colts Neck, NJ; and Helen Carroll, Nutley, NJ; fourteen grandchildren; two sisters and brother-in-law Marilyn and Gerald Quinn and Anne Carpinello. Visitation will be from 6 to 9pm Monday, February 18 at St. Mary's Church, Colts Neck, followed by a prayer service and tribute. A Funeral Mass will be offered at 10:30am Tuesday at St. Mary's Church, Colts Neck. Interment will be at St. Catherine's Cemetery, Sea Girt.

NEBENZAHL--Paul at 86 of New York, NY passed away on February 16, 2008 of complications from a cerebral hemorrhage and Alzheimer's. Born on August 9, 1921 to Meyer and Ethel Nebenzahl in Far Rockaway, NY, Paul grew up a devoted son and a loyal older brother to Kenneth Nebenzahl. Paul was the grandson of A. Louis Nebenzahl, founder of the Nebenzahl Department Store. Mr. Nebenzahl began his career in advertising at age 16 working as a mail clerk. Self educated after graduating from Lawrence High School, his career was interrupted by his distinguished service as a paratrooper and a member of the SF during WWII. Just before D-Day Mr. Nebenzahl participated in a covert operation led by the French underground to destroy all avenues of transportation available to the Germans, thus preventing them from reinforcing the western front. He was decorated for heroism by the United States, France, and China. He retired from advertising as the Chairman of Harrison Services after 56 years in the business. He spent his retirement traveling around the world spending time with his beloved family on Twin Lakes and at the Hodge Podge Lodge, campaigning for the Democratic party, taking gorgeous photographs, volunteering as a docent at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and occasionally enjoying a game of golf. He married Nancy Baar Nebenzahl, deceased, in 1947 and together they raised three children: Marcie, James, and Andrew. He is remembered as the most gracious man with a happy and warm smile. He leaves behind a legacy of great values, intellectual curiosity, political activism, commitment to family, and they hunger for adventure. His greatest gift to his family is the love they have for each other. Mr. Nebenzahl is survived by his children: Marcie Aiuvalasit, James Nebenzahl, and Andrew Nebenzahl, their spouses: Tony Aiuvalasit, Maureen Nebenzahl, and Sue Molinda, his seven grandchildren: Sharon, Jason, Alethea, Tony, Amelia, Christopher (Bubs), and Adam, great-grandchildren Aiden, and Liam, Paul's wife, Judith Nebenzahl, his brother, Kenneth Nebenzahl, and sistersin-law, Jocelyn Nebenzahl and Susan Baar Rose. Funeral services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue at 81th Street on Tuesday, February 19th at 3:30pm. Shiva to follow at the home of James Nebenzahl at 1175 York Avenue, apartment 6D. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Alzheimer's Association.

RYAN--Dale. The Trustees, faculty and students of the Institute for Child, Adolescent, & Family Studies mourn the death of our respected colleague, beloved teacher and valiant friend. Her devoted commitment to her work and her life was an inspiration to all of us. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Peter, and her entire family.

UDEL--Jane Manna, died peacefully at home among family and friends on February 8, 2008. A native New Yorker, Ms. Udel studied at Hunter and Smith Colleges, earning an M.A. in English. Devoted Mother, ardent feminist, erudite reader and poet, she loved politics and music. Mourned by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and sister Eleanor Parker. We will miss her outrage at social injustice, her wonderful sense of humor, and her unfailing compassion.

Outsourcing's Next Wave The first wave of offshore outsourcing sent software development and maintenance abroad, mainly to India. The next wave, well under way, is shipping back-office business tasks overseas, like finance, payroll, claims processing and procurement. That's business process outsourcing, or B.P.O., in nerd talk.

The Oscar broadcasts from recent years can't touch those of decades past. The average rating for shows in the last five years, for example, was 23.7. Still, the Oscar event remains king of the awards shows, especially this year, when the writers' strike turned the Golden Globes into a virtual press conference and reduced the Screen Actors Guild awards to a 2.1 rating. A sure winner on Oscar night is Barbara Walters, who presents a celebrity interview show, which last year earned a 9.3 rating. This year's edition will feature Harrison Ford, above with Ms. Walters. SHELLY FREIERMAN

LAWRENCE--Alice. We mourn the passing of Alice Lawrence. She was a champion for individuals suffering from chronic lung disease. She created a department for pulmonary rehabilitation at Beth Israel Medical Center which continues to inspire and care for individuals so afflicted. We thank her for her tremendous generosity and dedication. She will be remembered with great admiration and affection. Our sincere condolences to her family. Jonathan Raskin, M.D. Joanne Tejera, M.D.

9 P.M. (13, 49) KIT CARSON Is he a hero of westward expansion or a villain to one of the great American Indian tribes? That's the question at the heart of this ''American Experience'' documentary about Kit Carson, the guide who left his Missouri home in 1826, when he was just 16, and blazed a path for a westward-moving nation. Carson, above, took an Arapaho wife and learned at least six Indian tongues as well as the universal sign language of the Western tribes, but he has also been immortalized as an Indian killer. In 1862, as a mediator between the white and native residents of the northern New Mexico territory, he was ordered to wage war on the region's nomadic tribes. Ultimately Carson was linked to the Long Walk of the Navajos, a journey remembered as a death march. 8 P.M. Despite Senator Barack Obama's strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News. The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clinton's previous supporters are now undecided.

CHRIS CAGLE ''My Life's Been a Country Song'' (Capitol Nashville) The funniest moment on Chris Cagle's new album arrives somewhere around the 10-minute mark. He has just finished a brash Southern-rock song called ''It's Good to Be Back,'' complete with screaming electric guitars and defiant lyrics: ''I'm stone-cold on a roll/No one gonna tell me no.'' In an instant the noise dies down, replaced by tinkling keyboards, the audio equivalent of raised eyebrows. Suddenly this stand-up guy is down on his knees, pleading, ''I don't wanna live without you anymo-o-ore.'' Sounds as if someone did tell him no, after all.

DREW GRESS ''The Irrational Numbers'' (Premonition) The center of gravity shifts constantly throughout ''The Irrational Numbers,'' an album of new compositions by the jazz-trained bassist Drew Gress. Some of the pieces deliver a definitive impact, while others coalesce and dissolve. Tempos buckle or shift, but just as often they stick, locking into a groove. Altogether the effort feels like some act of subversive diplomacy. If there's still any line in the sand between ''inside'' and ''outside'' in postmodern progressive jazz, here comes Mr. Gress with his rake and trowel.

TOPOLSKI--Andrew, Artist and Teacher, dies at 56. Mr. Topolski was an accomplished and unique artist residing in Brooklyn and Callicoon, NY. He was a devoted art teacher for over 36 years. He taught Foundation at Parsons School of Design. He was born in Buffalo, NY. Mr. Topolski was an exceptional and prolific artist whose work includes mixed media drawings and sculptures. His work has been his personal message board for the social, political and historical events that deeply affect him and shape the collective memory of humankind. He exhibited extensively in Europe and the US. Mr. Topolski's work is in many major public and private collections, including the National Gallery of Art. He was well recognized for his devotion and passion to his work, his teaching and most notably his unfailing warm heart and distinguished presence. Mr. Topolski died February 14, 2008 after a brief illness. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife, Cindy, His adoring children James and Julia, His parents John and Lorraine and his brothers, Ronald and Thomas and sisters-in-law, Diane and Michelle and will be sadly missed by his family and many friends. Services will be held at Pacer Funeral Home in Depew, NY, Monday, February 18th from 2-4 and 7-9. In lieu of flowers, Donations may be made to The Burchfield Penney Art Center, 1300 Elmwood Avenue, Buffalo, NY 14222.

They are the inductees to the National Toy Hall of Fame.The honored toys include the sophisticated but obsolete (Atari 2600, inducted in 2007) and the humble (cardboard box, 2005), the trademarked (Scrabble, 2004) and the generic (kite, 2007), the domestic (Easy Bake Oven, 2006) and the militaristic (G. New York Democrats are feeling the pressure building within their ranks and within the bigger Democratic machine, as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama continue to battle it out on the campaign trail with no end soon in sight. Some of the more influential New York Democrats are even calling for one or the other to step down sooner or later to maintain accord in the party. “I think Hillary and Barack, if there’s not 2,025, have to get together and figure out a mechanism that they both abide by,” Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Clinton supporter, said after a speech at the annual Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian caucus for state lawmakers in Albany over the weekend.

On Saturday, Sam Roberts reported that in about 80 of the city’s 6,106 election districts, unofficial results showed Senator Barack Obama without a single vote, including several districts where he ran a respectable race in a nearby area. City election officials said their formal review of the results, which will not be completed for weeks, had confirmed discrepancies between the vote totals reported publicly — and unofficially — on primary night and the actual tally on hundreds of voting machines across the city.

The Spitzer administration’s decision to scrap a long-promised expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and sell some of its property to plug gaps in the state budget has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials, state legislators, trade show producers and tourism executives, Charles V. Bagli reports. It has also revealed deep fault lines within the coalition that in 2006 hailed a since-defunct $1.8 billion proposed expansion as critical to the city’s tourism industry and the creation of 20,000 jobs and tens of millions of dollars a year in economic benefits for New York.

Serrano, a Bronx Democrat — went out of his way to actually praise the Cuban leader today.

By their very nature, the world’s 80 million blogs — give or take a few million — seem to defy easy categorization and evaluation. Sites like Technorati and Bloglines claim to track the most popular blogs, but popularity is just one way to find blogs worth reading. A new book, “Ultimate Blogs: Masterworks from the Wild Web,” takes a different tack. I don't see many plays. In fact, being a mother of four small kids, I don't see much of anything lately except for the interior windshield of my minivan. What goes down inside that minivan, however - and I mean along the lines of family conflict and sibling relations and, for that matter, angry mothers (me?!) lashing out at their children - what goes on inside that minivan as we tear away to drop the eldest off at first grade, or try to get our act together in the parking lot of a grocery store as a three year old is in shambles well, let me tell you, it is high drama. I'm not kidding. Babies, toddlers, and small children are people who might as well be in the throes of Tracy Letts's play. They are all raw and barely patient, attached to their siblings unwittingly, vicious and angry, and then, by turns, hysterically funny and apt.

It's well established that Manhattan is for the rich, the rent-controlled and the prescient who bought years ago. And it's old news that most up-and-coming New York writers and editors live in Brooklyn. But who'da thunk that Dumbo - the gritty-chic Brooklyn neighborhood whose acronym means "down under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass," home of million-dollar condos, the York Street Projects, artists' studios and high-end boutiques - would become a bastion of indie publishing? Lured by the subsidized rent offered by the developer David Walentas, in recent months, Verso, the leftie British press, and Melville House, the literary publisher, have moved to Dumbo, and the upstart literary quarterly N+1 is on its way. The London-based New Left Review has some space in Verso's office, and the London Review of Books is also said to have scouted out space there.

How should the nearly 800 unpledged "party leader and elected official" delegates - the so-called superdelegates - vote when the Democratic convention is held in August? These delegates may well hold the balance of power in this year's nomination contest, and unlike "regular" delegates, they will not arrive at the convention with a binding pledge to vote for either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama. How they will exercise their power is crucial, and is already the subject of some high-level angst among the Democratic Party's most important leaders.

Last week we discussed how Goodman Global's deal got done. One of the points made there was that in these troubled times limiting complexity was a means to ensure greater certainty of deal completion in private equity deals.

Even in the homestretch -- Oscar ballots are due today -- some people are having trouble generating enthusiasm about this year's race. Scott Feinberg is not one of them. As the overlord of the And the Winner Is blog he has covered every wiggle and wobble in the race, some real and some imagined, and spends a great deal of time reporting, which is breathtakingly uncommon in the blog world.
Cuba's dictator has resigned, so resign yourself to more like this:
What a difference a few hours makes.

Surely something will rush in to fill the post-Oscar vacuum created by the cancellation of this year's Vanity Fair party? Surely not, says Anne Thompson. She suggests all of the action will be on the run-up, after which the air will just start leaking out of the balloon. She also says that the Elton John bash, which is billed as a viewing party, will stay that way.

Take a look at the video tribute to Mark Lisanti at Defamer, who is leaving so he has enough time to screw up his life enough so that he can go into rehab. The weird thing about the video? Everybody seems so darn sincere.
T. L. Stanley is about up to here with all of the chatter in the best actress race.
Selections from the runway shows during Milan Fashion Week.

Kenneth Chang has written a piece in this week's Science Times exploring the Los Alamos National Laboratories concept for nuclear-powered fuel refineries that could turn atmospheric carbon dioxide and water into gasoline, jet fuel or methanol. I wrote an initial post on this last week. [UPDATED below]

In a letter to investors about the state of Cerberus Capital Management's investments in Chrysler and GMAC, the firm's founder, Stephen Feinberg, came off sounding at turns cavalier and ruthless, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his latest DealBook column.

It's no Super Tuesday, but Hawaiian Democrats and Wisconsinites will head to the voting booths today. Washington State Republicans will allot 19 more delegates in their primary (18 were doled out during the state's caucus on Feb. 9). Early voting begins in Texas, as well.
Delta Air Lines moved closer on Monday to a deal to buy Northwest Airlines, according to The New York Times.

MBIA, the beleaguered bond insurer, said Tuesday that Joseph Brown had returned as chairman and chief executive, replacing Gary Dunton, who resigned. Mr. Brown, 59, served as chairman and chief executive until May 2004 and served as executive chairman until May 2007 before retiring.
Carl Zimmer visits Dr. Roger Hanlon in his lab at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA.
Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.
Barclays, Britain's third-biggest bank, raised its 2007 write-down on the value of risky assets to 1.6 billion pounds ($3.1 billion) but reported profits broadly in line with analysts' expectations.

Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term, The New York Times says.

"The Majlis" refers to a group of people sitting down together to talk, informally or formally, or where they meet. These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in "Generation Faithful," a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the "Stalled Lives" of Egypt's young, and the initial "Majlis" entries are from the staff of The Times' Cairo bureau.
More of your "late night" comedy (send via the comment link below):
Prada, the Italian fashion house, is getting ready to send its latest styles down the runways in Milan this week.
Aired Monday night on NBC: Happy President's Day, or as Mitt Romney calls it, "Monday," I guess.
How to make a big impression at your next job interview, from the New York comedy troupe Olde English:
Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse in the open market and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Unless Yahoo quickly reverses course and enters into talks, Microsoft would then seek to nominate a slate of directors to Yahoo's board by March 13, the final deadline for nominations, and pursue a lengthy campaign to oust the board.

Aired Monday night on CBS: Ladies and gentlemen, I know you heard about this: the big tainted meat recall. This is a huge story. Out in California, they found out that something was haywire with the beef. They recalled -- listen to this -- 143 million pounds of tainted beef, 143 million, yes. That's one triple stack burger at Wendy's.

It appears that Merrill Lynch is about to get another foreign investor, albeit one with a very small stake. South Korea's Hana Bank has agreed to buy 1 million shares of Merrill Lynch from Temasek Holdings, Singapore's state-owned investment company, for $50 million, according to Dow Jones.
In 2006, when a newly installed Robert Iger annexed Pixar Animation to Walt Disney, the company he had recently been appointed to run, the deal was met with skepticism.
Solar energy startup Pythagoras Solar has completed a $10 million first round of funding led by Israel Cleantech Ventures, according to a report by Clean Edge.
If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?

Forget the big bonus, access to the corporate jet and oceans of pricey champagne at dinner. For many bond and equity traders, The New York Post suggests, the new status symbol on Wall Street may a steady job.
Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Monday defended his decision to nationalize the ailing mortgage lender Northern Rock, facing down angry shareholders and even the bank's own management.
RAB Capital and SRM Global, two of Europe's best known hedge funds, are likely to be the biggest losers following the British government's decision to nationalize the troubled lender Northern Rock.

In a six-month period from mid-summer to mid-January, government-allied, offshore institutional investors poured more than $40 billion into blue-chip American and European financial institutions, including Barclays, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and UBS.

Citigroup, which has been raising funds since taking a huge hit from the United States subprime mortgage meltdown, has sold its Japan headquarters to a rival, Morgan Stanley, in a deal reportedly worth $445 million.
Silicon Valley is in danger of creating its own digital divide.

The former chief executive of Refco, one of the world's biggest commodities brokerage firms, pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy and fraud charges that carry a possible prison term of more than 300 years.

Dexion Absolute, the largest listed closed-end fund investing in a pool of hedge funds, said it raised a further $263 million Monday as demand for those kinds of investments showed no signs of waning despite volatile returns in recent months.

Volkswagen denied on Sunday that the chairman of its supervisory board, Ferdinand Piech, wanted to oust Wendelin Wiedeking as chief executive of the sports car maker Porsche, V.W.'s biggest shareholder.

JPMorgan Chase announced a major push on Monday into private-equity investing in Asia, saying it had earmarked at least $750 million of its own capital to take minority stakes in businesses in a region where buyouts are notoriously difficult.

The Australia & New Zealand Banking Group fell to a 2-1/2-year low in Sydney trading after the chief executive, Michael Smith, said the "bloodbath" in debt markets would erase profit growth this year.
CNBC interviews Ron Allen, former chief executive of Delta Airlines and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, on the two carriers' push to create to world's largest airline.

The supervisory board of Deutsche Post on Monday picked Frank Appel to lead the mail and global logistics company after his predecessor resigned last week amid a growing tax evasion investigation that has gripped Germany.
A major shareholder in the Italian motorcycle maker Ducati plans to bid for the entire company and delist it, Italy's financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported, according to Reuters.
Qatar Petroleum,a state-owned oil company, said on Sunday it would sell a 65.8 percent stake in a new holding firm in an initial public offering starting on Feb. 28.
India's Reliance Power, owned by the billionaire Anil Ambani, could issue bonus shares to investors in a move to compensate them for a sharp decline in its stock price, the company said on Monday.

Delong Holdings, a Chinese metals maker, gained 16 percent in Singapore after the Evraz Group, a steelmaker part-owned by the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, said it might buy the company in its first Asian takeover.
As Turkey lurches toward a repeal of a ban on head scarves at universities, the country’s secular upper middle class is feeling increasingly threatened.

David Li, the Hong Kong banker and lawmaker who is paying $8.1 million to settle a United States inquiry into his possible role in an insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones & Company, resigned from the city government's executive council late Saturday.
An initial public offering of 156 million shares of India's state-run lender, the Rural Electrification Corporation, was fully subscribed within the first hour of the opening.
A Web analytics company NuConomy has raised $3 million in its first round of venture funding led by a large advertising conglomerate WPP.

IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the German bank wracked by losses from the United States subprime mortgage crisis, has announced plans to sell 1.5 billion euros ($2.19 billion) in shares as part of a government-sponsored bailout, provided its shareholders agree to the move.

(This week's guest blogger has been bleeding Giant blue since the late 1960s with Fran Tarkenton, Spider Lockhart and Ron Johnson. From 4th-and-17 to the Tyree-play-to-be-named-later, all things Giants football can be found on his blog at ultimatenyg.blogspot.com)
Scorpion Offshore, a money-losing oil rig startup, agreed on Friday to a takeover offer from Abu Dhabi-based Fortune Super Equity Management .

A buyout shop, the 3i Group of London, agreed on Friday to buy a laser eye surgery provider, Ultralase, from Spanish cosmetic surgery group Corporación Dermoestética for 174.5 million pounds ($343.2 million).

Sweden's center-right government has chosen four bidders in its auction of Vin & Sprit, the maker of Absolut vodka, that will be allowed to perform due diligence of the company, the business daily Dagens Industri reported.
The Walt Disney Company may acquire a controlling stake in India's UTV Software Communications, maker of last year's box-office hit "The Namesake," after it offered to buy additional shares.
A Swedish wireless equipment maker, LM Ericsson, said Monday it would sell its enterprise PBX solutions business to Aastra Technologies of Canada for 650 million kronor ($103 million).

For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

J. David McSwane, the student editor of The Rocky Mountain Collegian who drew global attention last fall for a four-word editorial criticizing President Bush, is facing another storm.

Two major players in international high-end residential development are merging.

Yes, it's that time of year again: the NHL general managers are meeting to concoct a whole new grab bag of innovations that read less like a summit of hockey executives and more like a Mad Magazine parody of a professional sport.

HP’s first-quarter net income grew 38 percent to $2.1 billion, as revenue climbed 13 percent to $28.5 billion, beating the muted expectations of Wall Street analysts.
Barack Obama’s broad win in Wisconsin put new pressure on Hillary Rodham Clinton, while John McCain closed in on the G.O.P. nomination.
Crude oil vaulted through a psychological barrier amid concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.
Wall Street gave up a big early gain Tuesday as oil prices closed above $100 for the first time and stoked fears that inflation will stymie an already troubled economy.
The closing of Wikileaks.org, which invites people to post confidential material, presents a First Amendment test.
Dozens of safety violations were found at the former Deutsche Bank tower near ground zero where two firefighters died in a blaze.

Companies should have a plan for replacing their employees as they grow older.
Microsoft will wage a proxy fight to oust Yahoo’s directors, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.
The boards of Delta and Northwest have both scheduled emergency meetings for Tuesday where the deal, which would reshape the airline industry, could be approved.
A man died Monday afternoon after a fight with another man at a Dunkin’ Donuts in eastern Queens.
Radek Martinek’s slap shot midway through the second period broke the cage on the mask of San Jose goalie Evgeni Nabokov, sending him to the dressing room to receive stitches on his nose.
The possible inclusion of Keith Van Horn in a deal that would send Jason Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks means Van Horn, a former Net, would have to come out of retirement.
It was the largest increase in consumer prices in more than a decade. Officials said the country would likely continue austerity policies to combat inflation.
Juan Jose Haedo of Argentina emerged from a big sprinting pack to claim Stage 1 of the Amgen Tour of California by more than two bikes lengths Monday.
Roy Hibbert had 18 points, Jonathan Wallace added 14 and No. 12 Georgetown won at Providence, 68-58, on Monday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Russian-Chinese draft treaty to ban weapons in space referred incorrectly to five signers of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that were asked to meet to discuss nuclear disarmament. They are the five nuclear powers that are parties to the treaty; they are not the only signers.

Parviz Khan, the Birmingham man who pleaded guilty last month to plotting to kidnap and behead a British Muslim soldier, was sentenced to life in prison. Described by witnesses as a keen cricketer and pubgoer until contacts with Islamic militants radicalized him on a trip to Pakistan, he was ordered to serve at least 14 years for the plot, and for supplying militants in Afghanistan with money and equipment. The plot was uncovered by Britain’s security services. In secret recordings played in court, Mr. Khan was heard teaching his 5-year-old son to carry out a beheading. “How do you cut them with a knife?” he said to the boy. “Show me. Like this.” At another point, he asked the boy, “Who do you love?” The boy replied, “I love Sheik Osama bin Laden.” Mr. Khan then asked, “Who do you kill?” The boy’s reply: “America kill. Bush I kill, and Blair kill.”.

Japan voiced anger after the weekend arrests of two United States marines in Okinawa and said it would complain to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on her visit next week. One marine was accused of driving drunk; the other, the police said, was found drunk in the middle of the night on the sofa of a family who did not know him. “What’s the matter with the U.S. military?” Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda asked reporters. “I have to demand seriously that they pin it down.”.

New procedures outlined by the Vatican call for “greater sobriety and rigor” by diocesan officials in deciding to begin the process of beatification, the main step toward canonization, and in determining the required miracles. Cardinal José Saraiva Martins, who heads the department in charge of the process, said more than 2,200 beatification and sainthood causes were pending and stressed the need for a “true reputation for holiness” among candidates before the process leading toward beatification began, along with “rigorous historical research.”.
The police arrested Pasquale Condello, said to be a top boss of the Ndrangheta, the crime group of Italy’s far south. He had been a fugitive since 1987.

A judge in Trinidad and Tobago ruled that three men accused of plotting to bomb a fuel pipeline leading to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York should be extradited to face trial in the United States. The defendants have a week to appeal.

The World Council of Churches, the Geneva-based ecumenical affiliation of 349 Protestant and Orthodox denominations, began a search for a new chief after its current general secretary, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Kobia of Kenya, announced that he would not seek a second five-year term. The election will be in September 2009. Dr. Kobia, a Methodist whose doctorate was revealed last week to have been issued by a nonaccredited institution, said his decision was for private reasons. He will be the first council chief to serve just one term.

A $7.15 billion structured investment vehicle managed and sponsored by the British banking company Standard Chartered may default this week after failing to repay maturing debt, Standard & Poor’s said. The investment vehicle, Whistlejacket Capital, was put into receivership last week. It failed to pay notes due last Friday, S.& P. said, and will be in default if it fails to make a payment by Thursday, when a three-day grace period ends. Whistlejacket, based in the British Channel Islands, appointed receivers after a decline in the value of its holdings set into motion rules forcing it to wind down and prompted Standard Chartered to abandon a bailout it had proposed. Standard Chartered is pursuing a reorganization of Whistlejacket, S.& P. said, citing information from Deloitte & Touche, the company’s receiver.

Research In Motion is suing Motorola over several patents used for wireless devices like its BlackBerry e-mail devices and Motorola’s Razr smartphones. Research In Motion, which is based in Waterloo, Ontario, asked a United States District Court in Dallas to rule that Motorola was breaching commitments it had made to license essential patents to competitors on a fair and reasonable basis. Research In Motion also says in a court filing dated Saturday that Motorola is violating nine of its patents and is breaching a 2003 agreement by refusing to negotiate reasonable terms for the agreement’s extension beyond January 2008. The Canadian company’s filing came one day after Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., filed a suit against Research In Motion, claiming it had violated some of Motorola’s patents. A Motorola spokeswoman said the company believed the complaint was without merit and would defend itself.

Brazilian retail sales climbed 9 percent in December from December 2006, capping their best year since at least 2001 as record low borrowing costs stimulated consumer spending. Retail, supermarket and grocery store sales rose 9.6 percent last year, the biggest gain since the national statistics agency started the current series in 2001. “The sales that gained the most were those that depend on credit,” said Alex Agostini, chief economist at Austin Rating Serviços Financeiros in São Paulo. Sales of home appliances and furniture rose 15.4 percent in 2007, the national statistics agency said. Computer and office material sales increased 29.4 percent and vehicle sales jumped 22.6 percent.
One hundred sculptures and engravings by Shinjo Ito, a renowned Buddhist artist, will be showing at Milk Gallery in Chelsea.

The Chicago Bears released the former Pro Bowl wide receiver Muhsin Muhammad after three seasons. Chicago also gave defensive end Alex Brown a two-year contract extension. Muhammad, who turns 35 in May, spent nine seasons with the Carolina Panthers and twice made the Pro Bowl. He was released in February 2005 after setting career highs with 1,405 receiving yards and 16 touchdowns. He signed a six-year contract with the Bears, but his numbers dropped dramatically. He caught 40 passes for 570 yards and 3 touchdowns last season.

Louisiana State said Monday in a news release that quarterback Ryan Perrilloux had been suspended indefinitely for violating team rules. Perrilloux, who started two games last season — both victories — has been widely considered the successor to the starting quarterback Matt Flynn. But Coach Les Miles says Perrilloux’s status for spring practice, which starts Feb. 29, is uncertain.

Two years ago, Marcus O’Sullivan, the former miler and now the Villanova men’s track coach, feared for Bobby Curtis’s future.“He’d fall asleep in the middle of a meet,” O’Sullivan once said. “I wasn’t sure if he would be awake for a race. I would enter two names for his relay leg. I thought his career might be over.”The problem was circadian rhythm disorder, which prevented him from sleeping or staying awake. Now Curtis, a senior from Louisville, Ky., is fine, and two weekends ago he ran 3,000 meters in 7 minutes 50.17 seconds, the fastest time indoors by a collegian this winter. He will run the 3,000 and the distance medley in the Big East indoor championships Saturday and Sunday at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.“I don’t have trouble with sleep now,” Curtis told the New York Track Writers Association by telephone Monday. “At the time, it was a very bad thing. For a while, I was going to bed at 2 a.m. and waking up at 7. I had no energy. It closed down everything. The problem was unbearable. It took four months, but I learned better sleeping habits. Now I sleep from 1 to 9 a.m. I feel good now.”.

Winning Colors, the 1988 Kentucky Derby winner, was euthanized Sunday after a bout with colic and was buried at Greentree Farm, according to the Gainesway thoroughbred farm in Lexington, Ky. She was 23. Winning Colors is one of three fillies to win the Derby. The others are Regret in 1915 and Genuine Risk in 1980. As a 3-year-old, Winning Colors won the Derby in wire-to-wire fashion under Gary Stevens, defeating Forty Niner. She also won the Grade I Santa Anita Derby and the Santa Anita Oaks that year and finished with eight wins, three seconds and a third.

Shahar Peer became the first Israeli to compete in a WTA Tour event in the Gulf Arab region, when she defeated Andreja Klepac of Slovenia, 6-3, 6-4, to reach the second round in the Qatar Open in Doha. Peer and Klepac played before about 50 spectators. Despite the empty stands, Peer was pleased with the reception. “I have been received with a lot of warmth by people in Doha,” she said.

Vince Young, the Tennessee Titans quarterback who led Texas to the 2005 national championship, is back in class this semester, working toward his degree in education. “I just wanted to come back and finish up because I wanted to show not only myself and my family, but all the people that have respect for me, that school is the key,” Young said. He is taking 12 hours this semester.
The Kennedy assassination re-entered the spotlight Monday when the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years were unveiled.

Nancy Reagan was undergoing tests at a hospital in Santa Monica after spending a precautionary night there for a fall she took in her Los Angeles home, her spokeswoman said. Mrs. Reagan, 86, was doing well after falling on Sunday morning, a spokeswoman, Joanne Drake, said. It was not immediately clear when Mrs. Reagan would be released from St. John’s Health Center, where doctors determined she did not break a hip as feared, Ms. Drake said. Mrs. Reagan’s last major public appearance was at the Jan. 30 Republican presidential debate at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif., where she sat with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Confusion over two Chinese factories with similar names led to regulators’ failure to inspect a plant that makes an ingredient linked to life-threatening side effects with the blood-thinning drug heparin, the Food and Drug Administration said. The regulators mistakenly referred to inspection records for a plant from a different company and cleared the heparin facility without necessary inspections and evaluations, said Joseph Famulare, deputy director at the agency’s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. The agency will begin inspecting the plant this week. On Feb. 11, the F.D.A. said use of heparin in multidose vials made by Baxter International Inc., of Deerfield, Ill., had been tied to dangerously low blood pressure, vomiting and difficulty breathing. Four patients died, the agency said.

Homeowners and utility crews worked to clear wreckage and restore services after the latest round of winter tornadoes. At least 50 people were injured in Prattville, and Mayor Jim Byard said about 200 homes and 40 businesses were damaged. No deaths were reported. The tornado was part of a system that swept across the Southeast on Sunday, damaging homes elsewhere in Alabama and in Georgia and the Florida Panhandle.

Renovations to the big cat exhibit at the San Francisco Zoo are complete after a fatal attack by a tiger. The zoo’s lions and tigers got their first look at the renovated pen. Once the animals acclimate to their surroundings, officials will decide when visitors can see the cats. The animals have been kept indoors away from public view since a Siberian tiger killed a teenager and mauled his two friends on Dec. 25. It was killed by the police. The renovations include raised walls, new glass barriers and electrified wires to keep the animals from trying to escape. Before the improvements, the exhibit’s walls were about four feet lower than national guidelines suggested. The renovations raise the walls to the recommended height of 16.4 feet.
It is impossible to believe claims by many tobacco companies that they are not trying to addict new smokers but only to convert adults who are using inferior local brands.
I could barely watch Ida, one of our mares, at the veterinarian’s. I don’t quite understand how we got from that terrible place to where we were half an hour later.
The English Premier League’s plan for its 20 teams to play an extra league game outside England, a scheme that could be dubbed Plan 39 from Outer Space, gained a grain of support Monday.
If you decide to go to a doctor or hospital outside your insurance plan’s network of providers, experts suggest keeping a few things in mind.
Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.
A retired New York police sergeant was shot to death by his wife on Monday morning during a domestic dispute at their home in Howard Beach.
The suicide rate among 45-to-54-year-olds increased nearly 20 percent from 1999 to 2004.
Many at The Los Angeles Times are skeptical of David D. Hiller, saying he doesn’t understand journalism.
It is common in this country for under-age girls engaged in prostitution to be arrested, even though it is a serious crime for an adult to have sex with a minor.
Jason West, the first member of the Green Party to be elected mayor in New York State, now sleeps on a friend’s floor, but says he hasn’t compromised his ideals.
From the Siemens bribery investigation to the prosecution of illicit conduct at Volkswagen, the German business world is undergoing a painful national cleansing process.
A Russian dive that was the basis of a claim to nearly half of the Arctic seabed had American origins.
Commercial education companies are offering student loans as they scramble to ensure a steady stream of college-level students amid the credit squeeze.
A permit to dock a boat is one of the last real estate bargains in Manhattan. Despite complaints, the city has agreed to grant new permits for the 79th Street Boat Basin by next year.
The senators are pushing their party further from the business-friendly posture championed by Bill Clinton.
Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado believes that his forgettable statistics in 2007 were a result of his stubbornness and a mechanical flaw, not the start of a decline or slow hands.
Despite fears of impromptu inspections, two sweeps of a total of 33 contractors in Suffolk County only produced one worker without proper documents.
Eric Gagné, who was accused in the Mitchell report of purchasing human growth hormone in 2004, tackled the issue Monday the way a pitcher nibbles at the corners of the plate.
The 16th-ranked Drake Bulldogs have clinched their first Missouri Valley Conference regular-season title since 1971, which is also the last time they qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament.
Former President George Bush’s endorsement of John McCain was just the latest chapter in the sometimes-tangled saga of their families’ dynasties.
Barack Obama said he should have credited Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, a friend, for a passage in a recent speech, but added that his rival was “carrying it too far.”
For a while it looked as if New York would have two candidates in the presidential election, maybe three if Michael R. Bloomberg jumped in, but it may be none.
The Italian tennis player Giorgio Galimberti was suspended for 100 days and fined $35,000 Monday for betting on matches.
The shuttle Atlantis has cleared the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite.
Over the years, confrontations with drivers have done nothing but reinforce Kurt Busch’s bad-boy reputation. But Ryan Newman had Busch to thank for his Daytona 500 victory on Sunday.
Wall Street deal makers were shocked by statements in a letter to investors from Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management.
Elaine Joyce, a champion amateur golfer, and her father were not allowed to play in a tournament at the Dennis Pines course because the tournament was not open to women.
The revelation that Steven P. Kazmierczak stopped taking Prozac before fatally shooting five college students and himself is likely to fuel the debate over the drug’s risks and benefits.
The United Nations is worried that refugee camps, which are home to an estimated 100,000 people in East Timor, are a growing source of security problems and aid dependency for the country.
Mr. Roberts was a prominent arbitrator best known for his ruling that major league baseball owners had improperly colluded to prevent free-agent players from obtaining richer contracts.
Speaking publicly for the first time about his preference for surgery, Curt Schilling said he had to follow the team’s insistence on rehab because he was under contract.
The initiative is a significant shift for Amtrak, which has had relatively little visible increase in security since the 2001 terrorist attacks
The decision to scrap the expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Center by the Spitzer administration has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other officials.
Jeffrey T. Schwartz, a criminal lawyer, is faced with defending the stepfather of Nixzmary Brown in one of the city’s most notorious child murder case’s in recent history.

PLAYER Angelica Figueroa, a 17-year-old senior at Linden High School in California, is hoping to land a spot on Mexico’s women’s national team when it plays qualifying matches for the Beijing Olympics at a regional tournament April 2-13 in Juarez, Mexico. Two of the six teams in the tournament will advance to the Summer Games in August. Figueroa was born in the United States, but her parents are from Mexico. She is expected to be with the Mexican team Friday when it plays Southern California, the N.C.A.A. champion, in Los Angeles.
Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year.
On Monday a general strike called by ethnic minorities demanding more rights created a fuel shortage that caused schools to close and many buses to stop running in Katmandu.
The BBC World Service, which began its shortwave transmissions 75 years ago, ended its English-language shortwave services in Europe on Monday.
Mr. Oats was president of the Flushing Meadows-Corona Park World’s Fair Association, a civic group he started in 1967.
Mr. Phillips Jr. was a retired Civil Court judge who owned theaters in Brooklyn that were a prominent platform for black activists in the 1980s.
European stocks rose Monday on speculation about a new investment in the banking sector. Asian markets were mixed, and United States markets were closed.

In the middle of the first act of a packed English National Opera performance of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” on Saturday, a chest infection claimed the voice of the bass Clive Bayley, who was singing the leading role of Raimondo, Lucia’s tutor. Could the show be saved? Yes indeed, Reuters reported. Out from the audience came Paul Whelan, 38, who just happened to have been studying the role and was scheduled to take over from Mr. Bayley in a few weeks, through he had had no chance to rehearse. As the performance continued, Mr. Whelan sang from the wings and Mr. Bayley mimed the action. At the conclusion Mr. Whelan, wearing suit and tie, joined the cast for a bow onstage, above. The performers received a standing ovation. “I’m just so glad I was wearing my Armani tie,” he said.

Jude Law, Colin Farrell and Johnny Depp, from left above, will replace Heath Ledger, above right, in the film he was starring in when he died last month, Ain’t It Cool News reported. The future of the $30 million film, “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” a morality tale directed by Terry Gilliam, was thrown in doubt halfway through shooting when Mr. Ledger died of an accidental drug overdose. In the film — which a synopsis says is about a traveling theater troupe that tempts its audiences with the chance to “transcend mundane reality by passing through a magical mirror into a fantastic universe of limitless imagination” — Mr. Ledger was playing a character who is transported into three separate dimensions. These will now be inhabited, instead, by Mr. Depp, Mr. Law and Mr. Farrell.
“Black Watch” is coming back this fall for another limited engagement at St. Ann’s, from Oct. 9 to Nov. 30.

Dedication ceremonies are to be held on Wednesday for the Sheila C. Johnson Design Center for Parsons the New School of Design. The 32,800-square foot campus center, designed by Lyn Rice Architects and made possible in part by a $7 million gift from Sheila C. Johnson, a New School trustee and Parsons governor, combines learning and public program spaces with exhibition galleries at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 13th Street in Greenwich Village.

“The Great Debaters” was a big winner at the 39th N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards ceremonies, Variety reported. The film, about the ascent of a debate team from a small all-black college in the 1930s, captured honors for best film, actor (Denzel Washington, who was also its director), actress (Jurnee Smollett) and supporting actor (Denzel Whitaker). Janet Jackson was named outstanding supporting actress for her performance in “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” In the ceremonies at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, “Talk to Me,” a tale of the symbiotic relationship of two men, was honored for its script, by Michael Genet and Rick Famuyiwa, and its direction, by Kasi Lemmons.

DVD copies of the movie “Rambo,” starring and directed by Sylvester Stallone, below, are much in demand in Myanmar but very had to find, Agence France-Presse reported. That is because the police there have banned the film, in which Mr. Stallone portrays a Vietnam War veteran battling soldiers of the military junta that rules the country. “Police have warned me I could go to jail for up to seven years if I sell the latest Rambo film,” said a DVD vendor who declined to be identified. Another seller said that at least 20 customers asked for it every day. One democracy advocate, who declined to say how he obtained a copy, said, “I watched the movie at home with my family and gave it to my friends because I wanted them to see it.”.

The Clint Eastwood film “Letters From Iwo Jima,” about the lives and deaths of Japanese soldiers in the battle for Iwo Jima in World War II, was named best foreign film at the 31st Japan Academy Awards ceremony on Friday in Tokyo, Variety reported. Joji Matsuoka’s “Tokyo Tower: Mom and Me, and Sometimes Dad,” about a mother-son relationship, took the prizes for best film, best director, best actress (Kiki Kirin as the dying mother), best supporting actor (Kaoru Kobayashi as the absent father) and best screenplay (Masuo Suzuki). Hidetaka Yoshioka, who won the best actor prize in 2006 for his performance as a struggling novelist in “Always,” won again for reprising the role in the nostalgic drama “Always 2.”.

Paul McCartney and Heather Mills had their chance, and now it is up to a judge to determine a divorce agreement and financial settlement for them, The Associated Press reported. As legal teams left the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Monday after no deal was reached between the parties, Mr. McCartney’s lawyer, Nicholas Mostyn, said that Justice Hugh Bennett had reserved his ruling and would spend several weeks working out a settlement. Ms. Mills smiled as she departed. Mr. McCartney did not attend. The terms of a settlement will not become public unless it is challenged in the Court of Appeal or if one of the parties elects to disclose its contents. The couple, who separated in 2006 after four years of marriage, went to court to decide how much of Mr. McCartney’s fortune, estimated to be as high as $1.6 billion, Ms. Mills would receive.

WELT--Maurice, 90, died peacefully at home on February 16, surrounded by his wife and family. Born in New York City in 1917, he had been a long-time resident of Glen Cove and Sands Point, New York, and more recently of Greenwich, CT. Mr. Welt worked for 45 years in the New York graphic arts industry. He was hired by Crafton Graphic, Inc., in 1937 as an opaquer and retired as the company's president in 1982. Upon his retirement, Crafton, a national award-winning lithography company, was sold to the Finnish newspaper publisher Sonoma. During his tenure, Mr. Welt produced official portraits of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. He also printed posters for Mobil's Masterpiece Theatre and for the artist Ben Shahn. Mr. Welt remained a lifelong member of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America. He served on the board of directors of the National Association of Photo-Lithographers and of the Metropolitan Lithographers' Association. Mr. Welt played leadership roles in Jewish organizations, in the Democratic Party, and in community life. He served on the Glen Cove Zoning Board of Appeals. He was a member of Governor Robert Wagner's Committee on Scholastic Achievement as well as the board of directors of the Long Island Philharmonic Society and the Nassau County chapter of the American Heart Association. He was treasurer of the local chapter of B'nai B'rith; a trustee of Temple Tifereth Israel in Glen Cove for 10 years, serving a term as president of its board of trustees; and a passionate fund raiser for Israel's bond drives and other Jewish causes. He served most recently as an associate trustee of North Shore University Hospital, where he had been a committed emergency room volunteer, and on the board of directors of the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation. Mr. Welt, the son of the late Simon and Rose Welt, is survived by his wife of 68 years, Evelyn Levy Welt; his daughters Corinne Welt Garland (Charles) of Williamsburg, VA, and Rissa Welt Grossman (Richard) of Greenwich, CT; grandchildren David Garland, Allison Garland, Robert Garland, Jeffrey Grossman, Matthew Grossman, Sharon Herzog, and Sabra Kelly; nine great grandchildren; and by his sister, Anne Goodman, of Boca Raton, FL.

JAFFE--Ernst R., M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns with great sorrow the loss of our beloved Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Medicine (Hematology) and Senior Associate Dean Emeritus. He came to Einstein as a postdoctoral research fellow when the College opened in 1955, and for more than a half-century our medical school has been the fortunate recipient of his scientific talent and creativity and his thoughtful, humane and compassionate leadership. He was among the most devoted, selfless and dedicated members of our community, willing to assume any role that was important to advancing the mission of our College of Medicine, its faculty and its students. A gentleman at all times, his equanimity, his soft-spoken manner and sense of fairness endeared him to one and all. He was named Professor of Medicine in 1969 and a year later became Einstein's first Chief of the Division of Hematology, a position he held until 1982. He twice served as interim Dean of the medical school, from 1972-1974, and from 1983-1984. He also served the medical school as Senior Associate Dean, Associate Dean for Faculty, and Director of our Belfer Institute for Advanced Biomedical Studies. Dr. Jaffe was widely recognized as one of the founders of modern hematology. He was the quintessential clinician and investigator-scholar, and made significant contributions to the understanding of hereditary anemias due to enzyme deficiencies and hereditary methemoglobinemia. One of the best-known hematologists in the country, he served as President of the American Society of Hematology; Editor-in-Chief of Blood, the Journal of Hematology; and Co-Editor of Seminars in Hematology. Albert Einstein College of Medicine was built on the shoulders of giants. Dr. Ernst Jaffe was one of those giants. His kindly and gracious presence in our lives is already greatly missed. We extend our very deepest condolences to his beloved wife of 57 years, Jayne; his daughter, Stephanie Anne Jaffe Green, M.D., Einstein Class of 1981, and her husband, Stephen; his son, Richard Jaffe and his wife Gwendolyn; and grandchildren Andrew, Christopher, Cortland, and Caroline. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Ruth L. Gottesman, Ed.D. Chair, Board of Overseers Edward R. Burns, M.D. Executive Dean

8 P.M. (13, 49) APE GENIUS In search of a meal, a female chimpanzee in Senegal breaks off a branch and chews the end to sharpen it -- after which she skewers a bush baby hiding inside a tree. Elsewhere, a chimp and a human toddler are taught the same technique for obtaining a piece of candy, only the chimp masters it more quickly. These are just a couple of findings about ape behavior that are causing scientists to rethink the intellects of chimpanzees, bonobos (like the one above), gorillas and orangutans. This ''Nova'' episode examines some of these discoveries, which are illuminating the differences between great apes and humans, and explores why apes never made the breakthrough into a human-style culture that builds on the achievements of past generations. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER: COUPLES The contestants are sent home to visit their loved ones for the first time since arriving at the ranch. But that doesn't mean the dieting and workouts will stop.

You and Shelby, always there for anyone who needed you. Your goodness lives in our hearts. Noreen and H. Robert Greenbaum

UDEL--Jane Manna, died peacefully at home among family and friends on February 8, 2008. A native New Yorker, Ms. Udel studied at Hunter and Smith Colleges, earning an M.A. in English. Devoted Mother, ardent feminist, erudite reader and poet, she loved politics and music. Mourned by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and sister Eleanor Parker. We will miss her outrage at social injustice, her wonderful sense of humor, and her unfailing compassion.
RIZZO--Raymond, 2/19/2007. Hey, pardner! Slim and Jake sure do miss you. You never lost my heart. Your loving daughter

BELKIN--Selma, 91, loving mother of Linda Belkin and Salo (deceased), grand daughter of Rabbi Bernard Louis Leventhal, Chief Rabbi of Philadelphia, grandmother of Tamara Wagner (Stephen) and Alan Schuchalter (Rachel), great-grandmother of ten, great-great-grandmother of one. Service Plaza Memorial Chapel, Tuesday at 9:30am. Burial in Philadelphia.

LIBERMAN--Muriel ''Mickey'', passed away suddenly February 16, 2008. Born in New York on March 22, 1921, adored wife of Saul Liberman, husband of 66 wonderful years, New York state scholarship winner and Cornell graduate. She was a patron of the arts, theater, museums, Philharmonic, ballet and Channel 13. She led a book club and a bridge group, traveled widely, studied history and maintained an avid interest in politics, carrying on her family's commitment to the Democratic Party, which began with Tammany Hall in the 1920s. She is also survived by her three loving sons, Donald, James, and Robert; 11 grandchildren; and seven great-grandchildren. Memorial service Eden Memorial Chapels, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee, NJ, February 19, 2008, at 2pm.

The father and brother of David Tarloff, who was under evaluation at Bellevue Hospital Center after his arrest in the killing of a psychologist, Kathryn Faughey, on the Upper East Side last week, recounted his long struggle with a mental illness. The family had dealt with a mental health system that, in general, prohibits patients from being hospitalized against their will unless they have been proven to be dangerous to themselves or to others. Eric Konigsberg and Ann Farmer describe an ordeal that began with Mr. Tarloff’s diagnosis of schizophrenia 17 years ago. The psychiatrist who made the diagnosis, Kent D. Shinbach, was critically injured when Mr. Tarloff went to his office last week and fatally stabbed his colleague, Kathryn Faughey, a psychologist.
