Several readers have pointed out the importance of Johnna, the Cheyenne woman whom Beverly hires to keep house at the beginning of the play - and in whose arms Violet takes comfort at its very end. Since we get to know the Westons through their pathologies and their acid tongues, it's easy to ignore the other woman in the house: she's kind to everyone, stays in the background and is all but mute in most of her scenes. But, as Paul Gambaccini points out in a comment, she is essential to the symmetry of the play. In the prologue, Beverly quotes T.S. Eliot's poem "The Hollow Men" to her: "Life is very long." And in that final scene, when Violet has finally driven the last of her daughters away, Johnna sings to her from the last lines of the same poem: "This is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends." (Eliot's punchline, not spoken in the play but entirely relevant: "Not with a bang but a whimper.")

After all my anticipation and anxiety, jury duty came and went in a flash. Day 1 was interesting. And short. I arrived at 60 Centre Street at 8:45 a.m. along with throngs of fellow citizens and took my seat. The clerks who run the jury process -- two women so polished they could play their roles in "Jury Duty, the Movie" -- began orientation with a list of rules. They sprinkled their instructions with more than a few well-placed one-liners. "Do not remove any articles of clothing below the waist." "Never put your face to the water-fountain fixture. We have cups." "Never abandon your possessions; we have had thefts." My neighbor leaned in and whispered to me, "If they say it, it's happened." We bonded. She agreed to be the trusted buddy whom Clerk #1 advised us to find, available to watch my possessions should I need to use the restroom. I offered the same back.

Fareed Zakaria's forthcoming book, "The Post-American World," tackles big issues - globalization, the rise of China and India, the decline of American hegemony - sometimes by looking at small facts. In a couple of pages, Zakaria discusses the relationship between modernity and clothing, particularly women's clothing. "Not surprisingly," he writes, "the Muslim world has the biggest problems with its women wearing Western-style clothes. It is also the region where women remain the farthest behind by any objective yardstick." Zakaria has less to say about men's styles, but the connections he draws between politics and clothes made me think of a photograph of one of the Republican presidential debates that appeared in The New York Times last December.

Bangkok has lots of great food stalls. And those who live in the city know that the capital also has very good Italian food. It was only a matter of time before the city spawned the Italian food stall. Jo-Joe Pasta opened last year and has what I firmly believe is the best spaghetti with tomato sauce east of the Adriatic. That's debatable, says my wife. But you won't argue over the price: 65 baht, or just under $2 a plate. Other pasta dishes - penne with seafood, garlic and chili, for example - cost slightly more: 95 baht. Chef Joe has the right credentials: he used to work at Gianni's one of the better and long-standing Italian restaurants in Bangkok. Bring your own bottle of wine to Jo-Joe Pasta (no corkage!) They also have beer for 55 or 65 baht a bottle. There's no sign but it's easy to find, just off the corner of Lang Suan Soi 5 and Soi Tonson in the Ploenchit area (motorcycle taxis available on the corner of Tonson and Ploenchit, near BTS Chidlom). Open, lunch and dinner every day but Sunday. Last order at 9pm.

The many moving parts of the mission began after the shuttle landed, though rough seas could delay the launch.
Saint Peter’s College was evacuated after the school received a note that Jeremiah Healey, the mayor of Jersey City, described as “troubling.”
Federal Reserve policy makers are forecasting slower economic growth, higher unemployment and higher inflation.
The Supreme Court ruled that the manufacturer of a federally approved medical device cannot be sued under state law if the device causes an injury.
Oil futures rallied again Wednesday, pushing briefly past $101 a barrel after the Fed lowered its forecast for economic growth this year.
Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain both went on the offensive against Barack Obama after his victories in Wisconsin and Hawaii on Tuesday.
In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court said Maine cannot impose a regulatory scheme on transportation companies delivering tobacco products directly to consumers.
In an 8-to-1 decision, the Supreme Court made it harder for consumers to sue manufacturers of federally approved medical devices.
With decisive victories in Wisconsin and Hawaii, Barack Obama cut into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s support among women.
A new inflation report raised concerns that the Federal Reserve will back away from cutting interest rates again.
The shuttle ended a challenging 13-day mission to deliver a major new section to the International Space Station.
On Tuesday night, the Knicks seemed rested and energized, going on a 19-1 run spanning the fourth quarter and overtime in beating the Wizards.
Rafer Alston scored 22 points, Yao Ming added 16 points and 14 rebounds, and the Houston Rockets tied a team record Tuesday with their ninth road victory in a row, 93-85 over the Cleveland Cavaliers.
Matee Ajavon powered Rutgers with 15 points and 7 assists in its hard-earned triumph over No. 14 Notre Dame, which had won its previous five games.
The Japanese electronics giant threw in the towel on its HD DVD technology, announcing that it would no longer develop, produce or market disc players for the format.
Airbus, the European plane maker, said on Wednesday that it expected orders for new aircraft to halve to around 700 this year after a record order intake in 2007.

An article on Saturday about discrepancies in the vote count in New York’s Democratic primary misstated the role of Jerome A. Koenig, a former chief of staff to the State Assembly’s Election Law Committee. He is an adviser to Senator Barack Obama’s campaign, not a lawyer for the campaign.

Because of an editing error, a dance entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstated the date of Fluid hug-hug’s final performance at the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival. The troupe’s final performance was Sunday; it is not this Sunday.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about Qatar’s plans to invest in Credit Suisse and other European and American banks misstated Credit Suisse’s fourth-quarter earnings report and its write-down of assets because of soured American investments in debt and leveraged loans. It has written down $1.2 billion, not $13.7 billion, and it earned 1.33 billion Swiss francs in the fourth quarter — it did not lose 12.5 billion Swiss francs. The article also misstated the date of the earnings report. It was Feb. 12, not Thursday. (The figures cited were for another large Swiss Bank, UBS.).

An article on Saturday about grief on campus after the shootings at Northern Illinois University misstated the course of study in graduate school of the gunman, Steve P. Kazmierczak. He had been a graduate student in social work at the University of Illinois — not sociology, his undergraduate major at N.I.U.

An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie — as a United States attorney — awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christie’s former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract.

A sports article on Friday about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens over the use of performance-enhancing drugs misidentified the investigators to whom Mr. McNamee revealed that he had injected Mr. Clemens’s wife with human growth hormone. They were Congressional investigators, not Mr. Clemens’s investigators.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about President Bush’s role in Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign referred incorrectly to the campaign position of Mercer Reynolds, a Cincinnati businessman. As a national finance co-chairman, Mr. Reynolds is one of several people raising money for Mr. McCain; he is not leading the fund-raising effort. (That position is held by former Representative Tom Loeffler of Texas, the national finance chairman.).

A chart on Sunday listing Democratic superdelegates who are supporting a candidate other than the one who won their state or Congressional district erroneously included Representative Bill Pascrell Jr. of New Jersey, a superdelegate who supports Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mr. Pascrell’s district was won by Mrs. Clinton, not by Senator Barack Obama.
A music review on Monday of ****** Jeans at the Silent Barn in Queens misidentified the bassist. He is Randy Huth — not Dave Rosenstrauss, who left the band.

An article on Friday about the Food and Drug Administration breaking its own rules by not inspecting a plant in China that made the active ingredient of a blood-thinning drug misspelled part of the name of the company that founded American Capital Strategies Ltd., the majority owner of Scientific Protein Laboratories, which owns the plant. It is Oscar Mayer, not Meyer.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births misstated the meaning of the term “vanishing twin.” It is a miscarriage of one twin, not a fetus eliminated in a medical procedure called a reduction.

An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie — as a United States attorney — awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christie’s former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract.
With decisive victories in Wisconsin and Hawaii, Barack Obama cut into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s support among women and union members.
Texas as a whole is booming, but across the state’s outermost exurbs, building has ground almost to a halt.
David Tarloff’s father and his brother, Robert, describe his sudden and precipitous descent into illness and their own dealings with the mental health system.
A diagnosis of schizophrenia and repeated commitments to mental institutions might seem like obvious qualifications for an insanity defense — or maybe not.
The actions of a key figure in a controversy over destroyed interrogation tapes show the C.I.A.’s protective instinct.

A military contractor was sentenced to 12 years in federal prison for bribing former Representative Randy Cunningham with cash, trips and other gifts in exchange for nearly $90 million in Pentagon work. The contractor, Brent Wilkes, 53, was convicted in November on 13 counts of bribery, conspiracy and wire fraud. Prosecutors argued during a three-week trial that Mr. Wilkes lavished Mr. Cunningham with more than $700,000 in perks. In return, they said, Mr. Cunningham helped him secure $87 million in Pentagon contracts. Mr. Cunningham, an eight-term Republican congressman, is serving eight years and four months in federal prison.

State education officials voted to add evolution to the required course work in public schools, but only after a last-minute change depicting Darwin’s seminal work as merely a theory. Bending to pressure from religious conservatives, the State Board of Education, on a 4-to-3 vote, included the “theory” language as part of a retooling of the state’s science standards for public school education. The compromise would require teaching that Darwin’s proposal that life evolved over billions of years is a theory that has yet to be proved conclusively. The panel includes the word “evolution” in state science standards for the first time, but it is relegated to a number of ideas including Einstein’s theory of relativity. Newton’s law of gravity is taught as fact.

A school bus and several other vehicles crashed in Cottonwood, leaving at least three people dead and more than a dozen injured, the authorities said. Forty students were on the bus when it crashed about two hours southwest of Minneapolis, a spokeswoman for Avera Marshall Regional Medical Center said. The Marshall Independent newspaper said the first motorists on the scene were asked to take some children to the hospital.
Hasheem Thabeet had 16 points, 13 rebounds and 8 blocked shots and No. 13 Connecticut rallied from a 13-point deficit to beat DePaul, 65-60, Tuesday night.

A man who sold Civil War relics that included munitions was killed by an explosion. The body of the relics dealer, Samuel H. White, 53, was found in his Chesterfield County backyard by neighbors who had heard the blast, the police said. Capt. Steve Neal said that what exploded was military ordnance, possibly dating from the Civil War.
Federal prosecutors have widened their criminal case involving questionable tax shelters at the accounting firm Ernst & Young, adding two outside defendants.
NASA has chosen two aerospace companies to develop a commercial spaceship capable of flying cargo to the International Space Station.
Nancy Reagan, 86, has been released from a hospital two days after falling at her Los Angeles home. Doctors determined that she had not broken a hip.

A National Guardsman was one of two men sentenced to at least three years in federal prison for helping smuggle illegal immigrants through a Border Patrol checkpoint. The National Guardsman, Sgt. Clarence Hodge Jr., 36, of Fort Worth, and Jerry Zuniga, 29, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to transport illegal immigrants. Mr. Hodge was sentenced to 38 months, and Mr. Zuniga, of Laredo, to three years in prison.
Shannon Veal, the star point guard for Glen Oaks High School, collapsed and died during a game on Monday night. She was 17.

The body of a 16-year-old girl was found hanging in the woods in the Welsh village of Bridgend, and the authorities said it was the 17th suicide among youngsters in the area since the beginning of last year. No evidence has been found of a suicide pact or a cult, the police said.

Washington’s envoy on the North Korean nuclear issue, Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill, met in Beijing with Kim Kye-gwan, who leads the North Korean negotiating team, for the first time in two months. Mr. Hill said that they had “a good, substantial discussion” but that there was no breakthrough. North Korea’s disarmament process has come to a virtual halt over differences on whether the country has fully accounted for its nuclear programs.

The military junta declared that a new draft of the country’s constitution had been completed after 14 years and approved for a national referendum in May. It will clear the way for democratic elections in 2010, the junta says, the first since 1990, when the opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party, the National League for Democracy, won a landslide victory that the junta never recognized. Foreign Minister Nyan Win told a regional gathering in Singapore that the document would bar Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi from running because she had been married to a foreigner, a Briton who died in 1999. She remains under house arrest in Yangon.

The Environmental Protection Administration said water quality was barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam and in the upper reaches of the Yangtze, although the water does meet national standards for drinking, fisheries and swimming. Water quality is worsening in several branches of the Yangtze that drain into the main reservoir, the agency said in a water management plan, echoing previous government documents. The dam has slowed the flow of the Yangtze, and that reduces the ability of the river and its tributaries to flush out polluted areas.
The schoolyard will be redesigned to help relieve the dark memories of last August’s murder.

A Japanese naval destroyer collided with a two-man fishing boat in waters near Tokyo, apparently slicing the smaller craft in two, Japan’s military said. No survivors from the fishing boat have been found. The authorities are investigating why the ultra-modern warship’s crew and sophisticated Aegis radar systems had not seen the fishing boat.

A car bomb exploded near a police compound in the city of Kandahar, killing one civilian and wounding four, a police official said. It was the third attack in Kandahar Province in three days. More than 100 people were killed by a suicide bomber just outside Kandahar City on Sunday, and 38 died Monday at a market near the Pakistan border in a suicide car bomb explosion. The death toll made the bombings the deadliest spate of militant attacks in post-Taliban Afghanistan. The blasts might also indicate that insurgents are now willing to inflict high civilian casualties to weaken the government in Kabul.

The United States military indefinitely imposed tight restrictions on all personnel in Okinawa, limiting troops to bases, places of work or off-base housing, amid a furor over the arrest of a marine on suspicion of raping a junior high school girl on Feb. 10 and of several other marines on less serious charges since the weekend. The new restrictions tighten a midnight curfew and bar military personnel from leaving their bases except for official business, work, worship or travel to and from off-base housing.
MBIA replaced its chief executive with its retired chairman, Joseph W. Brown Jr., who said he would consider splitting up the firm’s insurance business.
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia bought portions of Emeril Lagasse’s franchise for $45 million in cash and $5 million in stock, her company’s first major acquisition.

Michael Ryder and Alex Kovalev each scored twice and the Montreal Canadiens staged the biggest comeback in their storied history, rallying from five goals down and beating the Rangers, 6-5, in a shootout Tuesday night.
As municipal bond auctions fail, it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.
Dozens of safety violations were found at the former Deutsche Bank tower near ground zero where two firefighters died in a blaze.

A possible unification of America’s two open-wheel series was still on track, with both sides saying Tuesday progress was being made. David Higdon, a spokesman for the Champ Car World Series, said discussions were “heating up.” Fred Nation, a spokesman for the Indy Racing League, said I.R.L. officials remained optimistic an agreement could be reached. Each series has struggled for fans, sponsors and TV ratings since the I.R.L., founded by Tony George, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway president, began competition in 1995.

The Indiana Fever acquired Katie Douglas, an All-Star forward and an Indianapolis native, in a trade with the Connecticut Sun. The Fever sent forward Tamika Whitmore, the 12th pick in this year’s W.N.B.A. draft and the rights to the former Duke guard Jessica Foley to the Sun. The trade came at Douglas’s request. Douglas, 28, was a star for Purdue and led the Boilermakers to the N.C.A.A. title in 1999. She averaged 17.0 points, 4.6 rebounds and 3.7 assists last season for the Sun and was a second-team All-W.N.B.A. guard.

The American Lindsey Vonn had the fastest time in training in Whistler, British Columbia, on Tuesday for this week’s World Cup downhill as skiers got their first look at the course that will be used for the 2010 Vancouver Olympics. Vonn, who has won four of seven World Cup downhills this season, including the opener at Lake Louise in Canada, charged down the course in 1 minute 46.54 seconds. Canada’s Britt Janyk was second fastest in 1:46.67, followed by the Frenchwoman Marie Marchand-Arvier.

Lindsay Davenport was taken by the Newport Beach Breakers with the top pick in the World TeamTennis marquee player draft. Davenport, who is back on the WTA tour after giving birth to her first child in June, will be playing her eighth WTT season. Andy Roddick was the second choice in the draft, going to the St. Louis Aces. Other top players selected included Serena Williams, taken by the new Washington Kastles; her sister Venus, drafted by the Philadelphia Freedoms; and Martina Navratilova, headed to the Boston Lobsters.

Liverpool scored twice in the final six minutes to defeat visiting Inter Milan, 2-0, in the first knockout round of the European Champions League. A.S. Roma and Schalke also won first-leg matches at home.Dirk Kuyt scored in the 85th minute and Steven Gerrard added a goal in the 90th for Liverpool, which is in fifth place in the English Premier League and was eliminated from the F.A. Cup last weekend by Barnsley, a 14th-place team in the League Championship, which is one level below the Premier League.Inter played the final 60 minutes a man short after Marco Materazzi was ejected for receiving his second yellow card — both for fouls against Liverpool striker Fernando Torres. During the 2006 World Cup final, Materazzi drew the head butt that led to the ejection of France’s Zinédene Zidane, and Italy went on to win on penalty kicks. In other games, Roma rallied to beat Real Madrid, 2-1; Schalke defeated Porto, 1-0; and Chelsea tied, 0-0, at Olympiakos in Greece. Wednesday’s schedule has the defending champion A.C. Milan at Arsenal, the 2006 champion Barcelona at Glasgow Celtic, Manchester United at Lyon and Sevilla at Fenerbahce.
The man who killed five students at Northern Illinois University and himself on Thursday took steps to hide his tracks and conceal his motive.
The strategy of Cesar Rodriguez’s defense in the case of the murder of his stepdaughter Nixzmary Brown has been to try to shift focus onto Nixzaliz Santiago, the girl’s mother.
The retailer said net income in the fourth quarter rose to $4.1 billion as its focus on low prices paid off. International growth also helped lift profit and sales.
Lawmakers in New Jersey and in Washington should expressly bar the use of campaign contributions to pay legal bills.
Deciphering the depth and breadth of the New England Patriots’ electronic taping habits still largely rests with a former video assistant being prodded to talk from several angles.
In part of a hard-nosed takeover campaign that Microsoft began two weeks ago, the company has begun preparing for a proxy fight to oust Yahoo’s directors.
Barack Obama’s success at fund-raising is tempting him to back away from accepting public financing in the general election.
After years of futile attempts at replacing the defective gene that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy, researchers are now more intent on overriding the gene.
Severe crimes committed by the rebels during the war will be tried under a special division of the country’s High Court, according to the agreement.
The temptation for lawmakers to pander to the gun lobby is never-ending, and 47 senators are on record in favor of tolerating loaded weapons in the parks.
After two days of sprint finishes by a largely intact peloton, the Tour of California will receive a sharp jolt Wednesday, when the route includes two significant climbs.
President Bush must reach out to Pakistan’s newly elected leaders, many of whom resent the U.S. for its uncritical support of the former general, Pervez Musharraf.
H.P.’s first-quarter net income grew 38 percent to $2.1 billion, as revenue climbed 13 percent to $28.5 billion, beating the muted expectations of Wall Street analysts.
In the last week, Senator John McCain has increasingly been taking on Senator Barack Obama at campaign events. And now their wives seem to be entering the fray.
After weathering days of criticism from Germany over a spectacular tax evasion case, Liechtenstein is digging in to defend its lucrative tradition of banking secrecy.
For the first time this year, Tiger Woods, Phil Mickelson, Steve Stricker and Ernie Els are playing at the same time — but all could be gone after one round.
A former music director at a Greenwich church who was convicted of possessing child pornography hired a pedophile and failed to tell the authorities when that man sexually assaulted a choirboy.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges against Phillip R. Bennett, former chief executive of the commodities broker Refco Inc.
The Netherlands-based Corporate Express rejected an unsolicited $3.67 billion buyout offer from Staples as too low, but some analysts expect an eventual agreement.
A frantic search for four stolen paintings led to a most unlikely place: the parking lot of a mental hospital just a few hundred yards from the scene of the crime.
Consumer groups are criticizing the government’s handling of problems with Sears kitchen ranges in an effort to pressure legislators to toughen safety laws.
The ethics of one of the top aides inside Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s office, Sean Patrick Maloney, have come under scrutiny.
A lawyer accused of paying the private detective Anthony Pellicano to tap telephone calls on behalf of financier Kirk Kerkorian will have his trial separated from Mr. Pellicano’s.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s accusations of plagiarism against Barack Obama revived questions about Bill Clinton’s 1993 Inaugural Address.
Before the polls even opened in Wisconsin, the Democratic contenders had moved on to campaign in Texas and Ohio, the two next big prizes on the primary calendar.
Steven Register, who led the minor leagues in saves last season, joined the Mets by way of the Rule 5 draft, meaning he must make the 25-man roster or be offered back to the Rockies.
When the San Diego Minutemen “adopted”a stretch of highway, including a Border Patrol checkpoint, complaints from immigrant advocacy groups were swift and strong.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine is weighing eliminating the Department of Personnel and pushing for an early retirement package — not layoffs — to save tens of millions of dollars.
Skeet Reese, a former nightclub dancer, was audacious long before he became 2007 Angler of the Year on the Bassmasters Tour and set himself as the standard in the sport.
A trial widely seen as a test of the the impartiality of Iraq’s judicial system got off to an inauspicious start on Tuesday.
Leaving jobs at global giants, small miners are striking out for Mexico’s Sierra Madre mountains.
Miguel Tejada refused to answer any of the questions about the Mitchell report, preferring to discuss baseball and his fresh start with the Houston Astros.
New development on the Tejon Ranch has environmentalists concerned about the health of a fragile landscape, where several distinct ecological regions converge.
The report claims that New Jersey’s civil union law “creates a second-class status” for same-sex couples.
NBC Universal’s move to a year-round schedule of staggered program debuts could alter an American cultural cycle that dates to the days of radio.
A program, the Juvenile Justice Initiative, sends medium-risk offenders back to their families and provides intensive therapy.
The Phoenix Suns plumped up their middle by adding center Shaquille O’Neal, to the mortification of many denizens of Phoenix who pride themselves on not being superficial.
A new report shows that even as Congress presses wealthy colleges and universities to spend more of their endowments, they continue on a fund-raising streak.
The reporter, Toni Locy, faces fines of up to $5,000 a day for refusing to reveal sources for her reporting of a 2002 anthrax case.
The Mets’ stunning collapse last season, combined with its acquisition of Johan Santana, prompted owner Fred Wilpon to issue his boldest spring declaration in recent years.
Having forgotten what managers other than Joe Torre sound like, some longtime Yankees are wondering what Joe Girardi will say when he holds his first team-wide clubhouse meeting.
TVT Records, long ranked as a top independent label, was hit last year with a $9.1 million court judgment over the release of old recordings of the rapper Pitbull.
LOS ANGELES (Reuters) — The apparel company Gap Inc. said on Tuesday that the president of its Old Navy division, Dawn Robertson, was leaving, effective immediately.
A union is trying to force nonprofit groups like hospitals to comply with standards of governing similar to those that federal law requires of private companies.
Justices on the Supreme Court seek to carve more exceptions out of the exclusionary rule, which forbids the use of evidence obtained as the result of an improper search.
For more than 30 years Mr. Savada’s second-floor store in Manhattan, Records Revisited, was a haven for die-hard record collectors.
Credit Suisse shook the markets on Tuesday when it announced that pricing errors by traders on asset-backed securities would result in write-downs of $2.85 billion.
The Santuario de Chimayo, a small adobe church in Chimayo, N.M., is known as the Lourdes of America.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said OTB could not operate without taxpayer subsidies and that the city simply could not take dollars away from schools and hospitals to pay for a gambling operation.
The contents of the site, whose goal is to discourage "unethical behavior" by corporations and governments, can still be found on "mirror sites" around the Internet.
The poor could have a harder time moving up the income ladder as the higher education gap widens, a report said.
Ms. Bessmertnova was a ballerina with the Bolshoi Ballet known for her lightness, delicacy and Romantic style.
At least 15 policemen were killed Tuesday after rockets exploded before they could be defused, Iraqi officials said.
The site preparation took 48 days longer than anticipated, costing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey $14.4 million in late fees.
Canada’s fourth-largest bank cited turmoil in the credit markets, and said it would provide up to $13 billion in liquidity for two of its structured investment vehicles.
Miuccia Prada turned lace into a holy and fetishistic enterprise, while Raf Simons of Jil Sander tested the structural foundations of minimalism.
To the Editor:.
Cinema operators are increasingly taking steps to entice adults out of their living rooms and back to the theaters. Some even have waiters to deliver food to seats.
To the Editor:.
When it is first broadcast later this month, “Ippadikku Rose” (“Yours, Rose”) is expected to cause a sensation, introducing India’s first transgender celebrity to television.
Diners in Asia, where sesame-oil-drenched jellyfish salad has long been considered a delicious, wholesome dish, are way ahead of us.
The Bush administration should advocate direct, unconditional talks between Washington and Tehran.
To the Editor:.
The Japanese electronics giant threw in the towel on its HD DVD technology, announcing that it would no longer develop, produce or market disc players for the format.
A U.S. District Court judge has reduced the sentence of a South Korean businessman who accepted more than $2.5 million to secretly work on Iraq’s behalf to influence the U.N. oil-for-food program.
Kim Sunée’s memoir chronicles the rapturous meals she has eaten or cooked while searching the world for love, a convincing identity and a sense of home.
Small dairy farmers, unable to keep afloat selling milk to large processors, are turning to alternatives such as making butter, yogurt and crème fraîche.

AFTER tasting artisanal dairy products for the last six months, it was apparent that descriptors like artisanal, small batch, farmstead, local and grass-fed are no guarantee of great flavor. Here are some favorites:.

The Supreme Court of Japan on Tuesday overruled a 2003 Tokyo High Court decision and decided that “Mapplethorpe,” a book of erotic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe (1946-89), shown at right in a self-portrait, did not violate obscenity laws, The Associated Press reported. The decision should pave the way for sale of the book in Japan for the first time in eight years. Although it decided that the book was not indecent, the Supreme Court rejected a demand by the publisher, Uplink, for government compensation of $20,370, according to Takashi Ando, a spokesman for the court. Takashi Asai of Uplink had been contesting the confiscation of the book in 1999 and his voluntary suspension of its sales in 2000 in response to police warnings. In the Supreme Court decision, by a majority of the five-judge bench, Justice Kohei Nasu wrote that the 384-page volume of black-and-white portraits, including 20 close-ups of male genitalia, “compiles work from the artistic point of view, and is not obscene as a whole.” Mr. Asai sold about 900 copies of the Japanese version of “Mapplethorpe,” originally published in Japan by Random House in 1994 without objection from the authorities. But airport customs officials, declaring the book obscene, confiscated Mr. Asai’s copy when he returned from a trip to the United States in 1999. He called the Supreme Court decision “groundbreaking” and said it “could change the obscenity standard” used for banning foreign films that depict nudity and for censoring photographs in books.
Ethan Coen’s “Almost an Evening,” which recently closed, is headed for a second life at the Bleecker Street Theater.

For the outcast A&E bounty hunter Duane Chapman, the foreseeable future is ending. Mr. Chapman, below, familiarly known as Dog, is going back on the air in his reality show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” the gossip Web site TMZ.com reported on Tuesday. The site said that preparations were in progress to restart production as soon as possible, although a premiere date had not been set. The series, the most successful on A&E in recent years, was suspended last fall after Mr. Chapman made racially charged comments in a private telephone conversation that was made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapman’s son for it. At the time, A&E announced it was stopping production “for the foreseeable future.”.

“Frozen River,” which won the grand jury prize at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival, will open the 37th New Directors/New Films series, from March 26 through April 9 in New York at the Walter Reade Theater and the Museum of Modern Art. Starring Melissa Leo, far right, and Misty Upham, near right, “Frozen River,” directed by Courtney Hunt, is the story of two women in upstate New York — one recently left with two sons to rear, the other a widow on a Mohawk reservation — who become partners in smuggling illegal immigrants from Canada into the United States.

Saudi Arabia, where movie theaters are banned, has something new to look forward to, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the English-language newspaper Arab News: its first official film festival. On May 20 a five-day competition underwritten by the government will feature films from Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf and Arab states. Planned as an annual event and including the participation of film critics from the region for the first time, the festival will take place in the eastern city of Damman under the auspices of the Damman Literary Club and the Saudi Society of Arts and Culture. Films were exhibited in private clubs in Saudi Arabia until all public screenings were banned in the early 1980s on the ground that they contravened Islamic law. Nevertheless, cafes in main cities show films, sports and video clips on large-screen televisions.

Mallika Sherawat, above, the actress known in some circles as Bollywood’s Bardot, has been cast as an ascetic who befriends Jesus of Nazareth in “The Aquarian Gospel,” a Hollywood film based on the legend that Jesus visited India, Reuters reported. The $15 million film, directed by Drew Heriot, deals with the life of Jesus between the ages of 13 and 30, a period not documented in the Gospels, when some believe he journeyed through India, Tibet and Persia. In a statement released by her press agent, Ms. Sherawat, whose 17 kissing scenes in her Bollywood debut, “Khwahish,” created a stir, said: “I find that in most mythological and spiritual film stories, women seem to be lacking any true wisdom or a sense of humor. I look forward to bringing both of those qualities to this character.”.

The combination of “Deal or No Deal” and the new game show “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. Nielsen estimated that the new series, which pits father-child teams against one another, attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing, but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for “Deal or No Deal” at 8 p.m. Opposite the game shows, however, the finale of ABC’s “Dance War” averaged 9.1 million viewers while earning the show’s lowest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked fourth over all, trailing with “October Road” (4.4 million) at 10 p.m. behind NBC’s “Medium” (8.5 million) and CBS’s “CSI: Miami” repeat (9.6 million). CBS finished second for the night behind NBC, but third among adults 18 to 49, behind NBC and Fox, which got a boost in that demographic from the finale of “Prison Break” at 8 (7.4 million) and “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 (8.1 million). On Sunday NBC’s “Knight Rider” (12.7 million) drew the highest ratings in the 18-to-49 age group for a made-for-television movie on any network in almost three years.
Tokio Hotel is a German act that scrambles musical categories in a way that feels ideally suited to the current era.

In a remarkable feat of cooperation between France and Israel, the Israel Museum in Jerusalem has opened an exhibition of important art looted by the Nazis from France and then returned after the war.
Serbs set fire to two U.N. posts in the north of Kosovo, forcing NATO troops to intervene and fanning fears that Kosovo’s declaration of independence could lead to partition.
James Patterson's books for young adults have sold millions of copies, but he wants to sell more. A lot more.

Among the great pleasures of regularly attending concerts is the occasional encounter with a performance that far surpasses expectations. The concert by the Juilliard Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday did just that.

KRAMER--Frieda. Congregation Beth Sholom of Lawrence, NY, records with sorrow the passing of our member. May her memory be for a blessing. KRAMER--Frieda Emilia. Born in 1928 in the Netherlands, recently of Cedarhurst, Long Island. Frieda passed away peacefully surrounded by her loving children on February 18, 2008, after a courageous battle with cancer. She is the daughter of the late Chief Rabbi of the Sephardic community of the Netherlands, HACHACHAM Rabbi Salomon Rodrigues-Pereira and his wife Henriette Emilia and devoted wife of the late Dr. Melvin M. Kramer and loving partner of Hans Werthauer. Frieda is the sister of deceased siblings, Martinus Rodrigues-Pereira, Miriam Van den Bergh, and Caro Zivi. She is survived by her brother Arnold RodriguesPereira and his wife Trudi, and sister-in-law Theresia Rodrigues-Pereira. She is also survived by her four children and their spouses: Carol Ruchelsman and her husband, Manny; Jonathan Kramer, M.D. and his wife Maria; Nancy Karp and her husband, Lloyd; and Salomon Kramer and his wife, Marci. The grandchildren she dearly loved will miss her deeply: David, Michal, and Jason Ruchelsman; Raphaela and Jesse Kramer; Daniel, Michael and Zachary Karp; and Jacqueline and Jesse Kramer. Frieda escaped Nazi occupation of the Netherlands in 1942 and came to settle in New York years later. Deeply proud of her Sephardic roots, she dedicated her life to caring for the world through volunteer work in hospitals and nursing homes, through the care of friends and community members, and through loving-kindness toward animals of every kind. She delighted in sharing laughter and food with friends and was known for her welcoming and abundant shabbos table. Frieda taught all of those she touched to celebrate life through her irrepressible joie de' vivre. Services will be held on Wednesday, February 20th at Beth Shalom Temple, Lawrence, New York, beginning at 9:30 am. Shiva services will be held at the home of her daughter Nancy Karp, 47 North Wood Lane, Woodmere, New York. Donations in her name can be made to Chabad of Naples, Florida, 1195 Creech Road, Naples, Florida, 34103 where she received extraordinary care.

TENS of thousands of telecommuters are receiving tax bills from states where they do not live, do not vote and do not use local services like schools. That is because their employers are based in states like New York, Georgia and Delaware, which assess income tax on nonresident employees, even if they come into the office only occasionally.

AS the mother of three small children, Missy Carr loved the meal assembly concept. Go to a store, use its recipes and raw ingredients to prepare meals and cart home a bunch of dinners that could be cooked with a toddler hanging on your leg. In May 2006, Ms. Carr, a trained chef who once owned a catering business, opened Thyme Out in Gaithersburg, Md., on her own. Like hundreds of other independents, she followed the basic concept set by the industry leaders. But she created her own menus and ditched several of the industry's core traditions, and unlike most store owners, she built her company into a sizable business. Thyme Out reported sales of $700,000 for 2007, more than double the revenue of others in the industry, and Ms. Carr plans to open a second store.

HELLER--Jerome (Jerry). March 11, 1918 to February 18, 2008. Died peacefully at home of cancer surrounded by his family, three weeks short of his 90th birthday. Resident of New York City and Upper Saranac Lake, NY. Cherished husband of the late Muriel Gordon Heller, beloved father of Louise (Robert) Schwab, Elizabeth (Eugene) Rosenberg and Richard (Sharon) Heller. Loving Poppy to Adam, Andrew, Paige, Hillary, Michael, Alexis, Marisa, Gregory and Melissa. Jerry was a graduate of the University of Virginia, St. John's Law School and a Veteran of WWII. A long time resident of Great Neck, NY and former Mayor of Russel Gardens in Great Neck. Jerry was a real estate developer, investor and attorney. Donations in his memory may be made to the Muriel Gordon Heller Research Fund at the New York Chapter of the ALS Association, 116 John St. New York, NY 10038, suite 1304. Service will be held at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St., at 11:30 on Wednesday. Shiva will be observed following interment at 10 East 70th St. and continue the following day.

IN the 1960s, when Downie McCarty was a teenager and his head was filled with the futuristic wonders of space age technology, he asked his father about his own future. ''I used to say, 'Dad, how am I going to make a living making these old kinds of tools?' '' The young Mr. McCarty -- Harry Downman McCarty, properly -- was acknowledging his responsibility to the family business, a forge in Baltimore that his grandfather founded in 1925, primarily to make chisels and punches. His father tried to reassure Downie, saying, ''There is always a need for basic tools.''

PROTECTING the electronic re- cords of your business has gotten easier and more affordable, thanks to services that can make backups of computer files across the Internet. These services are useful for three reasons. First, for a few hundred dollars a year, you can buy inexpensive protection for disaster, fire or theft. Second, they can work automatically so you don't have to remember to make backups. Finally, once they are set up they don't take a lot of skill to maintain.

The medlar is a small, round, hard fruit that softens only after a frost or in storage, developing an ugly wrinkled brown skin and pulp the consistency of applesauce. It was popular in medieval and Victorian times, but fell out of fashion as other fruits, especially citrus ones, became popular. It is still cultivated, and now preserves from the fruit, or confiture de nèfle, as the French call it, is sold at Pierre Marcolini, a chocolatier at 485 Park Avenue (58th Street), (212) 755-5150 or marcolinichocolatier.com.

IN 2005, meal assembly shops were the hottest trend in small business, a concept taken on with gusto by mom-and-pop entrepreneurs. In storefront and shopping-center kitchens nationwide, they sold millions of uncooked entrees in freezer-ready Ziplocs and to-go tins, with stick-on instructions for boiling, simmering, baking or stir-frying the contents into quick dinners at home. The concept boomed, as the number of stores mushroomed from four in 2002 to 1,400 in 2007, almost exclusively by catering to women who wanted to provide home-cooked meals for their families, according to the Easy Meal Preparation Association.

The Santa Maria Novella pharmacy in Florence, Italy, is known for its perfumes and herb- and spice-based items, like candles. Now it has introduced small boxes of elegant wrapped chocolates. There are no commercial vineyards in Brooklyn, but that isn't keeping the borough's name -- and its bridge -- from showing up on wine labels. Brooklyn Oenology sells a well-made merlot ($18) and a crisply fruity chardonnay ($15), made by Premium Wine of Long Island. These wines are sold at a few shops in New York, including Vintage New York stores. The labels, by Brooklyn artists, depict parts of the borough, like one of Newtown Creek by Tracy Silva Barbosa on the 2005 chardonnay.

FREEMAN--John L. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home & Hospital Lifecare System extends it deepest sympathies to the Freeman family on the passing of their beloved father John Freeman; David and Ellen, William and Beth and Robert Garafola. He was predeceased by his wife of 62 years, Dody (Josephine). For over 70 years, the Freeman family has provided a legacy of support and leadership to Jewish Home. John was an active trustee and joined the Board in 1960. Most recently, he served on the Westchester Division Board (Sarah Neuman Center). He was president of the Jewish Home & Hospital Board from 1981-85 and his years of service were marked by strong growth and development. John was made a Life Trustee in recognition of his unselfish and distinctive commitment to The Home. In honor of his 95th birthday, his family, friends and colleagues created the Freeman Family Summer Serenade Series that provides outdoor concerts for residents in the summer months. The concerts are a part of John's lasting legacy. John's father served as Board President from 1935-1940. His son David carries on the family tradition of Jewish Home service as a trustee, joining the Board in 1988, and as Chair of the Nominating and Housing Committees. He currently serves on the Westchester Division Board. John's wife Dody was an original member of the Friends of Sarah Neuman, an auxiliary dedicated to ensuring a high quality of resident life. This involved, committed, caring family has made many wonderful contributions to Jewish Home and for that, we are most grateful. Out thoughts will be with David and the entire family during their time of loss. John will be warmly remembered and revered by all who had the pleasure to know and work with him. Gene D. Resnick, M.D., Chairman of the Board Audrey Weiner, DSW, President/CEO FREEMAN--John, February 19, 2008. The partners and entire family of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freemen & Herz LLP note with immense sorrow the passing of our founding partner and dear friend, John L. Freeman. A true gentleman and scholar, John was our partner, inspiration, and guiding light for more than 70 years, beginning his career at our firm in 1935. After a short absence during World War II (he was a D-Day veteran), John was a presence at the firm until last year. Husband of the late Josephine (Dody) Freeman, and father of David, Bill, and the late Betsy, John will be sorely missed by all. Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz LLP. FREEMAN--John L., 96, of Rye, February 19, 2008. For 61 years the beloved husband of Josephine W. (Dody) Freeman, who passed away January 31, 2008. He was born in New York City and educated at Horace Mann School, Harvard College and Columbia Law School. Upon graduating from law school in 1935, he joined the firm of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, with which he remained for over 70 years, becoming senior partner. After the outbreak of World War II, he enlisted in the U.S. Army as a private and rose to the rank of major. He landed on Omaha Beach with the 29th Infantry Division on D-Day, served throughout the European campaign, and was awarded the Bronze Star. He was a trustee and President of the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, of which his father, Charles H. Freeman, had also been President. He also served as a trustee and President of Jewish Child Care Association of New York. He is survived by his son David and his wife Ellen of Larchmont; his son Bill and his wife Beth of Hillsborough, CA; his son-in-law Robert Garafola of New York City; his grandchildren Matt, Julie, Laura and Scott Freeman; and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his daughter Betsy. Always caring, giving, full of good humor and relentlessly optimistic, he never stopped insisting he was a lucky man. We are the ones who are lucky to have known him. Memorial services will take place at a later date. Contributions to the Jewish Home & Hospital Foundation, 120 West 106 St., NYC , 10025.

JAFFE--Ernst R., M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns with great sorrow the loss of our beloved Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Medicine (Hematology) and Senior Associate Dean Emeritus. He came to Einstein as a postdoctoral research fellow when the College opened in 1955, and for more than a half-century our medical school has been the fortunate recipient of his scientific talent and creativity and his thoughtful, humane and compassionate leadership. He was among the most devoted, selfless and dedicated members of our community, willing to assume any role that was important to advancing the mission of our College of Medicine, its faculty and its students. A gentleman at all times, his equanimity, his soft-spoken manner and sense of fairness endeared him to one and all. He was named Professor of Medicine in 1969 and a year later became Einstein's first Chief of the Division of Hematology, a position he held until 1982. He twice served as interim Dean of the medical school, from 1972-1974, and from 1983-1984. He also served the medical school as Senior Associate Dean, Associate Dean for Faculty, and Director of our Belfer Institute for Advanced Biomedical Studies. Dr. Jaffe was widely recognized as one of the founders of modern hematology. He was the quintessential clinician and investigatorscholar, and made significant contributions to the understanding of hereditary anemias due to enzyme deficiencies and hereditary methemoglobinemia. One of the best-known hematologists in the country, he served as President of the American Society of Hematology; Editor-in-Chief of Blood, the Journal of Hematology; and Co-Editor of Seminars in Hematology. Albert Einstein College of Medicine was built on the shoulders of giants. Dr. Ernst Jaffe was one of those giants. His kindly and gracious presence in our lives is already greatly missed. We extend our very deepest condolences to his beloved wife of 57 years, Jane; his daughter, Stephanie Anne Jaffe Green, M.D., Einstein Class of 1981, and her husband, Stephen; his son, Richard Jaffe and his wife Geraldine; and grandchildren Andrew, Christopher, Courtland, and Caroline. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Ruth L. Gottesman, Ed.D. Chair, Board of Overseers Edward R. Burns, M.D. Executive Dean JAFFE--Ernst R., M.D., DHL, age 83, Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Medicine and Senior Associate Dean Emeritus of Albert Einstein College of Medicine passed away on February 16th. He is remembered with deep affection by his devoted wife, Jane, of 57 years, his daughter, Dr. Stephanie Green, and her husband, Dr. Stephen Green, and his son, Richard Jaffe, and his wife, Gerry, and his four grandchildren Andrew and Christopher Green and Courtland and Caroline Jaffe. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, a long time resident of Tenafly, NJ, and, more recently, a resident of Port Washington, NY. Alma maters included Francis W. Parker School and the University of Chicago as an undergraduate and medical student. He was an intern and resident at Columbia University Presbyterian Hospital in New York. At Albert Einstein College of Medicine, his career as a hematologist was established. He was active in many academic societies and served as a member of the Board of the American Red Cross. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Ernst R. Jaffe Scholarship Fund, Office of Institutional Advancement, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, New York 10461.

PORCINO--Jane, Ph.D., on February 18, 2008. An internationally known author, lecturer and gerontologist, Jane believed she could help the world and she did. Memorial contributions, personal messages at: www.SimpsonGaus.com

BERNSTEIN--Alfred J., M.D., 98, died on February 18th in Goshen, NY. Survived by his daughter Anne of Berkeley, CA, son Andrew of Wayne, NJ, sister Minerva Mandelkern of Laguna Hills, CA, daughter-in-law Linda, sonin-law Conn Hallinan, grandsons Mark and Greg Bernstein and David Hallinan, stepgrandsons Sean, Antonio, and Brian Hallinan, and brother-in-law Herbert Handelman, extended family and friends. Preceded in death by his beloved wife of 57 years, Clara. A proud alumnus of Townsend Harris and CCNY, he received his M.D. from St. Andrews University. Having studied at the Curie Institute, he had a long, respected career as a radiologist practicing in the Bronx. He served in the U.S. Army Medical Corps during WWII, for 20 years was Director of Radiology at Bronx Hospital, and was on the clinical faculty of Albert Einstein Medical School. Funeral services will be at noon, Thursday the 21st, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mount Vernon, followed by interment at the Mount Hebron Cemetery. Donations in his memory may be made to: Doctors Without Borders, P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741.

COWAN--David, co-founder of The New York Society of Security Analysts (NYSSA), was born in 1903. He died peacefully on February 17, 2008, aged 104. David was part of the NYSSA founding group that included Benjamin Graham, the father of securities analysis and one of the most influential men in the history of finance. Born in London, David's family soon moved to Montreal, Canada. He graduated from McGill University in 1923 with first class honors in economics, political science and French. In 1925, while employed in the investment department of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, he beat 437 other entrants and won the Bonbright Prize and $5,000 for his Review (and Forecast) of the Development of the Electric Light and Power Industry 1920-1930. This achievement paved the way for his career as a utility industry analyst and he soon moved to New York City, where he worked almost fifty years on Wall Street, many of them with Shearson Bros. During World War II, David volunteered for the War Production Board. President Roosevelt established the War Production Board in 1942 to organize war procurement and production programs including the allocation of materials and production facilities. David, son of the late Alice and Albert Cowan, and brother of the late Lucien, was the devoted husband of the late Henriette Cowan, loving dad to Dianne Anderson, and doting grandfather of Steven and Caryn Hecht. Gentle, wry, funny, and above all, a gentleman, David will be missed and his spirit will be cherished forever.

HOGAN--William R. P., on February 16. Beloved husband of Felicia (nee Maggio), cherished father of Justin Michael. Visiting hours 4-8pm, Thursday, February 21, Yardley-Pino Funeral Home, East Hampton, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, 11am, Friday, February 22, Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton. Memorial contributions to American Irish Historical Society, 991 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028 or East End Hospice, Westhampton, NY.

MICHAEL AYOUB was an experienced chef and restaurateur when a Brooklyn business owner enlisted his help in 1988 to turn around a struggling catering company. In exchange for his sweat equity, Mr. Ayoub would acquire a one-third interest and be an equal partner with the founder and his daughter. The next 10 years were a ''lovefest,'' Mr. Ayoub said, during which they opened two successful restaurants in Park Slope. But as competition intensified, the partners disagreed about strategies. Father and daughter ousted Mr. Ayoub in 2001.

ONE of the most frequently cited advantages of coworking is the cross pollination that takes place. People share ideas rather than actually drum up business. ''I'll ask Ryan for video tips, or I'll ask John for travel advice,'' said Eddie Codel, a Web video producer who works at the Hat Factory in San Francisco, referring to his office mates Ryan Bailey, who runs a Web video start-up called Viddyou, and John Vlahides, executive editor of 71miles.com, a travel site.

BELKIN--Selma. Yeshiva University expresses sorrow upon the passing of Selma Belkin, who was married to the late Dr. Samuel Belkin, the second President of Yeshiva University. Our heartfelt condolences to her daughter Linda Belkin and to all the members of the bereaved family. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees

GOLDBERG--Jack Alan, M.D. Beloved husband of Dr. Suzanne Dickinson, cherished father of Janet, Michael, Stuart and David, son of Mrs. Sylvia Jacobson, brother of Edward Goldberg, JoAnne Landi and Ruth Cohen, grandfather of Evan Lerner. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St., February 21 at 1:30pm. Private burial.

BERGER--Harold, M.D., beloved husband of the late Minna Berger, father, grandfather, brother and brotherin-law, passed away while visiting family in Los Angeles, on Sunday evening, February 17. He was 93 years old. Harold was a practicing pediatrician in Elizabeth, New Jersey, for over 60 years. Until his death, he proudly took care of over 20,000 babies in his long and memorable career. He will be missed by his four sons, Brian, Andrew, Alan and Jimmy, their wives Judy, Emily, Phyllis and Sherrie and his 10 grandchildren. Dr. Berger was a graduate of Cornell University, Class of 1936 and New York University School of Medicine, Class of 1940. He served four years as an officer in the Medical Corps. Until his death, Dr. Berger was an avid golfer, pianist and was thoroughly engaged in all of his family's lives. While he lived a full and rich life, his passing has left a void in his family's hearts. The funeral service will be held at 11:30am on Thursday, February 21, at the Menorah Funeral Chapel, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment Bnai Israel Cemetery, Newark, NJ.

LIBSOHN--Mitzi. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of Mitzi, wife of our former esteemed member David Libsohn, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Board of Governors Stuart B. Wilkins, President

NEW FOCUS Rather than concentrate on a cure for muscular dystrophy, some researchers are intent on developing drugs to alleviate the effects of the disease. OIL HITS A RECORD An explosion at a Texas refinery helped push the closing price of crude oil above $100 a barrel. [C1.]

MORRIS--Constance Hand, of Sharon, Connecticut, died peacefully in Salisbury, Connecticut on February 17. Born on July 21, 1909, to Judge and Mrs. Learned Hand, she graduated from Bryn Mawr, summa cum laude. She was married to Robert Jordan and then to Newbold Morris. She is survived by two daughters, Constance Jordan and Frances Morris, five grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.

PEARLMAN--Lucy, at age 75. We mourn the passing of a good friend, mother, wife and grandmother. Lucy was a Packer Institute and Vassar graduate of 1954 and NYU where she received a MA. She was in charge of external affairs at Poly Prep in Brooklyn for many years. She served on Community Board 14 in Queens. Lucy was a member of Westend Temple in Neponsit. She was the wife of Dr. Hubert S. Pearlman for 53 years. She is also survived by adoring sons, Fred, Henry and George and her grandchildren Lindsey, Samantha and Max. Also mourning her passing are her brother, Robert J. Friedlander and his entire family. To know her was to adore her. Those of us who weep now, are strengthened by memories of her meaningful life. Funeral service 10am, February 20, 2008 at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY. 718-338-1500.

MANOWITZ--William, died peacefully at home on February 18. Loving husband of Joanne for 55 years. Devoted father of Wendy and Amy and their husbands Stu and Gil. Adoring grandfather of Lea, Joshua, Max and Izzy. He is also survived by his brother Robert. Services will be private.

LEOPOLD--Sophia Stulman. The family of Sophia Stulman Leopold express their sorrow at her death on February 18. She was the loving mother of Judy Leopold Kantrowitz and her husband Paul A. Kantrowitz of Brookline, MA, beloved grandmother of Stephen Kantrowitz of Madison, WI, Amy Kantrowitz of New York, NY, and the late Jeff Kantrowitz; and sister of Esther Moldauer of Woodmere, NY, and the late Pearl Goldenthal and Julius Stulman. She died peacefully at home at the age of 97. We will all miss her and the creative energy she brought to her life and ours. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Wednesday, February 20 at 12 noon.

NEUBAUER--Peter B., M.D. The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourns the loss, on February 15th 2008, of its longstanding and esteemed member Peter B. Neubauer, M.D. Dr. Neubauer's outstanding contributions to psychoanalysis, both his clinical work with children and adults, and his research on child development have been recognized throughout the world. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Roger Rahtz, M.D., President Philip Herschenfeld, M.D., Dean of Education NEUBAUER--Peter B., M.D. The Faculty of the NYU Psychoanalytic Institute (NYUPI) and the members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) are saddened by the loss of our esteemed colleague on February 15th. An admired teacher, editor and author, but above all a devoted psychoanalyst, he will be missed by all whom he touched.Samuel Herschkowitz, M.D., Director NYUPI; Milagros Picon, M.D., President PANY; Joseph Reppen, Ph.D., Secretary PANY

KYLES--Carasandra Cayten, 38, lost her courageous battle with colon cancer on February 16, 2008. She is survived by her devoted husband, John, her beautiful daughter Charlotte, her loving parents Drs. Gene and Marianna Cayten, her brother Christopher and his wife Megan, her grandparents Rose and Charles Dale, and Gus and Joyce Lawrence. Cara received a BA in Studio Art from Kenyon College and an MBA from Columbia University. She worked most recently at New York Life Insurance Company as a Corporate Vice President. In addition to her business acumen, Cara was an artist who expressed herself through oil and watercolor painting, interior design and fashion. Cara greatly valued her friends, and stayed close to friends from many chapters of her life, many of whom were by her side through her battle with cancer. Cara had a fierce determination to achieve whatever she set out to do, and always did it in style. Cara loved and was loved by many people, all of whom will miss her greatly. Her family and friends celebrate her life and rejoice in the time that they shared with her. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Cara Kyles' memory to the Jay Monahan Center at New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 23, 2008, at 3pm at The First Presbyterian Church of New York, Fifth Avenue at 12th Street, NYC.

FOR those who have started their own business or are thinking of doing so, there's inspiration, comfort, camaraderie -- as well as nitty-gritty advice -- online. Dozens of blogs offer small-business owners and entrepreneurs free start-up tips and business advice -- much of it drawn from their creators' experiences. The blogs include the inspirational and motivational, for those who are thinking about chucking corporate life and going out on their own. One of these is escapefromcubiclenation.com, where Pamela S. Slim, a former leadership development consultant, writes about traits that fence-sitters should consider about themselves -- like their working styles and finances -- before deciding whether to take the leap into self-employment.

After a long darkness, the Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport — that abandoned embodiment of the “Come Fly With Me” era of jet-setting — would reopen this year, under a plan advanced Thursday by the Port Authority.The authority’s board approved a $19 million project to perform the essential repairs needed to allow travelers to pass through the 46-year-old terminal on their way to the enormous new JetBlue Airways terminal that wraps around the T.W.A. building in a crescent shape.

Federal, state and city officials joined several civic organizations today to express support for a new four-acre waterfront park that would be built in the shadow of the United Nations and cost as much as $100 million, but the project faces considerable logistical and financial hurdles. The park would be at the northern end of Glick Park, at 36th Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan, where decaying concrete is blocked off by a gate and a fence with barbed wire. The area, which houses a now-defunct Consolidated Edison, is one of the largest parcels in Manhattan facing redevelopment in the next few years.

Two deaths brought about the decision to close Cafe La Fortuna, the three-decade-old cafe that attracted John Lennon, Yoko Ono and many other Upper West Side neighborhood residents with its outdoor garden, opera music and Italian desserts.The first death, which took place a few years ago, was of the longtime landlord, who had generously kept the rent for the space at 69 West 71st Street at a reasonable rate despite the escalating real estate costs in the neighborhood.

The New York City schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein today, announced that 52 new schools will open in September. But the average parent or student would not necessarily see all 52 schools as “new.” Of the total, 25 will replace schools that are being phased out, 12 will open in new school buildings constructed to alleviate crowding and the remaining 15 will open in underused school buildings or school buildings where schools are being permanently reduced in size.

A group of city Parks Department workers said today that the agency’s intention to use palm scanners in place of time sheets is a violation of their privacy. The Parks Department is one of more than two dozen city agencies that is preparing to use — or has already began using -– the Bloomberg administration’s “CityTime” payroll plan, which includes the use of biometric devices such as palm scanners to collect workers’ start and end times. According to the city’s Office of Payroll Administration Web site, supervisors may choose to place the scanners near the entrance of an office, allowing an agency to record when employee arrive at work and leave for the day.

Over the past decade, golf, the leisure activity that is often closely associated with corporate success in America, has been in a kind of recession, Paul Vitello writes. The total number of people who play has declined or remained flat each year since 2000, dropping to about 26 million from 30 million, according to the National Golf Foundation and the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association. More troubling to golf boosters, the number of people who play 25 times a year or more fell to 4.6 million in 2005 from 6.9 million in 2000, a loss of about a third.

I can't remember when the pre-made sandwich thing took over completely. (Oh, and now there are "paninis.") Why would anyone spend 15 euros for pre-shredded cabbage?

Johnna's umbilical cord locket really struck me, I think, because of the horror of the idea that if it ever gets lost it, "our souls belong nowhere and after we die our souls will walk the Earth looking for where we belong." I found my mind wandering off after that line, wondering: how does it stay on? How can she be sure the clasp doesn't break and it falls off? Does she periodically replace the cord, meticulously, in order to be sure it remains intact for her whole life? And if it does get lost, would Johnna's friends and relatives shake their heads, shrug their shoulders - sorry, your soul belongs nowhere now?

When Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992, he talked, memorably and incessantly, about protecting those families who "worked hard and played by the rules." Sixteen years later, it appears ever more likely that the outcome of this year's Democratic nomination fight will rest, in the end, on how party leaders interpret the rules. As I've written here before, there is no real ideological divide in the party; most Democrats would seem to be satisfied with either Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama, so there's no reason to think either candidate's followers will automatically revolt if they lose. But no matter who wins, if the process itself ends up confirming the growing suspicion among voters that the rules are only there to be rigged, then the outcome could devastate a party whose central argument is all about fairness. Much has been written about the possible permutations in the Democratic race from here on out, but at this point it's fairly simple. After his victories Tuesday, Mr. Obama now has a slim but hard-to-surmount lead in "pledged delegates" - those awarded in state contests. If Mrs. Clinton were to win the trio of Texas, Ohio and Pennsylvania by huge margins, then she might be able to overtake him, but that doesn't seem terribly likely, given the dynamic of the race right now. Even so, neither candidate has much chance of emerging from the primaries with the 2,025 delegates needed to lock up the nomination, which means that even if Mr. Obama maintains his lead, Mrs. Clinton can-and probably will-fight on.
(Matt Ross)

In 2006, Badgley Mischka put out its first namesake perfume, created by perfumer Richard Herpin under the artistic direction of Mark Badgley and James Mischka. Three weeks ago they launched their second (initially an exclusive at Saks), this time by perfumer Rodrigo Flores-Roux. Nobody bats a thousand. Still it is a disappointment to announce that Badgley Mischka is 1 for 2.

If my neighborhood in Brooklyn is representative (let's hope not), I'm afraid more people watched "American Idol" last night than stepped outside to see the total eclipse of the Moon. Watching it from my stoop, I was the only ecliptophile on the block. A few people walking their dogs stopped to take a look through my binoculars, but most of them hadn't even noticed the eclipse until then.

He would like to write that the place is crackling with golden energy, but it's sorta the opposite. Even his fellow ninnies are suffering from an energy crisis.

When Google purchased Postini last year for $625 million, it was making a big commitment to the enterprise software business. But not surprisingly, Google isn't committing itself to business as usual. And it is causing a little heat among Postini's existing partners.

The apparent collapse of a Chinese company's effort to buy a stake in 3Com shows the growing role of the the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius, in vetting cross-border deals. It is also likely to aggravate tensions between the United States and China.
William Ackman has been betting for years that the major bond insurers were headed for trouble. Now that trouble has arrived, he has emerged with a rescue plan for the industry.

The spread between Restoration Hardware's stock price and its $4.50-per-share buyout agreement with Catterton Partners has grown wider, even as the Feb. 28 deadline for its "go-shop" period approaches. TheDeal.com looks at why investors might be getting skittish.

3i, the publicly listed British venture capital and buyouts shop, is moving away from investing in early-stage companies as part of a reorganization that will merge its venture business with its growth capital unit, says PE Hub's Tom Allchorne.

First of all, thanks to everyone for the terrific comments and funny asides on the blog, and to georgianna8 for the lace history (new stuff to learn!), RC (glad you couldn't resist), Marko for mentioning Raf Simons the big romantic (let's not talk austere anymore), and, Brooksie, couldn't agree with you more that it's Miuccia's responsibility to show racial diversity on her runway. It DOES matter, it's not a trend, and it astounds me that designers in Europe and the U.S. are blankishly ignorant about why this matters. One or two black or Asian or Latina models on their runways is not enough. In general ways, in skin color, body shape, and physical expressiveness, the runways need to be far more diverse and surprising than they are. And a designer should lead the way.

“Baseball Prospectus,” the annual handbook of major league statistics, prides itself on including a heavy dose of counterintuitive thinking. Steven Goldman, the co-editor of this year’s edition, which comes out Monday, described it as “the antidote to Joe Morgan” -- the Hall of Fame player whose game analysis supplies regular fodder for those following new statistical measurements.

Twin-tips, skis rounded and curved up at the tail like the front of a traditional ski, simplify jumping and landing backward. And as The Times reports, while total sales numbers remain small compared to other skis, sales of twin-tips have increased 32 percent in specialty stores and 167 percent in online sales over last season “The answer to their sudden popularity is as old-fashioned as it is modern,” The Times reports. “Twin-tips are new, cool and make people feel young. So middle-aged men and women are buying them, and not just for their sons and daughters.”.

As Newton knew, gravity is great. But for snow lovers searching for an alternate force to help them cruise, carve, and catapult into the air, wind power is the way to go. Over the past 10 years, the sport of snowkiting, in which skiers and snowboarders strap themselves to lightweight foil kites and ride the wind, has started to blossom in the United States- and not just in mountain regions. Minnesota and North Dakota are some of the current snowkiting hotspots where beginners, using their own skis, boots and snowboards along with the specialized kites, can figure out how to harness the breezes in just a few hours. (Though snowkiting is, of course, colder than its liquid counterpart, called kiteboarding, it’s also safer and easier to learn.).

An article last Thursday about favored projects, known as earmarks, that lawmakers sponsor in spending bills misstated the approach that Representative Bill Sali, Republican of Idaho, uses in dealing with people seeking such funds. Mr. Sali provides earmark application forms to those who ask; he does not solicit applications for earmarks.

An article in Business Day on Nov. 5 about Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC business reporter, misspelled the surname of the dean of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, who commented on her promotional appearance on behalf of Citigroup, a frequent subject of CNBC coverage. He is John Lavine, not Levine. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last Thursday.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the strategy that winners of Pakistan’s election hope to use to deal with Islamic militancy misstated, in some editions, the government experience of Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Benazir Bhutto and the leader of the Pakistan Peoples Party. He has indeed held office, having been elected to the National Assembly twice and to the Senate once.

A music review on Tuesday about the opening concert in the Meredith Monk/Multi-Musics series, at Symphony Space, gave the wrong date for the next performance. It is today, not next Thursday. The phone number for information is (212) 864-5400.

A dance review on Tuesday about the Sugar Salon showcase, at the Abron Arts Center, misstated the title of a piece choreographed by Heather McArdle. It is “Ballad of Arrivals & Departures” — not “BlueprintViolation: Ballad of Arrivals & Departures,” which is the name of Ms. McArdle’s company.

An article on Feb. 9 about the fading possibility of Michael R. Bloomberg’s becoming a candidate for president misidentified the person with whom Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, discussed the possibility of running on a ticket with the New York City mayor. Senator Hagel said there had been talks about it, but one of his aides said later that the talks had been with Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, not with Mr. Bloomberg.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a design flaw in the Ares I, the rocket NASA plans to use to replace the space shuttle, misstated the process by which a solid-fuel rocket burns its fuel. It burns outward from the center of its cylindrical core, not from bottom to top.
The Philadelphia 76ers scored 100 points in the first three quarters Wednesday night and went on to crush the Knicks.
