The union representing 2,500 rank-and-file Phoenix police officers said Tuesday that a new policy requiring the police to ask the immigration status only of people under arrest does not go far enough and could allow illegal immigrants to commit more crimes. The policy announced Friday by Mayor Phil Gordon and an advisory panel applies to misdemeanor and felony arrests but not civil traffic stops. The police would have the option to send written notification to Immigration and Customs Enforcement on people detained but not arrested. Mark Spencer, president of the union, the Phoenix Law Enforcement Association, said a suspect’s immigration status was already checked at the county jail under a sheriff’s department policy, making the Phoenix policy moot.

A businessman was convicted of faking his disappearance after a car crash two years ago to draw attention to his Congressional campaign. The man, Gary Dodds, left, was convicted of falsifying evidence, causing a false public alarm and leaving the scene of the April 2006 crash. He faces up to seven years in prison. Mr. Dodds, 43, claims he injured his head in the crash in Dover and nearly drowned in a river before being rescued 27 hours later. Prosecutors say he spent part of that time soaking his feet in cold water to make it appear he had spent the night outdoors.

People who had surgery for spinal stenosis, a common back ailment, had less pain two years later than those who decided to skip the surgery, researchers said. They said the study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, should help patients make an informed decision when they develop the painful condition. “This study says surgery is better,” said the lead author, Dr. James Weinstein of Dartmouth. Spinal stenosis is caused by a narrowing of the spinal canal that gradually pinches off nerves in the spine, making it painful to stand or walk. The findings are part of a five-year, 11-state study looking at the effectiveness of common back surgery.

Heart surgery patients were more likely to die if given an antibleeding drug, Trasylol, two new studies have found. The manufacturer, Bayer, stopped selling the drug after a Canadian study was halted because of deaths. The research reignites a controversy over Trasylol, which was on the market for 14 years. The studies are being published this week in The New England Journal of Medicine. The first looked at about 10,000 patients who had bypasses at Duke University Medical Center from 1996 through 2005. It found that 6.4 percent of patients who were given Trasylol died within 30 days of the surgery, a rate nearly 2.5 times higher than patients who got another drug or who received no treatment for bleeding. The second study, financed by Bayer, looked at about 78,000 patients nationwide from 2003 to 2006. After adjusting for other factors, the researchers found the risk of death was 64 percent higher in the Trasylol group than in those taking a comparison drug.

Older Americans are having less trouble with their memories, and it may be because they spent more time in school, researchers said. They found that the rate of cognitive impairment fell 3.5 percentage points among people 70 and over from 1993 to 2002. “We found a clear relationship,” said Dr. Ken Langa of the University of Michigan, whose study appears in the journal Alzheimer’s & Dementia. “The more education people had, the better they performed on cognitive tests.” The researchers used data on 11,000 people from the Health and Retirement Study and compared data gathered in 1993 with data from 2002.
A group of alcohol producers in Henan Province is seeking to overturn a year-old ban on government officials’ drinking at lunch, citing a fall in restaurant trade.
Mohamed al-Fayed accused the Secret Intelligence Service of Britain of having plotted the car crash that killed the Princess of Wales and her lover, Mr. al-Fayed’s son, in 1997.

Kevin O’Dea joined the Jets as the special-teams coordinator after spending the past two seasons as Chicago’s assistant special-teams coach. He replaced Mike Westhoff, who stepped down to have surgery on his left leg.

Robby Gordon was docked 100 points and his crew chief was suspended for six races and fined $100,000 as Nascar penalized 10 teams Wednesday for Nationwide Series infractions at Daytona International Speedway. Dale Earnhardt Jr. was one of seven drivers penalized, and six crew chiefs were suspended. Todd Bodine, the winner of the Truck Series race, was one of two drivers penalized in that series.The harshest penalty went to Gordon, who had an unapproved front bumper cover on his No. 7 Dodge during an opening-day inspection for the Daytona 500. The deduction of points dropped him t0 41st in the standings from 9th. Frank Kerr, Gordon’s crew chief, is not eligible to return to the track until April 12 in Phoenix. Kerr was also placed on probation through the end of the year.

The Green Bay Packers designated defensive tackle Corey Williams as their franchise player, preventing him from becoming an unrestricted free agent. Green Bay also cut tight end Bubba Franks after eight seasons. A first-round draft choice in 2000, Franks had 256 catches for 2,300 yards, and 32 touchdowns.

Frank Gansz, the former Kansas City Chiefs coach, who had been out of football since 2001, was hired to coach special teams at Southern Methodist. Under Gansz, who turns 70 in November, the Chiefs were 4-11 in the strike year of 1987 and 4-11-1 in 1988.

Safety Dwight Smith, who had two interceptions for Tampa Bay in the 2003 Super Bowl, was released by the Minnesota Vikings. Smith, 29, had four interceptions in each of his two seasons in Minnesota, including a 93-yard touchdown return last November against the eventual Super Bowl champion Giants. But he had disagreements with the coaching staff and off-field problems.

New York Road Runners, the club that organizes the New York City Marathon, is asking its members to volunteer if they want to compete. About 7,000 club members gained entry to this year’s marathon, which will be run Nov. 2, by competing in at least 9 of 41 races of various lengths in 2007. To qualify for the 2009 marathon, members will also be required to volunteer for one of the 50 events the Road Runners organize this year.
Stocks came off early losses to finish higher Wednesday as investors found reassurance in evidence that the Federal Reserve remained committed to stoking growth.

Tight end Dallas Clark, one of Peyton Manning’s favorite receivers, signed a six-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts, a day after the team placed the franchise tag on him. Germany’s steel trade union and employers said they had reached agreement on a 5.2 percent pay increase for workers in the northwestern part of the country. Under the deal, reached after 10 hours of talks, about 85,000 workers will receive the increase from March, as well as a one-time payment of 200 euros ($294.50) in February.

Japan’s exports rose more than expected in January as shipments to Asia and Europe cushioned soft exports to the United States. The trade deficit of 79.3 billion yen ($734 million) was the biggest since the 394.4 billion yen in January 2006, the government said. Overall exports rose 7.7 percent in January from a year earlier. Exports to the United States fell 3.2 percent while shipments to China rose 4.6 percent.

Fourth-quarter profit at Tim Hortons, the restaurant chain, rose 11.5 percent, as new locations and higher prices more than offset rising costs. Net earnings rose to 75.7 million Canadian dollars ($75.1 million) from 67.9 million Canadian dollars a year earlier.

The retailer Asda Group, a unit of Wal-Mart Stores, unveiled a $776 million expansion that it said would create more than 9,000 jobs this year. Asda plans to open as many as 22 stores and build 12 extensions, totaling 800,000 square feet, after attracting two million new customers last year. Asda grew faster than its major competitors in comparable-store and in total sales in 2007, the chief executive, Andy Bond, above, told reporters at a briefing. Mr. Bond said sales rose 8 to 10 percent in 2007.
Oil futures rallied again Wednesday, pushing briefly past $101 a barrel after the Fed lowered its forecast for economic growth this year.

The British bank Standard Chartered said it had abandoned a plan to rescue its $7 billion structured investment vehicle, Whistlejacket, which was placed into receivership last week and failed to make a debt payment due on Friday. Standard Chartered said it had withdrawn conditional proposals to rescue Whistlejacket because of a number of factors, including ”the pace of continuing deterioration in the market for certain asset classes and the impracticality of completing any proposal within the confines of the receivership as it has evolved.” .

Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal) is the No. 1 album for a second week, with sales of 180,000 copies, but the big winners on the Billboard chart are Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock, who had big post-Grammy Awards sales bumps. Ms. Winehouse, who won five Grammys, jumped 22 spots to No. 2 with “Back to Black” (Universal), selling 115,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. And Mr. Hancock, whose “River: The Joni Letters” (Verve), above, was named album of the year, leaped to No. 5 from No. 159 with 54,000 sales, a 967 percent increase from its sales the week before. Alicia Keys, who performed at the ceremony and took home two prizes, holds at No. 3 with 109,000 sales of “As I Am” (J), and the compilation “2008 Grammy Nominees” (Hip-O/Universal) is No. 4 with 72,000. ... A new 25th-anniversary edition of Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” (Epic), with several new tracks, was the second-best-selling album in the country last week, moving 166,000 copies, but Billboard’s rules prevent “Thriller” from appearing on its main album chart; instead, it is No. 1 on the catalog chart, for albums more than 18 months old.

One week after registering relatively mediocre ratings in their debuts, CBS’s “Big Brother” and the second season of “Jericho” each lost more than a million viewers on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Big Brother” drew just 5.4 million viewers at 9 p.m., compared with 6.9 million a week ago, while “Jericho” attracted 5.9 million at 10 p.m., down from 7.1 million. CBS ranked third for the night over all, faring best at 8 p.m. with a rerun of “NCIS” (10.8 million). Fox dominated the night with a two-hour edition of “American Idol” (28.8 million). NBC finished second over all, winning the 10 p.m. hour following “Idol” with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (9.3 million). NBC’s “Biggest Loser” (8.2 million) was also the runner-up from 8 to 10 p.m. among adults 18 to 49. ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

More than six months after the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles agreed to hand over 40 artifacts to Italy, the criminal trial of its former curator of antiquities lumbers on in Rome. A prosecution witness painstakingly presented the court with photographs and documents on Wednesday in an effort to establish that more than a dozen looted artifacts had made their way into the Getty’s collection. Marion True, the former Getty curator, is charged with conspiring to acquire illicitly excavated antiquities for the museum. Several of the pieces discussed on Wednesday by the prosecution witness, Daniela Rizzo, are now on view at the presidential palace in Rome as part of an exhibition of objects recovered from American museums in the last two years. Ms. Rizzo repeatedly projected an image of an artifact onto a screen next to a photograph of the same piece in a dirt-encrusted, unrestored state. For most of the pieces, she said, acquisition documents provided by the Getty did not cite the object’s provenance. “If it came from an authorized dig, it would say so and give a date,” she said. “The fact that it doesn’t makes you think, doesn’t it?” Ms. True and the American dealer Robert Hecht, who is on trial with her on similar charges, have both proclaimed their innocence. The next trial hearing is scheduled for mid-March.

Could it be that more than 60 years after the end of World War II, the Amber Room has been found? Long-lost amber panels backed with gold leaf were stolen by the Nazis from the Soviet Union during the war. Now it appears they may lie in a man-made cavern 60 feet underground near the village of Deutschneudorf on the German border with the Czech Republic, Spiegel Online International reported. The Amber Room, below, created by German and Russian craftsmen, was a gift from King Friedrich Wilhelm I of Prussia to his ally Czar Peter the Great of Russia in 1716. The possible discovery of an estimated two tons of gold was made over the weekend when electromagnetic pulse measurements found the cavern near a long-abandoned railway station. Heinz-Peter Haustein, the mayor of Deutschneudorf and a member of Parliament who led the search, said, “I’m well over 90 percent sure we have found the Amber Room.”.

Viacom’s BET Networks will make their debut in Britain on Feb. 28, carrying American series like “106 & Park,” “College Hill” and “American Gangster” to more than 8.8 million digital satellite homes, Reuters reported. The 10-time Grammy winner Beyoncé, above, will be an executive producer and star as Etta James in “Cadillac Records,” a Sony BMG film about the Chicago label Chess Records, Billboard reported. She joins a cast that includes Adrien Brody as Leonard Chess, the label’s founder; Jeffrey Wright as Muddy Waters; Cedric the Entertainer as Willie Dixon; and Columbus Short as Little Walter. Darnell Martin, who wrote the screenplay, will direct. ... Owen Wilson is to return to work next month for the first time since his reported suicide attempt last summer, The Associated Press reported. On March 10, Mr. Wilson and Jennifer Aniston are to begin starring with Alan Arkin in “Marley & Me” for 20th Century Fox. The film, directed by David Frankel, tells of a couple who adopt a dog as preparation for parenthood, only to find the mischievous animal more than they bargained for. ... Hasbro Inc. and Universal Pictures have entered a six-year partnership to produce at least four films based on Hasbro games, including Monopoly, Battleship, Candy Land and Ouija. An announcement said the first film would be released in 2010 or 2011.

Talese/Doubleday, an imprint of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group. Last month Ms. Silver, 53, was edged out of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Adult Trade Books when Becky Saletan, publisher of the trade division of Harcourt, was appointed publisher of the combined unit. At Nan A. Talese Ms. Silver, who spent 24 years at Houghton, will focus on editing while working out of her home in Concord, Mass.

WITH improvements in foam technology and a growing interest from snowboard clothing manufacturers, riders who want to take some pain out of the learning curve now have more padding options than ever. Padded shorts and pants are second to only helmets in terms of popularity, according to Jim Bartlett, the owner of XSportsProtective.com, an online store that sells safety gear exclusively. The options include burly, baby-got-back pads designed for beginners, as well as snow pants with integrated and removable pads for expert riders (who often hit large jumps at speeds of 30 miles per hour and more and sail as far as 80 feet before touching down) and slim-profiled undershorts.

Scandyna, a Danish electronics manufacturer, recently introduced its curvy, brightly colored speakers, amplifiers and iPod docks in the United States. Peter Hasselriis, the company's owner, said he designed them to appeal to women who are ''fed up'' with ''black vinyl or brown wood'' components. Prototypes were tested at electronics stores in Denmark ''to see, if a couple went by, if the wife would stop and drag the man back to have a look.'' That almost never happened with ''old-fashioned hi-fi systems with black metal boxes,'' he said, but it did with the new perky components. The Drop speaker, above, can stand upright or hang from the ceiling ($849 a pair). Available at the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (212) 755-9079. ELAINE LOUIE

TRALONGO--Jack Thomas, 60, lost his battle with lung disease on February 19, 2008. We mourn the loss of this wonderful man, who brought laughs and deep love to his wife Jennifer Crosby, his daughter Alison Tralongo, his sisters Patricia Ruggiero and Lorraine LoPresti and his brother Frank Tralongo. He was deeply devoted to his mother Katherine Tralongo who survived him and he was a loving uncle to his nieces and nephews, whom he loved dearly. A technology executive who made important contributions to IBM, Morgan Stanley and CitiBank. Culminating at CUNY graduate center. Jack loved his work and his passion for project management was a source of great pride to him. Resposing at the Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place, Brooklyn (off Court St.) until Saturday. Funeral services at Saint Mary Star of the Sea R.C. Church, 9:30am. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

Tom Dixon, the post-punk British furniture designer whose best sellers include the swoopy S-chair for Cappellini and the biomorphic molded plastic Jack Lights, is coming to New York. His new line of tough metal furniture was inspired in part by motorcycles, with which Mr. Dixon has a fractured history. During art school, a motorcycle accident put him in the hospital with a broken leg for a few months, which is when he learned to play bass. He never went back to what was then the Chelsea School of Art and Design (now College) in London (''It was a brilliant excuse,'' he said), but he did join the post-punk band Funkapolitan. In another accident, he broke his wrist, ending his career as a musician, but jump-starting one as a furniture designer, when he began experimenting with a borrowed welding machine. Punch Lights, above, modeled on the fins of early air-cooled engines, are $820 at Shop by Tom Dixon, opening Feb. 25 at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000. PENELOPE GREEN
MORGAN--John P., M.D. We mourn the death of John Morgan, the best of friends. Our love and condolences to the entire extended Morgan family. Robert and Marsha Dennis and Family

A quick look at the work of Lucas Samaras reveals that he has a serious thing for chairs. Since the 1950s, they have turned up constantly in his sculptures, drawings and paintings, and as props in his self-portraits and photographs. They are also the focus of ''NYC Chairs,'' opening Friday at PaceWildenstein in Chelsea. For the last year, Mr. Samaras, above, has spent his days walking around Manhattan with a digital Leica, photographing chairs he encountered on the streets. The 50 images in the show, which he pumped up with fluorescent colors using Photoshop, capture them in all manner of situations: junked on the sidewalk, beside vendors' carts, for sale in flea markets.

An article on Jan. 31 about the difficulties of campaigning in the sprawling and diverse state of California misidentified the winner of the Republican primary there in 1968. It was Ronald Reagan, who ran unopposed as the favorite son -- not Richard M. Nixon.

FREEMAN--John L., 96, of Rye, February 19, 2008. For 61 years the beloved husband of Josephine W. (Dody) Freeman, who passed away January 31, 2008. He was born in New York City and educated at Horace Mann School, Harvard College and Columbia Law School. Upon graduating from law school in 1935, he joined the firm of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, with which he remained for over 70 years, becoming senior partner. After the outbreak of World War II, he enlisted in the U.S. Army as a private and rose to the rank of major. He landed on Omaha Beach with the 29th Infantry Division on D-Day, served throughout the European campaign, and was awarded the Bronze Star. He was a trustee and President of the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, of which his father, Charles H. Freeman, had also been President. He also served as a trustee and President of Jewish Child Care Association of New York. He is survived by his son David and his wife Ellen of Larchmont; his son Bill and his wife Beth of Hillsborough, CA; his son-in-law Robert Garafola of New York City; his grandchildren Matt, Julie, Laura and Scott Freeman; and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his daughter Betsy. Always caring, giving, full of good humor and relentlessly optimistic, he never stopped insisting he was a lucky man. We are the ones who are lucky to have known him. Memorial services will take place at a later date. Contributions to the Jewish Home & Hospital Foundation, 120 West 106 St., NYC , 10025. FREEMAN--John, February 19, 2008. The partners and entire family of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freemen & Herz LLP note with immense sorrow the passing of our founding partner and dear friend, John L. Freeman. A true gentleman and scholar, John was our partner, inspiration, and guiding light for more than 70 years, beginning his career at our firm in 1935. After a short absence during World War II (he was a D-Day veteran), John was a presence at the firm until last year. Husband of the late Josephine (Dody) Freeman, and father of David, Bill, and the late Betsy, John will be sorely missed by all. Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz LLP.

DAYLIGHT saving time begins in a few weeks, which means it's time to get ready for spring. For many people, the necessary household preparations include not just cleaning closets but shopping for new tableware for entertaining, too. And for those invited to spring parties, dinnerware, candleholders and serving pieces can make thoughtful gifts for the person preparing the meal.

TRENTIN--Leonard Ernest, 91, February 15. Beloved son of Gerda S.E. Peterson and Louis Elias Trentin. Major USA (Ret.) 152nd Anti-Aircraft Battalion, 11th Airborne, WWII, architect, arts patron and cherished friend. His kindness, delightful humor, and presence in his lifelong neighborhood of Yorkville will be greatly missed. Interment Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial service 11am March 29, Holy Trinity, 316 E. 88, Manhattan. Donations welcome in his name to the Metropolitan Museum.

Twenty pieces of bronze furniture by Ingrid Donat, a Parisian sculptor, are on display in a show opening today at the Barry Friedman Gallery. Ms. Donat, who began making furniture in the 1980s at the encouragement of the artist Diego Giacometti, tried to distinguish her pieces from his by avoiding green patinas and ''round tables with glass and animals,'' she said. She uses textures like bamboo or alligator skin on the dark, matte exterior surfaces, she said, to ''counteract the coldness of the bronze.'' On the interior surfaces, the bronze gleams a burnished coppery-gold. The pieces, in limited editions of eight, range from $6,500 for a lamp to $145,000 for a commode, below; the bench, above, is $23,500. Through March 15 at 515 West 26th Street, (212) 239-8600. ELAINE LOUIE

KYLES--Carasandra Cayten, 38, lost her courageous battle with colon cancer on February 16, 2008. She is survived by her devoted husband, John, her beautiful daughter Charlotte, her loving parents Drs. Gene and Marianna Cayten, her brother Christopher and his wife Megan, her grandparents Rose and Charles Dale, and Gus and Joyce Lawrence. Cara received a BA in Studio Art from Kenyon College and an MBA from Columbia University. She worked most recently at New York Life Insurance Company as a Corporate Vice President. In addition to her business acumen, Cara was an artist who expressed herself through oil and watercolor painting, interior design and fashion. Cara greatly valued her friends, and stayed close to friends from many chapters of her life, many of whom were by her side through her battle with cancer. Cara had a fierce determination to achieve whatever she set out to do, and always did it in style. Cara loved and was loved by many people, all of whom will miss her greatly. Her family and friends celebrate her life and rejoice in the time that they shared with her. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Cara Kyles' memory to the Jay Monahan Center at New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 23, 2008, at 3pm at The First Presbyterian Church of New York, Fifth Avenue at 12th Street, NYC.

GOLDBERG--Jack Alan, M.D. Beloved husband of Dr. Suzanne Dickinson, cherished father of Janet, Michael, Stuart and David, son of Mrs. Sylvia Jacobson, brother of Edward Goldberg, JoAnne Landi and Ruth Cohen, grandfather of Evan Lerner. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St., February 21 at 1:30pm. Private burial. GOLDBERG--Jack, M.D., 74. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Jack Goldberg, M.D. an esteemed colleague in the Division of Cardiology for over 30 years, past president of the medical staff and a mentor to hundreds of young Cardiologists during his tenure in the department. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Dr. Suzane Dickinson, his children Janet, Michael, Stuart and David as well as his entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

8 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES The 120-seat Curry Lounge has recently undergone a million-dollar renovation, with décor right out of Bollywood. But the menu is do-it-yourself, which makes life more than difficult for the head chef, who must concoct unfamiliar dishes for each order. Here Gordon Ramsay, above right with the chef Zahir, tries to fix his first Indian restaurant. 6:30 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ONE PERCENT Jamie Johnson, a great-grandson of the founder of Johnson & Johnson and the Emmy-nominated director of the documentary ''Born Rich,'' in which several young heirs did the unthinkable and talked about their family money, focuses this time on the growing gap between the rich and everyone else in America. Specifically, he examines the 1 percent of society that controls nearly half of the nation's wealth. Among those offering their opinions: the economist Milton Friedman; the billionaire Adnan Khashoggi; Roy O. Martin, a Louisiana lumber tycoon who spends with the Bible as his guide; Chuck Collins, a great-grandson of Oscar Mayer who gave up his inheritance for moral reasons; and Bill Gates Sr., the father of the richest man in the United States.

LEVIN--Mae. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the death of our longtime dedicated member, Mae Levin. Mae was the devoted wife to the late Samuel Aronowitz and the late Irving Levin. She is survived by her grandson, David Grosse and stepchildren Jim and Connie Levin. Our deepest condolences to them and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Roger Meltzer, President

CAMPBELL--Dr. Rolla D. Jr., of Hobe Sound, FL and Fishers Island, NY, died peacefully on February 16, 2008, his 88th birthday. He is survived by his wife, Kim Kendall Campbell, his children, Rolla Bruce Dunbar Campbell, Alison Campbell Swain, Graham Campbell Strigaro and Cynthia Campbell Waters, his stepchildren Kane Kendall Baker, and Lavinia Baker Logan, 10 grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and his brother, William Cammack Campbell. A native of Huntington, West Virginia, Dr. Campbell graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard, and the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. In college, he was a leading, middle distance and track star, and continued distance running well into his forties, finishing with the Boston Marathon at the age of 46. Dr. Campbell served as an Orthopedic Surgeon in the U.S. Army's Medical Corps in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. He spent many years in private practice at the Hospital for Special Surgery in NYC and the New York Roosevelt Hospital. He was a member of several notable groups of orthopedic surgeons. He also lectured frequently and pioneered a specialized golf fitness center and swing clinic in Tequesta, FL. In private life, he was a member of several leading golf clubs in the U.S.A. and abroad, including the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews and the Honorable Company of Edinborough Golfers (Murifield, Scotland). His favorite charity was the Palm Beach Zoo, where he served as Board Chairman for several years and was a member of the Board for the past 20 years. He worked tirelessly to fulfill his dream of having a stateof-the-art animal hospital, which is now in the process of being built as part of the Animal Wellness Center at the Palm Beach Zoo. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Salvator Zeitlin Animal Hospital at the Palm Beach Zoo. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 23 at the Christ Memorial Church on Jupiter Island in Hobe Sound at 4:00pm.

Choose between two exhibits that should leave you feeling -- if not transcendent at least transported. The Milk Gallery is staging the first-ever show of works by Shinjo Ito, a sculptor, engraver and monk who founded the Shinnyo-en order of Buddhism. Though it has some 900,000 followers worldwide, few thought of their leader as an artist until recently, when his depictions of Buddha and his own family were part of a blockbuster show in Japan. While you're feeding your wanderlust, head to the ClampArt gallery, where the photographer Brian Finke -- known for his photos of football players and cheerleaders -- has a new series on flight attendants. Contemplate takeoff at the opening tonight. ''Inspired by Buddha, Admired as Art,'' by Lily Koppel

PRESS--Florence (nee Asteroff), 94, of Sarasota, FL, and formerly of Brooklyn and Yonkers, NY, died February 19, 2008. Florence was born November 21, 1913 in Yonkers to the late Charletta and Jacob Asteroff, and was the beloved wife of the late Sid Press. Florence is survived by her nieces and nephews, Esta Asteroff (Bob Bruno), Sarasota, FL; Janet Asteroff, Yonkers, NY; and Carol Press Stavenhagen (Joe), Lexington, MA; a sister-in-law, Elizabeth Asteroff, Sarasota; a stepson, Peter Kirschner, Miami, FL; grandniece and grandnephew Jill (Stavenhagen) and Kevin Plut, of Bay Harbor Island, FL; and numerous cousins, nieces, nephews and friends of a lifetime. A sweet and loving woman, a supportive and loyal friend, kind and generous always, Florrie was one in a million. She will be missed by all who knew her.

DOBRIN--Louise (Wasserman), 89, of Londonderry, NH, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died February 19, 2008 in Bedford, NH. Services by Peabody Funeral Homes, Londonderry, NH. To send a condolence or for more information, please visit: peabodyfuneralhome.com

CHEVINS--Anthony C. (''Tony''), 86, of Key Largo, Florida and Quechee, Vermont, died Tuesday, February 12, 2008 at Mariners Hospital in Tavenier, FL, following a short illness. He was born in Frackville, PA on April 1, 1921, the son of Charles and Mary Chevins, both deceased. His parents were immigrants from Lithuania and his father, a coal miner, died around the time of Tony's birth. He was the youngest of 10 siblings and his mother singlehandedly raised the seven children who survived to adulthood. During WWII, Tony joined the U.S. Navy and served as a pilot, flying a fighter plane from an aircraft carrier in the Pacific. Following the war, he attended college on the G.I. Bill, earning a Bachelors Degree in English and Journalism at Syracuse University, graduating Magna Cum Laude. He began work in the advertising industry in New York City in 1949, first with BBD&O and then in 1951, joining Cunningham & Walsh as a copywriter. He rose to become Creative Director, and ultimately earned the position of President, then CEO and Chairman of the Board. When Cunningham & Walsh later merged with N.W.Ayer, he served as Vice Chairman. Anthony was active in numerous advertising organizations, including as Director of the National Advertising Review Board, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, and Speaker for the Advertising Educational Foundation's Ambassador Program. He served on the Board of Directors of the Medic Alert International Foundation and the Mickelberry Corporation. Tony remained an active alumnus of Syracuse University and also served on the S.U.D. Advisory Board, the Community and Publication Issues Council, the Newhouse Board and the Alumnae Club. He received the George Arents Pioneer Medal from Syracuse in 1987 as well as awards from Tau Beta Epsilon and Phi Beta Kappa. Tony was an avid golfer, belonging for many years to Woodway Golf Club in Darien, CT, National Golf Links in Easthampton, NY and the Card Sound Golf Club at Ocean Reef in Key Largo, FL. He was an avid and accomplished photographer, a fisherman, an amateur gardener and an international traveler. He was actively involved after his retirement with public service work in the various communities in which he and his wife, Margaret, lived; publishing newsletters, managing an interdenominational chapel, running prayer groups and taking on whatever other organizational tasks were needed. Tony loved to be with people and made friends wherever he found himself. He will be grievously missed. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Macy Chevins, of Key Largo, FL, two children, Cheryl L. Davis (Jeffrey Noe) of Rhinebeck, NY and Christopher M. Chevins (Cheryl Peterka) of New York, NY, as well as several grandchildren; Jennifer Davis, Chelsea Noe, and Garrett, Corinna and Travis Lander. His daughter, Cynthia M. Chevins, predeceased him last year. Memorial services will be held in the Chapel at Ocean Reef, Key Largo on Sunday, March 30, at 4 PM. The family requests that memorial donations be made to The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in New York (stjohndivine.org) or The Nature Conservancy (nature.org).

DeROSE--Louis, 87, died on February 19, in New York City. He was born in Calabria, Italy and came to New York City when he was twelve. He was the chef/owner of La Strada East Restaurant on 3rd Avenue and 22nd Street for 32 years until he closed it and retired in 1987. He was predeceased by his wife Doloros and son George and is survived by his beloved daughter and son-in-law, Denise and John Chilelli, of Garden City, and much loved grandchildren Adam, Marisa and Paul, by three siblings, Phyllis, Frank and Joe. He is also survived by his life partner Clare Garetano, whose life he filled with joy and love. Louis was loved for his sweet disposition, kindness and generosity. He will be waked at Dalton Funeral Home in New Hyde Park on Thursday, February 21st. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Anne's Church in Garden City on Friday, February 22nd. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.

SHIVITZ--David I., died February 19, 2008, Palm Beach Gardens, FL, at age 100. Survived by his loving wife Floren and by daughters Barbara Isaacs of NY and Stefanie Roth of London, son Richard Roth of London and granddaughter Elise Roth. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton, NYU, and NY Law School, David had a distinguished career in public service, as NYC corporation counsel during the LaGuardia mayoralty and as counsel for the Kefauver US Senate Crime Investigating Committee. As a lawyer in private practice, David was admired for skill, judgment and integrity; his friendship cherished by many far beyond NYC and Nyack, his home for many years. Funeral service Noon, Friday 22nd February, Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach, FL.

JIAVARAS--Arthur Nicholas, 76, died peacefully at his home, in the loving care of his family on February 20, 2008 after a valiant struggle with cancer. Reposing Riverdale Funeral home, 5044 Broadway (214 St) on Thursday 2-5 and 7-9. Mass on Friday 11:30am at St. Spyridon G.O. Church Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the St. Spyridon Church Restoration Fund (124 Wadsworth Avenue, New York City, NY 10033) or to Calvary Home Hospice (1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461).

REISCHER--Nathan, born 1948 in Trani, Italy, raised in Houston, Texas died February 16, after a valiant struggle with cancer. A loving and devoted husband to Lorie, he is also survived by his brother Harry, niece Erica and grandniece Avery. Nathan began his career in finance in Seattle, WA; moved to General Motors Investment Management Co. in New York and most recently was at RIMCO in Washington, DC. He will be missed by his loving family, friends and colleagues. Shiva calls may be made through Tuesday, February 26 at 60 West 66th Street, Apt 31A. ALEXANDER--Robert The founder and Artistic Director of The Living Stage Theatre Company, died Sunday, February 10 after a long illness. He was 78 years old. The Living Stage, founded by Alexander in Washington, D.C. in 1966 as an outreach of the Arena Stage, dedicated itself to working with the city's ''forgotten''. For 36 years Living Stage had a profound impact on the physically handicapped, men and women in prisons, and chiefly on the impoverished youth in D.C. and throughout the country, where he trained many teachers. Until his retirement in 1995, Bob tirelessly fought for the dignity and beauty of all he worked with by helping them harness their unique, empowering, creative voice. He was recognized nationally and received many public accolades as a champion for truth and justice and the well being of the young and vulnerable. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Bob first found success as an actor Off Broadway, and in early film and TV. He also drove a taxi for 13 years. In 1962 he married the actress Jane Alexander, and they had a son, Jace, now a film and theater director. Bob began directing childrens theater at the Charles Playhouse in Boston, and was then hired to direct at the Arena Stage, where he soon began his life's work. He later married Riki Alexander. Their son, Taro, is the Artistic Director of New York's Our Time Theatre Company. For the past 28 years he was married to Kelly Alexander, and they have a young daughter, Jazzoya. Besides his three children, and his wife, Kelly, Bob is survived by his sister, Carole Becker, and four grandchildren, Isabelle Moon, Mac, Finn and Jackson Miles.

The people at the Greenpoint Reformed Church, whose new soup kitchen and food pantry I wrote about for the Dispatches feature in this week’s City Section, say they got the whole endeavor off the ground, in seat-of-the-pants fashion, without a lot of instruction or training. Asked if, four months in, it was living up to what they had envisioned, the Rev. Jennifer Aull, one of the Brooklyn church’s pastors, said: “I don’t know if we really had much envisioning. You know, you kind of don’t know how to do things until you’ve done them already.”

Leslie Day, the author of “Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City” (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), took questions from readers over the past week. She is also an adjunct faculty member at Bank Street College of Education. Dr. Day and her husband live on a houseboat on the Hudson River in Manhattan.

If there is a silver lining to the wet storm that blanketed the Northeast with snow this morning, this is it: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has just postponed all construction activity that had been planned this weekend, meaning that most subways will run on their normal weekend schedules. Arguably, no one can outdo Martin Scorsese as a New York filmmaker. “Taxi Driver.” “Mean Streets.” “Who’s That Knocking at My Door?” Not only was he born in New York, but he also went to New York University’s film school. He even had a film called “New York, New York” (though admittedly a box-office and critical failure).So it was rather disappointing that, after being shut out numerous times, the movie that won him an Academy Award for best director was “The Departed,” which (gasp!) is set in Boston. That would be like Joe Torre taking over the Red Sox and managing them to a World Series title.

It has become widely known as the “50-shot” case, but as the trial of the detectives accused in the killing of Sean Bell approaches on Monday, Michael Wilson reports, the defense is expected to concentrate in particular on 2 of those 50 bullets: the first one fired by each of the two detectives who are charged with manslaughter. If the two detectives can prove that they were not acting recklessly or with criminal intent in firing their first shots at Mr. Bell and his friends in Queens on Nov. 25, 2006, then the shots that followed — 40 more rounds between them — could be determined to be justified as well, said lawyers who have represented police officers in the past and people who have been briefed on the case. A third detective faces two misdemeanor charges.

Several works in “Design and the Elastic Mind,” an exhibition that opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, offer intriguing and unexpected perspectives on New York. A team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has mapped the international phone calls and Internet traffic that connect the city with countries around the world, showing, for example, just how often Queens immigrants are on the phone back home with India. A design lab at Columbia University has traced the costs of incarceration in poor minority neighborhoods, demonstrating that taxpayers in some cases pay $1 million a year to imprison inmates from a single Brooklyn block.

Over the last few months, we've had quite a debate in the comments here about the relative merits of Blu-ray, HD DVD and standard DVD discs. Some argue we don't need discs at all because we'll all be able to download movies. And others have suggested that the price of memory chips is falling so fast that we might still buy movies in stores, but they may come loaded on U.S.B. memory sticks or the sort of SD memory cards that go in digital cameras.
(Matt Ross)

Trust the Bagger when he says that one of the show-stoppers of Sunday night will come when Impact Repertory sings "Raise It Up," one of the nominees for best song, from the movie "August Rush." It turned out that she also had her own musical career, along with film and television work, including a role in "I'm Reed Fish."

But Rodriguez predicted on Thursday that Jeter would have an M.V.P. season in 2008. Rodriguez based this on a conversation he had at lunch with Jeter on Thursday about Jeter's conditioning during the off-season.

A quick announcement: Deanna Dunagan, who plays Violet in the current production of "August," will be on a panel of Broadway actors in a TimesTalks event this coming Monday, Feb. 25, at 6:30 at the Times Center in Midtown Manhattan. Campbell Robertson, the Times theater reporter, is interviewing her along with Ian McShane and Brian Cox.

Unless you know that the suffix "-innen" denotes the feminine plural in German, you might miss the meaning conveyed by the title of this exhibit. You've probably heard of Manet, Monet, Renoir and Degas. This is all about the women who belonged to the same movement in late 19th century Paris, but have been unjustly filtered out of most historical accounts.

Municipal politics can get heated and personal in almost any city or town in America, and Kirkwood, Mo., was no exception even before Charles Lee Thornton, a 52-year-old contractor, walked into a city council meeting on Feb. 7 and opened fire, killing two council members, the city public works chief and two police officers and wounding the mayor and a reporter before he was shot dead by police. Mr. Thornton, in fact, was said to have been a frequent, angry presence at earlier meetings, waging a war of shouts with city officials that led to him being banned from speaking.

I often hear people asking whether it's worth trying to limit your personal "greenhouse effect" by driving less, buying less, eating local, and the like. Personally, I choose to limit my energy use as much as I can for both economic and environmental reasons. I try to telecommute whenever possible not just to save the planet, but to relish a break taken walking in the woods instead of to an elevator.

I'm almost never censored at the Times. However, I was told that I couldn't use the lede I originally wrote for my column following the 2007 State of the Union address, in which Bush made ethanol the centerpiece of his energy strategy: "Before the State of the Union address, there had been hints and hopes that President Bush would offer a serious plan to reduce our dependence on imported oil. Instead, however, he took refuge in alcohol."

The Gagosian Gallery on North Camden Drive in Beverly Hills hosted the opening of a massive array of skeletons on Thursday night by an artist who also makes the occasional movie. The work was by Julian Schnabel, and was inspired by some X-rays, made early in the 20th century, that he came across in an uninhabited house in Berck-sur-Mer on the Normandy coast while making "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly." The paintings, like the film, explore the human condition from the inside out. And they were also virtually cinematic in size, towering over the gallery full of filmies, arties and wannabees.

The Bagger is a little long on material and a little short on space (and he thought the Interweb was infinite), so forgive him if he sounds like Liz Smith with a modem. O.K., here goes: The dinner after the opening at the Gagosian was thick with luminaries. Russell Simmons was there, as were Colin Callendar of HBO Films, his wife Elizabeth and Chris DeWolfe, the founder of MySpace. And that was just at the Bagger's table.

The surprise $2.85 billion write-down at Credit Suisse this week underscored the difficulty banks face in valuing complex investments. But the cause of the blunder may be simple: traders at the bank used old prices.

The Chinese aluminum company Chinalco, which this year led a $14 billion acquisition of 12 percent of Rio Tinto, said in remarks in an influential magazine that it will continue to seek acquisitions abroad.

A New York hedge fund, DB Zwirn, is winding down its principal funds after investors - rattled by lapses in internal controls, including the expense of a private jet used by the firm's founder - said they would withdraw more than $2 billion, The Financial Times reported.

A horseplayer with an itch to bet has two options in New York City. Drive out to the racetrack or step into one of the 60 or so Off-Track Betting parlors scattered over the five boroughs. Option two is not an inviting prospect.
“Vantage Point,” a gimmick in search of a point, is nothing if not, er, timely.

Genentech’s Avastin received federal approval to treat breast cancer, a decision that could be a major shift in standards to assess the effectiveness of cancer medicines.

Manu Ginóbili hit a jumper from the top of the key with 6.2 seconds left for the last of his 44 points, leading the San Antonio Spurs to their fourth straight win.

The governor of the Bank of Japan said on Friday that the global economy continued to expand but that, if the slowdown in the United States deepens, it could affect growth in other parts of the world.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn. (AP) — A former music director at a prominent church in Greenwich, Conn., has been sentenced to 5.5 years in federal prison for possessing child pornography.

A theater review last Friday about the musical “The Blue Flower,” at the West End Theater in Manhattan, misquoted part of a lyric that served as a response to a series of deaths and dislocations in the show. It should have been “All ships that are sailing/Will come again to port,” not “And ships that are sailing.”.
A film review last Friday about this year’s Oscar-nominated shorts misidentified the animation technique used in Aleksandr Petrov’s “My Love.” It was hand-drawn using oil paint on glass, not pastels.

The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about movie downloading, referred incorrectly in some editions to a feature of the TiVo digital recording device that lets users rent or buy movies from Amazon. The movies can be ordered and downloaded through TiVo; it is not necessary to order the movies from Amazon.com using a personal computer.

An article on Feb. 12 about a lawsuit challenging a new campaign finance law in New York City, filed by a lawyer who successfully challenged Vermont’s campaign finance restrictions before the United States Supreme Court, misstated, in some copies, the limit per donor for each election in statewide races in Vermont, which the justices said would prevent some candidates from getting their message out. It was $400, not $200.

An article on Monday about plans to move and restore the Grange, Alexander Hamilton’s country home in Upper Manhattan, attributed an erroneous distinction to that home. At least one other house associated with Hamilton survives: the Schuyler Mansion in Albany (also known as the Pastures), where he was married. The Grange is not the only one associated with him that still exists.

An article on Thursday about the big legal bills being run up by New York City and a state authority over a criminal investigation into the fatal fire at the former Deutsche Bank building last August referred incorrectly to the two law firms hired by the city and the authority, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The law firms — Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, and Dechert L.L.P. — are full-service firms; their practices are not limited to criminal defense.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sale of some parts of the chef Emeril Lagasse’s franchise to Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia misstated which of his two Food Network television programs was older. “Essence of Emeril,” which had its debut in 1994, was Mr. Lagasse’s first program on the cable network — not “Emeril Live,” which ran from 1997 to 2007. (“Essence of Emeril” went off the air in 1996 and returned in 2000 in a new form. It continues to be produced.).

An article on Monday about Washington State’s presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the state’s nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one.

An article on Jan. 12 about jury selection in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, a Brooklyn man accused of fatally beating his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, referred incorrectly to Mr. Rodriguez’s courtroom attire. He wore handcuffs as he was led into and out of the courtroom while prospective jurors were absent; he was not wearing handcuffs, hidden beneath his leather jacket, in the presence of prospective jurors. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

An article on Monday about Washington State’s presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the state’s nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one.

A 5-year-old Queens boy died Thursday in a fire that broke out after he had apparently been left alone in his family’s locked apartment, the authorities said.

The picturesque forested trail that runs past Otter Lake and Long Lake on the southern edge of the Adirondacks near Woodgate, N.Y., has been the location for the deaths of three snowmobilers over five days. Over all, the recent spate of snowmobile fatalities in Oneida County — a total of four deaths in nine days — pushed the number of people killed in snowmobiling accidents this winter in New York to 18. That put the state on pace for its deadliest sledding season since 31 riders died in 2002-3, according to the state Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.The most recent accident was late Monday or early Tuesday when 22-year-old Craig Albert crashed into a stand of trees about a half-mile from where two of his friends were killed over the weekend.

Playing crisply on a course he designed, Greg Norman used a run of birdies to move up to fifth place at the Mayakoba Golf Classic in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, on Thursday. Then his rustiness kicked in. Norman’s concentration wavered when a clump of grass blew across his ball in a greenside bunker on his 16th hole. Instead of pausing, he hit anyway — and failed to make it out, the ball rolling back to nearly the same spot. Then it happened again. Norman, making his second PGA Tour start of the year but only his fifth in four years, wound up with a double bogey. Another lapse of concentration on the next hole resulted in a three-putt from about 12 feet for a bogey. After coming up inches short of a birdie on the final hole, Norman walked off with an even-par round of 70 — tied for 40th.“I pretty much let a good one get away,” Norman said. “You need the feel for tournament play and I don’t have it. At the end of the day, I did hit some quality shots out there, so you know they’re still in the system.”The field was chasing John Merrick, who holed a roughly 50-foot putt on his final shot for a six-under-par 64 and a one-stroke lead.

ESPN must provide the relatives of George Gipp, who died in 1920 of pneumonia, with any materials it has related to the exhumation of the Notre Dame halfback’s body, according to a ruling in a lawsuit stemming from the exhumation.Gipp’s remains were dug up Oct. 4 for DNA testing to determine whether he had fathered his girlfriend’s child. The results were negative.ESPN crews recorded the exhumation for a planned program.Karl Gipp, who says he and George Gipp are first cousins once removed, and another cousin, Ron Gipp, filed the suit in November in Houghton County Circuit Court in Michigan. In seeking damages of more than $25,000, they accuse the defendants of negligence, contending that the remains of the player’s sister, Bertha Isabelle Gipp Martin, were disturbed because workers initially dug in the wrong spot. She was buried next to her brother.

Carolina Kluft of Sweden withdrew from the 60-meter hurdles and the long jump at the GE Galan indoor meet in Stockholm because of a right thigh injury. Kluft, the reigning European, world and Olympic heptathlon champion, could miss the rest of the indoor season. The Swedish team doctor said an examination indicated it was internal bleeding, and that it would require three to four weeks of rest.

CONANT--Frank E., a 60-year resident of Darien, CT died on February 20, 2008 at Broad Creek Care Center on Hilton Head Island, SC. He was 98. During World War II, he served three years in the Army Air Corps as a Major in Intelligence. Initially stationed in England, Mr. Conant saw action after D-Day in St. Lo, France. His business career in Manhattan included stints as Vice President of the Irving Trust Company and Chase Manhattan Bank and Vice Chairman of Cushman Wakefield. Mr. Conant was past president and chairman of the Fifth Avenue Association. He served on numerous boards of directors, most notably as chairman of the finance committee at MetroGoldwyn-Mayer. Mr. Conant belonged to Woodway Country Club in Darien. He was also an active member of the U.S. Seniors Golf Association, an honorary member of the Union League Club in Manhattan and worked with the Darien Republican Town Committee in the 1980s. He was predeceased by his wife Frances. He is survived by a sister, Florence Celley; three nephews; his son Scott of Hilton Head, SC; his daughter-inlaw Lynn; a step-granddaughter; two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice Care of the Lowcountry, P.O. Box 3827, Bluffton, SC 29910 or the Salvation Army. The Island Funeral Home and Crematory is in charge of services.

'ON TOP OF SPAGHETTI' In a Queens theater recently, minutes before showtime, a student of about 6 was doing what most small children do in an auditorium: everything but keep still. ''Sit down!'' her teacher said. ''You're in a theater. You're not in a playground.'' Poor benighted woman; she had obviously never seen the Paper Bag Players. For them every show is a playground, stretching the imaginations and the muscles of those who come to frolic as well as to watch. By the end of the next hour, the girl and her fellow pupils had been encouraged to shout directions, make swimming motions, sneeze loudly, twist like boiling pasta and sing ''On Top of Spaghetti'' at a volume that would make heavy metal seem like Bible study. I didn't see exactly what the teacher was doing, but she wasn't issuing reprimands.

In its sweet, lackadaisical way, Michel Gondry's ''Be Kind Rewind'' illuminates the pleasures and paradoxes of movie love. Its two main characters, a pair of Passaic, N.J., loafers named Mike and Jerry, are devotees of the Hollywood mainstream, paying tribute to well-worn classics like ''Ghostbusters,''''Driving Miss Daisy,''''Rush Hour 2'' and ''The Lion King.'' The way they express this affection lands Mike and Jerry in a spot of copyright trouble, but they (and Mr. Gondry) provide a welcome reminder that even the slickest blockbuster is also a piece of handicraft, an artifact of somebody's nutty, unbounded ingenuity and the potential object of somebody else's innocent, childlike fascination. Mike (Mos Def) works in a shabby video store whose owner, Mr. Fletcher (Danny Glover), has not yet made the leap to DVD. His business threatened by the dubious improvements of a city-backed redevelopment scheme, Mr. Fletcher sneaks away on a mysterious trip, leaving the blundering, well-intentioned Mike in charge of his stock of battered VHS cassettes. Jerry (Jack Black), an avant-garde auto mechanic and tireless tinkerer, suffers an accident that magnetizes his body, causing him to accidentally erase all the tapes.

Visitors to the annual orchid show at the New York Botanical Garden are accustomed to seeing and sniffing more than 8,000 blooms from all over the world. This year they will do so in a setting inspired by Singapore, a center of flower growing and hybridizing with a $20 million orchid industry. (Its national flower, the Vanda Miss Joaquim, is a native orchid hybrid discovered on the island by a Miss Agnes Joaquim in 1893.) An orchid-covered pagoda resting in a pool leads the way to an alley of orchid-covered arches; the designers looked to the Singapore Botanic Garden for ideas, said Francisca Coelho, a curator of the exhibition. This Sunday and next, Michael A. Morales, a founder of the Manhattan Orchid Society, will give a talk on the species cultivated in Asia, focusing on the dendrobium, cymbidium, phalaenopsis and vanda families of Singapore. The display also includes a hundred or so of the approximately 30,000 Old World and naturally occurring orchid species, as well as many of the 150,000 man-made ones. ''There's new stuff that's created every year,'' Ms. Coelho said. ''We have the parents of the plants that we're using to make new ones. Go smell the generations.'' (Through April 6, the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard at 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx, 718-817-8700, nybg.org.) MELENA RYZIK

A carefree hit man throws a party-killing punch in a crowded disco and then just as quickly gets back on the dance floor. A mobster trying to escape the underworld with his sweetheart is struck down on a train platform by a roving pack of trench coats. These are not scenes from a jazzy French New Wave film or an American Mafia tragedy, but from the violent and highly Westernized crime movies that flourished in Japan in the 1960s under Nikkatsu, one of the country's oldest studios. Unlike the sober historical work by Kurosawa and Mizoguchi, the Nikkatsu action pictures -- called akushon, they were churned out by the hundreds -- are quick-cut, intoxicating rides through noirish city alleyways and bars where gangsters order whiskey and take home the waitresses. Since September Japan Society has been presenting a monthly series of these films, none of which have been screened in the United States before.

SKURA--Sam. We are inconsolable at the passing of our dearest friend Sam Skura. A wonderful person and a partner in all our endeavors and life's mission of Remembrance, he gave of himself tirelessly and selflessly. We will miss his presence, good counsel and uncompromising friendship. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Stella, Cheryl, his grandchildren Iris Lifshitz and Adam Lindenbaum, and Ilana Lifshitz, his two sisters and their entire family. Our hearts are with you at this difficult time. Dr. Elizabeth Mundlak Zborowski and Eli Zborowski Dr. Lilly Zborowski Naveh and Avner Naveh and Family Murry Zborowski and Family SKURA--Sam. The American Society for Yad Vashem, its Officers, Board of Directors, and staff deeply mourn the passing of its esteemed and beloved Founding Vice Chairman and friend Sam Skura. A Holocaust survivor, Sam was an outstanding leader and mentor who was tirelessly committed to Remembrance and the teaching of tolerance in our community and around the world. His work set an example for generations to come. A truly righteous and generous man, his work will continue to serve as an inspiration to all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Stella, his daughter Cheryl Skura Lifshitz a member of the Executive Committee of the American and International Society for Yad Vashem, his grandchildren Iris Lifshitz and Adam Lindenbaum, and Ilana Lifshitz, his two sisters and to their entire family. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The American Society for Yad Vashem Eli Zborowski, Chairman Joseph Wilf, Vice-Chairman SKURA--Sam. We, at Yad Vashem in Jerusalem, note with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed benefactor Sam Skura. A true friend and co-founder of the American Society for Yad Vashem, Mr. Skura dedicated his life's work to the acts of Remembrance and tolerance and his generous efforts will forever be evident through the many programs and facilities at the Yad Vashem museum. We send our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Stella and his daughter Cheryl, a member of the Executive Committee of the American and International Society for Yad Vashem, his grandchildren, his sisters and to their entire family. 'LIVE ****' It's hard enough keeping tabs on all the official performances on any given night in this city, let alone all the lively, artist-run events percolating around them. Thankfully, the shows in that category -- which often have a leg up on their proscenium competition in terms of offering alcohol and a festive but seriously experimental atmosphere -- aren't as frequent. Take ''Live ****,'' situated in the unfinished basement of the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens. The artists who run it, Chris Peck and Chase Granoff, describe the series as ''an intermittent performance party situation.'' The next installment, on Saturday, features the wonderfully uncategorizable Karinne Keithley, whose talents run from choreography to publishing to film; the composer Jon Moniaci, whose movement and sound installation with Mr. Granoff, ''Boredom!!! (as an amplifier)'' (above, Mr. Granoff, top, and Mr. Moniaci) was one of 2007's most charming performance pieces; and Bárbara Bañuelos Ojeda, a Spanish choreographer whose work Mr. Granoff has never seen but whose ideas about performance intrigued him.
SETH PRICE Friedrich Petzel Gallery

To the Editor: ''Poverty Is Poison,'' by Paul Krugman (column, Feb. 18), echoes what members of Congress heard at a national summit meeting about child development that Democrats convened last year. Children who grow up in poverty have a much lower chance of success in school and in life, but investments in early childhood development help to even the odds, offering hope and opportunity where little existed before.

In tones freighted with frustration, Britain's foreign secretary, David Miliband, told the House of Commons on Thursday that, ''contrary to earlier explicit assurances,'' the Central Intelligence Agency had confirmed using an American-operated airfield on a British island in the Indian Ocean for refueling two ''rendition'' flights carrying terrorism suspects in 2002. The American acknowledgment contradicted previous assurances by the United States to Britain's government that no such flights had landed on British territory or passed through British airspace. Each flight carried a single detainee and stopped on the island of Diego Garcia.

CHEVINS--Anthony C. (''Tony''), 86, of Key Largo, Florida and Quechee, Vermont, died Tuesday, February 12, 2008 at Mariners Hospital in Tavenier, FL, following a short illness. He was born in Frackville, PA on April 1, 1921, the son of Charles and Mary Chevins, both deceased. His parents were immigrants from Lithuania and his father, a coal miner, died around the time of Tony's birth. He was the youngest of 10 siblings and his mother singlehandedly raised the seven children who survived to adulthood. During WWII, Tony joined the U.S. Navy and served as a pilot, flying a fighter plane from an aircraft carrier in the Pacific. Following the war, he attended college on the G.I. Bill, earning a Bachelors Degree in English and Journalism at Syracuse University, graduating Magna Cum Laude. He began work in the advertising industry in New York City in 1949, first with BBD&O and then in 1951, joining Cunningham & Walsh as a copywriter. He rose to become Creative Director, and ultimately earned the position of President, then CEO and Chairman of the Board. When Cunningham & Walsh later merged with N.W.Ayer, he served as Vice Chairman. Anthony was active in numerous advertising organizations, including as Director of the National Advertising Review Board, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, and Speaker for the Advertising Educational Foundation's Ambassador Program. He served on the Board of Directors of the Medic Alert International Foundation and the Mickelberry Corporation. Tony remained an active alumnus of Syracuse University and also served on the S.U.D. Advisory Board, the Community and Publication Issues Council, the Newhouse Board and the Alumnae Club. He received the George Arents Pioneer Medal from Syracuse in 1987 as well as awards from Tau Beta Epsilon and Phi Beta Kappa. Tony was an avid golfer, belonging for many years to Woodway Golf Club in Darien, CT, National Golf Links in Easthampton, NY and the Card Sound Golf Club at Ocean Reef in Key Largo, FL. He was an avid and accomplished photographer, a fisherman, an amateur gardener and an international traveler. He was actively involved after his retirement with public service work in the various communities in which he and his wife, Margaret, lived; publishing newsletters, managing an interdenominational chapel, running prayer groups and taking on whatever other organizational tasks were needed. Tony loved to be with people and made friends wherever he found himself. He will be grievously missed. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Macy Chevins, of Key Largo, FL, two children, Cheryl L. Davis (Jeffrey Noe) of Rhinebeck, NY and Christopher M. Chevins (Cheryl Peterka) of New York, NY, as well as several grandchildren; Jennifer Davis, Chelsea Noe, and Garrett, Corinna and Travis Lander. His daughter, Cynthia M. Chevins, predeceased him last year. Memorial services will be held in the Chapel at Ocean Reef, Key Largo on Sunday, March 30, at 4 PM. The family requests that memorial donations be made to The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in New York (stjohndivine.org) or The Nature Conservancy (nature.org).

WESTENBURG--Richard. The Board of Directors of Musica Sacra mourns the passing of Richard Westenburg, its esteemed founder. One of the great choral conductors of our time, he was a beloved teacher and mentor, respected scholar, leader and friend to all who had the privilege of making music under his direction. For over forty years audiences have been inspired by his interpretations of choral masterworks old and new, as well as commissioned works by modern composers such as Rorem, Hovhaness, Diamond, Danielpour, Larsen, collaborations with many such as Dave Brubeck and Meredith Monk and by his commitment to musical excellence throughout the repertoire of choral music. A giant has fallen, but his artistic legacy will endure. His graciousness, elegance, joy, wit and integrity in all areas of his life will be sorely missed. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Memorial gifts may be made to the Musica Sacra Richard Westenburg Memorial Fund, P.O. Box #

RUTH ROOT ''Richard Tuttle''; ''Josef Albers''; ''The Quilts of Gee's Bend''; ''Ski Socks.'' The news release for Ruth Root's first solo at Andrew Kreps since 2003 is an illustrated litany of free-associative visual references, some more predictable than others. A nod to the visionary colorist Sonia Delaunay might be expected, but what about ''Matching Dresses and Wallpaper in 'The Umbrellas of Cherbourg' ''? For an emerging artist, a list like that might sound pretentious, but Ms. Root has been around long enough to get away with it. Her eight recent paintings, all made with enamel on shaped aluminum panels (and untitled, like the one at left), exhibit combinations of geometric forms and saturated colors -- a toothpaste green and a crocuslike violet, a warm gray and a wan chartreuse. It is probably no accident that they resemble comic-strip speech bubbles; in the past, Ms. Root has adorned her compositions with pairs of tiny eyes and trompe l'oeil cigarettes.

Tucked down Aisle 900 of Toy Fair (just Toy Fair, mind you, not ''the Toy Fair'') at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center -- amid the newest whirring, glowing, hovering, shrinking playthings clamoring to be the hit product this year -- is a space reserved for the elite of the elite, the toys that don't have to prove themselves anymore to anybody. They are the inductees to the National Toy Hall of Fame. The honored toys include the sophisticated but obsolete (Atari 2600, inducted in 2007) and the humble (cardboard box, 2005), the trademarked (Scrabble, 2004) and the generic (kite, 2007), the domestic (Easy-Bake Oven, 2006) and the militaristic (G. I. Joe, 2004).

Even very strong players are not immune to making fairly basic mistakes, as shown by the first two problems in this set, which come from games in the Aeroflot Open. Endgames are often won with precise play, as seen in the fourth problem. The last problem is not from a game, but rather is based on an actual position and involves a king hunt. In each case, click on the chess board and wait for the viewer to load, then make a move on the chess board by clicking and dragging a piece and wait for the computer to respond. If you get the whole sequence of moves right , the computer will let you know that you succeeded. Hints are available. Enjoy!

It isn't every day - or ever, really - that Sandy Koufax decides to speak with reporters but that day came today (you can read all about him online later tonight) Koufax, a childhood friend of Fred Wilpon, usually drops by spring training to speak with a left-hander - Tom Glavine or Al Leiter, in the past - and he did so today at the request of Billy Wagner, who is learning to throw a curveball. And, really, is there anyone better to learn that pitch from than Koufax? But Koufax has a very special relationship with Pedro Martinez, who met Koufax about 20 years ago when he was a 17-year-old in Dodgertown, up in Vero Beach, for the first time. Pedro spoke about that relationship with us today. Some of it you'll see in my story, but Pedro was so fantastic speaking about the subject that it would be unfair for baseball fans not to read more. Here's a chunk of the Q&A with Pedro. Enjoy.

I've had a ton of indignant emails about last Sunday's column about John McCain, in which I said I disagreed with his positions but admired his willingness to disagree so often with the voters whose support he needed. Most of the criticism was from people who think it's wrong to give McCain any credit, given his recent moves to the right.
