Oscar weekend, for a blogger who has been mostly typing in his basement, is disconcerting in that suddenly this world he has been flicking at from a distance comes to life before his very eyes.

Industry types have taken a few gentle whacks at the diminutive 20-year-old, Ellen Page, suggesting that the star of "Juno" and a best actress nominee has not paid respect to all the glamour and gravitas of the Oscar season as she should. Page is not unaware of the blandishments of the process, she just prefers to treat it as a buffet table, taking some of it and leaving the rest, rather than just diving in. The Bagger interviewed her at the beginning of the season and now at its end, and she has not lost any of her gee-whiz or her innate skepticism of the trappings of stardom.

Glen Hansard, front man of The Frames and a best song nominee for "Falling Slowly" from "Once," thought for a quick second when the Bagger asked whether he was more intimidated by the prospect of performing for the Oscar hordes or sitting in his seat while the best song winner is announced.
Diablo Cody has been motoring through the season without much of a hitch, but Saturday was tough.

The bar at the Four Seasons hotel in Beverly Hills is a good place to take a seat in the peanut gallery. In the early evening, Harvey Weinstein motored through, Leslee Dart and Allan Mayer, the reps to the stars, were sharing a drink. Mr. Mayer said that the Oscar weekend's quieter affect had less to do with some mutual agreement to keep a lid on than a kind of opportunity.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 23 column.
(Mark St. Amant is the author of Committed: Confessions of a Fantasy Football Junkie and Just Kick It: Tales of an Underdog, Over-Age, Out-of-Place Semi-Pro Football Player.)
In “Witless Protection,” Larry the Cable Guy plays a small-town deputy, fantasizing about becoming an F.B.I. agent. Sitcom wackiness ensues.
From the moment he finished his comeback two days earlier to the moment he shook hands with Aaron Baddeley there has been an almost palpable sense of certainty about Tiger Woods.
Jeremy Lin scored 20 points, including a layup near the end of regulation, as host Harvard defeated Princeton, 74-67, in overtime to stop a seven-game losing streak.
Economic policy makers in developing countries couldn’t help but raise an eyebrow as the United States began trying to mitigate its credit crunch.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and top Australian officials insisted that the security alliance between the United States and Australia has not frayed.
One man was killed and two others were injured in a shooting at a popular Mexican restaurant in Brooklyn on Friday night.
As the N.B.A.’s trading season grinded to a halt, Coach Isiah Thomas was left with nothing to sell Friday but well-worn rhetoric.
Mike Dunleavy scored 34 points as the Indiana Pacers beat the Nets, 113-103, on Friday night in Indianapolis to end a three-game losing streak.

A former top state lawmaker was sentenced to more than three years in prison for using his legislative influence to benefit a pharmacy chain and an insurance company. Judge Mary M. Lisi of Federal District Court said Gerard Martineau, a former House majority leader, had used his office “in the most perverse way” but also had shown genuine remorse. Judge Lisi sentenced him to 37 months and fined him $100,000. Prosecutors also said Mr. Martineau, a Woonsocket Democrat, was cooperating in an influence-peddling inquiry at the Statehouse. Mr. Martineau pleaded guilty to using his influence to benefit the CVS pharmacy chain and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Rhode Island while doing hundreds of thousands of dollars in personal business with them.

The driver of a van that hit a school bus in a crash that killed four children was charged with four counts of criminal vehicular homicide and two lesser charges, the authorities said. The driver, identified as Alianiss Nunez Morales, 23, of Minneota, ran a stop sign Tuesday before hitting the bus, which was carrying 28 students from Lakeview School, a prosecutor said. The accident happened near Cottonwood. Ms. Morales was also charged with a stop sign violation and for driving without a valid license, the Lyon County attorney, Richard Maes, said. The authorities said Morales was not the woman’s real name, and Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents were trying to figure out her identity. Claude Arnold, special agent in charge of investigations, said Ms. Morales told investigators she was from Mexico. She does not have a Minnesota driver’s license, or a license “anywhere that we’re aware of,” said Lt. Mark Peterson of the Minnesota State Patrol.

Confused police abandoned their search for a car wreck, leaving a 66-year-old man, who died outside his vehicle in freezing temperatures, and his autistic grandson, who huddled inside for nearly a day. A passer-by talking to a dispatcher tried to direct city officers and DeKalb County sheriff’s deputies to the wreck, but they mistook the car as belonging to someone gathering firewood, the police said. Deputies later found the body of Duane Squire outside his car; his grandson Erich, 14, was treated and released from a hospital.

N. Wayne Hale Jr., a 30-year veteran of NASA who helped lead the space agency’s recovery from the 2003 Columbia disaster, was transferred from his job as manager of the shuttle program. Neither NASA nor Mr. Hale gave a reason for the shift, to a new position in space operations at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Mr. Hale, who championed making safety the paramount factor in deciding when shuttles are to fly, said in a memorandum to colleagues that he had expected to stay with the shuttle program until it ended in 2010 with completion of the International Space Station, but that he had recently been asked to assume the new job. He will be succeeded by John Shannon, a former flight director who is chairman of NASA’s Mission Management Team.
If a new agreement is reached, it would provide a swift end to yet another broken private equity deal, a phenomenon that has become more common as the credit markets have tightened.
Many fans are still unhappy over how quickly Chris Drury signed a five-year $35.25 million deal with the Rangers.

Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda ordered a review of the Defense Ministry’s structure amid mounting criticism of its handling of a collision between its most advanced naval destroyer and a small fishing boat.

A sports article on Feb. 15 about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens paraphrased incorrectly from a transcript of a conversation between Mr. McNamee and investigators for Mr. Clemens on the day before the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball was released. Mr. McNamee said he told Jim Murray, a New York-based representative for Mr. Clemens’s agent, that steroids had come from the former Mets bat boy Kirk Radomski. He did not say he had purchased steroids and growth hormone from Mr. Radomski.
About 45 tons of fish have washed up dead along 200 miles of beach on the outlying Penghu Islands after an unusual cold snap.
A remotely controlled roadside bomb ripped through cars carrying a wedding party, killing at least 14 people, including the bride.
A judge in Ipswich sentenced Steven Wright, the killer of five prostitutes in 2006, to life in prison with no hope of release.
China disclosed a large percentage rise for 2007 in diseases transmitted sexually or via blood, including AIDS and syphilis, without reporting exact figures.
A 26-year-old engineer was sentenced to three years in prison for creating a fake profile of the king’s brother on Facebook, the Internet social networking site.
President Abdullah Gul approved a change in the Constitution that lifts a ban against women’s head scarves at universities.

An article on Thursday about campaign spending by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama misstated, in some copies, the amount of money Mrs. Clinton had at the end of January. For the nominating contests, she had $8.9 million, not $10 million. For the general election, she has $20.3 million set aside, not $19 million.
An article last Saturday about competition at the Berlin Film Festival misstated the day awards were to be handed out. The ceremony took place last Saturday, not Sunday.

An obituary on Thursday about the choral conductor Richard Westenburg misidentified the resident choir at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church while he was music director there. It was the church’s own choir of paid professionals and church members — not the Musica Sacra Chorus, though Musica Sacra sometimes performed at the church. The obituary also misstated Mr. Westenburg’s title at the Collegiate Chorale from 1973 to 1980. He was music director, not conductor.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on Sunday, misidentified the American Express executive who discussed his company’s sponsorship of the broadcast. He is Diego Scotti, not Aldo Papone.

An article in some editions on Jan. 16 about Katherine Gamble, a woman who got help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to declutter her Manhattan apartment after depression and ill health made it difficult for her to throw things out, misstated her age. She is 60, not 50. A social services agency that worked with Ms. Gamble pointed out the error recently; this correction was delayed for research.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births referred incorrectly at one point to the procedure by which embryos enter the womb in in vitro fertilization. They are transferred, not implanted.

An article on Friday about the building of a Transcendental Meditation palace in Parma, Ohio, referred imprecisely in some editions to the percentage of the population practicing TM that Maharishi Mahesh Yogi believed would be necessary to achieve increased coherence in the collective unconscious. It is the square root of one percent of the population (for example, about 1,700 people in the United States) — not merely “the square root of one percent,” which is 10 percent.

An art review in Weekend on Friday about the Art Show fair, at the Park Avenue Armory, contained an outdated reference to the Armory Show, an annual fair that opens on March 27 this year. It is held solely at Pier 94 — not at two piers, as was the case from 2001 to 2006.

An article on Friday about the building of a Transcendental Meditation palace in Parma, Ohio, referred imprecisely in some editions to the percentage of the population practicing TM that Maharishi Mahesh Yogi believed would be necessary to achieve increased coherence in the collective unconscious. It is the square root of one percent of the population (for example, about 1,700 people in the United States) — not merely “the square root of one percent,” which is 10 percent.

A chart on Friday comparing fund-raising and spending for presidential candidates misstated the amount of money raised by two of them between Jan. 1, 2007, and Jan. 31, 2008. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised $133 million in contributions, loans and transfers, not $118 million. Senator John McCain raised $52 million, not $48 million.

An article on Wednesday about August Wilson’s 20th Century, a series of staged readings of the playwright’s 10-play cycle, at the Kennedy Center, misstated the history of the plays. “Jitney” was written first, not “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.”.

Qualifying for Sunday’s Nascar Sprint Cup race at Auto Club Speedway in Fontana, Calif., was rained out Friday, with the 43-car field determined by the rulebook. Car-owner points from the past season will determine the lineup, so the two-time reigning Cup champion Jimmie Johnson and his Hendrick Motorsports teammate Jeff Gordon, who finished second in 2007, will start from the front in the Auto Club 500.
A report could provide the first public accounting for legal advice endorsing methods widely denounced as torture.
Tom Coughlin, who until recently was criticized for his inability to mold Eli Manning into a consistent quarterback, never mind a championship one, has been redefined.
Oliver Pérez will make $6.5 million, a hefty raise from last year’s $2.325 million. The Mets’ offer for this season has been $4.725 million.
Congress must insist that Washington be allowed to spend its own money on needle exchange programs, which have proved highly successful around the world.
The next president will have to show more leadership if there is any hope of reversing the damage from decades of underfunding America’s crumbling infrastructure.
Talk among banking executives for an epic government rescue plan is suddenly coming into fashion.

Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, was indicted on 35 counts of corruption, including fraud, money laundering, extortion and other crimes.

Levi Leipheimer, who won last year’s Tour De France final time trial, won the fifth stage of the Tour of California by 29 seconds over David Millar, the British time-trial champion.

A center devoted to the life, works, papers and policies of President Bush will be built at Southern Methodist University, despite lingering concerns and opposition from some Methodists.
Officials from the Indy Racing League reached an agreement with leaders of the opposing Champ Car World Series to unify the two into one open-wheel racing series.

Officials with the U.N. nuclear watchdog said Iran had refused to deal with the evidence that served as the basis for American charges that Iran had tried to design a weapon.
The Los Angeles Sparks signed the three-time W.N.B.A. All-Star guard Marie Ferdinand-Harris. In six seasons, she averaged 11.5 points, 3.2 rebounds and 2.1 assists.

Nick Price overcame a stiff wind to shoot one of the best rounds of the day at the Mayakoba Golf Classic, a two-under-par 68 that moved him to two-under 138 for the tournament, putting him in a tie for eighth and allowing him to advance to the weekend in his first PGA Tour start since 2006. Greg Norman, who designed the El Cameleon course in Riviera Maya, Mexico, missed the cut with a 79. Norman could not recover from an early five-hole stretch of three bogeys and a double bogey. He finished at nine over, missing the cut by five strokes. The first-round leader, John Merrick, shot a 68 to remain on top at six-under 132. Brian Gay was a stroke back after a 67.

West Virginia University wants a judge to dismiss counterclaims that Rich Rodriguez raised to its lawsuit over his $4 million buyout, arguing he cannot benefit from a contract while refusing to comply with parts of it. Rodriguez claims he signed his contract under false pretenses, expecting verbal promises by the university to be kept. The university argues that Rodriguez knew what he was doing and had help from lawyers, financial advisers and agents.
Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein seemed unconvinced that a constitutional violation had occurred and noted that city officials had already sifted the debris at Fresh Kills.
In a plea bargain that legal experts called extremely unusual, a man who admitted to shooting a police officer in 1969 will serve just 30 days in jail.
Courtney Paris, possibly the greatest player in the history of women’s collegiate basketball, is on the same team as her twin sister Ashley, Courtney’s de facto personal assistant.

Dalilah Muhammad led Cardozo High School of Queens to the girls’ team title with 78 points in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Muhammad won the high jump, finished second in the 55-meter hurdles and was third leg on Cardozo’s 4x800 winning relay (9:27.11). Midwood of Brooklyn captured the boys’ team crown with 51 points. Donald Williams paced Midwood with a victory in the 55-meter dash and ran second on Midwood’s winning 4x400 relay (3:28.60). Nadonna Rodrigues of Brooklyn’s Boys & Girls, who recently posted the fastest 400-meter time in the country at 52.83 seconds, took the 300 in 38.39 seconds and anchored her school’s winning 4x400 foursome (3:56.83).
Tape recorder in hand, promoter and would-be gossip columnist Baird Jones was a longtime fixture on the party scene.

A New York real estate developer, agreed to buy half of the Miami Dolphins from Wayne Huizenga for $550 million, with an opportunity to become managing general partner.
The powerful 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East, usually aligned with Republicans in Albany, has been shifting its support.
The rocker Bob Geldof, who has made ending poverty in Africa a personal cause, is convinced that President Bush has undergone some sort of epiphany about Africa.

Even Hunter Douglas, the leader in the custom window coverings industry, is not immune from the housing slowdown and the current economy.
Kelvin Sampson accepted a $750,000 buyout of his contract and resigned as the coach at Indiana after being accused of committing recruiting violations.

Two former executives of Marsh Inc., the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.
The softening economy, shortfalls in government financing, political inertia and logistical problems have contributed to the near collapse of the project.
On Friday, a court handed sentenced Volkswagen’s former top labor leader to nearly three years in prison.
Bush administration officials said Friday they would begin creating a virtual fence along the Mexican border, and that construction had been completed on 302 miles of physical fence.
Three former British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months each in prison for their role in a fraud related to Enron.
The Vanguard Group surprised the industry on Friday when it announced that its chief executive, John J. Brennan, would step down.
The findings mean only that the defendant, David Tarloff, understands the charges against him and can assist in his own defense.
A high official at Yongbyong said the disabling of the nuclear reactor had slowed down, because other countries were not meeting their commitments in the disarmament-for-aid deal.
Wall Street staged a turnaround late Friday after word that a bailout plan for the troubled bond insurer Ambac Financial Group could be announced next week.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ebbing campaign fortunes are causing one New York City vendor concern about when, exactly, he will see payment for all that coffee, tea and orange juice.
Citigroup, the investment bank, said on Friday that it had provided a $500 million line of credit to its Falcon multistrategy fixed-income hedge funds.
In his 60 years in racing, Mr. Watters proved a versatile figure. He rode steeplechase horses, then trained champions in steeplechase and flat racing.
The victim had just withdrawn the large sum from the bank when he was attacked.
After signing with the Mets, one of the Braves’ main rivals in the National League East, Tom Glavine found his way back to Atlanta in the twilight of his career.
The American International Group is pulling out the stops to try to prevent its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, from seeing confidential internal documents.
The Philharmonic made its debut in Shanghai, and it was far more than a simple in-and-out pair of concerts.
Basra’s experiment in self-rule is occurring under relatively optimal conditions, yet the city remains deeply troubled.
Everyone stands to gain from a full and public disclosure of the privately owned cultural properties in Russia’s hidden repositories.
Under pressure over the crisis in Darfur, China has begun to do something it swears it never does — meddle in the internal affairs of one of its trading partners.
Yale must finally return the artifacts that symbolize Peru’s great heritage.
The Academy Awards are New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day rolled into one, a day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew.
Carmelita Jeter hopes to win at the national indoor championships on Saturday and Sunday at the Reggie Lewis Track and Athletic Center.
Dancers scattered throughout St. Mark’s Church read books in a murmured cacophony in Juliette Mapp’s new “Anna, Ikea and I” on Thursday night.
How the Oscar telecast holds up on Sunday will go a long way toward determining whether the 80-year-old Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences can transform itself.
An 18-year-old woman was arrested in Texas in connection with threatening e-mail messages sent to a student at Saint Peter’s College in Jersey City.
Verbally meticulous, restrained and constitutionally glum, the songwriter Stephin Merritt is no one’s idea of a rocker — apparently not even his own.
Mr. Mecham was a firebrand conservative who served 15 months as governor of Arizona before an impeachment trial removed him from office in 1988.
Lindsey Vonn clinched the World Cup downhill title on Friday, becoming the first American woman to claim the crown since Picabo Street in 1996.
Audiences who came of age in the Iron Curtain era still find it astonishing to contemplate a career like Diana Vishneva’s.
The F.D.A.’s decision appeared to lower the bar slightly for approval of certain cancer drugs.
Golf is one of the few sports in which a weekend amateur player can make a shot as good as that of any given pro, especially on or around the greens.
Germany has become the promotional hub for boxers from the former Soviet Union, turning the traditional wellspring of skilled amateur boxers into a source of professional powerhouses as well.

The mortgage crisis has put “for sale” signs in front of houses across the country — including so-called McMansions — the large, expensive, often tasteless homes that have taken up so much suburban space over the last couple of decades.
The Oneida Indian Nation has been offered a plan to place more than 13,000 acres into a federal trust, re-establishing a sovereign homeland.
The British government warned on Friday that it would impose legislation on Internet service providers by April 2009 if they did not work to curb illegal downloading.
The Mount, Edith Wharton’s estate in Lenox, Mass., is in danger of being put in foreclosure.
The Graduate Center of the City University of New York is setting up a center where biographers can meet, trade ideas and work.

Will Smith has received an apology and damages from a news agency after it falsely accused him of saying Hitler was “a good person,” the BBC reported. World Entertainment News Network published the article “Smith: Hitler Was A Good Person” in December, after which Mr. Smith sued for libel in a London court. “The defendant accepts that the allegations concerning the claimant were misleading and published in error,” the agency’s solicitor said.

The results edition of “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to that network’s other singing competition, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, 23.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for “American Idol,” the night’s top-rated show. At 9, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” drew 12.5 million viewers, more than 5 million above its average this season. Among adults 18 to 49, this karaoke-themed game show ranked third for the night, trailing only “American Idol” and ABC’s “Lost,” which led at 9 with 13.5 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night in the 18-to-49 set but third in total viewers behind both Fox and CBS, whose reruns of “CSI” at 9 (11.9 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (12.1 million) buoyed the network after a solid showing for “Big Brother” at 8 (12.5 million). NBC was a distant fourth over all, as both “The Celebrity Apprentice” at 9 (8 million) and “Lipstick Jungle” at 10 (5.8 million) struggled in their respective time slots.

The 92nd Street Y named Deborah Grace Winer, a playwright and author of several books on American song, the artistic director of Lyrics & Lyricists, the Y’s long-running American Songbook series. She replaces Kristin Lancino, who will leave at the end of the 2008 season. ... Jennifer Lopez, who is married to Marc Anthony, gave birth to twins, a boy and a girl, on Friday morning, The Associated Press reported. The girl arrived first. ... Stacy Keach will star as Richard M. Nixon in the national tour of “Frost/Nixon,” Playbill reported. The role was created on Broadway by Frank Langella, who won a Tony Award for it. The tour is scheduled to start on Sept. 26 in Owensboro, Ky.

A county judge in Nashville is to issue a ruling within 30 days on whether Fisk University can keep a 101-piece art collection that includes “Radiator Building — Night, New York” (1927), below, given to it by the artist Georgia O’Keeffe, The Associated Press reported. In a three-day trial that ended on Thursday, lawyers for the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., argued that Fisk lost the right to the prized collection and violated the terms of the 1949 gift when it took the works off display and tried to sell some. Fisk countered that it had never tried to sell the whole collection and that it now had the money to display the works according to the artist’s wishes. Seeking to shore up its finances, Fisk agreed in principle last fall to sell a 50 percent stake in the collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., for $30 million. But on Feb. 8 Ellen Hobbs Lyle, a Davidson County Chancery Court judge, struck down that proposal, saying it went against the donor’s wishes. Now the judge will rule on whether Fisk has forfeited its right to the art and whether it should go to the O’Keeffe Museum, which represents the artist’s estate.

Odeon, Britain’s largest chain of moviehouses, will not show “Rambo” at its theaters this weekend, citing “commercial reasons,” Variety reported. This is the film’s opening weekend in Britain. The news has enraged fans of Sylvester Stallone, right, especially those who live in rural areas where their only local cinema is an Odeon. The company said “the decision not to screen ‘Rambo’ will free up screens to show alternative popular new films such as ‘Jumper,’ ‘Be Kind Rewind’ and ‘Juno,’ ” but there was speculation among British movie exhibitors that the cause of the abrupt move was a disagreement over terms between Odeon and Sony, the film’s distributor. “I can’t remember the last time this happened in the multiplex era,” one film booker said. Sony Pictures Releasing U.K. declined to comment.
Ambac Financial Group plans to split itself in two and raise $3 billion, a person who has seen the plan said on Friday. The move could help restore confidence in the credit markets.
In his recital at the Rose Theater on Wednesday, the pianist Christian Zacharias argued that virtuosity comes most notably as an expression of patient introspection.

Steinberg, devoted mother of Shari, Jill and Peter, adored grandmother of Nathaniel, Michael and Jeremy, mother-in-law of Alan Harley and Serge Cohen, cherished sister of Sue Delson and sister-in-law Michele Ammirata. Ralph Nader is scheduled to appear on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' on Sunday, prompting speculation that he is planning another third-party run for the White House. Mr. Nader announced the appearance in an e-mail message on Friday to supporters of his exploratory committee, formed in January, encouraging them to watch and donate money to his effort.

IN a gift to marketers -- and trivia buffs -- everywhere, The American magazine has put together a fascinating look at ''the diurnal and nocturnal habits'' of the average resident of the United States. Here are snapshots from the report compiled by Karlyn Bowman, using results from a survey conducted by the Gallup Organization in August.

Here's further grist for the mill for anyone deconstructing how Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton lost so many states to Senator Barack Obama. The story is starting to sound the same everywhere: Mrs. Clinton had a slow start and was outspent, if not out-organized. These are the details from Wisconsin, as culled by Ken Goldstein, director of the Wisconsin Advertising Project, which analyzes political advertising across the country.

When Lily Santiago woke up on Friday to six inches of thick, wet snow, there was little doubt about what she would do. She and her twin brother, Trey, 11, made a beeline with their father, Ruben, for Cedar Hill in Central Park, near East 79th Street. There they joined dozens of other snow-starved children and parents armed with plastic sleds of various colors, including a few that were inflatable and looked like boats.

BRENNAN--Robert J., age 71, beloved husband of 49 years to Helen Brennan, son of the late James and Madelyn Brennan, passed away peacefully on Thursday, February 21, 2008. Bob was a 1954 graduate of Bishop Dubois High School, NYC, where he was an all-city basketball player, and a 1958 graduate of Manhattan College, Bronx, NY. He enjoyed a great career; most recently retiring in 2004 as President and CEO of The American Institute For Foreign Study, as well as a thirty year career in public accounting with Ernst & Young; retiring as a Partner in 1988. Most recently, Bob had also been serving as Chairman of The Board of Trustees of Richmond, The American University in London and also Chairman of the Board of Metro International. He was also an active volunteer in the business and education community having served on the boards of NAFSA -The Association of International Educators, The Advisory Council for The Schools of Arts, Sciences and Education as well as the School of Business at Manhattan College. Bob also served on The Business Council of Fairfield County and was a past President of The Connecticut Society of Certified Public Accountants. He was honored for his devotion to education as a recipient of an Honorary Doctorate of Business Administration-Richmond, the American International University in London in 1995 and a Fulbright Award for Contributions to International Education in 2003. Bob had an immense love for travel with his wife Helen and his family, reading, all sports, singing, music, clowns, candles, flowers, children, and God. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his two sons; Bob and his wife, Andrea, and Kevin and his wife, Anne, his four grandchildren; Kevin and his wife Cassandra, Corinne, Bobby and Andrew, his brother; Jim and sister-in-law, Barbara and his sister-in-law; Mary Ellen. He is also survived by his sisters-in-law; Joan and Mary, his brotherin-law; John, many nieces, nephews, good friends and colleagues. Bob was predeceased by his brother John in 2004. A Mass of Christian Burial to celebrate Bob's life will be held on Monday, February 25, 2008 at 10:30am meeting directly at St. Pius X Church, 834 Brookside Dr., Fairfield, with interment to follow in Oak Lawn Cemetery, Fairfield. Friends and family may call on Sunday, February 24, 2008 from 3-7pm., in the Spear-Miller Funeral Home, 39 South Benson Rd., Fairfield. The family prefers in lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Brennan be made to Metro International, 285 West Broadway, Suite 450, New York, NY 10013. To offer an online condolence, visit: spearmillerfuneralhome .com

Tangel and Mathew R. Warren. It was, by comparison, a modest snowstorm -- with less than a quarter of the snowfall than the one that coated New York City with 28 inches two years ago. 8 P.M. (HBO) JOE LOUIS: AMERICA'S HERO ... BETRAYED Joe Louis, below, who held the heavyweight boxing championship title for 11 years, was the first black sports star heralded by both black and white fans and became a national hero when he defeated the German Max Schmeling in 1938. For more than half his life, though, he was pursued by the Internal Revenue Service for unpaid taxes, which led to his staying in the ring far past his prime. This documentary chronicles his impact on segregated America through interviews with his son, Joe Louis Barrow Jr.; former President Jimmy Carter; Maya Angelou; Jerry Louis; Dick Gregory; and Representative Charles Rangel, Democrat of New York, among others. At 9:30 HBO will broadcast a heavyweight title fight between Wladimir Klitschko and Sultan Ibragimov from Madison Square Garden. 5 P.M. ADLER--Max, 21, of Brooklyn, NY, died Wednesday, February 20. Max was born on June 7, 1986 in Manhattan. He graduated from Saint Ann's School. Max was a student at Eugene Lang College at the New School University where he was an active member of the school's debate team. Max was the greatly beloved and wonderfully loving son of Jerry Adler and Beth Lebowitz. Max was a voracious reader and an amateur poet and playwright who possessed a sharp wit and a talent for argument. He was also blessed with a sweet temperament and a courage uncommon in anyone so young. He is already desperately missed by his parents, his brother Ben, his relatives and friends. Services will be held Sunday at noon at Congregation Beth Elohim, at 8th Avenue and Garfield Place in Brooklyn. Max's family requests that donations be made in Max's honor to any of these organizations: The National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 317 East 34 St., NY, NY 10006; Kids of NYU Foundation Inc., 902 Broadway, Suite 1603, NY, NY 10010; Saint Ann's School, 129 Pierrepont St, Brooklyn, NY 11201; Rivendell School, 277 3rd Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11215.

It takes a pretty big snowfall to hinder your basic commuter train, but a mere layer of ice on the electrified third rail can block the current and tie up a whole branch, delaying thousands of commuters. So when winter storms hit, the Long Island Rail Road activates its fleet of three de-icing trains before the peak morning and evening rush travel periods.

HUNTER--Renate Alsberg, 91, died February 20 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in NYC while courageously undergoing a heart valve repair. Renate was remarkably fit, feisty and free-spirited to the very last day, and was dearly loved by her family and friends. She was fortunate to have had a full, fascinating life: born in Berlin and educated in Switzerland, Renate successfully escaped Nazi Germany and continued her studies in London and later New York, graduating from NYU School of Law to become an attorney and then the cherished wife of Allan B. Hunter. Renate was a deeply devoted mother to Andre Hunter, a loving and supportive mother-in-law to Kelly Hunter, and the much adored grandmother of Max, Cameron and Casey -all of whom will miss her terribly. A celebration of Renate's life is planned for this spring.

The Bagger showed up on time this year -- he got clobbered last year for trying to slip in late and caused a red alert. This year, he was far more obedient and the staff was enormously helpful. But what could have been a gracious ingress and egress was marred earlier when he busted a move down the carpet to leave a little early. Two guys came up on either side and walked him to a gate. They told him he could go in through the adjacent hotel. The Bagger knew better. He was ejected. The guys with the headpieces can smell fear, and the Bagger knew what was coming. He has finally hacked his way back in.

"'Who in the world am I?' Ah, that's the great puzzle!" says Lewis Carroll's Alice after experiencing a sudden, disorienting growth spurt. While she meditates on this philosophical conundrum, her body changes again. The girl shrinks. I have asked myself the same question many times, often in relation to the perceptual alterations, peculiar feelings, and exquisite sensitivities of the migraine state. Who in the world am I? Am "I" merely malfunctioning brain meat? In "The Astonishing Hypothesis" Francis Crick (famous for his discovery of the DNA double helix with James Watson) wrote, "You, your joys and your sorrows, your memories and ambitions, your sense of personal identity and free will, are, in fact, no more than the behavior of a vast assembly of nerve cells and their associated molecules." Mind is matter, Crick argued. All of human life can be reduced to neurons.

The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend. Even though the strike lifted and the whole show is back on, Jon Stewart and the producers continue to insist on showing filmed segments that would have been broadcast, as if to menace the crowd with what might have been. Maybe it would have been worse, but for the time being, there seems to be an odd juxtaposition of hackery -- a filmed riff on telescopes and binoculars -- sentiment -- Jon Stewart going so sweet on the kids from "August Rush" -- and vamping -- pregger jokes about Cate Blanchett and Jessica Alba.

The press room generally likes a surprise as much as the next person -- "Golden Compass for effects!????" -- because it makes for a story that has a few twists and turns. But the newsies like a front-runner because it makes them feel smug and knowing. Which is why they yelled like 8-year-olds when the Javier Bardem won for best supporting male.

Miley Cyrus (a k a Hannah Montana), one of the evening's presenters, was told by her publicist that it was time to quit an interview and step up to be interviewed by Robert Osborne, the red carpet host of the Oscars.

Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in "Charlie Wilson's War" -- and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won, btw.) Hoffman is known as somebody with very little taste for the pomp and silliness of the awards campaign.

Ellen Page, the tiniest presence on the circuit, at least in terms of body mass, was standing in front of the Bagger when Michael Moore, one of the largest, came by. They squeezed by each other, a waif walking around a mountain, award circuit familiars.

Marion Cotillard has been on the circuit for a month, going hither and yon in Los Angeles in support of "La Vie en Rose" and her nomination for best actress. Her English has improved rapidly -- "Why thank you!" --as has her understanding of the business. "I had no idea that a little French movie would go this far, but this is what you do once it does."

As John McCain comes ever closer to securing the Republican nomination, his age has remained notably absent as a campaign issue. So far it has attracted so little attention that the network exit pollsters have not included even one question on the subject in 23 state surveys - an extraordinary occurrence given that Senator McCain would be the oldest man ever to take office, if he were to win the presidency.

Sergey Karjakin of the Ukraine is ranked No. 14 in the world and has been ranked in the top 30 for a year. Last December, he made it to the semifinals of the World Cup before narrowly losing to Alexei Shirov Spain. Because of that performance, he is seeded into the Grand Prix, the series of tournaments that will help select a challenger for the world championship. He holds the record as the youngest grandmaster in history (12 years 7 months). And he turned 18 a little more than a month ago.

In one of those ironies that make life interesting, the University of Colorado, which dismissed controversial professor Ward Churchill because of doubts about his academic qualifications, has appointed a president who doesn't have any. (The final vote was taken on Feb. 20.)

I had plans--plans I tell you!--to be up early and roaming the town but my pillow snatched me back and it was past noon before I set off to the Place de la Concorde, already crowded with people. It was a stunning day, cloudless and mild. The first show for most of the editors and buyers was Balmain (the tightest, smallest pants and club tops in leather and metal mesh, nothing surprising) and a number of the guests had brought their young children. In the course of the day I heard a lot of things. Will Robert Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano of 6267 take over Ferre? Is Hedi Slimane in negotiations for his own men's and women's label? Time will tell. I thought Slimane's pictures (in New York Magazine) of Carine Roitfeld were terrific, and evocative of her. And take a look at the spreads with Lara Stone in the current Paris Vogue, particularly Neo Classiques, by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott.

Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of Vogue Paris, bequeathed her children her soigné style as if it were their birthright. Her daughter, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, is a freelance art director for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier and was the face of Tom Ford's latest fragrance; her son, Vladimir Restoin-Roitfeld, is a film school graduate and a sometime model. Going to a fashion shoot when they were young, says Mom, was as normal as tarte Tatin. (The photographer Mario Testino is their godfather.) Many consider Roitfeld the stilettoed embodiment of modern dressing: she describes her style as ''tacky chic.'' Never afraid to take a risk, she has put a bearded drag queen on a cover and printed a fashion story with a model dressed as an Anna Wintour clone. After 20-plus years in the business, certain things have changed: ''I don't go too much to the parties now, but my kids do.'' Like their mom, they're always on the list.

The Bagger's more carefully considered doppelganger has a point-counter point about the cultural value of the Oscars in the newspaper today with A. O. Scott, a real, actual movie critic. The package includes an audio file of the throw-down, but the overlords at the House of Many Doors edited out the part where Scott called the Bagger an "ignorant slut," but it is still a lively and blessedly brief - the Bagger's voice has been compared to the sound cows emit when they get a batch of bad feed - podcast about the worthiness of the national bonfire of glitter and gamesmanship.

Every year, the Oscars pay a visit to that mid-Atlantic place where British and American culture mash up into something that combines Yankee rigor with English refinement. This year, that phenomenon shows up in the form of "Atonement," with a young British director, Joe Wright, and ingénue Keira Knightley defining Anglophilian upper crust lust. And in the acting categories, you've also got your Tilda Swintons - who could win this year, btw - and Julie Christies, who is favored to win. Cate Blanchett is nominated, twice in fact, a sorta Brit from Australia.

Dan, the Bagger's digital peer, has been crunching some data: For the third straight year, our readers have weighed in on the race. The first year ... well, we let people vote more than once, so the results were just a tad skewed. But this year, the numbers look right, and in more ways than one. NYTimes.comers' votes align nicely with the general zeitgeist (though not necessarily with the Bagger's picks), though there are a few surprises. "No Country" gets picture, director, supporting actor and screenplay. But Daniel Day-Lewis is neck and neck with Johnny Depp for Best Actor. Cate Blanchett would win both actress awards if the readers were in charge.

When he learned I wanted to write a play, Jon Jory, who was then Artistic Director of Actors Theatre of Louisville, took me out to lunch and said, "OK, here are the three mistakes you don't have to make." And that's pretty much the way I teach to this day - telling writers the traps they don't have to fall into, not saying how it has to be done, just trying to save them some of their precious time. Over the years people have yelled at me for teaching the rules, or even for suggesting that there are rules. But I never expect these rules to be followed absolutely. They serve the same purpose as the boundary flags in ski resorts. You can ski in the ungroomed powder if you want, but you'd better know what you're doing, and be willing to take the risk. Still, we do not turn on the television to watch average skiers take safe trips down the green trails. We turn on the X Games to see heli-skiers land on the top of glaciers and shoot off the edges of the cliffs, or watch the great Shaun White "shred some gnarly terrain", as my son says. And that brings us to "August: Osage County," a play that only seems traditional, but actually creates its excitement by breaking the rules.

This year's Oscars would have seemed to be a great time to innovate, to put together a show on the fly that perhaps attacks some of the creakiness and convention that is part of Oscar gospel. Ain't. Gonna. Happen. In spite of the fact that organizers had little more than a week to put together the show, this will be no ad-hoc Oscars. Look for the same glorious goo to be poured into the extant template. People who have seen the auditions say that there is a palpable desire for normalcy, for business as usual, but that means the same brutal copy will show up on the teleprompter and be beamed straight at you.

Yesteday, Tom O'Neil took a seat on the high wire, suggesting that George Clooney could sneak past Daniel Day-Lewis in the best actor category. He got some company yesterday. The Bagger bumped into Tom Bernard, the co-chief honcho at Sony Pictures Classics, at the Spirit Awards. Bernard has a pretty good record in Oscar matters and has good sources among old members of the Academy, although he was wearing sunglasses that play MP3's, so there is that. (Dog the Bounty Hunter, who is staying at the Bagger's hotel, has a similar pair.) And Bernard said that Day-Lewis may not be the lock we have all said he was. "You're probably right about Daniel Day-Lewis, but I wouldn't be surprised to see Clooney sneak in."

Last night's Miramax party had all the trappings of a major Oscar bacchanal. Tight door, movie stars, even an appearance by the elusive Cormac McCarthy (the author of "No Country for Old Men"). The Soho club here offered a great space and amazing views and even a smoking cage, a place where the muse often hunts the Bagger down, but no one wants to put both pom poms in the air - not the night before, and maybe not the night after. Strike, rain, macro-business problems, the death of Heath Ledger, blame it on whatever you want, but no one is doing the backstroke in Oscar froth this year.

Alabama safety Rashad Johnson was charged with disorderly conduct for knocking a security guard down at an off-campus bar, the Tuscaloosa police said. The 22-year-old Johnson, a first-team all-Southeastern Conference pick, was arrested after a brief struggle, the police said.

Hannes Reichelt of Austria won the men’s World Cup giant slalom in Whistler, British Columbia, ahead of Didier Cuche of Switzerland and Benjamin Raich of Austria. Bode Miller, who finished seventh, retained his lead in the overall World Cup standings.

Radek Stepanek used deep ground strokes and crafty drop shots to beat Robby Ginepri, 6-7 (5), 6-4, 6-1, and move to the finals of the SAP Open in San Jose, Calif. Stepanek will play the top-seeded Andy Roddick, a 7-6 (2), 6-1 winner over Guillermo García-López.

Kyle Busch added a win Saturday in the Nascar Craftsman Truck Series race at Auto Club Speedway in Fontana, Calif., to his runner-up finish in the truck race last week at Daytona. Busch was dominant in the 100-lap truck race in Fontana, leading for 51 laps.
The players who were kept from playing in a blowout loss on Saturday had violated an unspecified team policy, according to the Red Storm’s coach.
Josh Young hit three free throws with 20 seconds remaining, to help Drake end a nine-game winning streak for Butler.
With their loss to Utah Valley State, the Highlanders finished their season with the worst record ever for an N.C.A.A. Division I team.
The largest crowd to ever watch a women’s game at the Lloyd Noble Center saw Courtney Paris, the Sooners’ center, surpass 2,000 career points while leading her team to victory.
The Ottawa Senators rallied from three goals behind Saturday to beat the Penguins, 4-3, in Pittsburgh.
The Devils fired 20 shots in the final period of Saturday’s game, scoring twice and undoing Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro’s mastery over them.
The dispute over Kosovo is resonating in immigrant communities in the city.
Larry Davis, the notorious Bronx killer who was stabbed to death in prison last week, had a running conversation with the host of a radio show called “Radio Unnameable” for nearly 20 years.
General Manager Jerry Reese’s Giants team is molded in his scrappy image with a roster that is young and filled mostly with players who were drafted, not assembled through free agency.

Anja Hüber of Germany edged Katie Uhlaender of the United States to win the world skeleton title in Altenberg, Germany. Hüber, the European champion, finished her four runs in a combined 4:02.78. Uhlaender, the World Cup overall champion, was 0.30 back.

The unseeded Argentine José Acasuso advanced to his second Copa Telmex final with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over eighth-seeded Filippo Volandri of Italy in Buenos Aires. He will face top-seeded David Nalbandian, who defeated fourth-seeded Juan Ignacio Chela, 6-1, 6-2, in an all-Argentine semifinal.

The Toronto Maple Leafs signed forward Alex Steen to a two-year, $3.4 million contract extension. Steen, who turns 24 next week, had 10 goals and 16 assists entering Saturday night’s game against Atlanta. He was Toronto’s first choice, 24th over all, in the 2002 entry draft. He will earn $1.7 million in each of the 2008-9 and 2009-10 seasons after coming out of his entry-level contract.

Russia’s Olga Kaniskina set the world record in the women’s 20-kilometer walk with a time of 1:25:11 at the national championships in the southern Russian city of Adler. Kaniskina, 23, who won the 20-kilometer gold at last year’s world championships in Japan, bettered the time of 1:25:41 set by her compatriot Olimpiada Ivanova on Aug. 7, 2005, at the world championships in Helsinki, Finland.

Maria Sharapova beat Agnieszka Radwanska, 6-4, 6-3, to extend her unbeaten run to 13 matches and set up an all-Russian final at the Qatar Open. Sharapova, who lost to Radwanska at the United States Open, will face Vera Zvonareva in Sunday’s final.

The seven-time Formula One world champion Michael Schumacher will be back behind the wheel of a Ferrari when he steps in as a test driver for his former team. Schumacher, 39, will drive Monday in Barcelona, Spain. His time behind the wheel will allow the Ferrari driver Felipe Massa to rest before the season starts March 16 in Melbourne, Australia.

The Chicago Bears signed quarterback Rex Grossman on Saturday to a one-year contract and prevented him from entering the free-agent market. Grossman, a 2003 first-round draft pick, started Super Bowl XLI for the Bears. After being benched following the third game last season, he returned for five more games and showed enough improvement to keep the Bears interested.

Islanders center Mike Sillinger will have season-ending hip surgery within the next week. Sillinger, 36, has not played since Feb. 5, and is in the second season of a three-year deal that pays him $2.2 million this season and $2.3 million for 2008-9. He has 14 goals and 12 assists this season. Sillinger, who has played 134 games with the Islanders, has 238 goals and 546 points in 1,042 games over 17 N.H.L. seasons.
After admitting he lacked the legislative support to raise tolls sharply, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is poised to unveil a budget with at least $2.5 billion in spending cuts.
South Korea has devoted several years and millions of dollars to make a cabbage dish suitable to go into space with its first astronaut in April.

The investigation into charges of campaign finance violations relating to Gov. Aníbal S. Acevedo Vilá has captured the imagination of Puerto Rico’s political class and news media.
Khadevis Robinson, who was entered in an 800 heat Saturday in preparation for Sunday’s final, is the United States’ most productive 800-meter runner since Johnny Gray in the 1980s and 1990s.

The crash in Guam was the first for a B-2. Both pilots ejected safely and there were no injuries on the ground or damage to buildings.

An article last Sunday on the role of charisma in politics referred incorrectly to Republicans who were important to President Johnson’s push for the Civil Rights Act. They were Senate Republicans, not Southern Republicans. The article also referred imprecisely to Johnson’s well-known “We shall overcome” speech before Congress. He made it in 1965 as part of his push to get the Voting Rights Act passed; he did not give the speech before the Civil Rights Act, which had passed the previous year.

The French writer Alain Robbe-Grillet died last week. These days, the name doesn’t ring many bells — but he had a profound impact on international taste.
Petty Enterprises has moved from Level Cross, N.C., to just north of Charlotte in Mooresville, a town that bills itself as Race City USA and is a hub for the Nascar racing community.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about gentrification in Harlem referred imprecisely to an increase in apartment prices there. While prices for some apartments have indeed doubled in the past year, the prices of other apartments did not increase that much. (As the article noted, the average sale price in Harlem in the last quarter of 2007 was 93 percent higher than in the last quarter of 2006.).
